headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                                               Previous      Year                               Yesterday       Day       Ago

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;South Korea's Trade Deficit Surges
abstract: South Korea's trade deficit surged 57 percent in 1995 from the previous year, to a record $9.9 billion, as the won's strength cut into exports, the Trade, Industry and Energy Ministry said yesterday. The ministry said exports last year rose 30.4 percent from 1994, to $125.23 billion, while imports rose 32 percent,  to $135.11 billion. The 1994 trade gap was $6.3 billion.          The won has strengthened about 4 percent against the dollar in the last year, making Korean products more expensive in overseas markets. The trade ministry said the deficit could shrink to about $7 billion this year.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;New German Partner Joins British Telecom
abstract: British Telecommunications P.L.C. lined up a new partner yesterday for its German venture and disclosed plans for increased investment. The new partner is  the German utility RWE A.G. It will join the alliance that British Telecom formed last year with Viag A.G. to position the British company for the German residential market when it is opened to competition in 1998.         British Telecom's managing director of global communications, Alfred Mockett, said the enlarged alliance had plans to commit up to four billion marks of investment. Mr. Mockett estimated that about one- quarter of the German telecommunications market, Europe's largest, would be wrested away from Deutsche Telekom by 2000.    (Reuters)

headline: OUTLOOK '96: MARKETS AND INVESTING;Experts Are Upbeat. Can Markets Thrive Anyway?
abstract: With its vertiginous rise in stock prices and a bond rally that in some respects was even more impressive, 1995 is going to be a tough year to top for financial markets.         Nevertheless, seven people who advise clients on how to shape their investment portfolios still expect good things to happen this year.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt Federal Home Loan Bank is selling $25 million of step-up notes due in 2006 through First Tennessee Bank. The notes are callable in one year, carry an interest rate of 7.3 percent and are priced at par.

headline: Wireless Bidder Drops His Push
abstract: John Dolan, who bid more than $900 million in the Federal Government's auction for new wireless communications licenses, dropped out of the competition yesterday, saying the bidding had gone too high.         Mr. Dolan, the nephew of Charles F. Dolan, the cable television billionaire,  said he had been outbid by Nextwave Communications for a license to serve the New York area. Nextwave bid $994 million. .np

headline: Sculley Buys Stake in Software Company
abstract: John Sculley, the former chief executive of Apple Computer Inc., has taken an equity stake in a small California photo software concern, where he is also serving as a part-time chief executive.         Mr. Sculley said on Wednesday that he had joined the privately held Live Picture Inc. of Soquel, Calif., in early 1995 and had bought a piece of the company, although he would not detail his holdings. He said he continued to have a venture capital business in New York.

headline: Did Yeltsin Get a Sweetheart Deal on I.M.F. Loans?
abstract: Poor countries usually do a bit of groveling and a lot of kicking and screaming when they negotiate with the International Monetary Fund, needing the  loans the organization provides but resenting the demands for austerity that accompany its help.         The pattern seemed different, though, as the fund negotiated and then reached agreement on a three-year, $10.2 billion loan package with Russia last month, raising questions about whether Moscow was getting special treatment.

headline: Sales of New Homes Jumped in January
abstract: Despite some havoc from the blizzard, new-home sales shot up 4.2 percent in January. It was the second straight gain as mortgage rates dipped to a two-year  low.         "I think that a lot of people in January decided to take advantage of mortgage rates that in many parts of country were below 7 percent," said David Berson, an economist at the Federal National Mortgage Association.

headline: Duke Power Sets Buyback
abstract: The Duke Power Company said this week that it planned to buy back up to $1 billion of its common stock in the next five years. Duke Power, a utility holding company in Charlotte, said it might buy back up to $200 million in 1996. Duke shares rose 75 cents today, to $48.50.

headline: Yeltsin's Chief of Staff Submits His Resignation
abstract: President Boris N. Yeltsin's chief of staff said today that he was resigning.         The official, Sergei Filatov, who has directed Mr. Yeltsin's staff since 1993, said he had accepted another job in the Kremlin that he would not identify. His resignation had been rumored for months.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Super Bowl Was Animal Lover's Paradise
abstract: The Rams, Bengals and Eagles were missing from Super Bowl XXX along with the  Colts, Jaguars and Cardinals. But in their absence, advertisers unleashed an ark's worth of animals upon the game's record estimated audience of 138.5 million viewers.         The beasts conscripted into pitching products on what is considered the biggest day in advertising included frogs, buzzards, horses and a penguin in commercials for Anheuser-Busch beers; cattle for the Ford F-150 pickup truck; lions and elephants and zebras -- oh my! -- for the Nissan Pathfinder; wolves for the Toyota 4runner, and a spunky goldfish named Sparky for Pepsi-Cola.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Italian Power Plant
abstract: Asea Brown Boveri said yesterday that it had received an order worth $470 million to build a 260-megawatt power plant in Italy. The plant will be at an oil refinery in Falconara that is owned by Anonima Petroli Italiana. The order was placed by Api Energia, a 50-50 joint venture between ABB. and Petroli Italiana. The plant will produce electrical power from oil refinery residues.   (Associated Press)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Lloyds TSB Profit Falls
abstract: Lloyds TSB Group P.L.C., Britain's largest domestic bank, said yesterday that its pretax profit dropped 7.9 percent in 1995. A charge of L425 million for the  merger of Lloyds Bank and TSB Group P.L.C. last year offset the benefits of surging earnings and restrained costs. Excluding the reorganization charge, Lloyds TBS profit rose 15 percent, to L2.08 billion ($3.20 billion), from L1.79  billion in 1994.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: Rescuers at Peru Crash Site Find Bodies as Crowd Watches
abstract: Hundreds of somber onlookers watched today as firefighters lined up bodies on an Andean hillside where a fiery plane crash killed 123 people. The plane, a Faucett Airlines Boeing 737, went down on Thursday night five miles outside Arequipa, Peru's second largest city.         Fifty-one foreigners, including two Americans, were aboard the flight. The Transportation Minister, Manuel Vara Ochoa, said that 103 bodies were recovered  by midday, but that everyone aboard had been killed.

headline: Strife in Chechnya Embroils a Neighboring People
abstract: The men moved in tense groups through this tiny hamlet shortly after midnight. "The Russians are going to gas us," their leader, Tarzan Etiyev said,  waking foreign journalists early this morning to warn them of an imminent attack on this Chechen settlement in the Russian republic of Dagestan. "They have agreed with the Dagestanis to kill us."         There was no such agreement -- nor reason to believe there ever would be one. There was no attack, and this town only a mile from where Chechen rebels, surrounded by Russian troops, are holding more than 100 hostages survived another tense night on Friday.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Sandoz Buys Product Rights
abstract: Sandoz A.G. said today that it would pay up to $37.5 million to Organogenesis Inc. for the licensing rights for Graftskin, a product containing living tissue  to replace damaged skin.         As part of the agreement, Sandoz, the Swiss drug and chemical maker, will buy an initial 1.6 percent stake in Organogenesis, a biotechnology company in Canton, Mass.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;FAMILY OWNERS AT LEVI STRAUSS CONSIDER STOCK BUYBACK
abstract: Levi Strauss & Company said yesterday that some of the family members who own 94 percent of the apparel maker were considering whether to buy back stock from  employees and other family members at $250 a share. A spokesman for the company, a unit of Levi Strauss Associates Inc. in San Francisco, said that after adjusting for two stock splits in the 1980's, the $250 figure was roughly 50 times higher than the $50 a share paid when the company bought back stock in 1985. Morgan Stanley in November valued the stock at about $189 a share, a company spokesman said. There are 52.8 million shares outstanding.

headline: White House Rebukes G.O.P. For Scuttling Nominee to Fed
abstract: The White House, giving up on the nomination of Felix G. Rohatyn to be the Federal Reserve's vice chairman, attacked Congressional Republicans yesterday for blocking the appointment of an "obviously qualified" candidate, and poisoning the atmosphere in Washington.         Michael D. McCurry, President Clinton's press secretary, said the Republicans had engaged in cheap election-year politics, while Laura D'Andrea Tyson, director of the White House National Economic Council, took the criticism a step further, accusing the Republicans of opposing potential appointees simply because they failed to share conservative views.

headline: Auto Sales for January Increased by 4.7%
abstract: New vehicle sales over all rose 4.7 percent for most auto makers in January compared with the comparable 1995 period as buyers snapped up brawny pickups, sport utility vehicles and mini-vans but passed over passenger cars, according to sales data released today by nearly a dozen auto companies.         "January was a pretty strong month," said Joseph S. Phillippi, an auto analyst with Lehman Brothers. The total number of vehicles sold was 656,980, up  from 627,694 in January 1995.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;A POISON PILL IS ADOPTED PRIOR TO A SPINOFF BY G.M.
abstract: Electronic Data Systems said yesterday that it had adopted a poison-pill takeover defense as the General Motors Corporation prepares to spin off the company. The strategy would make it prohibitively expensive for an unwanted suitor to buy E.D.S., as the company, which provides computer services, is known. E.D.S. said the plan was not adopted in response to any known takeover threat.

headline: Corrections
abstract: The Minding Your Business column on Jan. 14, about estate planning, referred  incorrectly to some features of a charitable lead trust, which lets people give  money to charity while offsetting estate taxes. The trust is indeed required to  pay taxes on any capital gains, but it receives a deduction for the amount it distributes each year to charity. While most such trusts are designed to avoid estate and generation-skipping taxes, a part of the assets may in fact be subject to these taxes, depending on the amount contributed, the estimated rate  of return and the specified life of the trust.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;AUTOZONE TO BUY ALLDATA FOR $56 MILLION IN STOCK
abstract: Autozone Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the closely held Alldata Corporation for $56.8 million in common stock. Alldata develops and markets software that provides automotive diagnostic and repair information to more than 15,000 repair shops nationwide. Autozone said it would operate Alldata as unit that would continue to be based in Elk Grove, Calif. Autozone, based in Memphis, has a chain of retail stores.  Autozone's stock closed at $27.625, up 75 cents a share.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;VESTAR EQUITY TO BUY SPRINGS INDUSTRIES UNIT
abstract: Springs Industries said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its fiberglass-making subsidiary to the buyout firm Vestar Equity Partners L.P. and  the unit's management for $185 million in cash and preferred stock. The Springs  subsidiary, Clark-Schwebel Inc., is one of the world's largest makers of fiberglass and industrial fabrics and employs more than 1,500 people in plants in North Carolina, South Carolina and Georgia. Under the agreement, Vestar would pay $155 million in cash and Clark-Schwebel securities consisting of preferred stock with a liquidation value of $30 million. Clark-Schwebel contributed about 10 percent of the Springs 1995 revenue of $2.23 billion. Springs is a maker of home furnishings based in Fort Mill, S.C.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;FIRST BANK EMPLOYEES TO SHARE IN A CASH WINDFALL
abstract: First Bank System Inc. said yesterday that its employees would share $11 million of a $200 million cash windfall from its unsuccessful fight to buy First Interstate Bancorp of Los Angeles. John Grundhofer, chief executive of the bank, told full-time employees they would receive $750 each and part-timers would get  less. They will get the payments on Feb. 15. The bank was the "white knight" in  First Interstate's attempt to resist a hostile takeover bid from Wells Fargo of San Francisco, but in the end First Interstate accepted a $11.6 billion Wells offer. First Bank got a $200 million breakup fee when First Interstate backed out.  First Bank said the legal, investment banking and other costs of the takeover fight were about $10 million.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Additional Work On Jack Daniel's
abstract: The Brown-Forman Beverages Worldwide unit of the Brown-Forman Corporation in  Louisville, Ky., said yesterday that it had named Simmons, Durham & Associates in St. Louis to handle additional responsibilities for Jack Daniel's Tennessee Whiskey and other brands like Jack Daniel's 1866 Classic Amber Lager. The billings were not disclosed. Simmons, Durham will introduce products in markets  into which Brown-Forman is expanding like Malaysia and Thailand as well as introduce Jack Daniel's and Cola, a premixed cocktail beverage, in Australia and New Zealand. The agency already handles advertising for products in the United States and in overseas markets like Britain and Japan.

headline: S.E.C. Allows Priests' Bid for Vote on Nabisco Spinoff
abstract: In a tersely worded opinion supporting two small orders of Roman Catholic priests, the Securities and Exchange Commission has rejected an attempt by the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation to block their proxy resolution, which calls for a rapid spinoff of the company's food business from its tobacco operations.          The ruling, which came in a letter from the S.E.C., guarantees a clear-cut choice on a spinoff for RJR Nabisco's 450,000 shareholders at the company's annual meeting in April. It also creates a highly unusual alliance between the sponsors of the resolution -- two groups of priests and brothers who own 980 shares -- and the bottom-line investors Bennett S. LeBow and Carl C. Icahn, who  own 13 million shares and are seeking a favorable spinoff vote in a separate consent solicitation.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;CROWN CORK AND SEAL DECLARES CASH DIVIDEND
abstract: The Crown Cork and Seal Company announced yesterday that it was declaring a quarterly cash dividend of 25 cents a share, the company's first dividend since  1956. The packaging products company plans to pay the dividend on March 29 to shareholders of record on March 15 and it plans to continue paying quarterly dividends. Crown Cork had said it would renew its dividends when it acquired Carnaud Metalbox S.A. of France recently. The company said it generally used extra cash to buy back shares. The stock rose $1.625 yesterday, to $49.

headline: Leslie Fay Plans to Spin Off Sassco to Creditors
abstract: The Leslie Fay Companies said yesterday that it had decided against selling its Sassco unit to a management group led by Sassco's president and founder, Arthur S. Levine. Instead, Leslie Fay intends to spin off the division to creditors.         Leslie Fay would have received $226 million for Sassco, its most profitable business, under the deal with the management group. Leslie Fay, which has been in Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings for several years, had described the transaction in a court filing in October. Leslie Fay, a maker of women's apparel, warned then that it might spin off Sassco to creditors if Mr. Levine were unable to get financing.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;Slight Drop In Coke Stock Despite Profit
abstract: Buoyed by surprisingly high beverage volume in the United States and on-target international growth, the Coca-Cola Company yesterday announced solid  fourth-quarter earnings. Nevertheless, the stock fell as much as $2 during heavier-than-average trading yesterday, closing at $73.625, down $1.50.         For the quarter, net income rose 14 percent, to $648 million, or 52 cents a share, from $567 million, or 44 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter last year, matching the expectations of analysts.

headline: China Detains U.S. Attache and Seeks Recall
abstract: In yet another diplomatic dispute between Beijing and Washington, China has demanded the recall of an American military attache whom it detained for 19 hours last week, the State Department said today.         State Department officials would not say whether the United States has agreed to the demand by China that the assistant military attache, Lieut. Col. Bradley  Gerdes of the Air Force, be recalled by Friday. They said he had been traveling  with the permission of the Chinese Government when he and a driver were arrested on Jan. 11 near a military air base at Saixi, in Guangdong province in southern  China.

headline: WHX Urges a Teledyne Shareholder Vote
abstract: The WHX Corporation said yesterday that it wanted shareholders of Teledyne to vote on its $1.78 billion bid for the company, a Los Angeles-based maker of aviation and electronics products. The offer was rejected last week by Teledyne's board.         Teledyne rejected the offer, for $32 a share, late Thursday, saying that the  price did not come close to the "far greater" value it expected to generate from improved earnings and business strategy.

headline: OUTLOOK '96: THE ECONOMY;Why China Is Ready To Cool Off
abstract: CHINA's economy may be coming to the end of its wild ride.         The background is still a little scary: Beijing lives in an uncertain political climate, the gray economy has grown so large and unwieldy that no one knows its actual size and the danger of high unemployment looms like a cloud that could break into rain anytime.

headline: FUTURES MARKETS;Frigid Weather in Midwest Spurs A Jump in Winter Wheat Prices
abstract: Winter wheat prices surged on the Kansas City Board of Trade yesterday, as frigid temperatures sweeping across the Midwest threatened to kill dormant crops and cut output.         On other markets, the cold weather bolstered natural gas and heating oil prices while copper also gained. The Commodity Research Bureau index rose 0.79 point, to 245.45.

headline: Rio Frets as Michael Jackson Plans to Film Slum
abstract: In the sweltering heat of a summer afternoon in the hillside slum of Santa Marta, a toddler cools herself under the water dripping from a rag that dangles  from a wire stretched high above her head. Raw sewage runs down the hills, sending nauseating odors like curses through the neighborhood. Drug dealers stand at checkpoints along winding alleys.         This is the favela, or hillside slum, that the singer Michael Jackson will use as a backdrop for his music video, "They Don't Care About Us." The knowledge that the poverty here will be used as an international image of urban misery has sparked an emotional debate dividing the "Marvelous City," as Rio likes to be called.

headline: With Investors Like This, Who Needs Salesmen?
abstract: MUTUAL fund managers are permitted and even expected to be big boosters of the stocks they buy. But one manager at Fidelity Investments appears to be taking the practice to a new extreme.         Through his Fidelity Advisor Strategic Opportunities fund, the manager, Daniel R. Frank, has made a big bet on a little medical products company known as the I-Stat Corporation of Princeton, N.J., which has invented a faster way for hospitals to administer blood tests. Many hospitals, though, remain unconvinced that the company's single product is cost-effective.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;Allstate's Net More Than Doubles in Quarter
abstract: The Allstate Corporation, the nation's biggest publicly traded home and automobile insurer, said yesterday that its quarterly earnings more than doubled from a year earlier, mainly because of sharp growth in auto premiums and a decline in catastrophe claims.         Allstate posted net income of $397 million, or 88 cents a share, in the fourth quarter, compared with $163 million, or 37 cents a share, in the corresponding 1994 quarter. Revenues rose 9.5 percent, to $5.85 billion from $5.34 billion.

headline: REACTOR ACCIDENT IN JAPAN IMPERILS ENERGY PROGRAM
abstract: Two months after an accident at its prototype reactor, Japan's program to use plutonium to provide a virtually inexhaustible supply of energy is at a crossroads, and could be in danger of collapse.         Even the most optimistic officials think it will take three years to restart  the fast-breeder reactor, where the leak of dangerous sodium coolant occurred in December. Some other analysts think that the reactor, which is in the city of Tsuruga on the coast of the Sea of Japan, will never be activated again.

headline: U.N. Sees Some Gain In Iraqi Oil Talks
abstract: Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali told the Security Council today that Iraqi and United Nations negotiators had worked out a 12-step plan that would lead to a limited resumption of oil sales to pay for food and medicine.         Two weeks of talks ended here on Monday, and United Nations officials are waiting to hear if Baghdad is prepared to continue the talks.

headline: Taking In the Sites;More Phone Directories Spring Up on the Web
abstract: In more than 5,000 United States telephone books, no one has a phone listed under the name Newt Gingrich. There are 13 listings of Bill Clinton. One Hillary Clinton is listed, but she's in California. Slightly more than 600 people have the last name Madonna, and one is Madonna Madonna.         There have been telephone numbers on the Web for months, but every month seems to bring more. A new Web site called Switchboard, which has numbers for 93 million people and 11 million businesses, can be searched instantly at no charge.

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: ALLIED DIGITAL TECHNOLOGIES CORP., Detroit, named George Fishman, co-chairman, to the additional position of chief executive.

headline: INVESTING IT;A Little-Known Strategy for Bond Buyers
abstract: KURT GUTFREUND, the president of a Chicago company that makes children's clothing, is like many other bond buyers. He doesn't like to take risks, and he  puts a high priority on yield.         So why did Mr. Gutfreund recently sell $250,000 of triple-A municipal bonds,  bought just two years ago and carrying a coupon yield of 6.75 percent, and buy an equivalent sum of bonds paying only 6.35 percent?

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: An Indonesian Asset Is Also a Liability;Low Wages Woo Foreign Business, But the Price Is Worker Poverty
abstract: Many days Tongris Situmorang, in his blue baseball hat with a large X on the  front, hangs around the gates of the enormous Nike sport shoe factory here, talking to friends leaving the assembly lines at the end of the work day.         The gangly 22-year-old used to work inside the well-guarded gates, but five months ago he was dismissed for organizing workers to demand more than the 4,600 rupiah they are paid each day, about $2.10, the Government-dictated minimum wage. Then, after being dismissed, he was locked in a room at the plant and interrogated for seven days by the military, which demanded to know more about his labor activities.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;BRODERBUND PREDICTS EARNINGS BELOW EXPECTATIONS
abstract: Shares of Broderbund Software Inc. fell sharply yesterday in after-hours trading after the company announced that earnings for the second quarter, which  ends on Feb. 29, would fall short of analysts' estimates. After rising $3, to $53.125, in regular Nasdaq trading, Broderbund shares fell to $49. Broderbund, based in Novato, Calif., said it expected revenues in the quarter of $44 million to $49 million, compared with $45.2 million in the corresponding period last year.

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization                                                Jan. 12    Jan. 5   Jan. 13                                              1996      1995      1995 Gasoline production, daily                    7.3       7.6       7.0 Distillate production, daily                  3.1       3.4       3.0 Gasoline stocks                             205.8     202.6     200.1 Distillate stocks                           125.8     131.6     110.4 Crude imports, daily                          7.4       6.7       6.7 Product imports, daily                        1.7       1.7       1.6 Crude stocks                                303.5     301.3     279.1 Crude production, daily                       6.5       6.4       6.3 Refinery utilization (%)                     89.8      92.1      86.8

headline: World News Briefs;Solidarity Loses Vote On Polish State Assets
abstract: The Solidarity union conceded today that its latest challenge to the former Communists who have won control of the Government, a referendum on sharing state assets, probably had failed to win enough support.         By law, more than half the 28 million voters had to take part to make the Government act on Sunday's vote, in which Solidarity sought a mandate for state  enterprises and other assets to be distributed among citizens in the form of free coupons. But informal estimates put the turnout at 30 to 40 percent.

headline: World News Briefs;Poltical Motive Alleged In Killing of Cambodian
abstract: A Oscar-winning Cambodian actor slain in Los Angeles may have been killed by  agents of the Khmer Rouge, his brother said today.         The accuser, Chan Sarun, said he believed that his brother, Dr. Haing S. Ngor, was killed because of his political efforts against the Khmer Rouge, which brutally ruled Cambodia two decades ago. On Tuesday the Co-Prime Minister of Cambodia, Hun Sen, described Dr. Ngor as "an activist against the Khmer Rouge,"  but said there was not enough evidence to implicate the group.

headline: Bank of Tokyo Pursues Embezzlement Case
abstract: The Bank of Tokyo, a leading Japanese bank, said today that it had lodged a criminal complaint against a former employee who is said to have embezzled 850 million yen, about $8 million.         Bank officials said that the employee, whom they identified only as a 39-year-old loan officer at a domestic branch, had used the money for gambling.

headline: INVESTING WITH: Edward C. Mitchell;Invesco Total Return Fund
abstract: EDWARD C. MITCHELL thrives on bad news.         When the stock of Compaq Computer fell 17 percent this month after the company predicted lower earnings, Mr. Mitchell, the manager of the Invesco Total Return fund, didn't sell the shares the fund has owned since 1991. Seeing a bargain, he bought more.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;AMERICAN STANDARD TO LOWER EARNINGS ESTIMATE
abstract: The American Standard Companies said yesterday that its first-quarter earnings would be below expectations because of weak European sales. The company, which makes air-conditioning units and bath fixtures, will also take a  charge of about $200 million to reduce the value of some assets. Earnings will be "somewhat below" analysts' estimates but in line with earnings a year earlier, said Emmanuel Kampouris, company chairman, chief executive and president. The Piscataway, N.J., company reported profit from operations of $26  million, or 38 cents a share, in the first quarter a year ago, before a $30 million charge for a loss on debt retirement.

headline: Indiana Bank Acquisition
abstract: The First Merchants Corporation said today that it had agreed to acquire Union National Bancorp of Liberty, Ind., for $25 million in stock. First Merchants is a bank holding company based here. The deal, which has been approved by both companies' boards, is expected to be completed by the middle of the year.

headline: Mexico and Insurgent Group Reach Pact on Indian Rights
abstract: Leaders of the Zapatista rebel movement said today that they would sign an agreement with the Government expanding the rights of Indians in Mexico, clearing the way for a peace accord in the two-year-old armed conflict in Chiapas, in the south.         The decision by the mainly Indian guerrillas of the Zapatista National Liberation Army was announced in the rustic square of a Chiapas village where the negotiations were held. A top commander known as Tacho, whose face was concealed behind a hallmark black ski mask, said "dozens of thousands" of Indians had been consulted and 96 percent endorsed the accord, "the first in this long process of constructing a just and honorable peace."

headline: COMPANY NEWS;DIGICON AND VERITAS AGREE TO $72 MILLION MERGER
abstract: Digicon Inc., which acquires seismic data used to search for oil and natural  gas, said it agreed yesterday to a stock-swap merger worth about $72 million with a Canadian competitor, Veritas Energy Services Inc. Under the agreement, the acquisition will be structured as a tax-free pooling of interests, in which  each Veritas share will be exchanged for 0.80 Digicon share, or about $8.50 worth of Digicon stock.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;An offbeat campaign enlists a giant bee to sing the praises of flora.
abstract: YOU certainly have heard of a spelling bee. Now brace yourself for a selling  bee.         The National Promoflor Council, which receives financial support from flower  growers, importers and wholesalers, is undertaking its first effort to reach consumers with a sweet yet offbeat campaign that seeks to generate a buzz -- literally and figuratively -- for cut flowers and greens.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS;Treasury Prices Plummet On Delay in Budget Talks
abstract: Prices of Treasury securities fell sharply late yesterday as budget meetings  in Washington were unexpectedly postponed and investors grew wary about the progress of those talks.         Bonds, headed for a second consecutive day of gains, bounced in choppy trading, with the market supported by a strong dollar in overseas trading and expectations that a budget resolution was near. But early optimism turned to late disappointment as market participants were suddenly forced to come to grips with the probability of no budget agreement this week, as the budget talks were  called off.

headline: Putting Porsche in the Pink
abstract: Not too long ago, the production floor of Porsche's factory was not a pretty  sight. Workers would storm off in a huff. Managers would fume. Voices would rise above the hum and bang of the line.         And Japanese engineers -- mostly Toyota alumni -- would wave their fingers, demand explanations, scold, lecture and browbeat, essentially telling some of Germany's finest automobile craftsmen how poorly they were doing their jobs.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;UNITEL VIDEO CLOSES EDITEL UNIT IN CHICAGO
abstract: Unitel Video said yesterday that it planned to get out of its money-losing television special-effects and graphics business by selling its Editel unit and  that it would shrink the unit, dismissing 75 people, while looking for a buyer.  The company closed its Editel Chicago division, dismissing 40 workers, and will  trim the staff of its New York division by half. The job cuts amount to about 16 percent of Unitel Video's work force. The Editel divisions generated about one-third of Unitel's annual revenue of $83 million last year. Editel provides special effects, graphics, film coloring and editing primarily for television commercials.

headline: Ex-Chief Executive at Viacom Is Said to Be Offered Job at MCA
abstract: Frank J. Biondi Jr., ousted last month as president and chief executive of Viacom Inc., has been offered the position of chief executive at MCA Inc. by Edgar Bronfman Jr., the chief executive of the Seagram Company, which owns 80 percent of MCA, several people close to the discussions said yesterday.         Mr. Biondi declined to comment last night, and a spokeswoman for Mr. Bronfman said he would not comment.

headline: U.S. Companies Competing To Be First in Gas to Mexico
abstract: The competition to profit from the opening of Mexico's energy market intensified this week as Tenneco Inc. entered a race with California's huge utilities to become the first American company to ship natural gas for retail sale in Mexico.         These companies and a host of others, including electric utilities and power  plant builders, are striving to capitalize on new Mexican rules inviting Americans to enter businesses that for decades were restricted to Mexican Government agencies.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;SMITH'S IS IN TALKS TO BUY SMITTY'S SUPERMARKETS
abstract: Smith's Food and Drug Centers Inc. said yesterday that it was in talks to buy the Phoenix-based supermarket operator Smitty's Super Valu Inc. Smith's, a Salt  Lake City-based supermarket operator, also said it would repurchase up to 50 percent of its class A and class B shares "at a premium to recent trading levels." Further details of the proposed transactions were not provided. Publicly traded class B shares of Smith's fell 25 cents, to $27.75. The company has a market value of $605.7 million. The privately held Smitty's operates 28 supermarkets in Phoenix and Tucson.

headline: Polish Secret Police Still Making Trouble, Dissidents Say
abstract: Two of Poland's most prominent dissidents, who were jailed many times by the  Communist secret police, wrote in an open letter published today that the nation's intelligence services are just as powerful now as they were in the Communist era.         The two writers said public accusations that Prime Minister Jozef Oleksy, a former Communist, had spied for Moscow, had been prepared by senior secret service agents who had been members of the intelligence services during the Communist era.

headline: Investors Said to Prepare Plan To Make Pan Am Fly Again
abstract: It flew the first scheduled flights across the Atlantic and Pacific, and operated the first commercial jet service. Its name towered over the Manhattan skyline, and its logo is as recognizable to millions as Coca-Cola's.         But next summer, Pan Am may carry an unfamiliar label: start-up airline.

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization                                                Feb. 16    Feb. 9   Feb. 17                                              1996      1996      1995 Gasoline production, daily                    7.5       7.2       7.2 Distillate production, daily                  3.1       3.0       3.0 Gasoline stocks                             210.1     211.0     221.1 Distillate stocks                           103.3     107.2     125.8 Crude imports, daily                          7.6       7.0       6.7 Product imports, daily                        1.7       1.6       1.8 Crude stocks                                299.1     303.0     327.4 Crude production, daily                       6.5       6.5       6.6 Refinery utilization (%)                     89.2      89.5      88.9

headline: Head of Israel's Shin Bet Security Service Resigns
abstract: Under fire for failing to prevent the assassination of Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin, but basking in the glow of the killing of Israel's most wanted Palestinian terrorist, the head of Israel's Shin Bet security service stepped down today.         A statement by the Prime Minister's office said the Shin Bet chief had submitted a resignation letter on Sunday, but was asked by Prime Minister Shimon Peres to reconsider. After the security chief served notice today that the decision was final, Mr. Peres accepted the resignation.

headline: Honduras to Pursue Trial for Officers
abstract: The Attorney General of Honduras, Edmundo Orellana, said today that he would  challenge an appellate court's ruling that 10 military officers could not be prosecuted in civilian courts for human rights abuses.         The court's ruling on Friday, which said that the officers are immune from prosecution under amnesty laws, blocked what would have been the first civilian  trial of the military.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Nestle Reports Drop Of 10.2% in Net Profit
abstract: The Swiss food giant Nestle S.A. said its 1995 net profit declined 10.2 percent as the strong Swiss franc and higher coffee bean prices cut into earnings. The company reported net income of 2.92 billion francs ($2.45 billion), compared with 1994 income of 3.25 billion francs, which included a one-time gain of 306 million francs from the sale of cosmetics units. The fall was in line with analysts' expectations.          Nestle shares were down 7 francs, to 1,335 francs, having fallen as much as  14 francs before the earnings release, after the company said it held "good perspectives" for the current year. Nestle added it would pay an unchanged dividend of 26.5 francs a share.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: U.S. Ships Shifted to Gulf After Hint of Iraqi Buildup
abstract: Five years after the Persian Gulf war, a dozen United States Navy cargo ships laden with tanks, armored vehicles and other military hardware are anchored off  the coast here, reflecting the wariness of American forces that Iraq might start the conflict again.         Until late last summer, the cargo ships were stationed at Diego Garcia, an American base in the Indian Ocean, and in other ports, ready to rush anywhere in the world.

headline: MARKET WATCH;A Fight That's All Smoke and Mirrors
abstract: For those who treat politics as a spectator sport, Pat Buchanan's 1996 campaign has been a blessing, transforming a dull process into an exciting one.  Bennett S. LeBow is doing the same thing for the tobacco industry.         Things got interesting last week when Mr. LeBow, who runs the Liggett Group,  a minor player in the cigarette business, cut deals with some anti-tobacco lawyers and state attorneys general.

headline: FUTURES MARKETS;Heating Oil Surges on Concern About a Decline in Inventories
abstract: Heating oil prices surged yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange for the fifth consecutive session as concerns grew over supply.         On other markets, wheat and sugar prices also gained, driving the Commodity Research Bureau index of 17 commodities up 0.18 point, to 249.25.

headline: AMERICAN TOPICS : A 5-Year Test for Alcoholics
abstract: Recovering from alcoholism is similar to recovering from cancer: The subject must be symptom-free for five years to be out of danger of relapse, according to a study by George E. Vaillant of Harvard Medical School and Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston.

headline: World News Briefs;Cali Drug Leader Escapes in Bogota
abstract: One of the top three leaders of the Cali drug cartel escaped today from a prison in Bogota. The cartel leader, Jose Santacruz Londono, apparently sneaked  out of Bogota's La Picota prison today, said Miller Rubio, spokesman for the Prisons Institute.         The authorities believe that Mr. Sanctacruz slipped out in a car that resembled one used earlier in the day by prosecutors. Prosecutors' cars are not  checked when they enter or leave the prison.

headline: A GIANT MERGER OF PHONE AND CABLE
abstract: U S West, a regional phone company, will acquire the nation's third-largest cable operator in a multibillion-dollar deal. Business Day, page D1.

headline: Company Briefs
abstract: MICROPOLIS CORP., Chatsworth, Calif., which makes high- performance disk drives used to record information, sold its disk-drive business to Singapore Technologies Industrial Corp. for $55 million.

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;French Court Bans Book On Mitterrand's Health
abstract: A book about the late ex-President Francois Mitterrand's health by his former doctor was banned this week by a French court, but not until after a first printing of 40,000 copies had already sold out.         The court ruled on Thursday in favor of a complaint by Mr. Mitterrand's widow, their two sons, and his daughter. They contended that the revelations in  the book, "The Great Secret" by Dr. Claude Gubler, constituted "a particularly serious intrusion into intimate details of President Francois Mitterrand's private family life, and that of his wife and children."

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;Caterpillar Earnings, in a Surprise, Rise by 7.5%
abstract: Caterpillar Inc. said today that earnings rose 7.5 percent in the fourth quarter, surprising analysts, who had expected a decline, and sending the company's stock up 10 percent.         At the same time, however, the maker of heavy equipment warned that growth may slow this year.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent

headline: COMPANY NEWS;K-TEL SALE OF CONSUMER ENTERTAINMENT BUSINESS IS OFF
abstract: K-Tel International Inc., which sells recorded music, said yesterday that an  agreement to sell its consumer entertainment business had been ended. Last July, K-Tel's board approved selling the consumer entertainment business to a group led by K-Tel's president, Mickey Elfenbein, for $25 million. Among other factors, the proposed sale was subject to the closing of a related transaction involving K-5 Leisure Products Inc., the purchasing group and Mr. Elfenbein. Details of that transaction were not disclosed. K-Tel said that it had received  written notice on Thursday that K-5 had terminated the related transaction. K-5  is owned by K-Tel's chairman, Philip Kives, who also holds a roughly 66 percent  stake in K-Tel.

headline: S. .H. Bayles, 85, Prominent Executive In Advertising World
abstract: S. Heagan Bayles, a founder of SSC&B, a major New York advertising agency, died of cancer on Jan. 30 at his retirement home in Fort Lauderdale. He was 85.          In 1946, Mr. Bayles founded SSC&B with three colleagues: Raymond Sullivan, Donald Stauffer and Robert Colwell. Aware that the advertising business was becoming increasingly global, SSC&B bought a major interest in Lintas, an agency that had offices in 34 countries. He continued as chairman of SSC&B-Lintas until its sale in 1979.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
abstract: * Skellyvision Inc., New York, to Lockhardt & Pettus Advertising, New York, to introduce Skelly, an air-cushion board game. The billings were not disclosed. * Dallas Burn to Levenson & Hill, Dallas, as the first agency to handle advertising, marketing and public relations for the new team, which will be part of Major League Soccer. The billings have not been determined. * FMC APG Specialty Products Group, Princeton, N.J., to Gillespie, Princeton, to handle advertising for the manufacturer of pest control products, previously handled in-house. The billings were not disclosed.

headline: German Developer Accepts Extradition
abstract: Jurgen Schneider, the fugitive German property developer arrested in Miami last May, has agreed to be extradited to Germany, his German lawyers said today.         Mr. Schneider has agreed to give up his appeal of a United States Federal court ruling that he be extradited to Germany to face charges of fraud in connection with the 5 billion mark ($3.5 billion) collapse of his former real estate business.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;EARNINGS RESULT IN A SPECIAL DIVIDEND AT ALCOA
abstract: The Aluminum Company of America said yesterday that it would pay shareholders a special cash dividend of 43 cents a share because 1995 earnings exceeded $3 a  share. The company, the world's largest aluminum maker, pays a special dividend  of 30 percent of the amount exceeding annual per-share earnings of $3, said Al Posti, a company spokesman. On Monday, Pittsburgh-based Alcoa posted net income  for the year of $790.5 million, or $4.43 a share, the company's best results since 1989. The bonus dividend is in addition to Alcoa's regular quarterly dividend of 22.5 cents a share.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;China Puts Restrictions On Futures Speculation
abstract: The Chinese Government said yesterday that it had banned state enterprises from engaging in futures speculation in an attempt to further regulate the once-chaotic futures market. State enterprises and Government departments will be allowed to trade futures securities only for protecting against financial risk, the order from the Securities Commission said.          In addition, state enterprises and Government departments must provide documents showing that they have been approved by futures administrations or directors of futures exchanges before they can trade futures. Futures exchanges  and brokerage firms face fines or suspensions if they violate the ban.   (AP)

headline: Japanese Stocks Lower
abstract: Stock prices were lower here today. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 40.56 points, or 0.20 percent, at 20,300.38. On Thursday, the Nikkei was down 31.29 points.

headline: MARKET TIMING
abstract: Monday The Commerce Department reports on construction spending in February. In January, spending rose three-tenths of 1 percent.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Japanese Banks Offer Vague Help in Bailout
abstract: In a faint bow to blistering public criticism over a proposed rescue of mortgage companies, Japanese banks agreed today to shoulder a bit more of the burden. But the banks' plan is so vague that it is not clear whether the banks will actually have to put up any more money.         "The banks will not share an additional burden," said Yoshinobu Yamada, an analyst with Merrill Lynch Japan here.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;NEXGEN SEES A QUARTERLY LOSS OF AT LEAST $25 MILLION
abstract: Citing price pressures in the semiconductor market and a substantial inventory write-off, Nexgen Inc. said yesterday that it would post a loss in the quarter that ended in December. The company, which is merging with Advanced Micro Devices Inc., said the loss would be at least $25 million to $30 million and could top $50 million. During the quarter that ended in September, the company reported a loss of $20.5 million. Year-ago figures are not available because Nexgen was a private company until last May.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Swiss Reinsurance Buys 3.6% Stake in Fortis
abstract: Swiss Reinsurance, the world's second-largest reinsurance company, will buy a 3.6 percent stake in Fortis A.G. for 5 billion Belgian francs ($328 million). Fortis, the Belgian insurance and banking company, sold 1.35 million new shares  to the Zurich-based company, bringing the total number of issued shares to 37.6  million.          Swiss Re paid 3,717 francs a share, 2.25 percent more than the price of Fortis shares at the close of the Brussels stock market yesterday.  Sophie Van Bowel, a Fortis spokeswoman, said Swiss Re had been providing reinsurance for Fortis for a year. She said no joint ventures with the Swiss company were planned.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Prudential's new campaign suggests that the best person to handle your finances  is . . . you.
abstract: THE words "Be your own rock" sound as if they might have been an exhortation  offered by a hard-headed coach like Vince Lombardi or a positive-thinking preacher like the Rev. Norman Vincent Peale. But the phrase is actually the centerpiece of a campaign that seeks to use the popular notion of empowerment to polish the tatty image of the Prudential Insurance Company of America.         Quirky television commercials that begin appearing tomorrow will introduce "Be your own rock" as the Prudential theme -- a sort of financial version of the Nike Inc. mantra to "Just do it." The theme replaces various versions of the familiar Prudential "Piece of the rock" slogan, all of which were derived from the company's longtime icon, the Rock of Gibraltar. Prudential plans to spend $56 million on the commercials as well as on print advertisements that start running next week in a lengthy list of magazines.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;LAZARD SAID TO BE IN TALKS TO ACQUIRE A FIRM
abstract: The investment firm of W. R. Lazard & Company is in talks to acquire another  firm, according to the newsletter P & I Daily. Melvin Neal, Lazard vice president, told P & I the discussions were in the early stages but he would not  name the other firm. P & I said Smith, Graham Asset Management was rumored to be the other party, but both Mr. Neal and Ladell Graham, chairman of Smith Graham,  denied it. Lazard, based in New York, is Wall Street's largest black-owned firm. Graham is also minority-owned. Mr. Neal confirmed that his firm was in the early stages of acquisition talks with another firm. He said the other firm was  engaged in the equities business but declined to specify the name of the firm or any other details.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;China Shifts Position On Currency Exchange
abstract: China will let foreign investors buy hard currency with their Chinese yuan in banks on a limited basis, a central bank official said yesterday. The move is China's first major currency change since it allowed domestic companies to buy foreign currency at banks in January 1994, and it marks a step toward convertibility of the yuan.          Foreign-invested enterprises in China must now exchange currencies at so-called swap markets. This involves a Government approval, and the often-difficult task of locating a counterparty. Under the change, businesses in which foreign companies have a stake will have the option of depositing their export earnings at designated state banks.   Bloomberg Business News

headline: A Dial Tone All the Same
abstract: Lawmakers and journalists like to describe the impending deregulation of the  nation's telecommunications industry as revolutionary, sweeping, even historic.  That may be true for telecommunications companies. But for most Americans, life  immediately after deregulation will not seem much different than life before it.         At the outset, before the din of telemarketing starts, it may actually be a bit quieter. The titans of the telephone business -- the local and long-distance carriers -- will call off their lobbyists and cease the chorus of  advertisements that have championed one position and denigrated others.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;VENTURE PLANS TO CLOSE 10 STORES AND CUT 1,200 JOBS
abstract: Venture Stores Inc., a general-merchandise retailer based in O'Fallon, Mo., said yesterday that it would close 10 stores and eliminate 1,200 jobs as part of a plan to transform itself into a family merchandise chain. The retailer cited poor sales and earnings performance for the stores involved, two in Chicago, two in Houston, one in Champaign, Ill., and five in Indianapolis. About 120 workers  will be cut from each of the stores, or about 7 percent of the company's total work force of 17,000, a spokesman, Randy Myers, said. Venture will keep 105 stores open. The plan will save the company $22 million and is not expected to result in a charge against earnings, Mr. Myers said.

headline: Japanese Stocks Gain
abstract: Japanese stocks were trading higher here today. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 205.40 points, or 1.03 percent, to close at 20,125.37. On Wednesday, the index fell 80.43 points.

headline: Massacre in Croatia Described in Court
abstract: Prosecutors at a hearing of the international war crimes tribunal explained in detail today what they called the first episode of "ethnic cleansing" in the  Balkan war, a 1991 "orgy of beatings" in Vukovar, Croatia, that left 261 Croats  dead.         Three Yugoslav Army officers accused of directing the slaughter were charged  in November. But Serbia has refused to surrender them, so the hearing was held without them.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Shipbuilder Rescued
abstract: The creditor banks of Bremer Vulkan A.G. pledged to grant almost 100 million  German marks ($70 million) in fresh credit to keep the cash-short shipbuilder afloat for the next two months, the group's administrators said yesterday. "Production can continue," the court-appointed administrator, Jobst Wellensiek,  said after Bremer Vulkan's 40 creditor banks hammered out an interim solution to the company's fiscal problems on Monday. Bremer Vulkan, Germany's largest shipbuilder, with yards dotted across northern Germany, filed last week for protection from creditors after presenting a loss of 1 billion marks ($700 million) for 1995 and saying many of its units were insolvent.   (Reuters)

headline: Stocks Jump to Yet Another High, Led by Technology Issues
abstract: Stocks jumped broadly yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average setting another new record. Technology shares were stars of the market.         The Dow climbed 50.57 points, to 5,242.84, surpassing the previous high of 5,219.36, set on Monday. "Almost half of today's gain came from program trading  in the morning," said Jeffrey Rubin, an analyst for Birinyi Associates.

headline: World News Briefs;At Least 20 Afghans Die As Rockets Hit Capital
abstract: Rockets that struck a southwestern suburb of Kabul on Tuesday killed at least 20 people, many of them children, witnesses and hospital officials said today. At least 48 others were wounded.         No one claimed responsibility for the assault, but the Defense Ministry blamed Taleban rebels, who are seeking to topple the Government.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Five Foreign Companies Barred by Singapore
abstract: Singapore has barred five foreign companies from new Government contracts for five years after they were named in what is being called the country's biggest corruption case, a Government official said yesterday. The companies -- BICC Supertension Cable (1980) Ltd, a unit of BICC P.L.C. of Britain; the Tomen Corporation and the Marubeni Corporation of Japan; Siemens A.G. of Germany, and  Pirelli Cables, a unit of Pirelli S.p.A. of Italy -- were barred after the conviction of Choy Hon Tim, former deputy chief executive of the Public Utilities Board.

headline: Negotiator Says U S West Was Told of Turner
abstract: An adviser to Time Warner Inc., Oded Aboodi, testified today that he told Richard D. McCormick, the chairman of U S West Inc., in 1993 that Time Warner was contemplating buying Turner Broadcasting System Inc. and that he asked whether U S West wanted to invest in the purchase.         The testimony came in the fifth day of a trial in Delaware Chancery Court. U  S West is attempting to block Time Warner's planned acquisition of Turner, the owner of Cable News Network and other cable television networks.

headline: FROM THE DESK OF: LLOYD M. KRIEGER;Hey, Mac, Don't Fail Me Now!
abstract: MEMBERS of my computer-savvy generation can be divided into two groups: PC people and Macintosh people. The difference goes beyond what sits on our desks or what we carry in our briefcases. It reflects our attitude about our work and  ourselves.        I have always been a Macintosh person. I got hooked while in college at Stanford, a stone's throw from Silicon Valley. I bought my first Mac when I was  a sophomore in 1986. I used it to write term papers and to make presentations and run statistics for my biology class. It was a modular design, without wires  and a separate monitor. In that pre-laptop era, on a warm day, I would take it outside and work in the sun.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;KERKORIAN MIGHT INCREASE GAMING INVESTMENT
abstract: Kirk Kerkorian is considering raising his investment in the gaming industry,  the chairman of his investment company, the Tracinda Corporation, said yesterday. "Our investment in the gaming industry is one that we will continue to find ways to expand over the next several years," the chairman, Jerome B. York, said yesterday. Mr. Kerkorian already owns 47.9 million shares, or 74 percent, of the stock in MGM Grand Inc., which operates the MGM Grand hotel in Las Vegas, Nev. Mr. Kerkorian, Chrysler's largest shareholder, ended a 10-month  battle with the auto maker earlier this month. Chrysler pledged to repurchase $2 billion of its stock this year and $1 billion next year, and Mr. Kerkorian stands to receive about 14 percent of that, or about $420 million.

headline: Court Won't Shift Okinawa Rape Case
abstract: Japan's highest court rejected an appeal today by the mother of an American serviceman accused of rape, ordering that his trial continue on the island where the attack occurred.         The serviceman, Pfc. Kendrick Ledet, of Waycross, Ga., and the two other United States servicemen are being tried for the rape of a 12-year-old girl on Okinawa in September.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Fox Restates Support Of TV Rating System
abstract: The Fox Network said yesterday that it would provide ratings for the content  of its programs, similar to those provided for films by the Motion Picture Association, regardless of whether such a system is devised by all major broadcasters.         "Our goal is to help parents by providing them with information while continuing to respect freedom of our producers," Rupert Murdoch, the chairman of the News Corporation, which owns Fox, said in a statement.

headline: A Rapper Who Found Music to Be the Easy Part
abstract: Poetic, the rapper formerly of the group Too Poetic, rents out the basement of his sister's home in Brentwood, L.I. His car is a 1989 Ford Escort and, he says contentedly, "it serves its purpose."         This is a far cry from where he thought he and his group were headed in 1988, after he signed on the dotted line of a 60-some page contract for Tommy Boy Records, a unit of Time Warner. His struggle of working a regular job while shopping demo tapes had seemingly paid off: suddenly he was staying in grand hotels, riding in expensive cars and basking in the adoration of fans. "It culminates into an overwhelming sense of accomplishment," he said.

headline: At African Heart of Voodoo, Pride Over Heritage
abstract: There are no factory whistles to compete with the church bells or the muezzin's call to prayer in this sun-battered town that resembles so many other  forgotten stops along the West African coast. So few cars move about that schoolchildren think nothing of strolling down the middle of its sandy streets.          If it were not for the small whitewashed Portuguese fort that nowadays serves as a museum to a trade in humans that in the last century made this town the capital of what Europeans called the Slave Coast, at first glance little would give away Ouidah's place in history.

headline: Balkan Leaders Pledge to Carry Out Dayton Accord
abstract: Officials of the United States and its NATO allies concluded two days of sometimes tense meetings with Balkan leaders here today, producing a series of declarations that recommit the former warring parties to full compliance with the Bosnian peace accords.         In four formal documents, the Presidents of Serbia, Croatia and Bosnia pledged to resume contacts with commanders of the NATO-led force, to carry out on schedule the establishment of a unified administration in the Bosnian capital of Sarajevo, to insure the safety of war prisoners and refugees, and to commit themselves to the prosecution of war crimes and other human rights abuses.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Two Are Promoted At Compton Partners
abstract: Compton Partners, Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising in New York, which is owned by Cordiant P.L.C., has promoted two creative executives.          Dick Anderson, 50, executive vice president and executive creative director, was promoted to chairman and chief creative officer. As chairman, he succeeds Tony Wainwright, who in May became chairman of Harris Drury Cohen in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.; the position of chief creative officer is new at Compton Partners. And Joe Petruccio, 37, senior vice president and creative director, was promoted to succeed Mr. Anderson as executive creative director.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Volvo Profit Fell 38% in Fourth Quarter
abstract: Volvo A.B., the Swedish automobile maker, said yesterday that its pretax profit fell 38 percent in the fourth quarter, chiefly because of a loss in its car division. The profit of 2.28 billion kronor, about $337 million, did not meet analyst expectations. It included a charge of 303 million kronor for cuts in staff numbers at the car division. The company's pretax profit for the full year fell to 13.05 billion kronor from 16.38 billion a year earlier.          Volvo Cars said it would cut 2,200 jobs, of which 760 are managers; the unit said that the cutbacks would bring more charges.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: Having Gotten the Part, Bronfman Plays the Mogul
abstract: LSS than three weeks ago, 80 top executives of MCA Inc. were ordered to show  up at a hotel in downtown Los Angeles for an all-day meeting with their new boss, Edgar Bronfman Jr., chief executive of the Seagram Company. The invitation had only one request: wear jeans.         With his troops seated around him in a huge circle, Mr. Bronfman got right to the point. He declared that he wanted to redesign MCA from top to bottom to cut  costs and increase profits. Seagram, he said, was in this for the long haul; it  believed in buying, not selling, companies. And he appealed to the divisions, which had a long history of squabbling, to cooperate more closely. Employees had already gotten a taste of the new openness when MCA had its first Christmas party in memory, a boisterous celebration on a sound stage at Universal Pictures, MCA's movie division.

headline: Bomb in Bahrain
abstract: A bomb exploded in the lobby of a luxury seafront hotel in Bahrain today, reportedly wounding four people, and an Islamic organization claimed responsibility.         The blast followed weeks of anti-Government unrest in the country, a financial hub in the Persian Gulf region and the site of an important American Navy base.

headline: Trial Forces New Look At Apartheid-Era Crime
abstract: After dark on Jan. 21, 1987, a half-dozen men with AK-47's burst into Victor  Ntuli's small house in what is now the province of KwaZulu-Natal, spraying it with gunfire. Their goal was to kill Mr. Ntuli, an African National Congress leader.         Instead, they massacred 13 sleeping people, most of them children who had been at a prayer meeting at the house. Mr. Ntuli was not home.

headline: Stocks Slip in Japan
abstract: Stocks were trading lower here today. At midday, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 70.36 points, or a third of 1 percent, at 20,581.72. On Tuesday, the Nikkei rose 88.50 points.

headline: BellSouth's Chairman Is Planning to Retire
abstract: John L. Clendenin announced today that he would retire as chairman, president and chief executive of the BellSouth Corporation at the end of 1996.         The company said he would be succeeded by Duane Ackerman, vice chairman and chief operating officer, although Mr. Clendenin would remain as a nonemployee chairman through 1997.

headline: Israel, Fearing Attack, Closes Off West Bank and Gaza
abstract: The Israeli Government closed off the West Bank and Gaza Strip until further  notice on Monday night, saying that it had intelligence information that Muslim  militants were planning a terrorist attack.         The closing, which bars Palestinian Arabs from entering Israel proper with very few exceptions, infuriated the Palestinians, especially since it barred many Muslims from worshiping at the Al Aksa mosque in Jerusalem in the last week of the sacred month of Ramadan. As many as 240,000 Muslims have worshipped at the mosque on the Fridays of Ramadan.

headline: Premier-Designate Seeks Change in Italy
abstract: Seeking to break an deadlock in talks to form a new cabinet, the Prime Minister-designate, Antonio Maccanico, promised today to back fundamental changes to Italy's troubled political system.         The pledge was intended to halt two weeks of squabbling over whether Mr. Maccanico would spearhead reforms aimed at ending decades of revolving-door political crises, which have produced 55 Governments since World War II.

headline: Jidda Journal;Saudis Feast Freely From TV Dishes
abstract: Whether the satellite dishes that crown nearly every roof here are, well, entirely legal is not entirely clear.         But in a country in which censors still black out magazine photographs that display too much cleavage, no one in this seaside city seems to be standing in the way of the latest onslaught from abroad.

headline: Corporate America Is Courting Agricultural Biotech
abstract: WALL STREET has been bitten by this bug before.         Back in 1992, investors loved agricultural biotechnology stocks. Even as drug-related biotech stocks were getting hammered, excitement over Calgene's Flav'r Sav'r tomato sent the group, then composed of a half dozen or so companies, soaring.

headline: Novell Executive Quits Over Revamping Plan
abstract: Novell Inc., the leading producer of software for desktop computer networks,  yesterday announced the resignation of its executive vice president and chief technology officer, Sheldon Laube, who joined the company only last May.         Mr. Laube's departure followed the announcement last week by Novell that it was consolidating the company's three product groups under Steve Markman, a Novell vice president. Before that, Mr. Markman and Mr. Laube both reported directly to Robert Frankenberg, Novell's chief executive.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;CONSECO ANNOUNCES PLANS TO DOUBLE ITS DIVIDEND RATE
abstract: Conseco Inc., an insurance and financial services company, said yesterday that it would double its dividend rate. The company, which now pays a quarterly  dividend of 2 cents a share, will raise its dividend to 4 cents a share before accounting for a 2-for-1 stock split. The company will pay the dividend on April 1, the same day it will issue two shares for every one share held. After the split, the quarterly dividend rate will be 2 cents a share, effectively doubled. The stock split and higher dividend will be for shareholders of record  on March 20.

headline: Kuwait-China Oil Project
abstract: The Persian Gulf nation of Kuwait has awarded a $391 million contract to a Chinese company to build two oil-gathering centers. The contract was signed between the Kuwait Oil Company and the state-owned China Petroleum Engineering Construction Corporation. An official of the Kuwaiti concern said the two gathering centers, to be completed in a little less than three years, would add 410,000 barrels a day to production capacity.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Health Advertising Is Focus of Moves
abstract: Two agencies have announced initiatives in health care advertising.         Cordiant P.L.C. has combined elements of two of its divisions, Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising and Compton Partners, both of New York, to form a unit specializing in marketing consumer health care products and services.

headline: INSIDE
abstract: INVESTING IT/Page 3/ With Tenneco now busy cleaning house, investors may soon have to decide what a share in the company's shipyard will be worth. By James Sterngold.

headline: Russians Open Fire to End Chechen Protest
abstract: Local police officers backed by Russian troops fired tear gas and guns today  in an attempt to break up a rally of least 1,000 protesters in the center of Grozny, the Chechen capital.         But later tonight, the leader of the Russian-backed Government in Chechnya, Doku Zavgayev, said a compromise had been worked out to end the standoff peacefully.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                                               Previous      Year                               Yesterday       Day       Ago

headline: Fed Survey Sees 'Modest Pace' of Growth
abstract: The economy was growing at a "generally modest pace" at the turn of the year, a Federal Reserve survey showed today, but an index intended to predict turning  points in the economy suggested an increased possibility of a downturn this year.         The Fed's periodic pulse-taking of business conditions in all 12 of its regions found a mixture of disappointing holiday sales, uneven factory activity  and subdued inflation.

headline: Sudan Pays High Price for Ties to Islamic Militants
abstract: Americans no longer occupy the American Embassy here. Every last diplomat left by airplane last week in a protest at what Washington says is the sanctuary that Sudan provides to some of the world's most violent terrorist groups.         The United Nations has set a late-March deadline, with the potential threat of economic sanctions, for the Sudan to surrender suspects wanted in connection  with an attempt to assassinate Egypt's President last June. The economy is already in a shambles, Sudan's relations with its neighbors are in crisis, and the country remains hobbled by a long and costly civil war.

headline: World News Briefs;As Cyprus Hijack Ends, Arms Prove to Be Fake
abstract: A Turkish waiter hoping to win sympathy for the Chechen revolt in Russia used fake weapons to hijack a Turkish Cypiot airliner to Germany but freed his hostages and gave himself up this morning.         He took over the Boeing 727 Friday evening during a flight from northern Cyprus to Istanbul and for 11 hours duped Turkish, Bulgarian and German authorities into believing three more armed hijackers were aboard.

headline: Patents;Getting a grip on those teeny-weeny cups doctors love to give you to hold your urine sample.
abstract: IT'S probably safe to say that every woman at one time or another has been handed a little plastic cup by a doctor or nurse and sent off to provide a urine sample. The specimen cups seem always to be small and awkward to handle, making  the process cumbersome and sometimes unsanitary.         Debbie Estay of Springfield, Mo., an engineering technician and frustrated visitor to doctors' offices, has devised a solution that is striking in its simplicity: a long-handled cup holder.

headline: Japanese Stocks Fall
abstract: Japanese stocks traded lower today. At the close of trading, the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 34.16 points, or .16 percent, to 21,295.82.  On Wednesday, the Nikkei gained 315.21 points.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;The N.C.A.A. basketball tourney has graduated to the ranks of major sports-marketing events.
abstract: THE ardor of advertisers to affiliate themselves with the annual tournament of the National Collegiate Athletic Association is approaching levels that might even require a repunctuation, to March? Madness!         The 58th installment of the games -- long known as March Madness for the fervor fans bring to the tournament and workers bring to the office pools -- begins tomorrow. The elimination rounds will end with the final teams battling for the championships of collegiate basketball on March 31 in Charlotte, N.C., for the women and on April 1 at the New Jersey Meadowlands for the men.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent

headline: Newbury Journal;Going Out On a Limb Over Plans For a Road
abstract: It was a typical morning at the not-yet-built Newbury bypass, the $160 million road that the British Government hopes to construct to ease the traffic  in this car-clogged town 50 miles west of London.         Dozens of workers were flattening pine trees in the woods. Hundreds of hulking security guards surrounded them, shoulder to shoulder in a military-style cordon.

headline: Israeli Opposition Chief Making Comeback
abstract: After the assassination of Yitzhak Rabin in November, it seemed there was nothing Benjamin Netanyahu could say that Israelis cared to hear.         In the grief of the moment, the very fact that Mr. Netanyahu, the leader of the conservative Likud Party, had opposed Mr. Rabin's peace policies seemed a profanation of the fallen Prime Minister's memory. Mr. Netanyahu's image as a smooth operator and slick talker made him seem unworthy compared with Mr. Rabin's old-fashioned candor and soldierly roughness.

headline: An Offering To the U.S.: The Head Of a Fugitive
abstract: For years, the authorities say, Juan Garcia Abrego was one of Mexico's billionaire drug traffickers, operating freely and shielded in his stronghold south of the Texas border by a private army and millions of dollars in monthly bribes.         So, moments after his arrest on Sunday, his first reaction was grinning defiance: he spat out an obscene phrase at the police that meant, roughly, "You'll get yours for messing with me." But on Monday when he boarded the plane  that took him to the United States for trial on charges of drug trafficking and  money laundering he grew desperate.

headline: Bank Official Saw Apparent Loan Fraud
abstract: A scheme that defrauded eight prominent international financial institutions  out of hundreds of millions of dollars for more than two years might have continued but for the efforts of an executive at the Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan, according to an affidavit submitted by an F.B.I. agent in charge of the case.         The affidavit provides the first extensive details of the unusual case, in which a former employee of the Philip Morris Companies is accused of posing as an officer of a fictional Philip Morris subsidiary to obtain more than $300 million in loans from the Signet Banking Corporation, the Nationsbank Corporation, the Long-Term Credit Bank and others.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Arianespace Plans Rise in Launchings
abstract: To meet an anticipated surge of 30 percent in international demand for satellite launchings, the European space transportation company Arianespace said yesterday that it planned to increase its activity in the coming years.          Charles Bigot, chairman of the European consortium, which already controls more than 50 percent of the world market, said Arianespace, which had 13 launchings last year, now expected to put between 65 and 70 satellites in orbit  between 1997 and 1999. The stepped-up tempo of launchings implies an extra investment of 4 billion to 5 billion francs ($816 million to $1.02 billion) over the next three years. Mr. Bigot also said that Arianespace intended to create its own finance company.   (Dow Jones)

headline: Encircled By Peril, G.I.'s Stay Nonchalant
abstract: Sgt. Stephen Kessler, 31 and a calm-eyed veteran of the Persian Gulf war, considered the concrete building to his right: a warehouse stacked with crates of ammunition that Bosnian Serb soldiers have been carting away. To his left was a loaded antiaircraft gun on a school playground.         He pointed out a ridge to the south, where the night before he saw 11 large-caliber rounds arc across the star-blotted sky.

headline: World News Briefs;Oil Pipeline in Colombia Shut by Rebels' Dynamite
abstract: Dynamite attacks by leftist rebels shut down an oil pipeline in northeastern  Colombia this week, a spokesman for the state oil company Ecopetrol said today.          He said two separate attacks on the pipeline occurred on Monday afternoon outside the city of Arauquita, 250 miles northeast of Bogota near Colombia's border with Venezuela.

headline: Discovery of Graves in Bosnia Raises Hope of Tracing Killers
abstract: The discovery of a suspected mass grave in the mountains of western Bosnia is giving Government investigators -- as well as family members of the estimated 3,000 people still missing from this valley -- increased hope that the remains of most of the slain will be found and that it will be possible to build legal cases against those who directed massacres here.         The suspected burial site, found on Wednesday, is a large natural hole in the side of a mountain where officials believe as many as 120 bodies may lie beneath a covering of stones.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;METROCALL AGREES TO ACQUIRE 2 MORE PAGING SERVICES
abstract: Metrocall Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the assets of Satellite Paging and the Message Network for $28 million in cash. The deal was announced two days after Metrocall said it would buy Parkway Paging Inc. for $28 million. Satellite Paging has about 60,000 subscribers in New York and New Jersey; Message Network has about 50,000 subscribers in Florida, and Parkway Paging has about 140,000 subscribers in Texas. Metrocall, which is based in Alexandria, Va., has more than 940,000 subscribers in the United States. Its shares rose 50 cents, to $20, in Nasdaq trading.

headline: Carlow Charged In Fraud Case
abstract: The entrepreneur Michael P. Carlow, who once owned the D. L. Clark Company, the maker of Clark candy bars, was charged today with defrauding the PNC Bank Corporation of $31 million.         United States Attorney Frederick W. Thieman said Mr. Carlow had used some of  the money to pay the debts of companies he controlled and the rest for personal  expenses.

headline: World News Briefs;Zairian Troops Surround 2d Rwandan Refugee Site
abstract: Zairian troops surrounded a second refugee camp in eastern Zaire today, stepping up pressure on the one million refugees in the country to return to Rwanda, where many fear reprisals for the 1994 genocide there.          United Nations officials said the troops were sent at dawn to the camp, Nyangazi, in the town of Bukavu, in the second phase of an operation to send the Rwandans home.

headline: In a Surprise, President of Moody's Rating Agency Resigns
abstract: In a surprise move, John A. Bohn Jr. yesterday announced his resignation as president of Moody's Investors Service Inc., one of the top credit rating agencies. Mr. Bohn will step down on April 1; no successor has been named.         Mr. Bohn's resignation comes at a time when Moody's is facing increasingly stiff competition from its larger rival, Standard & Poor's Rating Group, owned by McGraw-Hill, and just as its parent company, the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation, is being split into three new companies.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;CAPCO AGREES TO TAKEOVER AFTER HIGHER BID BY EATON
abstract: The Eaton Corporation said yesterday that it had reached an agreement to buy  the Capco Automotive Products Corporation after raising a bid to $12.50 a share, or more than $138 million. Eaton, a maker of auto parts, had previously offered  $11 a share in an unsolicited proposal that valued Capco at $122 million. Capco, which is based in South Bend, Ind., makes manual transmissions and related parts. It urged its shareholders last week not to act on the previous bid until Capco's board responded. Capco's board has approved the latest bid, which  will expire on April 15. Capco shares closed at $12.375 yesterday, up 12.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange. The shares of Eaton, which is based in Cleveland, were up 25 cents at $61.25.

headline: Tenneco to Spin Off Newport News Shipbuilding
abstract: Tenneco Inc., one of the last big industrial conglomerates, said today that it would spin off its Newport News Shipbuilding unit and that it was also considering a sale or spinoff of its energy division.
