The moves, part of a transformation that began in 1992, will allow Tenneco to focus on its growing plastics and automotive parts divisions, which each earned  the company strong profits last year.

headline: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, Feb. 24;Commerce Chief Scouts New U.S. Market: Africa
abstract: When President Jacques Chirac of France exhorted the United States not to leave Africa "in the vicious circle of exclusion" in his recent speech on Capitol Hill, it is safe to assume that what Mr. Chirac had in mind was not more visits to the continent by Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown.         Mr. Chirac's speech was consistent with a French tradition of chiding the United States for not being more generous toward sub-Saharan Africa, where France, a former colonial power, has long taken the political and commercial lead among Western nations.

headline: Seoul Frees Labor Unionist
abstract: South Korea has released on bail a labor union leader adopted as a "prisoner  of conscience" by Amnesty International, a Justice Ministry spokesman said today. The union leader, Kwon Young-kil, head of the Korea Confederation of Trade Unions, was arrested in November.          Amnesty International last month urged South Korea to release Mr. Kwon and his deputy, Yang Kyu-hun, who was arrested last month, saying it had adopted them as prisoners of conscience.

headline: Marburg Journal;Germans Discover a Joke Gap, and It's Not Funny
abstract: In a comic strip, a mysterious figure arrives at an old woman's door. His business, he explains, has to do with the tax on facial wrinkles.         The what?

headline: THE BALKAN PEACE: THE OUTLOOK;Bosnia's Checkerboard Partition: Instability More Likely
abstract: According to the Dayton peace agreement, the return of Sarajevo's largely Serbian suburbs to Government control was supposed to be an important step toward rebuilding a multi-ethnic country. But this morning, when the Bosnian police entered the last Serbian neighborhood designated to be transferred, their presence seemed instead to seal the lasting partition of Bosnia into three ethnic enclaves.         Preventing Bosnian territory from being seized by Serbs and Croats and carved up for their use had been the chief goal of the Bosnian Government, the United Nations and the West through four years of savage war. The restoration of a shared country was, on paper, the goal of the peace plan negotiated under American auspices last fall.

headline: Lord Jay, 88, Laborite Gadfly Who Defied Leaders on Europe
abstract: Lord Jay, an iconoclastic British Labor politician and former Cabinet officer who was such a fierce opponent of economic ties with Europe that he railed against Britain's entry into the Common Market even as his own Prime Minister, Harold Wilson, was aggressively campaigning for membership, died yesterday at his home in Oxfordshire. He was 88.  Known as Douglas Jay until he received a life peerage in 1987, Lord Jay was an Oxford-trained economist who worked for The Economist and other publications before entering politics.         A protege of Clement Atlee, Lord Jay served as his personal assistant when Mr. Atlee became Prime Minister in the Labor sweep of 1945.

headline: COMPANY NEWS
abstract: SWISS REINSURANCE CO., Zurich, will buy one million common shares of Enhance Financial Services Group Inc., a New York-based reinsurance company, for $24.4 million.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Weapons Industry Turns to Latin America
abstract: Of the hundreds of billions of dollars spent each year on arms and weapons worldwide, Latin America has not been among the big buyers because of its weak economies and a United States policy that restricts the sale of high-technology  military equipment.         But recent cutbacks in spending by major industrialized nations have forced military contractors to chase whatever business they can get, no matter how small, and developing countries with newly stabilized economies like those in Latin America have increasingly become the new target customers.

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Farrakhan, in Libya, Seeks to 'Unify' Muslims
abstract: Louis Farrakhan, head of the Nation of Islam, visited Libya this week to meet Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi and discussed how to "unify, mobilize and organize" American Muslims for elections in the United States this year.          Colonel Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, quoted by the state press agency, said:  "Our confrontation with America used to be like confronting a fortress from outside. Today we have found an opening to enter the fortress and to confront it from within."

headline: Texas Family Will Acquire Omni's Hotels in the U.S.
abstract: The Omni Hotels Corporation said yesterday that the Rowling family of Texas had agreed to buy its hotels in the United States from Wharf (Holdings) Ltd. of  Hong Kong for about $500 million.         The wealthy Corpus Christi family agreed through its holding company, TRT Holdings, to buy nine hotels and to get management contracts or franchise agreements for 26 others.

headline: Cairo Journal;Above the City's Din, Always the Voice of Allah
abstract: From a worn-out tape player in the back of Saad Eddin Saleh's carpentry shop, a silvery voice read out the rhythmic verses that in this din-filled city form a kind of constant chorus.         "I have two ears," Mr. Saleh said. "One for work, and one for listening to the Koran."

headline: Japanese Stocks Lower
abstract: Stock prices were lower here today. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 74.64 points, or 0.36 percent, at 20,589.20. On Friday, the index rose 249.15 points, or 1.22 percent.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;HOECHST UNIT IN PACT WITH ALLIANCE PHARMACEUTICAL
abstract: The Hoechst Marion Roussel unit of Hoechst A.G. of Germany and the Alliance Pharmaceutical Corporation entered a worldwide license agreement yesterday to develop and market Alliance's Liquivent, a drug designed to treat acute respiratory failure. Hoechst Marion will get exclusive manufacturing and worldwide marketing rights to the product in return for providing funds for development of the drug, which is in clinical trials. Hoechst Marion will pay Alliance a license fee and make certain royalty payments after the drug is brought to market. Hoechst Marion will also buy a minority-stake interest in Alliance, which is based in San Diego. The total value of the transaction was not disclosed.

headline: Jordan Marsh To Be No More
abstract: Jordan Marsh, the department store familiar to New Englanders for 145 years,  will vanish this spring and be replaced by Macy's, the name made famous in New York.         Macy's East, a division of Federated Department Stores Inc., announced the name change on Tuesday.

headline: Navy to Hunt 'Black Box' From German Tourists' Plane Crash
abstract: The Navy said here today that it had shipped equipment to the Dominican Republic to help find the flight data recorder of the Boeing 757 that crashed offshore on Tuesday night, killing all 189 people on board.         Navy officials said they had been asked to locate the so-called black box, but so far have not been asked to help retrieve it or any other parts of the wreckage. In the meantime, discussions continued about who would pay to salvage  parts of the jet.

headline: Medaphis Plans Purchase
abstract: The Medaphis Corporation agreed today to acquire Rapid Systems Solutions Inc. for stock valued at about $42.6 million. The Atlanta-based Medaphis, which provides billing and accounts-receivable services to hospitals, said it would acquire Rapid Systems' capital stock in exchange for 1.14 million Medaphis shares. Rapid Systems, which is based in Columbia, Md., is a privately held computer-network concern. Last year Rapid Systems had revenue of $14.7 million,  while Medaphis had revenue of $468 million.

headline: U.N., Facing Bankruptcy, Plans to Cut Payroll by 10%
abstract: The top financial official of the United Nations said today that the organization is sliding toward bankruptcy and will have to cut about 10 percent  of its permanent staff of more than 10,000 people at its headquarters in New York City and in seven foreign cities during the next two years.         The official, Joseph E. Connor, Under Secretary General for Administration and Management, told a General Assembly working group dealing with the financial crisis that by the end of this year the organization is expected to be about $420 million in debt for regular budget expenses alone, not counting peacekeeping operations.

headline: Serb Pledges Cooperation
abstract: Pressed by an American official's tour of suspected mass grave sites, President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia proclaimed his support today for human-rights investigations in Bosnia.         John Shattuck, the Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights, told reporters that Mr. Milosevic had said investigators would continue to receive "full cooperation." Mr. Milosevic, regarded as a prime mover in fomenting the Bosnian war, has taken on the role of peacemaker.

headline: Mexican Party Pulls Out of Talks on Political Reform
abstract: The main opposition party has embarrassed President Ernesto Zedillo by pulling out of negotiations to make Mexico's political system more democratic, charging that the Government is continuing a decades-old practice of stealing elections.         The party, National Action, announced its decision to withdraw from the talks late on Saturday. The discussions between the Government and the major political parties are intended to produce a broad reform of the electoral process by creating a genuinely independent oversight organization and limiting campaign financing, among other measures.

headline: Citibank's Records Examined As Part of Mexican Inquiry
abstract: Federal law-enforcement agencies recently subpoenaed sheaves of records from  Citibank's New York offices in an effort to assist Mexico with its investigation of Raul Salinas de Gortari, the brother of Mexico's former President, according  to Government officials and bankers.         The bank records relate to money that Mr. Salinas transferred out of Mexico through Citibank to New York, usually sending the money on to accounts in Switzerland, according to people knowledgeable about the transactions. Mexican officials said Mr. Salinas was transmitting tens of millions of dollars, even as he reported annual income of about $200,000 a year.

headline: Ex-Kmart Official Indicted in Bribery
abstract: A former Kmart Corporation executive has been charged with receiving kickbacks and bribes totaling more than $750,000 as a part of a scheme involving the sale of some Kmart properties.         Michael Dowdle, the company's director of shopping-center development and marketing until February 1993, oversaw a $170 million sale of Kmart properties to the Milwaukee developer Frank Crivello in 1991, a Federal indictment said.

headline: Polish Coalition Fails to Agree on a New Premier
abstract: The two parties in Poland's governing coalition failed today to choose a successor to Prime Minister Jozef Oleksy, who announced on Wednesday that he would resign over allegations that he had spied for Moscow.         But the leaders of the parties said that they would continue talking and that they planned to maintain their sometimes uneasy alliance.

headline: Treasury to Auction Only Bills This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.         By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 5.00 percent and a six-month bill was 5.02  percent.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;D.M.B.& B. Gains LG Group Account
abstract: The LG Group in Seoul, South Korea, which was formerly known as Lucky Goldstar, said yesterday that, as expected, it had named D'Arcy Masius Benton &  Bowles in New York as the first agency to handle its worldwide corporate advertising account. The billings were estimated at $40 million.          The agency was awarded the account after a three-month review that also included BBDO Worldwide in New York, a unit of the Omnicom Group; McCann-Erickson Worldwide in New York, owned by the Interpublic Group of Companies, and the M& C Saatchi Agency in London. LG, which has its United States headquarters in Englewood Cliffs, N.J., has interests in businesses like  electronics, telecommunications and financial services.

headline: Japanese Stocks Lower
abstract: Stocks traded lower here today. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues  was down 90.30 points, or four-tenths of 1 percent, at 20,287.62. On Thursday the Nikkei closed down 234.40 points.

headline: Clinton Signs Law Barring Some State Tax on Retirees
abstract: President Clinton signed legislation yesterday that gives a tax break to tens of thousands of people who have retired to states with no income taxes or lower  rates than the states where they lived during their working lives.         The law prohibits the states where the pensions were earned from reaching beyond their borders to tax retirees -- a practice known as source taxing.

headline: NATO to Let Bosnia Serb Army Aid Exodus
abstract: Convinced that Serbs who remain in Sarajevo's suburbs are determined to flee  rather than submit to the Muslim-dominated Government, NATO today agreed to allow the Bosnian Serb army to send trucks here to transport them out.         Relief agencies, including the United Nations High Commission for Refugees, had refused to help Serbs leave, saying doing so would be tacit support for a form of "ethnic cleansing." But NATO's commander in Bosnia, Adm. Leighton Smith, said after touring Vogosca and other suburbs that since Serbs are leaving anyway, their flight should be made as painless as possible.

headline: Oil and Technology Stocks Lead Modest Rise in Market
abstract: The stock market rose broadly yesterday, helped by a recovery in technology issues and a surge in oil shares.         The gains came on a day when Federal Reserve policy makers left short-term interest rates unchanged, as expected.

headline: Prisoner Exchange Put Off
abstract: Demanding an explanation of the fate of thousands of Muslims missing in Serbian-held parts of Bosnia, the Bosnian Government today postponed one of the  largest scheduled exchanges of prisoners of war.

headline: Silicon Graphics Reported Ready to Rescue Cray
abstract: Silicon Graphics Inc., a leader in 3-D computer work stations, will announce  today that it plans to acquire control of the struggling supercomputer maker Cray Research Inc., according to people familiar with the deal.         The talks between the two companies were initiated by Cray, these people said, because some of Cray's large government and corporate customers have expressed reluctance to continue buying multimillion-dollar computers from a company whose financial survival is in doubt.

headline: Netscape Plans Additions to Software Line
abstract: The Netscape Communications Corporation plans to introduce updated and new software this week, its co-founder, Marc Andreessen, said.         Netscape plans to cut prices on many of the server programs as part of its battle with the Microsoft Corporation, analysts said. Businesses use server software to build storefronts, for electronic commerce and mail, and to exchange information between offices.

headline: Mexico City Journal;Mexico's Robbers Diversify: Nobody's Safe Now
abstract: Amalia Garcia knew a lot about the soaring crime rate in this capital from the figures she gathered while serving as president of a Mexico City Council committee that monitors public security.         But Mrs. Garcia, a prominent politician, did not understand the full meaning  of the statistics until a robber pushed a pistol into her cheek while she was stopped in her car at a red light one sunny morning in October on a major boulevard.

headline: Rich Nations Urge Action to Cut Dangers of Lead
abstract: Industrialized nations have reached the first international agreement on measures to reduce the dangers posed by lead in the environment.         After a two-day meeting in Paris this week, the environment ministers of 26 nations committed their governments to fight the noxious effects of lead through cutting back use, tightening regulations and working with industries. The group met at the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, whose 26 member nations consume 65 percent of the world's lead.

headline: A Consumer Advocate Is Like a Fine Wine
abstract: To the Editor:         In "Consumer Crusader Feels a Chill in Washington" (Dec. 31), why bother to mention up front that Ralph Nader has a growing bald spot, that he uses a manual typewriter, or that he exhibits the "classic behavioral symptom of the old-timer: a refusal to bend to changing times"?

headline: I.B.M. to Lift Output of Hard Disk Drives
abstract: Citing a "terrific opportunity" to meet rising demand, I.B.M. said yesterday  that it would spend $500 million over the next two years to increase its production of sophisticated hard disk drives that store data in computers.         The new investment comes on top of $250 million previously earmarked for expansion and will increase the company's disk drive manufacturing capacity by 60 percent at I.B.M. plants in San Jose, Calif., and Guadalajara, Mexico, as well as in Germany, Hungary and Singapore. The money will go toward producing more 2.5-inch disk drives, which are used in many portable personal computers, as well as high-capacity 3.5-inch drives used inside large-scale systems.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;AMOCO RESOLVES DISPUTE INVOLVED IN A SALE TO POCO
abstract: Poco Petroleums Ltd. and the Amoco Canada Petroleum Company said yesterday that they had resolved a dispute with Gulf Canada Resources Ltd., clearing the way for Amoco to sell part of an Alberta oilfield to Poco by Wednesday. Earlier  this week Poco, an oil and natural gas producer, agreed to buy Amoco Canada's interest in the Swan Hills area of Alberta for $145 million (Canadian), or about $105 million (United States). But then Gulf Canada filed a motion to block the transaction, saying it had right of first refusal to the land. Under the resolution, Gulf will withdraw its motion.

headline: 200 Killed in Quake in Southwest China
abstract: A severe earthquake rocked southwestern China today, killing about 200 people in the remote mountainous region and injuring hundreds, local officials said.         "About 200 people have been killed," a county official in Lijiang, a scenic town in the mountains Yunnan Province, said by telephone.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: RENAL TREATMENT CENTERS INC., Berwyn, Pa. which provides dialysis treatment, purchased 11 dialysis centers in Oklahoma City for $16.2 million in stock.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;PARKER HANNIFIN TO BUY PNEUMO ABEX AEROSPACE UNIT
abstract: The Parker Hannifin Corporation of Cleveland said yesterday that it was buying the aerospace assets of Abex/NWL, a division of the Pneumo Abex Corporation, for $193 million in cash. Abex/NWL is an international producer of  aerospace hydraulic equipment, engine thrust-reverser actuators, hydraulic pumps and other devices. The division had sales of about $200 million in 1995, evenly  split between commercial and military sales. Abex/NWL, which is based in Kalamazoo, Mich., employs 1,290 worldwide. It will become a part of the Parker Bertea Aerospace Group.

headline: Bausch & Lomb Lens Deal
abstract: Bausch & Lomb said today that it had acquired Award P.L.C., a maker of daily-disposable soft contact lenses based in Scotland. Financial terms of the deal were not disclosed.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;PAXSON AGREES TO BUY TWO RADIO STATIONS IN FLORIDA
abstract: The Paxson Communications Corporation of West Palm Beach, Fla., said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire two Florida radio stations for about $115 million. Paxson said it would acquire WXDJ-FM in Homestead and WRMA-FM in Fort Lauderdale from New Age Broadcasting Inc. and the Seventies Broadcasting Corporation. Paxson owns and operates radio and television stations. Its shares  fell $1.25 yesterday, to $20, on the American Stock Exchange.

headline: Karoly Grosz, 65, Is Dead; Began Hungarian Reforms
abstract: Karoly Grosz, a former Hungarian Communist leader who unleashed reforms that  destroyed the system he believed in, died on Sunday. He was 65.         Mr. Grosz died of kidney cancer at home after a long illness, the official news agency M.T.I. announced today.

headline: T.W.A. Plans To Hire 2,100
abstract: Trans World Airlines Inc., which emerged from bankruptcy-law protection within the last year, said today that it planned to hire a total of 2,100 pilots, reservation sales agents and flight attendants in 1996.         The first 20 new flight attendants in two years began training today, T.W.A.  said. The airline said it planned to hire 500 flight attendants, 300 pilots and  1,300 reservation sales agents this year.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;BIRD SET ON ITS ACQUISITION BY CERTAINTEED
abstract: The Bird Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by the  Certainteed Corporation, a subsidiary of Saint-Gobain S.A., in a transaction valued about $50 million. Bird, based in Norwood, Mass., and Certainteed, of Valley Forge, Pa., are producers of asphalt roofing shingles. Saint-Gobain, of France, is a glass and building-materials group. The deal values Bird's common shares at $7.50. The shares were up $1.25 yesterday, at $7.25, in Nasdaq trading. Bird, which was founded in 1795, has annual sales of about $50 million.

headline: Bosnia Holds 8 Serbs In War Crimes Cases
abstract: The Muslim-led Bosnian Government told NATO today that it had arrested eight  Bosnian Serbs, including a general and a colonel, for investigations into suspected war crimes.    NATO said in a statement that its ground forces commander, Lieut. Gen. Michael Walker, was told of the arrests by a Bosnian Government security official, Bakir Alispahic.          Mr. Alispahic was quoted as saying that the Bosnian Government had informed  the United Nations war crimes tribunal in The Hague of the arrests and asked the tribunal to question the detainees on Tuesday.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;SPRINT NAMES EXECUTIVES FOR CELLULAR UNIT
abstract: The Sprint Corporation said yesterday that it would appoint Frank Reed as non-management chairman and Dennis Foster as president and chief executive of its Sprint Cellular subsidiary after the unit's expected spinoff early this year. Mr. Reed, 60, was president and chief executive of Corestates Philadelphia National Bank, a unit of the Corestates Financial Corporation. Mr. Foster, 65, joined Sprint as a senior vice president of operations for the company's local telecommunications division and earlier served as president of GTE Mobilenet, a  cellular subsidiary of the GTE Corporation. Sprint, the No. 3 long-distance telephone company behind AT&T and MCI Corporation, proposed the spinoff of Sprint Cellular on June 14.

headline: Citing Crackdown on Dissidents, Cuban Group Cancels Conference
abstract: A coalition of Cuban dissident and human rights groups has canceled plans to  hold a conference here this weekend, citing what they called "a wave of repression" by the state security apparatus against the organizers of the event, which would have been the first of its kind.         In a statement made available to reporters here, six of the main leaders of Concilio Cubano, as the recently formed group is known, said they canceled the conference because of "the imprisonment of numerous dissidents and acts of harassment against others."

headline: Bogota Leader Assails U.S. And May End Cooperation
abstract: In a televised address tonight, President Ernesto Samper called the United States decision to decertify Colombia as an ally in the fight against drug trafficking "deplorable," and vowed that Colombia would "re-examine and re-evaluate the terms of bilateral cooperation in the anti-drug fight."         Mr. Samper, who is battling for political survival against allegations that he solicited more than $6 million from Cali drug figures to finance his 1994 election campaign and engaged in a cover-up afterward, said that not he, but "the Government, the institutions and the Colombian people" had been "condemned" by the decision.

headline: Big Bidder Quits Wireless Auction
abstract: Another big bidder dropped out of the Federal Government's superheated auction of wireless communication licenses today.         The Go Communications Corporation of Alexandria, Va., which had bid more than $1 billion in an auction reserved for "small" companies, said it simply could not keep up with what it called exorbitant bids that reached $9.4 billion today.

headline: YOUR TAXES;Deducting Everything While You Still Can
abstract: SOME people will go to any lengths to avoid paying taxes. Lewis J. Altfest, a fee-only financial planner in Manhattan, recalls a client who insisted on investing in municipal bonds rather than higher-yielding Treasuries because the  interest was tax-free. The woman, who would have made more money buying Treasuries even after paying taxes, did not care about the lower returns -- she  wanted to owe the Government as little as possible.         "People get more satisfaction in saving on their taxes than just the amount of money," Mr. Altfest said. No matter that a fat refund check is more a symbol  of poor tax planning than of victory. "You've bested the Government," he said.

headline: Love Among the Ruins
abstract: ON Feb. 26, 1995, the day her husband helped bring down a venerable British investment bank, Lisa Leeson joined a rather exclusive sorority. Its members include Lori Milken (wife of Michael) and Seema Boesky (former wife of Ivan), part of an elite group whose husbands perpetrated spectacular feats of fraud and illegal financial manipulation.         But unlike her fellow sorority members, Lisa Leeson -- though she certainly lived well -- has never had the pleasure of enjoying the exalted life of the seriously rich. Although Nicholas W. Leeson managed to rack up more than $1 billion of losses before his bosses at Barings got wise to his scheme, his house of cards collapsed less than a month before he was to receive a bonus of nearly  $700,000.

headline: Court in Honduras Blocks Trial of Officers
abstract: A Honduran court has blocked the country's first civilian trial of military officers in connection with the killings of suspected leftists in the 1970's and 80's.         The First Appeals Court ruled late Friday that soldiers accused in the 1982 torture of six students are immune from prosecution under amnesty laws passed after the end of the Government's all-out war on suspected rebels.

headline: Corrections
abstract: A report in the Business Diary column last Sunday about earnings at brokerage firms misstated the results from trading at Salomon Inc. in the fourth quarter of 1995. Salomon had a sharp decline in profits from proprietary trading, compared with the previous quarter, but not a loss.

headline: Fidelity Deal In Britain
abstract: Fidelity Brokerage Services Inc., a British unit of the mutual fund giant FMR of Boston, said today that it was in talks to buy Hambro Clearing Ltd., the futures, options and bond clearing business of the British merchant bank Hambros P.L.C.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt * Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp., or Freddie Mac, is selling $70 million in debentures due in 2003 through Lehman Brothers. The debentures are noncallable,  carry an interest rate of 5.630 percent, paid semiannually, and are priced at par. * Federal Home Loan Bank is selling $45 million in bonds due in 2006 through First Tennessee Bank. The bonds are callable in one year, carry an interest rate of 6.730 percent, paid semiannually, and are priced at par. * Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, is selling $50 million in medium-term notes due in 2003 through First Tennessee Bank. The notes are callable in two years, carry an interest rate of 6.250 percent, paid semiannually, and are priced at par.

headline: Coming to a Theater Near You: the Latest Format War
abstract: For movie theater owners, the digital revolution is proving anything but peaceful.         Digital sound systems are bringing resonance and clarity of the quality of compact disks to movies, making it possible to hear the quiet desperation in Oliver Stone's "Nixon" and the gritty mayhem of Martin Scorsese's "Casino." One  in five American cinemas is now equipped to play digital soundtracks, and new theaters are being outfitted weekly.

headline: Retailers Call Sales in December Worst Since '90-'91 Recession
abstract: In the culmination of a dismal year for retailers that may well lead to a further industry shakeout in the next few months, the nation's merchants reported the worst December sales figures yesterday since the 1990-91 recession.         Retailers cited all sorts of reasons for poor sales, half-empty stores and indifferent shoppers, and the overall weakness among consumers suggested that the economy was likely to grow at best only slowly in the months ahead.

headline: Ruling Expands Women's Roles in the Israeli Military
abstract: The image of the Israeli Army woman, in fatigues and sometimes carrying a gun, has long been viewed around the world as a sign of equality in the only country that drafts women as well as men.         For years, the Israeli Army has touted its recruitment of women as proof of an egalitarian approach lacking in the armed forces of other nations.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;PRESSTEK CANCELS OFFERING AND SWITCHES AUDITORS
abstract: A executive of Presstek Inc. said yesterday that the company had canceled a sale of unregistered stock to international investors. "We have since canceled it," said Dick Williams, Presstek's corporate secretary. The company did not give a reason for canceling the offering, and it declined to elaborate. Shares of the printing equipment maker closed up $3.25, at $86.75, in Nasdaq trading. On Thursday, the company said it had dismissed Deloitte & Touche as its auditor. That day, its shares closed down $10.75.

headline: Apple Computer Cuts Prices on Its Performa Line
abstract: Apple Computer Inc. said today that it had reduced the prices of its Performa line of consumer-oriented Macintosh's as much as 12 percent, and broadened a rebate program on printers and monitors.         Separately, Apple said it was developing a version of Linux, a popular form of the Unix operating system, to run on the Macintosh. The company said Linux would allow scientists, students and other Unix users to run both the Macintosh  operating system and Unix on a single machine. Apple said it expected the software to be available this summer and that the company would post updates on  the World Wide Web at: http://www.mklinux.apple.com.

headline: FUTURES MARKETS;Rising Prices of Oil and Gold Drive Up Index of Commodities
abstract: Crude oil prices rose above the psychologically important level of $20 a barrel yesterday for the first time since May 1995 on reports of supply restrictions.         The gains in oil, along with rising gold prices, helped push the Commodity Research Bureau index of 17 commodities up 1.29 points, to 246.78, its highest since May 21, 1990.

headline: As Big Deal Closes, Gangsta Rap Falls Out of Its Critics' Sights
abstract: By all accounts, this ought to be a busy week for critics of media companies  and the supposedly socially corrosive products the companies purvey.         MCA Inc. is about to sign a $200 million deal to acquire 50 percent of Interscope Records, the Los Angeles label known for its hard-edged gangsta rap artists. And the latest album from one of Interscope's hardest-edged rappers, Tupac Shakur, is likely to be No. 1 on the charts when Billboard magazine hits the newsstand on Wednesday.

headline: Big Board's Profits Climb
abstract: The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that it had income of $56.7 million last year, nearly 29 percent higher that the $44 million it earned the previous year. Revenues were $500.8 million, about 11 percent higher than the $452.3 million in 1994. For the fourth quarter, the exchange had profits of $13.5 million on revenues of $136.1 million, compared with earnings of $1.4 million on $114.7 million a year earlier.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Taiheiyo Bank of Japan to Be Liquidated
abstract: Four Japanese banks have agreed to liquidate the ailing Taiheiyo Bank and establish a new bank to take over its operations, the Finance Ministry announced today.         Taiheiyo holds $2.7 billion in nonperforming loans, including about $1.6 billion deemed irrecoverable, said Yoshimasa Nishimura, head of the ministry's banking bureau.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;CBS Executive Chosen to Head NBC's All-News Cable Channel
abstract: NBC yesterday appointed Mark Harrington, a longtime CBS executive, to be vice president and general manager of its new all-news cable network, currently called MSNBC.         The channel, which could be operating as early as July and may be renamed, is a co-venture between NBC and the Microsoft Corporation. Mr. Harrington will report to Andrew Lack, the president of NBC News, who is in charge of MSNBC.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Top Honors For Ogilvy Direct
abstract: For the fifth consecutive year, Ogilvy & Mather Direct, a unit of the WPP Group, took top honors from the judges of the John Caples International Awards for excellence in direct marketing. At the 18th annual ceremony last week in New York, the Ogilvy Direct offices in Malaysia, New York, New Zealand and Singapore won 8 of 59 prizes in 20 categories. Rapp Collins Worldwide, a unit of the Omnicom Group, followed with five awards.          Andrew Cohen, president and chief executive of Direct Resources International in New York, was presented the Irving Wunderman Award for his creative work. And Lee Epstein, chairman of Mailmen Inc. in New York and a co-founder of the annual conference known as Direct Marketing Day in New York, was presented the Andi Emerson Award for service to creativity.

headline: After 3-Year Wait, Arms Pact Wins Senate Backing but Faces New RussianOpposition
abstract: Today, three years after President Bush and President Boris N. Yeltsin signed a major strategic arms reduction treaty, Start II, the Senate approved it, 87 to 4.         But the treaty, which would cut the number of nuclear warheads held by both countries by 50 percent, may be dead, some senior American officials fear. The current Russian legislature, elected on Dec. 17, is significantly more opposed to Mr. Yeltsin than the old one, and it may prove impossible to get the necessary votes there to approve the treaty as written.

headline: Rig Count Drops by 10
abstract: The number of oil and gas rigs operating in the United States dropped by 10 last week, to 693, Baker Hughes Inc. said. There were 724 rigs operating nationwide during the corresponding week a year ago. Of the rigs running last week, 389 were exploring for natural gas and 295 for oil. Nine rigs were listed  as miscellaneous. The rig count represents the number of rigs actively exploring for oil and natural gas.

headline: SAP America President to Run New Company
abstract: Klaus P. Besier, the man credited with fueling SAP America Inc.'s phenomenal  growth over the last two years, is stepping down as president and chief executive to lead a hot Internet software company called Business         Mr. Besier said SAP America was entering into a partnership with Business @ Web to develop products for doing business on the Internet. Mr. Besier said that SAP America was exploring an equity investment in Business @ Web and added that  his new company, in Cambridge, Mass., would be going public "sooner than later."

headline: America's Small-Town Team;Packers Play for Touchdown Not for Profits
abstract: Most football fans know who owns the Dallas Cowboys -- the ultra-aggressive Jerry Jones, a one-time oil wildcatter who bought the team and Texas Stadium for $140 million in 1989, hired and then fell out with Jimmy Johnson as his coach, won two Super Bowls and stars in Pizza Hut commercials with Deion Sanders.         Now, name the Green Bay Packers' owner. You can't. There are too many.

headline: Easing Is Urged On Encryption
abstract: The Commerce Department will recommend easing export controls on encryption software after a study by the department and the National Security Agency found  that American companies are being hurt, Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown said  last week.         Such a move may pit Mr. Brown against the military and intelligence agencies, setting the stage for a White House battle over one of the last computer technologies still covered by export controls.

headline: Mexicans Tire of Police Graft as Drug Lords Raise Stakes
abstract: Last week officers from an elite police anti-narcotics unit seized Rogelio Hernandez, 32, a motorcycle repairman, and drove him to the home of a cocaine trafficker, where they beat and threatened him as the trafficker demanded payment of a debt.         But Mr. Hernandez's large family -- he has 102 siblings and cousins -- protested quickly and loudly, with the result that state and federal police and  even a truckload of soldiers rushed to the trafficker's home to rescue Mr. Hernandez.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: CORT BUSINESS SERVICES CORP., agreed to acquire Evans Rents for $27 million. Both companies are furniture rental concerns.

headline: Micron Offers No Insight On Chief's Exit and Return
abstract: Hundreds of shareholders and employees packed the convention center here today, drawn by the corporate soap opera that has captivated both locals and Wall Street: Why did Steve Appleton, chief executive of Micron Technology Inc.,  return to his job on Friday, just a week after resigning?         Even the local paper, The Idaho Statesman, urged the company, which is the largest corporate taxpayer in the area, to give an explanation. But at the meeting, Mr. Appleton and the board were mum.

headline: This Model Was Too Rough;Why Economic Forecasting Became a Sideshow
abstract: Want to know what I.B.M.'s in-house economist thinks is in store for the American economy in 1996? You're out of luck: the giant computer maker, which counted more than two dozen economists on its payroll in the early 1970's, no longer employs a single professional to estimate key numbers like interest rates, capital spending and inflation.         And the International Business Machines Corporation has lots of company. Dozens of other big corporations have either slashed or eliminated their forecasting staffs and signed up with commercial services to do their crystal gazing for them. "It's more economical," said Bruce Bunch, a spokesman for the General Electric Company, a conglomerate with $60 billion in annual sales -- and no in-house economist.

headline: Kagga Kamma Journal;Endangered Bushmen Find Refuge in a Game Park
abstract: It is 10 A.M. and, breakfast over, the tourists are waiting for the morning's activity. A young boy pulls on the arm of a guide here and asks impatiently:         "Where are the Bushmen babies? I want to see the Bushmen babies."

headline: A Tejano Singer Sets Out To Bridge Music and Nations
abstract: If millions of Anglos are ever going to love country music performed by a Mexican-American Tejano star, first a couple of dozen of them filming a music video are going to have to learn Emilio Navaira's sly, hip-swiveling stage turn -- known to his Hispanic fans as the Emilio Shuffle.         Record company executives and corporate sponsors are betting that Emilio, as  he calls himself, can fulfill the promise of the late Selena by becoming the first Tex-Mex musician singing in both Spanish and English to capture nationwide audiences in Mexico and the United States.

headline: MARKET TIMING
abstract: Sunday

headline: Kohlberg Kravis Group Set To Trim Stake in Safeway
abstract: A Kohlberg Kravis Roberts group said today that it planned to cut its stake in Safeway Inc. by selling stock in a secondary offering.         KKR Associates, led by Henry Kravis, will cut its stake in Safeway, a grocery store company, to 53.4 percent from 61 percent by selling 16.25 million shares, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;CHAIRMAN RESIGNS AT MICRON TECHNOLOGY
abstract: Micron Technology Inc. of Boise Idaho, a leading chip maker, said yesterday that Steve Appleton had resigned as chairman, chief executive, president and director, a little more than a year after he assumed control. Mr. Appleton was replaced by Tyler Lowrey, formerly the vice chairman and chief technical officer. Mr. Appleton's resignation comes after Micron shares skidded 66 percent from a high of $94.375 in September as prices fell for the company's dynamic random access memory chips. Micron shares closed at $32, down 25 cents, yesterday. Mr. Appleton was named chairman in September 1994 after Micron's biggest shareholder, the Idaho potato magnate J. R. Simplot, grew disenchanted with previous management's cautious approach to expansion.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS;Refunding Dominates Trading
abstract: Treasury prices were mixed yesterday as the market is facing the task of absorbing a huge supply of new debt securities this week.         With market participants wondering if investor demand will be weak at this week's quarterly sales by the Treasury, primary dealers -- securities firms required to bid at all Government sales -- were setting up and busy discounting prices as they often do to raise yields and try to insure that the securities will be attractive to investors.

headline: 2 Blasts Hit Nigeria Soon After Air Crash
abstract: Separate explosions have shaken an airport and a hotel in Nigeria, just days  after a group claimed it had sabotaged a plane that crashed on Wednesday, killing a son of the country's military ruler.         Reporters said an explosion, possibly caused by a bomb, occurred today at the airport in Kano, in the north. No one was killed.

headline: U.S. Doctors Aid Rwanda War-Crime Panel
abstract: To bolster the Rwanda war crimes tribunal, volunteers led by an American physicians' organization is to exhume bodies from mass graves over the next three weeks and conduct autopsies to gather evidence of massacres that left hundreds of thousands of Rwandans dead in 1994, the group said today.         The organization, Physicians for Human Rights, is also preparing to send forensic teams to possible mass graves in Serb-controlled areas of Bosnia and Herzegovina as soon as sites become accessible, said Susannah Sirkin, acting executive director.

headline: Russians Set a Deadline
abstract: Russia today gave Chechen rebels a Sunday morning deadline to release more than 100 hostages but offered them safe passage home if they freed their captives and gave up their weapons.         Mikhail Barsukov, director of the Federal Security Service, told Interfax and Itar-Tass news agencies that the guerrillas had been given until 10 A.M. Sunday  (2 A.M. Eastern time) to free their captives in this southern Russian village.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Sandoz and Ciba Of Switzerland to Merge Sandoz and Ciba agreed to merge, subject to shareholder approval, forming a new  company, Novartis, "based on the concept of a merger among equals."

headline: Merrill Lynch Quits Russian Treasury Bill Deal
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Company has dropped out of a planned offering of $500 million of Russian treasury bills to foreign investors, a senior Russian central bank official said today.         The collapse of talks between the brokerage firm and the central bank came two days after the Russian Government canceled a bill auction that would have been part of the offering as Merrill Lynch backed out for the second consecutive week.

headline: Washington Post Purchase
abstract: The Washington Post Company said its Post-Newsweek Cable subsidiary had acquired the Columbus Television Cable Corporation of Mississippi for about $23  million in cash and stock. The company, which publishes The Washington Post and  Newsweek magazine, said Columbus Television Cable served about 15,700 subscribers in Columbus, Miss. With the purchase, Post-Newsweek has about 554,700 subscribers in 16 states.

headline: Offering by Fort Howard
abstract: The Fort Howard Corporation, a paper products maker, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the sale of 16 million common shares. The company, based in Green Bay, Wis., said it would sell the stock at the market price at the time of the offering.

headline: No Sign of Shift in Talks on Apple-Sun Merger
abstract: If anyone thinks a deal is imminent between Apple Computer and Sun Microsystems, Scott McNealy, chief executive of Sun, is apparently not among them. He is planning to spend Saturday and Sunday in Monterey, Calif., playing in the AT&T Pro-Am golf tournament.         Rumors continued to fly yesterday that a merger of Apple and Sun would happen, including a report by Bloomberg Business News that the companies would announce a deal after the stock market closed. They did not.

headline: Some Hedge Funds Are Hurt By a Rise in Interest Rates
abstract: Several big hedge funds, which invest billions of dollars for the wealthy, have lost money in recent days as long-term interest rates have risen unexpectedly. As a result, some of these swashbuckling investment firms have given up the sizable profits they made in January, and in some cases have even registered losses, traders and analysts said.         In general, hedge fund managers seem to be sticking to their positions, expecting the earlier market trends to reassert themselves. Still, the setbacks  for many big funds have contributed to the tone of uncertainty and volatility in the markets.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                                               Previous      Year                               Yesterday       Day       Ago

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt

headline: Apple to Close Its On-Line Unit
abstract: Apple Computer Inc. has decided to discontinue its once-heralded on-line service, eWorld, on March 31.         The move was announced yesterday in a memorandum to publishers on the service. Apple had said late last year that it planned to increase its presence  on the Internet's World Wide Web but had not yet decided whether or how to mesh its on-line service into that effort.

headline: Killings Tied to Drugs Delay Return of Mediators to Ulster
abstract: The international commission set up to deal with the disarmament of the Irish Republican Army has delayed its return to Ireland, apparently because of a recent resurgence of violence in Northern Ireland.         The new spate of killings, attributed by most officials to the overwhelmingly Catholic I.R.A., has thrown the Northern Ireland peace effort into doubt. The disarmament commission, headed by former Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, had been scheduled to return by the end of last week to continue its work toward a compromise of the dispute that has impeded for months the start of full-fledged peace negotiations involving Sinn Fein, the political wing of the I.R.A., which waged a 25-year campaign of violence to end British rule in Northern Ireland; the British and Irish Governments, and other parties in Northern Ireland.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;BAXTER TO DISTRIBUTE DEVICE USED IN BYPASS SURGERY
abstract: The Baxter Healthcare Corporation has agreed to distribute exclusively a synthetic coronary artery graft made by Possis Medical Inc., Possis said yesterday. The shares of Possis, a maker of cardiovascular surgery products that is based in Minneapolis, rose $1.75, or 12 percent, to close at $16.25 yesterday in Nasdaq trading. Baxter Healthcare, a unit of Baxter International Inc., will  make an initial cash payment to Possis, followed by further cash payments in the next three years to help pay for clinical trials. The amount of the payments was not disclosed. Possis said the device, called Perma-Flow Coronary Bypass Graft, was a synthetic tube used to bypass a blocked coronary artery during heart bypass surgery. Baxter Healthcare and Baxter International are based in Deerfield, Ill.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;BRADLEES TO CLOSE 12 DEPARTMENT STORES
abstract: Bradlees Inc., a discount retailer operating under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, said yesterday that it would close 12 stores by May. The company, which is based in Braintree, Mass., operates more than 100 department stores in  the Northeast. Bradlees said this month that it would consolidate the management positions at its stores and eliminate 450 jobs in an effort to save $19 million  a year. The stores to be closed are in Maine, Massachusetts, Connecticut, New York and New Jersey.

headline: Making the Shoe Fit, Perfectly;Companies Use Technology to Sell to a Market of One
abstract: When the Custom Foot shoe store opens its doors in Westport, Conn., for the first time tomorrow, it may be hard to judge how business is going: even shoppers making a purchase will be leaving empty-handed.         That's because this is a shoe store without shoes. Well, not exactly -- the store can draw on a potential inventory of more than 10 million pairs, with every style in every possible size. It's just that none of them have been made yet.

headline: Stocks Are Little Changed, With Dow Gaining by 3.97
abstract: Stocks were little changed yesterday in quiet trading.         Analysts attributed the trendless market to uncertainty as to whether economic growth would be damaged by higher interest rates. As it did on Wednesday, when stocks fell sharply, the stock market took its cues from bonds,  which slumped for a second day.

headline: Asa Herzog, 92, Chief Judge In Bankruptcy Court, Is Dead
abstract: Asa S. Herzog, a former chief United States judge in the nation's busiest bankruptcy court, in the Southern District of New York, died on Sunday at his home in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 92.         Thanks to his central position, the length of his tenure and his authorship of the standard text on bankruptcy during the years when the number and complexity of bankruptcies were increasing, Judge Herzog was widely regarded as  the dean of the nation's bankruptcy judges. His judicial tenure spanned 1958 to  1975, when he retired.

headline: Market Place;Deere seems poised to ride positive trends in farming.
abstract: AFTER nearly a decade of the blues in the heartland, there's a lot of optimism rising along with the corn and wheat in the Midwest. Commodity prices are climbing, as is demand for American grain exports. Farm income is going up.  And legislation making its way through Congress promises to bring more acreage under cultivation and more dollars into farmers' pockets.         All these factors are lifting the share price of Deere & Company, the world's largest maker of farm equipment. Deere, with $10 billion in sales, is an unusually sophisticated company: Its corporate headquarters, just off a cornfield in Moline, Ill., is an architectural masterpiece designed by Eero Saarinen, with an impressive art collection and swans fluttering in the corporate pond. Right after World War II, the company saw the trend toward larger farms and designed bigger equipment to match -- a move that pushed Deere  into the No. 1 position, where it has since remained.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;YAHOO INTERNET SERVICE PLAS A PUBLIC STOCK OFFERING
abstract: Yahoo, which operates one of the most popular directories on the World Wide Web of the Internet, announced yesterday that it would sell shares to the public for the first time. The initial public offering would be the latest in a flurry  of sales by Internet-related companies over the last year. In a filing with the  Securities and Exchange Commission, Yahoo said that it would offer 2.6 million shares and that it expected the price to be $10 to $12 a share. Yahoo was incorporated only last April. Yahoo's directory makes Web browsing easier, and the service has more than 800,000 users a day.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;RALSTON PURINA TO SPIN OFF ANIMAL FEED UNIT
abstract: The Ralston Purina Company said yesterday that it planned to split its international animal feed business into a separate company, reflecting its desire to focus on selling pet food and Eveready batteries to consumers. Ralston sold its domestic animal feed business in 1986. The international segment had sales of $1.12 billion and earnings from operations of $45.2 million last year.  The St. Louis-based Ralston said the spinoff might take up to a year to complete and was contingent upon a favorable tax ruling and final approval by Ralston's board. The transaction is meant to be tax free to current shareholders.

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;General Elections in India Are Set for April and May
abstract: India will hold general elections on four days starting in six weeks, election officials said today.         The announcement by the federal election commission of voting for April 27 and May 2, 7 and 21 kicks off an election process involving nearly 590 million voters. It came after weeks of speculation about the timing of the vote, which will decide the future of Prime Minister P. V. Narasimha Rao's Government.

headline: Poultry-Producer Shares Climb as Russia Ends Plan for a Ban
abstract: Shares of Tyson Foods Inc. and other poultry producers rose yesterday after Russia promised not to bar imports of chickens from the United States.         Stock of Tyson, of Springdale, Ark., the world's largest poultry processor, rose 50 cents, to $22.75, in heavy Nasdaq trading. Shares of Hudson Foods Inc. of Rogers, Ark., rose $1.125, to $15, on the New York Stock Exchange, and shares of the Pilgrim's Pride Corporation of Pittsburg, Tex., climbed 25 cents, to $7, on the Big Board.

headline: Dutch Concern to Acquire Stop and Shop Chain
abstract: Royal Ahold N.V., the big Dutch grocery retailer, said yesterday that it had  agreed to buy the Stop and Shop Companies, the largest supermarket chain in New  England, for $1.8 billion in cash.         The deal would make Royal Ahold, which posted revenues of $18 billion last year, the fifth-largest supermarket chain in the United States and the biggest food retailer east of the Mississippi River.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Listed below are the tentative release dates for major economic indicators this week. Some reports were delayed by last month's partial shutdown of the Government.      Monday

headline: THE MARKET'S STUMBLE;Bond Futures Push a Bit Lower in Chicago
abstract: Government bond futures pushed lower in Chicago last night, as a new round of Japanese dealer-led selling hit the market. United States bonds also fell in trading in Asia earlier today, and most Pacific stock markets closed down as well.         The price of the June Treasury bond futures contract pushed more than three quarters of a point and closed the Sunday session down 26/32, and ended at 110 5/32,the Dow Jones News Service reported.

headline: Decoded Cables Depict Big Wartime Soviet Spy Ring in U.S.
abstract: Decoded fragments of cables from Soviet spies in New York and Washington during World War II indicate the Soviets had contacts throughout the United States, including within the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the military and the chief American intelligence agency, according to documents made public today.         The documents depict a ring of more than 100 wartime spies who reported to Moscow on their contacts with atomic scientists, journalists and American intelligence officers. They reported from within the Office of Strategic Services, the precursor of the Central Intelligence Agency, and the War Department, the precursor of the Pentagon.

headline: Taking In the Sites;A Virtually Balanced Budget
abstract: Anyone who has taken the time to follow the budget impasse between Democrats  and Republicans in the nation's capital may secretly believe that he or she could resolve matters in minutes, if only given the chance.         On the Internet's World Wide Web, such armchair critics can indulge their Capraesque fantasies without having to follow Mr. Smith to Washington or wading through the arcana of foot-thick budget proposals. A computer model called the National Budget Simulation allows browsers to emulate the budget negotiators; all they have to do is point and click with their computer mouse.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;New Lloyd's Plan Backed by Britain
abstract: The British Government gave conditional authorization today to Lloyd's of London's proposals to transfer its old liabilities to a new reinsurance company  known as Equitas.         Equitas is a cornerstone of the 300-year-old market's ambitious reconstruction and renewal plan to put its recent troubled past behind it. Lloyd's has already seen losses of more than L8 billion ($12.2 billion).

headline: Supply-and-Demand Balance Weakens for Semiconductors
abstract: The semiconductor industry's leading indicator fell sharply in January, a trade organization reported today, providing a disturbing sign that the demand for computer chips is growing more slowly than the supply.         That news is likely to put pressure on technology stocks and could lead to a  big selloff on Tuesday.

headline: David M. Gordon, 51, a Leader Among Left-Wing Economists
abstract: David M. Gordon, a leader of leftist economic thought and a professor at the  New School for Social Research in New York, died on Saturday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 51 and lived in Manhattan.         The cause was heart failure, his family said. He had been awaiting a heart transplant.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;French Cut Key Rate
abstract: The Bank of France cut its intervention rate yesterday to 3.90 percent from 4.05 percent, and economists said more rate cuts looked certain. The independent central bank left unchanged at 5.60 percent the 5-to-10-day lending rate, which  sets the ceiling for money market operations. The bank last cut official rates Feb. 1, when it lowered the intervention rate, the floor for money market operations, to 4.05 percent from 4.20 percent. The Government is counting on lower interest rates to help revive flagging economic growth.   (Reuters)

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings this week:

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Britain, in a Surprise, Cuts Interest Rates
abstract: The Bank of England unexpectedly cut the cost of borrowing yesterday by a-quarter of a percentage point. The central bank pushed its base lending rate down to 6.25 percent from 6.5 percent, creating an identical cut in the minimum  lending rates charged by the nation's commercial banks. The reduction lowered the base rate to its level at the end of 1994 and rallied the stock market. British shares soared to a record high, with the Financial Times-Stock Exchange  index of 100 issues gaining 44.5 points to close at 3,748.7.          The rate cut followed a quarter-point cut in the lending fee on Dec. 13. In  Paris, the Bank of France reduced two rates as evidence grew that the French economy was slowing.   Bloomberg Business News

headline: A Struggle to Save a Shattered Legacy
abstract: The Rev. Marko Malovic, dressed in a brown Franciscan habit, parked his stocky frame in front of the semicircular wooden bookshelves that spiraled up along the heavy stone wall of a medieval church tower.         He took an 18th-century prayer book, its ornate Latin calligraphy bright and  crisp, opened it gently to the prayers for Epiphany and lovingly leafed through  the oversized pages.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;KODAK IN TALKS TO BUY CHINESE PHOTO COMPANIES
abstract: The Eastman Kodak Company is negotiating to buy controlling stakes in China's three biggest makers of photographic film, executives at two of the companies said yesterday. The Chinese companies under consideration by Kodak are the Henan Baoding Photographic Film Company, the Xiamen Fuda Photographic Materials Company and the Shantou Era Photo Materials Industry Corporation, said Ling Gang, a manager at Xiamen Fuda. The move would allow the Rochester company to bypass China's high import duties and gain broader distribution in China.  A Kodak spokesman, Charlie Smith, said the company had been in discussions with Chinese Government officials and photo executives.

headline: Kimana Tikondo Group Ranch Journal;Warily, the Masai Embrace the Animal Kingdom
abstract: There is no love lost between Marika Lonkoijoo, a 24-year-old Masai, and the  elephants who ramble at night through his farm on the dusty range beneath Mount  Kilimanjaro and feast on his tomatoes, onions and corn.         Tourists flood into nearby Amboseli National Park to see the huge beasts, but to farmers like Mr. Lonkoijoo they are a destructive and sometimes deadly menace. "When these animals come," he said, "they just eat everything. There is  nothing you can do."

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;China Drafting Rules On Internet Links
abstract: China's State Council, striving to embrace the Internet but not its pornographic and political content, adopted unspecified draft rules yesterday governing links to overseas computer information networks. In an executive meeting led by Prime Minister Li Peng, the council reiterated its provisional approval for global computer links, the official New China News Agency reported.          Officials declined to provide a copy of the draft rules or disclose their contents. Chinese insiders have said the rules will probably set limits on which organizations can offer public Internet access, order the screening of who can secure such access, and try to mandate the use of technology to filter out offensive materials.   (Reuters)

headline: MARKET WATCH;In Soap And Stock, Revlon Cuts Prices
abstract: Sometimes you should take what you can get, even if it's not what you hoped for.         Ron Perelman is trying again to persuade investors to buy stock in Revlon, the cosmetics and personal-care company he has been running since winning a bitterly fought takeover battle a decade ago.

headline: Business Travel;Donald Trump and the Pritzkers are giving the Grand Hyatt a face lift.
abstract: IN 1980, Donald Trump helped initiate a decade of glitz when he sheathed the  aging, brick-walled Commodore Hotel in glass and joined with the prosperous Pritzkers of Chicago, owners of the Hyatt chain, to give it a new name -- Grand  Hyatt -- as well as new management.         Now the partners are at it again, fluffing up their successful venture with new pillows, beds, curtains and all that other good stuff business travelers love, from work desks and posture chairs to fax machines and laptop ports. There will even be refrigerators in every room. The new and improved Grand Hyatt will  also feature a penthouse health club with skyscraper views -- a welcome addition for weary business travelers and talked-out meeting-goers who make up about 80 percent of the hotel's clientele.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;4th-Quarter Comeback For I.B.M.
abstract: Delivering some welcome news to edgy technology investors, I.B.M. reported a  39 percent increase in fourth-quarter earnings yesterday, surpassing Wall Street forecasts and sparking a rally in its stock price.         The results seemed to allay concerns about the International Business Machines Corporation's future that had been growing since last summer. Its stock price had been depressed by disappointing earnings, product delays, and fears that its $3.5 billion purchase of the Lotus Development Corporation was a  mistake.

headline: Last Days of Mitterrand
abstract: The former President, Francois Mitterrand, ended his own life by halting the  drug treatment against the cancer that killed him, friends and associates said today.         "A few days before his death, he told me, 'Now I have my philosophy,' " Roland Dumas, a close friend of Mr. Mitterrand and a former Foreign Minister, said on television.

headline: Nasdaq Reports a Decline In Uncovered Short Sales
abstract: In the largest decline since January 1995, the number of open positions of short sales on the Nasdaq market fell 3.8 percent in the month that ended on Jan. 12, the National Association of Securities Dealers reported yesterday.         The short position in Nasdaq shares, which represented trading that took place from Dec. 18, 1995, through Jan. 9 and was settled as of Jan. 12, totaled  887.2 million shares. That compared with 921.2 million in the period that ended on Dec. 15.

headline: Church Bombings Worry Nicaragua as Papal Visit Nears
abstract: The first of the church bombings took place last May, rattling the nerves of  the faithful and reviving memories of a decade of violence. Since then, 18 Roman Catholic churches in Nicaragua have fallen victim to attacks with explosives, most recently on Christmas Eve and New Year's Day.         No one has been killed in the unsolved wave of bombings, but with Pope John Paul II scheduled to visit early next month, a sense of crisis is building.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;BOSTON SCIENTIFIC TO BUY SYMBIOSIS FOR $153 MILLION
abstract: The Boston Scientific Corporation said yesterday that it had signed a definitive agreement to acquire the Symbiosis Corporation, a unit of the American Home Products Corporation, for about $153 million in cash, subject to regulatory approval. Symbiosis produces specialty medical devices. Boston Scientific's Microvasive Endoscopy division is a client. Boston Scientific, also a maker of medical devices, said it expected the acquisition to bring "important strategic and economic synergies." Shares of Boston Scientific rose $2.50 yesterday, to $49.50, while shares of American Home Products rose $2.50, to $98.625.

headline: Russian Diplomacy Gets a Wily Spy and Survivor
abstract: A month after American-led forces defeated Iraq in the Persian Gulf war, Yevgeny M. Primakov, then a top adviser to Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the last Soviet leader, published a dashing account of his last-ditch efforts to broker a face-saving solution for Saddam Hussein in February 1991 and prevent the ground  war.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Brunswick Selects Fallon McElligott
abstract: The Mercury Marine division of the Brunswick Corporation in Fond du Lac, Wis., yesterday named Fallon McElligott in Minneapolis to handle advertising and integrated-marketing assignments, which had been awarded only three months ago to Cramer-Krasselt in Milwaukee. Billings were estimated last year at $4 million, but Brunswick said they were expected to grow in 1996 to an estimated $20 million. The decision came after a review that included another finalist, Carmichael Lynch in Minneapolis.

headline: Irish Nationalists Starting to Agree Among Themselves
abstract: Gerry Adams and John Hume, the two most influential Roman Catholic political  leaders in Northern Ireland, said today that they had met with Irish Republican  Army officials on Wednesday and had come away with the impression that the group would restore the cease-fire it ended on Feb. 9.         Mr. Adams, the president of the I.R.A.'s political wing, Sein Fein, and Mr. Hume, the head of the mainstream Social Democratic and Labor Party, said they did not press for a firm commitment and got no such guarantee. But Mr. Hume said they had made it clear that they wanted "the restoration of the peace process and a cessation of violence."

headline: Two Exchanges Post Drops In Uncovered Short Sales
abstract: Open positions of short sales decreased on the New York Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange in the most recent period, the exchanges reported yesterday.         Short interest on the New York exchange fell to 1.9 billion shares from two billion shares in the month ending Jan. 12, reflecting settlement of trades through Jan. 9. On Jan. 12, short interest was equal to 1.3 percent of all shares on the exchange.

headline: Chechen Rebels Release 46 Of the 90 Hostages They Held
abstract: Chechen rebels today released 46 of the hostages they had seized in a raid this month in a neighboring republic that touched off a prolonged siege and humiliated the Russian Government and military.         The Chechens continued to hold 14 Russian policemen taken after the raid on Jan. 9 in neighboring Dagestan.

headline: World News Briefs;Iraqis, After a Standoff, Yield on Arms Inspection
abstract: After a tense all-night standoff, Iraq has admitted a team of United Nations  arms experts to a building they suspect contains documents about Iraq's arms programs, a senior United Nations official said today.         The group was permitted to begin an inspection under limitations governing the size of the team entering the building, said Charles Duelfer, deputy chairman of the United Nations Special Commission.

headline: World News Briefs;Demonstrators in Belarus Oppose Tie With Russia
abstract: About 15,000 people, many waving red-and-white Belarussian flags, marched through downtown Minsk today to demand continued independence and protest Government moves to form a political, cultural and economic union with Russia.         At one point, demonstrators shouting anti-Government slogans broke through a  police cordon. Scuffles broke out between the police and marchers who pelted them with snow and ice.

headline: High-Level Graft Case Rocks India's Political Establishment
abstract: Introducing new uncertainties into Indian politics only three months before a general election, prosecutors have taken the lid off a multimillion-dollar payoff scandal that has embroiled dozens of high-ranking politicians and civil servants, including prominent figures in all three major political parties.         In the last week, the scandal has produced a wave of corruption charges against some of India's best-known politicians, and forced the resignation of three senior ministers from the Government of Prime Minister P. V. Narasimha Rao.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: AT&T to Offer Customers Free Internet Access AT&T, pushing aggressively into the Internet business, said it would offer its telephone customers five hours of free Internet access each month for a year.

headline: Dialing the Rabbi
abstract: To the Editor:         Having recently served on a rabbinical search committee for our Conservative  synagogue and being aware of the round-the-clock duties of a rabbi to his congregation, I was surprised that Rabbi Radler would have the time for an extracurricular vocation.

headline: Stocks Plunge In Japan
abstract: Stocks fell sharply here today, amid concern, traders said, that a declining  dollar would hurt profits of electronics exporters and fears that higher interest rates could strangle a budding recovery.          The Nikkei index of 225 issues closed down 479.87 points, or 2.34 percent, at 20,000.40. Just before the close, the index fell below the psychologically important 20,00-point level. On Monday, the Nikkei rose 179.89 points.

headline: China Cited for Abuses
abstract: The Clinton Administration issued its annual human rights report, finding China guilty of "widespread and well-documented" abuses. Page A10.

headline: Unexpectedly, Kohl Coalition Gets Lift From State Elections
abstract: Against the odds suggested by rising unemployment and economic slowdown, Chancellor Helmut Kohl won a major boost today from three state elections that were cast as clues to the midterm fortunes of his coalition, according to early  projections.         Significantly the Free Democrats -- junior partners in the coalition -- increased their share of the ballots in all three elections, defying forecasts of another disaster after many defeats. And the opposition Social Democrats suffered major setbacks compared with the last balloting in 1992.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;'Pepsi Stuff' Campaign Set
abstract: The Pepsi-Cola Company announced yesterday that it would introduce "Pepsi Stuff," which it called the largest promotional campaign in the company's history.         By buying Pepsi merchandise, customers will be able to accumulate "points" to buy products like T-shirts, hats, denim and leather jackets, bags and mountain bikes. The total value of the merchandise is $125 million, the company said.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;DALLAS UTILITY SEEKS TO LEASE ITS UNDERGROUND CABLES
abstract: The Central and South West Corporation of Dallas said yesterday that it had filed with Federal regulators to enter the telecommunications market, making it  the first public utility seeking to take advantage of the new law opening the telecommunications industry to competition. The Federal Communications Commission has 60 days to act on the plan, which would open portions of the company's fiber optic and cable network to providers of telephone, Internet, cable television and other services. The underground lines now connect the company's computers with customer monitoring devices.

headline: Dagana Journal;Where Proud Moors Rule, Blacks Are Outcasts
abstract: Gazing across the broad blue expanse of the Senegal River into Mauritania, Alassane Watt, a stubble-bearded 72-year-old farmer, recently saw for himself what neighbors had been telling him about for months.         Just perceptible, at a bend in the river's far bank, a tractor was making a clearing where his animals once grazed. Where palm trees had shielded against the ferocious heat of the desert's edge, he could make out the roof of a house built by strangers on land that had been his.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;NatWest Bids $713 Million for Gartmore
abstract: National Westminster, the big British banking group, offered L466 million, or $713 million, today for Gartmore, one of the nation's fastest-growing asset-management companies.         Buying Gartmore would take National Westminster a considerable way toward plugging what analysts regard as a significant gap -- the lack of an active fund-management effort -- in NatWest's broader ambition to become a comprehensive financial services company with businesses ranging from its core commercial banking operations to investment banking and asset management.

headline: Stocks Higher in Tokyo
abstract: Stocks traded higher here today. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 111.03 points, or half of 1 percent, to 21,406.85. On Thursday, the Nikkei lost 34.16 points.

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;British Balloonists Delay Round-the-World Try
abstract: A British team of aeronauts who had hoped to make the first nonstop manned balloon flight around the world announced yesterday that unfavorable weather had forced them to postpone the attempt until October. The delay marked the end of a planned three-way race, from which the other two competitors -- a Dutch and an American balloonist -- had already dropped out.         The British balloon, the Virgin Challenger, had been waiting in Marrakesh, Morocco, for favorable winds since early this month. A run of rain and storms over the Sahara combined with erratic changes in the high-altitude jet stream caused one delay after another.

headline: Bank Fraud Charges For Currency Trader
abstract: Victor Gomez, a former currency trader for the Chemical Banking Corporation,  has been indicted on Federal charges related to the bank's loss of $70 million from unauthorized trading of the Mexican peso, prosecutors said yesterday.         Mr. Gomez, who was arrested on Wednesday in London, also faced civil charges  filed by the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Federal Reserve, but agreed to settle those cases without admitting or denying guilt.

headline: Islamic Party in Turkey Is Asked to Form Coalition
abstract: Necmettin Erbakan, leader of the party that won the largest bloc of seats in  parliamentary elections here last month, was formally invited today to form a coalition government, despite the avowed refusal of other political parties to cooperate with his pro-Islamic group.         After meeting separately with party leaders from the newly sworn-in Parliament, President Suleyman Demirel honored political protocol by extending the invitation to Mr. Erbakan's Welfare Party, which emerged from the Dec. 24 elections with 21.4 percent of the vote.

headline: Dakar Journal;Children of Islam, Piously Seduced Into Begging
abstract: Aboure Aboridiale's daily routines are as fixed as his beatific gaze. With his morning prayer completed, the wispy-bearded young man sets out early dressed in rags for a day of begging that will end only with the dark of night.         Mr. Aboridiale is not poor, and suffers no infirmity. In fact, what gives this son of a middle-class family the stamina to hit the cold morning pavement in bare feet, and withstand a blistering midday sun as he works this city's crowded sidewalks, is his robust youth.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;BMG Buys the Rest Of Windam Hill Records
abstract: A unit of Bertelsmann A.G. of Germany has bought the remaining 50 percent stake of Windam Hill Productions record label that it did not already own. The unit, BMG Entertainment North America did not diclose the terms of the purchase  of the label that specializes in New Age music, which comes three-and-a-half years after BMG bought a 50 percent stake.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: U.S. Decision on Mexico Drugs Draws Opposition in Congress
abstract: Angered by President Clinton's decision to declare Mexico a cooperative partner in the war on drugs, lawmakers in the House and Senate are trying to overturn the decision on the ground that Mexico has done little to shut down the huge pipelines for cocaine and other illegal narcotics that stretch across the border into the United States.         A House International Relations panel summoned top Administration counternarcotics officials to Capitol Hill today to defend Mr. Clinton's decision. At the hearing, Republican lawmakers sounded incredulous as they cited reports that more than two-thirds of the cocaine used in the United States flows through Mexico.

headline: Company Briefs
abstract: CONMED CORP., Utica, N.Y., a maker and distributor of electrosurgery, heart monitoring and other medical products, purchased most of the assets of New Dimensions in Medicine Inc. for about $32 million.

headline: YOUR TAXES;With the U.S. Budget Unresolved, So Are Many People's Taxes
abstract: NATIONAL Industrial Contractors Inc., a maintenance company based in Raleigh, N.C., usually gets its taxes in right on time. But this year, the company will file for an extension and turn in the documents during the summer, Harvey Hales, its president and chief executive, said.         The reason? The budget impasse in Washington has left a number of tax issues  for 1995 up in the air, and Mr. Hales has no desire to pay accountants to prepare the company's returns twice.

headline: OUTLOOK '96: THE ECONOMY: Middle Age Catches Up With the MeGeneration; Replenishing the Ranks Of High-Skilled Workers
abstract: When the United Automobile Workers begin negotiations this year with the Big  Three auto companies, the shifting of work to outside suppliers is expected to be its single biggest concern. But it may not be at the top of the agenda for many U.A.W. members.         For hundreds of thousands of auto workers, the protection and -- if possible  -- the extension of retirement benefits are of paramount importance.
