Roughly half the combined hourly work force at the General Motors Corporation, the Ford  Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation will be eligible to retire within a decade.

headline: Russia Drops Big Tariff Increase, Clearing Way for an I.M.F. Loan
abstract: Russia has dropped a plan for a sharp across-the-board increase in import tariffs, clearing the way for a $10.2 billion loan from the International Monetary Fund, Western economists said tonight.         The election-year loan had been thrown into doubt earlier this month after Russia's Finance Minister, Vladimir G. Panskov, proposed a 20 percent increase in the tariffs, contradicting previous assurances to the I.M.F.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;CIGNA SAYS PENNSYLVANIA APPROVES RESTRUCTURING PLAN
abstract: The Cigna Corporation said yesterday that the Pennsylvania Department of Insurance had approved a plan to restructure the insurance company's domestic property and casualty business. Approval is still pending in California, Connecticut, Illinois, Indiana, New Jersey, Ohio and Texas. The restructuring splits Cigna's property-casualty business into one company for the continuing profitable business and a separate company for the unprofitable, discontinued business. Cigna would provide the runoff operation $500 million in new capital and financial support, after a $1.2 billion pretax increase in the company's net reserves in the third quarter. Shares of Cigna rose $2.625 yesterday to close at $120.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
abstract: Manhattan Bagel Co., Eatontown, N.J., to DKB & Partners, Morristown, N.J., as the first agency to handle its account. Billings were estimated at more than $4  million.

headline: Britain Faulted on Oil-Spill Damage Estimates
abstract: Wildlife experts accused British officials today of either misleading the public or of being naive about the extent of damage 70,000 tons oil from a grounded and leaking oil tanker caused to the coast of Wales.         Estimates of what it will cost to clean up the oil left by the tanker, the Sea Empress, since it ran aground 10 days ago near the port of Milford Haven reached $15.4 million.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
abstract: First Midwest Bank N.A., Itasca, Ill., to Grant/Jacoby Inc., Chicago, to handle  its account, previously at Salzinski & Buda Inc., Chicago. The billings were estimated at more than $1 million.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Europeans Let Britain Review Drug Concern Bid
abstract: The European Commission yesterday gave British authorities the power to review Gehe A.G.'s proposed acquisition of Lloyds Chemists P.L.C., raising the likelihood that the British drug wholesaler could remain independent. Britain's  Department of Trade and Industry, which referred an earlier bid by Unichem P.L.C. to the Monopolies and Mergers Commission, said it was seeking to "properly assess the competition consequences of the merger." Gehe is a unit of  Franz Haniel & Cie.          On March 1, John Taylor, the British Minister for Competition and Consumer Affairs, asked the European Commission to allow British authorities to examine the bid by Gehe, a German company. The same day the Government said it would investigate Unichem's competing offer for Lloyds Chemists.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: COMPANY NEWS;4HEALTH AND SURGICAL TECHNOLOGIES PLAN TO MERGE
abstract: 4Health Inc. said yesterday that it would merge with Surgical Technologies Inc. in a "reverse acquisition" that would allow shares of closely held 4Health  to trade publicly. The companies valued the transaction at $36 million. Surgical Technologies will buy 4Health, which will then assume control of the merged company. 4Health, based in Boulder, Colo., makes Nature's Secret and Harmony Formulas nutritional supplements. Surgical Technologies, based in Salt Lake City, will issue nine million shares for 4Health shareholders. Its stock will be split 1 for 2 after the transaction is completed, leaving Surgical Technologies  shareholders with 2.25 million 4Health shares, or 20 percent of stock outstanding.

headline: The Tide Is Rising For Refinancing
abstract: THOUGH home sales have not ignited, loan rates are flirting with record lows.        In the last few weeks, the average rate on a 30-year mortgage has dipped below the psychologically important barrier of 7 percent several times. At that  level, rates are approaching the 25-year lows recorded in 1993. So not only is it a good time to buy, but it is also a good time for many homeowners to consider refinancing. The potential advantages are several: smaller payments, better cash flow and perhaps more favorable loan terms.

headline: World News Briefs;Seoul Opens War Games At Isle Claimed by Japan
abstract: South Korea began a military exercise today around the tiny islands over which it is locked in a territorial dispute with Japan, a Defence Ministry spokesman said.         The spokesman did not give details but ministry officials said a navy destroyer, a maritime police ship, a helicopter and four air force fighters would take part in the exercise, which they said was partly intended to protest  Japan's claim.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Account Review For Playskool Toys
abstract: Hasbro Inc. in Pawtucket, R.I., has placed in review the broadcast advertising portion of the account of its Playskool line of toys, which has been handled by Griffin Bacal Inc. in New York. Though the billings were not disclosed, Advertising Age estimated them at $30 million.         Sharon Hartley, general manager of the Hasbro division that oversees Playskool, said that Griffin Bacal, which is owned by the Omnicom Group, "has done a great job for us over the years, but we feel the time is right to explore other opportunities." Other accounts that Griffin Bacal handles for Hasbro, like the Hasbro Interactive unit, are not part of the review, she added.

headline: Seagate Acquires Arcada Stake
abstract: Seagate Technology Inc. said today that it had paid $158 million to acquire the remaining 31 percent of Arcada Holdings Inc. that was not owned by Conner Peripherals Inc., which Seagate recently acquired.         Under the agreement, Arcada Holding's six minority stockholders would receive 0.1545 Seagate Technology share, which closed at $61.625 Friday, for each Arcada share. All outstanding Arcada stock options are expected to be converted into options to purchase Seagate shares.

headline: Nampheun Journal;Hellbent on Progress, Thais Sidestep Priesthood
abstract: Like his father and his grandfather before him, Kasem Wayamo set the world aside recently to enter the Buddhist monkhood in a coming-of-age ritual that lies at the heart of Thai tradition. He may be the last in his family to do so.          His gaudy procession by the side of a major highway, with fringed umbrellas and clashing cymbals, was an incongruous and increasingly rare sight as this country hurtles toward the 21st century.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;LIMITED COMPLETES TENDER OFFER FOR 85 MILLION SHARES
abstract: Limited Inc. said yesterday that it had completed its tender offer to buy back up to 85 million shares for a total of $1.61 billion. The $19-a-share buyback was intended to return cash to shareholders from the $680 million initial sale of stock in its Intimate Brands Inc. and the sale of its credit-card bank unit last year. Limited said the tender offer, which expired on March 6, was oversubscribed. It said about 185.9 million shares were tendered, including 428,525 shares held by odd-lot shareholders. Limited said it would purchase all shares tendered by odd-lot holders. The company operates Limited, Express, Structure and Abercrombie & Fitch stores.

headline: Owners of Barney's Will End Partnership With Restaurateur
abstract: In the latest unraveling of a Barney's business relationship since the company filed for bankruptcy protection last month, the owners, Bob and Gene Pressman, said yesterday they would dissolve a partnership with the restaurateur Pino Luongo.         The sale might be an effort to raise some cash for Barney's Inc., which owns  the specialty stores. Just a few weeks ago, the Pressman brothers got permission from a bankruptcy court judge to spend $200,000 to keep the Mad. 61 restaurant open. The restaurant, inside the Madison Avenue Barneys, is run by Mr. Luongo.

headline: OUTLOOK '96: THE ECONOMYThe Economic Consensus on 1996: The Year of the Big Yawn; Outlooks at the Edge: From Bust . . .
abstract: Not only is John Mueller one of the few economists predicting recession in 1996, he has been arguing for a long time that the new year will be a downturn,  a Presidential election notwithstanding. No worse than 1990-1991, but a recession this year will still be the real, painful thing.         Causing this recession, the signs of which he sees emerging in various reports of deceleration, is the delayed effects of Federal Reserve policy that doubled short-term interest rates between February 1994 and February 1995.

headline: Fiat to Cut Production
abstract: Blaming a continuing crisis of the European auto market, Fiat, the Italian auto maker, said this week that it planned to put thousands of workers on temporary layoffs to curtail its production in February. Fiat said it would produce 21,000 fewer vehicles next month, but it did not disclose how many cars  it would have produced without the cutback. Under a temporary state-supported unemployment program, 26,800 workers will be laid off in the week between Jan. 29 and Feb. 4 while 12,000 will be affected in the week of Feb. 5-11. Fiat said  that the cutback would affect older models; newer models, like the midsized Bravo and Brava, would proceed as scheduled.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Svenska Cellulosa Says Profits Soared Last Year
abstract: The big forest-products company Svenska Cellulosa A.B. said yesterday that its pretax profit rose more than fivefold in 1995 because it was able to increase prices and because units it bought earned more than expected. Pretax profit rose to a higher-than-expected 5.731 billion kronor ($868 million), from  1.060 billion kronor the previous year. The result includes 1.085 billion Swedish kronor from Papierwerke Waldhof-Aschaffenburg A.G. of Germany, in which  the Swedish concern bought a 75 percent stake last year.          Total sales almost doubled, to 65.317 billion kronor, from 33.676 billion, mainly because of higher prices, Svenska Cellulosa said. Of the sales, 91 percent went to customers outside Sweden, compared with 84 percent in 1994.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Plan to Mix Oil With Oil In Europe
abstract: In an effort to cut costs in Europe where demand for gasoline has been declining while refining capacity has been increasing, the Mobil Corporation and the British Petroleum Company said yesterday that they would combine their refining and marketing of fuels and lubricants.         If the step is approved by the European Commission, the two companies will create a huge new force that would control about 12 percent of the European fuel market and 18 percent of the lubricant market.

headline: Trump Moves to Put Taj Mahal in His Company
abstract: In a sign that his financial recovery is gathering speed, Donald J. Trump moved yesterday to fold his Taj Mahal Casino Resort in Atlantic City into his publicly traded casino company.         Trump Hotels and Casino Resorts, his publicly traded company, is doing well enough that Mr. Trump expects to attract new investors. He plans to raise $59 million in equity above the costs of transferring ownership of the Taj.

headline: Kellogg Ends Pensions for Some Directors
abstract: The Kellogg Company has ended pensions for its nonmanagement directors. Kellogg, which makes Rice Krispies and Special K cereals and Pop Tarts, said in  a preliminary proxy statement this week with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it was swapping stock grants, to be held in trust, for the retirement plans.         While the value of the stock grants is the same as the pensions' current value, the move is intended to make the directors more independent and more dedicated to improving the company's stock price.

headline: World News Briefs;Party Moves to Replace The Ailing Papandreou
abstract: The governing Panhellenic Socialist Party said today that it would take steps to replace Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou, who remains in critical condition  at an Athens hospital.         The party's decision came after a hospital statement today that Mr. Papandreou, 76, had suffered extensive kidney damage. Doctors have said it is unlikely that Mr. Papandreou, who has been on life support for 45 days, will be  able to resume his duties even if he recovers.

headline: Grand Union Reorganization
abstract: The Grand Union Company, a struggling supermarket chain, announced a reorganization today that was intended to save the company $5 million a year in  administrative costs.         The company said it would eliminate its two separate regional operations by consolidating all merchandising and administrative functions at its headquarters here. The company will also establish five operating units, each focusing on store operations within a particular geographic area.

headline: Under Pressure by NATO, Bosnian Serbs Free Captives
abstract: Under mounting pressure from the United States and NATO, Bosnian Serb officials backed down from their most serious challenge yet to the Dayton peace  agreement and late today released 16 Bosnians who had been detained while traveling through Serb-controlled suburbs of this city.         The 16 people, almost all middle-aged men, looking haggard and bewildered, were taken from a jail in the Serb-controlled suburb of Lukavica and left in a nearby restaurant.

headline: Correction
abstract: A chart last Sunday with an article about investing in Irish companies misstated the stock symbol and the March 1 price of the American depository receipts of the Jefferson Smurfit Group. The symbol is JS, not JJSC; the price on March 1 was $25, not $11.375. (The symbol and price shown were for the shares of the company's United States affiliate, the Jefferson Smurfit Corporation.)

headline: INVESTING IT;I.P.O.'s: When Employee-Friendly = Investor-Friendly
abstract: LOOKING to invest in a company new to the market? Check out its personnel policy.         The way a company treats its employees may be a window on both its chances for long-term survival and its initial stock price, according to a recent study  from Cornell University.

headline: Fund Growth Sets Record And Doesn't Break Stride
abstract: It may sound like a broken record, but Wall Street loves the tune: Investors  have continued to pour money into stock and bond mutual funds in February, barely pausing for breath after their purchases set a record in January.         According to figures released yesterday by the Investment Company Institute,  a trade group, net inflows to stock and bond mutual funds totaled $33.3 billion  in January, passing the previous monthly record of $29.4 billion, set in January 1994, and the $27.5 billion estimate for January 1996 that the institute had made earlier this month.

headline: Swedes Haunted by Palme's Killing, Unsolved After 10 Years
abstract: The bloodstain on the sidewalk has been replaced with a brass plaque in memory of Prime Minister Olof Palme, but 10 years and 18,000 leads later there is still no solution to his murder.         Several bungled investigations have led nowhere, and despite all the tip-offs, a murder weapon has yet to be found by the 14 detectives still working on the case.

headline: Chinese Deny Maltreatment at Orphanage
abstract: The former director of Shanghai's largest orphanage acknowledged today that perhaps one-fifth or more of the orphans under his care died in 1989 because "that year was very cold and we had no electricity." But he denied charges that  some orphans had been deliberately singled out for maltreatment and death.         The disclosure was made as Chinese officials opened the doors to the large state-run orphanage here and put on display for foreign journalists hundreds of  well-fed children in what appeared to be a healthy and nurturing environment.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;ESCO ELECTRONICS LOOKS TO SELL ITS HAZELTINE UNIT
abstract: The Esco Electronics Corporation of St. Louis said yesterday that it had hired J. P. Morgan & Company to explore the sale of its Hazeltine Corporation electronic systems subsidiary. Hazeltine makes and services advanced electronics systems for military purposes, including electronic identification equipment. It also makes antenna systems for the wireless communications market. Shares of Esco rose $1.125 yesterday, to $11.875, on the New York Stock Exchange. Esco makes products for the military industry.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Renault Profit Off 41%; Car Unit Shows a Loss
abstract: Renault S.A., France's second-largest car maker, said yesterday that its profit fell 41 percent last year, hurt by a prolonged transport strike and a sluggish economy. Renault, whose biggest shareholder is the French Government, said net income fell to 2.14 billion French francs ($428 million) from 3.64 billion francs a year earlier. The company said its car division had an operating loss of 1.7 billion francs, in contrast to a profit of 289 million francs in 1994.          Renault predicted there would be little improvement this year. The automobile market in France will grow "only moderately," the company projected,  adding that a "weakening of growth in commercial vehicles from the latter part of 1995 seems to have been confirmed by early indications for 1996."   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: COMPANY NEWS;PULLMAN SELLS ONE UNIT AND CONSIDERS SELLING OTHERS
abstract: A unit of Mark IV Industries has bought the Pullman Company's Imperial Eastman fluid-carrying-products division for about $75 million in cash plus certain liabilities, Pullman said yesterday. Pullman also said it was in talks with potential buyers for its remaining businesses: Clevite Elastomers, which manufactures vibration control components, and Conforma Clad, which makes specialty custom-engineered components. Pullman, a maker of automotive components and specialty industrial products that is based in Lebanon, N.J., said it would use the proceeds from the sale of Imperial Eastman to pay off debt. Mark IV, based in Amherst, N.Y., manufactures transportation, engineered and technical products.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Agency Changes By 4 Marketers
abstract: Four marketers have made agency roster changes.         Outback Steakhouse Inc., the restaurant chain in Tampa, Fla., awarded its account, with billings estimated at $20 million, to two units of the Interpublic Group of Companies, McCann Amster Yard in New York and McCann-Erickson New York. The account had been handled by the West Group Inc. in Tampa, Fla., since 1992. The two McCann shops were selected after a three-month review that also included two other New York agencies, D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles and the M &  C Saatchi Agency.

headline: French Government Will Sell Thomson This Year
abstract: The French Government announced yesterday that it planned to sell Thomson S.A., the huge defense and consumer-electronics company, to private investors by the end of 1996.         It also said it would work to merge two other military giants, Dassault Aviation, manufacturer of fighter jets, and Aerospatiale, producer of aircraft,  missiles and satellites, within two years.

headline: California Homes Are Selling Again
abstract: Beth Combee could hardly contain her excitement. After worrying about their jobs during the recent recession, she and her husband just received unexpected promotions and took a step she said they had only dreamed of during the years of economic uncertainty: they bought a handsome $104,000 house in a new development here known as May Ranch, 60 miles east of Los Angeles, in Riverside County.         "It's going to be empty for a while," said Mrs. Combee, 25, a supervisor in a pharmaceutical plant, as she explained that they would be moving from a one-bedroom mobile home to a three-bedroom house but would not be buying a lot of furniture right away. "We were thinking about this for about four years, but  we just weren't sure about our jobs or that we could finance it until now."

headline: COMPANY NEWS;MANUFACTURERS LIFE TO SELL ENHANCE FINANCIAL STAKE
abstract: Enhance Financial Services Group Inc. said yesterday that the Manufacturers Life Insurance Company planned to sell its remaining 12.3 percent stake in the company. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Enhance said that Toronto-based Manufacturers, a founding shareholder of the company, planned to sell up to 1.95 million shares in an underwritten offering and more than 211,000 more shares if demand was strong enough. On Feb 9, Manufacturers agreed to sell 400,000 shares at $24.48 each to the Swiss Reinsurance Company. Enhance is a New York reinsurer of financial guaranties issued by insurers of municipal bonds and other insurance products.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;AMOCO TO CONSIDER SALE OF FOAM BUSINESS
abstract: The Amoco Corporation said yesterday that it might sell its Amoco Foam Products unit, which had sales last year of $288 million. Amoco, the oil and chemicals giant based in Chicago, said it was reviewing strategic alternatives for the division. "We feel that Amoco Foam may well be a better strategic fit for another company," said Enrique Sosa, executive vice president of Amoco's chemical division. He added that the unit was "strongly profitable." Amoco Foam, based in Atlanta, manufactures polystyrene foam products at nine plants in the United States. The products include cups and plates, packaging trays for meat and poultry and industrial products.

headline: DIARY
abstract: FILTERS (I) Offensive Yes, Indecent No

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Pope's Plea for Peace Bears Fruit in Guatemala
abstract: Pope John Paul II made a final plea for peace in Guatemala at the end of his  five-day tour of Central America, and President Alvaro Arzu responded by announcing that formal peace talks with leftist rebels would reopen this month.          "I call on all people, especially those who hold positions of responsibility, exhorting you to create a climate of peaceful coexistence, of solidarity and justice for all Guatemalans," the Pope said. President Arzu then announced new talks to end the 35-year civil war.

headline: Lear Hurt by G.M. Strike
abstract: The Lear Corporation said today that it expected its first-quarter earnings to be reduced by 10 cents a share by the 17-day strike at two General Motors Corporation brake-parts plants in Dayton, Ohio. In last year's quarter ended April 1, Lear earned $17 million, or 34 cents a share, on sales of $1.04 billion. Lear said that depending on G.M.'s production schedules, a partial recovery would be possible. Lear supplies car seats and other interior parts.

headline: World News Briefs;Niger's Elected President Ousted in Military Coup
abstract: Niger's first democratically elected President was apparently ousted in a military coup today and put under arrest in the presidential palace.         Col. Barre Mainassara Ibrahim announced on state-run radio that President Mahamane Ousmane was under arrest, that the Constitution was suspended and that  a temporary national council was in control of the Government.

headline: Sunrise Medical Cuts Earnings After Inquiry on Bio Clinic Unit
abstract: Sunrise Medical Inc. said today that its 1994 and 1995 earnings would be restated downward as a result of its investigation into financial irregularities at its Bio Clinic Corporation subsidiary.         The company's shares fell $2.375 today, to $16.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Haughty Couture
abstract: THEY have always known how to put on a good show. At a cocktail party shortly before Christmas, Bob and Gene Pressman were in the best of spirits. Barneys New York, the flamboyant retail chain over which the two brothers preside, had just  pulled through one of the most difficult holiday seasons in recent memory, and with its best sales ever.         "They were telling everyone there, 'Business is great,' " one old friend said, recalling the party.

headline: Lotus Wins Software Case
abstract: A court has ordered a Singaporean accountant to pay the Lotus Development Corporation $2.3 million for selling pirated copies of the company's software. Lotus, which spent five years pursuing the case, said today that the award was one of the highest ever for software piracy.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;MEDTRONIC TO BUY REMAINING SYNECTICS SHARES
abstract: Medtronic Inc. said yesterday that it would pay $59 million, or $41.74 a share, for the shares of Synectics Medical A.B. of Sweden that it does not already own. For the last three years, Medtronic has held about a 7.4 percent stake in Synectics. Its tender offer valued the Stockholm-based company at about $63.7 million. Synectics is a world leader in computerized systems that help diagnose urological and digestive problems and sleep apnea. Shares of Minneapolis-based Medtronic fell $1.25, to $55.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Open Skies in France
abstract: The Italian airline Alitalia flew its first flights between French destinations yesterday as French skies opened to competition, ending a virtual monopoly by Air Inter. Under a law that took effect on Monday, all French airlines may fly domestic routes without restriction, in a dress rehearsal for deregulation in 1997, when airlines of one European Union state will be able to  fly domestic routes in another. Foreign airlines also won the right to fly French routes, but the aircraft must continue on to a destination outside France.   Reuters

headline: Night Brings Terror and Arson to Sarajevo Suburb
abstract: They are out in the night, boozy young men with temper and purpose. They threaten with guns, knives and gasoline, beating old men in their homes and setting apartment buildings on fire.         "When the sun goes down in Grbavica, it's like being in a bad alley in the Bronx," said Joseph Byrnes, a United Nations doctor who patrols what in four days will be the final Serbian enclave in the Sarajevo area to come under Muslim-Croat rule.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;His Place Among the Moguls
abstract: Perhaps it is fitting that MTV will begin its coverage of the 1996 Presidential campaign with an interview tomorrow of Bob Dole, the Senate majority leader. In recent weeks, Senator Dole has figured prominently in the thoughts of Sumner M. Redstone, the chairman of MTV's parent company, Viacom Inc.         On Wednesday Mr. Redstone forced out his longtime deputy, Frank J. Biondi Jr., and took over the duties of chief executive. "If Dole thinks he can run the country at 72," Mr. Redstone, who is also 72 years old, said yesterday, "then I  can run Viacom."

headline: Stocks Fall in Japan
abstract: Stocks traded lower here today. The Nikkei index of 225 issues closed down 250.65 points, or 1.20 percent, at 20,653.38. On Friday, the Nikkei fell 31.09 points.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Bear, Stearns in Greece
abstract: Bear, Stearns & Company said yesterday that it was joining with the National  Mortgage Bank of Greece, the leading Greek mortgage bank, to bundle local loans  into mortgage-backed securities. "The agreement with the National Mortgage Bank  is a major step in our strategy to develop asset securitization in Europe," said James E. Cayne, president and chief executive officer at Bear, Stearns in New York. The National Mortgage Bank has total assets exceeding 1.7 trillion drachmas ($7 billion).   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: INSIDE
abstract: INVESTING IT /Page 4/ It may sound dull, but water has become a hot investment.  By Laura Pedersen.

headline: BOMBING IS ISRAEL: THE WHITE HOUSE;As Israeli Peace Team Flies Home, Clinton Calls a Special Meeting
abstract: President Clinton's top advisers will recommend that the United States provide Israel with more intelligence and antiterrorism technology and take further action to isolate Iran because of its history of sponsoring terrorism, American officials said tonight.         The recommendations came during a special White House meeting that was called by Mr. Clinton, who was in Michigan on a political fund-raising trip. The President condemned the latest bombings in Israel and vowed that the United States would help Israel "stop the killings, to bring the killers to justice."

headline: Bus Blast Claimed by the I.R.A.; Bomber May Be One of Victims
abstract: The Irish Republican Army claimed responsibility today for the bomb that tore through a double-decker bus in central London late Sunday night, and the police  said there was a chance the single body they pulled from the wreckage was that of the bomber. Nine others were wounded in the explosion.         The bomb was the third in 10 days in an increasingly frightened London and left few doubts that the I.R.A. was resuming a full-scale campaign of violence.  London is already on a high security alert, and the I.R.A.  said it might well expand its bombings to other major English cities, Irish National Radio reported today.

headline: A Scuffle Reopens Canadian Wounds
abstract: In English-speaking Canada, he is a hero who gave a demonstrator a lesson he  will never forget. "True Grit: Big Jean Throttles Quebec Protester," blared the  headline in The Edmonton Sun. The Ottawa Sun weighed in with "Hull Hogan."         But the incident involving Prime Minister Jean Chretien got a different reading in French-speaking Canada. "Chretien Brutalizes a Protester," Le Devoir  complained. "Chretien Loses It," declared Le Journal de Montreal.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;Adobe Stock Plunges 23% as Earnings Trail Wall St. Expectations
abstract: The shares of Adobe Systems Inc. tumbled 23 percent in after-hours trading today after the company reported a loss for the fiscal fourth quarter and operating income that was well below Wall Street analysts' expectations.         With today's announcement, Adobe joined a long list of technology companies,  including Silicon Graphics Inc., the Cyrix Corporation and Apple Computer Inc.,  that have reported disappointing results for the fourth quarter or warned investors that earnings would not reach analysts' estimates. The shares of two smaller computing companies, the Microdyne Corporation and FTP Software Inc., plummeted today after both companies warned that quarterly earnings would be lower than expected.

headline: Belying Yeltsin Statement, Chechens Press Attack in Grozny
abstract: An increasingly desperate President Boris N. Yeltsin said today that, "as of  this afternoon, everything in Grozny is calm," even as Chechen rebels rampaged again through the secessionist capital, destroying water lines, gas depots and heating supplies while taking control of as much as a third of the city.         Russian commanders, afraid of running short of ammunition, pleaded on open radios for increased air support and reinforcements as the battle intensified, with hand-to-hand combat reported only several hundred yards from the heavily fortified main Government administration building in Grozny, the capital.

headline: Nintendo Game Is Delayed
abstract: The Nintendo Company said today that it would delay the introduction of its new 64-bit game machine in the United States until Sept. 30 because of a shortage of chips. The company had been aiming for April. The machine will still be introduced in Japan in April, a Nintendo spokesman said. "We have tried to procure chips for hardware, but they are still in tight supply," he said. Nintendo has not decided when to introduce the 64-bit player in Europe, the spokesman said.

headline: AT THE GATE;No High-Tech High Jinks With Hoists and Chains
abstract: AFTER last week's market turbulence, investors who scout out new offerings may be particularly wary of technology stocks.  For them, there is a promising new issue for a company that is about as far from high technology as can be: it  makes chains.         Such low-technology offerings give investors something they seldom see in the high-tech world of new issues: a stock price that small investors can handle, and a product that all can understand. And such industrial issues are rare. "You really don't see too many of these companies as I.P.O.'s," said D. Forbes Tuttle, research director of research for the I.P.O. Value Monitor.

headline: Deal for Berlusconi Stake
abstract: Five banks led by the investment bank Istituto Mobiliare Italiano paid $233 million to acquire 5.49 percent of Mediaset S.p.A., the television company controlled by former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, I.M.I. said today. The sale is part of a plan to reduce Mr. Berlusconi's stake in Mediaset, which owns  three national television networks, to less than 50 percent.

headline: Dow Registers Rise of 63.59; Passes 5,600
abstract: Stock prices lurched sharply higher yesterday, pushed by a number of large computer-driven buy orders and another good day in the long end of the bond market.         At the close of a hectic session, the Dow Jones industrial average was up 63.59 points, to 5,600.15. With only about 30 minutes of trading left yesterday, the blue-chip average was up as much as 90 points.  At that point, it lost about half of its gain, only to scoot upward again near the close.

headline: On-Line Software Deal
abstract: The Netscape Communications Corporation has agreed to integrate software from Aurum Software Inc. into its popular Navigator software to help companies track  sales leads from their sites on the World Wide Web. The companies said today that they would announce the agreement on Tuesday. Aurum's software enables companies to merge sales leads coming from their Web sites into their current internal sales and marketing systems. Financial terms were not disclosed.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Barings Bondholders To Sue Ex-Chairman
abstract: Bondholders of the former Barings P.L.C. voted yesterday to sue Peter Baring, the former chairman, along with other officials and advisers. They seek to recover L100 million ($153 million) lost when the British merchant bank collapsed a year ago. The bondholders said they also planned to name Andrew Tuckey, the former deputy chairman; Peter Norris, former head of investment banking, and three advisers -- BZW Securities, Hoare Govett Securities and Cazenove & Company.          The suit would come a year after Barings collapsed amid L860 million in losses on futures and options in Asia attributed to unauthorized trading by Nicholas W. Leeson, a trader based in Singapore. The Dutch banking company Internationale Nederlanden Groep took over Barings' assets.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: Canada's Justice System Faces Charges of Racism
abstract: TORONTO, Jan. 24         Kenny Belmar, 27, a night student in business administration at Ryerson Polytechnic University here, was waiting for a bus outside his home in east Toronto when two plainclothes policemen drew up in an unmarked car, accused him  of stealing an outboard motor and arrested him.

headline: Wary Britons Turning Backs on Beef
abstract: No doubt it was a scene played out in countless grocery stores across Britain over the last week: An elderly man and his wife stood looking at the mountain of packaged beef in the Waitrose store on King's Road in Chelsea.         "But we've had roast beef every Sunday for as long as I can remember," he protested. "I'm 72 years old. What's my chances of getting it before I die?"

headline: Market Place;Tobacco stocks these days are not for the faint of heart.
abstract: BATTERED by days of bad news, tobacco stocks have plummeted in an otherwise buoyant bull market, and investors are wondering, hardly for the first time in the turbulent world of tobacco, whether to buy, sell or hold.         Many analysts are offering the same answer. "I'm telling people to buy Philip Morris," Gary D. Black, an analyst for Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, said yesterday. "We've always made money by buying on weakness with Philip Morris."

headline: COMPANY NEWS;BELL ATLANTIC MOVES INTO LONG-DISTANCE MARKET
abstract: The Bell Atlantic Corporation became the first of the seven regional Bell telephone companies to file applications to offer long-distance service outside  its region. It filed yesterday with regulators in North Carolina, Florida, Illinois, South Carolina and Texas. The company's newly formed long-distance unit, Bell Atlantic Communications Inc., said it expected to enter each state as it got approval from regulators, which could take several months. The move came less than a week after President Clinton signed a sweeping telecommunications bill that lets Baby Bells and long-distance companies enter each other's markets.

headline: Reversing Field, Ford Will Aggressively Cut Costs
abstract: After months of dismissing concerns that its cars have become too expensive,  the Ford Motor Company has reversed course and begun an aggressive cost-cutting  campaign that includes the elimination of 6,000 product engineering jobs.         Ford officials said today that the company planned to reduce its product development staff to 23,000 from 29,000 in the next few years, mainly by cutting the number of engineers who are hired on long-term contracts but are not on the  permanent payroll. Some of the shrinkage in staff will also come through retirements, possibly including an early retirement program, and by not replacing people who leave.

headline: MCI Signs Siemens Deal
abstract: The MCI Communications Corporation said today that it had signed signed five  agreements with Siemens Rolm Communications Inc., a unit of Siemens A.G. of Germany, to offer services and discounts to each other's customers.    MCI said it would gain $1 billion in additional business from the deals in the next five years.          "Dual discounts make it possible for small-to-midsize businesses to take advantage of more sophisticated telecommunications solutions that would otherwise be affordable only to larger companies," said George Nolen, senior vice president of national sales at Siemens Rolm.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Saab Plans to Cut Auto Production
abstract: Saab, the Swedish car maker jointly owned by the General Motors Corporation and the Swedish investment firm Investor A.B., said yesterday that it planned to cut production because of fewer orders. "It is bad now and, therefore, we are planning several days of stoppage," a spokesman, Olof Wallen, said. "The year has not got off to a good start, and so we have to slam on the brakes."          Mr. Wallen said production might be reduced by up to 3,000 cars. He declined to comment on whether the company's goal to produce 100,000 cars annually had been altered. Last year Saab sold 98,700 cars.   (Reuters)

headline: U.N. Members Slow to Send Bosnia Police
abstract: Three months after it began sending international civilian police monitors and trainers to Bosnia, the United Nations has been able to field fewer than half the 1,721 officers it was asked to recruit because member countries are either not meeting their pledges or are sending unqualified candidates.         The United States, which promised 200 police officers, is one of the primary  defaulters. Only 33 Americans have reached the Balkans, and the scheduled arrival of another contingent this week was canceled, United Nations officials said. Another 50 are not expected until next month, and officials are waiting to hear about the remaining 117.

headline: SUMMIT IN EGYPT: CLINTON;A FORCE OF 10,000 GUARDING CLINTON
abstract: Arriving in Jerusalem to show solidarity with Israelis, President Clinton also stepped into an epic security operation today -- and into some feisty politicking as well.         After four suicide bombings in the last three weeks, which created the crisis that Mr. Clinton came to help defuse, the Israeli police have been on the alert  for more. Their fear is that the Presidential visit, coming on the heels of a "Summit of Peacemakers" in Egypt at which terror was condemned, would be a prime target for Islamic radicals.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Forte Cool To New Offer By Granada
abstract: The Granada Group P.L.C. increased its hostile takeover offer for Forte P.L.C. by 15 percent today by adding a special dividend, but the target company  continued to spurn the approach.         If it succeeds in its bid, Granada said, it will sell Forte's Exclusive and Meridien four- and five-star hotel chains to concentrate on Forte's midmarket Posthouse and Travelodge budget chains. Granada, which has holdings in media and leisure services, valued Exclusive and Meridien at L1.7 billion, or $2.6 billion.

headline: Bonn Admits Currency Plan Faces Problem
abstract: At a time of increasingly troubled debate over Europe's future, German officials powering the drive for integration have begun to acknowledge publicly  what other Europeans have long been saying: that their blueprint may turn out to be too ambitious.         For Germany, Europe's economic giant, the key to European stability and competitiveness in the next century has always been in setting an irrevocable course by 1998 for a monetary union, which would propel the region to some form  of political federalism.

headline: Kabul Offers Power-Share
abstract: The Afghan Government, under siege by a militant Islamic faction, has offered to share power with another opposition faction, both sides said today.         Representatives of the opposition faction, Hezb-i-Islami, led by former Prime Minister Gulbuddin Hekmatyar, have been in the Afghan capital, Kabul, for two days discussing power-sharing options with President Burhanuddin Rabbani's Government, the officials said.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Enron Hopes to Restart Work on Plant in India
abstract: The Enron Development Corporation hopes to restart construction on its power  plant in India by May 1 after agreeing on a new price for the plant's electrical output, a company spokeswoman, Diane Bazelides, said yesterday. The company reached the revised power purchase agreement on Thursday with the Maharashtra State Electricity Board. The agreement still needs final approval, however, from the Maharashtra Cabinet, the central Government of India and project lenders.          The government of Maharashtra canceled the project last August, contending it was too expensive and could damage the environment. But the state agreed to revive the project in January, after the company offered cost cuts and reductions in electricity prices.   (AP)

headline: FEDERAL RESERVE TRIMS KEY RATES TO SPUR ECONOMY
abstract: Worried that the economy has slowed and needs a modest spark, the Federal Reserve lowered short-term interest rates today by one-quarter of a point. The move amounts to tossing out a bit of a lifeline at a time when housing and retail sales are flagging and consumer confidence is sinking.         It is the central bank's second rate cut in less than six weeks. The move is  expected to ease borrowing costs for consumers and business, and indeed banking  companies, including Citicorp and BankAmerica, shaved the lending rates for their best customers today to 8.25 percent from 8.5 percent.

headline: Long Bond Loses Ground; Other Prices Up Slightly
abstract: With the exception of the bellwether 30-year bond, prices of Treasury securities rose slightly yesterday in an abbreviated session ahead of a three-day holiday weekend.         For the second time in a week, Federal offices were closed because of a snowstorm. Meanwhile, investors sold long maturities while waiting for some signs of progress in talks aimed at producing a balanced budget. The stalled talks between the Administration and Congressional Republican leaders have pushed interest rates on the long bond up nearly 20 basis points, or one-fifth of a percentage point, since the start of the year.

headline: New Capital For Rodman
abstract: Rodman & Renshaw Capital Group Inc. said today that its majority stockholder, the Mexican brokerage firm Abaco Casa de Bolsa, had agreed to invest $9.5 million more in the investment company in the next two months.         Rodman also said late on Friday that it expected to post a loss of about $29  million for 1995, largely because of a continuing restructuring of its Rodman &  Renshaw Inc. brokerage unit. The company said that restructuring was essentially complete, and that it expected to turn a profit by this year's fourth quarter.

headline: Cold War Over, France Plans a Slim, Volunteer Military
abstract: Announcing the most sweeping military changes since development of a nuclear  deterrent almost 40 years ago, President Jacques Chirac said tonight that France's armed forces would shrink by about a third and become an all-volunteer  force within six years.         To replace the military draft for young men, a hallowed institution since Napoleon, Mr. Chirac called for a national debate about how both men and women could serve France in civilian jobs instead.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Harper's Shares Electronic Profits With Authors
abstract: Harper's Magazine yesterday became the first publication to begin sharing its profits from electronic publishing with writers.         The decision represents a breakthrough for freelance writers in their continuing battle with publishers over who should profit when an article that has already appeared in print is published on an on-line service or on CD-ROM.

headline: Many Markets Remain Open
abstract: Most banks and the Treasury bond market will be closed in the United States today in observance of the birthday of Martin Luther King Jr. The stock market and the commodity markets will be open, although the Chicago Mercantile Exchange will end trading on most contracts at noon. Japan's financial markets are closed today for Adult Day.

headline: Steep Hurdles To a Web Shortcut;Rapid-Access Computer Lines Are Stumbling Over High Prices
abstract: When Stewart Dickson moved to Delaware last year, he signed up with one of the Bell Atlantic Corporation's newest residential services: a digital phone line that would let him browse the Internet four times as fast as he could on ordinary phone lines. Mr. Dickson, a computer artist, promptly set up a colorful site on the Internet's World Wide Web to display his work.         Then he got his bill for the month of September: $1,014.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Image Campaign For Plank Road
abstract: The Miller Brewing Company unit of the Philip Morris Companies has expanded its relationship with BBDO Toronto by awarding the agency an assignment to create an image campaign to promote Plank Road Brewery as a division of Miller that markets smaller specialty beer brands like Icehouse and Red Dog. Billings were not disclosed.         The campaign by BBDO Toronto, the Omnicom Group unit that also handles Red Dog, will begin running Sunday; commercials, print advertisements and billboards will carry the theme "Against the grain." The goal is "to get consumers to understand the Plank Road trademark and how the products fit together," Michael  Johnson, who handles marketing for Plank Road in Milwaukee, said yesterday.

headline: Union Lays Out Demands in G.M. Strike
abstract: Strikers at a brake factory here want safer equipment, more training, more hiring and an end to moves by the General Motors Corporation to buy more parts from outside companies, local union officials here said shortly before the two sides agreed to stop discussing their differences in public.         Joe Buckley, chairman of the bargaining committee for the United Automobile Workers Local 696, and Jerry Domi, the local's negotiator on G.M.'s outside purchases, laid out the strikers' demands in interviews on Thursday. Mr. Buckley said that the union was insisting that all of its concerns be addressed. "All of the issues are of equal importance to us," he said.

headline: Cable Companies Part Ways On Strategy for Satellite TV
abstract: Tele-Communications Inc. and Time Warner Inc., the nation's two biggest cable television operators, have parted ways in what had been a joint effort to launch satellite services that beam as many as 150 channels of television directly to individual homes.         With the Federal Communications Commission scheduled to auction off two valuable satellite licenses on Wednesday, Tele-Communications announced today that it would be a bidder in competition with MCI Communications Inc. and perhaps several other companies.

headline: FUTURES MARKETS;Improved Outlook for Iraqi Sales Pushes Price of Oil 38~ Lower
abstract: Prices for crude oil fell yesterday amid revived concern Iraq and the United  Nations would agree on a limited oil sale, which could mean about 600,000 barrels a day of new supply.         May crude oil fell 38 cents, to $21.41 a barrel, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. April gasoline fell 1.28 cents, to 64.44 cents a gallon.

headline: G.I.'s in Bosnia Shun Hunt for War-Crime Suspects
abstract: The mountainous, snow-swept Bosnian town of Han Pijesak is surrounded by American troops. It is inside the American peacekeeping zone in eastern Bosnia,  and soldiers assigned to the regional headquarters of the United States Army's First Armored Division could reach the outskirts of Han Pijesak in a leisurely hike.         But the Americans usually steer clear of Han Pijesak, the base of operations  for the man accused of the worst atrocities committed in Europe since World War  II: Gen. Ratko Mladic, the commander of the Bosnian Serb military. He has been indicted by an international war crimes tribunal for the deaths of thousands of  Bosnian Muslims.

headline: China Faults Guidance System in Crash of Satellite
abstract: In its first full account of an explosion during a satellite launching last month, China's state-run media reported this weekend that defects in the rocket's guidance system caused the disaster. The incident was a blow to China's cut-rate commercial launching business.         The explosion, which killed six people, destroyed a $126 million satellite made by the Loral Corporation of New York, which was intended to provide voice and video transmission for the Intelsat satellite network.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Technology Issues Send Dow to 9th Record of '96 A recovery in technology stocks lifted the stock market broadly higher as the Dow Jones average hit its ninth record of the year, rising 52.02 points to 5,459.61. The rally was led by Intel, Micron Technology and I.B.M. The Nasdaq and Standard & Poor's indexes also advanced. [Page D8.]

headline: Corrections
abstract: An article last Sunday about corporate medical benefits for executives and rank-and-file workers misstated the relationship of two executives in the Gannett Company, one of the companies cited. John J. Curley, the chief executive, is the brother of Thomas Curley, the publisher of USA Today, which is owned by Gannett.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;COMPUSA REPORTS 10% INCREASE IN SAME-STORE SALES
abstract: CompUSA Inc. reported yesterday that its second-quarter sales surpassed those of the corresponding period last year. The company, a computer retailer based in Dallas, said same-store sales for the quarter that ended on Dec. 23 rose 10.5 percent from a year ago. CompUSA, which operates 95 computer superstores, said the same-store figures referred to sales at the 80 stores open for more than a year. The company said total sales for the quarter increased 22 percent, to $931 million, from $762 million a year ago. The company's shares rose 75 cents yesterday, to $33.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Apparent Defection From North Korea That Hurts to the Heart
abstract: If North Korea's "Great Leader" did not have enough problems, with hunger spreading throughout the world's last Stalinist state, his former wife was reported today to be in hiding and apparently planning to cooperate with Western intelligence agencies.         The defection of the leader's former wife, Sung Hae Rim, would be a blow to North Korea. The nation's press fulminates whenever a third secretary in a distant embassy defects, and the Government's inability to maintain the loyalty  even of its leader's former wife -- who has led a lavish life in virtual exile at North Korean Government expense -- would be a humiliation.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;APACHE AGREES TO ACQUIRE PHOENIX RESOURCE
abstract: Broadening its expansion into Egypt, the Apache Corporation agreed yesterday  to buy the Phoenix Resource Companies for $409 million in cash and stock. The Houston-based Apache said Phoenix has oil-drilling concessions in Egypt and two  producing fields expected to generate $70 million next year. Apache will pay three-quarters of a share of Apache stock and $4 in cash for each of Phoenix's 16.1 million shares, or about $25.38 a share at Wednesday's closing price. Shares of Phoenix, based in Oklahoma City, jumped $4.125, or 21 percent, to $24  yesterday, on the American Stock Exchange, while Apache shares fell $1, to $27.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: G.O.P. Abandons Tactic In Budget Dispute

headline: Fiery Farewell in Bosnian Land Transfer
abstract: A group of ragged Bosnian Serb police officers, their voices barely audible over a scratchy recording of the old anthem of the kingdom of Yugoslavia and the thunder of ammunition exploding nearby, lined up for a formal farewell to the neighborhood they will hand over to the Muslim-Croat federation on Tuesday.         The police officers lowered the Bosnian Serb flag from the front of the Grbavica police station, kissed the cloth and folded it. Milenko Karisik, Deputy Interior Minister for the Bosnian Serbs, proclaimed the officers "heroes" and reminded the few onlookers that the police were the first to raise the rebel Serbian flag in the suburb four years ago.

headline: yCosmetics Romance the Bull;As Industry Lures Investors, Can Revlon Also Rise?
abstract: As Wall Street weighs the value of the planned public offering of Revlon Inc., it is clear that the $6 billion cosmetics industry has never looked lovelier -- at least to investors.         Not that it has ever lacked visibility, with its glammy advertising celebrating the super faces of Cindy Crawford, Elizabeth Hurley and Christy Turlington.

headline: FUTURES MARKETS;Wheat Prices in Sharp Decline As Fungus Disrupts Export Sales
abstract: Wheat prices plunged yesterday, after a rare fungus discovered in Arizona crops forced the Government to halt exports last week to 21 countries, some of them large wheat importers.         In other markets, rising prices for crude oil and coffee pushed overall commodities indexes higher for the fifth consecutive day. The energy-weighted Goldman, Sachs Commodity index rose 0.21 point, to 196.18, while the Commodity Research Bureau index gained 0.42 point, to 246.89.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                                               Previous      Year                               Yesterday       Day       Ago

headline: U.S. Set to Impose Limited Trade Sanctions on China
abstract: The Clinton Administration intends to punish China for supplying nuclear materials to Pakistan by applying selective sanctions intended to hurt China without disrupting American companies that do business there, senior officials say.

headline: Maputo Elephant Reserve Journal;Thinking Big ($800 Million) to Rescue Big Game
abstract: In this remote and beautiful corner of the world, representatives of a conservative Louisiana millionaire used to hand American cash to a rebel movement so cruel that it kidnapped children for its assassination squads.         Today, a representative of the same man is handing children little American and Mozambican flags. Mozambique's flag is the only one in the world with an AK-47 assault rifle on it, and the socialist Government the businessman was trying to undermine won the war and the elections two years ago.

headline: Canadian Mounties Accused of Failing to Protect Their Man
abstract: In his scarlet tunic, blue breeches with a yellow stripe and wide-brimmed hat, the Mountie has long been a symbol of Canada. But these days, that figure of fortitude and rectitude who always gets his man is likely -- at least in the  nation's irreverent press -- to wear the face of Mickey Mouse.         The Royal Canadian Mounted Police have taken a drubbing lately over incidents that have raised questions about their ability to protect the Prime Minister.

headline: TENSION IN TAIWAN: THE POLEMICS;China Denounces U.S. 'Interference' in Dispute With Taiwan
abstract: China lashed out at the United States today, accusing Congress and the White  House of meddling in Taiwan, and warning that the People's Liberation Army would "bury" American naval forces now in the Pacific if they came too close to China's coastline.         With two American naval groups now in the western Pacific, one near Taiwan and the other approaching, a Communist Party-controlled newspaper in Hong Kong asserted that, should a clash occur, China's numerical advantage in planes and ships would easily overwhelm American technological superiority.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;EDMARK STOCK IS HURT BY OUTLOOK ON EARNINGS
abstract: The stock of the Edmark Corporation, a software maker, fell 15 percent yesterday after the company said it expected second-half results to come in below analysts' expectations. The stock lost $6.25, to $33, in Nasdaq trading. The company, based in Redmond, Wash., said on Thursday that its earnings would be hurt by a slowdown in retailer reorders for its multimedia software products. Edmark said it expected to incur an unspecified operating loss in the third quarter ending March 31 on revenues of $5.5 million to $6 million. A survey by I/B/E/S, which tracks Wall Street analysts, said it expected the company to report a profit of 4 cents a share for the quarter.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;STOCK OF HILTON HOTELS SHOWS SHARP INCREASE
abstract: The stock of the Hilton Hotels Corporation shot up yesterday after Stephen F. Bollenbach, the chief executive, told The Wall Street Journal, that he did not intend to split Hilton into separate hotel and casino companies. Instead, he will concentrate on adding hotel rooms. Hilton shares were up $4.875, or 5 percent, at $97.625, on the New York Stock Exchange. Mr. Bollenbach is a longtime hotel-casino executive who quit as Disney's finance chief to run Hilton last month. Before his appointment Hilton's shares were trading in the mid-$70's. Since then, they have traded as high as $99.625 on hopes that Mr. Bollenbach, the first outsider to run Hilton, will energize the company, which was long under family control.

headline: Lonrho Founder Is Selling Stake
abstract: Roland W. Rowland, founder of the conglomerate Lonrho P.L.C., is selling his  stake in the company to the German executive who ousted him last year, it was announced today.         Mr. Rowland says he will exercise an option to sell 5.85 percent of Lonrho for L91.2 million, or $139.5 million, to Laerstate B.V., a company owned by Lonrho's chairman, Dieter Bock.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;HELENE CURTIS TO CONSIDER SEEKING A BUYER
abstract: The shares of Helene Curtis Industries rose yesterday after its directors said they would consider the recommendation of Shamrock Holdings of California Inc. that the personal-care products company seek a buyer. Shamrock, the investment manager for members of the family of Walt Disney, made the recommendation in a letter to Helene Curtis dated on Tuesday. Shamrock, which holds a 7.6 percent stake in Helene Curtis, also called for the dismantling of the company's dual-class shareholder structure. Shares of Helene Curtis, the maker of Suave shampoos and Degree deodorant, closed up $1.25 at $42, and have risen 38 percent in the last week.

headline: INVESTING IT;Think That I.P.O. Looks Good? If It's Offered to Pay Debt. Look Twice.
abstract: INVESTORS buy initial public offerings because they want to get in on a venture's ground floor. As the company uses the offering's proceeds to build the business up, people hope that their returns will ride higher and higher, too.         But, more and more, the money from new issues is used not to expand a company; it is designated to pay for debt. In 1995, about 34 percent of all such proceeds went to repay or refinance bank loans and fixed-income debt, according to the Securities Data Company. That share is the second-highest annual number since 1986.

headline: Bristol-Myers Reports Loss In 4th Quarter
abstract: The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company reported yesterday a net loss of $208 million for the last three months of 1995. The loss includes a new after-tax write-off of $590 million for claims by women who say they were injured by breast implants and a $310 million charge for plant closings and reorganizing.         Bristol-Myers Squibb said pretax profit on operations, before the charges, was $910 million, up 9 percent from the fourth quarter of 1994.

headline: Tribune Plans An Acquisition
abstract: Continuing to reshuffle its educational investments, the Tribune Company said today that it had agreed to buy the privately held Educational Publishing Company for $200 million in cash.         Tribune, a media and information services company based here, plans to buy Educational Publishing from Brentwood Associates, a private equity and venture capital firm in Los Angeles.

headline: New Head For Poynter
abstract: James Naughton, the former executive editor of The Philadelphia Inquirer, has been named president of the Poynter Institute for Media Studies in St. Petersburg, Fla., the institute announced yesterday.         Mr. Naughton, who is 57, will succeed Robert J. Haiman, who in 13 years as president built the institute from its small beginnings in a storefront to a journalism school offering 60 courses a year to about 1,500 journalists, most of them in mid-career, but including some young interns as well. The institute has  a full-time faculty and staff of 40.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings this week: 2-12

headline: Q&A / Russell J. Cheetham : East Asia's 'Huge Opportunity'
abstract: Rapid growth has made East Asia a powerhouse for global trade and economic activity. Russell J. Cheetham, the World Bank's vice president for East Asia and the Pacific, discussed prospects for the region with Michael Richardson of the International Herald Tribune.

headline: Stock of Phamis Plummets 38%
abstract: The stock of Phamis Inc. plunged today, one day after it said its first-quarter profits would fall far short of analysts' estimates.         The Natwest Securities Corporation, which had previously recommended buying Phamis, a provider of health care information systems, downgraded it to hold. Alex. Brown & Sons also lowered its rating to neutral from buy.

headline: Old Problems Surface Between China and Taiwan
abstract: With the dust-up between China and Taiwan settling down, their officials began grappling in public today with the obstacles that remain before the two sides can even begin talking about delivering mail to each other, much less about a meeting between their leaders.         Blunt comments by officials in China and Taiwan have demonstrated that despite the euphoria over receding military tensions in recent days, major differences remain.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
abstract: John R. Puglisi, executive vice president and managing director at William Douglas McAdams Inc., New York, was promoted to president and chief operating officer, succeeding Thomas Lom, who left. * Steve Aaron was named vice president and publisher at Premiere, New York, succeeding Mark Furlong, who left. Mr. Aaron was previously associate publisher at Elle Decor, New York, which is owned by the Hachette Filipacchi Magazines unit of the Lagardere Group. Premiere is owned by a joint venture of Hachette Filipacchi and the New World Communications Group.

headline: Bosnian Serbs Now Say They Will Keep Ties to NATO Force
abstract: Bosnian Serb government leaders said today that an order by the military commander, Ratko Mladic, to sever ties with the NATO-led peacekeeping force until the Bosnian Government released two senior officers was "invalid" and had  been rescinded.         "This demand by General Mladic does not reflect the view of the Bosnian Serb  government," the self-styled prime minister, Rajko Kasagic, said in an interview. "General Mladic does not speak for the government. Our government decides policy and our army implements government policy."

headline: Let It Snow
abstract: To the Editor:         It is a sad commentary on American life that so many workers can't sit home for one day during a blizzard and enjoy it ("Who's Really Essential? In a Blizzard, It's a Blur," Earning It, Jan. 14). We all want to feel essential, but let's face it: the world is marching on despite the millions losing jobs to downsizing. Those who live in this fear won't stop the inevitable by risking their lives to get to work in a blizzard.

headline: World News Briefs;4 Western Hostages Sighted in Kashmir
abstract: An American and three other Westerners held hostage for six months were seen  in a village in northern India this week, and witnesses said they were wearing warm clothes and looked healthy, Indian officials said.         Residents saw the hostages walking with 30 or 40 escorts in Hakura village in Jammu and Kashmir State, said a state government official in Jammu, the winter capital.

headline: At Funds, They're Down But Not Out
abstract: MOST children are bright enough to wrinkle their noses when presented hand-me-downs. Why aren't mutual fund investors that smart?         Before you plunge your savings into a fund that promises to enliven its portfolio with new blood, take a closer look. One fund's fresh face may well be  another's failure.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Mexican Protesters Block Oil Wells in a Gulf State
abstract: Demonstrators have blockaded dozens of oil wells belonging to Petroleos Mexicanos in the state of Tabasco this week, demanding compensation for pollution by the huge state oil monopoly.         Officials at Petroleos Mexicanos, widely known as Pemex, said today that oil  and natural-gas production had not been affected so far by the takeovers. But the company is taking the disruptions in Tabasco, a Gulf Coast state, seriously  -- announcing that it is working with law-enforcement officials to prosecute the leaders of the estimated 1,000 demonstrators for sabotage.

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;G.I. on Patrol in Bosnia Shot by Intruder at Camp
abstract: An American soldier was shot and wounded in the left shoulder today after challenging an intruder at a base in the American-monitored sector of northern Bosnia.         The soldier was identified as Specialist Shawn R. Austin, 21, a tank driver from Tacoma, Wash. The gunshot wound was not considered life-threatening, and Mr. Austin was in stable condition at an American field hospital, a United States Army spokesman said.

headline: Bangkok Journal;The Guilty Suitcase: Good Fiction or Bad Luck?
abstract: In his days as a big-city television reporter, Stephen Roye would probably have found the story irresistible:         An American reporter is arrested at the airport of an exotic Asian capital, carrying heroin sewn into the lining of his suitcase, insisting to the police that while working on a blockbuster story, he was coerced into drug smuggling in order to save the life of his mother and son.

headline: Chirac to Unveil Plans for an All-Volunteer French Army
abstract: PARIS—  Sweeping defense changes planned by France, including an end to the military draft, are aimed at streamlining its armaments industries and forging a much smaller, all-volunteer army designed to intervene in Bosnian-type crises on Europe's fringes.

headline: In Finland, an EU Aide's Salary Goes Over the Top
abstract: BRUSSELS—  Call it a testament to Europe's economic and social disparity. Or perhaps to the ability of Europe's bureaucracy to attract controversy.

headline: Bosnian Croats Resist Peace Accord
abstract: The priest in the familiar brown, hooded robe and rope cinch of the Franciscan order was making his rounds in this village recently, trailed by local children and a cat, when he stopped to explain to a visitor why Croats here in western Bosnia will never share power with the Bosnian Government.         "That is a Government of Muslims," the priest, the Rev. Vinko Mikolic, said.  "They are no better than the Turkish occupiers from our history. We cannot let them occupy us again, never."

headline: Chemical Producers Weigh Ethylene Plant
abstract: The Eastman Chemical Company has joined the Lyondell Petrochemical Company, Union Carbide and the Quantum Chemical Company in studying whether to build an ethylene plant that could cost as much as $900 million.         The plant, which would be jointly owned by the four companies, would produce  two billion pounds a year of ethylene, the world's most widely used petrochemical.

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: AT&T CORP., New York, named Alex J. Mandl, formerly head of long-distance services, to the positions of president and chief operating officer of the new AT&T, which will run long- distance and wireless operations. John D. Zeglis, currently AT&T's chief legal counsel, was named to the new position of senior executive vice president of policy development and operations support. Harold W. Burlingame was named executive vice president of human resources and Marilyn Laurie was named executive vice president of public relations and employee information. LIFE MEDICAL SCIENCES INC., Princeton, N.J., named John Spitznagel, formerly president of Reed & Carnrick Pharmaceuticals, Jersey City, a division of Block Drug Co., to the positions of chief executive and president, succeeding Herbert  Moskowitz, who continues as chairman.

headline: Mexico 'Turning Corner' : Q&A /Ernesto Zedillo
abstract: Ernesto Zedillo inherited the presidency of Mexico in 1994 and with it a major currency and debt crisis, as well as political and labor turmoil and a peasant uprising in the Chiapas region.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent

headline: 67 Million Settlement by Bankers Trust
abstract: The Bankers Trust Company has agreed to pay $67 million to Air Products and Chemicals Inc. to settle a dispute over money-losing derivatives contracts, the  companies announced yesterday.         The settlement is by far the largest so far in disputes involving the New York bank holding company and its clients over the highly complex, volatile securities, which in 1994 generated huge losses at some of the nation's best-known and biggest companies.

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;U.N. and Baghdad Scale A 3d Diplomatic Hurdle
abstract: After a 12-hour standoff, Iraqi soldiers today allowed United Nations weapons monitors to enter a training base used by the Republican Guard, which has close  ties to President Saddam Hussein. It was the second confrontation in three days.         After a flurry of diplomatic contacts, James Moore, director of operations for the United Nations monitors, said, the inspectors had been permitted into the compound. But it was unclear whether the Iraqis had agreed to allow a full inspection. The inspectors are authorized to monitor the dismantling of Iraqi programs for chemical and biological weapons and long-range missiles.

headline: 2 Die in Clash With Police in Bangladesh
abstract: The police fired rubber bullets and tear gas and swung bamboo canes today to  disperse anti-election protests that left two people dead and at least 90 wounded in Dhaka, the capital, and around the country.         The unrest came as opposition members stepped up a campaign to disrupt general elections scheduled for Thursday, which they say should be held under a  neutral caretaker government.

headline: FUTURES MARKETS;Suspension of Iraq-U.N. Talks Lifts Oil Prices to 4-Year Highs
abstract: Crude oil futures surged yesterday to their highest levels in more than four  years after oil talks between Iraq and the United Nations were temporarily suspended and traders rushed to buy crude.         Also benefiting from the rally were heating oil, unleaded gasoline and natural gas futures, as well as copper and sugar futures. Over all, the Commodity Research Bureau's index of 17 commodities rose 2.16 points, to 250.43.

headline: Italy Opens Inquiry Into Jail Escape by Achille Lauro Gunman
abstract: The Justice Ministry said today that it was investigating the disappearance of a Palestinian terrorist convicted of killing an American Jew in a cruise ship hijacking in 1985.         The Palestinian, Magid al-Molqi, 34, was convicted in 1986 by a court in Genoa and sentenced to 30 years in prison for shooting Leon Klinghoffer, a 69-year-old tourist from New York, who was then pushed overboard from the cruise ship, the Achille Lauro, in his wheelchair.

headline: Equity Offerings Planned
abstract: Equity Offerings Set for This Week The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:      Sagebrush Inc., Claremont, N.C., an initial public offering of 1.7 million shares. Wheat First Butcher Singer Inc.

headline: Texaco Spending Up
abstract: Texaco Inc. said today that it would spend $3.6 billion this year on oil and  natural gas exploration programs, which is an increase of $500 million from 1995's spending.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Miscellany
abstract: * The Publishers Information Bureau, New York, said that the number of magazine  advertising pages in February fell 4.9 percent from February 1995, to 15,960. For the first two months of 1996, total ad pages fell 4.6 percent, to 28,750, from the corresponding period a year earlier.

headline: Publishers, Joan Collins And That Fine Print
abstract: When the eyebrow-raising trial in State Supreme Court in Manhattan ends, as it is expected to later this week, the British actress Joan Collins may be forced to repay a $1.2 million advance she received several years ago and forgo  the total of $4 million promised for the two books she had agreed to write.         But the real losers may be Random House and its fellow publishers. For after  the celebrity-on-the-stand glitter fades, Ms. Collins and her lawyers will have succeeded in exposing both the secret weapon of the publishing industry --  the vague and subjective language of author contracts -- and its Achilles' heel, the dependence on megabooks and celebrity authors to bolster bottom lines.

headline: SPENDING IT;Type: Corporate Chief. Passion: Riding Harleys.
abstract: TAKE a little Malcolm Forbes, add a dash of Jim Rogers, the investment biker, and you get RUB's, rich urban bikers.         Though they might resist the label -- affixed by some long-time Harley-Davidson enthusiasts -- RUB's are business executives, lawyers, doctors and other professionals who don black leather jackets and become weekend road warriors. Some of them own several motorcycles, including high-end Italian and Japanese bikes designed for racing. But for cruising, their vehicle of choice remains the Harley. And they may think nothing of dropping $15,000 to $20,000 on a "hog" and several thousand more for custom bike touches and accessories.

headline: Colombia Leader's Accuser Is Causing Political Turmoil
abstract: Colombia's politics have been thrown into turmoil by a former senior official's charges that President Ernesto Samper knowingly received contributions by drug traffickers to his 1994 campaign.         On Sunday night, Fernando Botero, who served as Mr. Samper's campaign manager and later as his Defense Minister, said in a television interview that Mr. Samper had been "very seriously compromised" by receiving millions of dollars in contributions from leaders of the Cali cocaine organization.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;FIRST NATIONWIDE RAISES BID FOR LOMAS FINANCIAL
abstract: First Nationwide Bank has increased its offer for assets of the Lomas Financial Corporation by $7.75 million, or 5.2 percent, to $157.75 million. Lomas disclosed the higher offer in a filing in United States Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, Del., where the Dallas-based mortgage-servicing company filed for Chapter 11 protection on Oct. 10. First Nationwide is offering more money for less of Lomas Financial. The original bid was for the entire company. Now First Nationwide is not bidding for Lomas's insurance business. Last month, Judge Peter Walsh sided with Lomas's creditors and allowed them to seek bidders  other than First Nationwide.

headline: Oil Tanker Refloated Off Wales
abstract: An enormous oil tanker that ran aground off the Welsh coast last week was finally set afloat again tonight, but only after it spewed more than 65,000 tons of crude oil into one of Britain's most environmentally sensitive areas.         The amount of oil that the Government says has already leaked from the tanker Sea Empress far exceeds the 38,000 tons spilled by the Exxon Valdez when it ran  aground off Alaska in 1989. The oil has created a 25-mile slick that is beginning to wash up on the tiny islands along the Pembrokeshire coast that are  home to much of the region's wildlife.

headline: France Ending Nuclear Tests That Caused Broad Protests
abstract: The French Government said today that it had ended its nuclear weapons test program for good after conducting an underground blast in the South Pacific on Saturday, the last in a series of six such tests that were deplored by most of France's European allies and scores of other countries.         President Jacques Chirac announced the decision on national television this evening, calling the halt "the definitive end of French nuclear testing."

headline: RJR Nabisco Asks 'What If'
abstract: The head of the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation has said the American tobacco industry would not rule out a deal to settle anti-         smoking claims if it was guaranteed immunity from litigation, The Financial Times reported today.

headline: Going Broke and Cutting Loose;Bankruptcy Has New Appeal for Music Groups Chafing at Their Contracts
abstract: Success, as abrupt and electric as a summer thunderstorm, enveloped the music group TLC five years ago and shows no sign of ending. The three-woman group based in Atlanta -- its music is a blend of rhythm and blues and hip-hop -- has  two "multi-platinum" albums and half a dozen top singles. So the music industry  was somewhat taken aback last year when the three women all filed for bankruptcy court protection, telling whoever would listen that they were "broke."         Their manager, Pebbitone Inc., and their record label, LaFace Records, do not believe it. Both have protested in court that the women are simply misusing Federal bankruptcy law to pressure them into renegotiating TLC's contract and to shortchange the people who helped create their glittering success. LaFace is a unit of Bertelsmann.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;ARCHER-DANIELS IN JOINT VENTURE WITH RHONE-POULENC
abstract: The Archer-Daniels-Midland Company said yesterday that it would form a joint  venture with Rhone-Poulenc S.A.'s animal nutrition unit to market pre-mixes for  animal feed.
