Pre-mixes are blends of amino acids, vitamins, medicinal additives  and other elements. Archer-Daniels, the grain processor based in Decatur, Ill.,  will contribute pre-mix operations in the United States, Canada, China and Vietnam, and stakes in ventures in Mexico, Taiwan and Thailand. Rhone-Poulenc, the French drug and chemicals concern, will contribute pre-mix operations in France, Australia and Indonesia, as well as stakes in pre-mix companies in Italy and Japan.

headline: Limiting a Medium Without Boundaries;How Do You Let the Good Fish Through the Net While Blocking the Bad?
abstract: All over the world, a growing number of governments, schools, special interest groups and families are struggling to find acceptable ways of tapping into the riches of the Internet without also hitting the darker veins of the global computer network.         But with its ability to carry all kinds of information across borders and oceans in a flash, the Internet has evolved faster than the laws and technical structures of the countries it touches. Although communities have struggled for  centuries to preserve local laws and standards when they come into conflict with the outside world, the Internet and on-line information networks are presenting  them with new problems that defy old solutions.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Lonrho Shares Rise On Reports of Split
abstract: Shares of Lonrho P.L.C. rose yesterday to a three-year high on expectations that the London-based company was planning to split its mining and hotels interests into separate companies.          A breakup would allow Lonrho, which owns the Metropole hotel chain and is one of the world's largest gold producers, to raise the value of shares that have lagged behind market averages in the last year.  Shares rose as much as 8.5 pence, to 192.5 pence, their highest since Dec. 3, 1991.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: MINDING YOUR BUSINESS;Wrapping a Gift? Remember the String
abstract: Q. How can grandparents setting up Uniform Gift to Minors Act accounts for their grandchildren's education make sure the money won't be squandered by divorcing parents?

headline: Is West Slighting Africa's Hot Spots Like Liberia?
abstract: When the chief American delegate to the United Nations, Madeleine K. Albright, stopped here briefly on Wednesday during a tour of several African countries, there were the predictable pledges of assistance from Washington to war-torn Liberia.         But along with the promise of helicopters and trucks to help in the disarming of combatants in a devastating six-year civil war, there was also a stern warning that the international community had little patience for crisis-ridden African countries that failed to settle their own problems.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS;Bonds Drop on Weakened Rate-Cut Hope
abstract: Prices of Treasury securities slumped yesterday, as hopes for a quick cut in  interest rates were weakened by a strong factory orders report and by comments by the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan.         Trading was fairly light with many market participants looking ahead to Friday's report on employment for February. The market was pressured by selling of intermediate-maturity securities by large hedge funds, traders said.

headline: The Neediest Cases;Some Give With Grateful Nod to Past
abstract: A year after Hitler came to power, Eric W. Zielenziger left Berlin, his birthplace, and moved to the Netherlands. It was 1934, and he was 14.         During the war that followed, Mr. Zielenziger's parents were deported. He went underground in Amsterdam, living with a Christian family that wanted to help the Jews. If the Nazis came looking, his hiding place was to be a broom closet in the kitchen.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Jerry & Ketchum Wins 2 Accounts
abstract: Jerry & Ketchum in New York has been awarded assignments from the Collagen Corporation and the Block Drug Company. The billings were not disclosed.         Collagen has selected the agency to handle advertising for its Collagen Replacement Therapy SM treatment, which had previously been handled by Grey Advertising in San Francisco. Becky Stirn, vice president for marketing strategy at Collagen in Palo Alto, Calif., said Jerry & Ketchum was awarded the  account after a three-month review that had narrowed the choice to that agency and three other finalists, all based in California: Esprit Communications in Corona del Mar, Forsythe Marcelli Johnson in Newport Beach and Mullaly Communications in San Ramon.

headline: Croatian General Plans to Surrender To Hague Tribunal
abstract: The Croatian Government announced today that a Bosnian Croat general charged  with involvement in the killing of hundreds of Muslim civilians would turn himself in to international prosecutors on Monday. The move was described by visiting American officials as an important step forward in bringing war criminals in the Balkan conflict to justice.         The suspect, Gen. Tihomir Blaskic, is the only Bosnian Croat officer under indictment by the International War Crimes Tribunal in The Hague. The extradition of such a high-level suspect could signal a new willingness by Croatia to cooperate with the tribunal.

headline: Rich Nations See Slowdown In Economies As Temporary
abstract: Top financial officials of the world's seven richest industrial democracies decided today that a slowdown in economic growth in Europe and the United States was probably only temporary and that existing policies were enough to insure continued recovery.         "We concluded that despite a temporary slowdown of activity in most of our countries in recent months, the underlying conditions for sustained recovery are in place," the French Finance Minister, Jean Arthuis, said in words that were substantially repeated by his American, German and other counterparts.

headline: Microsoft Sets A Revamping To Gain Edge On the Internet
abstract: The Microsoft Corporation plans to announce a company-wide reorganization today to strengthen its focus in both the interactive computing market and its traditional operating systems business.         The moves are aimed, in part, at placing Microsoft in a position to dominate  the next wave of the computer business that will be based on interactive technologies, now primarily on the Internet, just as it dominates personal computer software. Interactive technology is an expanding market in which Microsoft is perceived in the industry to be trailing the Netscape Communications Corporation.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;RIVAL AGREES TO ACQUIRE BIONAIRE FOR $24 MILLION
abstract: The Rival Company, based in Kansas City, Mo., has agreed to acquire Bionaire  Inc., a Canadian maker of air purifiers and humidifiers, for $24 million. Rival, a maker of small household and personal-care appliances, said it would pay about $1.65 a share for Montreal-based Bionaire, to increase its focus on home environmental products. Rival said it hopes to close the deal early next month.

headline: Law Knows No City Limits;As New York's Firms Thin Out, Outsiders Rush In
abstract: Reed Smith Shaw & McClay, a 118-year-old Pittsburgh law firm, had consciously avoided the costs and competition in New York. Last year it hired an international lawyer, Alan A. D'Ambrosio, away from the New York firm of Schnader Harrison Segal & Lewis and put him in charge of a new Reed Smith office in Manhattan. "We realized that we could never get a reputation in the international arena without a New York office," said David W. Christopher, Reed Smith's chief administrative officer.         Pitney, Hardin, Kipp & Szuch, a 150-lawyer firm in Morristown, N.J., opened a tiny New York office two years ago to serve one domestic client. Now it is expanding that office, in hopes of wooing foreign business. "Offshore clients won't even consider you unless you are in New York," said Clyde A. Szuch, a partner.

headline: NATO Urged to Keep Force In Bosnia After Pullout Date
abstract: As warnings mount that the fragile Bosnian peace could collapse without the presence of NATO peacekeepers, international civilian and military authorities here have begun to press for keeping at least a reduced NATO force in Bosnia beyond the currently scheduled departure at the end of this year.         While the Clinton Administration continues to insist that all 20,000 American troops will be out of Bosnia only nine months from now, key officials here say the delicate tasks of resettling refugees and rebuilding the country are likely  to fail without the security of outside peacekeepers. The NATO-led international force, known as IFOR, totals about 60,000 troops.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Maybelline's new campaign stresses the cosmetics industry's latest credo: The meek need not apply.
abstract: AN extensive campaign for Maybelline Inc. that begins tomorrow is going to roar "Great!" almost as often as Tony the Tiger does.         Maybelline, the No. 2 brand of mass-market cosmetics behind Cover Girl, will  present a series of energetic television commercials and print advertisements declaring Maybelline products to be "Just the latest and the greatest." The campaign, with an estimated budget of $35 million, features the models Christy Turlington and Bridget Hall, who have been given the monikers of "Maybelline Greats."

headline: Even With Peace and Rain, Ethiopia Fears Famine
abstract: Ethiopia's farmers recently finished harvesting the biggest crop the country  has seen in a decade. The rains were plentiful and, most important, there was peace and stability.         Yet the Ethiopian Government has appealed for 250,000 tons of food aid for 1996 to feed about three million of its people. Though the appeal will be for less than the 400,000 tons of food aid delivered last year, the famine of 1984-85, in which more than a million people died, remains a specter for Ethiopia.

headline: AT&T Acquisition, Soon to Be Spun Off, Regains NCR Name
abstract: Four years after it was gobbled up by the AT&T Corporation for $7.5 billion and renamed, the NCR Corporation got its name back yesterday -- the first step toward being cut loose from what has turned out to be a disastrous relationship.         AT&T, which acquired NCR in September 1991 after a long, hostile takeover battle, never really combined the strengths it had envisioned between computers  and communications. Instead, it found itself saddled with a company with plunging profit and stalled sales.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;GAMING COMPANIES ADJUST TERMS OF MERGER AGREEMENT
abstract: The Alliance Gaming Corporation and Bally Gaming International Inc. amended the terms of their merger agreement yesterday to assure that the combined company has enough cash to fuel growth. Under the amended agreement, Bally shareholders will receive a combination of cash and Alliance preferred and common stock totaling $11.70 per Bally share, the two Las Vegas-based companies  said. The original agreement valued Bally Gaming at about $13 a share. Bally Gaming, the world's largest maker of casino gambling equipment, agreed to a takeover by Alliance in October after fighting the bid for months.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS;Bond Prices Rise, Retaking Some Ground
abstract: Prices of Treasury securities regained some ground yesterday in choppy trading after a big decline on Wednesday. Traders cited a number of positive factors, including the belief by many investors that a balanced budget agreement can be reached.         The price of the 30-year bond rose 20/32, to 109 29/31 to yield 6.14 percent, down from 6.18 percent on Wednesday.

headline: World News Briefs;New Leader Pledges Vote in Sierra Leone
abstract: Sierra Leone's new leader, who took over in a bloodless coup on Tuesday, is committed to holding multi-party elections on Feb. 26, as planned, a Government  spokesman said today.

headline: France to Miss '95 Deficit Target 'by Just a Little Bit'
abstract: PARIS—  France will miss its 1995 budget deficit target of 322 billion francs, but it will stay within a "reasonable" distance, according to Finance Minister Jean Arthuis.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;$87 MILLION DEAL IS SET FOR TODAY'S BANCORP
abstract: Mercantile Bancorporation Inc., a bank holding company in St. Louis, said yesterday that it would acquire Today's Bancorp Inc. of Freeport, Ill., for $87.3 million in stock and cash. Today's Bancorp has about $518 million in assets and operates two banks, with 12 offices, in northwestern Illinois. Mercantile has assets of $18 billion and is based in St. Louis. It operates banks in Missouri, Iowa, Kansas, Illinois and Arkansas and provides brokerage services, asset-based lending, investment advisory services and credit life insurance. The shares of Today's Bancorp were up $2.875, at $29.625, in Nasdaq trading. Mercantile's stock was up 25 cents, at $45.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Nintendo Postpones New Game Machine
abstract: The Nintendo Company said today that it would postpone the introduction of its new 64-bit game machine in Japan until June 23.         The company had previously set April 21 as the introduction date for the machine, the Nintendo 64. Nintendo said the delay was necessary because not enough semiconductors would be available to have 500,000 of the machines ready for sale in April. The company said 500,000 was its estimate of initial demand.

headline: FROM THE DESK OF: VALERIE FOLEY;No Credit Where It Is Due
abstract: IF there is any other woman on the face of the planet who has ever had an income exceeding the old standard of $1,000 for each year of age, more than a year's salary in savings and an excess of $10,000 in material assets with no outstanding debt since 1980, but was still unable to get a bank to trust her with a credit card, I would like to meet her to commiserate.        In 1977, I did get a credit card at a department store where I worked. For purchases elsewhere, I relied on my husband's Mastercharge (the predecessor to Mastercard), which he had received unsolicited during the early heady days of charge-card expansion.

headline: NATO Limits Policing Role
abstract: NATO troops enforcing peace in Bosnia lack the manpower to insure the free movement of civilians across ethnic front lines and will not get involved in local police work, their ground commander said today.         Lieut. Gen. Sir Michael Walker defended NATO's security policy in Bosnia after the release of 16 Muslims abducted by Serbs when they tried to leave Sarajevo on routes patrolled by alliance troops last week.

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;U.N. Says Afghans Face Food Shortages
abstract: The besieged residents of Kabul face a dire shortage of food unless new supplies reach the freezing Afghan capital soon, a United Nations official said  today.         Martin Barber, the coordinator for the United Nations aid program in Afghanistan, warned in an interview that food stocks in Kabul would run out in two weeks unless routes into the city could be reopened.

headline: Cardinal Scherer, 93, Brazil Conservative
abstract: Alfredo Vicente Cardinal Scherer, one of the leaders of the Roman Catholic Church's conservative wing in the 1960's and 70's, died on Saturday in the southern Brazilian city of Porto Alegre. He was 93.         He became a Roman Catholic priest in Rome in 1926 and a Bishop in 1946 and was nominated a Cardinal by Pope Paul VI in 1969. Cardinal Scherer retired as leader of the Porto Alegre archdiocese in 1981.

headline: South Africa Journal;Sporting Life Thrives On Beer and Cigarettes
abstract: And you thought the D Train was tough.         The Johannesburg Railway Station doesn't just forbid smoking. The long menu of slashed red "No" circles also specifically bans axes, assault rifles and Zulu war clubs.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Unemployment in Germany Rose to 9.9% in December
abstract: Germany endured a barrage of negative economic news today -- in particular, that unemployment soared in December -- creating a sense of gloom that has not been seen since the country began to climb out of its worst postwar recession more than two years ago.         And if the conventional wisdom is true that as the German economy goes, so goes Europe, the reports mean that much of the Continent this year will see little growth, rising unemployment, depressed business and consumer activity, and a further falling behind the United States.

headline: Three Views, No Agreement
abstract: IS a recession coming? How much will the Fed ease, and what will that do for  the stock and bond markets? During a week in which the Fed cut short-term interest rates a bit, and which ended with a surprisingly weak employment report, we put the questions to three leading Wall Street economists -- Stephen  S. Roach of Morgan Stanley; Philip Braverman of DKB Securities, a part of Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank of Japan, and Robert J. Barbera of Capital Investments International. We found big disputes on the past as well as the future, with one panel member saying workers were going to start scoring big wage gains and another arguing that workers had not done that badly in recent years, whatever the statistics say.      Q. The European economy seems to be weak. Christmas sales were atrocious in this country. Is there a danger that we're going to have an election-year recession?

headline: Plane in Zaire Hits Market, Killing 250
abstract: A cargo plane crashed into a crowded market in the center of Kinshasa, the capital, today, killing at least 250 people, rescuers said.         Most of the victims were women and children crowded together at the market, made up of corrugated iron and wooden shacks. The number of injured was difficult to determine, rescuers said.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: AMERICAN MOBILE SATELLITE CORP., Reston, Va., said it planned to raise about $130 million in a public offering of up to 4.6 million common shares.

headline: World News Briefs;Zaire Plans to Close Rwanda Refugee Camps
abstract: Zaire said today that it would gradually begin closing 40 camps holding a million Rwandan refugees, prompting some refugees to leave the camp that is expected to be shut down first.         "We will close the camp," Interior Minister Gustave Malumba Mbangula said, referring to the settlement at Kibumba that some refugees began leaving today. "When the camp is closed we will proceed to close another camp. The operation will continue until all camps are closed and all refugees go home."

headline: Ford Offers Taurus Designed for Japan
abstract: The Ford Motor Company said today that it expected to increase its car sales  in Japan with a new model: a United States-built Taurus with right-hand drive and features specifically for the Japanese market.         The Taurus model, made at a Ford plant in Atlanta, went on sale today in Japan at prices from 2.49 million yen ($23,990), well below Japanese brands in the same class.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;RTZ-CRA Profits Rose 8.3% in 1995
abstract: The RTZ Corporation and CRA Ltd., which combined into the world's largest mining company, reported yesterday that the merged concern had an 8.3 percent rise in after-tax profits in 1995, helped by higher aluminum prices. RTZ-CRA earned $1.29 billion, up from $1.19 billion in 1994. Sales rose 12 percent, to $8.90 billion.          Leon Davis, chief operating officer of RTZ-CRA, said he expected this year's earnings to exceed 1995's if prices at least hold steady. The two companies, RTZ of Britain and CRA of Australia, merged on Dec. 21 but remain as separately  listed stocks. The combined company is controlled by a single board.   (AP)

headline: Funeral Chain Settles, Avoiding a Big Bill
abstract: The Loewen Group said yesterday that it had agreed to settle a Mississippi lawsuit that it said would have pushed the company toward bankruptcy. The suit was settled for cash and stock valued at $175 million.         Shares of Loewen, a Canadian funeral home chain, surged after the settlement  was announced. In Nasdaq trading, the stock rose $8.50, or 41 percent yesterday, to $29. On the Toronto Stock Exchange, Loewen shares rose $12.25 (Canadian), to $40 (Canadian.)

headline: Ex-Orange County Official in Settlement
abstract: The former assistant treasurer of Orange County, Matthew Raabe, has agreed to a settlement with the Securities and Exchange Commission, his lawyer said today.         Mr. Raabe, who was indicted by a county grand jury last year for his involvement in the largest municipal failure in United States history, has agreed to sign an agreement with the S.E.C. that will bar him from engaging in fraudulent conduct in the sale of securities in the future, his lawyer, Gary Pohlson, said.

headline: BOMBINGS IN ISRAEL: THE SCENE;For Rescuers, It Was 'Entering Gates of Hell'
abstract: The woman in the red sweater was frantic.         Running down a street toward the twisted remains of the bus that was bombed today by a suicide attacker, she pleaded with police officers for information about a relative she feared had been aboard.

headline: 3 NATO Soldiers Killed
abstract: Two Portuguese soldiers and one Italian were killed in an accidental explosion in Sarajevo today, the first deaths among NATO troops in Bosnia since  they arrived last month.         Six Italians and one Portuguese were wounded in the blast, which was caused by "some form of unexploded ordnance," Lieut. Col. Iacono Salvatore said in a statement.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Taiwan Will Add To Stabilization Fund
abstract: Taiwan's Cabinet has tentatively lined up $150 billion (new Taiwan), or $5.4  billion (United States), to add to a stabilization fund to support stock prices  if military tension with China persists after this month. The Cabinet persuaded  a group of insurers, banks and other financial institutions last month to purchase up to $200 billion (new Taiwan) worth of shares if stocks fell amid rising military tension with China.          About $50 billion (new Taiwan) of the $200 billion has been used, said Thomas Yeh, a spokesman for the Council for Economic Planning and Development, the Cabinet agency overseeing the plan.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: Mattel Seeks Hasbro but Is Rebuffed
abstract: In a move that stunned the toy industry, Mattel Inc. said yesterday that it had offered to buy Hasbro Inc. and that Hasbro's board had rejected the overture.         The offer, in Mattel stock valued at $5.2 billion, would merge the nation's two largest toy manufacturers, bringing together a host of products that are household names, from Barbie dolls to G. I. Joe and Scrabble, Monopoly, Mr. Potato Head, and Cabbage Patch dolls.

headline: Australia Pushes Compromise For Treaty to Ban Atom Tests
abstract: With only a month left to finish most of the drafting of a treaty banning nuclear testing worldwide, the Conference on Disarmament in Geneva has been given fresh momentum by Australia, which proposed a compromise text that tries to close gaps on several important issues.         "Concern is widespread in Geneva and in capitals that the opportunity to complete and sign a treaty this year is slipping away," said Michael Costello, Secretary of Australia's Foreign Ministry, as he presented the proposal. "We need a new momentum. The negotiations have reached a critical point."

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: AGRIBIOTECH INC., Las Vegas, Nev., a farming equipment company, named Henry Ingalls chief financial officer and vice president.

headline: Drug Makers' Pricing Policies Are Raising More Objections
abstract: The prices that drug companies charge to community drugstores drew increasing scrutiny from all three branches of the Federal Government yesterday.         In the executive branch, the Federal Trade Commission began subpoenaing the pricing records of 22 drug companies in an investigation of possible price-fixing that was ordered by the five F.T.C. commissioners on March 14.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Stock Market Extends Record-Breaking Advance Record highs have had no chance to grow old in this stock market: the Dow Jones  industrial average broke its previous record close every day this week. The Dow  rose a total of 167.63 points, the most points ever in a week for the closely watched index.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;SUNAMERICA TO BUY ANNUITY CONTRACTS FROM BENEFICIAL
abstract: SunAmerica Inc. said yesterday that its SunAmerica Life Insurance unit had agreed to buy the $950 million annuity portfolio of the Central National Life Insurance Company of Omaha, a unit of the Beneficial Corporation. The purchase price was not disclosed. Central National will transfer about 45,000 single- and flexible-premium fixed annuity contracts, held mainly in New Jersey, Pennsylvania and North Carolina. The purchase, along with other recently announced acquisitions, will add about $4.5 billion in assets to Los Angeles-based SunAmerica, bringing its total assets to nearly $34 billion.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;NORTHWEST AIRLINES AGREES TO AIRBUS ORDER
abstract: In its first major aircraft purchase since it went public two years ago, Northwest Airlines said yesterday that it had a memorandum of understanding with Airbus Industrie for a new order of 20 Airbus A320 planes. Northwest, based in St. Paul, did not disclose the value of the purchase, but it is expected to be $500 million or more. Northwest also said it had delayed delivery on 16 long-range Airbus A330 planes. Under the Airbus agreement, Northwest would take delivery of 10 A320's in 1998 and 10 more in 1999. It now operates a fleet  of 50 A320's.

headline: Stake in McDonald's May Be Buffett Boon
abstract: The multibillionaire investor Warren E. Buffett may have added more than another hundred million dollars to his portfolio if he still owns the stake of seven-tenths of 1 percent in the McDonald's Corporation that he held at the end  of 1994.         A Securities and Exchange Commission filing that was kept confidential until  Tuesday shows that Mr. Buffet owned 4.92 million common shares in the company as of Dec. 31, 1994. Under S.E.C. regulations, investors can request confidential treatment of their filings, allowing them to keep the document from public view  for a year.

headline: Offer of New Bangladesh Election Fails to Solve Political Crisis
abstract: A bitter power struggle between the two main political parties in Bangladesh  took a new turn today when Prime Minister Khaleda Zia, yielding to months of protests and strikes, offered to step down in favor of a "non-party" government  that would conduct a new election.         Mrs. Zia made the offer as concern mounted over the possibility of a military coup. For months, top generals have watched uneasily as the confrontation between the governing Bangladesh National Party and the opposition Awami League  has paralyzed the economy and prompted widespread violence. Last week, the Awami League announced plans for an economic shutdown to begin next Saturday if its demand for a general election under a neutral caretaker government is not met.

headline: Lawsuits to End All Lawsuits;Settlements May Limit Victims' Future Right to Sue
abstract: Imagine you are diagnosed with a disease linked to a toxic substance, but then discover you can't sue its manufacturer. The reason: A lawsuit settled years earlier limited your ability to do so, even though you never heard about the deal or met the lawyers who made fortunes supposedly representing you.         In a country where thousands of lawsuits are filed daily, the prospect might  seem farfetched. But it is one that is increasingly being played out in courts nationwide.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;British Water Company Is Target of Bidding
abstract: Shares in Britain's South West Water surged yesterday after Severn Trent P.L.C., another regional water company, said it would seek clearance from Britain's Monopolies and Mergers Commission to make a cash bid for the company.  The move followed an announcement by Wessex Water on March 7 that it intended to bid for South West Water. Wessex Water said it would not provide details of its  offer until a regulatory review could be carried out.          South West Water advised shareholders to take no action concerning the planned Wessex bid and it made no immediate comment on the announcement by Severn Trent. Shares of South West Water rose 44 pence, to 659 pence, on the London Stock Exchange. Severn, whose shares fell 19 pence, to 617 pence, said it would decide on the size of any offer only after getting the necessary regulatory approvals.   (Reuters)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Pilkington to Revamp Its Glass Operations
abstract: Pilkington P.L.C. announced plans yesterday to restructure its glass-making operations worldwide and cut 1,900 jobs. The company cited weak European construction markets and the recent strike at North American plants of the General Motors Corporation. As a major G.M. supplier, the Pilkington unit LOF was forced to temporarily lay off 1,000 workers.          Pilkington said the revamping included its automotive glass-making plants in the United States and its building products business in Germany. It was not immediately clear if any of the job cuts would be in the United States. The company said it expected a one-time charge of L155 million ($236 million) to cover the job cuts and an asset write-off of L85 million million.   (Reuters)

headline: Right's Rise Confronts Austria With Its Nazi Past
abstract: Late last September, under the guise of a war veterans' get-together, a group called Kameradschaft 4, or Comradeship 4, organized a gathering of supporters from across Europe in the small southern Austrian village of Kumpendorf. It was  no ordinary reunion.         The guests were predominantly former members of the Waffen SS, the military arm of the Nazi SS. The guest speaker, who lauded his listeners as "decent people," was Jorg Haider, the leader of Austria's right-wing Freedom Party, the  third biggest in the country.

headline: INVESTING IT;Bre-X Has a Cinderella Story to Tell
abstract: THREE years ago Bre-X Minerals Ltd., then operating out of the basement of its president, David Walsh, paid $80,000 (Canadian) for mineral rights to 475,000 acres near Busang in northeast Borneo.         What has happened since has become a Cinderella story of investing. Underneath the hilly rain forest, Bre-X made one of the largest gold strikes of  this century, sending its penny stock to $148 (Canadian) a share and Bre-X from  the basement to an office building in Calgary, Alberta.

headline: Japanese Try to Reach 20 Trapped in a Road Tunnel
abstract: Rescue workers blasted the side of a mountain with dynamite today in an unsuccessful attempt to reach some 20 people trapped in a collapsed highway tunnel. They said they would try again.         A giant slab of rock, about the size of a 20-story office building, had peeled off the mountain and crashed through the tunnel roof early Saturday, apparently crushing a bus carrying people, including a group of teen-agers, to nearby Sapporo for an annual snow festival.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS;Expectations Of Rate Cuts Lift Bonds
abstract: With the bond market still holding fast to its expectations of further interest-rate cuts by the Federal Reserve, prices of Treasury securities moved higher yesterday, with a weak regional report on business conditions generating  only a muted response.         Prices rose early as traders anticipated a flow of cash into short-term Treasuries from investors taking profits on the recent gains in the stock market. This forced traders short-selling the bonds -- that is, betting against  the market -- to buy Treasuries instead, to either take profit or limit losses.  At the same time rumors of a hedge fund buying three-year notes helped keep prices generally higher.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Time Life Names President and Chief
abstract: Time Life Inc., the direct marketing unit of Time Inc. that sells books, videotapes and recorded music, yesterday named George Artandi to be president and chief executive. He will be based in New York and will continue as president and chief executive of another Time Inc. division, the Book-of-the-Month Club.          Mr. Artandi, 54, succeeds John M. Fahey Jr., 43, who has been based at the Time Life headquarters in Alexandria, Va. Time Inc., which is owned by Time Warner Inc., said Mr. Fahey was leaving to "explore career opportunities."

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;J. P. Morgan's Net Income Surged 90% in 4th Quarter
abstract: J. P. Morgan & Company said yesterday that net income jumped nearly 90 percent in the fourth quarter -- well above expectations -- as profits surged from trading, investment banking and other nonlending businesses.         Another big bank, the First Union Corporation, said that operating earnings rose 21 percent in the quarter but that net income, which reflected charges related to its acquisition of First Fidelity Bancorp of Newark, declined.

headline: STREET SMARTS;When Investors Leap, Then Look
abstract: A NEW year offers an opportunity for a fresh beginning, a chance to seek success without being weighed down by the mishaps of the previous 12 months.         At least, that's what the New Year's cliches say. Of course, the opposite is  also true: A new year offers everyone who has done well for 12 months an opportunity to blow it.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Ragu Sauce Account Is Placed in Review
abstract: The Van den Bergh Foods Company unit of Unilever, the British-Dutch consumer  products giant, said yesterday that it had placed in review the account of its Ragu line of pasta sauces. The account, with billings estimated at $20 million,  has been handled by J. Walter Thompson New York for the last eight years.         "We're at a point where it's appropriate for us to evaluate our marketing approaches," Simon J. Rothon, executive vice president at Van den Bergh in Trumbull, Conn., said in confirming a report this week in Adweek. Trade publications speculated last year that Thompson New York's hold on the account might be loosening.

headline: U.N. Prosecutor Asks Serbs to Hand Over War-Crimes Suspect
abstract: The United Nations prosecutor of war crimes in the former Yugoslavia asked Serbian officials today to hand over a soldier who is suspected of taking part in the massacre of thousands of Muslims last year in Srebrenica.         The prosecutor, Justice Richard Goldstone, is demanding the release of the soldier, Drazen Erdemovic, so he may testify in proceedings at the tribunal at The Hague. The soldier is said to have confessed to shooting scores of Muslims at the direct order of his superiors, and to have witnessed his fellow Bosnian Serb officers hurling hand grenades into a building where hundreds of Muslims were held prisoner.

headline: Clothes You Gave Away Are a Hot Item in Africa
abstract: Martin Eshitemi had to bargain hard for his latest sartorial acquisition, haggling a good 15 minutes with the owner of a wooden stall overflowing with shirts. When it was over, the taxi-driver paid $1.50 for his prize: a used T-shirt with the N.F.L. logo on the sleeve and Budweiser emblazoned across the chest.         "I don't know what Budweiser means," Mr. Eshitemi, 36, acknowledged as he stuffed the shirt into a plastic bag. "I bought it because I like foreign designs. I can't get these kinds of T-shirts in the local shops. I'm looking for some jeans to go with it."

headline: Arguing Over the Dawn of Cyberspace's 'Day' Book
abstract: Talk to the photojournalist and entrepreneur Rick Smolan and he will describe an ambitious and innovative undertaking that will occur on the Internet this Thursday. On that day, Mr. Smolan, who gained fame from his best-selling "Day in the Life" series of coffee-table books in the 1980's, is sending 100 photojournalists around the globe armed with conventional and digital cameras to document a day in the life of cyberspace.         Those images, of people and how their lives have been affected by access to the Internet, will then be sent digitally to San Francisco, where an army of editors, designers and technicians will create an instant book on the World Wide Web called "24 Hours in Cyberspace." Mr. Smolan calls the $5 million project the largest one-day on-line event ever on the Internet.

headline: World News Briefs;I.R.A. Says It Planted Bomb Found in London
abstract: The Irish Republican Army claimed responsibility today for planting a bomb in London on Thursday, less than a week after a bomb attack ended its 17-month cease-fire.         In a telephone call to the BBC, the I.R.A. said it had planted the bomb, found in a telephone booth in the heart of London's theater district. The device was defused by the police.

headline: Ex-Credit Suisse Official Charged in Theft
abstract: A former Credit Suisse executive has been charged with embezzling $331,100 from the bank before he was to take over its United States operations.         Peter R. Nardin secretly wired the money from Credit Suisse accounts to his personal bank accounts from August 1994 to November 1995, prosecutors charged in a criminal complaint filed in Federal court in New York.

headline: General Who Fled Goes Home to Iraq, Blessed by Hussein
abstract: The Iraqi general and son-in-law to Saddam Hussein who defected six months ago has returned to Iraq with President Hussein's blessing.         The general, Hussein Kamel, returned to Iraq yesterday from Jordan accompanied by his brother, Col. Saddam Kamel, the former head of Iraq's special forces, and their wives, both of whom are daughters of President Hussein.

headline: Jefferies Group Stock Split
abstract: Jefferies Group Inc., a Los Angeles-based brokerage firm, said today that its board had approved a 2-for-1 split on all outstanding shares. The split is payable March 29 to shareholders of record on March 15. The company said the board had approved continuation of the quarterly cash dividend rate of 5 cents a share on the approximately 12 million shares to be outstanding after the split.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                                               Previous      Year                               Yesterday       Day       Ago

headline: U.S. Sees Bosnia Role Widening To Protect War Crimes Inquiries
abstract: Signaling that NATO will soon broaden its duties in Bosnia, and clarifying American policy on a sensitive topic, Defense Secretary William J. Perry says that beginning later this month, American and other alliance troops will provide security for human rights investigators looking into evidence of war crimes in Bosnia.         Under the terms of the Balkan peace plan reached in November, the main military missions of the 60,000-member force are to supervise marking of cease-fire lines and to insure that rival forces withdraw from the lines.

headline: Mexican State Governor Tied to a Massacre of Peasants Quits
abstract: The powerful Governor of the state of Guerrero, Ruben Figueroa Alcocer, resigned today, bowing to pressures arising from the police massacre of 17 opposition peasants on a remote country road in the state last year.         Mr. Figueroa presented his written request for a permanent leave to the state Congress, saying he sought to ease the investigation into the case. Opposition parties have charged that Mr. Figueroa encouraged the killings and had a role in fabricating a crude cover-up.

headline: Stock Market Revives a Bit, With Dow Rising by 9.76
abstract: Stock prices advanced yesterday for the first time since Monday, after investors weighed the week's Government statistics and concluded that the economy was expanding moderately.         Volatility has contracted, with the range between the highs and lows of major indicators narrowing from the swings of early March. For the third consecutive day, turnover dropped below the three-month average.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;$605 MILLION PURCHASE OF FORUM GROUP PLANNED
abstract: Marriott International Inc. said yesterday that it would buy Forum Group Inc. for $605 million in cash and debt in a move that would make Marriott the nation's second-largest owner of housing communities for the elderly. Marriott,  which mainly manages hotels, now operates 27 elderly housing communities that offer residents private apartments, common dining facilities, on-site medical attention and recreational activities. Forum operates 42 similar facilities. Shareholders of Forum, based in Fairfax, Va., will receive $13 a share in cash,  or $302 million. Marriott will also take on $303 million of Forum's debt.

headline: 3 Britons Believed Killed by Bosnia Mine
abstract: Three British soldiers on a routine patrol in western Bosnia were presumed dead today after their vehicle was blown up in an unmarked minefield, and a 28-year-old American officer was shot in the neck and slightly wounded in the Serb-held Sarajevo suburb of Ilidza.    NATO spokesmen said the American officer, Second Lieut. Shawn H. Watts, 28, of Greenwood, Miss., was back on duty after being grazed by a sniper at 6 A.M. today.          The bullet struck him as he walked in the hotel complex used by NATO as its  ground force headquarters in Bosnia. Soldiers did not return fire.

headline: MUTUAL FUNDS;Lacking in Knowledge, Not in Confidence
abstract: Investors are becoming more confident about their abilities, according to a survey of 401(K) retirement plan participants conducted last year by the Gallup  organization for John Hancock Financial Services.      Nearly 70 percent of those surveyed said they had beome more knowledgeable about investing in the last year or two. And 70 percent agreed with financial advisers that it made sense to put some retirement money in stocks. Still, there was much they did not know.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;British and Japanese In Multimedia Venture
abstract: British Telecommunications P.L.C. and the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company said yesterday that they would develop multimedia products together. British Telecommunications and a unit of Matsushita that sells products under the Panasonic brand name said they would develop television set-top controllers  for on-line and broadcast subscription services, video-telephone semiconductor chips and video servers, for use in services like video on demand.          A British Telecommunications spokesman said that the two companies had signed a memorandum of understanding but that it was too early to give further details on how much they planned to invest or where the joint venture would be situated. He said, however, that the products would be sold worldwide.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: MARKET TIMING
abstract: Monday

headline: Lawsuit Is Filed In Cellular Fraud
abstract: Bell Atlantic Nynex Mobile has filed a Federal suit contending that two men swindled the company out of $130,965.         The company says Edward L. Harrison and Stephen T. Baldwin plucked nearly 40,000 cellular phone codes from the skies above Maryland and Pennsylvania, loaded the numbers into mobile phones and sold the phones on the streets of Baltimore. They are said to have sold about 100 phones each month, mostly to drug dealers.

headline: Teledyne Rejects New WHX Offer
abstract: Teledyne Inc. said last night that it was rejecting the WHX Corporation's latest merger offer, even though it had been sweetened to $1.78 billion, from $1.67 billion on Monday.         The company said the board had concluded that Teledyne "is worth far more than $32 a share," the level of the most recent offer from WHX.

headline: Treasury Schedules Regular Bill Sales
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.         By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.78 percent, traders said, while the six-month bill was at 4.71 percent.

headline: Panel Ruling Hurts Stock Of Genzyme
abstract: The shares of the Genzyme Corporation lost nearly 10 percent of their value yesterday after a scientific panel recommended that a new product be approved but that its use be limited to a narrower range than analysts had anticipated. The panel also expressed concerns about possible side effects.         The product, Seprafilm, is an absorbable membrane intended to prevent post-operative adhesions -- internal scar tissues that often develop after surgery, causing a harmful joining of tissues and organs.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Cuts by British Brewer
abstract: The British brewer Scottish and Newcastle P.L.C. said yesterday that about 1,600 jobs would be lost and two of the country's biggest breweries would close  as part of its integration of the Courage beer business. Scottish and Newcastle, which acquired Courage from the Australian company Foster's in August for L550 million, or $850 million, said it would close breweries in Halifax and Nottingham by October.   (Reuters)

headline: 16 Children Are Slain in Scotland As Gunman Storms Into a School
abstract: A man carrying four handguns stormed into a school here this morning and opened fire on a gym class filled with 5- and 6-year-olds, killing 16 children and a teacher, and reserving a final bullet to take his own life.         Twelve more children from Dun- blane Primary School were wounded, three critically, the police said.

headline: Rwanda Seeks Ex-Officer From Cameroon
abstract: Rwanda asked Cameroon today to extradite a former Rwandan army colonel accused of helping plan the 1994 killings of at least half a million people.         The former colonel, Theoneste Bagosora, was arrested in Yaounde, Cameroon on  Sunday. He is also wanted by Belgium for the slayings of 10 Belgians who were part of the United Nations peacekeeping force in Rwanda.

headline: Virgin Founder May Start Anew
abstract: The flamboyant British entrepreneur Richard Branson is looking to re-enter the music business, three and half years after selling his Virgin Records label  for $853 million.         "Richard's spoken to a number of people in the industry, and he's decided, 'Yes, we're going to look at it,' " a spokesman, Will Whitehorn, said this week.

headline: Burger King in Japan
abstract: Burger King is broadening its presence in Japan. Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., the conglomerate that owns Burger King, and Japan Tobacco Inc. said today that they would form a 50-50 joint venture to open 100 new Burger King restaurants in the Tokyo area by the end of the century.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;Salomon Earnings Declined From 3d Quarter to the 4th
abstract: Salomon Inc., the parent of Salomon Brothers, the beleaguered investment bank, reported a steep decline in profits yesterday from the third to the fourth quarter of last year.         Investors responded to the decline, largely attributable to the investment bank, by sending the parent company's stock down 87.5 cents, or 2.3 percent, to close at $36.625.

headline: Genesis Health Plans Sale
abstract: Genesis Health Ventures Inc. said today that it would sell four Indiana nursing homes and a related pharmacy to Hunter Acquisition L.L.C. for $22.3 million. The four homes operate about 635 skilled nursing beds and have annual revenue of about $21 million, Genesis said.

headline: Patents;Prodigy's patent is being debated as a possible threat to Sun Microsystems' Java language.
abstract: THE on-line world has been riddled with messages recently, debating whether a patent held by the Prodigy Services Company, the third-largest on-line service,  is a killer that would give Prodigy control over Java, Sun Microsystems Inc.'s new computer language.         The patent was issued on Sept. 13, 1994, and described the concept of sending chunks of computer code in small packages for use in a remote computer, much like the modular applications, or "applets," that can be written in Java.

headline: A Bulge on Croatia's Coast Is a Thorn in Serbia's Side
abstract: Its pine-covered rocky slopes blend casually into the cold, cobalt-blue Adriatic Sea as if the Prevlaka Peninsula were just another of the many small bulges along Croatia's coast.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;Aetna Posts Weaker Results for Quarter
abstract: The Aetna Life and Casualty Company yesterday reported weaker results for the fourth quarter and took a $218.1 million charge for asbestos cleanup claims in a unit it plans to sell.         While earnings rose nearly 10 percent in the quarter, to $175.7 million, or $1.53 a share, those results include its property and casualty businesses, which Aetna agreed in November to sell to Travelers Group Inc. for $4 billion. A year earlier, a loss from investment sales of $7.6 million and income from discontinued operations of $38.3 million resulted in net income of $160 million, or $1.42 a share.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;The country's biggest brewer renews its defense of that position.
abstract: ANHEUSER-BUSCH is seeking to regain momentum in the beer wars by undertaking  several marketing initiatives.         For one thing, Anheuser-Busch, the beer marketing unit of the Anheuser-Busch  Companies, is returning to Times Square with an oversized neon sign promoting its flagship Budweiser brand. And the company has expanded its relationship with Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco by designating that agency  to produce two unconventional corporate and product campaigns.

headline: Refco Settles Commodity-Pool Case by U.S.
abstract: Refco Inc. has agreed to pay a $925,000 civil fine as part of a settlement of charges that the firm failed to properly segregate funds in five German commodity pools, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission said today.         Refco, a huge futures broker based in Chicago, settled without admitting or denying the C.F.T.C.'s allegations.

headline: Primaries for Seats in Israeli Parliament Bring Some Surprises to BothMajor Parties
abstract: Israel's major political parties have chosen their slates for the May 29 elections, with both parties pushing former military men to the fore for a campaign that is likely to focus sharply on security issues.         The primary elections -- the governing Labor Party's on Monday and the opposition Likud's on Tuesday -- cleared the last formality before the start of  a campaign that many Israelis consider one of the most important in their history.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Gains Tax Defeated in Taiwan
abstract: The Parliament defeated legislation today that would have imposed a capital gains tax on profits from stock transactions, easing worries that institutional  investors would withdraw from the stock market.         The legislators also voted to leave the tax on stock transactions unchanged at three-tenths of 1 percent.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Philips Is Looking For Trims at Grundig
abstract: The Dutch giant Philips Electronics N.V. wants to cut at least 1,000 jobs this year at its unprofitable German consumer electronics company, Grundig A.G., Philips said yesterday. The cuts will come on top of 10,000 jobs that were eliminated at Grundig the last four years. Grundig employed 11,600 people at the end of last year.

headline: OUTLOOK '96: MARKETS AND INVESTING;Wall St. Takes a Shine to Fee-Based Businesses
abstract: ONCE considered too tame for Wall Street's gunslingers, businesses like asset management, global custody and clearing are being wooed by investment bankers with Romeo-like ardor.         And no wonder. These businesses are the industry equivalent of Valium. They are impervious to sudden drops in the Dow, increases in interest rates, rising unemployment, sinking consumer confidence and the various other uncontrollable factors that buffet the fortunes of securities firms. And they can, if properly  managed, produce fees year in and year out.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
abstract: The Bon Marche, Seattle, a division of Federated Department Stores, to McCann-Erickson Seattle, a unit of Interpublic Group, to handle the media part of its broadcast account, with billings estimated at $10 million. The media duties had been handled in-house; the creative part of the account will continue in-house. True Fitness Technology, O'Fallon, Mo., to TBWA Chiat/Day, St. Louis, a unit of  Omnicom Group, to handle national advertising for the maker of exercise treadmills, previously handled by Kupper Parker Communications, St. Louis. The billings were estimated at $1 million to $3 million.

headline: New Flexibility By Iraq on Oil Worries Market
abstract: After a five-year standoff, Iraq's willingness to hold talks with the United  Nations about selling oil for the purchase of food has raised prospects for an accord this year. But it could also provoke a sustained decline in oil prices, industry executives and analysts said today.         An expected surge in the supplies of crude oil would create havoc in world markets and within the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, some experts say.

headline: Senate Approves Compromise Bill Tightening Curbs on Cuba
abstract: The Senate moved today to punish the Cuban Government for its downing of two  American private aircraft last month, passing legislation that would tighten the embargo on American trade with Cuba and punish other countries that insisted on  continuing trade on their own.         The vote, on the final compromise version of legislation first approved by the House and Senate last fall, was 74 to 22. The compromise now goes to the House, which is expected to approve it later this week.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;U.S.-Japan Pact Reached In Dispute Over Air Cargo
abstract: The United States and Japan said today that they had reached an agreement on  air-cargo service, resolving one dispute that threatened to mar next month's summit meeting between President Clinton and Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto.         The agreement will expand the routes between and beyond the two countries, which are available to two Japanese airlines and to several American companies,  particularly the United Parcel Service of America. A formal accord will be drafted in Washington next month.

headline: Du Pont Joins Olin in Sale
abstract: The Olin Corporation and E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company said today that they had put their chlorine plant in Niagara Falls, N.Y., up for sale.         The two chemical companies started the Niachlor joint venture in 1987 to operate the chlorine and caustic soda plant. Each company owns half of the venture.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Lowe Awarded Baseball's Account
abstract: Major League Baseball in New York said yesterday that it had awarded Lowe & Partners/SMS its account, which had been handled by Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco. Advertising spending was estimated at $18 million, including spending by television stations that broadcast baseball games.         The decision came after a three-month review that had narrowed to four finalists, all of New York: Lowe, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies;  Partners & Shevack, owned by Mickelberry Communications; Serino Coyne Inc., and  Warwick Baker & Fiore. Goodby, Silverstein, part of the Omnicom Group, worked on a project during the 1994 baseball season before it was halted by a players' strike, and was named to handle the account in March 1995; the agency declined in mid-January to participate in the review. A campaign being created by Lowe, carrying the theme "What a game," will replace a Goodby, Silverstein campaign carrying the theme "Welcome to the show."

headline: Bellinzona Journal;Poor Swiss Get U.S. Bill: $125 Billion and Change
abstract: This is a town of steep lanes, floodlighted castles atop rocky outcroppings and thick Alpine mists. It finds relief from February's glumness mainly in weeklong Carnival festivities.         Relief is something the burghers of Bellinzona sorely need. Word belatedly got out in the fall that Ticino, the canton of which Bellinzona is the capital,  had been ordered by a court in New York to come up with $125 billion to pay American investors who say they lost their money when a tiny bank in Ticino, Inter Change Bank, failed nearly three decades ago.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;2 Canadian Banks Buy or Raise Stakes in Bancomer and Inverlat
abstract: Two of Canada's largest banks, the Bank of Montreal and the Bank of Nova Scotia, are betting on a recovery of Mexico's economy and currency by investing  in Mexican financial-services companies.         The Montreal institution, Canada's third-largest bank, said today that it would acquire a 16 percent equity interest and a 20 percent voting stake in Grupo Financiero Bancomer, Mexico's second-largest bank, for a price between $425 million and $475 million.

headline: Yeltsin's Assault on Chechens Meets Critics on Left and Right
abstract: If President Boris N. Yeltsin hoped that a last-minute show of force in the six-day hostage crisis in southern Russia would somehow quell his critics, he miscalculated.         By hints and recent personnel changes, President Yeltsin has been sounding more and more like a man preparing himself for a re-election bid. And that may help explain why, immediately after Russian troops began firing on the village of Pervomayskoye where 200 Chechen rebels held about 100 hostages, prominent political figures on his left and right began hammering at the President -- even before the toll was known.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;German Output Rises
abstract: German industrial output rose 1.3 percent in January from the year earlier, according to preliminary seasonally adjusted data released yesterday by the Economics Ministry. A 10.2 percent rise in production of capital goods offset declines in consumer goods and construction, the ministry said. December output, however, was revised to show a 1.1 decline from November and a 4.7 percent fall  from the month a year earlier. The ministry said it could not rule out a downward revision of the January data. Germany is in a pronounced economic slump, with 10.3 percent unemployment nationwide.   (Reuters)

headline: U.S. Describes Plan to Ease Israeli Curbs on West Bank and Gaza
abstract: Secretary of State Warren Christopher announced an emergency plan today to ease Israel's restrictions on Palestinians on the West Bank and the Gaza Strip.  His announcment came at the opening of a two-day conference of 27 nations on protecting Israel against terrorism.         Israel is to permit construction material and Egyptian trucks into the two areas, and citrus and other exports are to be shipped to the outside world from  Israel and Jordan.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;SHARES OF APPAREL DESIGNER, MOSSIMO, CLIMB SHARPLY
abstract: The stock of the apparel designer Mossimo Inc. closed sharply above its offering price yesterday in its first day of trading on the New York Stock Exchange. The company, a designer of jeans, shorts and other beach wear, based in Irvine, Calif., has long been hot among teen-age boys and the company will introduce a line of girls' clothes this fall.The three-million-share offering was priced at $18, well above the expected range of $14 to $16 a share. The stock closed at $25 after almost 3.7 million shares were traded, some of them more than once.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Russian Shepherd of Mutual Funds
abstract: When Dmitri V. Vasiliev was a student of Marxist economics, he was taught that the stock market was a casino for the super-rich.         "They stressed it served a narrow circle and was not in the interests of the  broad masses of people," Mr. Vasiliev recalled with a smile.

headline: Microsoft and DirecTV Form an Alliance
abstract: The Microsoft Corporation and the satellite broadcast system DirecTV said yesterday that they would collaborate to deliver digital entertainment and information services to personal computers within the year.         In addition to the 175 channels of entertainment, sports, music and information that DirecTV, a unit of General Motors' Hughes Electronics Corporation, now beams to 1.3 million homes equipped with 18-inch receiver dishes and television set-top boxes, The two companies said they would work with others to develop new forms of interactive, digital services that can be displayed on a television or a computer screen.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Trafalgar to Sell Unit
abstract: Trafalgar House P.L.C., the troubled British conglomerate, agreed yesterday to sell its British home construction business to Persimmon P.L.C. for L170 million, or about $255.6 million. The companies said earlier this month that they were having discussions. The sale of the unit, Ideal Homes, will end Trafalgar's involvement in residential construction. The company said in December that it would sell its house-building operations in the United States.   (Dow Jones)

headline: COMPANY NEWS;AFTER $2.5 BILLION INVESTMENT, MGM IS PUT UP FOR SALE
abstract: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Inc. was put up for auction yesterday, with bids expected from around the world for the resuscitated entertainment company. MGM's owner, Credit Lyonnais, which invested about $2.5 billion in the company, hired Lazard  Freres, the investment bankers, last November to study a sale. Published lists of potential bidders include Chargeurs S.A. of France, Polygram N.V. of the Netherlands, Bertelsmann A.G. of Germany, the Walt Disney Company, the General Electric Company and New Regency Productions. Bank and studio officials would not say what price MGM might fetch, but estimates ranged from $1.5 billion to $2 billion. Frank Mancuso, a onetime Paramount Pictures studio chief who transformed MGM into a box office contender over the last three years, also has  an option to put together a bid. MGM took in $333 million last year on 15 releases, for a 6.3 percent share of the domestic box office.

headline: Gyula Kallai, 85, Former Premier Of Hungary
abstract: Gyula Kallai, a Hungarian intellectual who shared the vagaries of postwar Communism at the side of Janos Kadar, the party chief installed after the 1956 uprising, died on March 12 after a long illness, news dispatches from Budapest reported. He was 85.         Mr. Kallai tried to balance his positions as a Hungarian patriot with the tenets of Marxism as laid down by Stalin and his successors in the Kremlin. He held various Cabinet portfolios in the Communist republic established in 1949 before being arrested with Mr. Kadar in 1951 as a "Titoist."

headline: COMPANY NEWS;TWO NEW FAMILIES OF WORK STATIONS ARE DISPLAYED
abstract: The Digital Equipment Corporation displayed two new families of work stations and new graphics for its machines yesterday in a bid to improve its fifth-place  market share. Digital Equipment, based in Maynard, Mass., said the new entry-level and midrange machines would offer more computing power for the money than its competitors. Work stations are powerful computers used by engineers, scientists and software programmers. Digital Equipment's new entry-level line, called the Alpha Station 255, consists of two models with prices starting at $7,399, the company said. The midlevel line, called Alpha Station 500, consists  of three models, with prices starting at $15,863.

headline: World News Briefs;Farrakhan, in Iran, Hails 17 Years of Islamic Rule
abstract: The Nation of Islam leader Louis Farrakhan attended a rally marking the 17th  anniversary of the Islamic revolution in Iran today in Teheran, the capital, and told the crowd their country had become a model religious democracy.         President Hashemi Rafsanjani, in a rare gesture to a foreign visitor, invited Mr. Farrakhan to sit next to him at the pavilion erected for the rally.

headline: The Master Builder of Malaysia;He Thrives With a Little Help From His Friends
abstract: It isn't often that across-the-board rejection by swaggering American and European investment banks warms a developer's heart. But Francis Yeoh Sock Ping acts as if it is the best thing that has ever happened.         Refusing to capitulate to the foreign bankers' terms for financing his 1,200-megawatt power project, Mr. Yeoh (pronounced YEOW) instead found a way to  borrow the $1.1 billion through Malaysian institutions. As a result, he said, he saved the project money and provided power for 25 percent less.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: TYLAN GENERAL INC., San Diego, a provider of equipment used in semiconductor manufacturing, agreed to buy Span Instruments Inc., a software maker in Plano, Tex., for an undisclosed amount of stock.

headline: Stocks Lower in Japan
abstract: Stocks traded lower here today. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues  was down 83.42 points, or four-tenths of 1 percent, at 20,802.77. On Thursday the index fell 57.40 points.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;MESA SAYS IT IS TALKING TO 3 COMPANIES ABOUT A DEAL
abstract: Mesa Inc. said yesterday that it was in discussions with three companies interested in buying assets or in making a deal that would infuse cash into Mesa, the debt-laden oil and natural gas company. After fielding interest from more than 100 companies last year in assets that include natural gas fields in the Hugoton basin in western Kansas, the company and its investment banker are negotiating with a final group of three, Mesa's chairman, T. Boone Pickens, said. He declined to identify the possible buyers. Mesa faces a June 30 deadline for payment on a portion of its $1.1 billion in debt and expects to complete a deal before then, Mr. Pickens said. The transactions being negotiated do not include an outright sale or merger of the entire company, which is based in Irving, Tex., a Mesa spokesman said.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Military Ruler Ousted By Army in Sierra Leone
abstract: Army officers ousted Sierra Leone's military leader in a coup today, six weeks before elections to restore civilian rule.         There were no reports of bloodshed, and the ousted leader, Capt. Valentine Strasser, was said to have been given safe passage to Guinea.

headline: Japan Premier Resigns in Sign Of a Party Shift
abstract: The abrupt resignation today of Prime Minister Tomiichi Murayama stunned Japan and triggered a political struggle that will lead not only to a new prime  minister but perhaps also to a major political realignment.         The resignation of Mr. Murayama, 71, who was regarded by much of the electorate as equally honorable and incompetent, is expected to lead to a generational shift toward younger and more dynamic leaders.

headline: World News Briefs;Yeltsin and Kohl Discuss Investment and NATO
abstract: President Boris N. Yeltsin met today with Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany for talks on Mr. Yeltsin's efforts to win re-election, the decline of German business interests in Russia and the expansion of NATO.         Mr. Yeltsin said after the meeting that German businesses are waiting to see  who wins the election in June. Communists and nationalists effectively won December's parliamentary elections.

headline: Wells Fargo Wins Battle for First Interstate
abstract: Winning a bitter four-month hostile takeover battle, Wells Fargo & Company said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the First Interstate Bancorporation for $11.6 billion, the most ever paid for an American bank.         In reluctantly agreeing to the unsolicited bid, First Interstate broke off its $10 billion engagement to First Bank System of Minneapolis, a white knight that promised to preserve more jobs for employees, including those of executives at First Interstate's Los Angeles headquarters.

headline: U.S. Cites Cuban Retraction on Shootdown
abstract: A display of American intelligence data apparently persuaded Cuba to drop its claim that the two unarmed civilian planes it shot down last month were in its airspace, Administration officials said today.         A national security official at the White House said that during a New York City meeting in late February, senior officials of the Central Intelligence Agency showed Cuban intelligence officers "evidence that the shootdown did take  place in international airspace."

headline: COMPANY NEWS;PHYSICIAN COMPUTER IN VENTURE WITH GLAXO WELLCOME
abstract: The Physician Computer Network Inc. and Glaxo Wellcome Inc. said yesterday that they had formed a 50-50 joint venture to provide information technology systems and services to the health care industry. Physician Computer said both companies contributed product and development assets to the venture and would contribute at least $50 million more in capital, with $43 million coming from Glaxo Wellcome. The venture, not yet named, will be operated independently of the parent companies, Physician Computer said. Physician Computer makes network  computer systems for health care providers. Glaxo Wellcome is a unit of Glaxo Wellcome P.L.C. of Britain.

headline: U.S. Sending Envoys to Seek Peace in Armenian-Held Region
abstract: The Clinton Administration has begun an unusually high-level effort to settle the bitter war over Nagorno-Karabakh, a disputed enclave of ethnic Armenians in  Azerbaijan, and to help make the region safe for oil development, American officials said today.         The deputy national security adviser, Sandy Berger, and the Deputy Secretary  of State, Strobe Talbott, have been dispatched to Azerbaijan and Armenia for talks this week.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Knight-Ridder Tries To Sell Cable Stake
abstract: Knight-Ridder Inc. is negotiating to get out of cable television by selling its share in TKR Cable to its partner, Tele-Communications Inc.         Both Knight-Ridder and TKR confirmed the talks today after a report in The Wall Street Journal but said proposed terms of payment to Tele-Communications have not been established.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: 'American Flyer' Trains Planned for Northeast Moving decisively to upgrade train service in the Northeast and challenge the airlines, Amtrak chose the contractors to build a $611 million fleet of "American Flyers" that will dramatically cut train travel time between Washington and Boston. The top speed of the new trains, the first of which is to be delivered in 1999, is 150 miles an hour -- 25 miles an hour faster than trains that now travel between New York and Washington, and 50 miles an hour faster than between New York and Boston.

headline: Suzanne Prou, 75, French Novelist and Activist
abstract: Suzanne Prou, a French novelist and militant opponent of anti-Semitism, died  in Paris, where she lived, during the night of Dec. 29-30. She was 75.         Le Monde reported her death on Tuesday, without giving its cause, and called  her "a novelist of bittersweet nostalgia."

headline: COMPANY NEWS;I.B.M. REPORTED READY TO REPLACE BUTTERFLY NOTEBOOK
abstract: The International Business Machines Corporation is considering abandoning its best-selling Butterfly notebook computer and replacing it with a new ultra-lightweight, much more powerful model, analysts and retailers said yesterday. The computer, a Thinkpad notebook that got its nickname for its two-part expandable keyboard, was introduced by the I.B.M. PC Company in March and racked up the most first-day sales of any product in the unit's history. "If you don't see Butterfly anymore, it'll be because you'll see something better," a company spokesman, Mike Corrado, said, adding that I.B.M. had not made a decision.

headline: To Retain Momentum, Peres May Call Israeli Elections by May
abstract: Israel's major newspapers all reported today that Prime Minister Shimon Peres had all but decided to advance national elections to May and that he would make  the announcement within two weeks.         Mr. Peres evidently reached the decision at an international economic meeting in Davos, Switzerland, after concluding that no breakthrough was imminent in the talks with Syria and that his chances of victory would diminish with time.

headline: Economic Scene;Paying to pollute: a free market solution that's yet to be tested.
abstract: THE 1990 amendments to the Clean Air Act give electric power companies the right to pay to pollute, much the way sinners bought indulgences in the Middle Ages. Yet although the trading of sulfur emissions between utilities is now permitted, there is not much activity in this market, and prices of marketable permits are far below initial projections. Does that mean the system is not working -- that free market environmentalism is being sabotaged by myopic corporate executives or hostile state regulators?         According to the latest studies, the answer is both cheerier and more complicated. So far, it seems, trading among utilities has not been needed to meet Federal standards. Indeed, A. Denny Ellerman, director of the Center for Energy and Environmental Policy at M.I.T., argues that thanks to the plunging price of low-sulfur coal "compliance has been essentially free" in some parts of the country.

headline: Killings in Croatia
abstract: The Security Council expressed concern today at reports of isolated killings  and human rights abuses in areas of Croatia recaptured last year from Serb control.         In a statement today, it called on the Croatian Government to insure the security and well-being of the Serb minority in the territory and to prosecute those suspected of offenses.

headline: Microsoft and BET Form Joint Venture
abstract: The Microsoft Corporation and Black Entertainment Television said today that  they were beginning a joint venture that at first would provide entertainment and news for black Americans on the Internet.         The Microsoft-Black Entertainment Television alliance is the latest in a series of ventures the software giant has announced with other broadcasters and  media companies to distribute their products on the global computer network.

headline: Dreamworks In New Alliance
abstract: Dreamworks SKG said today that it was acquiring a 40 percent stake in Pacific Data Images, a closely held computer animation company. Financial terms were not disclosed.         Dreamworks, the Hollywood studio formed two years ago by Steven Spielberg, Jeffrey Katzenberg and David Geffen, said it had also committed to begin production on a feature-length computer-animated film, using Pacific Data's proprietary state-of-the-art technology.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Lowe Gets Account From Time Warner
abstract: Time Warner Inc. and units of Nike Inc. and Pepsico Inc. have made decisions  involving accounts.         Time Warner in New York selected Lowe & Partners/SMS in New York as the first agency to handle its corporate image advertising account, with billings estimated at $10 million. Lowe, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, was awarded the account after a six-to-eight-week review that also included undisclosed agencies.

headline: Sturdy Advance by Stocks Halts a Two-Day Selloff
abstract: The stock market rebounded yesterday from the debacle of the previous two days, despite three rounds of computer-guided sell orders.         "Today's up move is simply a reaction to the oversold condition created by Tuesday's and Wednesday's 164-point decline in the Dow," said Jerry Hegarty, a market analyst at Thomson Research. "The transition of funds from high-tech stocks into large-cap stocks appears to be over."

headline: FUTURES MARKETS;Heating Oil Prices Keep Rising As Cold Weather Persists in East
abstract: Heating oil and natural gas drove commodity prices higher yesterday for the fourth consecutive session, as unseasonably cold weather in the Eastern United States suggested increased demand at a time of low inventories.         Crude oil prices also rose, bolstered by increased speculation that Iraq and  the United Nations would not agree soon on a proposal to allow limited Iraqi sales of oil for the purchase of food and medicine. The Commodity Research Bureau index of 17 commodities gained 1.1 points, to 246.47. On other commodities markets, pork bellies rose.

headline: Forte Moves To Thwart Granada Bid
abstract: Forte P.L.C., the British hotel company, began a further, aggressive effort today to thwart a hostile takeover bid by the Granada Group.         Forte, which is resisting a bid valued at L3.3 billion, or $5.1 billion, said it would raise its dividend for the first time in five years, buy back shares worth L800 million and spin off its stake in the Savoy hotels of London.

headline: 2 Holders Sell Stake In Czech Chemicals
abstract: Stratton Investments and the Czech investment company Harvard Capital and Consulting have sold their stakes in Spolana Neratovice A.S., a Czech chemical company, to Chemapol A.S.         Stratton, which is based in Prague, and Harvard together held a 30 percent share in Spolana.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;U.S. SATELLITE BROADCASTING'S STOCK GAINS
abstract: The stock of the U.S. Satellite Broadcasting Corporation rose strongly yesterday in its first day of trading after the company, a direct-broadcast TV concern, offered 8.3 million shares to the public. Initially priced at $27, the  shares closed at $34.75 after 6.8 million were traded on the Nasdaq market. U.S. Satellite Broadcasting came to market just after the AT&T Corporation and the MCI Communications Corporation had marked satellites as the preferred method for information delivery in the future. U.S. Satellite Broadcasting has 14 movie channels and 6 channels of basic service. It had 628,000 subscribers at the end  of 1995. Revenues is running at $182 million a year, and the company has posted  losses since it was formed in 1993.

headline: Colombia's Chief Is Charged But a Tangled Inquiry Looms
abstract: The patio was radiant with Andean sun, wineglasses were clinking, and at the center of a crowd of diplomats at a United States Embassy reception today was Colombia's President, Ernesto Samper, smiling and seemingly serene.         Then into the patio swept the country's chief prosecutor, Alfonso Valdivieso, and his entourage of lawyers and bodyguards. The crowd parted, Mr. Valdivieso, a gray-haired fireplug of a man, strode directly up to Mr. Samper -- and Colombia's most celebrated antagonists shook hands.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings this week:      MONDAY

headline: Balkan Chiefs Air Problems Of Peace Plan In Rome Talks
abstract: In an effort to prevent the unraveling of the Balkan peace accord, officials  of the United States and its NATO allies began a two-day meeting here today with the Presidents of Bosnia, Croatia and Serbia.         As the meeting began this afternoon at the Italian Foreign Ministry, Assistant Secretary of State Richard C. Holbrooke underscored the problems by quoting words used by Churchill just before the Allied invasion in Normandy in World War II. "I don't argue the difficulties," Mr. Holbroke said. "They will argue for themselves."

headline: INSIDE
abstract: INVESTING IT/Page 4/ Bombs scarcely rattled investors in Israeli stocks. By Paul Lewis.

headline: Balkan Leaders Again Promise To Carry Out Accord on Bosnia
abstract: After eight hours of meetings today with Secretary of State Warren Christopher and a team of European diplomats, three top Balkan leaders agreed, once again but in more detail than before, to live up to their obligations under the Dayton accords.
