In a process that American officials described as both frustrating and intricate, the leaders agreed to hand over some officers for questioning regarding war crimes, to restore air and rail links and to release the last 219  prisoners of war who were to have been set free on Jan. 19. They also agreed to  improve freedom of movement and freedom of association before elections, which are scheduled for September, and to broaden the access of the press.

headline: 5 Are Killed in Attacks in Southern Egypt
abstract: Attackers ambushed a police truck today in southern Egypt, killing the driver and a riot policeman. Security officials said Muslim militants were responsible.         Earlier in the day, a police guard was killed and three men wounded in an attack also attributed to Muslim militants. Late Wednesday, two Christian guards suspected of being police informers were killed and their bodies thrown across a railroad line.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;A Bank Note, So Very Swiss and Computer-Drawn
abstract: The Swiss central bank has given the ordinary cash-paying Swiss the first of  a new series of bank notes so technologically advanced that it has become a Swiss parlor game to spot the more than 20 anti-counterfeiting features.         The 50-franc bill is the world's first digital bank note -- designed on a computer that resolves its design into 2.5 billion points, each of them individually accessible electronically. There is a raised triangle at one end to assist the blind and a number of official seals and figures that dance around on the face of the note like holograms.

headline: Peace Brings Boost In Tourism to Ulster
abstract: Northern Ireland had a 68 percent increase in the number of vacationers in the first year of peace after guerrilla cease-fires in 1994, tourist officials said today.         A survey commissioned by the Northern Ireland tourist board said that 92 percent of those questioned said they wanted to make a return visit. Visitors surveyed complained of a lack of public toilets, litter and the need for more foreign language services.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;320 JOB CUTS IN EUROPE AND $40 MILLION CHARGE ARE SET
abstract: The Mobil Corporation said yesterday that it would take a $40 million charge  and eliminate 320 jobs in a revamping of part of its European operation. The job cuts bring the number of jobs that Mobil, the energy giant based in Fairfax, Va., has said it plans to eliminate by the end of the year to 5,550. The additional charge also raises to at least $548 million the total of the charges  against earnings that Mobil will take in the fourth quarter. Mobil shares closed up $1.50 yesterday, at $112.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;As Goodby, Silverstein raises its profile, it's still different out there
abstract: THE agency that Madison Avenue considers perhaps the strongest creative force in American advertising today is raising its profile to a level more commensurate with its abilities and accomplishments.         Goodby, Silverstein & Partners, which was founded in this city in 1983, is at last attracting large, high-profile accounts. While it will still be some time before every giant blue-chip advertiser reflexively barks "Get me Goodby!" at the start of a review of its account, Goodby, Silverstein is beginning to break  through in the same manner in which many of its cleverly offbeat, meticulously researched campaigns have broken through with consumers.

headline: In a U.N. Success Story, Guatemalan Abuses Fall
abstract: One afternoon not long ago, dozens of farm workers faced off against a platoon of military policemen in the cool coffee groves of this mountainside plantation in a tense labor dispute.         The police never fired their rifles.  United Nations human rights observers arrived in the midst of the showdown and persuaded the police to leave and the coffee pickers to lay down their machetes. Unlike many similar confrontations in Guatemala in the last three decades, the episode ended without killing.

headline: Daiwa Asset Transfer Set
abstract: Daiwa Bank Ltd., which has been forced to leave the United States for covering up $1.1 billion in bond trading losses, said last night that it would sell its American operations to Sumitomo Bank Ltd. for $65 million.         The deal between the banks, both located in Osaka, Japan, had been widely expected.

headline: SPENDING IT;The Price of Your Nonrefundable Ticket Just Fell? Don't Despair.
abstract: ON a harsh winter morning when your car was covered in snow and the local weatherman predicted six more inches the next day, you booked a spring trip to Florida. Giving two months' notice, you figured the advance airfare was a good deal and paid for a nonrefundable airline ticket.         Now, just two weeks before departure, newspaper ads suggest that a ticket on  the same flight is available for $75 less. It just doesn't seem fair.

headline: Yeltsin, Seeking a Second Term, Points to Communism as the Foe
abstract: Casting himself as Russia's best hope for protecting democracy and market reforms from a lurch back to the past, President Boris N. Yeltsin announced today that he would seek a second term in the presidential election in June.         His declaration amounted to the formal opening of a campaign that, according  to every measure of public opinion, could well bring back to power the Communists Mr. Yeltsin ousted five years ago.

headline: Deals by Bancorp Hawaii
abstract: Bancorp Hawaii Inc. said today that it would acquire a majority stake in Banque de Tahiti in French Polynesia and Banque de Nouvelle Caledonie-Credit Lyonnais in New Caledonia, a Coral Sea island. Bancorp Hawaii said the total purchase price was about $53 million.

headline: Separatist Guerrillas Leave Kashmir Shrine
abstract: About 17 separatist guerrillas ended a two-day occupation of Kashmir's holiest shrine tonight, leaving the buildings peacefully after an agreement with the Indian Government.         A spokesman for the separatist group, the Jammu and Kashmir Liberation Front, and M. N. Sabarwal, police chief of the Indian state of Jammu and Kashmir, confirmed that the occupation of the Hazratbal shrine was over.

headline: 'Liquid' Assets Lure Big Investors
abstract: PARIS—  When Revlon executives made a public share offering earlier this month, they took to the floor of the New York Stock Exchange with more than just the usual lure of money to be made.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Britain to Investigate Unichem's Proposal
abstract: British authorities said yesterday that they would investigate Unichem P.L.C.'s proposed purchase of Lloyds Chemists P.L.C., a drug wholesaler and pharmacy chain.  Britain's Department of Trade and Industry said it would ask the Monopolies and Mergers Commission to investigate the antitrust implications  of a merger between Unichem and Lloyds. It also asked that the European Commission, which has jurisdiction over cross-border mergers, refer a proposed merger between Gehe of Germany and Lloyds Chemists to British authorities.          Unichem and Gehe A.G. are vying for Lloyds in an effort to expand in Britain. The latest cash offer by Gehe values Lloyds at L649.9 million ($994 million), topping Unichem's offer of L617.3 million.    (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
abstract: Jeffrey S. Mahl was named senior vice president for advertising sales at ESPN, New York, a unit of Capital Cities/ABC Inc., succeeding Jack Bonanni, who left.  Mr. Mahl was previously senior vice president for sales and marketing at OCC Sports Inc., New York, part of ESPN. Chris DuCharme was named to the new position of media services director at Capener, Matthews & Walcher, San Diego. She was previously senior vice president and managing director at Western International Media, San Diego, a unit of the Interpublic Group.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;NELLCOR BENNETT TO SWAP STOCK FOR INFRASONICS
abstract: Nellcor Puritan Bennett Inc. of Pleasanton, Calif., said yesterday that it planned to acquire Infrasonics Inc. in a $66 million stock swap. The deal would  add infant and high-frequency ventilators to Nellcor's product line. Infrasonics stockholders would receive 0.095 share of Nellcor Puritan Bennett for each Infrasonics share, with a minimum stock value of $6.25 a share. Shares of Nellcor Puritan Bennett, which makes health care products including monitors and sensors, jumped $6.25, to $71.25, while Infrasonics shares rose $1, to 6.50. Infrasonics, based in San Diego, had revenue of $23 million in the year ended in June. It is the leading producer of infant ventilators and second in production  of high-frequency ventilators.

headline: AT&T May Cut Fewer Jobs Than It Initially Estimated
abstract: Not three months after it stunned Main Street and delighted Wall Street by estimating that it would cut 40,000 jobs over two to three years, the AT&T Corporation is now predicting fewer reductions.         AT&T has made no official statement about the smaller numbers. For now, it is sticking with its original estimate, given in January. But queries from news organizations over the last few weeks have disclosed that the composition of the numbers is changing, and that the overall number may come down.

headline: Big Petroleum Concerns Said To Avoid a Gasoline Additive
abstract: The Environmental Defense Fund announced yesterday that some of the nation's  largest petroleum companies have said that they have no plans to use a controversial additive that increases the octane in gasoline.         The companies that indicated they were not using methylcyclopentadienyl manganese tricarbonyl, or M.M.T., include Amoco, Anchor Gasoline, ARCO, B.P., Chevron, Conoco, Exxon, Hess, Marathon Oil, Mobil, Pennzoil, Phillips, Shell, Sun and Texaco.

headline: U.S. Finds China Guilty of Wide Rights Abuses
abstract: The Clinton Administration issued its annual human rights report today, declaring China guilty of "widespread and well-documented human rights abuses,"  and announced that the United States would again co-sponsor a critical resolution on China at the coming meeting of the United Nations Human Rights Commission in Geneva.

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: CACI INTERNATIONAL INC., Arlington, Va., named James Allen chief financial officer, succeeding Samuel Strickland.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Alcan Aluminium Sheds Some British Assets
abstract: Alcan Aluminium Ltd.'s British subsidiary, British Alcan Aluminium P.L.C., has sold some of its businesses for $300 million, the company said yesterday. Included in the sale were 12 businesses in Britain and the United States that produce aluminum foil, high-pressure gas cylinders, wire, cable and other products. These businesses had combined sales of more than $750 million in 1995  and about 4,200 employees.          The businesses were sold to a group of institutional investors led by Mercury Development Capital; the Morgan Grenfell Development Capital unit of Deutsche Bank and CVC Capital Partners, a unit of Citicorp. Alcan, a Montreal-based aluminum producer, will continue to own three businesses in Britain.   (Dow Jones)

headline: American Radio Deals
abstract: The American Radio Systems Corporation has agreed to acquire Marlin Broadcasting Inc. for about $66.5 million, including the assumption of debt. American will buy Boston-based Marlin's stations in Philadelphia, WFLN-FM, and Detroit, WQRS-FM, both of which carry classical music. In addition, Marlin's president, Howard Tanger, agreed to buy Marlin's classical station in Miami, WTMI-FM, for $18 million. American, also based in Boston, owns 15 FM and nine AM stations.

headline: Key Executive At Citicorp Plans to Retire
abstract: Pei-Yuan Chia, the vice chairman of Citicorp who led its profitable growth in global consumer banking, will retire this year, the bank said yesterday.         The departure of the highly regarded Mr. Chia, 56, was not expected and prompted concern by some banking industry analysts.

headline: Pro-Chechen Hijacker of Turkish Jet Surrenders in Germany
abstract: A pro-Chechen gunman hijacked a Turkish Cypriot airliner to Munich late Friday, but released the 109 hostages early today. A Munich airport spokesman, Hans-Joachim Bues, said the 101 passengers and 8 crew members were safe.         The hijacker was arrested. Chechens have been at war with Russia for more than a year in an effort to win independence for their republic, in the Caucasus.

headline: OUTLOOK '96: THE ECONOMY: Middle Age Catches Up With the MeGeneration; Increasing the Demand For Health Care Services
abstract: The providers of health care can hardly wait as the latest crop of 50-year-olds crosses the threshold to the aches and pains of middle age. Having  grown up expecting and generally finding care that was both affordable and accessible, the graying boomers will now need it a lot more, and that should translate into bonanzas for drug makers, many physicians and hospitals, not to mention the makers of artificial knees for worn-out joggers who refuse to slow down.         "Inexorably, demand goes higher," said John F. Hindelong, a health care securities analyst with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. "The question is, who pays for it?"

headline: COMPANY NEWS;JAMES RIVER TO SELL INKS BUSINESS TO SUN CHEMICAL
abstract: The James River Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its inks business to the Sun Chemical Company, which is based in Fort Lee, N.J., and is a subsidiary of the Tokyo-based Dainippon Inks and Chemicals Inc. Terms of the sale were not disclosed. In December, James River said it intended to sell its CZ Inks division and its plastic packaging business to focus on its more profitable tissue-paper and consumer products business. Combined, the inks division and the plastic packaging business had about $540 million in 1995 sales, the company said. James River's CZ Ink's division employs 200 people at seven plants. James River said it would use proceeds from the sale to reduce its long-term debt.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS
abstract: TRINET CORPORATE REALTY TRUST, San Francisco, a real estate investment trust that acquires and manages office and industrial properties, has bought the headquarters complex of Federal Express Corp. in Memphis for $26 million.

headline: S.E.C. Panel Issues Proposals To Ease Corporate Offerings
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission took the first steps today to eliminate hundreds of rules and required forms in an attempt to simplify corporate offering procedures and make it easier for small companies to raise capital.         The S.E.C. voted to accept the 94-page report of an internal study group, which also urged that corporate prospectuses be written so that they were easy to understand, thus reducing small investors' need for professional advice.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;French Bank Posts Rise Of 7.7% in 1995 Profit
abstract: Banque Nationale de Paris said yesterday that its profit rose 7.7 percent in  1995 as cost-cutting and reduced provisions for risky loans offset a fall in income from securities trading. The company, also known as BNP, posted profit of 1.78 billion francs, or about $356 million.          Michel Pebereau, the bank's chairman, said that it had done well in light of a low demand for credit in France and the poor showing of Compagnie UAP S.A., in which BNP owns a 17.5 percent stake.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;NETSCAPE STOCK PLUMMETS IN BATTLE WITH MICROSOFT
abstract: The stock of the Netscape Communications Corporation, which has lost more than half its value in the last five weeks over worries that the Microsoft Corporation will beat it out in the war over software for use on the Internet, fell almost 14 percent yesterday. The shares were down $6.25, to $38.75, in Nasdaq trading. They stood at $83.50 on Jan. 31. Microsoft and Netscape are taking shots at each other's software and courting business partners. The Wall Street Journal reported yesterday that Microsoft was trying to license its Internet software to America Online Inc. in a move to derail talks between America Online and Netscape. America Online has more than five million customers; gaining access to them would be a coup for Netscape or Microsoft.

headline: U.N. Assesses Psychic Scars Left on Rwandan Children by Killings
abstract: For the children of Rwanda, the genocidal massacres of 1994 that left an estimated half million people dead were not horrors that happened in somebody's  else house, but before their eyes, according to a report to be published on Friday.         The survey, by the United Nations Children's Fund, or Unicef, says 95 percent of 3,000 Rwandan children surveyed witnessed violence up close. More than a quarter saw parents or other family members killed, many of them beaten or hacked to death with machetes.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;For more than a quarter of the advertisers, it'll be Super Bowl I.
abstract: THE Dallas Cowboys have played in the Super Bowl before. So too have the Pittsburgh Steelers. But when they meet Sunday in Super Bowl XXX, it will be Super Bowl I for more than a quarter of the advertisers buying commercials in the NBC broadcast of the game.         The Super Bowl rookies range from marketing giants like General Mills Inc. and Mastercard International to smaller, less well-known companies like Kinko's  Inc. and Mail Boxes Etc. Even the halftime show sponsor, Oscar Mayer, is a Super Bowl newcomer.

headline: Executive Producer at CBS News
abstract: Filling the final slot in his roster of top managers, the new CBS News president, Andrew Heyward, plans to announce today that Jeffrey Fager will take  Mr. Heyward's old job as executive producer of the "CBS Evening News."         "There's an obvious logic to it because he was my deputy," Mr. Heyward said over the weekend. "But beyond that, his skills are extremely valuable for what the 'Evening News' needs to be, which is something more than a headline spot-news service. It's important for us to offer more perspective, more analysis, more context, more insight, and Jeff's background is perfect for this."

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;PFIZER INC. (PFE,N)
abstract: Pfizer Inc. said yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings from continuing operations rose 24 percent, bolstered by strong sales of its new drugs, including the blood-pressure drug Norvasc and the antidepressant Zoloft.         The drug maker posted profits from continuing operations of $405.6 million, or 64 cents a share, up from $326.0 million, or 52 cents, a year earlier. Revenue rose 24 percent, to $2.74 billion.

headline: SPENDING IT;Few Financial Walls Against the Floods
abstract: THE blizzard and heavy rains in the Northeast last month caused more than $1  billion in insured losses, but a lot of other damage went uncovered because most people didn't have flood insurance.         Even though 500,000 more buildings in the United States carry flood insurance now than in 1994, the Federal Government estimates that more than two-thirds of the buildings that should be insured against flooding do not carry the coverage. In New York and Pennsylvania, where the rain and melting snow led to flooding that damaged thousands of buildings, only about 1 percent of businesses and homeowners have flood insurance.

headline: Quaker Plant for Atlanta
abstract: The Quaker Oats Company will spend about $50 million to build a new beverage  plant and distribution center near Atlanta, the company said today. The Chicago-based food and beverage concern said the plant would produce Gatorade and Snapple teas and juice drinks and would employ about 150 people. The start of production is set for January 1997. The Atlanta plant will be the seventh company-owned beverage plant.

headline: Saudi Gadfly and British Embarrassment
abstract: Each Friday for nearly two years, Mohammed al-Masari has faxed a newsletter to contacts in his native Saudi Arabia, reporting on what he calls the rampant corruption, human rights abuses and tyranny of the Saudi royal family.         Occasionally he adds a "Prince of the Month" special about a member of the royal clan whose behavior he considers particularly egregious.

headline: The Fate of Colombia's Leader
abstract: This week, in a special session of Congress called by President Ernesto Samper to weigh accusations that he had solicited millions of dollars in drug money for his campaign, many of the politicians who could ultimately impeach him gave Mr. Samper a standing ovation after his opening speech.         The show of support was a vivid reminder that, after a week of denunciations  from one-time allies and resignations by diplomats and ministers, Mr. Samper is  by no means ready to be written into history.

headline: Pentagon Boss Walks in Footsteps of Peacekeepers
abstract: Secretary of Defense William J. Perry walked across the Sava River from Croatia into Bosnia today, saw a minefield being cleared from his helicopter and acknowledged bluntly that the peacekeeping mission, after two weeks, has been hounded by difficulties that may not get much better.         "That's going to be the history of our time in Bosnia now," he said at a news conference at the air base near here that serves as the center of American operations in Bosnia. "It's going to be dealing with one problem after another."

headline: China Says Exports Slumped Last Month
abstract: China's exports slumped in December, leaving a monthly trade deficit for the  first time in 19 months, according to Customs Administration figures.         "This is a big surprise," said Joan Zheng, a Hong Kong-based economist with J. P. Morgan. "This confirms earlier indications that exporting companies were reluctant to expand exports last year."

headline: Market Place;Alza has taken the wraps off its drug pipeline, pleasing analysts.
abstract: FOR years, the Alza Corporation, the leading producer of skin patches for drug companies, has had a secretive culture that has left Wall Street mostly in  the dark about the company's prospects.         Then suddenly a week ago yesterday Alza turned the spotlight on itself at an  annual meeting with securities analysts and institutional investors where the company's top executives disclosed a pipeline of drugs the company is developing. The new drugs confirmed that Alza had made progess in broadening its business from that of a contractor to a developer and marketer of its own products.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;JUDGE DISMISSES CAREMARK'S SUIT AGAINST CORAM
abstract: The Coram Healthcare Corporation said yesterday that a Federal judge in Chicago had dismissed a $117 million lawsuit filed against the company by Caremark International Inc. Coram said its lawsuit against Caremark, seeking damages resulting from its acquisition of Caremark's home drug-infusion business, was pending in a California court. Coram's shares rose 50 cents yesterday, to $5.375, on the New York Stock Exchange; Caremark was up 12.5 cents, to $18.75. Caremark sued Coram, contending that Coram concealed its planned merger with Lincare Holdings Inc. to lure Caremark into selling the home infusion business to Coram. Caremark contended that the deal, which later fell apart, reduced the value of Coram's shares. Caremark had received Coram shares in exchange for selling the infusion business. Coram's stock plunged from as high as $26 a share to $3.

headline: Cruise Missile Is Test-Fired From a Ship By Iran's Navy
abstract: Iran has increased its military power in the Persian Gulf in the last year, most recently by testing a new Chinese cruise missile fired from a ship, senior  Pentagon officials said today.         Along with sea mines, two Soviet attack submarines, five Chinese patrol boats and land-based missiles, the new weapon could increase Iran's ability to try to  close the Strait of Hormuz -- the gateway to the Persian Gulf and its oil -- in  times of tension or war.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;ILLINOIS CENTRAL TO BUY OPERATOR OF 2 RAILROADS
abstract: The Illinois Central Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy CCP Holdings Inc., a privately held railroad company based in Waterloo, Iowa, for $139 million. Illinois Central, which is based in Chicago, said it would also assume about $18 million in equipment leases. CCP Holdings operates two railroads, the Chicago, Central & Pacific Railroad and the Cedar River Railroad, with track that totals about 850 miles. Illinois Central owns the Illinois Central Railroad, which operates a 2,700-mile freight railroad. Its stock gained 25 cents yesterday, to $37.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Palestinians Trying Out Elections, Warts and All
abstract: Awash in vivid campaign posters and banners, this city north of Jerusalem seems gripped by election fever these days, its crowded streets the picture of a carnival of democracy.         Cars plastered with smiling images of candidates creep through the traffic-choked main square as children dart into stores to hand out campaign flyers. Where they once fought street battles with Israeli soldiers, young men gathered one morning to chat with a candidate, holding a lively open-air symposium on a pedestrian mall.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;I.B.M. ANNOUNCES SOME STEEPER PRICE CUTS
abstract: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it had made additional price cuts of 4 percent to 9 percent in its line of commercial desktop personal computers. The price cuts were in addition to a 20 percent price cut announced two weeks ago and followed sharp price cuts announced on Monday by the Compaq Computer Corporation and the Digital Equipment Corporation. "We additionally fine-tuned prices to match those of our major competitors," an I.B.M. spokeswoman said. I.B.M. also said yesterday that it would invest $500 million to increase the manufacturing capacity of its storage technology unit.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;PUBLIC OFFERING PLANNED FOR PLANET HOLLYWOOD
abstract: Planet Hollywood International Inc. registered yesterday with the Securities  and Exchange Commission for a initial public offering of common shares. The restaurant chain, based in Orlando, Fla., estimated that the offering would raise up to $190.5 million. The company said it planned to use $130.8 million of the net proceeds to pay debt and the rest for general corporate purposes, including new restaurants. Planet Hollywood has 22 company-owned and six franchised restaurants in eight countries. Some of Hollywood's biggest stars, including Arnold Schwarzenegger, Sylvester Stallone, Bruce Willis, Demi Moore and Whoopi Goldberg, are shareholders.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Samsung Wins Contracts
abstract: The Samsung Electronics Company, South Korea's largest electronics maker, said yesterday that it had signed contracts worth $700 million to supply computer monitors to four United States personal computer makers in 1996. A Samsung Electronics spokesman would not name the four companies but said 1.1 million monitors would be supplied. Samsung will supply the companies with 17-inch, high-definition monitors.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: COMPANY NEWS;MAXXIM MEDICAL MAKES BID FOR STERILE CONCEPTS
abstract: Maxxim Medical Inc. said yesterday that it had offered to acquire Sterile Concepts Holdings Inc. for about $118 million, which includes the assumption of  about $29 million in debt. Maxxim offered $16 in cash or newly issued shares, or a combination of the two, for each Sterile Concepts common share. Maxxim said it made the offer in mid-February, but has not received a reply from Sterile Concepts. Shares of Sterile Concepts rose $3.75, or 29 percent, to $16.75, on the New York Stock Exchange; Maxxim Medical shares fell 37.5 cents, to $18.875.  Both companies make medical products. The combined company would have annual sales of more than $500 million. Sterile Concepts is based in Richmond; Maxxim is based in Sugar Land, Tex.

headline: Yeltsin the Politician Agrees To Let Top Liberal Aide Go
abstract: In the first major concession of the presidential race, President Boris N. Yeltsin accepted the resignation today of his Foreign Minister, Andrei V. Kozyrev, one of the last liberals in his increasingly hard-line Cabinet.         While it was long expected, the departure of Mr. Kozyrev, who will take the seat he won last month in parliamentary elections, underscored just how much the Communist victory in that election has changed the political landscape.

headline: Brazil Avoids Inquiry, but Not Doubt on Its Banks
abstract: With an all-out campaign, President Fernando Henrique Cardoso has averted a congressional investigation into the collapse of Banco Nacional, the fifth major Brazilian bank to require a Government bailout in the last year. In doing so, he calmed investors, who feared congressional scrutiny of the banking system and its major figures, but did little to quell doubts about the rules by which the banking industry here plays.         The President's behind-the-scenes deal-making also managed to win support for modest reforms of the social security system. But in doing so, he called into question his pledges, on taking office early last year, to avoid patronage and impose fiscal responsibility upon the nation's economic and banking system.

headline: OUTLOOK '96: THE ECONOMY;The Welfare State Is Alive and Welcome in Western Europe
abstract: FOR years, a favorite pastime of economists has been prophesying the demise of Europe's comfortable welfare state.         Social payments, wages and subsidies are all too high in Europe. Labor laws are inflexible, and Europeans take too much vacation and pay too much in taxes.  Technology is behind that of the United States and Japan. Everything is too expensive. And unemployment rates here are twice that of the United States.

headline: Iberia Reaches Pact With Pilots
abstract: Iberia, the Spanish state-owned airline, reached a deal with its pilots today, clearing the last obstacle to an injection of new capital to save it from bankruptcy.         The pilots' union had rejected a December 1994 revamping plan that was the basis for Iberia's argument for European Commission approval of its recapitalization. Today, the union accepted the plan, which freezes pilots' pay  until the end of 1998.

headline: S.E.C. Deal Seen in Orange County Inquiry
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission is expected to announce a deal on Wednesday that could end its yearlong inquiry into the role of Orange County in  its investment crisis, people close to the matter said today.         Under the deal, they said, the S.E.C. will file a cease-and-desist order against the county in an administrative proceeding, and the county will consent  to it without admitting or denying wrongdoing.

headline: Don't Mess With Sears
abstract: To the Editor:         After reading "Yes, He's Revived Sears. But Can He Reinvent It?" (Jan. 7), I  hope that Sears, Roebuck does not change its style of dealing with customers as  it looks for new efficiencies.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                                               Previous      Year                               Yesterday       Day       Ago

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: GRAND METROPOLITAN P.L.C., London, said it had appointed John Keenan, who headed the worldwide expansion of Kraft Foods International, as chief executive of its  spirits division.

headline: Closed-End Funds: A Tough '95
abstract: LAST year the stock market soared, the bond market boomed and mutual funds took in more cash than they knew what to do with.         Not so closed-end funds.

headline: Gasoline Prices Rise
abstract: Gasoline prices jumped more than 3 cents a gallon in the last two weeks as warm weather pushed up demand at a time of lagging international supply, according to the Lundberg Survey of gas stations across the country. The average pump price, including all grades and taxes, was $1.2439 a gallon last Friday. Compared with the survey of March 8, the price was up 3.3 cents, the largest price increase so far this year, the analyst Trilby Lundberg said.

headline: Poland's Ex-Premier Picked as Party Leader
abstract: Jozef Oleksy, who resigned this week as Prime Minister of Poland over charges that he once spied for Moscow, was chosen today to lead the Social Democrats, the former Comunist party, a party official said.         The official, Robert Dobrzynski, said that party members gave Mr. Oleksy 308  votes out of a total of 325, to lead the Social Democrats, the core faction of the Democratic Left Alliance, a coalition that also the Peasant party. The two groups are locked in talks over who should fill the top posts in a reshuffled Cabinet prompted by Mr. Oleksy's resignation on Wednesday.

headline: Wild Theory In a Slaying Dies in Mexico
abstract: A federal agent implicated in a wild theory that he assassinated the governing party's presidential candidate nearly two years ago and then himself was murdered showed up today in Mexico City and denied that he had been anywhere near the scene of the shooting in Tijuana on March 23, 1994.         The agent, Martin Antonio Gutierrez Cantu, was brought here from Mexicali by  federal officials to disprove recent articles given prominent space on the front pages of two major Mexico City daily newspapers.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;COURT APPROVES OFFER FOR LOMAS FINANCIAL
abstract: First Nationwide Bank's $157.75 million offer for the Lomas Financial Corporation's mortgage servicing portfolio was approved by a Federal bankruptcy  court yesterday. Lomas had filed for protection from creditors under bankruptcy  law on Oct. 10. An objection to the sale could still be raised by the Pima County, Ariz., Industrial Authority at a hearing scheduled for Jan. 26.

headline: Company Briefs
abstract: JOHN ALDEN FINANCIAL CORP., Miami, an insurance holding company, will sell two units: its asset-accumulation division and its credit life and disability business. The sale could fetch $275 million before taxes, analysts said.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;Wall St. Firms Say Earnings Rose Sharply
abstract: Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. and Alex. Brown Inc., two of Wall Street's  most closely watched niche players in the securities industry, yesterday posted  sharply higher earnings in the fourth quarter.         Donaldson, Lufkin's profits soared 53.6 percent, to $57.6 million, or 93 cents a share, from $37.5 million, or 63 cents a share, in the comparable quarter a year earlier.

headline: Starts of Housing Surged 3% in February
abstract: Builders started work on new homes last month at the highest rate in more than a year as they prepared for a rush of buyers eager to lock in mortgage rates before the rates move higher.         All regions except the Midwest reported increased construction, the Commerce  Department said today. The increases pushed national housing starts 3 percent above the January level, to an annual rate of 1.49 million. The February rate is the highest since December 1994, when the rate was 1.51 million.

headline: Rising Variety of Groups Vie for Attention at U.N. Rights Forum
abstract: Fearing that they are not being heard in Africa, two members of a dwindling tribe facing eviction from a Botswana game reserve went to Geneva this week to bring their case to a human rights forum that is opening its doors wider every year to petitioners from around the world.         "We came without any promise of getting anything done," said John Hardbattle, leader of the First Peoples of the Kalahari, whose ancestors have lived in what  is now the Central Kalahari Game Reserve for thousands of years. "We felt that if we can't get help at the U.N., then we won't get it anywhere else."

headline: Market Place;Magellan Shifted From Technology In November
abstract: Reinforcing his reputation of being as astute a trader as he is a stock picker, Jeffrey N. Vinik, manager of the $53 billion Fidelity Magellan fund, cut the fund's investment in technology stocks nearly in half in November while causing barely a ripple through the stock market.         Market watchers have speculated since early December that a sharp drop in technology stocks was being worsened by heavy selling from Magellan and other Fidelity funds. And such a drop, they worried, could cause the entire market to  come crashing down.

headline: Guatemala Election Becomes Vote on Former Dictator
abstract: On Sunday, Guatemalans will decide which of two conservative, 40-something career politicians should become their next President. But in many respects, the vote promises to be a referendum on a man who is not even on the ballot: Gen. Efrain Rios Montt.         On paper, General Rios Montt is merely the Secretary General of the Guatemalan Republican Front, the right-wing party whose nominal standard bearer  is Alfonso Portillo. But he is also a former military dictator of this Central American country, has made it clear he would like to rule again, and is said by  his enemies to be using Mr. Portillo as nothing more than a stalking horse.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Fed Lowers Interest Rates To Nudge a Weak Economy The Federal Reserve lowered short-term interest rates by one-quarter percentage  point to give the economy a modest spark. In its second rate cut in six weeks, the central bank lowered the Federal Funds rate at which banks lend each other money overnight to 5.25 percent and the discount rate, at which it lends banks money, to 5 percent.

headline: Indonesia Quake Toll Rises
abstract: The death toll in the earthquake that devastated remote islands off New Guinea a week ago rose to 105 today as three more bodies were found.         One hundred people were killed on Biak Island; the other five died on the nearby island of Yapen.

headline: BankAmerica Buyback Plan
abstract: The BankAmerica Corporation said today that it would buy back as much as $2 billion of its common stock and $1 billion of its preferred stock by the end of  1997.

headline: Accused Mexican Narcotics Trafficker Is Said to Offer to Answer AllQuestions
abstract: Juan Garcia Abrego, the accused narcotics trafficker, told Federal Bureau of  Investigation agents after his arrest and expulsion from Mexico "that he would be glad to answer any and all questions the agents would pose to him," according to an F.B.I. account of the encounter.         If, in fact, Mr. Garcia Abrego proves willing to cooperate further, he could  become an intelligence gold-mine because of his key role in forging closer ties  between Mexican and Colombian trafficking groups in the last decade, law enforcement officials said.

headline: Chip to Block TV Gore Popular in Canada Tests
abstract: Maxine Lawson says she did not think much about violence on television until  her 2-year-old son, Caden, came into the kitchen one day after watching the Mighty Morphin Power Rangers and started making karate chops.         "He wanted to deck me," Ms. Lawson, 29, an accountant in north Toronto, said  with a laugh. "He's very impressionable."

headline: Cox Is Reported About to Buy A Stake in Special-Effects Maker
abstract: Cox Enterprises, the big media company, is planning on Wednesday to announce  here that it is buying a one-third interest in Digital Domain, a leader in computer-generated special effects and images, people with knowledge of the deal said today.         The deal would be another step in the rapid convergence of various computer,  software, entertainment and media companies. Cox owns newspapers, notably the Journal and Constitution in Atlanta, and also cable- and movie-production businesses.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;HERSHEY BOARD APPROVES STOCK BUYBACK PLAN
abstract: The Hershey Foods Corporation's board has authorized the repurchase of as much as $200 million of the company's common stock, Hershey said yesterday. The  company, which makes Hershey's chocolate and Ronzoni pasta, plans to finance the repurchase plan with cash. Based on Monday's closing price of $71.25 for Hershey stock, the buyback would involve about 3.6 percent of Hershey's estimated 77 million outstanding shares. The new authorization followed a $200 million program begun in 1993. Hershey stock rose $2.375, to $73.625 in New York Stock Exchange trading.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;PRAXAIR AGREES TO SELL 4 PLANTS IN CBI DEAL
abstract: The Federal Trade Commission said yesterday that Praxair Inc. had agreed to divest itself of four production plants it will acquire in the $2 billion purchase of CBI Industries, to settle antitrust concerns about the deal. Praxair, the largest supplier of industrial gases in the United States, confirmed that the settlement had been reached and said its tender offer of $33  a share for CBI, a maker of industrial gases based in Oak Brook, Ill., would proceed. The F.T.C. had contended that the acquisition would reduce competition  and would raise prices for certain gases. Praxair, which is based in Danbury, Conn., agreed to divest itself of CBI plants in Vacaville and Irwindale, Calif.; Bozrah, Conn., and Madison, Wis., within 12 months.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;PREMIERE TECHNOLOGIES SELLS 6.5 MILLION SHARES
abstract: The stock of Premiere Technologies Inc. rose well above its offering price in its first day of trading on the Nasdaq stock market. Atlanta-based Premiere makes software that lets people use most telephones to also gain access to computers, fax machines and the Internet. The company sold 6.5 million shares to raise $117 million. Premiere's stock closed at $26.25, in trading of more than 6.5 million shares. The offering was priced at $16, or $4 higher than the low end of its original $12 to $14 price range, an indication of strong investor demand for the shares. The company plans to use proceeds from the offering to pay debts and to expand its software network.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Conoco in Venture For Vietnam Refinery
abstract: Petronas, Malaysia's state oil company, and Houston-based Conoco Inc. will take a 30 percent stake in a $1.2 billion Vietnamese refinery, Petronas officials said yesterday.  The project will be at Dung Quat Bay, south of Danang, and will have a capacity of 130,000 barrels a day. The project is scheduled to be completed by 2000.          Other partners include the state oil company PetroVietnam, the Chinese Petroleum Corporation of Taiwan and the Chinese Investment and Development Corporation. Petronas officials said Petronas and Conoco were replacing Total S.A. of France, which was reported to have pulled out because of a disagreement  over the site of the refinery.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;FLORIDA EAST COAST GETS OFFER FOR SUBSIDIARY
abstract: Florida East Coast Industries said yesterday that the St. Joe Paper Company had offered to buy its Gran Central Corporation subsidiary in a tax-free stock swap. St. Joe Paper owns a 54 percent stake, worth about $370 million, in Florida East Coast Industries. St. Joe Paper said it was interested in acquiring Gran Central in exchange for the Florida East Coast Industries stock it holds. Gran Central develops Florida office, commercial and industrial properties. Florida East Coast is based in St. Augustine, Fla.; St. Joe Paper is in Jacksonville, Fla. Trading in the shares of both companies was halted on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Broadcasters Bet on Sports As First Step In New Markets
abstract: In India, where World Cup cricket captivates the sporting public the way the  Super Bowl does in the United States, 10 million cable television households had access last week to 200 hours of televised matches through Star Sports, a joint  venture of Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation and John C. Malone's Tele-Communications Inc.         Those who cared only about the home team could switch to the rival programmer, the Walt Disney Company's ESPN International, which was showing "India Victorious," highlights of the Indian national team's past matches. ESPN  has obtained the rights to all the team's matches outside World Cup competition  from the Board of Cricket Control of India.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;TBC TO PURCHASE BIG O TIRES FOR $56 MILLION
abstract: The TBC Corporation reached a preliminary agreement yesterday to acquire Big  O Tires Inc. for $16.50 a share, or about $56 million. Big O, a tire retailer, also said it had terminated its agreement to be acquired by Boti Holdings Inc.,  a management group, for the same $16.50-a-share price. The agreement with TBC, a marketer and distributor of automotive products, is subject to certain price reductions based on transaction costs and other expenses. Big O said that a material adjustment was unlikely as a result of the costs. In Nasdaq trading yesterday, shares of Big O rose $1.4375, to $15.25.

headline: World News Briefs;Bangladesh Gets A New Premier
abstract: A former Chief Justice was sworn in today as head of an interim Government to replace that of Prime Minister Begum Khaleda Zia, the state television reported.         The report said Mrs. Khaleda, military chiefs and other key politicians, including the main opposition leader, Sheik Hasina, were present at the swearing-in of the judge, Habibur Rahman, at the presidential palace.

headline: BOMBINGS IN ISRAEL: THE OVERVIEW;2 Suicide Bombings in Israel Kill 25 and Hurt 77, Highest Such Toll
abstract: A six-month lull in terror attacks in Israel was shattered in the early morning today when militant Muslim suicide bombers detonated pipe bombs in Jerusalem and Ashkelon, killing 25 people and wounding 77, some critically. Among the dead were two Americans.         Messages received by news organizations said the attacks were an act of vengeance for the death of Yahya Ayyash, a Palestinian known as "the Engineer" for the bombing attacks he organized in recent years against Israel. Mr. Ayyash, who belonged to an armed wing of the militant Islamic movement Hamas called the  Qassam Brigades, was killed by a booby-trapped mobile telephone on Jan. 5.

headline: Equity and Convertible Offerings for This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:          Aavid Thermal Tech, Laconia, N.H., an initial public offering of 2.3 million shares. Montgomery Securities.

headline: Dozens Are Killed in Heavy Fighting in Liberia
abstract: Dozens of people have been killed in six days of fighting that has terrorized the northwestern Liberian countryside, military officials said today.         The fighting is the worst since an August cease-fire in Liberia's six-year civil war, which has killed 150,000 people and displaced half the country's 2.6 million people.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;QUALITY DINING TO BUY BRUEGGER'S BAKERIES
abstract: Quality Dining Inc., a restaurant operator, said yesterday that it would acquire the Bruegger's Bagel Bakeries chain from the Bruegger's Corporation in a stock deal worth more than $143.5 million. Bruegger's, a closely held company based in Burlington, Vt., owns and operates 40 retail bakeries and franchises 235 outlets in 26 states. Quality Dining, based in Mishawaka, Ind., surged $4.50, to $26, in Nasdaq trading. Quality Dining operates 62 Burger King restaurants, 42 Grady's American Grill restaurants, 18 Chili's Grill and Bar restaurants, 18 Bruegger's Bagel Bakeries and 5 Spageddies Italian Kitchen restaurants in 20 states.

headline: Apple Suspends Quarterly Dividend for First Time
abstract: Apple Computer Inc. has for the first time suspended payment of its quarterly dividend, the company said in a filing today with the Securities and Exchange Commission.         Apple did not declare a dividend for its first fiscal quarter, which ended Dec. 29, and does not expect to declare one "in the near future," according to the filing.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;British Airways Plans To Buy Up to 60 Jets
abstract: British Airways said yesterday that it was inviting five airplane makers to bid for an order of up to 60 regional jets worth $1 billion. The airline said some of the planes would replace 13-year-old Boeing 737-200's now used on domestic routes within Britain as well as routes to continental Europe from regional airports in Birmingham, Edinburgh, Glasgow and Manchester.          Bids are being sought from Airbus Industrie, the European consortium; Avro,  a unit of British Aerospace P.L.C.; ; Fokker N.V. of the Netherlands, a unit of Daimler-Benz of Germany; the Boeing Company of Seattle and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation of St. Louis. The carrier wants to place 30 firm orders for  planes to be delivered in 1997-99, with options on 30 more.   (AP)

headline: COMPANY NEWS;SOUTHAM ANNOUNCES CHARGE AGAINST EARNINGS
abstract: Southam Inc., based in Toronto, said yesterday that it would take a pretax charge against 1995 earnings of $120 million (Canadian), or $88.1 million (United States) as part of a three-year plan to cut 750 jobs and reorganize Canada's largest daily newspaper publishing company. Southam said the elimination of 750 of its 7,800 jobs would cost the company $80 million (Canadian). Southam said the rest of the charge, or $40 million, reflected the accounting for redundant assets at its Pacific Press, partly because of the move into new facilities. Southam earned $44 million on revenues of $1.2 billion in 1994.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Philip Morris Takes A Big Polish Stake
abstract: Philip Morris has signed a $372 million deal with Poland to take a majority stake in the country's biggest cigarette producer, Zaklady Przemyslu Tytoniowego Krakow.  Philip Morris said yesterday that it would pay $227 million for a 33 percent stake in the state-owned plant and for the right to acquire a further 32 percent once it fulfilled its pledge to invest $145 million over the next three  years.          The investment program will consist of modernization of the Krakow-based plant and support programs to enhance local tobacco production.   (Reuters)

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;Revenues at Oracle Rise 41%, But Profits Disappoint Analysts
abstract: The Oracle Corporation reported third-quarter earnings that fell just below Wall Street analysts' estimates despite a 41 percent rise in revenues.         The shortfall was not entirely unexpected. Some analysts began cutting their  estimates last week, citing slower growth in Europe, which indeed did trail the  United States and Asia in today's report. Oracle is the leading producer of data base management software.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;DIANA CORPORATION TO SELL FOOD DISTRIBUTION BUSINESS
abstract: The Diana Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its meat and  seafood distribution unit, though it did not disclose the buyer or the sale price. Diana, which is based in Milwaukee and which also makes telecommunications equipment, has been looking for a buyer for the food distribution unit, the Atlanta Provision Company, since July. Atlanta Provision  contributed $215 million, or 86 percent, of Diana's revenue in the 1995 fiscal year. The company said it would call off the acquisition if the sale did not close by March 15. Shares of Diana jumped $2.75, or 16 percent, to $19.50 yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Marvel Reports Loss for Quarter
abstract: Marvel Entertainment Group Inc. said yesterday that it would restructure its  publishing and trading-card operations, resulting in 275 layoffs, a fourth-quarter pretax charge of $25 million and a loss for the quarter.         In a statement the company said the fourth-quarter charge would bring its total special charges for the year to $65 million. Full-year net income before extraordinary items should be about 5 cents a share, the company said.

headline: The Fiercely Faithful -- A special report.;From Cold War, Afghans Inherit Brutal New Age
abstract: When the crowds were summoned to the main stadium in Herat earlier this month, they went as Romans did to the Coliseum, to watch the grim ritual of death.

headline: Saturn Plan For Used Cars
abstract: The Saturn division of General Motors plans to greatly expand its used-car business starting next month, Saturn officials said today.         On Feb. 12, Saturn will begin a nationwide advertising campaign about its plan to offer used-car customers the same no-haggle pricing it offers new-car buyers, John J. Orth, Saturn's director of consumer marketing, said. The advertising agency Hal Riney & Partners in San Francisco will handle the campaign.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: A Surprise Deal For National Medical Two days after spurning a $3.8 billion bid from Baxter International for its National Medical Care, W. R. Grace said it had agreed to spin off the unit, which dominates the kidney-dialysis market, with a new company created by Fresenius of Germany.

headline: Setback for U.S. Regulators in Texas Case
abstract: In a setback for Federal regulators, a judge ruled today that a Texas company was not in contempt of a 1995 court order concerning its sale of a life insurance policy's death benefits to investors.         But United States District Judge Royce C. Lamberth ordered the company, Life  Partners Inc. of Waco, Tex., not to violate securities laws in its sale of so-called viatical settlements, which enable people who have AIDS or other terminal illnesses to raise money for medical bills or living expenses by selling their life-insurance policies to investors like Life Partners.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;RICKEL HOME CENTERS PLANS TO CLOSE 13 MORE STORES
abstract: Rickel Home Centers Inc. said yesterday that it would close 13 stores by July, bringing the total number of closings to 26 stores since late 1995. After  the closings, Rickel, a retailer of home improvement products, will operate 66 stores in New Jersey, Pennsylvania, New York and Delaware. Rickel filed for protection from creditors under bankruptcy law on Jan. 10. The company has been battered by competitors, particularly The Home Depot Inc. The store closings are subject to United States Bankruptcy Court approval.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: APARTMENT INVESTMENT AND MANAGEMENT CO., a real estate investment trust, bought  two apartment complexes, the Peachtree Park complex in Atlanta and Villa Ladera  complex in Albuquerque, N.M., for a total of $28.1 million.

headline: Pension Insurance Fund Deficit Is at Its Lowest Level Since 1981
abstract: The deficit in the Government's single-employer pension insurance fund fell by $925 million last year to the lowest level since 1981, the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation announced today.         In its annual report to Congress, the Government's pension insurance agency attributed the improvement to a record $2 billion in investment earnings and to  the fact that no major pension plan was terminated.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;4 Agencies Win Grand Awards
abstract: Four agencies have won the best of show Grand Awards at the 38th annual international television advertising competition sponsored by the New York Festivals.         The winners were Dentsu Inc. in Tokyo, in the best commercial category, for a spot for National light bulbs; Delvico Bates Barcelona, a unit of Cordiant P.L.C., best campaign, for the Bulevard Rosa chain of apparel stores; Dektor Higgins & Associates in Hollywood, best creative/production achievement, for I.B.M., and the New York and Torrance, Calif., offices of Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide, also owned by Cordiant, best public service announcement, for the Partnership for a Drug-Free America.

headline: Colombia Chief Denies He Spoke of Quitting
abstract: The office of President Ernesto Samper denied today that he had said "that he is seeking at this time the capacity to leave in a dignified form from the presidency."         A statement from Mr. Samper's office disputed an article in The New York Times that said he had opened the way to resigning eventually.

headline: An Official at Pier 1 Is Said to Be on Leave
abstract: The chief financial officer of Pier 1 Imports Inc., which recently disclosed  $20 million in trading losses, is on a leave of absence, people close to the company said yesterday.         The financial chief, Robert G. Herndon, is said to be on leave until a committee investigating the trading losses finishes its review. Neither Mr. Herndon nor Pier 1 officials were available to comment.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Imperial Chemical Rise
abstract: Higher selling prices and improved volumes helped raise Imperial Chemical Industries P.L.C.'s 1995 pretax profit by 85 percent, the company said yesterday. Pretax profit was L951 million ($1.47 billion), up from L514 million. Sales were L10.27 billion, up from L9.19 billion.   (AP)

headline: Companies Aren't Snapping Up a Tax Break
abstract: How many big American companies would look a gift horse in the mouth?         Well, judging from the response to the expiration of the Federal 10 percent airline ticket tax, just about all of them.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;IOMEGA SHARES FALL AFTER OFFERING PLANS ARE CHANGED
abstract: Generally shares go up after a company announces it will delay or cancel a stock offering, but the Iomega Corporation's stock sank 15 percent yesterday on  the news that the company was postponing its planned offering. Iomega, a maker of computer disk drives, said on Thursday that it was putting its offering of 5.25 million common shares on hold. The company cited confusion in the marketplace and volatility in its stock price. Iomega shares have seesawed since the company announced the offering on Dec. 14 as rumors spread that company's earnings were below estimates. More questions were raised by reports that Iomega had made its fourth-quarter earnings look better through accounting  maneuvers. In Nasdaq trading yesterday, shares of Iomega closed at $13, down $2.375.

headline: Croats Jump Gun on Takeover of Sarajevo Suburb
abstract: A squad of Croatian police officers entered the burning Sarajevo suburb of Hadzici on Tuesday evening, jumping the gun on a scheduled takeover by Bosnia's  Muslim-Croat federation.         The action followed a dispute over the ethnic makeup of the federation police force, which under the Dayton peace accord was to take control of Hadzici from Bosnian Serb authorities this morning.

headline: 2 Tribunals On Atrocities Will Be Led By Canadian
abstract: Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali today appointed a Canadian judge with a background in civil rights and criminal law to replace Richard Goldstone  of South Africa as head of the international criminal tribunals on the former Yugoslavia and Rwanda.         The new judge, Louise Arbour, of the Ontario Court of Appeal, is to take office in October, subject to Security Council approval.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;MAY DEPARTMENT STORES TO SPIN OFF PAYLESS SHOE CHAIN
abstract: The May Department Stores Company said yesterday that it would spin off its Payless Shoe Source chain and take a $70 million charge in the fourth quarter. As part of the spinoff, the company expects to close or relocate about 450 of its 4,557 Payless stores. Payless, based in Topeka, Kan., is the largest chain of self-service family shoe stores in the nation, with sales last year of more than $2.1 billion. It has about 25,000 employees.

headline: Uncovered Short Sales Post A Slight Increase on Nasdaq
abstract: Open positions of short sales on the Nasdaq market rose slightly in the most  recent period, the National Association of Securities Dealers reported yesterday, still enough to reach the highest levels in 15 months.         The half-percent increase in the so-called total short interest moved it to 959 million shares. The rise indicates that many investors expect a decline in the value of shares traded on the Nasdaq market.

headline: Stop, Thief! And Give Me Back My Name.
abstract: I AM the real Marcia Vickers. I swear.         For the last year and a half, ever since my tote bag was snatched in a Manhattan restaurant, and with it my keys, credit cards, driver's license and other identification, there has been some confusion about this.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;DISNEY DEAL WITH CAPITAL CITIES/ABC ADVANCES
abstract: The Justice Department's antitrust division said yesterday that it had approved the Walt Disney Company's $19 billion purchase of Capital Cities/ABC Inc., after Disney agreed to sell the Los Angeles television station KCAL-TV. The department was investigating whether Disney's ownership of both the KCAL-TV  and KABC-TV stations in Los Angeles would reduce competition. The deal still requires approval from the Federal Communications Commission. Disney agreed to the appointment of a trustee to sell KCAL-TV; it has nine months to reach an agreement for the sale. Federal law does not allow broadcasters to own two VHF stations in a single market. Disney had filed an application seeking a temporary waiver of the rule.

headline: U.S. Rights Group Asserts China Lets Thousands of Orphans Die
abstract: A New York-based human rights organization asserted today that thousands of children have died in China's state-run orphanages from deliberate starvation, medical malpractice and staff abuse.         The group, Human Rights Watch, said it was impossible to obtain "a full accounting of the total number" and of the safety and health of China's orphan population, but based on detailed medical records smuggled out by a doctor from  a large Shanghai orphanage, and on a limited set of statistics relating to nationwide orphan mortality, there is cause for great alarm about the fate of countless abandoned infants, most of them girls.

headline: Bank Deal in Northwest
abstract: First Savings Bank of Washington Bancorp Inc. said today that it would acquire all the stock of Inland Empire Bank of Hermiston, Ore., for about $32.1  million in cash. Under terms of the agreement, shareholders of Inland Empire, which is closely held, will receive about $60.24 a share. Inland Empire had assets of about $159 million, deposits of $139 million, loans of $84 million and shareholders' equity of almost $18.5 million as of Dec. 31.

headline: Agency Tests a New Kind of Public Hearing
abstract: In a nationwide multimedia experiment that redefined the limits of a public hearing, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission linked its new World Wide Web site with the video conferencing system of four Kinko's copy shops around the country on Jan. 5 for a session on fire protection rules at nuclear power plants. The session married two media: the Web, in a real-time dialogue, and the video conferencing at Kinko's, whichallowed people in different cities to see and hear each other and interact. It was an experiment that the commission was not committed to repeating, but which it had hoped would be a milestone for a new way to conduct business.          No matter the outcome of the experiment, commission officials said that it could only be an improvement over the current system. William J. Olmstead, the commission's associate general counsel who served as master of ceremonies at the video conference, said that when he was a law student in Topeka, Kan., he was frustrated by not being able to attend hearings in Washington on affirmative action rules.

headline: U.S.-Chrysler Effort On Car of the Future
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation and the Department of Energy announced an $84 million research program today to develop high-tech "hybrid" propulsion systems  for cars of the future.         A hybrid vehicle combines two or more power sources -- like fuel cells, batteries, flywheels or combustion engines -- to achieve greater efficiency and  lower emissions of pollution than conventional cars.

headline: Anxiety at AT&T as Layoffs Loom
abstract: Lee Smith and Fred Dellanno shared lunch and anxieties today in the cafeteria at the AT&T Corporation's headquarters in the snowy woodlands of this quaint village.         Both are managers in the financial department that handles budgets for the long-distance company's customer-service representatives across the country. Mr. Dellanno, 44, seemed relaxed; he was recently told that his job and 13-year career is secure. But Mr. Smith, a 49-year-old father of three sons, has received no assurances that he would survive the 40,000-job cutback the telephone giant announced Tuesday.

headline: Ornda to Buy Hospital
abstract: Ornda Healthcorp agreed today to acquire Cypress Fairbanks Medical Center, an acute-care hospital in Houston. Terms were not disclosed. The 149-bed Cypress Fairbanks and its related operations had about $56 million in revenue last year. Ornda, a hospital management company based in Nashville, had revenue of $1.84 billion in its 1995 fiscal year.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Cowles Media Makes Acquisition
abstract: Cowles Business Media, a unit of the Cowles Media Company in Stamford, Conn., that publishes trade magazines like Inside Media, has agreed to acquire Promo Magazine and related assets of Smith Communications Inc. in Norwalk, Conn. Terms were not disclosed. Kerry E. Smith, 57, the editor and publisher of Promo, and his son, Kerry J. Smith, 32, the managing editor, are to continue to oversee editorial content and develop related properties.          Separately, Cowles Magazines in Stamford, a division of Cowles Media that publishes consumer titles like Fly Fisherman and Vegetarian Times, has changed its name to Cowles Enthusiast Media.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;German Shipbuilder Needs Immediate Bailout
abstract: Bremer Vulkan A.G., the largest shipbuilder in Germany, might declare bankruptcy today unless the group's management board, bankers and government officials can put together a rescue plan. Any plan would be subject to the approval of the European Commission in Brussels.          Ulrich Noelle, the finance minister in the city-state of Bremen, confirmed yesterday that the company needed money immediately. Late yesterday, Bremer Vulkan acknowledged that no candidate had declared an interest in a stake in the group, even though parts of Bremer were posting a profit. The shipbuilder employs 23,000 in Bremen and the eastern German state of Mecklenburg-Vorpommern.   (Reuters)

headline: Perry Says U.S. Spy Agencies Will Help Bosnia Tribunal
abstract: Defense Secretary William J. Perry said today that United States intelligence agencies could and would supply "important clues" to the international tribunal  investigating war crimes in Bosnia.         Other officials said the effort would center on mining through the mountains  of raw data collected over the last two years for other purposes. They said military intelligence agencies had only recently begun sifting through the material, including intercepted conversations among Serbian commanders, to find  information that might help convict military and political leaders of mass murder.

headline: F.T.C. Is Said To Investigate Toys 'R' Us
abstract: The Federal Trade Commission is investigating complaints that Toys "R" Us, the nation's largest toy retailer, has unfairly used its marketing power to discourage manufacturers from selling popular toys through discount stores, industry executives said yesterday.         They said the agency was also trying to determine if some of the biggest toy  makers, including Mattel Inc. and Hasbro Inc., had cooperated with Toys "R" Us in refusing to sell lucrative product lines, like some types of Barbie dolls, through warehouse clubs and other discount outlets.

headline: Dow Plunges 97.19 Points And Drops Below 5,100
abstract: Stock prices plummeted yesterday, spurred by the budget impasse in Washington and rising interest rates.         The Dow Jones industrial average, which at one time during the session was down more than 115 points, plunged 97.19 points by the closing bell, to 5,032.94. This decline of 1.89 percent marked the first time the Dow sank below  5,100 since Dec. 28 and pushed it to the lowest level since Nov. 21. Over the last two days, the average has fallen more than 3 percent -- its worst such drop in more than four years.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;INTERNATIONAL PAPER PLANS TO ELIMINATE 1,300 JOBS
abstract: The International Paper Company said yesterday that it would cut 1,300 jobs in the United States and Europe, resulting in a $70 million pretax charge against fourth-quarter earnings. The eliminated jobs represent 1.9 percent of International Paper's 70,000 employees at the end of 1994. George Adler, an analyst at Smith Barney Inc. in New York, said the moves by International Paper, the world's largest forest-products company, might be a response to reduced demand and lower prices for paper and cardboard boxes. The charge will reduce earnings by 17 cents a share, according to the company, which is based in Purchase, N.Y. A survey of 14 analysts by Zacks Investment Research before the announcement estimated that International Paper would earn $1.22 a share in the  quarter.

headline: Chrysler Stock Rise Was Aim Of Kerkorian
abstract: In the discussions leading up to last week's peace pact between the Chrysler  Corporation and Kirk Kerkorian, the billionaire investor was offered the chance  to sit on Chrysler's board. He turned it down, leaving that task to an aide.         Mr. Kerkorian was apparently more eager to see Chrysler's stock climb than he was to oversee the business, according to a series of documents that Mr. Kerkorian filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The papers, some of which were filed as recently as last week, indicated that he wanted to see the stock rise either through buybacks, dividend increases or a takeover.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Dispute Over U.S. Exports Of Poultry to Russia Settled
abstract: A trade dispute between the United States and Russia was apparently settled today when Washington received formal assurances that American poultry shipments to Russia would continue without interruption.         Vice President Al Gore announced this evening that he had been assured by Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin of Russia that a stoppage of poultry imports from the United States, threatened March 16, would not take place.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                                               Previous      Year                               Yesterday       Day       Ago

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Bankers Trust Dispute Settled
abstract: PT Dharmala Sakti Sejahtera of Indonesia has settled a dispute over $69 million in losses on derivatives it bought from the Bankers Trust New York Corporation.         The Indonesian financial services company agreed today to pay part of the $69 million it owed the New York bank for interest rate swaps, or bets on the direction of interest rates, that went awry in 1994, a Bankers Trust spokesman said in New York.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;HEALTH MANAGEMENT PLANS TO REVISE EARNINGS
abstract: Health Management Inc. said it would revise its financial results for the first and second quarters of the 1996 fiscal year, and the fourth quarter of the 1995 fiscal year, after an internal review. In a statement, Health Management, of Ronkonkoma, L.I., said the revision was not yet complete, but it believes it  will report a profit, before any one-time write-offs, for the first nine months  of the current fiscal year. The company also said it believes each of the first three quarters of the 1996 fiscal year will be profitable before one-time  write-offs. The provider of health management services warned last month that it might revise results after discovering accounting irregularities. The company's  stock rose $1.875, or 65 percent, to $4.75, in Nasdaq trading.

headline: Orders in Transportation Fell Sharply Last Month
abstract: The United States economy gained strength last month even though a midwinter  lull in aircraft purchases caused factory orders to fall by the largest percentage in 10 months, the Commerce Department reported today.         While overall orders dropped 2.5 percent in February -- as demand for passenger jets weakened -- analysts pointed to a seven-tenths of 1 percent increase in orders excluding transportation equipment as a sign that a spring rebound for the economy was likely.

headline: A Dissident Joins the Establishment
abstract: When he first arrived in Israel 10 years ago this month, Natan Sharansky rejected all the many efforts to get him to take sides, whether left or right, religious or secular.         All through his years of dissidence and incarceration in the Soviet Union, his dream was of an Israel where all Jews would have a place, and nothing seemed further from that than the rowdy divisions of his new homeland.

headline: Prosperous New Year?Asia's Markets Hope for Revival
abstract: HONG KONG—  Three years is a long time in the financial markets, and in Asia's volatile markets, it is an eternity.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;CONRAIL IN DISCUSSIONS ON SALE OF RAIL LINES
abstract: Conrail Inc. said yesterday that it was in exclusive talks with two companies on the sale of its nearly 400 miles of rail lines in eastern Massachusetts and Connecticut. Financial terms were not disclosed. Conrail, which is based in Philadelphia, said the talks were with Railtex Inc. of San Antonio and the Providence & Worcester Railroad Company, based in Worcester, Mass. Railtex would get certain tracks in Connecticut and Massachusetts, as well as operating rights on other tracks. Providence & Worcester would get ownership of freight service in parts of Connecticut and limited trackage rights on Conrail routes between the Connecticut-New York State border and the borough of Queens, as well as some freight rights in Massachusetts.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Tokyo Delays Decision On Breakup of N.T.T.
abstract: Japan's coalition Government yesterday postponed for a year any decision on whether to break up the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation. The postponement was included in an announcement of a package of measures aimed at deregulating the Japanese economy.          The Government had to respond by yesterday to a report issued in February calling for a breakup of the giant company as a way of increasing competition in the Japanese telecommunications market.   Bloomberg Business News

headline: Judge Blocks a Law On Smut on Internet
abstract: A Federal judge temporarily blocked enforcement of a new law that makes it a  felony to transmit indecent material over the Internet or on-line computer services if the material may be seen by children.  The judge ruled that the term "indecent" was unconstitutionally vague and was not defined in the new law, the  Communications Decency Act.          But, drawing a semantic distinction, Judge Ronald L. Buckwalter of Federal District Court in Philadelphia upheld another part of the same law. That section makes it a felony to use computer networks to display, in a way accessible to minors, "patently offensive" material. The complex ruling sets the stage for a swift judicial review of the law and an uncertain outcome.

headline: Corrections
abstract: A table last Sunday with an article about five hypothetical retirement portfolios included incorrect listings for the first-quarter portfolio of Eric M. Kobren, president of Insight Management in Wellesley, Mass. A corrected table appears today on page 7.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;U.S. ROBOTICS WITHDRAWS HAYES MICROCOMPUTER BID
abstract: The U.S. Robotics Corporation withdrew its $97.5 million bid to acquire Hayes Microcomputer Products Inc. yesterday, saying the acquisition would not be in the best interests of its shareholders. Hayes is a modem maker currently operating under bankruptcy-court protection. The withdrawal of U.S. Robotics' bid leaves two options for Hayes: to be taken over by Diamond Multimedia Systems Inc. for $111 million or to emerge from bankruptcy proceedings as an independent company. Hayes filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in November 1994.

headline: OFF THE RACK;Taking Promises of Profits With a Bigger Grain of Salt
abstract: BEFORE you put your money in companies whose promise is tied to some new product or developing technology, you'd better put up your defenses against securities fraud.         That is the most powerful of several messages in the package of four articles highlighted on the cover of Worth magazine's April issue.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Pharmacia & Upjohn To Cut 10% of Jobs
abstract: Pharmacia & Upjohn Inc. confirmed yesterday that it would trim its work force by 4,000, about 10 percent, and set up headquarters near London. The company's president, John Zabriskie, also said the company -- the world's ninth-largest drug concern -- planned to introduce 28 products for treating a range of illnesses, including Parkinson's disease, cancer, AIDS and central nervous system disorders.          The job cuts have been expected since November, when the Upjohn Company, one of America's largest drug makers, merged with Pharmacia A.B. of Sweden in a $13  billion deal. Mr. Zabriskie said job losses would be announced country by country in the next six weeks.   (AP)

headline: Britain and Ireland Move to Restart the Peace Effort in Ulster
abstract: The Irish and British Governments announced early this morning that they had  agreed on a new initiative aimed at reviving the Northern Ireland peace effort.          The agreement, announced at 12:20 A.M., was reached by Prime Ministers John Bruton of Ireland and John Major of Britain, who are to meet in London later today to disclose the details.

headline: COMPANY NEWS
abstract: GREENWICH BUYING AVIALL'S ENGINE SERVICES UNIT Greenwich Air Services Inc. signed a letter of intent yesterday to purchase Aviall Inc.'s Commercial Engine Services division for an estimated price of $260 million to $280 million. Shares of both companies surged yesterday. The acquisition will make Greenwich the world's largest company in the business of engine repair, maintenance and overhaul. The purchase includes Aviall's operations in Dallas, Fort Worth and Prestwick, Scotland, as well as its components business in McAllen, Tex. Greenwich shares rose $5, or 22 percent, to close at $27.75 in Nasdaq trading; Aviall shares rose $1.25, or 23.3 percent, to close at $6.625 on the New York Stock Exchange. (Reuters)

headline: Sale Suggestion Lifts Helene Curtis Shares
abstract: Shares of Helene Curtis Industries soared $6.625 on the Big Board today, to $40.75, after Shamrock Holdings of California Inc. asked the company to put itself on the block.         Shamrock, an investment group controlled by members of the Disney family, owns about 7.6 percent of Helene Curtis's shares. The firm said it was seeking a meeting with Helene Curtis management, shareholders and board members.

headline: Bellicose Beijing Makes Asians Uneasy
abstract: SINGAPORE—  China's increasingly bellicose approach toward Taiwan is fanning concerns in Asia that Beijing may be pursuing a plan to recover "lost territory" that goes far beyond the return of Hong Kong in 1997, Macau in 1999 and "early" reunification with Taiwan.

headline: OFF THE SHELF;Primers of Persuasion: How to Win With Words
abstract: A FRIEND of mine, a lawyer doing business in the former Soviet sphere, once told me about a contract he negotiated for some American businessmen investing in a Russian enterprise during the old perestroika days.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt

headline: Small Companies, Big Problems
abstract: These days, when the California Public Employees' Retirement System talks, big business usually listens.
