After a slow start, the pension fund, with $97 billion in assets and a reformist's fervor to match, has won several breakthroughs as the leader of the decade-old shareholders' campaign to hold poorly performing chief executives' feet to the fire.         So it was with confidence that Calpers, as the fund is known, decided last summer to turn its attention to the nation's small and medium-sized companies. It picked eight, all with less than $2 billion in sales, from among the weakest  performers in its portfolio of 1,500-plus companies. Last fall, it quietly started seeking meetings to air its concerns with the executives and directors,  just as it always had.

headline: Real Estate;Providence, R.I., is getting a $375 million shopping mall after nine years of planning.
abstract: THE development of a regional shopping mall in downtown Providence, nine years in planning, has moved into the site-preparation phase after final approval from the city.         The $375 million project will have 1.2 million square feet of shopping space  designed to link the State Capitol with the municipal offices, shops and restaurants of downtown. The Providence Place Mall, as it will be known, has already received lease commitments for 675,000 square feet of retail space.

headline: International Paper Names Chief Executive
abstract: The International Paper Company said today that John A. Georges would retire  on March 31 as chairman and chief executive and that John T. Dillon, president and chief operating officer, would succeed Mr. Georges.         Mr. Georges, who turned 65 on Saturday, has been chief executive since September 1984 and became chairman the following April. He will continue as a member of the company's board.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;EATON BIDS FOR CAPCO AUTOMOTIVE AFTER TALKS STOP
abstract: The Eaton Corporation offered yesterday to acquire the Capco Automotive Products Corporation for $11 a share in cash, or a total of $121.7 million, after Eaton said merger talks between the two companies had broken down. Eaton also said it would nominate its own slate of candidates for election to Capco's  board at that company's annual meeting on May 14. Eaton, which owns about 7.3 percent of Capco's stock, said that the companies had discussed a possible merger but that Capco's board had recently refused to continue the talks. Capco, based in South Bend, Ind., makes truck transmissions. Eaton, based in Cleveland, makes automotive equipment.

headline: Market Place;A reorganized SCEcorp faces California deregulation plans.
abstract: SCECORP and its electric utility subsidiary, Southern California Edison, rang in the new year by reorganizing themselves to prepare for the deregulation of California's $20 billion electric utility industry. The move prompted an upbeat  reaction from Wall Street analysts, but many continue to hedge their predictions for the coming year, waiting for clearer signs of what a competitive market will look like in California.        The changes, intended to streamline management and speed up decision-making,  created five business units devoted to its core activities: generating electricity, controlling bulk power transmission, delivering electricity, providing customer service and managing power contracts with third parties.

headline: Dijon Journal;To Arms! Rebuilt Organ May Have German Accent
abstract: Burgundy, with its matchless wines and architectural monuments, is the last place you might expect the French to be on the defensive about their culture.         There is little argument from Germans, Americans or anyone else who visits Dijon or nearby towns with names like Gevray-Chambertin, Fixin and Nuits-St.-Georges about the wine.

headline: Acquisition by Thomson
abstract: The Thomson Corporation's publishing unit said today that it had acquired Coriolis Group Inc. of Scottsdale, for an undisclosed amount. Coriolis publishes books, a magazine and computer software that is used to browse the Internet and  is also used by professional software programmers. Thomson, which is based in Toronto, bought Coriolis through its International Thomson Publishing unit of Stamford, Conn.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Keeping Corporate Score;In South Africa It's Even Hard to Find the Players
abstract: The South Afri can economy is Teddy Roosevelt's nightmare what America might  look like if the trusts had never been busted, John D. Rockefeller had won the Standard Oil case and the unions still had to deal with Andrew Carnegie, the autocratic steel magnate.         Nearly 80 percent of private industry is controlled by five super-conglomerates. Cartels in some industries, like diamonds, operate openly.  In staples like beer and sugar, one or two producers dominate the market and set prices. Goods that Americans take for granted, from steaks to new cars to televisions, are so expensive that the average South African cannot afford them.

headline: Technology: DIGITAL COMMERCE;Three companies are preparing fast-action games for the slow-motion internet
abstract: IT would be hard to find a medium less suited than the Internet for playing twitch-finger, fast-action video games. You can die a thousand virtual deaths in a video game if you bang on your fire button and nothing happens. Yet "nothing happens" has become the chant of anyone who spends time mouse-clicking buttons on the Internet's World Wide Web, which is slow and unpredictable on a good day.         But Internet mania has three start-up companies in the San Francisco Bay area laughing in the face of danger. The companies -- Total Entertainment Network of  San Francisco and Catapult Entertainment and Mpath Interactive, both based in Cupertino -- are preparing services designed to allow multiple players to battle over the Internet.

headline: Home Resales Fall Despite Lower Mortgage Rates
abstract: Sales of previously owned homes fell in December for a third straight month,  despite the lowest mortgage rates in nearly two years, a realty group said today, in another sign of a slowing economy.         Sales of existing homes fell to an annual rate of 3.91 million, down 3.2 percent from November, the National Association of Realtors said. The December sales rate was up 4 percent from the same month of 1994 but it was weaker than Wall Street forecasts of a 4.02 million December reading.

headline: Nerds' Revenge: A How-To Manual
abstract: IN August, the Netscape Communications Corporation held one of the most successful initial public stock offerings in Silicon Valley history. In a single day, the year-old company, with just $17 million in sales, was valued at more than $3 billion. And the stock kept climbing.         It was an exciting moment for Netscape employees, many of whom had instant personal fortunes -- on paper, at least. But almost as exciting was the day three months later when the underwriter, Morgan Stanley, decided Netscape's stock was strong enough to release the lock-out on its sale by non-officers. That's when the payoff became real.

headline: Keeping the Peace in Bosnia, and the Press
abstract: When a reporter approached some Army sergeants huddled around a kerosene stove for warmth recently, trying to engage them in conversation, the reception  was as chilly as the weather they were trying to ward off.         "Can we to talk to him, sir?" one sergeant asked when an officer came over. Sure, said the lieutenant, tell him whatever you want, and walked off.

headline: Charges in 1974 Killing Raise Tensions in Chile
abstract: For two decades, Sofia and Maria Angelica Prats have tried to determine who was responsible for the bombing in 1974 that killed their father, Gen. Carlos Prats Gonzalez, a former Chilean Army commander who opposed the military coup led by Gen. Augusto Pinochet.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: GENERAL ELECTRIC CO., Fairfield, Conn., said the consortium of its GE Power Systems division and two Italian companies, Snamprogetti and Turbotecnica, had received a $600 million contract to build a power plant in Sardinia. GE Power also won a contract worth more than $130 million to build part of a new power plant in Takoradi, Ghana.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Film Magazine Editor to Lead Disney's Development Efforts
abstract: The Walt Disney Motion Pictures Group has named Susan Lyne, editor in chief and founder of Premiere: The Movie Magazine, to the newly created position of executive vice president for acquisitions and development of intellectual material and new opportunities.         Ms. Lyne will work from New York, where the parent Walt Disney Company is assuming an increasingly larger presence. She founded Premiere in 1987 as a magazine devoted to coverage of all aspects of the movie industry and has been its editor in chief ever since. She is well regarded in Hollywood as someone who is knowledgeable about the industry and who knows virtually all the producers, directors, stars and other important players.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LOMAK PETROLEUM INC., Fort Worth, an independent oil and gas production and development company, agreed to buy three oil and gas properties in Texas and the Appalachian region for about $17.5 million.

headline: The Declaration by Peres: 'War in Every Sense of the Word'
abstract: Following are excerpts from a statement by Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel at a news conference after a suicide bomber attack in Jerusalem:          Good afternoon. We awoke this morning to a terrible blow, for everyone, with no exception, for the entire country. I have no intention of detracting in any way from the size of the blow or its pain. At the same time, the solution is not crying and not demonstrations; the solution is a correct analysis of the things  which can and should be implemented, without hesitation. Hamas has decided to attack Israelis, to destroy peace -- in my opinion it has decided to return the  Palestinians to a world of despair, hatred and animosity. . . .

headline: THE BALKAN PEACE: THE PROSECUTIONS;A Croat, a Muslim and a Serb Are Held in Balkan War-Crimes Cases
abstract: Authorities in Germany and Austria announced today that they had detained three men suspected of committing atrocities in the former Yugoslavia including, for the first time, a Bosnian Muslim said to have killed Bosnian Serb civilians.         The arrest of the Muslim suspect in Vienna and a Croat in Munich suspected of similar activities were the first tribunal actions in which the Bosnian Serbs had appeared as victims, Christian Chartier, a spokesman for the tribunal, said  today.

headline: Out of the Cold: U.S. and Russian Spies Share Cloaks in Bosnia
abstract: United States intelligence services, forced to cooperate with one another and with their Russian counterparts in the muddy fields of Bosnia, are creating an espionage network of dozens of spies, electronic-eavesdropping devices and sophisticated computer systems.         The choreography among the American intelligence services, the cross-fertilization of their information and its availability to soldiers in the field are equally unusual -- "unprecedented," said an admiral and a general, who spoke on the condition of anonymity.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Just in time for spring, hokum from a most traditional source.
abstract: SO outrageous is the hoopla, ballyhoo, bunkum -- and yes, secrecy -- of the $15 million advertising campaign for "Airiana the Arrow" that it could have been conceived by P. T. Barnum.         Airiana is the star of the 126th edition of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum  & Bailey Circus. But the circus will not permit interviews with her, nor can her flight be videotaped. And in television, radio, print and outdoor advertising, she is described as "ethereal and inspiring, mysterious and magnificent," a performer who traverses the ring like a comet "trailing across the darkened sky before passing into the infinity of space."

headline: Boeing Plans Higher Production Of Three Jetliners Next Year
abstract: The Boeing Company said yesterday that it would increase production of its 737, 747 and 757 jetliners next year, reflecting the continued rebound in demand for commercial aircraft.         The production rate increases follow modest growth in Boeing's 20-year forecast for commercial aircraft this month. Boeing predicted that air-passenger traffic would grow 5.1 percent a year, and that airlines would add 15,900 airplanes, worth more than $1.1 trillion, to their fleets during that 20-year period.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;True North Appoints 2 Top Executives
abstract: True North Communications in Chicago, which owns agencies including Foote, Cone & Belding, promoted two top executives yesterday.         J. Brendan Ryan, president and chief executive of FCB/Leber Katz Partners, also owned by True North, in New York since 1991, was named chairman and chief executive at Foote, Cone. And Jack Balousek, 50, who as president and chief operating officer at Foote, Cone since 1991 has overseen West Coast operations,  was named to the new position of chairman and chief executive at TN Technologies, the digital and interactive marketing services unit of True North.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;STERILE CONCEPTS REJECTS OFFER FROM MAXXIM MEDICAL
abstract: Sterile Concepts Holdings Inc. has rejected an unsolicited acquisition offer  of $118 million from Maxxim Medical Inc. Maxxim last month proposed acquiring all the outstanding common stock of Sterile Concepts at $16 a share. Sterile Concepts, based in Richmond, provides surgical and clinical trays to hospitals and surgery centers. Maxxim, based in Sugar Land, Tex., is a maker and supplier  of medical products. The shares of Sterile Concepts rose 37.5 cents, to $17.625, yesterday, and the stock of Maxxim was down 62.5 cents, at $18.875, on  the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;North Castle Hires a Castle
abstract: North Castle Partners Advertising in Stamford, Conn., said it expects to have someone named Castle working at the agency.

headline: INVESTING IT;Short-Sellers Are Lonely Hunters, but Is Their Bounty Near?
abstract: TRYING to profit from overvalued stocks has never been easy. But given the roaring bull market of recent years, the task has become onerous, and that has made a hard job even harder for short-sellers. These professionals hunt for sky-high equities and, by borrowing shares, sell them at the lofty price while later paying the lower price to which they expect the stock to tumble. They pocket the difference -- or pay it, if they guessed wrong.         Despite short-sellers' recent bad luck, investors in a soaring market can still learn from them. Indeed, if the Dow falters, their perspectives may be much in demand. So we paid a visit recently to Michael Katz and Geoffrey Hulme,  partners who manage a total of $30 million in Reynard Partners and Glenrock Global Partners in Manhattan. Reynard is a short-selling fund, and Glenrock is a hedge fund that is half short, half long.

headline: Talks Continue on Possible Sale of Prodigy
abstract: Like the child of a couple considering divorce, the Prodigy Services Company  is struggling to maintain life as usual, even while its parents, I.B.M. and Sears, haggle.         Linda Blakeley, a spokeswoman for Sears, Roebuck & Company in Chicago said yesterday that the company was continuing a review it began in the middle of last year "to assess the strategic value of Prodigy to Sears." She said the company expected to make a decision by the end of March. The giant retailer has  said in the past that Prodigy probably does not fit in with its refocused strategy.

headline: U.S. Sending More Ships to Taiwan Area in Warning to China
abstract: Faced with rising tensions between China and Taiwan, the Clinton Administration has decided to step up American forces in the area, including sending a second carrier battle group there, officials said tonight.        Secretary of State Warren Christopher today warned China against any further  "reckless" or "risky" acts in the wake of its missile tests just off Taiwan's shores last week and China's announcement Saturday of plans for more military exercises there in the days leading up to Taiwan elections on March 23.

headline: U.S. Linked To Saudi Aid For Bosnians
abstract: Saudi Arabia funneled $300 million in weapons to the Muslim-led Government forces in Bosnia with the knowledge and tacit cooperation of the United States,  it was reported tonight.         The report appeared in The Washington Post, which attributed the information  to an unidentified official. Attempts to confirm the account with United States  officials were unsuccessful tonight.

headline: Real Estate;A new agency of New York City is moving into the International Design Center in  Long Island City.
abstract: THE City of New York has leased more than 200,000 square feet at the International Design Center in Long Island City, Queens, for a new agency, the Department of Design and Construction Services. The agency, responsible for most city-sponsored construction projects, has an option for an additional 113,000 square feet. The 17 1/2-year lease was valued at $40 million.         Jeff Kondrat, assistant commissioner for leasing and space design in the Department of General Services, said the city had chosen the site because it was the "most cost effective."

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Hong Kong Stocks Plunge 7.3%, Rattled by U.S. Bond Prices and China
abstract: As Hong Kong's stock market spiraled precipitously lower amid worries of war  over Taiwan and over American interest rates, a mood of anxiety settled over this territory today.         In the four days since China fired three ballistic missiles into waters off Taiwan's two major ports, the volume of oratory and the pace of armed buildup have rapidly mounted. On Saturday, China announced that it would begin a week of live-fire military exercises over 6,000 square miles of the South China Sea off  the coastline of Taiwan. This was followed today by news that the United States  was sending two aircraft-carrier battle groups to the region.

headline: Jordan Now Succeeding in Mending Gulf Ties Frayed by Iraq
abstract: With a toughened stand against Iraq, King Hussein of Jordan has brought his country close to full rapprochement with Saudi Arabia and Kuwait, which had refused to forgive Jordan for supporting the Baghdad Government during the Persian Gulf war.         This weekend, for the first time since 1990, the Jordanian monarch is to make an official visit to Saudi Arabia to meet with Saudi leaders. The trip was announced this week after King Hussein installed a new Prime Minister who is an  open critic of the leader of Iraq, and it follows an exchange of letters between the ruling families of Jordan and Kuwait, the first since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in 1990.

headline: Syria to Stay In Israel Talks as U.S. Urges
abstract: The Syrians have agreed to continue peace talks with Israel in Maryland on Feb. 26, despite concern that early Israeli elections would slow or disrupt the  negotiations, Secretary of State Warren Christopher said here today.         "Both sides want to preserve a continuity of negotiations, whatever the election calendar," Mr. Christopher said, adding that the decision to keep talking "reflects the commitment of the parties to the goal of achieving a peace treaty in 1996."

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Morgan Stanley Plans Hotel Deal in Mexico
abstract: Morgan Stanley Group Inc. said yesterday that it and the Mexican hotel operator Grupo Posadas S.A. planned to spend $200 million in a joint venture to  buy and develop hotels in Mexico and elsewhere. The investment would be the first foray by a large United States corporation into Mexico's troubled real estate market since the peso collapsed in December 1994.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Fed's Finances Criticized In Congressional Report A Congressional report criticized the Federal Reserve's management of its finances, suggesting the central bank could spend less and return billions of dollars to taxpayers.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;USAir Posts Annual Profit After Seven Years of Losses
abstract: USAir Group Inc. said today that it posted a profit in the fourth quarter on  higher revenue and continued cost-cutting and also announced its first annual profit since 1988.         The airline, which is based here, said that its fourth-quarter net income was $60.3 million, or 61 cents a share, compared with a loss of $322 million, or $5.63, in the corresponding quarter in the previous year. Lower operating expenses, down 10 percent, to $1.75 billion, from $1.95 billion a year ago, helped increase income for the quarter.

headline: Berlin Journal;Exoneration Still Eludesc An Anti-Nazi Crusader
abstract: During his turbulent life, Carl von Ossietzky, winner of the 1935 Nobel Peace Prize, did not lack for enemies.         In the years before the Nazis took power in 1933, he edited a crusading Berlin magazine, Weltbuhne, which preached pacifism and strongly opposed German  rearmament. He spent time in jail and in two concentration camps before dying of the effects of his mistreatment in 1938, at age 48.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;NATIONAL ENERGY TO ACQUIRE ALEXANDER ENERGY
abstract: National Energy Group said yesterday that it had signed a letter of intent to acquire the Alexander Energy Corporation in a stock deal valued at $129 million, including assumption of about $48 million in debt. The Dallas-based National Energy has offered 1.8 shares of its stock for each Alexander share. National's  president and chief executive, Miles Bender, said the two companies' oil and gas reserves, mainly in the Midwest, were complementary. Alexander, which is 8.7 percent owned by the New York investor Carl C. Icahn, looks for and develops oil and gas deposits in Oklahoma and Arkansas. National Energy's stock fell 12.5 cents, to $3.375, while shares of Alexander, based in Oklahoma City, edged up 12.5 cents, to $4.688, in Nasdaq trading.

headline: One European Currency: Is the 1999 Target Credible?
abstract: A single European currency by the end of the 1990's is a goal that seems as distant today as German unity did at the beginning of the 1980's. Then as now, politicians were swearing that they wanted it, and experts were telling them that it was unrealistic.         The collapse of Communism made possible the reunification of Germany in 1990. But the threat of collapse in European economic growth now -- a real possibility after a slump in Germany and France since the end of last year -- could force Europe's leaders to put off a common currency into the next decade.

headline: Stroh to Buy Heileman in Big Brewery Deal
abstract: The Stroh Brewery Company said today that it planned to buy the G. Heileman Brewing Company in a complex deal estimated at $275 million to $300 million.         The deal would put Stroh, the nation's fourth-largest brewery, within striking distance of the third-ranked Adolph Coors Company, which last year had 10.1 percent of the beer market. Stroh and Heileman combined had 9.2 percent of the market last year, according to Benj S. Steinman, president of Beer Marketer's Insights, an industry newsletter.

headline: TECHNOLOGY: DIGITAL COMMERCE;A few resolutions for high-tech movers and shakers.
abstract: DESPITE the mood swings of high-tech stocks throughout last year, at the dawn of 1996 more people in the world are computerized, World Wide Webbed or dripping rich from Internet-related public stock offerings than anyone would have dreamed of at the dawn of 1995.         Yet there is always room for improvement. So as a public service, this column offers a few New Year's resolutions for those in the business who might otherwise be tempted to overlook their shortcomings.

headline: Merger Expert Quits Salomon
abstract: Mark Davis, the co-head of mergers and acquisitions at Salomon Brothers Inc., has resigned to become head of mergers at the combined Chase Manhattan and Chemical Banking Corporations, officials at both said yesterday.         Mr. Davis, 36, was one of Salomon's top investment bankers. His clients included the Scott Paper Company in its $7.4 billion acquisition last year of the Kimberly-Clark Corporation. He was not available to comment.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: McKECHNIE P.L.C., London, an automotive concern, agreed to buy Thompson International Inc., Troy, Mich., a wheel-trim maker, for $50.4 million and the assumption of $14.6 million in debt.

headline: Hewlett-Packard in Deal
abstract: The Hewlett-Packard Company said today that it would buy an equity stake in Businessweb, a company in Cambridge, Mass., that develops business applications  for the Internet. Financial terms were not disclosed. Hewlett-Packard, the computer giant based in Palo Alto, Calif., also said the two companies had signed a joint marketing and consulting agreement.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Daewoo Plans for India
abstract: The Daewoo Group of South Korea is planning to invest $5 billion in India in  the next five years, Lee Chul Soo, chairman of DCM Daewoo Ltd., told a meeting of Indian and Korean business executives in New Delhi yesterday. The spending will make Daewoo the largest foreign investor in India. Daewoo's main project is a car manufacturing venture with the DCM Group. Daewoo holds a 51 percent stake  in the venture.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                                               Previous      Year                               Yesterday       Day       Ago

headline: European Topics : Heading for Majorca? Brush Up on Your Catalan
abstract: In Palma, Majorca, the newspaper Baleares will soon become the Diari de Balears, ending a 60-year Spanish-language history to publish instead in Catalan.

headline: When High Technology Meets Low Stock Price
abstract: Never much of a bean counter, Carlo de Benedetti is watching the numbers closely these days, as shares in Olivetti S.p.A., the electronics company he controls, are buffeted by a wave of selling that appears to reflect bets that the share price will continue to decline.         With one eye, the Olivetti chairman, who is 61, says he is counting the subscribers who have signed up for Olivetti's mobile-phone system, Omnitel, which was inaugurated in December and is part of Olivetti's strategy to transform itself into a telecommunications company from a computer company.

headline: Farrakhan's Angry World Tour Brings Harsh Criticism at Home
abstract: Four months after his Million Man March edged him toward the political mainstream, Louis Farrakhan has touched off wide criticism with an extended world tour, which included countries the United States considers pariahs, and his bitterly anti-American remarks along the way.         Mr. Farrakhan, the head of the American group the Nation of Islam, said his 20-nation "world friendship tour" to Iran, Libya, the Sudan, Nigeria, Syria and  other nations was intended to spread the message of self-help and personal responsibility that was voiced in October at the Million Man March in Washington.

headline: Japan Pledges to Open Economy, But Lack of Detail Raises Doubts
abstract: Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto today pledged far-reaching changes in Japan's economic structure and promised a "thoroughgoing deregulation" of the thicket of restrictions that curb just about every aspect of commercial life.         Mr. Hashimoto, who was elected Prime Minister this month, also emphasized in  a major speech today to the opening session of Parliament that the relationship  with the United States would remain the foundation of Japanese foreign policy.

headline: Voters Are Few in Bangladesh As a Dozen Die in Clashes
abstract: A boycott by the major opposition parties in Bangladesh helped insure a scanty turnout today in a general election that was marked by widespread clashes between Government and opposition supporters.         The violence, in areas around the country, killed at least a dozen people and injured many others, adding to scores of casualties that occurred before election day. Reports reaching Dhaka, the capital, indicated that a large majority of the approximately 50 million eligible voters stayed away from the polls, with an overall turnout that might have been less than 10 percent.

headline: CUBAN COMMUNISTS TAKE HARDER LINE
abstract: Warning of what it described as a campaign by the United States to "deceive,  confuse and dismantle" the Cuban revolution, the Cuban Communist Party has called for strengthening ideological and economic orthodoxy and threatened "severe punishment" for those who failed to comply.         The party's Central Committee endorsed a harder political line against what it said were Washington-supported "Trojan horses" and "fifth columnists" in its  midst. Reports of the rare full session, which was held last weekendbehind closed doors, only began to emerge this week.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Treasury Prices Fall On Strengthening Economy Treasury bond prices fell sharply on comments by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, and a report on durable goods that both suggested that mounting economic growth could stave off further cuts in interest rates. Traders took the chance to sell, and the price of the 30-year bond dropped 1 8/32, to 91 8/32. Its yield rose to 6.68 percent, from 6.57 percent on Tuesday. [Page D20.]

headline: Malaysian Sports Car Due
abstract: The first sports car made in Malaysia is to roll out of the factory in April. TVR Sports (Malaysia) Pty. Ltd., which has the license to manufacture the composite-body sports car with TVR Engineering of Britain, began pilot production last month at a plant in Port Klang, near here, The New Straits Times reported today. About 1,000 TVR Chimaera cars a year will be produced, most for export, said the managing director of TVR Sports, Ti Teow Yong. The car, with a V8 engine, is expected to cost about $80,000. Malaysian companies already make or assemble passenger cars.

headline: Dealers Plan Huge Used-Car Chain With No Bargaining
abstract: A group of the nation's biggest car dealers said today that it planned to open 100 huge used-car dealerships, a move that it hopes will significantly change the way Americans buy used cars.         The chain, to be called Driver's Mart Worldwide Inc., will stock 350 to 650 late-model used cars and trucks at each dealership, offer detailed warranties and set fixed prices with no bargaining permitted, Thomas W. Eggleston, the chain's chief executive, said.

headline: INVESTING IT;With Fewer Stocks to Buy, The Bulls May Stay Hungry
abstract: IT'S not quite the incredible shrinking stock market, but there are fewer stocks around today than there were at the start of last year. And the shrinkage may be both a force that has pushed the Dow upward and a solid clue about where  it may be headed.         While investors seldom think about it, stocks are goods, just like oranges or tickets to the Olympics. As such, their numbers can grow or dwindle. New stock issues -- the initial public offerings of private companies and the secondary offerings of already-public ones -- add to the supply of stocks. But when companies go private, merge with other companies or buy back their own stock, the supply shrinks.

headline: Russia's Prime Minister Says He'll Soften the Economic Steps
abstract: Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin of Russia said today that he would soften the process of economic reform as demanded by President Boris N. Yeltsin.         Mr. Yeltsin, in Friday's state of the nation address, criticized his own Government for failing to protect living standards while steering the country to a market economy, and he said the Government could be kicked out of office as a result.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;R. J. Reynolds Picks Gyro Advertising
abstract: The R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company said yesterday that it had named Gyro Advertising in Philadelphia as agency of record for its Red Kamel cigarette brand, which is being reintroduced after a 60-year hiatus. The billings were not disclosed.         Richard Williams, a spokesman in Winston-Salem, N.C., for Reynolds, which is  owned by RJR Nabisco Holdings, confirmed a report of the assignment this week in Advertising Age. Gyro, which has worked for Reynolds "on a per-assignment basis," he said, was named to handle Red Kamel because Mezzina/Brown in New York, the agency for the Camel cigarette line, "is working on a lot of things for our core Camel brand that we didn't want to pull them away from."

headline: Market Place;C-TEC plays 'Beat the Clock' with Clinton capital gains plan.
abstract: THE 1996 award for the most hastily assembled, but best-timed, news release may go to the C-TEC Corporation, a telephone and cable television company based  in Princeton, N.J.         Late on Tuesday, C-TEC announced that it was thinking of spinning off part of its company, and that another part might be acquired by an unidentified suitor.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;British Companies to Sell 25% of Phone Venture
abstract: Hutchison Whampoa Ltd. and British Aerospace P.L.C. said yesterday that they  would sell 25 percent of their Orange P.L.C. mobile telephone venture, yielding  L500 million, or $750 million, to repay existing loans. Hutchison said it would  sell shares in a global initial public offering of the company in March.          Orange has added 20,000 subscribers since Dec. 31, reaching 400,000 subscribers, or 7 percent of the total mobile phone market. The company is 69-percent owned by Hutchison and 31 percent by British Aerospace.   Bloomberg Business News

headline: INSIDE
abstract: INVESTING IT/Page 3/ Odyssey Nutriceutical Sciences has no sales and no marketing staff. But no matter. It does have a weapon: doctors. By Kurt Eichenwald.

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Tajikistan Says It Impeded A Press by Islamic Rebels
abstract: Tajikistan said today that Government troops had stemmed an advance by Islamic rebels in heavy fighting in a remote mountain region 125 miles east of the capital, Dushanbe.         The rebels, who have based themselves in Afghanistan since being driven from  Tajikistan in the civil war in 1992, have regained a foothold in the region, whose population is broadly sympathetic to their cause. They have made their biggest advances in more than a year after opening an offensive just over a week ago that coincided with a revolt in the military.

headline: Longtime Ruler Overshadows Dominican Republic Election
abstract: This was supposed to be an election to mark the end of an era and usher in a  new generation of leaders. But with a presidential vote looming here, the dominant figure of the campaign now in full swing turns out to be the same man who has governed this country for most of the past 35 years: Joaquin Balaguer.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;BANKERS TRUST NEW YORK CORP. (BT,N)
abstract: The Bankers Trust New York Corporation reported yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings rose 25 percent. The results disappointed Wall Street and depressed the the company's stock.         Bankers Trust, the nation's eighth-largest banking company, said profits were bolstered by higher trading revenue and a $145 million pretax gain from the sale of shares in Northwest Airlines.

headline: Chechen Raid Again Captures Many Russians
abstract: In an audacious repetition of one of Russia's worst military humiliations, a  band of Chechen rebels stormed a large hospital in the center of this southern Russian city on Tuesday, taking an estimated 2,000 hostages, leaving scores dead and promising to leave only when Russian troops withdraw from Chechnya.         "We can turn this city to hell and ashes," the commander of the raid, Salman  Raduyev, declared in an interview broadcast Tuesday night by Russian television. Mr. Raduyev is married to the niece of Dzhokar Dudayev, leader of the Chechen separatists.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
abstract: The Clarion Business Communications division of Clarion Marketing and Communications, Greenwich, Conn., which is owned by D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, was named the first agency to handle accounts for three clients with combined billings estimated at $10 million: Hyperion Software, Stamford, Conn.,  for trade advertising; SEI Corp., Wayne, Pa., to handle marketing communications for the data processor, and Sony Entertainment Systems, New York, a unit of the Sony Corp., to develop a communications program.

headline: Down on the Farm, a Donor;Breeding Pigs That Can Provide Organs for Humans
abstract: In the United States today, about 3,000 patients die annually waiting for an  organ transplant. Some 100,000 more die each year never having qualified for a place on the waiting list. But in the near future, victims of organ failure may  have a new alternative: a heart, liver, lung or kidney from a genetically altered pig.         Four small biotechnology companies are racing to develop pigs that could serve as organ donors for humans. Significant medical and technical hurdles remain, but the progress in recent months by these companies and their academic  collaborators prompts some of their scientists to suggest that the first organ transplant from a pig to a human could occur within a year. Xenotransplants, as  such cross-species operations are known, could be commonplace a decade from now, they say.

headline: Cheers for Cautious Saving
abstract: To the Editor:         As headlines constantly scream the dangers of the national debt, Sherry Lansing, the chairwoman of Paramount Pictures, should be celebrated, not seen as "peculiar," for her conservative investing strategy ("Under a Mattress Will Be Fine, Thanks," Dec. 3).

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;WOOLWORTH CORP. (Z,N)
abstract: The Woolworth Corporation said yesterday that it lost more than $100 million  in its fiscal fourth quarter, mainly because of an accounting charge to write down the value of some assets.         The retailer said the loss totaled $107 million, or 80 cents a share, for the quarter ending Jan. 27, compared with profits of $90 million, or 69 cents a share, a year earlier.

headline: EARNING IT;Retiring? Check Over The Boss's Arithmetic
abstract: WHEN Bruce A. Durant was pondering early retirement last summer, his employer, United Parcel Service of America, gave him a signed statement showing  that his monthly pension would be $2,623.         But five months after he left his $80,000-a-year job, Mr. Durant, 51, says he got a letter from the huge delivery company that came as "just a shock." It said U.P.S. had made a mistake in figuring his benefits, and it was cutting his pension by $321 a month -- or more than $3,850 a year for the rest of his life.  The company also docked his monthly checks to recover about $1,600 in overpayments it had already made.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Bayer to Cut 1,500 Jobs
abstract: The German chemical company Bayer A.G. will cut 1,500 jobs this year as part  of its cost-cutting program, the company chairman said yesterday. The planned cuts represent about 1 percent of the worldwide work force.   (AP)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Big Dutch Insurer Posts Record Earnings
abstract: Aegon N.V., the largest independent Dutch insurance company, said yesterday that it had record profits in 1995 and reiterated its commitment to grow through cautious acquisitions.          Aegon, based in The Hague, said it profits soared 15 percent last year, to 1.32 billion guilders, or about $800 million, exceeding expectations. It forecast growth of 7 percent to 12 percent this year. Total revenues rose to 20.98 billion guilders, from 20.83 billion guilders in 1994.   Reuters

headline: COMPANY NEWS;UUNET TECHNOLOGIES WITHDRAWS STOCK OFFERING
abstract: Uunet Technologies Inc. said yesterday that it was withdrawing its registration to offer 6.62 million shares of its common stock to the public. The company said it had terminated the offering because of the recent drop in its stock price. Uunet fell 50 cents, to $24.50, near the stock's 52-week low of $21.75. The provider of Internet-access services filed for the offering in February to raise money to acquire undersea and European land-based fiber optic cable capacity. The company said it would continue its plan to acquire fiber optic capacity.

headline: Creditors Give Fokker a Month To Plot Survival
abstract: Seeking time to avert collapse, Fokker N.V., the Dutch aircraft maker, said tonight that its main subsidiaries had been granted one month's protection from  creditors after the cutoff of financial support from Daimler-Benz A. G., its German benefactor.         The decision appeared to be little more than a stopgap measure, with the announcement on Monday by Daimler-Benz, which holds a controlling stake in Fokker, that it was effectively abandoning Fokker after several years of heavy losses.

headline: Western Publishing Gives Snyder an Equity Stake
abstract: After months of start-and-stop negotiations, the Western Publishing Group announced yesterday that it had signed a definitive agreement that gives Richard E. Snyder and Warburg Pincus Ventures a significant equity interest in the company.         Mr. Snyder has been eagerly pursuing Western, best known for its Golden Books for children, since last spring as a way to re-enter the publishing arena. He was dismissed from his post as chairman and chief executive of Simon & Schuster  in 1994.

headline: G.M. Strikers Fear Threat To Way of Life
abstract: The rest of the world knows the nation's largest auto maker as the General Motors Corporation, but residents of this quiet southeastern Ohio city have their own name: Generous Motors.         The nickname reflects a mixture of awe and envy at the wages and benefits that G.M. provides to its workers here. The 3,200 brake factory workers who have been on strike for 15 days are mostly high school graduates who lately have earned an average of $69,000 a year by working six- and seven-day weeks.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;MEDAPHIS BUYS MEDICAL MANAGEMENT SERVICES
abstract: The Medaphis Corporation said yesterday that it had acquired Medical Management Sciences Inc. for about $149 million in stock, or four million shares. Medical Management, based in Baltimore, provides business management services to about 1,700 radiologists and radiation oncologists. Medaphis said that Medical Management had 1995 revenues of about $20.5 million and about $7.7  million in earnings before taxes. Shares of Medaphis, an Atlanta provider of business management services to physicians and hospitals, rose 25 cents, to $37.25 a share in Nasdaq trading.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;The life insurance industry unleashes a tough-talk campaign on the advantages of planning ahead.
abstract: IT'S 1998. You're dead. What do you do now?"         Life insurers across the country, who are about to introduce a tough campaign extolling the benefits of death, are hoping the question will not leave consumers cold.

headline: Proposal for Nasdaq Wins U.S. Support
abstract: The Justice Department has endorsed a plan to revise pricing on the Nasdaq stock market, saying that the changes could undermine Nasdaq broker-dealers' "willingness and ability to collude" on stock prices.         But the department, which is investigating possible price-fixing at Nasdaq, denied today that its comments meant investigators had decided that there was illegal price collusion among "market maker" firms that buy and sell stocks on Nasdaq's computerized markets.

headline: Hanoi Takes Aim at West's 'Social Evils'
abstract: A copy of Paris Match hit the newsstands here recently with the model Naomi Campbell's bare breasts scratched out. Customs officials are confiscating videotapes of prime-time American television shows, and on Wednesday there was a public burning of pornographic videos and magazines.        It's all part of a reinvigorated Vietnamese Government campaign to eradicate  what it calls "social evils" that have proliferated in recent years and are being blamed for everything from increases in crime to the spread of AIDS to the failure of children in school.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;HIGHWOODS PROPERTIES TO ACQUIRE NASHVILLE DEVELOPER
abstract: Highwoods Properties Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Eakin & Smith Inc., an office developer based in Nashville, in a deal valued at $100 million. The transaction gives Highwoods ownership of seven office buildings, with a total of 848,000 square feet, in suburban Nashville; a 103,000-square-foot office building under development; 18 acres of land, and brokerage and property-management operations. The purchase, which is expected to be completed by March 15 and which includes the assumption of $36 million in debt, will give Highwoods about a 6 percent share of Nashville's 17-million-square-foot office market. Highwoods, based in Raleigh, N.C., owns 87 office buildings and 103 industrial properties, mainly in North Carolina.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: A Mitterrand Legacy:Fall-Off in Relations With U.S.
abstract: PARIS—  Perhaps the least publicized legacy of former President François Mitterrand was a poisonous estrangement from Washington in the 1990s that constricted attempts to forge a new trans-Atlantic deal on Western security.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
abstract: Hewlett-Packard Co., Palo Alto, Calif., to Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising, London, a unit of Cordiant P.L.C., as the first agency to handle the personal computer division's pan-European retail dealer support activities. In Spain, Saatchi & Saatchi will work with De Federico, Herrero & Ochoa, Madrid. The billings were estimated at more than $20 million. The appointment comes as Hewlett-Packard is reviewing its estimated $30 million core branding account in  Europe, which is also handled by Saatchi & Saatchi.

headline: Company Briefs
abstract: PLATINUM TECHNLOGY INC., a maker of software products, will acquire Prodea Software Corp., Eden Prarie, Minn., for $36 million in a stock deal.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Greenspan Defends Fed As Its Efficiency Is Assailed Alan Greenspan defended the Federal Reserve against criticism of the management  of its finances by the General Accounting Office of Congress. At a hearing on his nomination to a third term as chairman, he called the Fed "an extraordinarily well-run organization." On a day that the Fed's policy committee decided to leave interest rates unchanged, Mr. Greenspan also gave a relatively  upbeat if brief assessment of the economy, saying it was operating at a "reasonably good clip."

headline: After Four Years, Muslims Return to Sarajevo Suburb
abstract: When the bus from Sarajevo pulled up here today for the first time in four years, the first person to jump out was 18-year-old Edin Spanic, who was chased  out of town in 1992 together with his family and all other local Muslims.         Asked how long the ride had taken, Mr. Spanic replied, "Four years and 20 minutes."

headline: Duke of Atholl, 64, Rich Scot With Castle and Private Army
abstract: George Iain Murray, the 10th Duke of Atholl, who was one of Scotland's richest landowners and the commander of of Britain's only private army, died yesterday at a hospital in Perth, Scotland.         He was 64 and had suffered a stroke in December at Blair Castle, the family seat in the Perthshire highlands since 1269.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;ANOTHER EXECUTIVE LEAVES CS FIRST BOSTON FOR RIVAL
abstract: An executive exodus from CS First Boston continued yesterday as the firm's top bank analyst, Thomas H. Hanley, resigned to join a rival, UBS Securities L.L.C. Mr. Hanley, 51, has been the No. 1 bank analyst for the last 12 years in  surveys by Institutional Investor magazine. He is the second senior official to  join UBS from CS First Boston in two days. John P. Costas, the firm's United States bond chief, left on Monday to become head of UBS's North American fixed-income unit. More than a dozen officials have left CS First Boston this year after bonus payments failed to meet many employees' expectations. Mr. Hanley was named a managing director and senior bank analyst at UBS, a unit of the Union Bank of Switzerland.

headline: The Theft of Identities: A Long and Winding Road
abstract: To the Editor:         In the article on stolen identity, I counted 10 references to the thief's girth. I don't see the fact's relevance to the article, and I wonder how the references escaped your notice.

headline: FROM THE DESK OF: RICHARD J. MAHONEY;Attention, I.R.S.: Send Us a Bill, Itemized
abstract: IT was the time of the month for paperwork. He checked every item on the $650 Visa bill to make sure it was correct. Likewise the phone bill. He even double-checked the deductions on his and his wife's paycheck stubs. Once, he had found an error in the amount withheld for Federal taxes, and it pleased him  that the monthly tedium of checking was worth it. This month, the Federal withholding correctly totaled $833.33.

headline: MIDDLE EAST TALKS ARE EFFORT TO AID PERES AND ARAFAT
abstract: In one sense, the more than two dozen world leaders gathering at this Sinai resort on Wednesday to prop up the tottering Middle East peace effort will have  succeeded just by showing up, according to some of the sponsors.         Convened with emergency haste, and sponsored jointly by the United States and Egypt, "summit of the peacemakers," as it is called, will send a powerful signal of international solidarity to both Prime Minister Simon Peres of Israel and Yasir Arafat, the head of the Palestinian Authority, who have vowed to soldier on in the pursuit of peace despite a bombing campaign by Palestinian militants that has killed at least 62 people in three weeks.

headline: Market Place;Asian Markets Start the Year With a Bang
abstract: Asia's stock markets, those darlings of 1993 and the dogs of 1994 and 1995, have come roaring back to life.         Since Jan. 1, stock markets in Southeast Asia are up, up, up. Hong Kong -- which is considered a level above an emerging stock market -- rose 13.7 percent  in January. Among the emerging markets, Indonesia climbed 13.1 percent and Thailand 11.6 percent.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;CHYRON TO BUY BRITISH VIDEO EQUIPMENT COMPANY
abstract: The Chyron Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire all the outstanding shares of Pro-Bel Ltd. for $21.1 million in cash, notes and stock. Pro-Bel, a privately held company based in Britain, makes video signal switching equipment and control software for broadcast systems. Chyron, which is based in Melville, L.I., makes products that broadcasters use to create special effects and titles  on television screens. Pro-Bel had profits of $2.1 million on revenue of about $27.2 million in 1995.

headline: Market Place;Wall St. Nudges Grace to Speak With Hercules
abstract: When it comes to unsolicited takeover offers, chief executives have learned to expect the unexpected. But an offer for W. R. Grace & Company has set a new standard, and Wall Street loves it.         Late on Monday, Grace, the specialty chemicals and health care conglomerate that has been rocked by problems for more than a year, said it would not consider an unsolicited merger offer from Hercules Inc. -- an offer Thomas L. Gossage, the chairman and chief executive of Hercules, had made while a member of the Grace board. Grace also said that Mr. Gossage had resigned from its board.

headline: Nine Slain in Sri Lanka
abstract: Tamil Tiger rebels carried out several raids against the Sri Lankan military  today, leaving at least nine people dead, including three Government servicemen, officials said.         One airman and six rebels were killed when Tamil guerrillas attacked an air force camp in the eastern Trincomalee district, 142 miles northeast of Colombo,  a military official said. Twelve airmen were wounded in the attack.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;TWO MORE EXECUTIVES DEPART LOTUS DEVELOPMENT
abstract: Two executives announced their departures from the Lotus Development Corporation yesterday, joining the exodus of upper management since I.B.M. bought the company last summer. Jeffrey Beir, 38, senior vice president in charge of applications software for desktop computers, resigned to pursue an "entrepreneurial opportunity," according to a Lotus spokesman. Separately, Russell Campanello, 39, the head of human resources, announced his departure to  pursue other interests. Neither was available for comment. Mr. Beir will be succeeded by John Throckmorton, who is in charge of the development of desktop applications programs. A successor to Mr. Campanello has not been named.

headline: A Great Corporation Is Not a Country Club
abstract: To the Editor:         In the article about the changes in management strategy at Sears, Roebuck & Company ("Yes, He's Revived Sears. But Can He Reinvent It?" Jan. 7), I was especially impressed by the quotation from Anthony J. Rucci, the executive vice  president for human resources and administration. "A compelling place to work does not mean a nice place to work," he said. "We want people to feel some degree of anxiety, the stress of achievement-oriented people."

headline: COMPANY NEWS;CENTURA PLANS TO ACQUIRE BANK IN NORTH CAROLINA
abstract: Centura Banks Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire First Community Bank, based in Gastonia, N.C., for about $28.7 million in stock. First Community has assets of $121 million and five branches. Centura, which is based  in Rocky Mount, N.C., has assets of $5.5 billion and 153 offices. Centura's stock slipped 12.5 cents yesterday, to $34.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: THE NEEDIEST CASES;Some Donors Have a Cause in Mind
abstract: The check and the note will vary each year, but the arrival of the envelope will not. This year, the check was $250 and the note was brief.         "Please use this donation to help those afflicted with AIDS," wrote Leslie J. Lane and Alan H. Vorchheimer of Manhattan. "Our thoughts are with them."

headline: Will Thieves Crack Your Automated Nest Egg?
abstract: PILOTS for Trans World Airlines can view their 401(k) retirement accounts on  their home computers to make sure their last contributions went into the proper  investment and to calculate their portfolio's performance. They cannot, however, use the computer to switch investment choices or to borrow from their accounts.          "There are just a lot of security problems there, and I don't see us doing that," said Joe Montanaro, executive director of the pilots' plan in St. Louis.

headline: Sinan A. Korle, 81, U.N. Protocol Chief
abstract: Sinan A. Korle, who served as United Nations chief of protocol -- smiling, shaking hands and smoothing the ruffled feathers of foreign ministers and heads  of state -- died on Sunday at Beth Israel North Hospital in Manhattan. He was 81 and lived in Istanbul, Turkey.         In the 1960's and 70's, Mr. Korle's duties required him to oversee as many as 350 receptions a year, some for several thousand guests. In 1974, when Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, addressed the General Assembly wearing a gun holster, Mr. Korle escorted him to and from the podium.

headline: Egypt Downplays News Of Sheik's Sentencing
abstract: After years in which Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman was a symbol of this country's turbulence, the apparent end of the militant cleric's career has been met here with a satisfaction that is reflected in official silence.         In not gloating at the life sentence given to the sheik in a New York courtroom on Wednesday for his role in an assassination and bombing plot, the Government may have been reluctant to inflame those who may sympathize with Mr.  Abdel Rahman's view that the trial against him was part of a Western war against Islam.

headline: THE NEW YORK TIMES BUSINESS BEST SELLERS
abstract: HARD COVER

headline: OUTLOOK '96: TECHNOLOGY AND MEDIA;Rough-and-Ready Time in the Internet Business
abstract: IF brilliant realizations really did appear as light bulbs flashing above people's heads, 1995 would have been an especially bright year for the information and telecommunications industry. Company after company came to understand that their futures were at least partly linked to the Internet.         Microsoft announced that it was redefining itself an Internet company. AT&T declared that it, too, wanted to be an Internet company. I.B.M. announced an ambitious Internet strategy. America Online set a new course for the Internet.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Ocean Spray Picks Campbell Mithun
abstract: Ocean Spray Cranberries Inc. yesterday added Campbell Mithun Esty in Minneapolis to its agency roster by naming that shop to handle advertising for all new beverage and food products. The billings were not disclosed; total billings for the juice drinks and other products that Ocean Spray now markets, which are handled by North Castle Partners in Stamford, Conn., were estimated at $30 million to $40 million.          John Moreton, new products manager at Ocean Spray in Lakeville, Mass., said  that Campbell Mithun had been selected without a review because of that agency's "expertise in new-product marketing and the depth of their experience in grocery products." Among the packaged foods that are handled by Campbell Mithun, which is owned by its managers and the Interpublic Group of Companies, are Nature Valley granola bars, Jeno's frozen pizza, Bugles snacks, Dolly Madison snack cakes and Land O'Lakes margarine.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                                               Previous      Year                               Yesterday       Day       Ago

headline: COMPANY NEWS;MOBILE TELECOMMUNICATION SHARES SLIDE BY 20%
abstract: The shares of the Mobile Telecommunication Technologies Corporation fell 20 percent after the paging company posted a wider-than-expected fourth-quarter loss late on Thursday and said its chief financial officer had resigned. Mtel also said it was in default of certain loan covenants and was seeking waivers from its banks. It plans to cut $20 million in expenses this year, including jobs. Those cuts amount to about 7 percent of Mtel's 1995 expenses. The results and Robert Fugate's resignation as chief financial officer surprised Wall Street analysts. They said it appeared that Mtel had not effectively managed the introduction of the nation's first two-way paging service. Mtel's shares were down $3.75, at $14.125, in Nasdaq trading of almost 9.1 million shares.

headline: BUSINESS WORLD;Outlook '96
abstract: From Wall Street to Hollywood, from silicon to steel, businesses will soon see the effects of changes passed by the Republican-controlled Congress. Decades of rules and restrictions have been swept away, and more deregulation is planned. But a number of hurdles could keep the Republican vision from becoming  a reality.         In addition to the prospect of a lighter regulatory burden, American businesses have benefited from powerful rallies in the stock and bond markets. But few analysts expect a repeat performance of 1995's spectacular run.

headline: Luxury Companies Focus on Service
abstract: PARIS—  Economic stagnation and more demanding, ever-thriftier clients are forcing luxury retailers to find ways to improve their image and create customer loyalty. Almost unanimously, they are focusing on service.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Hal Riney Gets Peet's Account
abstract: Hal Riney & Partners in San Francisco has switched coffees.         The agency said yesterday that it would begin working with Peet's Coffee and  Tea, a retail and mail-order company based in Emeryville, Calif. The account, with billings estimated at $1 million to $2 million, was awarded to Riney without a review after having been divided for the last seven years between Bridge Marcom and Westdal Design Associates, both of Berkeley, Calif.

headline: Los Angeles Magazine Gets a Serious Look
abstract: Michael J. Caruso's former boss at Vanity Fair, Tina Brown, subscribes to the cocktail party theory of magazine excellence, which holds that a disparate mix of articles will be as enticing to readers as an intriguing get-together. Now Mr. Caruso is putting her theory into practice as the new editor of Los Angeles  magazine, once a consistently profitable crown jewel in the $1 billion publishing division of Capital Cities/ ABC Inc.         But Mr. Caruso, who took over in November, may be in for more of a brawl than a convivial party. After years of stability and profits, the 34-year-old magazine is in turmoil. Recession has cut into circulation and revenue; its founder and former editor, Geoff Miller, left a year ago, and Buzz magazine, a five-year-old upstart with a circulation of 85,500 whose Internet home page lists concert dates for the Voodoo Glow Skulls, is gaining strength.

headline: Mexican Stocks Climb to Highs
abstract: Mexican stocks ended trading today at record highs, buoyed by news that Mexico had raised fresh funds on international markets and that it had received  a new loan from the Inter-American Development Bank.         The main Mexico City index gained 8.91 points, or almost three-tenths of 1 percent, to 3,087.99 -- eclipsing the previous record of 3,087.48 on Jan. 22.

headline: Levi Strauss Stock Buyout Would Benefit Small Group
abstract: A newly released company document shows that the proposed multibillion-dollar buyout of some shareholders by Levi Strauss Associates Inc. would provide unusual benefits for the company's chairman, Robert D. Haas, and a small number  of other people close to him.         Levi Strauss, the largest apparel manufacturer in the world and a leader in corporate responsibility, said two weeks ago that it wanted to buy out some shareholders, including participants in an employee stock plan, to insure that control of the privately held company would remain in the hands of the Haas family. But the new document, filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission  last week, showed that while most operations of the famous blue-jeans maker would remain unchanged, its power structure would be altered considerably.

headline: Interests Collide in Communications Ventures
abstract: Just as the digital age has made for strange bedfellows, it has also created  a new category of dysfunctional relationships: companies that form alliances, only to find later that their interests have diverged.         The latest case in point is the PCS Prime Company L.P., a venture owned by four telephone companies that plans to offer a new type of cellular service called personal communications services, or P.C.S. The venture was created in late 1994 by the Bell Atlantic Corporation, the Nynex Corporation, U S West Inc., and Airtouch Communications, with the goal of constructing a nationwide network for the new services.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;BOARD APPROVES BUYBACK OF UP TO $600 MILLION IN STOCK
abstract: The board of Travelers Group Inc., the insurance and financial-services company, has approved the repurchase of as much as $600 million of the company's common shares for distribution in employee stock option and benefit plans. The stock closed yesterday at $65.25, down 25 cents a share, on the New York Stock Exchange. At that price, the acquisition would represent 2.9 percent of the stock outstanding.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;CONE MILLS EXPECTS LOSS IN FOURTH QUARTER
abstract: The Cone Mills Corporation, a textile maker, said yesterday that it expected  a fourth-quarter loss of about 50 cents a share, mostly from accounting measures related to a drop in the value of certain stock holdings. Cone Mills, based in Greensboro, N.C., earned $7.3 million, or 24 cents a share, on sales of $205.1 million for the fourth quarter that ended on Jan. 1, 1995. Cone Mills said the charges were primarily related to write-downs of its equity interest and disposal of a portion of its ownership in Compania Industrial de Parras S.A., of Mexico. Cone Mills said that excluding the charges, it expected a loss of a few  cents a share because of continued weaknesses in specialty sportswear and decorative-print fabric markets. The company also plans to take write-downs associated with the relocation of its headquarters and other efforts to modernize the company.

headline: Business Travel;A historic reminder of how far commercial aviation has come.
abstract: FIFTY years ago this week T.W.A.'s Star of Paris lifted off from Washington,  stopped atLa Guardia Airport in New York and set off for Paris with 36 passengers including businessmen, diplomats, two fashion designers and a doctor  delivering penicillin. Cruising at a blistering 300 miles an hour, and after refueling stops in Gander, Newfoundland, and Shannon, Ireland, the graceful four-engine Lockheed Constellation touched down at Orly Airport in Paris almost 20 hours after leaving New York.         That historic flight, which inaugurated Trans World Airlines' European service, gives the airline the distinction of having flown to Europe longer than any other United States carrier flying today and brought much of Western Europe  within a day of America. The biggest obstacle was the round-trip coach fare of $675 -- a fare that T.W.A. said equaled $5,273.34 in 1996 dollars; the fare represented 27 percent of the average American's annual income of $2,500 in 1946.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;AVIA ATHLETIC-SHOE UNIT TO BE SOLD BY REEBOK
abstract: Reebok International Ltd. said yesterday that it planned to sell its Avia subsidiary, which makes athletic shoes. The company also predicted that its profit for 1995 would be lower than expected, because of markdowns at the end of the year. Reebok, the second-largest American maker of athletic footwear, behind Nike Inc., said it would take a charge of $34 million, or 44 cents a share, in the fourth quarter to write down the value of Avia. Many analysts have called on Reebok to shed the unit, which the company bought for $181 million in 1987 and which accounts for about 4 percent of Reebok's sales.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Guinness Awards Red Stripe Account
abstract: The Guinness Import Company said yesterday that it had named Gotham Inc. in New York to handle advertising for Red Stripe lager beer. Billings were estimated at $2 million.         Guinness Import is the American sales and marketing arm of the Guinness Brewing Worldwide unit of Guinness P.L.C. That company acquired the distribution rights for Red Stripe in December from Labatts USA in Darien, Conn. Under Labatts USA, the Red Stripe account had been handled by North Castle Partners in Stamford, Conn.

headline: Snow Slows, Doesn't Stop, Stock Markets
abstract: The East Coast blizzard of '96, one of the biggest storms of the century, caused major disruptions at financial markets yesterday, but some exchanges managed to open for limited trading. Trading today is expected to be practically normal.         Stocks were traded only between 11 A.M. and 2 P.M. on the New York Stock Exchange, the American Stock Exchange and the Nasdaq stock market. "We didn't make any money today," said Edward L. Goldberg, an executive vice president of Merrill Lynch. "But over all we functioned fine."

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;German Money Move
abstract: The Bundesbank set the stage yesterday for declines in German money market rates by lending banks extra funds in an unexpected move. The central bank lent  3 billion marks ($2.1 billion) under five-day securities repurchase agreements at a rate of 3.75 percent to prevent a shortage in the money market from pushing rates up. Economists said the cash infusion, only the second unscheduled round of credits in the last year, would keep a downward bias on money rates when the  Bundesbank allots its regular credits to banks next Wednesday.    (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: COMPANY NEWS;FUQUA ENTERPRISES TO BUY LUMEX MEDICAL UNIT
abstract: Fuqua Enterprises Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the Lumex medical products division of Lumex Inc. for $40.75 million in cash. Fuqua, based in Atlanta, said that the deal was part of its effort to become a major provider of medical products, a business it entered in November with the purchase of Basic American  Medical Products. Separately, Lumex said the sale was part of its strategy announced in December to focus on its Cybex worldwide institutional fitness and rehabilitation business. Lumex, based in Bay Shore, L.I., markets a wide range of health care products. In trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, shares of Fuqua rose 25 cents, to $23.875. On the American Stock Exchange, Lumex rose 62.5 cents, to $13.125.

headline: What Is an Apple Worth?;Ailing Innovator's Luster as an Acquisition Dims
abstract: The board of Apple Computer Inc. met for a second consecutive day yesterday to try to devise a rescue plan for the fabled Silicon Valley company, which is leaking money, market share, talent and industry support at an alarming rate.         Despite persistent reports of an impending deal in which Sun Microsystems Inc. would acquire Apple, some executives familiar with recent talks between the two companies said that the two sides remained far apart on the question of  price; at least one person said the talks broke off yesterday. With neither company willing to comment, the situation remained unclear.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Airbus Industrie Plans Jumbo Jet
abstract: Airbus Industrie plans to develop a jumbo passenger aircraft to take on its main rival, the Boeing Company, and its popular 747 jetliner, a top partner in the European consortium said today.         Manfred Bischoff, chairman of Daimler-Benz Aerospace A.G., or DASA, said he was working with his Airbus Industrie partners to complete development and production plans for the aircraft.

headline: Niall MacDermot, 79; Led World Jurist Unit
abstract: Niall MacDermot, who was Secretary General of the International Committee of  Jurists for 20 years and a former British Labor Government minister, has died at the age of 79, the committee announced today.         The committee, which links senior jurists around the globe in campaigning for the rule of law and defense of human rights, said that Mr. MacDermot died last Thursday in Geneva, where he had settled after retiring in 1990.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;CAMPBELL SOUP CO. (CPB,N)
abstract: The Campbell Soup Company said yesterday that increased sales of soups and Mexican-style sauces lifted earnings by 11.7 percent in the second quarter, which ended on Jan. 28.         The company earned $258 million, or $1.03 a share, up from $231 million, or 93 cents, in the quarter a year earlier. Revenue rose 9 percent, to $2.22 billion from $2.03 billion.

headline: 6 Dead in New Delhi In Bombing Claimed By Kashmiri Rebels
abstract: At least 6 people were killed and 31 injured when a bomb exploded today in a  crowded bazaar in New Delhi.         The Jammu-Kashmir Islamic Front took responsibility for the attack, at Sadar  Bazaar, an aging commercial district of decrepit 100-year-old buildings near New Delhi's main railroad station.

headline: G.M. Files a Lawsuit Against VW and Some Executives
abstract: Still angry about the defection of eight managers to Volkswagen A. G. three years ago, the General Motors Corporation announced today that it had filed a civil complaint against Volkswagen, four Volkswagen executives and the former G.M. executives for the theft of company secrets.         The lawsuit, filed in Federal District Court here late Thursday, accused Jose Ignacio Lopez de Arriortua and seven other former G.M. purchasing managers of stealing more than 20 cartons of confidential G.M. documents when they went to Volkswagen. The lawsuit accused Volkswagen and four of its executives of conspiring in the purported theft, using the documents to gain a commercial advantage and then shredding them.

headline: 8 Die in Plane Crash In Baja California
abstract: A small plane carrying Mexican state government officials slammed into the side of a canyon on Tuesday and exploded, killing all eight people aboard, the police said today.         A witness, Carlos Guerrero, told a local television station, XEWT, that he heard the Cessna 500 Citation sputtering in an attempted to gain altitude just after 1 P.M. on Tuesday. But the pilot could not pull up in time, and the plane  smashed into the mountain, exploding three times, Mr. Guerrero said.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Citizens Financial Picks Ingalls
abstract: The Citizens Financial Group, which is owned by the Royal Bank of Scotland, said yesterday that it had named Ingalls Advertising in Boston to handle marketing communications for its Citizens Bank unit, which has branches in Connecticut, Massachusetts, New Hampshire and Rhode Island. The account, with billings estimated at $6 million to $8 million, had been handled for the last eight years by Duffy & Shanley Inc. in Providence, R.I., which resigned last month.          James Dorsey, a spokesman for Citizens in Providence, said that Ingalls, a division of Ingalls, Quinn & Johnson, had been awarded the account after a three-week review that also included Holland Mark Martin in Burlington, Mass.; O'Neil Griffin Bodi Ekman in Manchester, N.H., which handles advertising for a sibling Citizens unit, First NH Bank in New Hampshire, and Pagano, Schenck & Kay in Boston. Citizens is talking to Duffy & Shanley about working for Citizens in  Rhode Island, Mr. Dorsey said, handling duties like public relations.

headline: Ousted Aide Gives Yeltsin His Support
abstract: Two months after he was abruptly forced out of office by President Boris N. Yeltsin, one of Russia's leading economic reformers has thrown his support behind the Russian leader.         The economist, Anatoly B. Chubais, a free-market advocate and former Deputy Prime Minister, said today that he had decided to support Mr. Yeltsin because he has the best chance to stop Gennady Zyuganov, the Communist candidate, from coming to power.

headline: Changing the Face of Publishing
abstract: The influence of the graphic designers Milton Glaser and Walter Bernard permeates the magazine world. Working separately at first and then in a formidable partnership, they have shaped and reshaped leading magazines and newspapers in the United States, Europe and Asia for more than 30 years.         Even more important than their mark on so many well-known magazines, however, is their influence on the scores of talented young assistants who have worked at their atelier, an ornate former Tammany Hall courthouse on East 32d Street. These former "paste-up kids" have gone on to head the art departments of Vogue,  Esquire, House & Garden, Time, Life, Money, Fortune, Atlantic Monthly and Philadelphia, among other magazines.

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;3d Blast Fails to Remove Boulder in Japan Tunnel
abstract: A third dynamite blast failed today to remove a huge boulder that trapped 19  people in a highway tunnel in northern Japan. Crews were planning another blasting attempt, but little hope was held out of finding anyone alive.         Anyone who survived the huge cave-in would now have spent three days and nights in freezing temperatures in their smashed bus inside the snowy mountain.  Rescuers can see the vehicle, but they cannot reach it.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;FIRSTAR PLANS TO DISMISS 1,400 EMPLOYEES
abstract: The Firstar Corporation said yesterday that it would dismiss 1,400 workers in the next 17 months to cut its annual operating costs by $110 million. Firstar, a bank company based in Milwaukee, plans to eliminate another 1,100 jobs through attrition, for a total reduction of 2,500. The company plans to have 7,300 workers after the cuts. Firstar plans to take a charge of $31 million, or 42 cents a share, against its earnings in the first quarter for the dismissals and for other costs. Firstar, which has $19.2 billion in assets, has more than 240 branches, in six states. The company made its announcement after the close of trading. Firstar stock had risen $1, to $40.

headline: Israeli Crackdown Renews Anxieties of Palestinians
abstract: A dank chill pervaded the Abu Ein cooking-pot factory today, the slow drip of water the only sound in the building that the Palestinian owner had dreamed would be clanging with new workers churning out housewares in time to sell for Passover.         The owner, Mahmoud Abu Ein, has yet to swing open the plant's heavy rust-colored gates this week because of the severe restrictions imposed by Israel in response to a string of terrorist attacks that began on Feb. 25. Now,  since the most recent bombings, internal movement is controlled and Palestinian  villages are sealed off from each other and essentially paralyzed.

headline: Enron Says India State Offers To Revive Big Power Project
abstract: The Dabhol Power Company has received a formal offer from the government of Maharashtra state in India to revive a canceled power project worth $2.8 billion, the Enron Corporation said here today.         Enron said Dabhol would reply to the letter shortly and hoped to resume construction on the project within 90 days. It also said that while it welcomed  the new offer, it planned to continue arbitration while it studied the Indian state's new terms.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;LEADER NAMED FOR ABC'S 24-HOUR NEWS CHANNEL
abstract: Jeff Gralnick, the executive producer of NBC's "Nightly News," is returning to ABC to head the network's planned 24-hour news channel. The channel, which is expected to be started later this year, is designed for cable and other distribution systems. Mr. Gralnick, 58, will be responsible for its news content and production. He left ABC in 1993, after serving as vice president and executive producer for special broadcasts. At NBC, he was credited with leading the "Nightly News" past the "CBS Evening News" into second place in the  ratings. NBC said that David Doss, senior producer at the "Nightly News," would  head the newscast until a new executive producer was announced.

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Clinton Asks Congress To Send Jordan F-16's
abstract: Citing the need to support Jordan's efforts for peace in the Middle East, President Clinton requested Congressional approval today for funds to send Jordan 16 F-16 fighter jets.         "The transfer of the F-16 aircraft to Jordan will contribute to Jordanian security, as well as to the security in the entire region, and further the commitment made by the United States to support Jordan's efforts to further the  Middle East peace process," Mr. Clinton said in a letter to the House Speaker, Newt Gingrich.

headline: Tanzania Closes Border With Burundi
abstract: The Tanzanian Army has shut the border with Burundi, turning back 17,000 Rwandan Hutu refugees fleeing Burundi's ethnic violence, a senior aid official said today.         Seamus Dunne, a relief official at the Ngara camp in Tanzania, said the border had been shut overnight after more than 14,000 Rwandan Hutu crossed into  Tanzania last week.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Florida Citrus Group Selects Ammirati
abstract: The Florida Department of Citrus in Lakeland, Fla., said yesterday that it had selected Ammirati & Puris/Lintas in New York to handle its orange juice and  grapefruit juice advertising accounts, with billings estimated at $27 million.
