The Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide unit of Cordiant P.L.C. in New York  had handled the accounts for the last 25 years until that agency was elim inated from the review last month.          The decision came after a four-month mandated review that had been narrowed  to Ammirati & Puris/Lintas, which is owned by the Interpublic Group of Companies, and three other finalists: Grey Advertising in New York; the Richards Group in Dallas, and the West Group in Tampa, Fla.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Daimler-Benz in Talks With Microsoft
abstract: Daimler-Benz A. G., Germany's largest conglomerate, and the Microsoft Corporation agreed yesterday to explore areas where they could cooperate on developing a sweeping range of technology markets.         Klaus Mangold, chairman of Daimler-Benz Interservice, said that the companies saw "tremendous potential" to develop technology for vehicles and production and that they would also work on developing on-line services.   (Reuters)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Australian Utility Sold
abstract: The Australian state of Victoria said today that it had sold Yallourn Energy  to a consortium led by Powergen P.L.C. of Britain for $2.43 billion (Australian), or $1.85 billion (United States). It is the first of five planned  sales of power companies by the state, which is the second-most populous in Australia. Yallourn Energy consists of the 1,450-megawatt Yallourn brown-coal power station and related coal mining operations. The Powergen bidding group includes some Australian investors.   (AP)

headline: Stocks Advance, Spurred by a Rally in Bonds
abstract: Stocks seesawed yesterday, but firmed in late trading following a sharp rally in the bond market.         Many reports of strong fourth-quarter earnings helped buoy the stock market.  Even a sluggish report on housing activity in November -- the first major Federal economic report since the three-week partial Government shutdown ended -- could not keep the market from closing the day near its highs.

headline: Henry S. Villard, 95, Diplomat Who Wrote Books in Retirement
abstract: Henry Serrano Villard, a former ambassador who retired in 1961 and turned to  writing books, died on Sunday in Los Angeles. He was 95 and lived in Los Angeles, Europe and the Bahamas.         The cause was pneumonia, his family said.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;ENRON UNIT BUYS A STAKE IN HANOVER COMPRESSOR
abstract: A unit of the Enron Corporation said yesterday that it had acquired a 10.5 percent stake in the Hanover Compressor Company, which leases gas equipment, and added that it would provide Hanover with a $100 million line of credit to help it expand. Enron Capital and Trade Resources paid $30 million for its stake in Hanover, a privately held company based in Houston. An investment partnership that includes the Pritzker family of Chicago and Daniel W. Lufkin, a founder of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, owns 44.8 percent of Hanover.

headline: Walesa Attacks the Victorious Ex-Communists
abstract: Partly snarling, partly sulking, Lech Walesa disappeared from Warsaw the day  before his successor's swearing-in and went home to Gdansk.         With a petulance many found unfitting for a Nobel Peace Prize winner, he refused to attend the Dec. 22 inauguration of Aleksander Kwasniewski, the former Communist who defeated him in Poland's presidential ballot in November.

headline: U.N. May Get Reinforcements From NATO
abstract: The United Nations peacekeeping force that is expected to disarm the last region of Croatia still held by Croatian Serbs will be strengthened by military  support from NATO, diplomats said today. The decision to add to NATO's tasks in  the Balkans beyond Bosnia will be spelled out in a Security Council resolution before Jan. 15.         The relationship between NATO and the United Nations forces will be similar to the one that characterized peacekeeping duties in Bosnia before December, an  arrangement that was criticized regularly in Washington by both Congress and the Clinton Administration, which had sought to keep NATO out of Croatia.

headline: Kaiser Makes Surprise Bid For Alumax
abstract: The Kaiser Aluminum Corporation made a surprise hostile offer yesterday for rival Alumax Inc., setting the stage for what could be a nasty takeover battle.          Kaiser, which is heavily indebted, said that it valued Alumax at $40 to $45 a share, or as much as $2.5 billion, and that it would pay $30 a share in cash and the balance in Kaiser shares. The bid is a substantial premium over Alumax's closing price of $32.50 a share yesterday, and above the stock's all-time high of $38.

headline: Chevron-Texaco Deal
abstract: The Chevron Corporation and Texaco Inc. said this week that their jointly held affiliate, Amoseas Indonesia, would build a 70-megawatt power plant in the  Darajat area of western Java at a cost of $125 million. Darajat currently taps its energy from a volcano on the so-called Ring of Fire, the world's most active volcanic zone, which rings the Pacific basin.

headline: Fearing Terrorism, U.S. Plans to Press Sudan
abstract: Convinced that the Sudan is moving rapidly to the top of a list of rogue nations harboring international terrorists, the Administration plans to increase pressure on the Sudan through the United Nations, while effectively closing the  American Embassy in Khartoum, officials said today.         While Washington is not breaking formal diplomatic relations with the Sudan,  all American diplomats and other embassy personnel will be withdrawn in the next few days. An office to handle American interests will be set up in a nearby capital.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Venezuela Again Opens to Foreign Oil Concerns
abstract: Venezuela, a petroleum-rich country that is currently starved for cash, is moving to vastly increase its crude oil production.         This is good news for private foreign oil companies, which, 20 years after all foreign oil operations were nationalized, are rushing back to the South American country at Government invitation to help prospect for crude. And Clinton Administration officials are praising Venezuela's plans because the production surge will insure that Venezuela, the No. 1 petroleum supplier for the United States, will have plenty of capacity to satisfy America's growing energy appetite.

headline: FUTURES MARKETS;Cold Spell in Mexico Threatens Coffee and Sends Prices Higher
abstract: Coffee prices surged on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York yesterday on concerns that cold weather in Mexico could cause frost damage to the country's crop.         On other markets, corn and soybean prices fell, while gasoline prices rose. The Commodity Research Bureau index of 17 commodities gained 0.46 point, to 245.49.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Satellite Order By News Corp. For Direct TV
abstract: The MCI Communications Corporation and the News Corporation said today that in a move to begin direct television broadcasting, they had ordered two high-powered satellites from the Loral Corporation at a cost of more than $400 million.         Loral said it would launch the first satellite late next year and the second  in 1998. MCI said it expected to offer satellite television in the United States by the end of 1997.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;2 Pepsico Divisions Drop Out As Sponsors of Carvey Show
abstract: Reports of the demise of the ABC sketch comedy series starring Dana Carvey, which drew complaints over the contents of skits performed in the first episode  on Tuesday, might have been premature. Though two of the three principal advertisers have withdrawn from the series, the third said yesterday that it would continue to participate.         The reason those advertising decisions are of more than passing interest is the gimmick that ABC used to help draw attention to the series and its star, a former featured performer on NBC's "Saturday Night Live." Advertisers were signed as sponsors whose names would appear in the title of each episode -- echoing a practice of the 1950's -- and whose products would be spoofed during that episode.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
abstract: * Hyett, Broadbent & Heimbrodt Advertising, San Francisco, was awarded two accounts with combined billings estimated at $4.5 million: Monterey Pasta Co., Danville, Calif., previously handled in-house, and Heald Colleges, San Francisco, previously at Ron Wren Advertising, San Francisco.

headline: Health Care Acquisition
abstract: The Standish Care Company said today that it had agreed to be acquired by Integrated Health Services Inc. of Owings Mills, Md., for $5 a share, or about $23 million. Standish develops assisted-living communities, while Integrated is  a diversified health care company. Standish said that its headquarters would probably remain in Burlington and that it expected that its executives would stay with the company. Shares of Standish were up 37.5 cents, or 10 percent, at  $4.125 each, in Nasdaq trading.

headline: TECHNOLOGY: DIGITAL COMMERCE;Wanted: Web site reviewers. Little or no experience necessary. Pay to match.
abstract: VENTURE capitalists these days are bragging about all the new jobs and wealth they're creating with the success of Internet-based companies like Netscape Communications and Cybercash.         But one suspects that the moneymeisters aren't including in their head count  all the laborers in a new cottage industry that has sprung up in response to the astronomical number of new sites on the Internet's World Wide Web.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Economic Growth Slowed To Just 0.9% in 4th Quarter The economy grew at a meager nine-tenths of 1 percent annual pace in the final three months of 1995, as consumers kept a tight grip on their wallets, Government spending fell and investment by business slackened, the Commerce Department said. For all of 1995, growth was 2.1 percent, the least since 1991.

headline: Drug Makers Raised Prices For Retailers 4.6% in 1995
abstract: Manufacturers' prices of the 500 most widely used prescription drugs rose 4.6 percent last year, the National Association of Chain Drug Stores, a trade group, said yesterday.         The association said the increase compared with 4.1 percent in 1994 and 4 percent in 1993. The chain druggists said pharmacies paid $41.6 billion for the  500 drugs last year, which was 85 percent of the cost of all prescription drugs purchased by the stores.

headline: Junk Rating For Kmart Debt
abstract: The ratings on $6.8 billion of the debt of the Kmart Corporation were cut to  junk status yesterday by Moody's Investors Service because of the company's weakened financial flexibility and the difficult business conditions confronting almost all retailers.         "Kmart is facing a challenging retail environment in which excess retail capacity, a wide range of competitors and value-oriented consumers are causing an imbalance of supply and demand," Moody's said.

headline: Random House Sued by Booksellers Group
abstract: The American Booksellers Association filed an antitrust suit last week against Random House Inc., accusing the world's largest book publisher of illegally providing discounts to major national chains.         The suit, filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan, sought a court injunction that would force Random House to give independent bookstores the same discounts it provides to the larger book retailers.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;Revlon Pushes an Offering At as Much as $22 a Share
abstract: Revlon Inc., the cosmetic company owned by the MacAndrews & Forbes Group, moved rapidly yesterday to offer its stock to the public by the end of the month.         Revlon filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell 7.5 million  shares at a price of $19 to $22 each, valuing the initial sale of 15 percent of its stock at $142.5 million to $165 million.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;AMR Posts 78.4% Increase From Operations in Quarter
abstract: The parent of American Airlines, the AMR Corporation, posted a 78.4 percent rise in its operating profit for the fourth quarter today, but after taking $372 million of charges, it had a net loss of $281 million.         The strong operating results from AMR, the first of the major airlines to report earnings, were driven by an increase in passenger traffic and higher ticket prices. AMR shares closed up 25 cents, at $71.75, on the New York Stock Exchange, and other airline stocks also rose.

headline: World News Briefs;Illegally Stored Dynamite Kills at Least 95 in China
abstract: Ten tons of illegally stored dynamite exploded in a village in central China, creating an inferno that killed at least 95 people, leveled 40 buildings and shattered windows for a mile around.         The blast, which occurred on Wednesday morning, injured more than 400 people  and left a 2 1/2-acre crater full of rubble in the center of Jiqi, a village in  the central province of Hunan, about 940 miles southwest of Beijing.

headline: In Missouri, Good Times or Bad?;Working but Not Spending in a Microcosm of the Nation
abstract: Churning out goods from pickup trucks to refrigerator magnets, factories across this Midwestern heartland are hiring so many workers that labor shortages are developing in some areas.         But the consumers who are supposed to be buying these products are holding back, anxious about their jobs and fearful of piling up more debt.

headline: Rig Count Down by 13
abstract: The number of oil and gas rigs operating in the United States dropped by 13 last week to 703, Baker Hughes Inc. said. During the corresponding week a year ago, there were 731 rigs operating nationwide. Of the rigs running last week, 404 were exploring for natural gas and 291 for oil.

headline: INVESTING IT;Lots of Data, Many Gaps In On-Line Research
abstract: I SAT, fingers poised, at my desk at home in New Jersey. The challenge was clear: Could I be an investor using only my computer keyboard?         Specifically, I wanted to see how much investment research I could do, and how cheaply, using the popular on-line services America Online, Prodigy and Compuserve.

headline: A $50 Million Payment Fuels Mexican Scandal
abstract: At best, the $50 million that one of Mexico's richest businessmen says he invested blindly with an old friend, the former President's brother, was a highly irregular business transaction.         Carlos Peralta Quintero, a billionaire who heads Grupo Iusa, one of Mexico's  largest companies and the Mexican partner of Bell Atlantic, says that in April 1994 he gave the $50 million to Raul Salinas de Gortari, no receipts given and no questions asked.

headline: INVESTING IT;Fidelity Tries Pitch To Masses
abstract: FIDELITY INVESTMENTS, already dominant in the $3 trillion mutual fund industry, is heading straight for Middle America.         This week, it will begin running a $25 million television advertisement campaign, according to a person familiar with the effort. Network television is  a departure for Fidelity, which mostly runs print ads highlighting the performance of specific funds.

headline: ROOTS OF TERROR: A special report.;Alms and Arms: Tactics in a Holy War
abstract: Hamas, the main force behind the suicide bombers who have thrown the shaky Middle East peace talks into crisis, is an organization with deep roots, a popular base that feeds on misery and resentment, an international support network, and a clear goal: to turn the nascent Palestine into an Islamic state.

headline: Cuba Blames U.S. in Downing of Planes
abstract: By turns scornful, angry and defiant, the Cuban Government blamed the United  States today for fomenting the incident in which two light planes were shot down over the Straits of Florida on Saturday and accused the Clinton Administration of lying about the attack for political ends.         At a news conference marked by belligerence and personal insults directed at  Secretary of State Warren Christopher, Ricardo Alarcon, the head of the Cuban Parliament and the country's third-highest official, said Cuba was justified in  attacking the planes to protect its sovereignty. It is not the Government of Fidel Castro that is guilty of terrorist acts, he maintained, but the United States, which has allowed Cuban exile groups to run rampant.

headline: As Sarajevo Declares Siege Over, Serbs Still Pack
abstract: In the early hours of this day when Muslim-Croat Federation police entered this town and the Bosnian Government formally declared the siege of Sarajevo over, Joka Gajic prepared for one last visit to her heart doctor.         The trip to the center of Ilijas was important to her because she knew that as soon as the federation police arrived, the doctor would be gone. Then she herself would finish packing and travel to friends in territory still held by the Bosnian Serbs.

headline: Stocks Slip in Japan
abstract: Japanese stocks were trading slightly lower here today. At the midday break,  the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 60.40 points -- a little less  than three-tenths of 1 percent -- to stand at 20,608.63. On Friday, the Nikkei index rose 51.03 points.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;BUFFETT GETS PERMISSION TO INCREASE HOLDINGS
abstract: The billionaire investor Warren E. Buffett has received permission to increase his holdings in the American Express Company to 17 percent, according to the company's proxy statement. Berkshire Hathaway Inc., Mr. Buffett's company, now owns a 10.2 percent stake, already the largest holding in American  Express, the financial-services giant.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Disney, Thorn EMI Select Firms
abstract: Two entertainment marketers have made decisions on their accounts.         The Walt Disney Company has named Leo Burnett U.S.A. in Chicago to handle the creative part of the account of its Disneyland theme park, which had been handled in-house. The billings were estimated at $13 million.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;MARUBENI TO ACQUIRE 29% STAKE IN SITHE ENERGIES
abstract: Sithe Energies Inc., an independent power producer, said yesterday that the Marubeni Corporation, a Japanese trading company, would acquire a 29 percent stake in Sithe by purchasing its outstanding shares for $15 each. Marubeni will  pay about $250 million for its stake. It will also contribute $42 million to the company this year and $24 million on April 1, 1997. That $66 million will finance Sithe's investments in projects in the United States and elsewhere, Sithe's vice chairman, Barry F. Sullivan, said. Shares of Sithe more than doubled yesterday, to $14.50 from $5.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: MUTUAL FUNDS QUARTERLY REPORT;Advisers Stay With the Program
abstract: ON the surface at least, the five investment advisers who created model retirement portfolios for The New York Times have little to complain about. After all, they have racked up sizable gains since starting this contest in the  summer of 1993.         But all of them have also lagged behind the general market, which in recent years has been driven largely by the biggest growth stocks. Those shares plunged shortly before the contest began, when Philip Morris slashed the price of its cigarettes on "Marlboro Monday." They bounced back soon after, though, and have  been the undisputed market leaders ever since.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;OPPENHEIMER OPENING A BROKERAGE BUSINESS IN ISRAEL
abstract: Oppenheimer & Company, the New York brokerage and investment banking firm, said yesterday that it would establish a brokerage business in Israel by recruiting Eddy Shalev and his staff from the Tel Aviv office of Oscar Gruss & Son. Mr. Shalev, 48, and his staff of 18 have built a significant brokerage business executing trades for Israeli institutions in the shares of American companies. Oppenheimer has longstanding ties to Israel and is a leading underwriter in the United States for securities offerings by Israeli companies.  Nathan Gantcher, Oppenheimer's president, said that by acquiring a securities brokerage business in Israel, the firm expected to broaden its business both in  brokerage and investment banking. Robert J. Mittleman, chief executive of Oscar  Gruss, said his firm was negotiating with several people to establish a replacement arrangement in Israel.

headline: U.S. to Apply New Vigor in Policing Trade
abstract: The Clinton Administration plans to announce a broad initiative to enforce dozens of trade accords with China, Japan, Canada and other big trading partners, in a move that appears directed at protecting President Clinton from Republican accusations that his free trade agreements are costing jobs in the United States.         Administration officials said today that as part of the initiative, the United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, would create an enforcement office, charged with forcing several nations to live up to their agreements.

headline: Leader of Peru Won't Intervene for American
abstract: The President of Peru said today that he would not intervene in the case of a New York woman who has been convicted of treason for associating with a terrorist group and sentenced to life in prison.         "I do not have the right to say the sentence was just or unjust," the President, Alberto K. Fujimori, said in an interview here at a convention of hundreds of political, business and educational leaders. "This was the judgment  of a military court."

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Workers Return to G.M., But Issues Are Unresolved Workers began returning to two General Motors plants, ending their 17-day strike without resolving critical issues between the company and the United Automobile  Workers union. While a few local disputes were resolved, the national issues are sure to come up again this summer when the U.A.W.'s three-year national contract expires.

headline: 20th Century Misstated a Stock Fund's Value
abstract: TWENTIETH CENTURY mutual funds misstated the net asset value of its top-performing Vista Investors stock fund for five months last year, meaning people who bought shares paid too much and those who sold shares got an artificially high price.         The error came to light recently as investors shared the information on computer bulletin boards. When asked about the incident on Friday, Gunnar Hughes, a fund spokesman, said Twentieth Century discovered the error and corrected the Vista fund's net asset value on Aug. 21. The fund company, based in Kansas City, Mo., sent corrected statements and an explanation to people who  bought or sold shares of the fund from March 13 through late August. No shareholders lost money because of the mistake, Mr. Hughes said.

headline: From a Defeated Ex-Leader, a Warning
abstract: If there was a big loser in today's presidential election, it was Hau Pei-tsun.         Even as he sought voters' acceptance in his effort to defeat President Lee Teng-hui by running as the vice presidential candidate on an opposing ticket, Mr. Hau, a 77-year-old former Prime Minister, had come to symbolize "mainlander" domination of Taiwan.

headline: Rockefeller Center Properties Is Sued
abstract: The financier Sam Zell has sued Rockefeller Center Properties Inc., contending the company breached an agreement to recapitalize with a $250 million infusion from Mr. Zell.         In the suit filed yesterday in United States District Court in Manhattan, Mr. Zell and his affiliates asked the court to force Rockefeller Center Properties to sell the financier 1.79 million shares for $10 million as part of the agreement.

headline: Israeli Press Lifts Cover Off Spy Chief
abstract: An Israeli newspaper today identified the newly designated head of Israel's overseas intelligence agency, the Mossad, challenging military censorship and breaching another wall of secrecy around the country's security services.         The liberal daily Haaretz defied a ban on publishing the name of the Mossad chief, reporting in today's issue that Prime Minister Shimon Peres had decided to appoint his close aide and military assistant, Maj. Gen. Danny Yatom, as the  new head of the secret agency.

headline: Jerusalem Journal;Handing Down the Word, but Not Carved in Stone
abstract: As of this week, an Israeli who wants a toaster-oven need no longer do a pantomime before a dumbfounded store clerk or reach for a foreign tongue. Now he or she can walk into a store with head held high and demand a tanuron.         That, according to the latest decree of the august Academy of the Hebrew Language, is what a toaster-oven shall hereafter be in Hebrew -- literally, a "little oven."

headline: Clinton Points to Competition As Way of Curbing Inflation
abstract: Wading deeper into the campaign debate over economic growth, President Clinton said today that "a lot of people" now believe that global competition can help hold down inflation, lessening the need for the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates.         In a speech at a fund-raising dinner in New York on Thursday night, Mr. Clinton offered a vigorous defense of Felix G. Rohatyn, the investment banker whom he had wanted to nominate as vice chairman of the central bank in an effort to help foster a debate with the more cautious monetary policies of its current  chairman, Alan Greenspan.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;DELTA RESTORING PAY CUT TO NONUNION WORKERS
abstract: Delta Air Lines Inc. said yesterday that it was restoring pay to the level before it imposed a 5 percent cut on all nonunion employees. Atlanta-based Delta, which cut its nonunion employee pay by 5 percent three years ago, said it was able to restore the pay because it was profitable and could afford to do so. The airline also said that on Feb. 23 it would pay out a lump sum advance profit-sharing equal to 5 percent of base salary from July 1, 1995, through Jan. 31, 1996. Delta, the nation's third-biggest carrier, cut employee pay in 1993, when the airline was in the middle of a string of losses that totaled nearly $2 billion. Delta's stock was up $1.625, to $70, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Loral Deal to Aid Globalstar, One of 4 Rival Phone Plans
abstract: One reason that the Lockheed Martin Corporation did not announce a full acquisition of the Loral Corporation yesterday, according to Bernard L. Schwartz, Loral's chairman, was that Lockheed could not meet the price he had placed on Loral's 31 percent ownership of Globalstar Telecommunications Ltd.         Globalstar plans to provide telephone service by bouncing signals off 48 low-orbiting satellites. But with no customers expected until 1998, the need for nearly $2 billion in investment and numerous competitors lurking in the shadows, Globalstar's prospects would not appear to be valuable to the average Lockheed shareholder. Still, Mr. Schwartz feels differently, and so now do many  investors.

headline: Islamic Rule Is Reaffirmed By Sudan Chief
abstract: Hundreds of Sudanese poured into the streets of Khartoum today to hear their  newly elected President, Lieut. Gen. Omar al-Bashir, vow to keep the country ruled by "Islamic law and dignity," with no return to party politics.         General Bashir, who appointed himself President in 1989 after overthrowing a  democratically elected Government in a military coup, told the crowd after his widely expected landslide victory in the presidential elections, "We have fully  returned power in full to the people."

headline: New Talks Begin in Belfast, But Adams Is Turned Away
abstract: A crucial phase in the accelerated Northern Ireland peace effort began today  with Gerry Adams, the political leader of the Irish Republican Army, being turned away from the guarded gates of the British Government building where a new round of talks is being held.         British officials repeated their insistence that Mr. Adams and his party, Sinn Fein, could not take part in the nine days of scheduled talks unless the I.R.A. restored the cease-fire it ended on Feb. 9 by resuming bomb attacks in London.

headline: Rules of Ownership Changing for Media
abstract: Media companies will soon be permitted to own more television and radio stations nationally and more radio stations in each local market, Federal regulators said today.          The Federal Communications Commission's order will lift a longstanding rule  that limits to 12 the number of television stations that one company can own. Companies basically will be able to own as many as they want, as long as the stations together do not reach more than 35 percent of all American households.  The current limit is 25 percent.

headline: Yes, He's Revived Sears. But Can He Reinvent It?
abstract: IT'S 9 A.M. on a November Friday. The auditorium at Sears, Roebuck & Company's headquarters here in suburban Chicago is filled with balloons. More than 900 employees jam the seats and spill over onto the floor.         A spotlight breaks the semidarkness, revealing a ringmaster. "Welcome to the  Sears P.S.E. Circus," he says. "It's eye-popping. Death-defying. Larger than life. Well, not death-defying."

headline: COMPANY NEWS;TURNER BROADCASTING APPROVES SPORTS CHANNEL
abstract: As expected, the board of the Turner Broadcasting System Inc. approved plans  yesterday to create a round-the-clock sports cable channel this year. The channel, to be called CNN/SI, will be a partnership between Turner's cable news  channel CNN and Sports Illustrated, the magazine owned by Time Warner Inc. The new network will broadcast sports news, not live sports events. The new channel  will be based in Atlanta, Turner's home, and will begin broadcasts in December. The channel would be a product of the proposed merger of Atlanta-based Turner and Time Warner. Time Warner agreed in September to take over Turner in a $7.5 billion deal, which is still being reviewed by Federal regulators.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;BWAY SIGNS AGREEMENT TO PURCHASE MILTON CAN
abstract: The BWAY Corporation of Atlanta signed an agreement yesterday to buy the privately held Milton Can Company. BWAY said Milton Can's shareholders would receive about $30 million in about equal portions of cash and BWAY stock, and BWAY would assume existing Milton Can debt. Milton Can, which has operations in  New Jersey and Massachusetts, had sales of about $60 million last year, while BWAY had sales of about $250 million, it said. BWAY makes steel containers.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Senior Iranian Official Faces Arrest in Germany
abstract: In a highly unusual move that could bolster the American campaign to isolate  Iran, a German judge has issued a warrant for the arrest of Iran's intelligence  minister on murder charges. The minister, Ali Fallahiyan, is suspected of having ordered the 1992 killing of a Kurdish exile here.         Five men, an Iranian and four Lebanese, are on trial for the killings. In January, a German intelligence officer testified that his agency believes Iran ordered the operation; Iran denies any involvement.

headline: NATO Forces Have to Watch As a Sarajevo District Burns
abstract: Grbavica, the final Serbian-held enclave in the Sarajevo area that will come  under Muslim-Croat control, was rent by huge explosions tonight as fires swept through the district and gangs armed with cans of gasoline dodged NATO patrols in an effort to ignite high-rise apartment blocks. There was little that the NATO-led peacekeeping forces appeared able to do.         Italian troops, their helmets adorned with black plumes, arrested 12 Bosnian  Serb men suspected of arson in four separate incidents, frisking the men as they stood against a wall. A few Serbs peered from windows as the troops marched one  group of nine men through the drizzle to the local Serbian police station. One young Serb among the suspects appeared to be in tears. Serbian police, angered by the NATO intervention, jeered at foreign reporters who watched.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;EXCEL INDUSTRIES TO BUY ANDERSON INDUSTRIES
abstract: Excel Industries signed a definitive agreement yesterday to buy the closely held Anderson Industries for an undisclosed amount. Anderson Industries is a holding company based in Rockford, Ill., whose main asset is Atwood Industries,  a maker of equipment such as gas ranges, water heaters, furnaces, air-conditioners for recreational vehicles and housing. Excel, based in Elkhart, Ind., said Atwood's sales were expected to be about $375 million this year. Atwood has about 3,700 employees at 13 plants in the United States, one plant in Mexico and one in Italy. Excel makes window and door systems for manufacturers of cars, vans, trucks and buses.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Volkswagen Gains In European Market
abstract: Volkswagen A.G. grabbed a larger slice of the Western European auto market in 1995, giving it the largest market share there for the 10th consecutive year, the company said yesterday. Volkswagen said deliveries to customers in Western Europe climbed 4.6 percent, to 2.1 million vehicles last year, giving it a 16.8  percent share of the market, up from 15.8 percent a year earlier.          Analysts attributed the gain to the success of recently released models, VW's strength in the German market and aggressive pricing. Analysts said the main reason for the increased market share was the success of VW's Polo model, the Audi A4 and the Skoda Felicia. Audi is VW's luxury car unit; VW holds a 70 percent stake in Skoda, the Czech auto maker.   (Reuters)

headline: Alumax Moves To Thwart Hostile Bid By Kaiser
abstract: Even as speculators bid up its stock, Alumax Inc. took steps yesterday to thwart an unwanted takeover by the Kaiser Aluminum Corporation.         Alumax said it had adopted anti-takeover provisions that would enable shareholders to buy additional stock at half the market price in the event that  a person or group acquired 15 percent or more of its voting shares outstanding.

headline: As Europe's Borders Fall, the Old Art of Bootlegging Thrives
abstract: On the docks at Calais, just across the wintry water from here in France, a line of innocuous white vans with British license plates waited the other day to board the Pride of Dover car ferry for the 90-minute trip to England.         Waiting at Dover's customs department, Steve Clements knew exactly what was afoot.

headline: World News Briefs;Mutiny in Guinea Reportedly Resolved
abstract: Mutinous soldiers in Guinea surrounded and shelled President Lansana Conte's  palace today after a pay dispute developed into an apparent coup attempt, the state radio said. But the radio later reported that an agreement had been reached and that all of the soldiers had been told to return to their units.         Mr. Conte told Radio France International early today that loyal troops had repulsed three attacks on his palace by rebels during the night. Shellfire had set the palace on fire.

headline: Philadelphia' Screenplay Suit To Reach Court
abstract: A lawsuit contending that the makers of the movie "Philadelphia" misappropriated a story about a New York lawyer, who was dismissed after his employer discovered he had AIDS, is scheduled to go to trial tomorrow in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;DOCUMENTUM PUBLIC OFFERING STIRS ENTHUSIASM
abstract: The shares of Documentum Inc. shares rose strongly on their first day of trading. Documentum stock, priced at $24, closed at $30 in trading of almost 2.1 million shares yesterday. Earlier it traded as high as $34. Documentum sold 1.8  million shares to raise $43.2 million. The company plans to use the money for general purposes. Documentum, based in Pleasanton, Calif., makes software that speeds and automates the creation and distribution of complex documents.

headline: A Rebel Attack on Afghan Capital Kills 18
abstract: Rebel fighters shelled the shopping district in Kabul today, killing 18 civilians and wounding 14 others, witnesses and Government officials said.         In the attack, which came in the middle of the day, one shell crashed into a  busy shopping street, killing six shoppers instantly. Twelve others died later in the hospital, hospital officials said.

headline: For Texaco, A Transition At the Top
abstract: Peter I. Bijur, a 53-year-old senior vice president of Texaco Inc. with wide  experience overseas, was elected yesterday to succeed Alfred C. DeCrane Jr., who will retire as chairman and chief executive on July 1.         Mr. DeCrane, who will step down when he reaches the company's retirement age  of 65, will hand over a slimmed-down and more focused company, which has increasingly looked overseas for its growth, particularly in Russia, where it is seeking to start two major projects.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Forte in Deal to Sell 67 White Hart Hotels
abstract: Forte P.L.C., the beleaguered British hotel and restaurant company, agreed yesterday to sell 67 of its 72 White Hart hotel properties to the Regal Hotels Group for L122 million, or about $184 million. Among other conditions, the sale  is subject to the failure of the Granada Group's bid to take over Forte. Forte has been attempting to block Granada's bid of L3.8 billion by selling hotel assets.          Analysts said Forte's agreement to sell the White Hart properties would not  reduce the likelihood that Granada, a leisure and broadcasting group, would win  its bid, which expires today. Forte said that if the Regal deal went through, it would receive L90 million in cash and L32 million in Regal Hotels shares.   (AP)

headline: COMPANY NEWS;SPINOFF OF SPRINT'S CELLULAR UNIT GETS TAX-FREE STATUS
abstract: The Sprint Corporation said yesterday that it had passed the last hurdle to spinning off its cellular-telephone business by getting approval from the Internal Revenue Service to make the spinoff tax-free for shareholders. The company plans to spin off the cellular unit, called the 360degrees Communications Company, in the first quarter to comply with a Federal law that prohibits the overlap of Sprint's cellular business with its new operations in so-called personal communications services. Sprint shareholders will get one share of 360degrees Communications for every three Sprint shares they own.

headline: Media Business Now a Job Fair For Executives Once Removed
abstract: For someone who was just thrown out of work, Frank J. Biondi Jr. certainly acts like a busy man. On Thursday, two weeks after he was ousted as the president and chief executive of Viacom Inc., Mr. Biondi raced from one meeting  to another before heading to a going-away party at La Grenouille, the venerable  midtown restaurant, where his former colleagues toasted him over a lavish dinner of ravioli with lobster and rack of lamb.         "The only difference between this and working," he said in an interview at his temporary offices, "is that people used to come and see me. Now, I go to see them."

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Apple Computer Dismissess Spindler; Names Amelio Apple Computer dismissed Michael H. Spindler as president and chief executive and replaced him with Gilbert F. Amelio, a board member, who will become chairman and chief executive of the struggling company.

headline: U.S., Waiving Ban, Will Send Arms to Pakistan
abstract: The Administration is to deliver $368 million worth of military hardware to Pakistan, overriding its own concerns that Pakistan's leaders are building nuclear weapons, members of Congress said today.         The weaponry, which Pakistan has paid for, was held up by a 1990 law barring  the sales in light of Pakistan's nuclear-weapons program. The Central Intelligence Agency says Pakistan has built several bombs and has bought nuclear-weapons technology and medium-range missiles from China.

headline: Ford Tests the Price Barrier;Auto Maker Takes a Risk With Fancy Redesigns
abstract: When the Ford Motor Company introduces the redesigned F-150 XLT pickup on Thursday, the truck will not have simple steel bumpers. Instead, its rear bumpers will glisten with chrome -- an option for which customers used to pay $150.         Other popular options, like power mirrors, dual air bags and air-conditioning, will also be standard on the XLT, the most popular version of  the nation's best-selling vehicle. And that's just the beginning. Many features, previously unavailable on the truck, will be standard, such as a more powerful engine and a new front suspension that gives a much smoother ride.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;ACE TO BUY TEMPEST REINSURANCE OF BERMUDA
abstract: Ace Ltd. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Tempest Reinsurance Company of Bermuda for stock valued at about $605 million. Tempest was formed in 1993 by the General Re Corporation of Stamford, Conn., to reinsure against property catastrophes. Reinsurance is protection that insurance carriers buy to  reduce their own risk. General Re initially invested $100 million in Tempest and then began seeking investments from other companies. General Re will not retain any interest in Tempest after Ace's purchase. Ace, an insurance concern also based in Bermuda, will exchange about 13.3 million shares in the deal. Its  stock rose $2.75, to $48.25, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
abstract: Pentland U.S.A., New Hyde Park, L.I., a unit of the Pentland Group P.L.C., to Needleman Fleizach Pilla, New York, to introduce Kickers footwear in the United  States. The billings have not been determined.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Media Merger Planned By British Companies
abstract: MAI Group P.L.C. and United News and Media P.L.C. said yesterday that they would merge, creating a $4.4 billion British media company. MAI's shareholders are to be offered 64 United Media shares for each 100 ordinary shares held. United News will own 50.7 percent of the unnamed new company.          The merger is intended to capitalize on a bill now before Parliament. Under  the current broadcasting laws, United News's national papers like The Daily Express, The Sunday Express and The Daily Star would not be allowed to merge with MAI, which has television broadcasting licenses. The companies are structuring the transaction to conform to existing law by placing the national newspapers in a separate unit. The new company will also sell some of MAI's financial services businesses.    (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: Board Resigns At U.S. Fund For Czechs And Slovaks
abstract: The entire board of a troubled investment fund set up to help the Czech and Slovak republics has resigned.  Now President Clinton is to appoint an interim board to help determine if the fund should be shut or merged with another fund, a spokesman for the Agency for International Development said today.         The Czech and Slovak American Enterprise Fund, established by Congress in 1989, has invested about $26 million but it expects to write off about $10 million in bad investments.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Serino Coyne Buys Comora Associates
abstract: Serino Coyne Inc. in New York, an advertising and public relations agency, has acquired Owen Comora Associates, a public relations agency in New York. The  terms were not disclosed. Comora will become a unit of Serino Coyne's public relations division and will continue to operate under the Comora name. Owen Comora, the president of Comora, will continue in that role, while Pamela Johnson will continue to be president of the Serino Coyne public relations division.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Drug Trial Disappoints
abstract: Ciba-Geigy said yesterday that results of clinical trials of its new anti-thrombotic drug Revasc were below expectations and that it was considering  whether to pursue use of the heart medication. Revasc is intended for treatment  of acute coronary syndrome, which is life threatening to some patients.   (Reuters)

headline: Dow Closes Above 5,300 on Rate-Cut Hopes
abstract: The stock market rose yesterday, as traders responded to strong earnings reports and hoped the Federal Reserve would cut interest rates this week.         "If rates are cut, that will set an optimistic tone for the market," said Barbara C. Marcin, vice president of Citibank Global Asset Management. "And with companies reporting better earnings, that should make for a good year."

headline: C.I.A. Confirms Blunders During Economic Spying on France
abstract: Blunders by Central Intelligence Agency operatives trying to gather secret information on French trade negotiations and economic espionage led to an international embarrassment, a report by the agency's inspector general concluded today.         The career of one legendary spy is over, the agency's role in gathering economic intelligence may be damaged, and its reputation may suffer another self-inflicted wound as a result of the internal investigation into the C.I.A.'s Paris station, officials familiar with the report said.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Lowe Acquires Health Agency
abstract: The Lowe Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies agreed yesterday to acquire William Douglas McAdams Inc. in New York, the sixth-largest agency specializing in health care advertising. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Consolidation Continues at Kodak
abstract: A day after the Eastman Kodak Company consolidated its worldwide consumer advertising account at two agencies, the company consolidated its worldwide professional and printing business-to-business account at the Saatchi & Saatchi  Business Communications unit of Cordiant P.L.C. in Rochester by naming that shop as its worldwide agency of record. Billings were not disclosed, but Kodak will spend an estimated $50 million to $70 million this year on marketing communications to promote its professional and printing services.         Kathleen Moran, director for brand management and communications and vice president for professional and printing imaging at Kodak in Rochester, said yesterday that the consolidated account was assigned after an informal review. The account had been divided between Saatchi & Saatchi Business, which has handled assignments including portrait photography in the United States, and various local agencies. Saatchi & Saatchi Business, which is the business-to-business network of Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide, also handles other Kodak assignments like the consumer imaging trade account.

headline: Canada Senses Fragility in Realm's New Coin
abstract: Canadians are smacking it against concrete walls, hammering it, boiling it, burning it and freezing it. The idea is to see if their new $2 coin -- composed  of a soft inner plug of bronze and hard outer disk of nickel -- falls apart.         Newspapers are full of accounts of the center not holding; some even pop out. Some call the coin a metaphor for the country, which faces a continuing threat from the Quebec separatist movement.

headline: Hijackers Seem to Ease Their Threat to Blow Up Turkish Ferry
abstract: A Turkish ferry seized by hijackers who support the anti-Russian rebels in Chechnya approached Istanbul today, with the hijackers seeming to pull back from threats to blow up the vessel along with themselves and more than 200 passengers.         The situation remained highly volatile, however, with several of the hijackers giving contradictory interviews to Turkish news organizations. High seas and thick fog slowed the ferry, and Turkish coast guard vessels shadowed it as it made its way slowly along Turkey's Black Sea coast, headed for Istanbul.

headline: Late Advance Drives Dow Above 5,500
abstract: Stocks continued to rise yesterday, pushing stock indexes to record highs for the fourth consecutive session, even as the market confounded professional investors who have been baffled by its recent gains.         The Dow Jones industrial average moved above the 5,500-point level for the first time, finishing ahead 47.33 at 5,539.45. Records were also set by the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, which closed at 656.07, up 6.14, and by the Nasdaq composite index, which was up 8.29, to 1,093.17.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;LYNCH JONES BUYS JOHNSON REDBOOK SERVICE
abstract: Lynch Jones & Ryan said yesterday that it had acquired the Johnson Redbook Service, a research organization that provides reports on sales by retailers. Terms were not disclosed. Johnson Redbook has been an affiliate of Lynch Jones,  a brokerage firm based in New York, since 1991, but Lynch Jones did not have an  ownership stake. The service was bought from the estate of the founder, Edward F. Johnson, who died last year at the age of 73. Lynch Jones named Jay Meltzer managing director of Johnson Redbook. Mr. Meltzer joined the service last July.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Helen Gurley Brown Leaving; Cosmopolitan Names Successor
abstract: Helen Gurley Brown, who took over a failing magazine called Cosmopolitan in 1965 and turned it into an industry legend, will step down as its editor in chief in 18 months. Her successor will be Bonnie Fuller, founding editor in chief of the United States edition of Marie Claire, who was named deputy editor of Cosmopolitan yesterday.         The announcement by Frank A. Bennack Jr., president and chief executive of the Hearst Corporation, and Cathleen P. Black, the recently named president of Hearst Magazines, parent to both Cosmopolitan and Marie Claire, ends years of speculation within the industry about who could possibly follow in the footsteps of the diminutive but formidable Ms. Brown, who is 73.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Europe Tightens Curbs On Foreign Films on TV
abstract: The European Parliament voted yesterday to strengthen the limits on the number of foreign films shown on television in European Union countries. The parliament, which has powers to decide jointly with governments on changes to the union's 1989 Television Without Frontiers law, said a requirement that channels devote at least 51 percent of their air time to European work should be enforced by "legally effective means." Until now, they have only been obliged to meet the requirement "where practicable."          The parliament, the union's elected assembly, also agreed to tighten curbs on advertising and teleshopping. The decision sets the parliament on a collision course with European Union ministers who agreed in November to leave the 1989 law virtually unchanged.   (Reuters)

headline: Eat, Sleep and Breathe Politics on Internet
abstract: Three Internet services will allow fans of this year's Presidential race to play campaign manager and dissect the raw fixings of political news -- including polls, speech texts, ad scripts, videotapes of candidates' appearances and even  copies of their tax returns.         One of the services, Politics USA, went on line in September. A second, All Politics, is set to start on Monday and a third, Election Line, is scheduled to  begin by Feb. 6.

headline: Canadian Bribe Inquiry Said to Look at Boeing
abstract: The Boeing Company and a former senior sales executive are under criminal investigation in Canada on suspicion that a former Boeing subsidiary paid more than $1 million in bribes and fees to sell five airplanes to Bahamasair in 1990, people with knowledge of the investigation said.         In addition, people close to the situation said the United States Justice Department had been looking into the matter, although it did not appear that a grand jury had been convened.

headline: Class Suit on Tobacco Illness Can Go to Trial in Florida
abstract: Anti-tobacco plaintiffs won a partial victory yesterday when a Florida state  appeals panel unanimously ruled that the first class-action lawsuit against leading tobacco companies for cigarette-related illnesses could go to trial. But the court limited the case to the state of Florida, instead of permitting the plaintiffs' lawyers to mount a case with national effect.         Nevertheless, analysts said that the lawsuit, Engle vs. the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, could potentially cover 500,000 to 3 million people in Florida, which has a population of about 14 million.

headline: Johannesburg Journal;Will Rugby Embrace, or Crush, a Dainty Flower?
abstract: A fan writes:         "The people on the National Sports Council are very clearly not rugby supporters on the level that most of us are. Don't you dare try and turn our game into a 'blommetjie' sport.  Real rugby players don't wear flowers. They give them to their girlfriends and wives. And the proteas grown at nurseries overseas nowadays are better quality than those growing in our country anyway!"

headline: Ivax Acquires Drug Concerns
abstract: The Ivax Corporation has bought three affiliated South American drug companies in exchange for about $41.75 million of Ivax common stock, the company said today. Ivax said revenues for the companies totaled $35 million last year.          Elvetium S.A. and Alet Laboratorios of Argentina and Elvetium S.A. of Uruguay make and sell pharmaceuticals.

headline: Dow Declines by 12.65; Chip Shares Have a Selloff
abstract: Stock prices slumped yesterday, hurt by a decline in bonds and by a selloff in semiconductor issues.         "This was a very, very nervous market," said Joseph V. Battapaglia, chief investment strategist for Gruntal & Company. "Stocks opened strongly as a follow-through to Tuesday's trading, but there were drops at the last moments, with a lot due to momentum trading."

headline: COMPANY NEWS;HOME SAVINGS DEAL HELPS WELLS FARGO
abstract: Home Savings of America said yesterday that it had agreed to buy 61 First Interstate Bancorp branches for about $200 million, a deal that will allow Wells Fargo & Company to complete its takeover of First Interstate, an all-stock offer worth more than $13 billion. Home Savings, a unit of H. F. Ahmanson & Company and based in Irwindale, Calif., is the nation's largest savings and loan, with about $50.5 billion in assets at the beginning of the year. The acquisition of the branches would give it $500 million in consumer loans and $121 million in small-business loans. Home Savings said it would close as many as 27 of the 61 branches near its existing branches, and expected "modest" layoffs. On the New York Stock Exchange, shares of Ahmanson rose 25 cents, to $24.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Pepsi Courts Myanmar, Preferring Sales to Politics
abstract: There are not many countries left where you can't buy a bottle of Pepsi-Cola, so when a suitable business partner turned up in the isolated Southeast Asian nation of Myanmar five years ago, Pepsico was eager to set up a bottling plant.          The timing was awkward, though. Almost three years before, in September 1988, an authoritarian Government with military backing choked off democratic protests that had evolved into an uprising, and the country formerly known as Burma was under tight army control.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;HSBC Earnings Rise
abstract: The British banking company HSBC Holdings P.L.C. said yesterday that its profit rose 20 percent in 1995, led by strong gains in Hong Kong and the United  States. HSBC said its profit was L2.46 billion ($3.79 billion), up from L2.05 billion in 1994. HSBC Americas Inc., formerly Marine Midland Banks Inc., reported a profit of $292 million, up 28 percent. The Hong Kong division's profit rose 16 percent and the British unit, Midland Bank, reported 3 percent higher profits. But the investment banking unit had a 19 percent decline in profits.   (AP)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Drinking Tequila but Thinking Cognac, Maybe?
abstract: To most Americans, tequila is some kind of exotic Tijuana firewater that if not the drink of connoisseurs, never fails to hit the spot.         But one tequila maker, Guillermo Romo de la Pena, is convinced that his liquor is really pure and sophisticated, the Mexican equivalent of cognac. And Mr. Romo, head of a small 225-year-old company named Tequila Herradura, is on a  campaign to convince both makers and drinkers that his way of thinking is right.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;BAUSCH & LOMB LAYOFFS AND EARNINGS CHARGE
abstract: Bausch & Lomb Inc. said yesterday that it would consolidate its sunglasses business, closing a plant in Oakland, Md., and eliminating about 800 jobs by the end of the year as part of a three-year reorganization plan. The maker of optics and health products, based in Rochester said that plant's 600 jobs would be eliminated and 200 jobs would be cut this year at a Rochester frame-making plant. The company plans to take a $27 million charge for the reorganization, which is expected to reduce fourth-quarter and 1995 earnings by about 30 cents a share. The company's chief executive, Daniel E. Gill, retired last month amid investor discontent and investigations into company sales and marketing practices.

headline: Fearing Reprisal, Publisher Drops Book on Greece
abstract: Anastasia Karakasidou's first book, a 300-page study of ethnicity and identity in the northern Greek province of Macedonia, seemed poised for publication after surviving months of grueling academic review at Cambridge University Press and winning high praise from academic specialists for its insights and fairness.         But in December, Ms. Karakasidou received surprising news: The press had decided not to publish the book after all, it said, because it feared for the safety of its staff members in Greece.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: PHOENIX HOME LIFE MUTUAL INSURANCE CO., will acquire a 15 percent stake in Aberdeen Trust P.L.C., of Aberdeen, Scotland, an investment management company,  as part of a joint venture agreement between the two companies. The mutual life  insurer will pay $37.5 million for the Aberdeen stake.

headline: AT&T to End Its On-Line Service And Join the World Wide Web
abstract: Only a year after paying more than $50 million for the Interchange on-line service, the AT&T Corporation said yesterday that it would phase out the network and move its current offerings to the Internet's World Wide Web by midyear.         The move is the latest evidence of how quickly the Web, the part of the Internet that combines text, audio and video, has established itself as the emerging standard for electronic publishing.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;MONSANTO AND DEKALB GENETICS IN JOINT VENTURE
abstract: The Monsanto Company and the DeKalb Genetics Corporation said yesterday that  they had joined forces in agricultural biotechnology. As part of the deal, Monsanto will invest nearly $160 million to take a significant minority stake in DeKalb, the second-largest company in the North American seed corn market. Monsanto will also pay DeKalb $19.5 million for a 10-year collaboration, which will concentrate on corn and soybeans. The agreement also covers other crops, including sorghum, wheat, oilseeds and produce. DeKalb's shares gained $4, to $63.25, in Nasdaq trading. Shares of Monsanto advanced $1.125, to $131.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Higher Earnings For CS First Boston
abstract: CS First Boston, the investment banking unit of the giant Swiss financial services company CS Holding A.G., had a sharp improvement in earnings in 1995, thanks to strong fixed-income trading results and a booming mergers-and-acquisitions business.         The firm said this week that its net income jumped 33 percent last year, to $207 million, after one-time charges, compared with $156 million in 1994. Profits would have risen even more dramatically were it not for $89.5 million in pretax charges largely related to the elimination of 23 percent of the firm's employees.

headline: OUTLOOK '96: MARKETS AND INVESTING;Dollar's Star Tied to Budget
abstract: The central question about the dollar in 1996 is: If President Clinton and the Republican Congress agree on a credible plan to balance the Federal budget in seven years, will this push the dollar higher or lower?         Naturally, economists are divided over this question.

headline: OUTLOOK '96: TECHNOLOGY AND MEDIA;Book Chains Extending Influence
abstract: FOR book buyers, 1995 was the year of more superstore openings, O. J. Simpson books, pocket-size novels and giant book-movie deals.         Big books were bigger, and smaller books often seemed to get lost. And the book chains boomed -- a trend that is expected to continue, at least in the near future. Indeed, Barnes & Noble Inc. plans to open at least 75 more superstores this year. Other chains are expanding as well.

headline: Chilean Politicians Urge Pinochet to Resign
abstract: Politicians from Chile's ruling coalition called today for the former dictator Augusto Pinochet to resign as army chief after a former secret service  agent was arrested for the murder of an exiled general.         "I believe that, seen from General Pinochet's position, this is is an occasion to resign," said a Christian Democratic senator, Jorge Lavandero.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;BUFFETT TO TAKE SHARES IN MERGED DISNEY-CAPITAL CITIES
abstract: In a vote of confidence for the newly merged company, the multibillionaire investor Warren E. Buffett said yesterday that he wanted shares of the Walt Disney Company in exchange for his investment company's $2.5 billion stake in Capital Cities/ABC Inc. Disney is buying the media company for $19 billion in cash and stock, but it gave shareholders some latitude on how they would be paid. Yesterday was the deadline for making the choices. The standard selection was a share in Disney stock and $65 in cash for each Capital Cities share. But shareholders could also request to be paid all in stock or all in cash, subject to certain limits. Mr. Buffett controlled 20 million shares, or 13 percent, of Capital Cities/ABC stock through the Omaha-based reinsurer and investment company Berkshire Hathaway Inc.

headline: Taiwan Aide Flies to U.S.
abstract: Taiwan's Vice President left on a trip today that includes plans for four brief stops in the United States that have brought criticism from China.         Vice President Li Yuan-zu plans to make stops in San Francisco, Los Angeles and twice in Miami en route to and from official visits to Haiti and El Salvador.

headline: COMMUNICATIONS RESHAPED: THE OVERHAUL;CONGRESS VOTES TO RESHAPE COMMUNICATIONS INDUSTRY, ENDING A 4-YEAR STRUGGLE
abstract: After four years of struggle and gridlock, Congress rewrote the nation's communications laws today, passing a bill that would transform television, telephones and the emerging frontiers of cyberspace.         Voting within two hours of each other, both the House and Senate approved a final version of a bill that is broadly intended to promote a free-for-all rivalry between local telephone companies, long-distance carriers, cable television operators and even electric utilities.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;AM INTERNATIONAL SEES BIG LOSS AND CUTS 200 EMPLOYEES
abstract: AM International Inc. said yesterday that its second-quarter loss would be "substantially greater" than the first quarter's and dismissed 200 workers because of worsening results. The company, a business and graphics-equipment maker, also said that it would temporarily shut one of its plants and that it had sold its AM Multigraphics subsidiaries in the Netherlands, France and Belgium. Terms were not disclosed, and company officials declined to elaborate. Shares in AM, based in Rosemont, Ill., closed down 62.5 cents at $3.125.

headline: Russia Wants No Return of Cold War, Official Says
abstract: Yevgeny M. Primakov, the new Russian Foreign Minister, said today that Russia continued to desire a close working relationship with the United States and had  no intention of trying to resurrect the Soviet Union.         Mr. Primakov, who spoke after two days of meetings here with Secretary of State Warren Christopher, also said Russia would not put into effect any new oil deal with Iraq until the United Nations lifted sanctions against it.

headline: EARNING IT;The Boss Was a Giant: How to Fill the Shoes?
abstract: SAM WALTON, the charismatic founder of Wal-Mart, built a single discount store in Rogers, Ark., into a retail behemoth. Workers, whom he respectfully dubbed "associates," loved him for team-building practices like the daily cheer: "W-A-L M-A-R-T," punctuated with a Chubby Checker-like twist they call a "squiggly." Known for his masterful selling instincts, down-home manner and habit of turning up at stores to inspect the wares and inspire the troops, he became a legend inside and outside his company.         For Wal-Mart Stores Inc., that was precisely the problem as Mr. Walton neared retirement age. Who could replace this icon, this man who once did a hula on Wall Street in a grass skirt? This kind of quandary is faced by any business with an outsize leader. Just this January, Helen Gurley Brown, the woman who gave Cosmopolitan, and with it many other women's magazines, a franker, bolder voice, announced that she would retire in June 1997.

headline: Technology Stocks Drag Market Down, and Dow Falls 17.34
abstract: The stock market weakened yesterday in sluggish holiday trading, as investors remained worried about earnings shortfalls and the absence of a budget agreement in Washington.         "There was weakness in the high-tech stocks and that impacted the Dow industrials," said Harry W. Laubscher, senior vice president of Tucker Anthony.  "Concern spread that earlier earnings estimates may not come to pass."

headline: Canadian Publishers Offer Editions in Chinese
abstract: After English and French, the largest language group in Canada is Chinese. In this country of nearly 30 million people, more than 500,000 are Chinese -- many  from Hong Kong, fearing for the future after the city is returned to China in mid-1997.         The Chinese influx is affecting the life of most Canadians, especially in Toronto and Vancouver, focal points of the immigration. Herbal medicine and acupuncture are common. Concepts like feng shui, the positioning of a house so that it brings good fortune to its residents, are well known. And Chinese-language newspapers are popping up in hotels, shopping centers and on subways.

headline: Fidelity Discloses a Big Shift to Cash by Magellan Fund
abstract: Reminding market watchers that he is a flexible investor, Jeffrey N. Vinik, manager of the $53 billion Fidelity Magellan fund, sharply reduced the fund's stock holdings in December, to their lowest level since he took over the fund in July 1992.         According to a report released yesterday by Fidelity, Mr. Vinik had 32.1 percent of the fund's assets in cash and bonds. That percentage is 15 times what it was in June, and almost double the reserves held in November.

headline: World News Briefs;Japan Decides Against Food Aid to North Korea
abstract: Japan does not see North Korea as being in a state of famine and has no plans to provide it either financial or food aid, the Government said today.         A Foreign Ministry spokesman, Hiroshi Hashimoto, said that Japan, South Korea and the United States had agreed in trilateral talks last month in Hawaii that the situation in the North was serious but could not yet be described as a famine.

headline: Christopher Cautions the Russians on Isolation
abstract: Secretary of State Warren Christopher warned Russian voters today that they face a choice in the June presidential elections between inclusion in the institutions of the West or self-isolation.         In a speech before the foreign ministers of 12 Central and East European countries, including the three Baltic nations, Mr. Christopher strongly reaffirmed the American commitment to the expansion of NATO no matter what happens in Russia.

headline: Yeltsin Picks Soviet-Era Aide To Guide Russian Economy
abstract: In the most vivid display yet of his disenchantment with economic reform, President Boris N. Yeltsin chose a Soviet-schooled industrialist today to serve  as Russia's top economic official.         Mr. Yeltsin announced that Vladimir V. Kadannikov, the director of Russia's largest and ailing automobile company and an advocate of protective tariffs, would replace Anatoly B. Chubais, the free-market crusader, as Deputy Prime Minister.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;TENNECO TO GET $815.7 MILLION FROM CASE STAKE
abstract: Tenneco Inc. will realize proceeds of $815.7 million from its sale of 15.2 million shares of the Case Corporation, whose public offering of 16.7 million shares was priced on Thursday at $53.75 a share. The stock of Case, which makes  agricultural and construction equipment, was down 62.5 cents yesterday, to $53.125, in New York Stock Exchange trading of almost 43 million shares. The Tenneco stake amounted to 21 percent of Case's outstanding shares. Tenneco, a Houston-based conglomerate, announced last month it was selling its remaining stake in Case, whose headquarters are in Racine, Wis.

headline: COMMUNICATIONS RESHAPED: THE BROADCASTERS;The Networks See Potential For Growth
abstract: Broadcasters walked away from yesterday's passage of the new telecommunications bill well satisfied with its deregulation of several parts of their industry and looking forward to a booming market in television and radio stations.         They were also so happy to have escaped for now a threat to their access to public airwaves that they supported the bill despite the inclusion of the so-called V-chip requirement, which would block programs deemed to have offensively violent or sexual content.

headline: Fidelity Shifts Management At 26 of Its Mutual Funds
abstract: In one of the largest management shifts in its history, Fidelity Investments, the country's largest mutual fund company, is reassigning 26 of its equity-portfolio managers in an effort to improve the performance of the funds.          The Boston-based company, which manages some $560 billion in assets and is a  unit of the FMR Corporation, announced the changes yesterday as part of a major  overhaul of how it handles investment responsibility for its domestic and international stock funds. In addition to shuffling managers at almost a third of its stock funds on April 1, Fidelity is dividing its funds into smaller groups and assigning each one a group leader.

headline: Bringing Advanced Medical Expertise to the World's Poorest Regions
abstract: The patient was getting the best care the local doctors could provide. But this case needed outside expertise, and a long-distance phone call was not an option.         There was a low-cost communications alternative, however, thanks to Satellife, a Boston-based nonprofit organization helping bring the information age to parts of Africa and Asia where up-to-date medical information can be scarce.

headline: In or Out of Presidency, Aristide Is Still the Issue
abstract: Rene Preval had not even been sworn in as Haiti's President before posters began appearing, urging his charismatic predecessor, Jean-Bertrand Aristide, to  return to office as soon as the Constitution permits. "Au revoir, President Titid," the banners said, using Mr. Aristide's nickname. "We'll meet again in 2001."         But the issue of most immediate interest to Haitians, especially Mr. Preval,  who took office on Wednesday, is what Mr. Aristide intends to do for the next five years. Will he retire to his comfortable suburban home with his new wife to think and write, as he has said, or will he end up as Haiti's co-president?

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;China's Move On News Flow Worries U.S.
abstract: Two weeks after China announced a broad plan to restrict the flow of news and economic information into China, the Clinton Administration said today that it would raise the subject in trade talks next week, the first indication that China's efforts to control Western news operations may soon become a new source of friction between the two countries.         "This is, of course, an issue of free speech and censorship, but it is also at the heart of our trade relationship," said Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative. "We don't know how China plans to implement its restrictions, but clearly it is a step in the wrong direction."

headline: In Heavy Smoking, Grim Portent for China
abstract: Rushing down a Beijing alleyway where a north wind was kicking up dust among  the vegetable stands and cigarette vendors, Huang Jinhui, 25, paused to explain  to a stranger why he smokes.         "Man must smoke," said Mr. Huang, a young barber from Sichuan Province in central China.

headline: Dow Finishes Down 31.07; Nasdaq Climbs to a High
abstract: Blue-chip stocks fell yesterday, tracking significant weakness in the bond market.         The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 31.07 points, to 5,373.99, marking its first falloff in six sessions. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 2.61 points, to 635.85. In contrast, the technology-laden Nasdaq composite index advanced 2.65 points, to a high of 1,072.11, surpassing its previous record of 1,069.79, set on Dec. 4.

headline: Market Place;USAir investors prove to be optimistic about new leadership.
abstract: THE day after USAir Group named Stephen M. Wolf, the former chief executive of the UAL Corporation, as its new chairman, USAir's share price rose $1.875, to $14.50, in trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The news of Mr. Wolf's appointment even lifted the American depository receipts of British Airways, which owns a 24.6 percent stake in USAir, to a new high of $78.375, an  increase for the day of 87.5 cents.         Investors are clearly optimistic that they will see some quick changes at USAir, which has struggled for years through heavy losses, partly because of its high cost structure.

headline: Bosnian Serbs Said to Detain Muslim Men
abstract: Bosnian Serb officials said today that they had detained several Muslim men who had wandered into areas under their control.         In a separate incident, a sniper believed to be a Bosnian Serb fired on a bus on the first day of service outside Sarajevo since the war began, wounding two people.

headline: OUTLOOK '96: THE ECONOMY: Middle Age Catches Up With the MeGeneration; Meeting Challenges In the Insurance Business
abstract: After several years of slow growth, life insurers are still counting on the aging of America as their ace in the hole. But before life insurers can cash in  on the baby boomers' increasing need for retirement and savings investments, they face some tall challenges: some from outside their industry and others of their own making.         "The banks are coming, and they want to eat our lunch," said Thomas B. Wheeler, the chairman of the Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company. Insurers and life insurance sales agents have been losing ground in their battle to keep bankers out of their business, and he said he expected to see many more  large banks in his business.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Saatchi & Saatchi Names No. 2 Official
abstract: John Fitzgerald, a top executive at McCann-Erickson Worldwide and other agencies, has been hired by Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide in New York  as president and chief operating officer, the No. 2 position behind Edward L. Wax, chairman and chief executive.         Mr. Fitzgerald, 48, headed the New York and North American operations of McCann-Erickson before becoming president and chief executive of McCann-Erickson Japan in Tokyo in 1994. Though he was to have been promoted as of today to chairman and chief executive, he said the opportunity to take "a broad-based global job" at Saatchi & Saatchi proved more attractive.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;G.M. Reports Surging Profits, Partly Because Of Tax Gains
abstract: The General Motors Corporation's core business suffered several reversals late last year, but nimble work by the company's tax accountants sent its net income soaring in the fourth quarter.         G.M., the nation's biggest auto maker, reported today that strong sales of lower-profit small cars, shortages of higher-profit trucks and foreign currency  losses combined to reduce its pretax profit for its automotive operations by 42  percent in the last quarter. But the conclusion of several tax disputes, some of which dated to 1982, allowed G.M. to post a gain of nearly 19 percent in net income to about $1.87 billion in the fourth quarter, or $1.98 a share. Revenue rose 3.2 percent to $43.93 billion.

headline: China Hints at a Timetable To Take Control of Taiwan
abstract: China took the first step today toward setting a timetable for the unification of Taiwan with the Chinese mainland, saying that after the return of Hong Kong and Macao to Chinese rule in 1997 and 1999 respectively, unification with Taiwan will become a top priority.         China's assertion that there is a tentative schedule for unification raises the question of whether the Communist Party leadership has set a limit on its patience for establishing control over the island of 21 million people off its southeastern shore, and whether Beijing's leaders might at some point abandon their longstanding commitment to "peaceful reunification" in favor of a more forceful approach.

headline: In AT&T's Attic, $1 Billion of Flops and Fumbles
abstract: The AT&T Corporation is coming to terms with its flops and fumbles, more than $1 billion worth of them.         Buried within the company's announcement on Tuesday that it plans to cut 40,000 people from its payroll, AT&T executives also made it clear they would be pruning or overhauling scores of ventures that sounded good a few years ago but  have been duds in the marketplace. These are among the ventures:

headline: Migrant Workers Take AIDS Risk Home to Niger
abstract: A life of hope, born of hardship, is beginning for Abdraymane Goumar, 27, a peasant who set out the other day from a barren village for the long-dreamed-of  promise of a big city that lies three days away by tortuous bus ride.         Only two weeks ago he married a bride he says is still too young to bear him  children. But eager to get a jump on the tens of thousands of other migrant workers who will follow in his footsteps before summer, Mr. Goumar is leaving his family behind in a landscape of parched fields and rivers run dry for the promise of Abidjan, the economic capital of Ivory Coast, 700 miles to the south.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;URS ACQUISITION OF GREINER IS PUT AT $73.5 MILLION
abstract: The URS Corporation said yesterday that it had signed a definitive agreement  to acquire Greiner Engineering Inc. for $73.5 million in cash and stock. The deal creates one of the nation's five largest transportation engineering concerns. Under the deal, URS will pay $13.50 cash and 0.298 share of URS stock  for each of Greiner's 4.7 million shares outstanding. URS, which is based in San Francisco, and Greiner disclosed the plan for the acquisition last month. URS offers a range of services in infrastructure and environmental projects. Greiner, which is based in Irving, Tex., provides engineering, planning, architectural, environmental and program management services. The shares of URS  closed at $7 yesterday, down 12.5 cents, and Greiner stock closed at $14.625, up 75 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Compaq Rank Again No. 1 In PC Sales
abstract: The Compaq Computer Corporation retained its top ranking as the world's leading marketer of personal computers last year, but I.B.M. edged past troubled Apple Computer for the No. 2 position.         The year-end tallies, reported yesterday by Dataquest, a computer market research firm in San Jose, Calif., showed that worldwide personal computer sales grew nearly 25 percent, to 59.7 million.
