In the United States, PC sales rose 21 percent, to 22.5 million.

headline: Prices of Treasuries Retreat for a Fourth Day
abstract: Prices of Treasury securities fell yesterday for the fourth time this week as concerns grew over the faster pace of economic growth.         Strong gains in reports on industrial production, capacity utilization and in the University of Michigan's consumer sentiment index caused selling that raised bond yields to their highest level in six months. The data appeared to bury any  remaining hopes of a quick interest-rate cut by the Federal Reserve.

headline: Rite Aid Hits Snag In Its Bid for Revco
abstract: The Rite Aid Corporation is having problems obtaining approval from the Federal Trade Commission for its $1.8 billion bid to buy Revco D.S. Inc.         Rite Aid voluntarily agreed today with the F.T.C. to extend the waiting period under the Hart-Scott-Rodino Antitrust Act for its proposed Revco purchase. The agency is considering whether the merger of the largest and second-largest United States drugstore chains would hurt competition and raise consumer prices.

headline: Naruto Journal;This Way to Peace of Mind: 750 Miles and 88 Stops
abstract: After 27 years working for a computer company in Tokyo, Michihiro Sakamoto found himself a victim of the quiet corporate cost-cutting that has been hitting Japan's older white-collar workers in this recession. At 52, he was induced to quit his job.         So Mr. Sakamoto took a hike. Wearing white pants and jacket and a straw hat,  and carrying a walking stick with a bell attached, Mr. Sakamoto spent 32 days trudging a 750-mile course around Shikoku, the smallest of Japan's four main islands, stopping and praying at 88 Buddhist temples along the way.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;Higher Results Are Reported By Microsoft
abstract: The Microsoft Corporation reported today that its earnings rose 54 percent in its fiscal second quarter. The results exceeded Wall Street estimates and set the stage for a continued rally in the technology stocks.         Microsoft reported its results after the close of the market. In Nasdaq trading, Microsoft shares had closed at $87.625, up $2.75, on a strong day for technology shares after the International Business Machines Corporation reported positive results.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;MICRON ELECTRONICS TO CLOSE PC PLANT IN MINNEAPOLIS
abstract: Micron Electronics Inc. said yesterday that it would close its personal computer plant in Minneapolis and take a $30 million charge. The move, which will eliminate about 300 jobs, will result in a loss in the second quarter, ending this month, the company said. The plant was originally owned by Zeos International Inc., which merged last year with two units of Micron Technology Inc. of Boise, Idaho. Shares of Micron Technology, which owns about 80 percent of Micron Electronics, fell $3.125 yesterday, to $33.625, on the New York Stock  Exchange. Shares of Micron Electronics fell $1.875, to $11, in Nasdaq trading. Micron Technology said on Monday that it would not install equipment at a new chip plant in Utah until demand improved.

headline: OUTLOOK '96: TECHNOLOGY AND MEDIA;Telecommuting Options Are Gaining Sophistication
abstract: TWICE a week, Ralph Silvestro skips the two-and-a-half-hour train ride from his home in Martinsburg, W. Va., to his office at the General Services Administration in downtown Washington.         Instead, he drives for about half an hour over rural roads to a building in Hagerstown, Md., about 50 miles northwest of the capital, where he and other Government workers do their jobs without the burden of a long trip fighting traffic. "With the office in Hagerstown, I can be home by 5 P.M.," Mr. Silvestro said. "It's nice to be able to go out to an early dinner now and then."

headline: COMPANY NEWS;ALBANK FINANCIAL REJECTION OF BID LIFTS STOCK
abstract: The shares of the Albank Financial Corporation rose yesterday after the company rejected an offer from the Trustco Bank Corporation. The takeover bid, which could have been worth more than $467 million, was made on March 8. Trustco announced the offer late on Thursday. Albank's stock closed up $1.875, to $26.875, in Nasdaq trading after reaching $28.875, a new 52-week high. "The net  bottom line is Albank is not for sale, and if Albank were for sale it would not be to Trustco," said Herbert Chorbajian, chairman of the Albany-based banking company. Trustco, based in Schenedctady, has 47 branches, all in the Albany area. Albank, with nearly $3.5 billion in assets, has 47 branches in New  York, 9 in Massachusetts and 7 in Vermont.

headline: London Journal;To Be Popular in Britain, It Helps to Be Dead
abstract: Death, or at least a nostalgia for the dead, seems to be enjoying a renaissance in Britain these days. Or maybe it's just undergoing a commercial vogue.         Wherever you look, it seems that dead people are back in the news, singing songs, selling products, attracting admirers and even -- in one macabre case --  turning up alive.

headline: Afrikaners Try to Stand in the Schoolhouse Door
abstract: Surrounded by television cameras and reporters, Meiki Kekana wasn't trying to hide her sense of triumph today as she walked her 7-year-old son through the doors of the all-white public elementary school here and enrolled him for classes.         The school's reception area, with its lace curtains and trophy cases, was filled with other black parents doing the same thing. And senior Government officials were on hand to make sure the white principal came out of his office to personally process the paperwork.

headline: Yeltsin Ends Visit to Norway With Accords on Pollution
abstract: President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia ended a two-day visit to Norway today after meeting with King Haakon and the Prime Minister. Both sides reported some  progress on trade and environmental cooperation.         Mr. Yeltsin used the occasion to pledge more than $200 million toward environmental cooperation that Norway has sought for several years. But in many ways the visit seemed like a red-carpeted campaign stop in Mr. Yeltsin's re-election drive against the Communist candidate, Gennadi A. Zyuganov, and he took several opportunities to campaign.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS;Little Change In Bond Prices
abstract: Treasury prices ended little changed yesterday, paring back earlier gains made after a Government report showed no mounting price pressures in the economy.         The price of the 30-year bond settled down 3/32, to 916/32, leaving its yield unchanged at 6.68 percent.

headline: Israelis' Crackdown And Support by U.S.
abstract: Israel mounted its war on terrorism, sending troops on a punitive raid to a West Bank refugee camp, home to two attackers who struck last week.         The idea behind the crackdown was to make potential attackers realize that their friends and families will pay a price.

headline: German Merger for Grace's Dialysis Unit
abstract: W. R. Grace & Company said yesterday that it had agreed to spin off National  Medical Care, its nationwide chain of kidney-dialysis centers, into a new company that would be controlled by Fresenius A.G., a big German medical-technology company.

headline: Netscape Bumps Yahoo! Internet Directory
abstract: The Netscape Communications Corporation has replaced the popular Yahoo! Internet directory in prominent positions on computer screens with two competing companies who paid for the top spots.         Architext Software's Excite and a product from the Infoseek Corporation now occupy the locations that customers see first when they use Netscape's software. Netscape's Navigator is used by an estimated 15 million people to browse through the global computer network.

headline: One Company Seen Settling Tobbaco Suit
abstract: Liggett & Myers, the nation's sixth-largest tobacco company, and lawyers representing smokers are expected to announce a proposed settlement today in the largest class-action lawsuit against the tobacco industry.         The settlement could drop Liggett from the suit and lead to a nationwide industry-financed smoking-cessation program. It could also put particular pressure on RJR Nabisco Holdings.

headline: With Layoffs Coming, Ontario Workers Strike Over Security
abstract: A cold wind battered Sheila Steaman's thickly bundled frame as she and a score of co-workers paced endlessly around the plaza in front of an Ontario government office building on Bay Street.          "Hands Off Our Pensions," said the sign that twisted in the wind from a string around her neck.

headline: Hispaniola's 'Sugar-Cane Curtain' Is Starting to Come Down
abstract: With a new President in office in Port-au-Prince and another scheduled to be  installed here this summer, Haiti and the Dominican Republic are suddenly moving to end decades of mutual hostility and suspicion that have helped make the Caribbean island they share a perennial tinderbox.         "The sugar-cane curtain is finally coming down," one diplomat here remarked after Haiti's new President, Rene Preval, paid a visit here this month. Barely on speaking terms before the trip, Haiti and the Dominican Republic agreed after two days of meetings to "open a new era in relations" by establishing a joint commission to resolve their many longstanding disputes.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;McDonald's Deal in Italy
abstract: The Cremonini Group of Italy said yesterday that it intended to sell its chain of 80 Burghy fast-food restaurants to the McDonald's Corporation. No terms were disclosed. The 80 restaurants will be converted to the McDonald's brand name, more than tripling the chain's presence in Italy. As part of the deal, the IN.AL.CA. unit of Cremonini will become a meat supplier to McDonald's in Italy,  Cremonini said.   (AP)

headline: Economic Scene;A study shows bias against the ugly. Should they have recourse?
abstract: IS prejudice in hiring ever justified? Most Americans agree that discrimination on racial, sexual or religious grounds is wrong. But what about against people who just happen to be ugly?         That is the issue that Jeff Biddle and Daniel Hamermesh, economists at Michigan State and the University of Texas, respectively, have investigated. They assay the roots of discrimination against unattractive people, an ill-defined group whose legal claim to protection against discrimination is now  being tested in the courts. And while their study -- just published by the National Bureau of Economic Research -- probably won't change many minds, it does air the awkward issue of whether employers should shoulder the economic and legal burden of fighting the prejudices of their customers and the community as  a whole.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;British Telecom Profit
abstract: British Telecommunications P.L.C. said yesterday that its third-quarter pretax profit rose 26 percent, mainly because it spent less on staff cuts. Pretax profits rose to L829 million, or $1.3 billion, in the period ended Dec. 31, from L660 million a year earlier. Without the decline in staff-reduction costs, the company said, its operating profit would have been "broadly at the same level" as a year ago. Lower prices for phone calls and the costs of signing up new mobile phone customers ate into earnings.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: World News Briefs;Drug Operation Seized By 1,500 Burmese Troops
abstract: About 1,500 Burmese troops have taken over the jungle headquarters of the leader of a drug operation in the opium-growing Golden Triangle, but the whereabouts of the man are not clear, civilian sources in town said today.         Civilians in the jungle stronghold of Ho Mong in eastern Myanmar, about 19 miles from the Thai border, said Burmese troops met no resistance when they entered the town on Monday morning.

headline: Bosnian Serbs Said to Hold Forced Laborers
abstract: Hundreds of people are being forced into what amounts to slave labor in dozens of towns and villages in Serb-held areas of Bosnia, according to the International Committee of the Red Cross.         Red Cross officials say that they have found about 700 of the people, but that the number does not account for all forced labor units, nor does it include workers who have been freed since the Red Cross discovered them.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;ADVANCED POLYMER TO BUYS DOW'S POLYTRAP TECHNOLOGY
abstract: Advanced Polymer Systems Inc. said yesterday that it would acquire the full rights to the Dow Corning Corporation's Polytrap technology, which is used in personal care products like deodorants and razor blades. The company also bought the rights to sell all products using Polymeric Transport Systems, a technology  based on Polytrap and Advanced Polymer's Microsponge systems. Advanced Polymer,  a personal care products company based in Redwood City, Calif., paid an undisclosed amount of common stock to acquire the rights. Polymeric Transport Systems are used to release ingredients in response to stimulants, including rubbing and changes in temperature. The companies had previously shared the rights to market the systems, which are used in deodorants, lipsticks and other  cosmetics. Shares of Advanced Polymer rose 37.5 cents, to $6.875, in Nasdaq trading.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Consumer Marketers Announce Switches
abstract: Three consumer marketers have changed agencies on their accounts.         Nora Beverages U.S.A. in Stamford, Conn., has named Avrett, Free & Ginsberg in New York to handle its Naya brand of spring water, with billings estimated at more than $4 million.

headline: Tandem Computers Names Chief Executive
abstract: Tandem Computers Inc. named Roel Pieper yesterday as its president and chief  executive as part of an effort to find a new focus in a computer market that is  increasingly based on commodity software and hardware.         Mr. Pieper replaces James G. Treybig, who founded Tandem 21 years ago. Mr. Treybig will remain on the company's board.

headline: Fed Watchers See a Shave for Rates
abstract: To most economists looking at signs of a slowing economy and well-subdued inflation, the question on interest rates boils down to this: Why not cut?         And while many economists expect just that, nothing is ever simple with the Federal Reserve. The Fed approaches a meeting of its top interest-rate committee next week against a backdrop of several unusual factors. There's the budget impasse, and the disruption in economic statistics caused by the Government shutdown. Just ahead lie some key decisions on the Fed leadership: While President Clinton is widely expected to reappoint its chairman, Alan Greenspan, to a third four-year term, there are two vacancies on the seven-member governing board. And even the Fed is aware that this an election year.

headline: World News Briefs;Mubarak Names Premier In Major Cabinet Shuffle
abstract: President Hosni Mubarak replaced a Prime Minister today for the first time in nine years after parliamentary elections that opposition leaders denounced as fraudulent.         Mr. Mubarak asked Kamal el-Ganzoury, an economist, to form a new Government to replace that of Afef Sedki, who had served longer than any Prime Minister in  modern Egyptian history.

headline: Mutual Fund Industry's Fast Growth May Be Past
abstract: Investors on Main Street love mutual funds, but the smart money on Wall Street has sent a strong signal that the brightest days of the rapidly growing mutual fund industry may be past.         Federated Investors, the nation's 10th- largest mutual fund company, yesterday canceled a planned initial public offering in which it hoped to raise  more than $20 million to expand its money-management business.

headline: Britain Defends Beef As Europe Asks Ban
abstract: The European Union moved yesterday to ban British beef as unsafe, while the British Government stepped back from earlier warnings and said no further steps  were needed to protect consumers from so-called mad cow disease.         The latest developments in the worldwide consumer scare were certain to strain Europe's effort to achieve greater unity.

headline: Heavy Floods Can't Cure Southern Africa Drought
abstract: This has been a summer of storms in South Africa. In December, 150 people died in flooding along the Umsindusi River. On Thursday, nearly 16 inches of rain fell in an hour in Johannesburg, and as the storm rushed east, 40 people were killed when cars were washed away and pedestrians foolishly braved swollen  rivers and submerged roads. Near the northern border, a herd of cattle was said to have been swept away.         But what is dismal news for those who lost family members, homes, livestock or crops is cause for celebration across much of southern Africa. This has turned out to be the summer that broke southern Africa's long drought.

headline: Equity and Convertible Debt Offerings Scheduled for This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:         ABR Information Services Inc., Palm Harbor, Fla., 3.1 million shares. Montgomery Securities.

headline: Rig Count Up to 707
abstract: The number of oil and gas rigs operating in the United States jumped by 12 this week, to 707, Baker Hughes Inc. said today. There were 724 rigs operating nationwide a year ago. Of the rigs running this week, 417 were exploring for natural gas and 285 for oil. Five rigs were listed as miscellaneous. The rig count represents the number of rigs actively exploring for oil or natural gas.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Agency Switch For Keds Account
abstract: The Stride Rite Corporation has unexpectedly ended its relationship with Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners in New York on the account of its Keds brand of casual footwear after almost two years. The account was shifted without a review to Toth Design and Advertising in Concord, Mass., which handles promotions for Keds and advertising for Stride Rite children's shoes.          "We decided it was time to make a change," Barbara Scott, a spokeswoman for  Keds in Lexington, Mass., said yesterday, as part of the company's re-evalution  of its entire strategy. A recent slump in sales of Keds has hurt financial results at Stride Rite. Jonathan Bond, co-chairman at Kirshenbaum Bond, estimated that billings on Keds had declined to between $3 million and $4 million, compared with $20 million when the agency landed the account in April 1994.

headline: INVESTING IT;Tenneco's Big Shipyard May Soon Sail Off Solo
abstract: WHAT'S a good used shipyard worth?         That question is much on the minds of the shareholders of Tenneco Inc., one of the last big industrial conglomerates. Tenneco, which has interests ranging from gas pipelines to auto parts to packaging materials, also owns the Newport News Shipbuilding yard in Virginia. The yard is huge -- the only place on earth capable of building a nuclear-powered aircraft carrier.

headline: Versailles Journal;Proud Castles Stripped, and France Is Scandalized
abstract: The women's prison of Versailles, just a short walk from the sprawling palace of Louis XIV, is a dour place for a Japanese heiress to be spending the winter.  But Kiko Nakahara is getting little sympathy in France.         In the small jailhouse along the Avenue of Europe, Mrs. Nakahara is awaiting  trial on charges of breach of trust and forgery. Her real offense, though, in the eyes of many French is far more serious: complete disrespect for this country's cultural and architectural heritage.

headline: A Family Album of Intrigue;Kansas City Tale of Inside Deals and Outside Investors
abstract: The volatile real estate markets of the 1980's produced plenty of tales of intrigue, many spiced with corruption, greedy executives and skewered investors. In the more stable 1990's, though, few stories have been more fascinating than that of the J. C. Nichols Company, a venerable Kansas City, Mo., developer that  was jolted last year by a bitter struggle between its top management and outside investors.         The investors were led by Allen & Company, the powerful New York investment firm best known as a key behind-the-scenes player in the deals reshaping the entertainment industry. They confronted longtime insiders who had been put in control by the still influential Nichols family but, according to Allen, had used their power to loot corporate assets -- most notably in a transaction in which the chairman grabbed two-thirds of the stock without paying a cent.

headline: Detroit-Beijing Flights
abstract: Northwest Airlines will begin offering nonstop flights to Beijing from Detroit on May 1, becoming the first United States carrier to provide such service, the company said today. Minneapolis-based Northwest will begin service  with three flights a week in each direction. Northwest can increase that service to nine flights by 1998 under a United States-China agreement.

headline: Tokyo's Lights Lure the Young To Forsake Rural Way of Life
abstract: Love was in the air, and Yoshihiko Tanaka talked sweetly to his beloved about marriage and the future and getting up at 3 each morning during the tea harvest  to work backbreaking 20-hour days.         The love suddenly dissipated, which is a nice way of saying that Mr. Tanaka's girlfriend dumped him.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;BENCKISER SEEKS APPROVAL TO BUY MAYBELLINE SHARES
abstract: An affiliate of Benckiser G.m.b.H. is seeking antitrust clearance to acquire  Maybelline Inc., even though the German company dropped out of a bidding contest for Maybelline earlier this week. Benckiser Cosmetics Holdings Inc. forwarded a  Jan. 23 notice to Maybelline saying that the estate of Albert Reimann, a Benckiser co-founder, had a "good faith intention" to acquire more than $15 million and more than 50 percent of Maybelline's common shares on the open market. Maybelline filed a copy of the notice with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday. Benckiser's action, however, may be more of a contingency  plan than an effort to pursue Maybelline, people familiar with the situation said. On Monday the company decided not to top a bid for Maybelline by L'Oreal S.A.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;SYQUEST TO CUT 60% OF WORK FORCE AND POST A LOSS
abstract: Syquest Technology Inc., a disk-drive maker, said yesterday that it would cut 60 percent of its work force, consolidate some Far East operations and assign some manufacturing to outside companies. The company also posted a loss of $33.8 million, or $2.98 a share, for the first quarter, which ended on Dec. 31. Syquest will cut 60 workers in the United States and 1,500 in the Far East from  its permanent full-time work force of 2,600. The company will also halt the expansion of its Malaysia plant.

headline: World News Briefs;Standoff as U.N. Team Is Barred From Iraqi Site
abstract: A United Nations arms inspection team was blocked today from entering a site  in Baghdad, provoking a standoff that continued through the night, United Nations officials said.         The confrontation followed an announcement by United Nations officials in Baghdad that they had found documents and parts of chemical or biological rockets at another site.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Along with talk about a merger with Sun are reports that Apple is pondering new  agency ties.
abstract: THE tumult surrounding Apple Computer Inc. is extending to the company's agency relationships.         Apple executives discussing whether to sell the company to Sun Microsystems Inc. are also focusing on Apple's advertising. According to agency executives who spoke late last week on the condition of anonymity, the Apple executives have begun talking to several shops about working for Apple in some capacity.

headline: Sprint Names a President And Its Wireless Venture
abstract: The Sprint Corporation announced today that Ronald T. LeMay had been named president and chief operating officer.         Mr. LeMay, an 11-year Sprint employee, has been serving as chief executive officer of Sprint's wireless telecommunications venture with several cable television partners. He will retain that post until a replacement is named, Sprint said.

headline: Ex-Warner Music Chief Forms Venture
abstract: The former chairman of Warner Music Group, Robert J. Morgado, has formed a company that hopes to raise $200 million to $300 million to invest in music and  entertainment ventures overseas, according to Richard Esposito, a partner in the venture.         Mr. Morgado was dismissed in May after a long career at Warner Music, a unit  of Time Warner Inc. He is being joined in the new venture by Oded Aboodi, a former senior consultant for Time Warner.

headline: In Hong Kong, a Sudden Demand for Putonghua Lessons
abstract: HONG KONG—  That Hong Kong's leaders and their future overlords in China have trouble communicating is hardly in doubt. The two sides think and function differently in areas ranging from finance to the arts to social control.

headline: Rwanda Atrocity Inquiries Focus on Former Officer
abstract: Out of the blur of politically or ethnically motivated death squads that carried out genocidal massacres in Rwanda in 1994, one suspected mastermind is now appearing on the wanted lists of several countries, the Rwanda war crimes tribunal and a United Nations commission on illegal arms trafficking.         The man is Theoneste Bagosora, a former army colonel accused not only of playing a central role in attacks that killed more than half a million Tutsi and moderate Hutu but also of trying to re-arm an exile resistance to the Tutsi-led  force that became the present Rwanda Government.

headline: Bombing Suspects' Neighbors Fearful
abstract: A pall of unease fell over this refugee camp near Hebron today, the home of two Palestinians suspected of being the suicide bombers who killed 25 people in  two attacks in Israel on Sunday.         Ibrahim Sarahne, 26, and Majdi Abu Warda, 19, two local men who have been missing for several days, were identified today by Palestinian security officials as the attackers.

headline: INVESTING IT;Israeli Stocks Hang On Despite Bomb Attacks
abstract: BOMBS scarcely seem to scare stock markets anymore. Investors appear to calmly go about their business as long as they remain confident that a country's economy will remain strong.         That was certainly the lesson from Dublin, which shrugged off the renewed Irish Republican Army bombing in London last month. The Israeli stock market was not quite so blase about the four Hamas bombings that killed 61 people in the last two weeks, but there was no panicked sell-off as some had feared.

headline: Stocks Drop in Japan
abstract: Japanese stock prices fell today, with the Nikkei index of 225 issues closing down 215.57 points, or 1 percent, at 19,734.70. On Tuesday, the Nikkei rose 153.98 points.

headline: Britons Losing Taste for 'the Royals'
abstract: The letter to the editor in The Independent last Tuesday attacked the Prince  of Wales in no uncertain terms. It said the person "likely to be our next monarch" was a hypocrite: a man who "spoke his marriage vows before millions of  people and shortly afterwards committed adultery." A man who professes worry about the environment yet drives "a large gas guzzling motor car." And who "claims concern about wildlife while killing animals for sport."         The letter ended on a plaintive, almost poignant note: "How can anyone reasonably be expected to have respect for him and the institution he represents? The Prince of Wales has badly let down those like myself who would,  on balance, sooner have the monarchy than any of the alternatives likely to be on offer."

headline: OUTLOOK '96: MARKETS AND INVESTING;Many See Sparkle Dimming In I.P.O.'s
abstract: WATCHING the initial public offering market last year was enough to give anyone goose bumps.         While no records were set for the volume or the dollar amount of deals done in 1995, despite a torrent of offerings over the last few months, the performances of many new issues were nothing short of spectacular. The average deal gained 31 percent, according to the Securities Data Company, a research firm in Newark.

headline: Anguish of Rwanda Echoed in a Baby's Cry
abstract: Exhausted from hours of labor in a hospital tent at the center of the sprawling refugee camp, Jacqueline Nyiranza held her first baby, a scrawny and wrinkled infant, close to her breast. The baby, born prematurely, was weak, and  she held it as if it were the most fragile thing imaginable, as if it were the only hope she had to rebuild a life shattered by war and flight.         "I was living alone and I didn't have any help, so I got married," whispered  Mrs. Nyiranza, 23, a Hutu refugee from northwestern Rwanda, who said her parents and siblings were killed in the civil war there. "I chose to have the baby rather than go into family planning, because so many people were killed. My husband wanted to have it also to replace the family members who died."

headline: Market Place;Mutual fund investors primarily took world tours last month.
abstract: USING the investment vehicle that served them so well in the United States stock market last year -- mutual funds -- individual investors turned their attentions overseas last month, putting a record amount of money into funds that invest both here and abroad and pushing foreign markets up sharply in the process.         The broad American market, as measured by the Standard & Poor's Corporation index of 500 stocks, is up 5.5 percent this year, and yesterday the Dow Jones industrial average rose 32.51 points, to 5,492.14, its eighth record high in nine sessions. But other markets around the globe have recorded similar -- or better -- gains.

headline: Stock Move by Alumax
abstract: Alumax Inc. took action today to prop up its stock price one day after the Kaiser Aluminum Corporation withdrew a takeover bid valued at up to $2.5 billion. Saying that its outlook was strong, Alumax canceled a shelf registration for an offering of up to 9.2 million shares of common stock. "In light of current business conditions and our strong projected cash flows, the company does not need to sell additional equity at this time and there are no plans to renew the proposed offering," the chief executive, Allen Born, said. Wall Street analysts said the action was an attempt to limit an expected tumble  in the stock price on Monday.

headline: Casino Bid Withdrawn
abstract: The Casino Resource Corporation has withdrawn its $12 million bid to acquire  the Palace Casino here, citing unacceptable financing terms. In November, a bankruptcy court in Mississippi approved Casino Resource's purchase of the Palace Casino from Maritime Group Ltd., a unit of Palace Casinos Inc. The casino has been operating under bankruptcy protection since December 1994.

headline: Arthritis Drug Approval
abstract: The Elan Corporation, the Irish drug company, said today that it had received approval from the United States Food and Drug Administration to sell a once-a-day formulation of the arthritis drug Naprelan. The drug will be marketed in conjunction with Wyeth-Ayerst Laboratories, a division of the American Home Products Corporation, Elan said. On the New York Stock Exchange, American depository receipts of Elan rose $1.875, to $50.625, while shares of American Home rose $1.75, to $97.125.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: FLEXTRONICS INTERNATIONAL LTD., San Jose, Calif., a maker of electronic components, purchased Astron Group Inc. for $35 million in cash, stock and promissory notes.

headline: Oil Spill Threatens the Coast of Southwest Britain
abstract: The coast guard declared a full environmental alert today to prevent an environmental disaster after a fully laden oil tanker ran aground off the southwest coast, spilling almost 50,000 barrels of crude oil into the sea, officials said.         Some oil is expected to come ashore, the officials added, but the 28 Russian  crew members on the tanker, the Sea Empress, appeared not to be in danger.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
abstract: Auto Palace, Avon, Mass., an auto parts chain, to Haggman Inc., Magnolia, Mass., to handle its account, previously at Cuneo Sullivan Dolabany, Boston. The billings were estimated at $1 million to $3 million.

headline: Dow Loses 43.71 in Flurry Fueled by Program Trading
abstract: A flurry of computer-guided sell orders caused the Dow Jones industrial average to fall sharply in the final half-hour of trading yesterday, the last session of the first quarter. Other market indicators were mixed.         "We had a wild day," said Ricky Harrington, senior vice president of Interstate/Johnson Lane in Charlotte, N.C. "Along with the sell programs, there was some end-of-the-quarter window-dressing by mutual funds."

headline: COMPANY NEWS;LOUISIANA-PACIFIC NAMES NEW CHIEF EXECUTIVE
abstract: The Louisiana-Pacific Corporation named Mark A. Suwyn, an executive at the International Paper Company, as its chairman and chief executive officer yesterday. Mr. Suwyn, 53, will replace Donald R. Kayser, a member of the wood products company's board of directors who has been serving as interim chairman and chief executive since the resignation of Harry Merlo on July 31. Mr. Merlo was forced out by the board while the company, which is based in Portland, Ore., was facing class-action lawsuits over faulty house siding, shareholder lawsuits, regulatory problems, a federal criminal investigation involving emissions at a Colorado plant, and a sexual harassment lawsuit against Merlo by  a former executive secretary. Mr. Suwyn had been executive vice president at International Paper since 1992. He previously worked at E.I. du Pont de Nemours  & Co. from 1967 to 1992.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: First Fidelity Securities Settles Kickback Charges First Fidelity Securities of Newark agreed to pay $2.3 million to settle charges by the S.E.C. that it paid secret kickbacks to a former New Jersey county official to get lucrative bond underwriting business. The firm neither admitted  nor denied any wrongdoing. The action is the first S.E.C. case brought against a broker-dealer firm rather than individuals for such payoffs.

headline: World News Briefs;New Polish Premier Replaces Accused Spy
abstract: A new Prime Minister of Poland and his Cabinet were sworn in today, replacing a Government toppled by allegations that the former Prime Minister passed state  secrets to Moscow.         Prime Minister Wlodzimierz Cimoszewicz and his 20 ministers formed Poland's seventh Government since Communism fell in 1989.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Stock Market Weakens, Particularly in Technology The stock market weakened, particularly in technology issues, in sluggish holiday trading, as investors worried about earnings shortfalls and Washington's continued failure to reach a budget agreement. Intel, the most actively traded stock, fell 3 1/4, to 53 3/8, as traders awaited today's earnings report.

headline: Merchant Banking Venture Is Formed
abstract: The Mitsubishi Corporation, the Japanese trading company, and Ripplewood Holdings L.L.C., a leveraged-acquisition business and equity fund manager, are forming a new merchant banking venture.         The objective of the venture, the Ripplewood Equity Fund, is to acquire smaller American companies with strong growth potential.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS;Mixed Data On Economy Cloud Bonds
abstract: Prices of Treasury securities were mixed yesterday, as the bond market wrestled with conflicting economic signals and changing perceptions on the economy's outlook. Many traders and investors believe the Federal Reserve still  intends to cut interest rates, with the timing uncertain.         The 30-year bond rose 13/32, to a price of 95 19/32 for a yield of 6.33 percent, down from 6.36 percent on Friday. Some analysts said that after the recent selloff in bonds, it appeared that much of the bad news the market anticipated -- real or imagined -- might be behind it.

headline: Market Place
abstract: IT took more than three months for executives at Lockheed Martin and Loral to work out their deal to merge most of Loral into Lockheed while spinning off Loral's space and communications business to shareholders. Then they waited more than two weeks to announce it. Late during that period, it appears that some options traders got word of what was going on.         Leaks in advance of takeover offers are far from unusual, but this one seemed to have spurred a lot of trading by speculators who, by last Friday, were paying ridiculously high prices for options that would expire this week. Ridiculously high, that is, unless the buyer had good reason to think that Loral's stock price would soar quickly, as it did yesterday.

headline: G.M.'s Chief Sets a Target For Asia Sales
abstract: The head of General Motors said today that his company would try to capture 10 percent of the Asian car and truck market by 2005, an indication that American auto makers are increasingly focused on that fast-growing market.         John F. Smith Jr., the chairman and chief executive of the General Motors Corporation, said that his company held 4.6 percent of the market and would try  to more than double that figure within 10 years, with a focus on East Asia.

headline: Low Turnout in Zimbabwe
abstract: Voter turnout was low on the first day of Zimbabwe's one-man presidential election today despite efforts by President Robert Mugabe and his party to bring voters out. Mr. Mugabe, 72, is the sole candidate in the election today and Sunday, following the withdrawal of his two challengers. Even before Ndabaningi  Sithole and Bishop Abel Muzorewa dropped out, many Zimbabweans saw the election as a mere formality for confirming Mr. Mugabe in power.          Some officials put turnout at 10 percent in the first six hours of voting.

headline: 50,000 to Be Moved For Vietnam Dam
abstract: Vietnam has announced plans to move at least 50,000 people from a remote northern province to make way for a big hydroelectric power project.         Rapid economic growth in Vietnam has increased the demand for power and worsened power shortages.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;WARNER AND MAI PLAN THEME PARK AND STUDIO COMPLEX
abstract: Warner Brothers and MAI P.L.C. will announce today a plan to build a theme park and studio complex near London, The Financial Times reported today. Warner, a subsidiary of Time Warner, will invest L225 million, or $338 million, in the park, Warner Brothers Movie World, and will include studio tours, the newspaper  reported. Officials of both companies could not be reached for comment. The park, in Hillingdon, about 16 miles west of London, would be Warner Brothers' second in Europe. The unit plans to open a $270 million Warner Brother Movie World near Bottrop, Germany, this spring. MAI, which operates regional television services in Britain and owns financial companies, agreed last week to merge with United News and Media, publishers of The Daily Express and The Sunday Express in Britain, for $4.5 billion.

headline: G.M. Considers Executive to Manage Learning
abstract: Seeking to better harness the knowledge of its employees worldwide, the General Motors Corporation will likely appoint a senior-level chief learning officer to coordinate the spread of information around the company's vast holdings, a executive said in a speech late Sunday.         Harry J. Pearce, vice chairman and an executive vice president of the giant auto maker, also said that General Motors might add a foreign-born director to its board in an attempt to gain perspective on world markets. "We have been looking worldwide for appropriate candidates for the past year," Mr. Pearce said at a meeting of the America-Israel Chamber of Commerce of Michigan in Troy.

headline: SPENDING IT;What's the Buzz? G.M.'s Electric Car Is Headed to Showrooms
abstract: ELECTRIC cars produced by a brand-name auto company, complete with warranty and dealer service, are just a few months away. But the EV1, the two-seater from the General Motors Corporation, will cost roughly $35,000, almost as much as a Corvette and a little more than two Saturns. At that price, who is going to want one?         Probably not someone who is comparing it to the Corvette or the Saturns, according to G.M.'s Saturn division, which will sell them. There is no car to compare it to, contended John J. Orth, director of consumer marketing at Saturn. "It's just a totally new category," he said.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;CARNIVAL OFFERS STOCK AND CASH FOR AIRTOURS
abstract: The Carnival Corporation said yesterday that it would acquire a stake in the  British tour operator Airtours P.L.C. in a stock-and-cash deal valued at about $310 million. The deal would give Carnival, a leading cruise-ship operator based in Miami, a 29.6 percent stake in Airtours, skirting British requirements that if a company makes an offer for 30 percent or more of a company, it must make a  public offer for the entire company. Carnival said it had agreed to buy 20 million new Airtours shares for about $155 million and bid for another 20 million existing shares in return for Carnival shares or for about $155 million  more in cash. Airtours is Britain's No. 2 tour operator.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;British Gas Plans To Split Into 2 Units
abstract: British Gas P.L.C. said yesterday that it would split into two companies, separating its financially troubled trading business from its profitable exploration and pipeline operations. The company also said its chief executive,  Cedric H. Brown, would step down in April.          The problems at the trading unit have been a drag on the company's share price. Fixed-price natural gas contracts negotiated by the trading division have forced the unit to pay much more than the going rate and could leave the parent company with losses of up to L1.5 billion, or $2.31 billion. The exploration and pipeline business will be renamed Transco International.   (AP)

headline: Ryder Says Strike Will Hurt
abstract: Ryder System Inc. says that it expects first-quarter earnings to fall short of Wall Street estimates, primarily because of the strike at the General Motors  Corporation, its largest customer.         Ryder, a provider of logistics and transportation services, said on Friday that the strike against G.M. by the United Automobile Workers union, which was settled on Thursday, hurt its Ryder Automotive Carrier Group unit, which ships more than half of G.M.'s North American production.

headline: New Yorker Is Given Life Sentence in Peru
abstract: Lori Helene Berenson of New York was convicted of treason by a secret Peruvian military court and sentenced to life in prison for aiding a Marxist guerrilla group.         The verdict was announced six weeks after Ms. Berenson was arrested along with 22 other people after an all-night shootout with anti-terrorist police in Lima, the capital.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;HECHINGER SAYS LOSS WILL BE BIGGER THAN EXPECTED
abstract: The Hechinger Company said yesterday that its loss in the fourth quarter would be bigger than expected, because of winter storms, strong competition and  slow home sales. The company also said it would stop paying dividends on its common stock. Hechinger, a struggling operator of 118 home-improvement stores, said it would report a loss from operations of $30 million to $35 million, or 66 to 73 cents a share, in the fiscal fourth quarter. The projected loss is much higher than analysts' estimates. The company, which is based in Landover, Md., is also taking a pretax charge of $25 million, or 57 cents a share, in the quarter, which ended on Feb. 3, for employee severance packages and expenses related to combining certain management and administrative functions. The charge will lead to a final loss of as much as $1.30 a share, the company said.

headline: INVESTING WITH: Mary Lisanti;BT Investment Small Cap Fund
abstract: WITNESSING the stock market's gyrations over the last week, investors with weak stomachs may have wanted to run and hide. Not Mary Lisanti, who runs two mutual funds for Bankers Trust.         Taking advantage of volatility is her stock and trade. Ms. Lisanti doesn't hesitate to snap up stocks in a free fall if she thinks the rest of Wall Street is panicking. And she is an aggressive buyer of new stocks, infamous for  their wild rides. "If we pick our spots, we'll make really good money," she said.

headline: World News Briefs;Honored Mexican Agent Arrested With Drugs
abstract: An agent who was voted "Policeman of the Year" in a northern Mexican state has been arrested on suspicion of drug trafficking after being detained with 436 pounds of marijuana, the Televisa television network reported today.         It said Jose Armando Cruz Gutierrez was voted policeman of the year just two  months ago by colleagues in the Chihuahua state detective force who gave him a new car as a prize.

headline: A Battle Royal Looms on Divorce
abstract: A day after Diana, the Princess of Wales, said she had reluctantly agreed to  divorce her estranged husband, Prince Charles, it became increasingly clear that her ringing threat last year to "not go quietly" had been deadly serious.         With the drama of the divorce announcement still dominating discussions in the news and on the streets of London, Charles and Diana both dug in for what is likely to be a bitter campaign, fought as much in public as in the offices of their high-priced lawyers.

headline: Antitrust Review Is Seen On Thomson Deal for West
abstract: The Thomson Corporation's proposed $3.43 billion purchase of the West Publishing Company, a leading provider of legal research materials, is likely to be examined closely by Federal antitrust regulators, Government officials said today.         The deal, which was announced Monday, "is big enough, and there are enough markets where both firms have very significant shares, that it is likely to receive scrutiny," said one senior official, who spoke on condition of anonymity.

headline: Both Sides See Victory in Shareholder Vote on RJR Nabisco Spinoff
abstract: The squabble between the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation and the investors Bennett S. LeBow and Carl C. Icahn took a strange turn yesterday as the company  announced that it had won, by a narrow margin, a nonbinding shareholder vote on  the desirability of a rapid spinoff of the company's food business from its tobacco operations.         But the holding company for the two investors, Brooke Group Ltd., charged yesterday that the company could have no knowledge of the outcome. And an industry executive close to Brooke Group expressed optimism that Mr. LeBow and Mr. Icahn would win, in a very close vote by the company's estimated 450,000 shareholders.

headline: Stocks Rise in Japan
abstract: Stocks rose strongly here today. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 315.21 points, or 1.5 percent, at 21,329.98. On Tuesday, the Nikkei gained 99.33 points, or nearly a half-percent.

headline: Eva Hart, 91, a Last Survivor With Memory of Titanic, Dies
abstract: Eva Hart was 7 years old and bound for a new life in Canada when her father woke her in the middle of the night, carried her outside in a blanket and told her, "Hold Mummy's hand and be a good girl."         It was the last thing he ever said to her, and she never saw him again. Later that night, wide awake and clinging to her mother in a lifeboat, the little girl watched as the Titanic rose straight up on her bow and plunged to the bottom of  the sea, carrying her father and more than 1,500 other passengers and crew members to their deaths in the North Atlantic.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Eurotunnel Seeks British-French Aid
abstract: Eurotunnel, the British-French operator of the Channel tunnel linking the two countries, appealed yesterday for the French and British Governments to intervene to relieve its financial burden. Patrick Ponsolle, co-chairman of Eurotunnel, did not specify what form intervention should take. The appeal came  at a news conference at which the tunnel operator announced that its 1995 sales  would exceed expectations and that traffic on its passenger trains rose 21 percent in December.    (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: Toronto Journal;Down These Frigid Streets: Homeless in Canada
abstract: Warily, he walked into the Moss Park Armory of the Canadian Armed Forces in downtown Toronto, spotted a large cardboard box filled with pile and down jackets and tried one on for size. Other homeless men and women were doing the same.         His eyes sunk in dark pools on a furrowed face, his hands slightly shaking, he gave his name only as Matt and said he was 53, a former construction worker,  living on the street for the last three years.

headline: The New York Times Introduces a Web Site
abstract: The New York Times begins publishing daily on the World Wide Web today, offering readers around the world immediate access to most of the daily newspaper's contents.     The New York Times on the Web, as the electronic publication is known, contains most of the news and feature articles from the current day's printed newspaper, classified advertising, reporting that does not appear in the newspaper, and interactive features including the newspaper's crossword puzzle.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;General Electric Reports Increase in Earnings
abstract: Led by its NBC broadcasting network and its finance and plastics divisions, the General Electric Company yesterday reported stronger earnings for the fourth quarter.         Net income rose to $1.865 billion, or $1.12 a share, from $768 million, or 45 cents a share, in the 1994 quarter. Earnings then were held down by the sale of General Electric's Kidder, Peabody brokerage operations -- for which it took  a charge of $868 million -- and another smaller charge.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;DELUXE MOVES TO CLOSE 26 PLANTS AND TRIM 1,200 JOBS
abstract: The Deluxe Corporation said yesterday that it planned to close more than half its check-printing plants and to eliminate 1,200 jobs in the next two years. The company said it would record expenses of $30 million to $35 million in the first quarter to pay for the closings. Deluxe, which previously said it would close five plants, said yesterday that it would close 21 more, leaving 15 open. The company, based in St. Paul, estimated that the closings would affect 2,400 full-time and 600 part-time workers at the 26 plants. The company said, however, that it expected to add as many as 1,800 positions to the remaining plants by expanding the number of work shifts. The company said it expected more staff cuts in the next two years.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Listed below are the tentative release dates for major economic indicators this week. The reports were delayed by the partial shutdown of the Government.      Monday

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Disney Clears F.C.C. Review Of Its Merger
abstract: The Walt Disney Company's $19 billion acquisition of Capital Cities/ABC Inc.  cleared its final regulatory obstacle today, with conditions.         Disney said it would "move promptly" to complete the merger within the next two business days.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Swedish Rates Cut Again
abstract: Sweden's central bank delivered a widely expected interest-rate cut yesterday, its fifth such move this year. The bank said it would trim the repurchase rate, the bank's main instrument for steering money market and short-term interest rates, to 7.85 percent from 8.05 percent. Most economists see cuts continuing throughout the spring and summer.    (Reuters)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS ;U.S. to Withhold Sanctions In Tricontinental Banana Rift
abstract: The Clinton Administration will not immediately impose sanctions against Costa Rica and Colombia in a trade dispute involving bananas, officials said today.         The United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, announced that after a year of talks, Costa Rica and Colombia had signed agreements pledging to cooperate in trying to get the European Union to scrap trade barriers involving  bananas.

headline: Rabin Killer Acts as Lawyer After His Quits
abstract: Yitzhak Rabin's confessed assassin, Yigal Amir, cross-examined prosecution witnesses himself today after one of his lawyers resigned.         Often interrupting the police to correct their accounts of the shooting, Mr.  Amir, a 25-year-old former law student, took over defense questioning in a chaotic six-hour court session. His actions came after one of his lawyers resigned and the other stumbled badly over the Hebrew language, bringing laughter from the packed courtroom and a sigh from Judge Edmond Levy.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;20% of Italian Bank Up for Public Sale
abstract: The foundation controlling Instituto Bancario San Paolo di Torino S.p.A., Italy's largest bank, said yesterday that it planned to sell 20 percent of the company to the public to take advantage of tax breaks. At current market prices, 20 percent of San Paolo is worth about 1.6 trillion lire ($1 billion).          The San Paolo foundation plans to reduce its stake in the bank to 45 percent from 65 percent by the end of this year. The move comes in response to a 1994 law that encourages greater public ownership of banks through cuts in capital gains taxes.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: Wife Remembers a Spy With Love and Disbelief
abstract: Despite his Richard Gere looks, it was not love at first sight. A newcomer from Cuba with no job or familiarity with American ways, Juan Pablo Roque seemed too much of a burden to the young single mother of two children who had left Cuba 30 years earlier.         But Ana Roque, 35, said he was persistent and impressive. He did not mind her children tagging along on their dates. He had a master's degree in history and had been a major in the Cuban Air Force, yet he also knew how to fix a broken window.

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Niger's Military Rulers Set Election Timetable
abstract: Niger's new military leaders announced a timetable today to return to democratic rule, with presidential, parliamentary and local elections in the last quarter of this year.         A referendum on a new constitution would be held in September. Political parties, which were banned after the Jan. 27 coup, would be able to resume activities in October, according to an official statement detailing the timetable.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
abstract: * Acer Inc., Taipei, Taiwan, to Hal Riney & Partners, San Francisco, to handle the branding assignment for the personal computer marketer, previously handled by Lai Venuti & Lai, Santa Clara, Calif. The billings are estimated at $7 million to $10 million. Riney was recently awarded the account of the Acer American subsidiary, the Acer America Corp., San Jose, Calif., with billings estimated at $20 million to $25 million.

headline: MUTUAL FUNDS QUARTERLY REPORT;The Tables Turned on Technology in the Latest Quarter
abstract: If 1995 is remembered as the year of the technology funds, it will be in spite of, rather than because of, the fourth quarter. More than a few funds specializing in technology stocks or laden with high-technology shares finished  among the fourth quarter's biggest losers even though they were on the list of leaders throughout the year.         Suffering a spectacular reversal was the Merrill Lynch Technology fund, which rose near the top of the third-quarter leaders' list after a poor first half. But the strategy that worked so well three months before -- betting heavily on a few technology companies -- fell apart in the fourth quarter, when several of those companies disclosed operating difficulties. To a lesser degree, reversals  befell Robertson Stephens Value and Growth, Seligman Communication and Information and a few Fidelity funds.

headline: Israel Eldad, 86, a Top Leader In Palestine Jewish Underground
abstract: Israel Eldad, a leader of the Jewish underground before Israel became a nation and for 50 years one of the most influential figures of the Israeli right wing, died today, his family said. He was 86.         Mr. Eldad, born in Ukraine, immigrated to Palestine when it was under the British Mandate in 1941 and, along with Yitzhak Shamir, who later became Israeli's Prime Minister, was a leader of Lehi, also known as the Stern Gang, the most militant of the Jewish underground groups fighting for independence.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;BAXTER WITHDRAWS BID FOR NATIONAL MEDICAL
abstract: Baxter International Inc. said yesterday that it was withdrawing its $3.8 billion offer to acquire the National Medical Care unit of W. R. Grace & Company. Grace had recently agreed to merge National Medical Care, a kidney dialysis services business, with Fresenius A.G. of Germany. Baxter disclosed that it was giving up its bid in a letter to Grace's chief executive, Albert J.  Costello. In the letter, Baxter's chief executive, Vernon R. Loucks Jr., said, "We firmly believe that our proposal is clearly more favorable." The bid was withdrawn after Grace's stock rose $1.25, to $68.625, on the New York Stock Exchange. A Grace spokesman was not immediately available for comment.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Navigation for the Directionally Challenged
abstract: President Clinton approved guidelines today that allow expanded commercial and civilian use of the Pentagon's satellite-navigation system, a move that will let pilots, motorists and others better pinpoint their location anywhere on earth.         "The same technology that helped our troops succeed in Desert Storm will bring us safer air travel throughout the world, improved transportation on our roads and highways, and faster response to emergencies by rescue vehicles," Mr.  Clinton said in a statement.

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;10-Year Terms Sought For G.I.'s in Okinawa
abstract: Japanese prosecutors today demanded ten-year prison terms for three American  servicemen accused of the rape of a 12-year-old Okinawan girl, a crime that brought nationwide resentment against American bases in Japan.         The requested sentence is considered harsh by Japanese standards, but some opponents of the United States bases in Okinawa said it would be too light given the nature of the crime and the age of the victim.

headline: Gannett to Sell Its Polling Unit To Competitor
abstract: The Gannett Company said today that it had agreed to sell its Louis Harris &  Associates polling unit to the Gordon S. Black Corporation, also a provider of polling and marketing services.         Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

headline: Bangladesh Premier Sworn In Amid Protests
abstract: The Prime Minister of Bangladesh, Khaleda Zia, was sworn in for her second term today, despite opposition protests against the elections that returned her  to power.         Nearly 200 people were injured in battles in the streets of Dhaka, the capital, as the newly elected Parliament met.

headline: Markets Closed
abstract: All financial and commodity markets and banks in the United States are closed today in observance of Washington's Birthday. Most overseas markets are open.

headline: Patents;On the horizon: digital videocassette recorders and the promise of sharper videotapes
abstract: MOST people know that computers are digital machines. Many also realize that  telephone equipment and radio signals are going digital. Some have even heard that television is supposed to be next on the horizon. Manufacturers in those industries have certainly received the message and are moving quickly to design  components that operate with the ones and zeroes of computer code.         Two South Korean inventors have won a patent for a digital videocassette recorder -- the kind of VCR that enhances recordings of analog signals and may operate with the digital television sets and programming broadcasts that should  be introduced sometime before the end of the century. Their patent falls into the arena of digital television transmitters, receivers, data compression devices and cameras -- all inventions that have emerged in the last few years as digital television edges closer to technical reality.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;T.W.A. TO BUY 10 BOEING AIRCRAFT AND LEASE 10 MORE
abstract: Trans World Airlines Inc. said yesterday that it would purchase 10 of the Boeing Company's 757-200 aircraft and lease 10 more to replace its aging L-1011  jets. The carrier said three of the new aircraft are to be delivered this year and 12 next year. Two more of the planes are to be delivered in 1998 and three more in 1999. The airline also has options for another 20 757's. Since it emerged from bankruptcy, T.W.A has said it was planning to replace three-engine jets like the L-1011's with twin-engine aircraft. T.W.A's L-1011's  average age is about 20 years.

headline: Francisco Villarreal, Defiant Mexico Mayor
abstract: Francisco Villarreal, a rebellious border city mayor who once went to jail for taking over an international bridge in defiance of the federal Government, died on Sunday. He was 65.         Mr. Villarreal died of lymphatic cancer. He also had Parkinson's disease.

headline: Intel Is Criticized Over a Newer Chip
abstract: Some users of computers with the Intel Corporation's speedy new Pentium Pro microprocessor are complaining about sluggish performance.         The problem is not with the Pentium Pro itself but with the chip set, or primary group of chips that work with the microprocessor. The chip set slows down data transfer when the computer is used in ways not recommended, Intel said on Friday.

headline: Apple Freezes Most Spending For Research
abstract: Uncertainty about Apple Computer Inc.'s future continued to gnaw at the company today, as Apple froze most research spending, while Standard & Poor's downgraded Apple's debt rating and a selloff pushed the company's shares to a 52-week closing low.         An internal memo announcing the research freeze said that Apple's management  was preparing a reorganization plan that would be presented to the board within  two weeks.

headline: Unaware, Over There
abstract: So, how's your wife? Never ask a potential client that question in Riyadh; it will be seen as an invasion of privacy. And, in Beijing, make sure to face the restaurant door when treating clients to lunch; otherwise, they'll assume you're not paying. If you have a tale of a cultural blunder on a foreign business trip, send it to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your phone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Chechen Casualties High
abstract: Russian aircraft and artillery pounded villages throughout Chechnya today, trying to stamp out rebel resistance, and casualties on both sides appeared to be high.         About 28 Russian servicemen were killed and 86 wounded in fighting in the secessionist republic since Thursday, the Interfax news agency reported.

headline: New Rules For Electing Pope Stress Secrecy
abstract: Pope John Paul II issued a new rule book on Friday for how future popes will  be elected, largely reaffirming existing guidelines but reinforcing the secrecy  of the process and improving accommodations for the 100 or so cardinals who will come to Rome to choose his successors.         At a news conference on Friday, Bishop Jorge Mejia, secretary of the College  of Cardinals, said the revised rules had been issued in part to take into account modern technological developments. More sophisticated listening devices, he said, mean the Vatican's walls "are no longer insurmountable." He said the new text bans all forms of communications between the secluded cardinals and the outside world.

headline: Marriott Said to Be In Bid for Hotels
abstract: Marriott International Inc. is leading the bidding to buy the bulk of the upscale Meridien and Exclusive hotels, which Granada Group P.L.C. acquired with  the L3.8 billion ($5.7 billion) takeover of Forte P.L.C., according to an article in The Sunday Times of London.         Marriott, based in Bethesda, Md., operates about 900 hotels. It is the front  runner to buy the hotel chains, valued at L1.6 billion, but other groups may outbid it, The Times said.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;China Says Growth and Inflation Eased in 1995
abstract: Chinese economic growth slowed slightly last year, the State Statistical Bureau said today, but that was in keeping with the Government's efforts to curb inflation, which slowed considerably.         Economic output increased 10.2 percent last year, down from the 11.8 percent  increase of 1994 but above the Government's target of a rate between 9 percent and 10 percent. Retail prices rose 14.8 percent, considerably slower than 1994's increase of 21.7 percent and meeting the Government target of an increase of less than 15 percent.

headline: CHINA SOLD PARTS FOR NUCLEAR ARMS, U.S. OFFICIALS SAY
abstract: China secretly sold nuclear-weapons technology to Pakistan last year and could face the loss of billions of dollars in business deals under United States law, Administration officials said today. But, they said, President Clinton may  waive the penalties to ease tensions with Beijing.         China sold Pakistan magnets used to refine bomb-grade uranium, the Central Intelligence Agency told the Administration late last year. State Department officials said today they had concluded that the evidence regarding the magnets  was strong enough to trigger the penalties.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Second Suitor Seen For Lloyds Chemists
abstract: The shares of Lloyds Chemists P.L.C. rose yesterday on speculation that Gehe  A.G. of Germany was poised to make a counterbid to the offer by Unichem P.L.C. of L514.2 million ($771 million). Shares in Lloyds, a British pharmacy and drug  wholesaling chain, rose 26 pence yesterday, to 452 pence ($6.79).          On Jan. 18, Unichem, a pharmacy and wholesaling chain, made a bid valuing each Lloyds common share at 396 pence in cash and stock, and each preference share at 255.5 pence. Gehe has refused to comment on the speculation. After a series of acquisitions in recent years, Gehe has become Europe's largest distributor of pharmaceuticals.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: S.E.C. Charges Former Trader For Kidder
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday charged Joseph Jett, a former senior bond trader at Kidder, Peabody & Company, with perpetrating fraud, and it charged that two of his bosses, Melvin Mullin and Edward A. Cerullo, had  failed to supervise him adequately.         The commission is seeking to bar Mr. Jett from the securities industry for life and to force him to give up profits and pay fines totaling several million  dollars, S.E.C. officials said.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;BAY NETWORKS AGREES TO ACQUIRE ARMON NETWORKING
abstract: Bay Networks Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to purchase Armon Networking Ltd., a maker of computer-networking products, for about $33 million. Armon is a private company in Tel Aviv. Bay Networks, which also supplies computer-networking equipment, plans to integrate Armon into its network management group under the name Bay Networks Israel Ltd. The acquisition would be subject to Israeli Government approval. Bay Networks, based in Billerica, Mass., expects to record a third-quarter charge for the purchase, equal to a "very significant" part of the total purchase price.

headline: When Fraud Truly Stings: Smaller Bank as Target
abstract: For a banker, what could be worse than discovering that you may have lent to  a fraud?         Answer: When that money represents the biggest loan on the books.

headline: Bosnian Mine Is Thought to Hold Evidence of Mass Killings
abstract: The vast open-pit iron mine, the hulks of ore-processing machinery and the bulldozers lie blanketed in snow, but the scene is not abandoned. Outside the gates of the complex, closed for four years, heavily armed soldiers patrol and the dirt roads leading to the heart of the mine are blocked with land mines.         This mining complex is believed by residents here and Western officials to be the central collection point and hiding place for thousands of corpses that remain from the Bosnian Serbs' campaign of "ethnic cleansing" in northwestern Bosnia.

headline: Hamas Unit Says It Will Resume Suicide Bombings
abstract: The Qassam military wing of the Muslim fundamentalist group Hamas said today  that it would resume suicide bombings because of crackdowns by Israel and the Palestinian Authority.         "The General Command of the Qassam units has studied the situation seriously  and objectively and has decided to resume its suicide operations," said a leaflet purported to be from the group that was distributed to news organizations.

headline: Tension Rises in Korean Stare-Down
abstract: Lieut. Brad Harris kept his olive-colored gas mask ready for instant use beside him as he pointed to the gullies where he would expect North Korean tanks to be lying in wait for him.         An icy wind numbed his face as he commanded a 70-ton M1-A1 Abrams tank on field maneuvers, a bit south of the minefields and razor wire that mark the border between North and South Korea.

headline: China Says Maneuvers Will Last Through Taiwan's Elections
abstract: China announced tonight that it would carry on large-scale military exercises off Taiwan through the presidential elections there, ignoring Taiwan's calls to  end belligerent acts and resume a dialogue.         "From March 18 to 25, 1996, the Chinese People's Liberation Army will conduct joint ground, naval and air exercises in and over a sea area" covering much of the northwest part of the Taiwan Strait, the official New China News Agency announced. Taiwan's presidential vote is March 23.

headline: Treasury Issues To Be Offered During Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week includes today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills and two- and five-year notes being  auctioned on Wednesday and Thursday.         At the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.95 percent and the rate on the six-month  issue was 5 percent. In when-issued trading, the two-year note was offered at a  price to yield 5.75 percent, and the five-year note at 6.05 percent.

headline: Haitians at Center of Montreal Election
abstract: Gilles Solomcariotte, a 40-year-old textile worker who emigrated from Haiti two years ago, is waiting for a bus on gritty Papineau Street, in a working-class district of northeast Montreal, the site of a fiercely contested election for a seat in the House of Commons.         Among the wooden-frame row houses strewn with "for rent" and "for sale" signs, posters hang from lampposts every few hundred yards to urge support for Pierre S. Pettigrew, the new Minister of International Cooperation. The battle in the Papineau-St. Michel district is the most important of six to be decided on Monday.

headline: Apple and Disclosure: How Golden Is Silence?
abstract: American investors expect to be told, promptly and publicly, all the important information they need to gauge the value of a company's stock. But for weeks, Apple Computer Inc.'s investors have been trading in the dark.         There had been, of course, conflicting reports over the status and terms of a rumored merger with Sun Microsystems Inc., which day after day neither company confirmed nor denied. The murkiness reached inky proportions yesterday morning, when buyers and sellers of Apple's shares literally did not know who was running the company.

headline: Surprise Job Report Ambushes Bond Investors
abstract: Bond investors were swept up in a wild scramble to sell off holdings yesterday after the Government reported a much stronger labor market than investors had imagined. Months of pricing in the climate of a weak economy and cuts in interest rates evaporated in a flash.         Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst for Chase Securities, said the day was "pandemonium." Bond prices plunged and their yields registered their biggest one-day jump since 1987.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;Barrick's New Policy Could Increase Price of Gold
abstract: The world's most profitable gold-mining company, the Barrick Gold Corporation, signaled changes today in its hedging policies that could mean higher prices for gold.         Gold companies manage the risks associated with fluctuating prices by agreeing on prices for future production that are higher than current rates, a practice known as hedging. Last year Barrick sold gold at an average price of $406 an ounce, or $22 above the average price of $384.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS;Bonds Surge On New Hope Of a Rate Cut
abstract: Prices of Treasury securities rebounded sharply yesterday as more evidence of a weak economy heightened expectations of another interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve, and a stronger dollar brought buyers back into the market.         Traders said the dollar's rise stemmed from a threat by the Chinese Government that it was prepared to fire missiles at Taiwan if Taiwan continued to seek international recognition. A stronger dollar makes Treasury securities and other United States investments more attractive to foreign investors because of the profits that can be made through currency appreciation.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;WARNER-LAMBERT TO SELL GENERIC UNIT TO NALE
abstract: The Warner-Lambert Company said yesterday that it would sell its Warner Chilcott Laboratories generic pharmaceutical business to Nale Laboratories P.L.C. Terms of the contract were not disclosed. Warner Chilcott had 1995 sales  of $125 million from the marketing of about 70 generic pharmaceuticals. Warner-Lambert has entered into a manufacturing and service agreement with Nale and will retain rights to a minority equity interest in it. Nale is a closely held Irish developer of generic medicines.

headline: Bond Prices Suffer a 3d Day of Steep Losses
abstract: Treasury prices fell sharply for a third consecutive session yesterday, weighed down by talk of selling by large funds and by concerns that the supply of securities might be larger than the demand. Trading was choppy in a session that ended early ahead of the Washington's Birthday holiday weekend.         The sharp decline in prices came even though Government reports in the last two days showed that the economy was slowing at a more pronounced pace than had previously been thought. The indications of weakness that were found in reports on durable goods and factory orders on Thursday were echoed in reports yesterday on industrial production and construction spending. In the past, the bond market has often rallied on such reports, with their portents of continued  mild inflation.

headline: Big 3 Dispute Challenge Over New-Car Costs
abstract: One of the nation's top experts on measuring consumer sentiment warned today  that car buyers were more concerned about prices now than at any time in the last decade, but top economists of the Big Three auto makers dismissed his contention.         The disagreement, coming at the start of what is expected to be a year of low growth, at best, in car sales, reflected an issue being discussed more and more  often in the industry: whether consumers can still afford to buy cars at the pace of recent years. The prices of new vehicles rose an average of about 8 percent annually from 1973 through 1993, according to a study by the University  of Michigan, and they are continuing to rise briskly. Family incomes rose about  5 percent annually during that period and have stagnated recently.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Congress Votes to Return Federal Workers to Payroll Congress voted to put 760,000 Federal workers back on the payroll for three weeks, and to reopen politically visible Government operations from the national parks to the payment of veterans' pensions until September.

headline: Ruling Backs Banks' Sales Of Insurance
abstract: National banks won an important Supreme Court victory today with a unanimous  ruling that the banks may sell insurance from branch offices in small towns, despite state laws to the contrary.         The decision, a setback for the insurance industry, was the latest of several Supreme Court rulings to endorse the broad view of national banks' powers held by the office of the Comptroller of the Currency. In an important decision last  year, the Court upheld the Comptroller's policy of permitting national banks to  sell annuities.

headline: P.& G. Plans To Cut Costs Of Marketing
abstract: The Procter & Gamble Company, one of the largest advertisers in the world, said today that it would cut its spending on marketing in the next few years to  reduce prices on products.         P.& G.'s marketing costs as a percentage of its overall sales will drop to 20 percent from 25 percent by the year 2000, a spokeswoman, Elizabeth Moore said, confirming a report in today's edition of The Sunday Times of London.

headline: Intel Signs Licensing Deal
abstract: Intel and Advanced Micro Devices have signed a five-year patent cross-licensing agreement.         The companies said Friday that they had agreed to negotiate the license as a  result of a patent-litigation settlement announced last January. The companies dropped pending litigation against each other, and Advanced Micro agreed to pay  $58 million for a perpetual license to the microcode of Intel's 386 and 486 chips.

headline: Japanese Stocks Lower
abstract: Stock prices were lower here today. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 4.28 points, or 0.02 percent, at 20,365.76. On Thursday, the Nikkei fell 200.22 points or nearly 1 percent.

headline: Seoul-Tokyo Dispute
abstract: In a growing dispute over an island claimed by both Japan and South Korea, President Kim Young Sam of South Korea has canceled a meeting scheduled for Monday with Japanese legislators.         A spokesman at the presidential office quoted Mr. Kim as saying today that Japan's claim to sovereignty over the island was unacceptable.

headline: Senate Confirms a Nominee for the S.E.C.
abstract: After an extended delay, the Senate has approved the nomination of an Ohio law professor, Isaac C. Hunt Jr., to fill a vacant seat on the Securities and Exchange Commission.         The Senate approved Mr. Hunt late Friday night as part of a vote on a package of routine matters, Senate and S.E.C. officials said today.

headline: Jardin Journal;Growing Coffee Is Losing Its Savor for Colombians
abstract: Fifty years ago, when cattle ranching was the main activity around here, Jorge Henao scratched out a living by herding cows.         Later, when coffee made its appearance, muddy country lanes became neatly paved roads. Schools, electricity and modern communications transformed the local economy and brought prosperity to Mr. Henao and other Colombians. He bought land, grew coffee, built a house and raised a family.

headline: FUNDS WATCH;Some Lessons From the 1930's
abstract: Investors looking for protection in today's volatile market might find refuge in the Dodge & Cox funds, says Susan Paluch, an analyst with Morningstar Inc., the fund researchers in Chicago. Dodge & Cox began managing money in the Depression, and the lessons of that era were not lost on the firm.

headline: Yeltsin Ouster Of TV Chief Stirs a Storm
