abstract: Almost immediately after telling voters that he is Russia's best hope for reform, President Boris N. Yeltsin has undercut his re-election campaign message by sparking concerns that he is trying to muzzle the media.         The controversy, which has dominated political news here for the last two days, centers on Russian television, an especially important medium for reaching voters across this vast country.

headline: China Appeals for Aid After Earthquake Kills 200
abstract: China mobilized its military today for rescue work and appealed for international assistance after a powerful earthquake leveled thousands of mud-walled village homes Saturday night and killed more than 200 people in the southern province of Yunnan.         Daylight today revealed a vista of devastation in Lijiang and Zhongdian Counties, 200 miles northwest of the provincial capital, Kunming, as rescue workers struggled to cope with 14,000 injured residents, 3,800 of them with serious injuries, the state-run New China News Agency said.

headline: New Virus Designed to Tackle Windows 95
abstract: Software saboteurs have created the first computer virus specifically aimed at the Microsoft Corporation's Windows 95 program, British researchers said today.         The virus can corrupt programs so that they no longer function. It can be spread when an infected program is run another user's PC, said Paul Ducklin, an  analyst for the British software company Sophos.

headline: European Topics : Genetically Altered Tomatoes Make Their European Debut
abstract: Last week, about 800,000 cans of tomato puree went on sale in British supermarkets. Nothing special, except that the contents of these tins were genetically altered, the first such foodstuff to reach Europeanconsumers.

headline: U.N. Panel Says Zaire Blocks Rwandan Arms Inquiry
abstract: The Government of Zaire is obstructing the work of an international commission investigating the illegal arming and training of Rwandan exiles attacking Rwanda across the border between the two countries, a report to the Security Council said today.         The six-member commission has been effectively stymied both by Zaire's refusal to allow the commission to function satisfactorily on its territory and  by a lack of cooperation from several arms-exporting nations believed to be withholding information. As a result, Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali suggested that the panel may have to be disbanded next month.

headline: Stocks Lower in Japan
abstract: Stocks traded lower here today. The Nikkei index of 225 issues closed down 169.23 points, or 0.83 percent, at 20,196.53. On Friday, the Nikkei fell 4.28 points.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Why Dun & Bradstreet Is Different From Disney
abstract: Splitting big companies into smaller ones has been the norm in American business recently -- witness the breakup of corporate brand names like AT&T, ITT and Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing.         But until this week, the media industry was a striking exception. Companies were merging left and right, led by multibillion-dollar deals like Walt Disney's purchase of Capital Cities/ABC and Time Warner's plan to acquire Turner Broadcasting System. Behind the mergers was a singular strategy: grab heaps of entertainment and information content, add a global distribution network and build a media mega-corporation.

headline: Small Book From a Small Publisher Is a Big Hit
abstract: To create a nonfiction best seller, take a big publisher with money and marketing heft, the discounting muscle of the bookstore chains and a well-known  author. Mix, and presto.         Not always. "Longitude," published in October, had none of those ingredients, yet it was one of the 203 hardcovers to make The New York Times best-seller list last year.

headline: SPENDING IT;When Frequent Fliers Could Use a Compass
abstract: IN growing numbers over the last 15 years, companies from airlines to credit  issuers to hotel chains have offered frequent-flier miles as incentives to vacation-hungry Americans.         And consumers have responded. A survey by Frequent Flyer magazine found that  a typical reader belonged to five to eight different frequent-flier programs and was in similar programs at one to four hotel chains.

headline: DEADLY TURNING POINT: A special report.;AIDS Epidemic, Late to Arrive, Now Explodes in Populous Asia
abstract: A ribbon of acrid yellow smoke rose from the crematory as a Buddhist monk approached, clutching his saffron robe in a bony, withered hand. His skin was mottled, his body wasting away from the disease that would soon take his life, just as it had killed two others whose bodies had been committed to the fire only hours before.         "I know that my body will end up here," said the AIDS-stricken monk, Phra Kamthorn Kitisalo, as he entered the crematory, the still-warm ovens at one end  of a high-ceilinged room. "I accept that."

headline: Computer City Talks Halted
abstract: The Tandy Corporation said today that it had conducted talks recently about selling its Computer City division to CompUSA Inc. but that the meetings had been discontinued.         A spokeswoman for Comp USA declined to comment.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: No Panic Seen After Market Drop At mutual fund and brokerage firms around the country this weekend, the volume of calls from customers rose, but there was no sign of panic selling in the wake of Friday's 171-point dive in the Dow Jones industrial average.

headline: Honduras Puts Rightist Officer In a U.N. Role
abstract: Honduras has appointed as a representative to the United Nations a former general who last year defied civilian efforts to arrest military officers on charges of rights abuses and who staged an intimidating show of military force in the capital.         The officer, Luis Alonso Discua Elvir, who has been the Honduran commander in chief for the last five years, was appointed alternate permanent representative  to the United Nations early this year and is expected to take up his appointment in early March, a spokeswoman for the Foreign Ministry said today.

headline: Venezuelans See Clashes Resuming
abstract: After weeks of anti-Government protests, Venezuelans put aside their rancor over collapsing living standards during Pope John Paul II's visit this weekend,  but the country was bracing for more conflict as he flew back to Rome tonight.         "He's placated things for a bit, but now people are going to have to face their daily realities again," said Antonio Diaz, an unemployed laborer who, with more than a million other Venezuelans, attended an open-air Mass at a Caracas air base today.

headline: Greek Party Chooses Rival To Replace Papandreou
abstract: In a break with the legacy of its founder and longtime leader, Andreas Papandreou, Greece's governing Socialist Party today elected one of his chief critics, Costas Simitis, 59, as the country's new Prime Minister.         The election, held in closed session by the party's 167 parliamentary deputies, was clinched on a second ballot, when Mr. Simitis won 86 votes to beat back a surge of support for Akis Tsohatzopoulos, a party apparatchik who was backed by Papandreou loyalists. He received 75 votes on the second ballot.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;HOECHST AND RHONE-POULENC COMBINE PLASMA UNITS
abstract: Hoechst A.G. and Rhone-Poulenc Rorer Inc. said yesterday that they had combined their plasma protein businesses in a new 50-50 venture known as Centeon. Based in King of Prussia, Pa., Centeon becomes the world's largest provider of plasma protein products, which are used to treat immune deficiencies, bone marrow transplants and neurological disorders. Centeon will have yearly sales of about $1.2 billion. Germany's Hoechst contributed the plasma protein division of its Behringwerke A.G. business. Rhone-Poulenc Rorer,  the United States business of Rhone-Poulenc S.A., contributed the plasma protein assets of its Armour Pharmaceutical Company unit.

headline: How a Would-Be Mr. Fix-It Left a Company in Ruins
abstract: WHITE-GLOVED waiters carried trays of hors d'oeuvres through the ballroom of  the St. Regis Hotel in Manhattan as an expectant crowd of investors awaited Paul G. Kahn, the man who had come to save their company.         The shareholders at the annual meeting last April of the long-beleaguered Safecard Services had cause for hope. Fifteen months before, Mr. Kahn had joined as chairman, bringing a reputation as one of America's savviest business executives. At AT&T, he had introduced the Universal credit card, building it into the nation's second-largest and winning the Government's prestigious Malcolm Baldrige National Quality Award. He told his new investors that perhaps  he could win again -- for Safecard.

headline: Pay for New Apple Chief Seen Topping $10 Million
abstract: However shaky the future of Apple Computer Inc. may be, Gilbert F. Amelio, the company's new chairman and chief executive, is sure to be financially secure.         Mr. Amelio's pay package, according to one expert on executive compensation,  will total at least $10 million a year for the next five years, and could go much higher if Apple's stock price improves. In addition, Mr. Amelio is guaranteed a payment of $10 million if the company is sold within a year -- a possibility, given Apple's recent merger talk with Sun Microsystems Inc.

headline: Prices in 1995 Up 2.5%, a 5th Subdued Year
abstract: Signaling that inflation has been vanquished to a degree not seen since the early 1960's, the Labor Department reported today that consumer prices rose only 2.5 percent for all of 1995, the lowest rate in nearly a decade and the fifth consecutive year that inflation held to about 3 percent or less.         Most economists toasted the news, saying that they expected the inflation rate to remain just as low in 1996 or to dip further. They said that this period of price stability, one of the longest since World War II, would give the Federal Reserve enough room to keep cutting interest rates, as it did on Wednesday, to spark a slowing economy.

headline: U.S. Aid Cutbacks Endangering Population Programs, U.N. Agencies Say
abstract: In the latest tactical victory by a resurgent anti-abortion movement in the United States, Congress has forced a drastic cut in aid that is the mainstay of  family planning programs around the world.         Recent legislation, intended to punish the Clinton Administration for allowing aid for family planning groups involved in abortions overseas, cuts 35  percent from the population and family planning budget of the Agency for International Development, the largest supporter of such programs in the world.

headline: Economic Scene;Changing the tax system has an allure. But will the fixes work?
abstract: TAX reform is the Republican flavor of the month. The Kemp Commission, recruited by Newt Gingrich to give his party a tonier image on economic issues,  is calling for an end to the income tax as we know it. Steve Forbes's tireless pitch for the flat tax has helped him to break away from the pack chasing Bob Dole for the Republican Presidential nomination.         And why not? A makeover of taxes that promises, in the words of the Kemp Commission, to double the rate of economic growth, sure beats abortion or affirmative action as a party-unifying, good-news issue.

headline: Seeking to Fix Damaged Image, Apple Hires Burson-Marsteller
abstract: Apple Computer Inc., still recovering from its public relations debacle during merger talks with Sun Microsystems Inc. and the ouster of its chief executive, said today that it had retained Burson-Marsteller to manage its worldwide public relations.         During years of affiliation with Regis McKenna Inc., the seminal Silicon Valley public relations firm, Apple had made little use of outside agencies. But Regis has switched its focus to marketing consulting and last month, Apple announced that its two top public relations executives, Barbara Krause and Betty Taylor, were leaving. Now the company has turned to Burson, a unit of Young & Rubicam Inc., Satjiv Chahil, Apple's senior vice president of corporate marketing, said in a telephone interview.

headline: Shell Makes a Big Oil Discovery Off Nigeria
abstract: Royal Dutch/Shell, which has been criticized by human rights groups for its operations in Nigeria, has made a potentially significant discovery of oil in a  deep-water area off the coast of the West African country, Shell officials confirmed today.         A 14,700-foot well has been drilled in an exploration area called Bongo 1 off the coast of the Niger Delta, where most of Nigeria's on-shore wells are located. Tests are being conducted to see how large the discovery is and whether production is commercially feasible.

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Settlement Is Reported On AIDS Virus in Japan
abstract: The Health and Welfare Ministry and five drug companies have agreed to a court-proposed settlement of suits brought by Japanese who contracted the AIDS virus from contaminated blood products, ministry officials said today.         The lawsuits were brought in 1989 by about 400 infected hemophiliacs who claimed the Government continued to allow use of unheated blood products in Japan after it knew that heat treatment killed the AIDS virus.

headline: Ernest Manning, 87, Ex-Alberta Premier
abstract: Ernest Manning, a Premier of Alberta for 25 years and father of the right-wing opposition leader Preston Manning, died on Monday at his home in Calgary, his son said. He was 87.         Mr. Manning, who began his public career as a radio evangelist, served as Premier from 1943 to 1968, representing the populist Social Credit Party. He was re-elected seven consecutive times before resigning.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Health Care Provider Selects Martin
abstract: The Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation, the health care service provider, has named the Martin Agency unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies in Richmond as the first agency to handle its national advertising account. Though  the billings have not been determined, Adweek this week estimated them at more than $20 million.          Lindy Richardson, senior vice president for marketing and public affairs at  Columbia/HCA in Nashville, said Martin was awarded the account after a five-month review. The other participants were Greenstone Roberts Advertising in Orlando, Fla.; Lewis Advertising in Mobile, Ala., and a collaboration of the Buntin Group in Nashville with Bozell Worldwide in New York, which is a unit of  Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt. Buntin continues to handle the media part of  the account.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                                               Previous      Year                               Yesterday       Day       Ago

headline: COMPANY NEWS;BRITISH AIRWAYS SAYS IT WILL NOT BUY MORE USAIR SHARES
abstract: British Airways P.L.C. said yesterday that it would not exercise two options  to buy another $450 million worth of preference shares in USAir Group Inc. The British carrier bought a 24.6 percent stake in USAir in 1993, hoping to expand the linkup if the United States lifted its 25 percent ceiling on foreign ownership. The Department of Transportation has not changed its stance, however, and British Airways said in a statement that an increase in the ceiling "was not expected to be forthcoming."

headline: Pioneer Electronic Expects Wider Loss
abstract: Battered by fierce price competition and sluggish overseas demand for its key products, the Pioneer Electronic Corporation said today that it was likely to post a wider loss than it had expected for the fiscal year that ends in March.

headline: Chase-Chemical Date Is Set
abstract: The Chemical Banking Corporation and the Chase Manhattan Corporation said yesterday that they had set March 31 as the effective date for their $10 billion merger. The merged entity, to retain the name Chase Manhattan, will be the largest commercial bank holding company in the United States, with $297 billion  in assets. The subsidiary banks will be merged later in the year, the companies  said.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;GLENAYRE'S OUTLOOK BRINGS A 23% DROP IN SHARES
abstract: The shares of Glenayre Technologies Inc. fell 23 percent yesterday after the  company, a telecommunications equipment maker, said its first-quarter sales might be hurt by a regulatory ruling. Glenayre said on Tuesday that a recent decision by the Federal Communications Commission to freeze new applications for 900 megahertz paging licenses may mean that first-quarter sales will fall $10 million to $12 million below analysts' estimates. The company, based in Charlotte, N.C., did not disclose those estimates. Glenayre shares fell $10, to  $32.25, in Nasdaq trading of 10.8 million shares.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;2 Executives On the Move
abstract: Alan Cohen, executive vice president for marketing at NBC television in New York, will join ABC in the new position of executive vice president for marketing. And Peter Chrisanthopoulos, who had been executive vice president for research, marketing and promotion at the ABC network in New York, is joining Ogilvy & Mather U.S.         At ABC, which is being acquired by the Walt Disney Company, Mr. Cohen, 39, will be responsible for establishing a department to direct the consumer, advertising and affiliate marketing efforts for the network. At NBC, a unit of the General Electric Company, Mr. Cohen helped develop large promotional campaigns that were co-sponsored by consumer marketers.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;OLYMPIA & YORK REACHES DEAL TO SPLIT ASSETS
abstract: The Olympia & York Companies (U.S.A.) reached an agreement yesterday to split its real estate assets between two creditor groups as part of a debt restructuring. One creditor group is led by the financier Leon Black and the other is led by the Bronfman family. The Bronfman-led group will get the keys to buildings holding 12 million square feet of a total of 15 million square feet of Manhattan real estate that Olympia & York (U.S.A.) owns. The buildings include the World Financial Center, One Liberty Plaza and 245 Park Avenue. Mr. Black's group will get control of office towers at 277 Park Avenue and 1290 Avenue of the Americas. The agreement allows Olympia, a unit of Olympia & York Developments Ltd. to restructure almost $5 billion in debt. Olympia will seek bankruptcy court approval.

headline: Gtech Sells Amtote
abstract: The Gtech Holdings Corporation has sold its Amtote International Inc. unit to the closely held Mudge Acquisitions Group of Baltimore. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;BRISTOL-MYERS BUYS ARGENTINE DRUG MAKER
abstract: The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company said yesterday that it had acquired Argentia S.A., an Argentine maker and marketer of pharmaceuticals. Argentia, whose 1995 sales were about $67 million, manufactures antibiotics and drugs to treat respiratory and gastrointestinal problems, Bristol-Myers said. Based near Buenos Aires, Argentia has about 600 employees. The purchase is Bristol-Myers's fourth  foreign pharmaceutical-company acquisition in the last 24 months, the company said. The terms of the deal were not disclosed.

headline: Italy Turns to Top Bureaucrat To Try to Remake the Country
abstract: Italy emerged from a three-week Government crisis today with a surprise choice as Prime Minister-designate and a vague pledge by major political parties to push through difficult constitutional reforms.         Heading off early elections, President Oscar Luigi Scalfaro today appointed Antonio Maccanico, a 71-year-old former cabinet minister and longtime civil servant, to head Italy's 55th postwar government, succeeding Lamberto Dini, who  resigned after one year in office.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;General Motors plans to redesign its Epcot Center exhibit as part of a bigger brand campaign.
abstract: THE General Motors Corporation plans to replace its exhibit at the Epcot Center attraction at Walt Disney World in Orlando, Fla., as part of an ambitious revamping of its car and truck advertising and marketing by emphasizing brands.          General Motors is scheduled to discuss its plans today at the exhibit, known  as the World of Motion. The exhibit was one of the original corporate-sponsored  pavilions when the Walt Disney Company opened Epcot in 1982.

headline: Merger Rumors Lift Phone Stocks
abstract: Shares of the Bell Atlantic Corporation and the Nynex Corporation climbed yesterday on speculation that merger talks between the two companies had intensified.         Nynex surged $3.875, to $59.25, while Bell Atlantic gained $1.75, to $72.375.

headline: Boksburg Journal;Black History Blooms in a White Couple's Garden
abstract: Perhaps the most charming ethnological museum in Africa is in one of the most unlikely places -- a gracious garden hidden behind a razor-wire-wrapped gate down a narrow alley in a warehouse district of this Johannesburg suburb. The showcase of black ethnic history is the amateur project of two white South Africans, Karl and Naomi Hechter-Schulz, and has been assembled in the home where Dr. Hechter-Schulz was born 83 years ago.         When visiting schoolchildren are numerous enough, their two maids help out, decking bewildered but game 5-year-olds in leopard skins, Ndebele neck-stretching rings or Boer bonnets and teaching them a few high-kicking Zulu  dance moves.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;SALE OF FUND AMERICAN UNIT TO MELLON HITS HURDLES
abstract: Fund American Enterprises Holdings Inc. of Norwich, Vt., said yesterday that  talks about the sale of its mortgage unit to Mellon Mortgage, a unit of the Mellon Bank Corporation, were going more slowly than expected. In December, Mellon had proposed in a letter of intent to buy all of Fund American's mortgage subsidiary, the Source One Mortgage Services Corporation. Mellon "has revised the scope and other terms of the transaction it is willing to discuss," Fund American said in a statement. It added: "Fund American is continuing discussions with Mellon and other parties. There can be no assurance any transaction will be negotiated or consummated."

headline: Equity and Convertible Offerings Set This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

headline: Russia Says, 'Sorry'
abstract: The commander of Russian troops in Chechnya issued a rare apology today after the "unauthorized" bombing of a village that had signed a peace accord with Russia.         The bombing killed a family of nine and wounded several other people in the village of Katyr-Yurt, news reports said.

headline: Weekly Earnings Off Slightly in December
abstract: Average weekly earnings of United States workers, after adjusting for inflation and seasonal factors, fell two-tenths of 1 percent in December after declining a revised seven-tenths of a percent in November, the Labor Department  said today.         The department previously reported that real average weekly earnings fell four-tenths of 1 percent in November.

headline: Guatemalans Covered Up Killing Of an American, U.S. Aides Say
abstract: Two Guatemalan Presidents, two Defense Ministers and high-ranking military officers paid by the Central Intelligence Agency helped cover up the facts of the killing of Michael DeVine, an American innkeeper in Guatemala, in 1990, United States officials have concluded.         The officials are also weighing new accusations from within the Guatemalan armed forces implicating the nation's top military and intelligence chiefs in the killing of Efrain Bamaca, a Guatemalan guerrilla married to an American lawyer, Jennifer Harbury.

headline: World News Briefs;Famine in North Korea Puts the South on Edge
abstract: President Kim Young Sam said today that national security must be South Korea's first concern, in light of reports of a possible famine in North Korea.          "Since North Korea's food shortages and economic difficulty have reached an extreme stage, national security should be the Government's foremost policy goal," Mr. Kim told his staff.

headline: Europe Inflation Falls
abstract: The European Union's annual inflation rate fell to 2.8 percent in January, the lowest level since 1987, according to figures released today. The figures show a fall of two-tenths of a percentage point from December.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Court Lets Workers Sue If Tricked of Benefits The Supreme Court ruled that workers whose employers trick them into giving up benefits can sue to have the coverage restored. The 6-to-3 decision gave new teeth to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;A Mistic Account Goes to Deutsch
abstract: Mistic Brands Inc., which markets fruit-flavored juice drinks and teas, has named Deutsch Inc. in New York to handle the creative portion of its account, with billings estimated at $7 million to $10 million. The assignment had been handled for the last six months by Krimstein/Clapps in New York before that agency withdrew from a review.         Ken Gilbert, senior vice president for marketing at Mistic in New Rochelle, N.Y., a unit of the Triarc Companies, said the review was narrowed to Deutsch and four other finalists -- Scaros & Casselman in Stamford, Conn., and three New York shops: Earle Palmer Brown; Pedone & Partners, and Penchina/ Biederman, Kelly & Shaffer, a joint venture of Penchina & Company and Biederman, Kelly & Shaffer.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS;Traders Focus on New Data And Fresh Talks on Budget
abstract: While the markets for Treasury securities were closed yesterday for the holiday honoring the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., traders began looking forward to a greater clarity in trading this week.         They are waiting for the budget talks to resume in Washington on Wednesday and for the release this week of some long-delayed Government economic statistics. The Government shutdown prevented the gathering and compilation of economic indicators, meaning that many market participants postponed investment  decisions or took smaller positions based on private statistics, which are typically less comprehensive.

headline: China, Vying With Taiwan, Explores Public Relations
abstract: Last November, representatives from the communications firm of Robinson Lerer Sawyer Miller were invited to the Chinese Embassy to present an ambitious three-year public-relations strategy for Beijing.         Focus on "hot-button issues" like human rights and weapons sales, the Chinese were told, according to people familiar with the day-long presentation. Put on a road show of Chinese athletes during the summer Olympics. Create a "command center" to handle crises. Set up a news bureau with television links and an on-line information system. The firm boasted that it operated "well behind the scenes" and represented corporate giants like Microsoft and Chrysler and the Governments of countries like the Philippines, Columbia, Chile and Indonesia.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;Times Co. Income Fell 18.8%, To $33 Million, in 4th Quarter
abstract: percent in the fourth quarter, reflecting one-time charges and higher paper costs.         The company said its net income totaled $33 million, or 34 cents a share, compared with $40.7 million, or 41 cents a share, in the corresponding period a year earlier.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;TEKTRONIX STOCK SLIDES AFTER EARNINGS REPORT
abstract: Shares of Tektronix Inc. plunged 24 percent yesterday after the company said  late on Thursday that its third-quarter net income had fallen well below analysts' expectations. Tektronix, based in Wilsonville, Ore., a high-technology printing and imaging company, said net income for the quarter ended Feb. 24 was  $22.4 million, or 67 cents a share, up from $21.4 million, or 65 cents a share,  a year earlier. But analysts had predicted Tektronix net would come in at about 86 cents a share. Tektronix's stock was down $10.50, at $33.25, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Late in the session the company said it would repurchase 1.5 million of its shares.

headline: U.S. Bars Ex-East German Spymaster
abstract: The State Department said today it has denied a visa to Markus Wolf, who once ran Communist East Germany's foreign spy service, on the ground that he had in the past been involved in terrorist activities.         The State Department said it had no plans to waive the law for Mr. Wolf as it has done for Gerry Adams, leader of Sinn Fein, the political wing of the I.R.A.

headline: Rabin's Killer Is Given a Life Sentence in Israel
abstract: Yigal Amir, the man who shattered Israel when he assassinated Prime Minister  Yitzhak Rabin, was sentenced to life imprisonment today after having been found  guilty of murder.         In a judgment laced with poetry and soaring prose, the presiding judge, Edmond Levy, brought two months of often technical proceedings to an emotional conclusion, grieving for the loss of a national leader and condemning Mr. Amir as someone who had "lost all semblance of humanity."

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Spanish Socialist Slain; Basque Rebels Blamed
abstract: A gunman assassinated a Spanish Socialist Party regional leader today in the  northern city of San Sebastian, and the police and political leaders blamed Basque separatists for the killing.         Fernando Mugica Herzog, a 62-year-old lawyer, died at a hospital after being  shot in the head while walking to his office. The victim was the brother of Enrique Mugica Herzog, a former Justice Minister who instituted the Government's policy of separating Basque prisoners into different prisons to prevent collective action behind bars.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings this week:      MONDAY

headline: COMPANY NEWS;DEPUY PLANS TO BUY ORTHOPEDIC TECHNOLOGY
abstract: The shares of Orthopedic Technology Inc. rose yesterday after the company said that it had agreed to be acquired by Depuy Inc., a unit of Boehringer Mannheim G.m.b.H., for $10.43 a share, or a total of $46.2 million. Orthopedic Technology stock rose 32.8 cents, to $10.313 in Nasdaq trading. Closely held Depuy, which is based in Warsaw, Ind., plans to begin a tender offer for all of  Orthopedic Technology's outstanding shares. Depuy, with more than $425 million in annual revenue, manufactures and sells orthopedic products worldwide including prosthetic implants, and trauma and spinal products. Orthopedic Technology, based in Tracy, Calif., manufactures custom and off-the-shelf orthopedic products. The company had revenue of $18.4 million for the year ended Sept. 30.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;FRUEHAUF POSTS ANOTHER LOSS AND SEEKS A MERGER
abstract: As the Fruehauf Trailer Corporation posted a fourth-quarter loss of $4.46 million, or 11 cents a share, the company said yesterday that it had hired Oppenheimer & Company to help it find a merger partner. Fruehauf, which has posted losses in three of its last five quarters, said it expected a wave of mergers in the truck-and-trailer industry. Thomas B. Roller, Fruehauf's chief executive and president, said the company had been negotiating a merger or sale of assets with several parties for five months. The fourth-quarter results  included a charge of $1.83 million, or 5 cents a share, for the early payment of debt, the company said. Fruehauf's shares fell 25 cents yesterday, to $1, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Bosnian Muslims Free 109 Prisoners
abstract: The Bosnian Government freed 109 prisoners of war from a jail in Tuzla late Saturday night in partial fulfilment of its obligations under the Dayton peace agreement, the International Committee of the Red Cross said.         The organization had registered a total of 152 prisoners of war who were still being held by Bosnia's former warring parties -- 129 by the Muslim-dominated Bosnian Government and 23 by the Bosnian Serbs.

headline: Japanese Suits on H.I.V.-Tainted Blood Settled
abstract: Five drug companies and Japan's Minister of Health and Welfare agreed today to a proposed settlement with hemophiliacs who were infected with the AIDS virus through contaminated blood-clotting products, setting the stage for the end of seven years of bitter litigation.         The case has roiled Japan because it seemed to show that the Government was more interested in shielding Japanese drug companies from foreign competition than in protecting public health.

headline: As Russian Vote Nears, U.S. Fears for Fate of Reform
abstract: Senior Administration officials, once invariably chipper about President Boris N. Yeltsin, are taking a markedly more shaded and wary tone about him these days.         After the strong Communist showing in Russia's parliamentary elections last month and Mr. Yeltsin's second episode of heart disease, American officials are  expressing considerable concern about the presidential election scheduled for June and the chance that pro-reform candidates will fail to unite behind a single candidate.

headline: G.M., Sharing Some Profit, Lifts Dividend
abstract: Deciding to share more of its record profits with shareholders, directors of  the General Motors Corporation today raised the quarterly dividend on the company's common stock by a third to 40 cents.         Wall Street analysts had been expecting a dividend increase and said that the company could afford the additional $300 million annual outlay.

headline: Dow Closes at a High Again And Ends Week Up 87.07
abstract: The Dow Jones industrial average closed at a new high yesterday for the third time this week, spurred by an easing of investor concern over the progress of Federal budget talks and by strong corporate earnings.         The Dow gained 54.92 points, to 5,271.75, setting off a New York Stock Exchange rule that curbs computer-guided program trading at 3:44 P.M.  As a percentage, the advance was more than 1 percent, the largest among the major stock market indicators. In the last five sessions, the Dow has climbed 87.07 points.

headline: Holbrooke Gets His Own Day in the Limelight
abstract: For Richard C. Holbrooke, a man for whom no amount of adulation can ever be quite enough, today was probably as good as it gets.         On his last day as Assistant Secretary of State for European and Canadian Affairs, Mr. Holbrooke met the President and Vice President and the NATO Secretary General, then received the State Department's second-highest honor from Secretary of State Warren Christopher, with Defense Secretary William J. Perry and the national security adviser, Anthony Lake, in attendance.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Merged Chase Bank Goes to McCann
abstract: The bank to be created March 31 by the merger of the Chemical Banking Corporation and the Chase Manhattan Corporation said yesterday that it had named McCann-Erickson New York to handle the retail portion of its account, with billings estimated at more than $50 million. The merged bank also selected Wells Rich Greene BDDP in New York to handle corporate advertising aimed at large businesses; those billings were not disclosed.         McCann New York, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, has handled the retail banking business for Chemical. The agency was awarded the highly prized retail account of the merged bank, which will carry the Chase name, after a six-week review that had also included Wells Rich, a unit of BDDP Worldwide that has handled retail assignments for Chase.

headline: Israel and Syria Upbeat as Early Talks Close
abstract: Israeli and Syrian negotiators today concluded six days of preliminary talks  on a possible peace agreement that Secretary of State Warren Christopher said were marked by "a new sense of pragmatism" and a "mutuality of purpose" that were missing in the past.

headline: Intel Sets Record In Nasdaq Trade
abstract: The shares of the Intel Corporation set a record yesterday for the most actively traded stock on a single day ever on the Nasdaq market.         More than 68.3 million shares changed hands after the country's biggest semiconductor company posted disappointing earnings after the close of trading on Tuesday.

headline: Technology: CONNECTIONS;Cyborgs 'R' (Almost) Us, or how we may be turning into a multimedia experience.
abstract: WE have seen them stitched together out of body parts like Frankenstein's monster and created from tin scraps like something out of Frank L. Baum's Oz. They have been molded from invading alien pods that snatch earthling's bodies and constructed out of $6 million worth of bionic flesh. We have watched them change form like futuristic Terminators and mutate into semi-animalistic beings  like Wolverine or bizarre X-Men shunned by normal society.         They are the cyborgs -- beings that are transformed humans, created by odd marriages of flesh and technology, mutants constructed by accident or design into a new shape. There has probably been no more plentiful populace in science  fiction and comic books. And during the last decade, the pace of their troubled  evolution has picked up in films ranging from "Robocop" to "Johnny Mnemonic."

headline: Rabin's Killer Fit for Trial
abstract: Israeli psychiatrists who examined Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin's confessed assassin, Yigal Amir, have concluded that he is fit to stand trial, Mr. Amir's lawyer said today.         Judges hearing the case gave defense lawyers the results of the psychiatric exam performed by three state psychiatrists.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;BET Rejects Offer For Units by Rentokil
abstract: A takeover bid for the British business services company BET P.L.C. took an unusual twist yesterday when the company said Rentokil P.L.C. wanted to make a partial offer for its textile and distribution divisions and most of its business services, including electronic security units.         BET rejected the approach, saying that it saw "no benefit for shareholders in discussing the sale of key strategic businesses with strong growth prospects and attractive margins." It said such a sale would have left it with only plant services and its resorts and conference management business.

headline: Simpson Reaches Accord With Citrus Board
abstract: O. J. Simpson and the Florida Department of Citrus reached an agreement last  week to share marketing rights to the initials O. J.         Mr. Simpson applied for a trademark of his first and middle names, Orenthal James, in July 1994, about a month after he was accused of murdering his former  wife, Nicole Brown Simpson, and her friend Ronald L. Goldman. The application is being considered by the Federal Patent and Trademark Office.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
abstract: USAir, Airlington, Va., to Earle Palmer Brown, New York, to handle its consolidated direct marketing account, which was previously handled by various agencies on a project basis. The billings were estimated at $3 million to $4 million. The agency's Bethesda, Md., office handles the general advertising account.

headline: THE NEXT WONDER: A special report.;Cracks Show Early in China's Big Dam Project
abstract: From horizon to horizon, the ancient landscape here has been sundered, scored and stripped by the big steel blades of countless front-end loaders. Dust storms rise from monster truck caravans hauling a million boulders across a riven plain to the place where the Three Gorges Dam is to emerge, eventually, to mount and tame the timeless and often devastating flood of the Yangtze River.         Mountains are disappearing and a new concrete topography is rising in their place, connected in a manmade design whose foundations are being laid across a dust bowl so broad that it seems almost planetary in scale.

headline: OUTLOOK '96: THE ECONOMY;Sideshows Aside, Economy Is Still Key to Election
abstract: WHAT will turn on -- or turn off -- the voters in 1996? Bob Dole's back-and-forth position on abortion? Bill Clinton's taste for the fast lane and  fast food? The Gingrich who stole Medicare?         Answer: None of the above. Again, it is the economy that matters most. The choice Americans make in Presidential elections, according to two statistical models produced by Ivy League researchers, are more directly tied to their perceived financial security than to any other factor. And strikingly, both models predict an exceptionally close contest in 1996.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;FINGERHUT REPORTS EARNINGS AND CONSIDERS SPINOFFS
abstract: The Fingerhut Companies said yesterday that it had hired Smith Barney Inc. and Bear, Stearns & Company to provide advice on a possible spinoff of its financial products and information services units. The company's core business is the marketing of consumer products through catalogues and on television. The  company, based in Minnetonka, Minn., also reported yesterday that its net income rose to $30.3 million, or 63 cents a share, in the fourth quarter. That compares with net income of $12.7 million in the corresponding period a year earlier, when the company took a one-time after-tax charge of $19.4 million. Analysts surveyed by Zacks Investment Research expected earnings of 67 cents a share for the most recent quarter.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: TECHNOLOGY: DIGITAL COMMERCE;In the quest to sort through a sea of Web data, a sudden flash of light.
abstract: WITH some 16 million pages on the World Wide Web, a gazillion entertainment titles, and oceans of data on big-ticket products like cars, soon we will need the rest of our lives to find what we want.         For many years, performing this hunter-gatherer function has been the promise of software agents. Researchers have long promised that these chunks of computer code, imbued with your preferences and the authority to make decisions  about them, will be able to comb computer networks and data to deliver to you the information, products or services you want, without requiring your active involvement.

headline: A Panel Is Formed On Meatpacking
abstract: Dan Glickman, Agriculture Secretary, appointed a panel today to determine whether large meatpackers use their market power to hold down prices for cattle  and hogs.         Mr. Glickman named the 21-member panel after a $500,000 Agriculture Department study failed to come up with evidence that large companies manipulate prices. Mr. Glickman said the study did not go far enough.

headline: Markets Closed
abstract: All financial and commodity markets and banks in the United States were closed yesterday in observance of Washington's Birthday. Most overseas markets were open.

headline: Islamic Group Vows Revenge On Americans
abstract: The most powerful group of Muslim militants in Egypt has vowed to strike at American "interests and people" in revenge for the life sentence for Sheik Omar  Abdel Rahman.         "The Americans have chosen war with Islam," the Islamic Group said in a faxed statement obtained by the Reuters news agency today. "The Gamaa al-Islamiya announces its vow to God that it will respond blow for blow. American interests  and people will be legitimate targets."

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;AT&T Loses $2.68 Billion In Quarter
abstract: The AT&T Corporation reported a fourth-quarter loss of $2.68 billion yesterday, reflecting $6.25 billion in previously announced write-offs associated with a planned reorganization and efforts to cut 40,000 people from the company's payroll.         While the write-offs had been expected, AT&T's operating income for the last  quarter was slightly below consensus expectations. Earnings were hurt by continued trouble at NCR, the company's computer subsidiary that is about to be  spun off as a separate company, and tepid growth in the sale of business and consumer communications equipment.

headline: TOBACCO'S BROKEN LINE: THE STRATEGIST;Tobacco Industry Split Might Benefit Financier
abstract: Bennett S. LeBow, a one-time computer scientist, has a reputation for clever  financial dealings that sometimes raise eyebrows on Wall Street. But his deals have never seemed very important to the broader public.         Now, however, he has split his minor player in the tobacco industry, the Liggett Group, apart from the industry giants in their legal battles, and has done so in a way that might make it easier for him to take control of one of the giants, the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation.

headline: Arafat's Police Hunt Bombers, Pushed Hard by Israelis
abstract: The Palestinian police, investigating two suicide bombings that killed 27 people on Sunday, rounded up scores of Islamic militants today in the West Bank  and Gaza and identified two Palestinians as suspects, saying they have been missing from their homes at a refugee camp in Hebron for several days.         Later the Israeli military chief met with Yasir Arafat, the leader of the Palestinian Authority, to tell him face to face that Israel expected a tougher crackdown than ones he has initiated in the past.

headline: World News Briefs;20 Arab Ministers Pledge Not to Support Terrorism
abstract: Interior ministers from 20 Arab countries agreed today to cooperate more closely in their fight against "terrorism," a term generally used by them to refer to militant Muslim fundamentalists.         The accord was unanimously adopted by the 20 members of the Arab League, said Prince Nayef bin Abdul-Aziz, the Saudi Arabian Interior Minister.

headline: Candy Maker Is Cutting Back
abstract: Leaf Inc., the maker of Milk Duds and Good & Plenty and one of the largest confectionery companies in the nation, said today that it had cut 20 jobs at its headquarters here and that it would sell several of its well-known candy brands.         Leaf, a unit of the Finnish consumer products company Huhtamaki Oy, makes chocolate, hard and soft candy and gum. Its other brands include Jolly Rancher,  PayDay, Heath, Whoppers, and Xylifresh gum.

headline: Company Briefs
abstract: PLATE GLASS AND SHATTERPRUFE INDUSTRIES LTD., Johannesburg, South Africa, a glass maker, said its Windshields America unit would merge with U.S. Auto Glass  to create the largest automotive glass replacement company in the United States.

headline: Overhaul of Rules Is Proposed For Savings-and-Loan Industry
abstract: The Office of Thrift Supervision proposed a major overhaul of lending rules today for savings and loan associations to bring the regulations in line with other banking regulations.         The proposed changes would allow expansion of commercial lending by certain savings-and-loan subsidiaries and relax some investment restrictions, but would  not weaken reforms passed by Congress in the late 1980's during the savings-and-loan crisis.

headline: Agreement Reached in Wellpoint Deal
abstract: Blue Cross of California reached a definitive agreement today to recapitalize Wellpoint Health Networks Inc. in a deal that will result in a charitable foundation initially holding more than 80 percent of the new Wellpoint.         Wellpoint said that its shareholders would receive a cash dividend of $10 a share in the transaction, which also contemplates a 2-for-3 reverse split of Wellpoint common stock.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEXINGTON CORPORATE PROPERTIES INC., New York, the real estate investment trust, agreed to acquire the headquarters of Northwest Pipeline Corp. in Salt Lake City for $57.6 million.

headline: World News Briefs;Nearly 50 Believed Dead As Philippine Ferry Sinks
abstract: Close to 50 people were believed dead after a ferry capsized in the central Philippines, the coast guard said today.         It said that 32 bodies had been found and that 14 people were still missing.  Radio reports said 52 people were dead and 126 were rescued.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;SALEM SAYS IT WILL NO LONGER SEEK BIDS FOR THE COMPANY
abstract: The Salem Corporation, which manufactures equipment for use in the coal and metals industries, said yesterday that it would no longer seek bids for the company. The concern, based in Pittsburgh, said that it had terminated its contract with the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation and that it had told the special negotiating committee and its counsel to cease activities. Salem said it had received no firm offers, though discussions with potential acquirers would continue. Salem also said inquiries from "financially  responsible" bidders would be welcomed.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: SWING-N-SLIDE CORP., Janesville, Wis., a maker of wooden playground equipment, said that Greengrass Holding had agreed to buy up to 59 percent of its common shares outstanding for $6.50 each in a tender offer valued at $22.8 million.

headline: Sacre Bleu! French Film a la Hollywood;Art Cinema Is Forced to Confront the Unthinkable: Crass Commercialism
abstract: France's troubled movie industry has long resisted change because change would mean abandoning its artistic tradition and surrendering to the commercialism of Hollywood. But change may be coming anyway, not from Hollywood  but from the television companies that are fast emerging as leading financiers of French films.         In truth, television companies have already "saved" the industry because they are required by law both to invest in French movies and to broadcast a quota of  French films each year. "French cinema would have died 10 or 15 years ago without television," said Ronan Girre, who runs the movie branch of the Government-owned France 3 television channel.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;PRIMECO TO BUY VIBROPLANT U.S. FOR $67.5 MILLION
abstract: Primeco Inc. said yesterday that it would purchase Vibroplant U.S. Inc. from  Vibroplant P.L.C. in a deal valued at $67.5 million, including the payment of existing debt. Primeco is owned by Investcorp S.A., a privately held merchant bank in New York. In conjunction with the transaction, Investcorp agreed to invest an additional $10 million in Primeco. Dallas-based Vibroplant U.S. is a heavy-equipment rental business, also known as American Hi-Lift Corporation, and has annual revenue of about $50 million. Vibroplant P.L.C. said in July that it would sell American Hi-Lift to focus on its British operations. Primeco supplies equipment to construction and industrial markets in the United States and has 72 rental outlets.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;MONEY MANAGER RAISES HIS COMPANY'S STAKE IN DIAL
abstract: The Heine Securities Corporation, the investment company controlled by the money manager Michael Price, has raised its stake in the Dial Corporation to 8.8 percent from 1.33 percent of the common shares outstanding. Heine bought almost  6.6 million Dial common shares between Dec. 19 and yesterday at $27.62 to $32.47 each, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Dial shares closed yesterday at $32.75, up $1.625. Dial, which is based in Phoenix, makes Dial soap, Brillo pads and other household products.

headline: JOB CUTS AT AT&T WILL TOTAL 40,000, 13% OF ITS STAFF
abstract: The AT&T Corporation announced the biggest single job cut in the history of the telephone business yesterday, and one of the largest corporate work-force reductions ever, as the company braces for a new wave of competition in the communications industry.         AT&T said it would eliminate 40,000 of its 300,000 jobs over the next three years and take a $6 billion charge against earnings, all in preparation for splitting itself into three companies by the end of this year. Up to 7,000 of the cuts will occur in New Jersey, where AT&T has its headquarters at Basking Ridge. With 48,000 employees statewide, AT&T is New Jersey's largest employer.

headline: Pepsico's Top Executive Is Set to Resign
abstract: Pepsico Inc. said today that Wayne Calloway, its chairman and chief executive, would resign and turn over the reins to Roger Enrico, the company's No. 2 executive.         Mr. Calloway -- who has led the soft-drink, restaurant and snack-food giant for 10 years -- said he was stepping down to make room for new leaders and because he continued to require treatment for prostate cancer.

headline: FUTURES MARKETS;Oil Prices Gain on Low Stocks During Cold in U.S. and Europe
abstract: Crude and heating oil prices rose on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday as frigid weather in the United States and Europe increased heating needs while stockpiles remained lower than last year.         The cold air that blanketed the Eastern United States could last for more than a week, driving up demand for heating oil. And low temperatures in Europe may be diverting cargoes of heating oil originally bound for the United States.  Inventories are about 15 percent lower than a year ago.

headline: Airbus Itching To Build Its Own Superjumbo Jet
abstract: SINGAPORE—  Airbus Industrie, stung by the recent loss of aircraft orders in Asia worth nearly $17 billion to Boeing Co., is hastening moves to build a superjumbo jet to compete with its American rival, officials said Monday.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;HASBRO INC. (HAS,A)
abstract: Hasbro Inc. said fourth-quarter earnings rose 12 percent, beating estimates on Wall Street.         Net income rose to $85.2 million, or 97 cents a share. Wall Street had expected the maker of G.I. Joe and the Monopoly board game to earn 92 cents a share, based on a survey by Zacks Investment Research. Revenue rose 8.4 percent, to $1.02 billion.

headline: FUNDS WATCH;Crunching Numbers Beyond the Border
abstract: Fund managers who rely on quantitative analysis -- meaning that they use computers to analyze reams of data and come up with good stock prospects -- have had a mediocre record abroad.         Citing poor performance, the Vanguard Group recently dismissed Batterymarch Financial Management as the adviser to its Trustees Equity International fund. When it came to foreign stock markets, Batterymarch's quantitative approach proved disappointing. Over the last five years, the fund's 8.6 average annualized return trailed the 9.7 percent of its benchmark, the Europe Australia Far East index. The fund is now managed by UBS International Investment London,  a unit of Union Bank of Switzerland. UBS looks for large and midsize stocks using a traditional value approach.

headline: Unilever Agrees to Buy Helene Curtis
abstract: Helene Curtis Industries agreed yesterday to be acquired by the British-Dutch consumer-products giant Unilever P.L.C. for $70 a share, or $770 million in cash, marking yet another big consolidation in the highly competitive global personal- and beauty-care products industry.         Unilever will also assume $145 million of Helene Curtis debt, bringing the total value of the deal to $915 million. The merger will give Unilever a powerful new presence in the United States shampoo and deodorant market.

headline: U.S. Vulnerable to Terrorist Chemical Weapons
abstract: The United States is "very poorly" equipped to defend itself against a terrorist group armed with nuclear, biological or chemical weapons, the Director of Central Intelligence, John M. Deutch, testified today.         "The ability of our country or, I might say, any other country in the developed world to protect their infrastructure from a terrorist attack based on nuclear, chemical or biological weapons is very, very small indeed," he told a Senate Armed Services subcommittee.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;CONSOLIDATION AND 1,000 LAYOFFS BY ALLEGHENY POWER
abstract: Allegheny Power System Inc. said yesterday that it planned to dismiss 1,000 employees, or about 17 percent of its work force, to compete better in a deregulating electric power industry. The cuts will result in a pretax charge of $75 million to $100 million and will be carried out over the next two years. The power company has about 5,750 employees. New York-based Allegheny also said it would consolidate operating divisions at its three main subsidiaries, Monongahela Power, Potomac Edison and West Penn Power.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt

headline: A Freer Vietnam Brings Rise in Violent Crime
abstract: When Tran Ngoc Bich, a 19-year-old honor student, was found bludgeoned to death in her own bedroom, apparently the victim of a burglar, it was a brutal example of the rise in violent crime in Vietnam.        Miss Bich, a sociology student at the Ho Chi Minh Institute of Marxist and Leninist Thought, was held up as a model for other students. Because she was so  young and her death so violent, the killing has shaken the authorities and citizens alike. But such brutality is not as unusual as it once was, say those who have watched violent crime climb as Vietnam moves from an authoritarian system to one that allows a freer way of life. And crimes like these have jolted Vietnamese into acknowledging the dark side of the country's rapid economic growth and emergence from years of international isolation.

headline: SPENDING IT;American Express May Offer a Tax-Service Discount
abstract: THE American Express Company, out to lure new clients for its growing tax and business services unit, may add tax preparation next year to its list of perks provided to card holders. But the deal may come with strings attached.

headline: Stocks Slip in Japan
abstract: Stocks were retrenching a bit here today. At the midday break, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 177.20 points, or nearly six-tenths of 1 percent, at 20,500.80. On Thursday, the first trading day of the year here , the Nikkeisoared 749.85 points, or 3.77 percent, to 20,618.00, its highest finish since Sept. 2, 1994.

headline: Bosnia Bridge Just the First Headache
abstract: Not since World War II has crossing a river posed such a challenge to the United States military.         When Army engineers finally spanned the unruly Sava River on Sunday, opening  a narrow gateway for the first American armor to rumble into Bosnia, Pentagon officials sighed with relief. Flooding, bad weather and other snags had bedeviled the building of the 650-yard pontoon bridge and embarrassed Army officers who initially promised to have the bridge up by Christmas Day.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;EASTMAN CHEMICAL SEES LOWER-THAN-EXPECTED INCOME
abstract: Citing suppressed profit margins, the Eastman Chemical Company said yesterday that it expected its first-quarter earnings to fall below analysts' estimates. The company, a maker of chemicals, fibers and plastics, said its profitability had been hurt by lower selling prices, while raw material and energy costs had not fallen accordingly. The company did not say exactly what it will earn for the quarter ending March 31 but did say analysts' consensus earnings estimate of $1.64 a share was "aggressive." In the first quarter a year ago, Eastman earned $132 million, or $1.58 a share, on revenue of $1.2 billion.

headline: Grand Jury Raises Possibility That Grace Violated Criminal Law
abstract: W. R. Grace & Company said yesterday that a Federal grand jury had raised the possibility that the company violated criminal laws while seeking to persuade the Federal Food and Drug Administration to allow Grace to resume imports in 1991 from its dialysis products factory in Dublin, Ireland.         The announcement added details to previous company disclosures that it was the subject of three Federal investigations.

headline: Russian Miners Strike, Defying Yeltsin
abstract: Defying the President they helped bring to power five years ago, nearly half  a million Russian coal miners went on strike today to demand $200 million in unpaid wages.         So did one million coal miners in Ukraine, who say they are owed $367 million in back pay.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;INTUIT'S PROFITS RISE, BUT ITS STOCK SLIPS
abstract: Intuit Inc. said yesterday that its second-quarter earnings rose 50 percent,  but its stock fell after the company projected only modest revenue growth from its Quicken personal finance software this year. Intuit earned $21.9 million, or 46 cents a share in the quarter, which ended on Jan. 31, compared with $14.6 million, or 33 cents, in the corresponding period a year earlier. Revenues rose  32 percent, to $221.7 million. Revenues are expected to grow 30 percent in the second half of the year, but profits are expected to remain flat because of lower-margin sales of Quicken, higher expenses for its electronic banking service and difficulties in Germany, the company said. "While Quicken's total unit volumes are growing well, we expect only modest Quicken revenue growth" for 1996, the company's chairman, Scott D. Cook, said. The announcement came after the stock market closed, but the company's shares tumbled $4 in after-hours trading, to $62.75. Earlier, the shares rose $2 in Nasdaq trading.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;SARA LEE NEGOTIATING TO BUY SOME BAYER PRODUCTS
abstract: The Sara Lee Corporation said yesterday that it was negotiating to buy several product lines from the consumer care division of Germany's Bayer A.G. An agreement is expected to be reached in the coming months, Sara Lee said in a statement. The product lines include the brands, trademarks and related fixed assets of Delial cosmetic sun protection products, Satina skin care products, Quenty facial care products and Natreen/Natrena tabletop sweeteners and low-calorie food, Sara Lee said. Total sales of the products were about $155 million in the 1995 fiscal year, the company said.

headline: Greenspan Calls the Fed 'Extraordinarily Well Run'
abstract: Responding to a Congressional report that was critical of the Federal Reserve's management of its finances, Alan Greenspan today defended his record as chairman of the central bank at a Senate hearing on his nomination to a third term, calling the Federal Reserve "an extraordinarily well-run organization."         On a day in which the Federal Reserve's monetary policy committee decided to  leave interest rates unchanged, Mr. Greenspan also gave a relatively upbeat though brief assessment of the economy, saying it was operating at a "reasonably good clip" with unemployment "lower than it's been at any time in the recent past."

headline: Anti-U.S. Bomb Baffles Saudi Officials and F.B.I.
abstract: Nearly two months after a car bomb here killed seven people, including five Americans, the authorities have made little progress in identifying the attackers, Saudi officials and Western diplomats say.         At least three Saudi opposition groups have declared responsibility for the attack, on Nov. 13, which ripped the face from a downtown building used by United States military personnel to train the Saudi National Guard. But officials from the Federal Bureau of Investigation and their Saudi counterparts  say they have not yet reached even a preliminary conclusion about whether such assertions are valid.

headline: Mexico City Journal;At 95, Still Labor's King, but Ruling Party's Vassal
abstract: The old man with ashes on his sleeve was born with the century. He was once a fiery rebel, but the fight went out of him long ago. Now it is cooperation, not  confrontation, that he seeks.         More than just another sign of advanced age, the pragmatism that today characterizes Fidel Velazquez Sanchez provides a clue to one of Mexico's more perplexing modern mysteries: how has the country managed to keep from blowing up in the face of one of its worst economic and political crises since the 1910-1919 revolution?

headline: Dime Officers Are Indicted
abstract: Seven former loan officers of Dime Savings Bank, a unit of Dime Bancorp, were indicted today by a Federal grand jury on charges that they falsified home mortgage loan documents in New Hampshire in the late 1980's.         The indictment contended that Phillip Thibeau, former sales manager of Dime Real Estate Services of New Hampshire Inc., told loan officers to lie on loan applications to help unqualified buyers get mortgage loans.

headline: Canada, Backed by Mexico, Protests to U.S. on Cuba Sanctions
abstract: In a sign of the growing tensions between the United States and its trading partners over stepped-up American sanctions against Cuba, Canada said today that it had lodged a trade protest with the Clinton Administration, and Mexico immediately asked to join Canadian-American discussions on the issue.         Responding to a new American law that seeks to tighten the economic vise on Cuba by putting pressure on other countries not to do business with Fidel Castro's Government, Canada said it asked for consultations with the United States under the terms of the North American Free Trade Agreement.

headline: Posting Matter From Church On Internet Is Ruled Illegal
abstract: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that a Virginia man violated the copyrights of the Church of Scientology by posting confidential church documents on the Internet, even though the material was obtained from public court records.         The Religious Technology Center, which owns the trademarks and copyrights of  the Church of Scientology International, had sued Arnaldo P. Lerma of Arlington, Va., for posting several dozen pages of secret church documents about the Scientologist philosophy on the Internet, the global computer network.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Tobacco Industry Inquiries Have Quietly Broadened The Justice Department has expanded an array of criminal and civil inquiries into the tobacco industry, lawyers say. While department officials had cautioned earlier that indictments were unlikely, the tobacco companies' aura of invincibility in court has been weakened by industry whistle-blowers, disclosures of internal company documents and an agreement by the Liggett Group  to settle its part of a class-action suit against the major tobacco companies. [Page A1.] Progress in G.M. Talks After a weekend of negotiations, representatives of General Motors and the United Auto Workers seemed optimistic about settling a 12-day strike at two brake plants that has forced the closure of 24 assembly plants and idled tens of thousands of workers. [A10.]

headline: Caldor President To Leave Post
abstract: The Caldor Corporation said yesterday that Marc I. Balmuth, its president for nine years, would not renew his contract when it expires this summer.         "I have decided not to renew my contract for personal reasons," Mr. Balmuth said in a statement. He did not return phone calls made to his office.

headline: 2 Deaths in Israel, and the Stark Echoes at Home
abstract: This morning's prayer service at The Frisch School ended the way another service did 10 months ago, with a remembrance of a vibrant young graduate killed in a suicide bomber's attack on an Israeli bus.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Business Week Reports Possible Violations Linked to Column
abstract: Business Week magazine said yesterday that it had noticed a pattern of suspicious trading in stocks recommended in its "Inside Wall Street" column and  that it had notified Federal regulators and stock exchange surveillance officials.         In the issue that will arrive on newsstands today, the magazine writes that in August it began noticing that stocks mentioned in its Wall Street column experienced sudden surges in trading volume on the day before the magazine was distributed to readers.

headline: Polaroid Organizes Into 3 Businesses
abstract: The Polaroid Corporation said today that it would separate its operations into three business groups in an effort to return the company to profitability.          Polaroid, which makes instant film and digital imaging equipment, said each of the three units -- consumer, commercial and new business -- would be responsible for its own product development, marketing and profit. The company also said seven officers would leave.

headline: Lawyer's Investment Plan Is the Target of Two Inquiries
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission and the Manhattan District Attorney's  office are conducting inquiries into an investment scheme run by a New York lawyer that may have bilked dozens of lawyers, businessmen and others of up to $100 million.         The reputed Ponzi-type scheme offered participants returns of 60 percent on their investments in a business that was to purchase premium Scotch whiskies and other quality liquors for resale in Asia. But the deal went bust last summer, three years after it started, when investors said they discovered that early returns did not reflect business profits but had been paid out of a growing pool of investments.

headline: 16 French Hostages Freed
abstract: Under threat of military attack, tribesmen today released 16 French tourists  held in the remote mountains of Yemen.         Security sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the tourists were  released shortly after the expiration of a deadline set by the authorities. All were in good condition, the sources said.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Top Appointments At 3 Agencies
abstract: Three agencies are making top-level appointments.         Helene Cote, 41, has joined the New York office of Rapp Collins Worldwide, the direct marketing unit of the Omnicom Group, as executive creative director.  She succeeds Jerry Genova, who left. Ms. Cote had been a senior art director at  Anderson & Lembke in San Francisco, which is owned by the Interpublic Group of Companies.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;Ford Quits Test Of Engelhard's Smog Reducer
abstract: The promise of the Engelhard Corporation's new smog-reducing technology dimmed yesterday, as the company announced that the Ford Motor Company, which has been conducting an exclusive test of the technology, had decided not to use  it.         In April, after Engelhard announced with great fanfare that a catalytic coating it had developed would sharply reduce ozone and other pollutants, the company's shares surged. But when the company said in November that the benefits from the new system were "less than originally projected," the share price plunged.

headline: Barnett Banks To Merge Units
abstract: Barnett Banks Inc. is planning to streamline its operations, merging its 32 banking units into five.         Barnett, the biggest Florida-based banking company, said it would combine 28  of its banks and several nonbank affiliates into a new subsidiary, Barnett Bank N.A.

headline: Business Advice From the Sidelines;It's Management By Game Theory
abstract: Can an N.B.A. coach offer an M.B.A. anything besides entertainment?         Phil Jackson and Pat Riley think so. Mr. Jackson, coach of the Chicago Bulls, the leading team in the National Basketball Association, turned his hardwood lessons into a new book, "Sacred Hoops." His debut on the management bookshelves follows the motivational success of Mr. Riley, author of "The Winner Within" and the former coach of the Los Angeles Lakers and New York Knicks who now leads the Miami Heat.

headline: Shutdown Affecting Rate Policy
abstract: Alan Blinder, the vice chairman of the Federal Reserve, said last night that  the temporary halt in the Government's release of economic reports had made it more difficult for the Fed to set interest-rate policy. The Government has stopped publishing the reports as a result of the partial shutdown.         Speaking in New York at a conference of the Mortgage Bankers Association of America, Mr. Blinder said the delay in economic reports would not prevent the Fed from considering interest-rate policy at the next meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee on Jan. 30 and 31.

headline: U.N. Agencies Feeling the Pain as the U.S. Lags on Payments
abstract: Congressional reluctance to provide money for international organizations combined with Clinton Administration delays in allocating the scarce funds that  are available have begun to cut into a wide range of United Nations programs, many of which serve the world's poorest countries.         At the World Health Organization, the failure of the United States to pay any of its 1995 assessment has forced reductions in global surveillance systems tracking epidemic diseases and in programs to provide expert assistance to vulnerable countries.

headline: Valujet to Fly Into New York At a Discount
abstract: Discount airlines are beginning to elbow their way into La Guardia Airport in New York, long a bastion of the business traveler paying top-dollar fares.         Valujet Airlines, a fast-growing, low-fare carrier based in Atlanta, said yesterday that on May 1, it would begin flying five round trips a day between La Guardia and Atlanta, offering fares as low as $89 each way for advance-purchase  tickets and $149 for last-minute bookings.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;2 Agencies Promote Top Executives
abstract: Young & Rubicam Inc. in New York and BBDO New York have promoted top executives to new positions.         John P. McGarry Jr., 56, who has been chairman and chief executive of Y.& R.  Advertising since January 1994, next month will become president of Y.& R., a new position. Mr. McGarry, 56, will report to Peter A. Georgescu, chairman and chief executive of Y.& R. Edward H. Vick, 52, president and chief executive of the Y.& R. New York office, will succeed Mr. McGarry at Y.& R. Advertising; Mr.  Vick will also continue to oversee Y.& R. New York until a successor is named there.

headline: Do Rights or Economic Growth Come First? Asia and Europe Clash
abstract: I can think of at least 10 issues to seriously embarrass the Europeans," the Indonesian Foreign Minister, Ali Alatas, said as the leaders of 25 Asian and European nations converged here for a meeting on trade and economics that opens  on Friday.         Those pugnacious words highlighted a political culture clash between East and West that has led to weeks of wrangling over the meeting's agenda, with some Asian officials saying the Europeans only want to preach to them.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Rolls Sales Up 10%
abstract: Vickers P.L.C. said yesterday that it had sold 1,556 Rolls-Royce cars in 1995, up 10 percent from 1994. The biggest increases were in North America and South America, where sales rose 25 percent, to 420 cars. In the British market,  sales rose 7 percent, to 493 vehicles. This equaled the 7 percent rise on the Continent, where 230 cars were sold. In Japan, Vickers sold 121 cars, up 4 percent. The only drop was in the Middle East, down 5 percent, to 71 cars.   (Reuters)

headline: OUTLOOK '96: THE ECONOMYThe Economic Consensus on 1996: The Year of the Big Yawn; . . . to Optimism on Everything
abstract: Gail D. Fosler, a former chief economist for the Senate Budget Committee, is  not known as a particularly venturesome forecaster. This year, however, she is much more optimistic than her colleagues: her prediction of 1996 growth was more than three-quarters of a percentage point higher than any other forecaster polled by the newsletter Blue Chip Economic Indicators.         Ms. Fosler, now at the Conference Board, a corporate-sponsored research group, finds economic strength nearly everywhere and does not assume any election-year gunning.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Billion Marks Lost, Shipbuilder To Seek Bankruptcy in Germany
abstract: Bremer Vulkan Verbund A.G., Germany's largest shipbuilder, said today that it had lost one billion marks, or $685 million, in 1995 and would seek court protection from its creditors to avoid bankruptcy.         At the same time, the European Commission, the administrative agency of the European Union, demanded that Bremer Vulkan repay $585 million in aid intended for the company's shipyards in the former East Germany. The commission says the  money was redirected to the struggling company's western German operations.

headline: Industrial Output Plunges, With Bad Weather Cited
abstract: Output at the nation's factories, mines and utilities took its biggest plunge in January since the nation was struggling to emerge from the last recession nearly five years ago, a Government report showed today. But bad weather was cited as a major factor.         The report provided further evidence that the economy slowed sharply in the first quarter. Many economists expect that the growth rate will be 1 percent or  less for the first three months of the year.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                                               Previous      Year                               Yesterday       Day       Ago

headline: Banking Agency Will Not Sue First Lady's Former Law Firm
abstract: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said today that it would not sue Hillary Rodham Clinton's former law firm for its work on behalf of a failed savings and loan that was owned by the Clintons' business partner in the Whitewater real estate venture.         The F.D.I.C.'s report was sent to Congress but not publicly announced. Word of its conclusion was reported tonight by The Washington Post, and Federal officials confirmed that the article was correct.

headline: MUTUAL FUNDS;FUNDS WATCH
abstract: Finding Bargains Against the Flow

headline: Future Communications
abstract: Most of the recent rise in the Dow Jones industrial average has been fueled by interest in technoloby stocks, and investors have turned an even more vigilant eye to that sector of the economy after Congress passed the telecommunications bill last month. In the long run, that legislation allowd local phone operators to compete with long-distance operators and vice versa. And those companies could also compete with cable companies, who, in turn, are faced with increasing competition from some home satellite firms as well as microwave broadcast transmissions.          As last week's acquistion of Continental Cablevision by U S West demonstrates, some companies hope to offer several of these services by themselves. This means that the consumer should enjoy cheaper prices for different types of telecommunication.

headline: 6th French Atom Test Held
abstract: France set off the sixth in a series of nuclear weapons tests in the South Pacific today, the Defense Ministry said.         The tests broke a 1992 moratorium on French nuclear testing, drawing protests from around the world. The first took place on Sept. 5.

headline: Gibson Dismisses Chief and Takes Company Off Selling Block
abstract: Gibson Greetings Inc., the country's third-largest greeting card company, said last night that it had dismissed its chief executive officer and taken the  company off the selling block.         The developments were buried three paragraphs deep in an earnings report that came out several hours after the stock market closed. Moments later, an operator at the Cincinnati-based company said that everyone had left for the day. Calls to two spokesmen were not returned.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Osborn to Buy Stations
abstract: The Osborn Communications Corporation agreed today to acquire radio stations  KNAX-FM and KRBT-FM of Fresno, Calif., for about $7 million in cash and stock. The company said the transaction was subject to the approval of the Federal Communications Commission. Osborn said that pending closing of the transaction, it would manage the stations under a local marketing arrangement.

headline: MUTUAL FUNDS QUARTERLY REPORT;The Forecast Looks Brighter for Adventure Travel
abstract: THIS could be the year that funds venturing into investor-forsaken places like Mexico, the Philippines and other emerging markets are amply rewarded for their daring.

headline: Milken Says He Has Abided by Agreement
abstract: Michael Milken insisted today that no wrongdoing would turn up in the new investigation that led to his being put on probation for an additional three months in Wall Street's biggest securities fraud scandal.
