Mr. Milken says he has abided by his 1990 agreement to be banned from the securities industry. In advising friends -- including Ted Turner, the broadcaster -- he said he had engaged in strategic consultations that did not come close to the limits of his agreement.

headline: Quebec Separatist Becomes Premier, Pledging Economic Agenda
abstract: Lucien Bouchard, Quebec's most popular politician and the man who brought separatist forces to within a whisker of victory in last October's referendum, was sworn in today as the province's 27th Premier, but he promised to boost employment and strengthen public finances before staging another independence vote.         Although most polls indicate that support within Quebec for independence is even higher today than in October, they also point to widespread electoral fatigue after two elections and two referendums in the past four years.

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: ALUMINUM COMPANY OF AMERICA, Pittsburgh, named Robert F. Slagle president for Alcoa World Alumina, responsible for the strategic, commercial and operational activities of Alcoa's global bauxite and alumina activities. Mr. Slagle is now a vice president of Alcoa and managing Director of Alcoa of Australia. He will be  based in Pittsburgh and report to Alain Belda, Alcoa's vice chairman.

headline: VOICES: VIEWPOINT;Who's Afraid of Jobs and Growth?
abstract: BOND and stock markets in shock! Dow plunges 171 points on stunning news of a big gain in jobs in February! Interest rates spike as unemployment drops to 5.5  percent! That was the report a few weeks ago.         But are more jobs bad for the economy? Or just for Wall Street?  Or is something else going on?

headline: Is the House of Lords Next?;Britain Plans to Sell 60,000 Military Dwellings
abstract: In the continuing garage sale that has marked the British Government's exit from the business world over the last 15 years, the latest item up for grabs is  a collection of some 60,000 rather ordinary houses and apartments scattered on and around military bases throughout England and Wales.         With the cold war over, Britain has found itself with an oversupply of housing for married military personnel, and rather than try its hand at being a  landlord, the Government wants to pass the job to the private sector.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;U.S. SHARES OF INSIGNIA SOLUTIONS FALL 55%
abstract: The shares of Insignia Solutions Inc. dropped 55 percent after the software company said that because of weak sales in the United States it had only broken  even in the fourth quarter. American depository receipts of the British company  fell $7.3125 yesterday, to $5.9375, in Nasdaq trading. Insignia said its fourth-quarter revenue was "significantly below" the third quarter's $16.3 million. Insignia writes programs that allow Apple Computer Inc.'s Macintosh computers to run software written for the Microsoft Corporation's Windows operating system. Insignia, which has administrative offices in Mountain View, Calif., had an initial public offering in November.

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: COMPUSERVE CORP., Columbus, Ohio, a unit of H& R Block Inc.,, named Steven P. Stanbrook to the new position of president of the on-line service's international operations. He was most recently president and chief executive of  Sara Lee Bakery in Chicago, which is owned by Sara Lee Corp.

headline: Data on Croatia's Rights Violations Lost in Theft
abstract: Most of the data on human rights violations in Croatia gathered by the United Nations in the last four years have been stolen, United Nations officials said today.         Four computers loaded with information were stolen from the United Nations Center for Human Rights on Friday night or Saturday morning. United Nations officials said the thieves had apparently broken in through a window and also taken a couple of walkie-talkies.

headline: Rome Journal;At 30-Something, Leave Home? Mamma Mia, No!
abstract: It usually takes a lot marriage at least -- for a young Italian man to leave  Mamma. So, with more Italians marrying later in life, more young men are staying home longer and, it seems, enjoying it more.         Giovanni Istroni is a 38-year-old sound technician who lives at home with his mother and two brothers, one 40, the other 35. For reasons that have little do with financial independence, something to do with his mother's cooking and a lot to do with emotional comfort, he sees no need to move out, let alone find a wife.

headline: Number of Religious Broadcasters Continues to Grow
abstract: To judge by the numbers, these are expansive days for Christian radio. Two decades after evangelical Protestant voters emerged as a force in national politics, conservative Christian broadcasters are continuing to carve out a greater share of the radio market.         Last year, the number of radio stations broadcasting 15 or more hours of weekly religious programming rose 10 percent to 1,463, said the National Religious Broadcasters, a trade association in Manassas, Va. That total was nearly double the number 15 years ago.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;MICROS SHARES PLUMMET FOLLOWING EARNINGS FORECAST
abstract: The stock of Micros Systems Inc. lost more than half of its value yesterday after the company warned of disappointing earnings in the third quarter despite  an expected rise in sales. The stock fell $25.75, to $25, in Nasdaq trading. Micros, which makes electronic terminals that perform cash register and data processing functions, said late on Friday that it expected third-quarter profits to lag behind the $2.2 million, or 28 cents a share, it earned in the corresponding period last year. Analysts had expected earnings of 40 cents a share for the quarter this year, according to a First Call survey.

headline: DIARY
abstract: THE ECONOMY Cooling It at the Fed For the most part, this nation's scattered economy has a mind of its own. But if anyone can nudge it this way or that, it's the folks at the Federal Reserve. At  the simplest level, the Fed's choice comes down to this: create jobs and risk inflation, or keep things cool and make the financial markets happy. President Clinton at first wanted a Fed vice chairman, Felix Rohatyn, who would come down  on the side of jobs. But Republicans balked, so last week the ever-flexible Mr.  Clinton reverted to the slow-and-steady approach. He gave Alan Greenspan a third term as chairman; picked Alice Rivlin, his budget director, as vice chairman, and named Laurence Meyer, an economic consultant, to fill a vacant slot. Those choices, Republicans quickly said, were more like it.

headline: Stock Prices Lower, With Dow Falling 14.09
abstract: The stock market took a breather yesterday, with prices lower after Monday's  record-setting performance.         "There was a little bit of profit taking, but that was not surprising after the Dow went up almost 100 points the previous day," said Richard C. Pell, chief investment officer of Bank Julius Baer. "And the big story was Philip Morris."

headline: Stock and Bond Issues Surge During Quarter
abstract: Despite an uptick in interest rates that slowed new debt offerings in March,  Wall Street enjoyed a healthy first quarter.         A buoyant stock market and low interest rates during much of the quarter brought a surge in new stock and bond offerings. Securities firms also benefited from a record volume of company mergers and acquisitions.

headline: Help for Social Security
abstract: To the Editor:         What Social Security and Medicare need most are:

headline: South Africa Opens Doors On a Charter
abstract: It's another meeting of the authors of South Africa's Constitution.         First on the agenda: financial matters. Right away someone objects to the wording of the clause about the Government's right to impose user charges.

headline: Homestake Bulgaria Deal
abstract: The Homestake Mining Company has exercised an option to buy up to 34 percent  more of a gold and copper operation in Bulgaria from Navan Resources P.L.C. for  $48 million. Homestake acquired the option last year when it invested $24 million for a 10 percent stake in Navan, an Irish mining company with mineral interests in Europe.  Homestake will initially pay up to $12 million to Navan Bulgarian Mining B.V., the Navan unit that holds a 68 percent interest in the operation.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Guinness Stock Buyback
abstract: Guinness P.L.C. said yesterday that it was buying back 100 million common shares, or about 4.3 percent of its stock. The stock was up 5.5 pence at 466 on  the London Stock Exchange. The Guinness chairman, Tony Greener, said the buyback was consistent with the company's policy of increasing returns to shareholders.  The company increased its dividends 8 percent on Thursday. Guinness brands include Guinness Stout, Johnnie Walker and Bell's Scotch whisky and Gordon's gin.   (AP)

headline: COMPANY NEWS;SAMSUNG HALVES OUTPUT OF 4-MEGABIT CHIPS
abstract: The Samsung Electronics Company, part of the Samsung Group of South Korea, said yesterday that it would cut monthly production of 4-megabit dynamic random  access memory chips to four million chips from eight million, in an effort to stem declining prices. In the last six months, the price of 4-megabit chips has  fallen sharply. The NEC Corporation and Hitachi Ltd. have also announced plans to cut production of 4-megabit D-RAM chips, switching to the more profitable 16-megabit chip. The moves by Samsung, the world's largest maker of memory chips, and the Japanese companies will reduce global output of the 4-megabit D-RAM to 31 million in the second half of 1996 from 50.5 million a month now, Samsung said.

headline: EARNING IT;Life of a Cold Caller: Riding on a Smile and a Thick Skin
abstract: EVELYN WILEY'S desk is unadorned. No family pictures. No mementos or favorite sayings. The only thing distinguishing it is a small hand mirror perched on the  keyboard of her computer.         She keeps it there to see if she's smiling. If she is, chances are she's selling.

headline: Correction
abstract: An article on Feb. 11, about the effect of spurned takeover bids on the stock price of the target companies, referred incorrectly to a stock split by Time Warner Inc. in 1992. The stock had a 4-for-1 split, in which four shares replaced each existing share. It was not a 1-for-4 reverse split.

headline: Aristide Hands Power to Successor in Haiti
abstract: In subdued, even somber ceremonies here today, President Jean-Bertrand Aristide ended a turbulent five-year term by becoming the first elected head of  state in nearly 200 years of Haitian history to peacefully transfer power to a popularly chosen successor.         To the applause of Haitian and foreign dignitaries well aware of both the significance and the high cost of his investiture by democratic means, the country's new President, Rene Garcia Preval, promised to duplicate Mr. Aristide's achievement.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;In Germany, Downsizing Means 10.3% Jobless
abstract: Corporate Germany has been producing a drumbeat of layoffs, downsizings, bankruptcies and the flight of jobs abroad. Individually, none of these has been of the magnitude of AT&T's plan to slash 40,000 jobs, but taken together they are producing the grimmest employment prospects in Europe's largest economy since the end of World War II.         That reality was graphically confirmed today when the Government announced that the jump in unemployment in February was twice what economists had expected, and that joblessness was now higher than in almost half a century.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;You can put a price on 'the most glamorous night of the year.'
abstract: ON no map does Madison Avenue run through Hollywood. But come Monday, when ABC broadcasts the 68th annual Academy Awards ceremony, advertisers and agencies will be as intrinsic a part of filmdom as avaricious agents and actors who insist, "What I really want to do is direct."         Eleven blue-chip marketers including Coca-Cola, Eastman Kodak, General Motors and Revlon are paying ABC a record average of $795,000 for each 30-second commercial run during the national portions of the program. That amount -- exceeded only by what networks charge for commercial time during a Super Bowl -- is 16 percent higher than ABC took in for a national spot during the 1995 Academy Awards.

headline: INVESTING IT;Pushing Goodyear To Focus Abroad
abstract: CAN Samir Gibara keep the good news rolling at the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company?         Mr. Gibara, known as Sam, is the Egyptian-born executive who succeeded the near-legendary Stanley Gault in January as the company's chief executive. Mr. Gault, 69, retires as chairman in June, and the Goodyear board has signaled that Mr. Gibara will get the additional title.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;HOSPITALITY PROPERTIES SIGNS DEALS FOR 45 HOTELS
abstract: Hospitality Properties Trust, a real estate investment trust in Newton, Mass., said yesterday that it had signed letters of intent to acquire 45 hotels  and to lease them back to the sellers or to other parties. Hospitality will acquire 11 Wyndham Gardens hotels for $136 million from an affiliate of the Dallas-based Wyndham Hotel Company and will lease them to another Wyndham affiliate. In a second deal, Hospitality will buy 18 Residence Inn hotels from an affiliate of the Host Marriott Corporation for $172.2 million and will lease  them to a Hospitality affiliate. Hospitality will also acquire 16 Courtyard by Marriott hotels for $176.4 million and will lease them to Host Marriott affiliates. Hospitality will own 82 hotels in 26 states after the transactions close.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Trade Group Orders U.S. To Alter Law For First Time
abstract: In its first major ruling as the international arbiter, the World Trade Organization determined today that a key section of the Clean Air Act discriminated against foreign oil refiners. It ordered the United States to develop a plan to change its rules on imported gasoline or face unspecified sanctions.         It was not immediately clear what the consequences of the ruling, which concerned the law's standards for reformulated gasoline, might be. Administration officials said tonight that they had not decided whether they would appeal.

headline: U.S. Business Cutting Plans For Spending
abstract: American businesses plan to spend only slightly more this year than in 1995 on new buildings and equipment, marking a sharp slowdown in an important sector  of the economy, a survey released today by the Commerce Department said.         Overall economic growth has depended heavily in the last several years on capital spending by business, and economists said that today's figures were more evidence that growth this year would be anemic.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;MANVILLE TO PAY SPECIAL DIVIDEND AFTER SALE
abstract: The Manville Corporation said yesterday that it would pay a special dividend  of $6 a share from the sale of its stake in the Riverwood International Corporation to a leveraged-buyout firm. Manville, a maker of building products,  received $1.08 billion, or $20.25 a share, for its 83.3 percent stake in Riverwood, an Atlanta-based paper maker. The buyer was an investment group led by Clayton, Dubilier & Rice, of New York. Manville said the special dividend, involving a total payout of $974 million, would be paid on April 12 to shareholders of record as of April 8. About $772 million of the dividend will be paid to the Manville Personal Injury Settlement Trust, which will use the proceeds to settle claims stemming from the asbestos business of Manville's predecessor, the Johns Manville Corporation. Also, Manville said its shareholders had approved the company's new name, the Schuller Corporation, which is expected to be effective today.

headline: After Ovitz, There's No Room for Mercy in Hollywood Agent Wars
abstract: Competition among Hollywood agents is never a pleasant spectacle to watch. But the new year is expected to reveal the kind of trench warfare among agents that is unusual even by Hollywood's rougher standards.         The decision by Michael Ovitz to leave the Creative Artists Agency in August  and take the No. 2 job at the Walt Disney Company behind Michael D. Eisner was a seismic event, and the tremors are still felt across Hollywood.

headline: Chip Factory for Taiwan
abstract: Texas Instruments-Acer Inc. will spend as much as $1.3 billion to $1.5 billion to build its third memory chip factory in Taiwan, a company executive said today. The latest project will be in a Government-backed technology park in southern Taiwan. Construction will begin at the end of the year. The company, a joint venture of Texas Instruments Inc. and Acer Inc. of Taiwan, recently broke ground on its second factory. That plant is to begin production of 16-megabit chips early next year and eventually shift to 64-megabit chips.

headline: U.S. Tool Orders Up 23% in January
abstract: Orders for American-made industrial tools surged during January from the previous month, the Association for Manufacturing Technology said, suggesting that capital investment by businesses continues to boom.         "We are encouraged that 1996 began on a robust note," Albert Moore, the association's president, said.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;Anheuser-Busch Shutting Its Eagle Snack-Food Unit
abstract: The Anheuser-Busch Companies said today that it had given up a four-month effort to sell its Eagle Snacks unit and would instead close the nation's No. 2  snack-food company and dismiss its 1,750 workers.         Anheuser-Busch of St. Louis, the world's largest brewer, said it was taking a charge of $205.7 million in the fourth quarter in connection with the closing. Anheuser said it would sell four of the unit's five plants to Pepsico Inc.'s Frito-Lay unit, which already has half the United States market for chips and pretzels. Terms of the sale were not disclosed.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                                               Previous      Year                               Yesterday       Day       Ago

headline: U.S. Plan to Change Iran Leaders Is an Open Secret Before It Begins
abstract: In an unusual operation conceived by Speaker Newt Gingrich, the Central Intelligence Agency is to mount a $18 million covert action to change the nature of the Government of Iran. The operation has not started, but the counteroffensive has.         The directive became public here and in Iran three months ago -- long before  it became law. Now the C.I.A. finds itself required, against its better judgment, to plan a "secret" mission, with its cover already blown, in a region  where American policy has suffered failures and fiascos.

headline: Q&A /Pierre Averbuch and Harry Bernas : 2 French Scientists Debate Tests
abstract: France's decision to resume nuclear weapons testing in the South Pacific not only aroused worldwide protest, but also opened an unprecedented breach in the French scientific community. Two leaders of the positions for and against testing, Pierre Averbuch and Harry Bernas, both senior phycisists, debated the issue in Paris last week. Barry James of the International Herald Tribune reported their views.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;CHIEF EXECUTIVE OF HENRY HOLT TO STEP DOWN
abstract: After nearly eight years as president and chief executive of Henry Holt & Company, Bruno A. Quinson said yesterday that he would resign from those posts effective March 31. Mr. Quinson, 58, who will keep an office at the publishing house, was named to Holt's board. He has been credited with a successful expansion by the publisher, which is owned by the German media conglomerate Holtzbrinck. Mr. Quinson is to be replaced by Michael Naumann, the publisher of  Rowohlt Verlag, one of Germany's largest general publishing houses, which is also owned by Holtzbrinck.

headline: A New Paper Accentuates the Positive
abstract: Really and truly, there are many politicians who serve nobly, businesses that are steadily thriving and parents who love and protect their children.         It is just that readers do not often find much about them in the mainstream media's usual doom-mongering coverage of crime, war, disaster and economic woes.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;QUORUM HEALTH ENDS MERGER TALKS AND ITS STOCK FALLS
abstract: Quorum Health Group Inc., which operates hospitals and provides hospital consulting services, said yesterday that it had ended talks with another health  care company about a possible merger. Quorum, based in Brentwood, Tenn., disclosed the talks last week but did not identify the company. Its shares, which rose after last week's announcement, fell $3.25 yesterday, to $24.75, in Nasdaq trading.   (Dow Jones)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Bankruptcies Expected For Fokker Companies
abstract: Ben van Schaik, chairman of the troubled Dutch aircraft maker Fokker N.V., said yesterday that Fokker Holding N.V. and Fokker N.V. would be declared bankrupt even if the business units of the company were allowed to continue to operate. In an interview with Dutch television, Mr. van Schaik said he wanted banks, administrators and the Government to provide more clarity this week on the future of Fokker. Fokker's principal owner Daimler-Benz of Germany, recently said it was discontinuing financial help for Fokker.          Fokker's administrators are talking to Samsung of Korea and Avic of China about a possible rescue of the aircraft production unit, Fokker Aircraft B.V. The administrators are also discussing Fokker's future with a number of Dutch   companies, including the machinery maker Stork.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: COMPANY NEWS;LITTON INDUSTRIES BUYS SPERRY MARINE
abstract: Litton Industries Inc. will purchase Sperry Marine Inc., a maker of navigation and guidance systems, for about $160 million, the companies said yesterday. Litton, which makes military electronics systems as well as destroyers for the Navy, will give Sperry's owner, the investment partnership J. F. Lehman & Company, two million shares of common stock and will assume Sperry's $52 million debt. Additionally, it will purchase the company's preferred stock, worth about $7 million. Sperry is based in Charlottesville, Va., and its  operations will remain in Virginia. In New York Stock Exchange trading yesterday, shares of Litton closed unchanged at $49.25 before the deal was announced. Sperry's 1995 sales totaled $145 million. Litton's sales last year were $3.32 million.

headline: Saks Planning Stock Offering And Growth In Outlet Stores
abstract: Saks Fifth Avenue, that icon of luxury goods and urban elegance, is looking to outlet stores in the suburbs for its future growth.         Investcorp, the company that owns Saks, disclosed the retailer's expansion plans yesterday when it announced its much-anticipated initial public offering of Saks's stock, which it hopes will raise $300 million.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;SHARES OF CEPHALON SINK ON F.D.A. MOVE
abstract: Shares of Cephalon Inc. plunged 34 percent yesterday after the company said late on Thursday that the Food and Drug Administration had declined to permit expanded clinical tests of its treatment for Lou Gehrig's disease. The company's stock had risen sharply in expectation of speedy F.D.A. approval of broader trials for the drug, Myotrophin. The Chiron Corporation, which is Cephalon's marketing partner for Myotrophin, has also benefited from investor optimism. The F.D.A.'s concerns apparently are related to a trial in Europe, reported in November, in which the mortality rate of treated patients was nearly twice that  of patients taking a placebo. Cephalon stock was down $12.50, to $23.375 a share, in Nasdaq trading. Chiron's shares were down $5.50, at $104 each. Lou Gehrig's disease is a progressive paralysis.

headline: It's a New Season For the Economy;Some of Winter's Worries Linger But Growth Is on the Rebound
abstract: Beverly B. Miller, president of a company that manufactures packaging equipment, first noticed the change in late February. Calls to her sales force surged unexpectedly, and one large customer, Hallmark Cards Inc., increased its  orders for the automated machinery that packages the cards and party favors it makes.         But Ms. Miller, the president of Miller/Bevco Inc., in Kansas City, Mo., is hardly getting her hopes up for a booming year. The way she sees it, customers are loosening their purse strings only slowly and reluctantly. "Many companies were taking a wait-and-see attitude, and now they are taking less of a wait-and-see attitude," she said. "Demand has backed up, and they have to do something."

headline: Speed Record: One Trillion Bits a Second
abstract: Making a dramatic leap in the speed of communications, three separate groups  of researchers have succeeded for the first time in transmitting information at  a rate of one trillion bits a second through an optical fiber.

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: GYMBOREE CORP., Burlingame, Calif., named a former Dayton Hudson Corp. executive, Gary White, senior vice president and chief operating officer.

headline: World News Briefs;24 Sri Lankan Soldiers Die in Attack by Rebels
abstract: Tamil Tiger rebels killed 24 Sri Lankan soldiers and wounded 14 in an attack  on an army patrol near the eastern town of Batticaloa today, police officials said.         But rebel fighters of the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, as the group is formally known, suffered heavy casualties when an air force helicopter counterattacked, the officials said. They did not have details of the number of  rebel dead but said there was "heavy damage."

headline: MUTUAL FUNDS;Hot Managers Getting the Star Treatment
abstract: WHILE no fund company will discuss how much it pays its star managers, the largest, highest-profile firms, like Fidelity, T. Rowe Price and Putnam, have the resources to pay top managers at least $1 million to $2 million a year, executive recruiters say.         That kind of compensation is well worth it if a manager can attract hundreds  of millions of dollars in assets by landing at the top of quarterly performance  rankings year after year.

headline: Israel-Syria Talks to Reopen, Focusing on Military
abstract: Syrian and Israeli negotiators will resume their negotiations near Washington on Jan. 24 with a renewed mandate and the help of ranking military experts, Secretary of State Warren Christopher announced today after a meeting with the Syrian President, Hafez al-Assad.         "Both parties understand the need to accelerate and intensify the discussions," Mr. Christopher said.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;LORAL ACKNOWLEDGES AN INVESTIGATION BY THE S.E.C.
abstract: The Loral Corporation said yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission was investigating trading in shares of Loral prior to an announcement that the Lockheed Martin Corporation would acquire the company. On Jan. 8, Lockheed Martin said it would acquire most of Loral in a deal then valued at more than $7 billion. In a filing with the S.E.C. yesterday, Loral said the commission informed Lockheed on Feb. 8 that it had begun an informal inquiry into the trading. Lockheed said on Jan. 25 that the New York Stock Exchange had  also asked for information on the trading. Also yesterday, Lockheed extended its offer until March 20 because the Federal Trade Commission had not acted on the transaction.

headline: Judge's Death Clouds Suit Over Tobacco
abstract: The giant class-action lawsuit against the nation's seven largest tobacco companies faced new uncertainty yesterday after the death of Okla B. Jones 2d, the judge in the New Orleans Federal District Court who was presiding over the case. Judge Jones, who was 50, died on Monday of leukemia.         The suit is not expected to be immediately affected because the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit, also based in New Orleans, is considering whether the companies can be sued by a class of smokers who said they were addicted to cigarettes. Judge Jones ruled that the smokers could sue.  People on both sides said they were watching closely to see which judge would be assigned to the case, a decision that could shape its outcome.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;SFAC of France in Bid For Trade Indemnity
abstract: Compagnie Financiere SFAC made a cash offer of L177.3 million ($266 million)  yesterday for Trade Indemnity Group P.L.C., a British credit insurer. SFAC offered 97 pence for each Trade Indemnity share, about 33 percent above the Wednesday closing price of 73 pence.

headline: GMC and Pontiac: One Division, 2 Images
abstract: With the merger of its Pontiac and GMC divisions, the General Motors Corporation has sent a clear signal of a strategy it plans to pursue in the years to come: keep well-known brand names alive, while seeking savings in areas that customers are less likely to notice.         As expected, G.M., the largest auto maker in the world, announced today that  it was combining the staffs and dealer networks of Pontiac and GMC into a single division. But the new division will continue to sell cars with the Pontiac name  and trucks with the GMC name, and it will maintain separate advertising agencies and campaigns.

headline: Old-Style Ward Politics Won For Turkey's Islamic Party
abstract: In its campaign to win votes on the back streets of this provincial Anatolian city, Turkey's pro-Islamic Welfare Party left little to Allah and nothing to chance.         Long before last month's elections, in which this onetime fringe party made the leap to the country's No. 1 vote-getter and earned the chance to try, as yet unsuccessfully, to form a governing coalition, its workers fanned out across Konya's neighborhoods, deployed like soldiers in an old-fashioned, big-city party machine.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;HARCOURT GENERAL INCREASING STOCK BUYBACK PROGRAM
abstract: Harcourt General Inc. said yesterday that it would raise its stock buyback program by one million shares. The publishing and retailing company may now repurchase from investors 3.5 million shares, up from 2.5 million shares previously. So far the company has bought back 1.8 million shares under the original program, which was approved in April 1995. Harcourt said it now had about 72.6 million shares outstanding. The company's shares were down $2, at $44.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Intel Admits It Overstated Chips' Speed
abstract: An embarrassed Intel Corporation acknowledged today that a bug in a software  program known as a compiler had led the company to overstate the speed of its microprocessor chips on an industry benchmark by about 10 percent.         However, industry analysts said the coding error, which was made in a pre-production version of the Intel software, was not an indictment of the technology of the world's largest chip maker but rather a sad commentary on a common industry practice of "cheating" on standardized performance tests.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;MERRILL LYNCH TO BUY BROKERAGE HOUSE IN SPAIN
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Company said yesterday that it would pay 3.7 billion pesetas  ($29.7 million) for the assets of FG Inversiones Bursatiles S.A., the biggest independent brokerage house in Spain. Merrill Lynch, the world's largest securities company, said its European unit would acquire the Spanish company's broker-dealer, corporate finance and asset management businesses, with net assets valued at 1.3 billion pesetas. The purchase of FG Inversiones, which had a profit of 1 billion pesetas in 1995, is Merrill's second recent takeover in Europe. In July, the company bought Smith New Court P.L.C. in Britain for $842 million.

headline: House Panel Backs Alien Farm Workers
abstract: Bowing to big farming interests, the House Agriculture Committee approved an  amendment to the House immigration bill yesterday that would grant temporary work visas to up to 250,000 foreign farm workers, even though many Republicans say the move would only encourage a flood of illegal immigrants.         The overall bill that the committee is considering would impose a tough crackdown on illegal immigration, which has become a major theme in the Presidential campaign, and several Representatives condemned the amendment yesterday.

headline: Journalists Approve Internet Reporters
abstract: In its first decision related to the Internet, the journalists' committee that oversees media operations in Congress voted today to provide credentials to reporters for qualified electronic publications.         In a 5-to-0 vote, the Standing Committee of Correspondents said it had recognized "the emergence of electronic publications as a legitimate extension of the print tradition."

headline: Correction
abstract: An article last Sunday about tax deductions for losses due to corporate mistakes misspelled the surname of a professor of accounting and taxation at New York University who noted a distinction between actions involving poor judgment  and those reflecting criminal intent. He is Joseph W. Rebovich, not Rebravitch.

headline: BOMBINGS IN ISRAEL: VICTIMS;2 Students Found Faith, Love and Death
abstract: They were in love with their faith and with each other, and they died together as the victims of hate.         Two American students, Matthew Eisenfeld, 25, of West Hartford, Conn., and Sarah Duker, 23, of Teaneck, N.J., were traveling from Jerusalem to Jordan yesterday when a bomb ripped through a packed city bus. Twenty-five people, including the students, were killed.

headline: Liechtenstein's Headstrong Prince Threatens Subjects — With Quitting
abstract: VADUZ, Liechtenstein—  Having survived all of Europe's convulsions, including two World Wars, the principality of Liechtenstein is facing its first constitutional crisis of the century.

headline: Rubin Sees the Big Powers Focusing on Effect of Slump
abstract: With growth slowing in the United States and Europe and anemic in Japan, Secretary of the Treasury Robert E. Rubin said today that a meeting of the Group of Seven industrial nations this weekend would focus on what to do if economic weakness worsened.         One danger of a softening economy in Europe is the possibility that it could  derail a move toward a common European currency, Government officials said. The  Clinton Administration is also concerned for reasons closer to home: slowdowns abroad could become a drag on the domestic economy, an unnerving prospect in an  election year.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                                               Previous      Year                               Yesterday       Day       Ago

headline: Cellular Industry's Party Could End Soon
abstract: It is party time for the cellular telephone industry, and not just because the singer Wynonna Judd and the Eagles are performing at the industry's annual convention here.         With yet another year of soaring revenues, up 34 percent over the last year,  to $19 billion, and no sign of slowing, the smell of money here is so pungent that even the most plodding telephone executives are getting giddy.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS: Market Place;Ann Taylor Stores shows that robust sales can hurt profit margins.
abstract: WHETHER a retailer sells brooms or bras, it is dangerous to try to sell too many of them. Just ask Ann Taylor Stores.         Like all retailers, the women's apparel retailer has been laboring under the  message shoppers sent long ago that everything from cotton shirts to Drano has to be sold at a discount. Merchants have been forced to order a slew of goods and promptly mark them down in order to get the healthy sales that satisfy Wall  Street.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;TRADING IN HELENE CURTIS FUELS DEAL RUMORS
abstract: Heavy trading in the shares of Helene Curtis Industries Inc. convinced some arbitragers yesterday that a deal for the company was likely. Curtis shares rose $8.25, or 18 percent, to close at $53.125, on New York Stock Exchange volume of  482,700 shares. The stock has risen 74 percent since its Jan. 10 close of $30.50. The exchange asked the company to issue a statement about any corporate  development that might explain the stock activity, but the company declined to comment. Curtis, which is based in Chicago, makes Suave shampoos and Degree antiperspirants. Shamrock Holdings had asked Curtis last week to sell itself or  alter its stock structure.

headline: After 50 Years, G.I.'s and Russians Meet Again
abstract: Lieut. Col. Jeff Hammond, the commander of the 429th Field Artillery, First Armored Division, peered into the empty hatch of a Russian armored personnel carrier.         "You airdrop soldiers while they are inside the vehicle?" the American said incredulously to the Russian commanding officer. "You're kidding!"

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;Pepsi Results Are Bolstered By Upswing in Restaurants
abstract: As Pepsico Inc. pressed strategies to further a revival in its restaurant business, the company announced fourth-quarter earnings yesterday that were driven by growth in the company's KFC fast-food chain, the Frito-Lay snack-food  business and international beverage shipments.         Wall Street seemed to interpret the results positively, and Pepsico shares rose 75 cents, to $60.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: New Spynet Links C.I.A. And Envoys
abstract: In a sign that it is re-thinking its role, the Central Intelligence Agency will give American diplomats in Bosnia and other trouble zones computer access to secret information that may help them solve political and military problems.          Though the intelligence agency has always been expected to share its secrets  with State Department officials abroad, the arrangement has sometimes been more  honored in the breach, according to former ambassadors and Foreign Service officers. They say the agency has been reluctant to share information, and at times has even concealed it.

headline: Another Departure at Kmart As Marketing Chief Resigns
abstract: In its latest housecleaning move, the Kmart Corporation announced yesterday that Kenneth W. Watson, vice president for marketing, would leave the company.         "It was a mutually agreeable decision," a Kmart spokeswoman, Mary Lorencz, said.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Deregulation Is Passed For Telecommunications Congress voted overwhelmingly to deregulate the nation's communications laws, passing, after four years of struggle and gridlock, a bill that will transform television, telephones and the emerging frontiers of computer networks.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Plans to Clarify Ownership of S.A.S.
abstract: The holding companies for Scandinavian Airlines System are preparing measures to clarify the ownership structure to strengthen S.A.S.'s position in capital markets, the companies said yesterday. The move is a response to criticism that  S.A.S.'s ownership is difficult to grasp. It is owned by Denmark's DDL, Norway's DNL and Sweden's ABA, which in turned is owned by SILA. These holding companies  are listed on their respective domestic exchanges, but each is 50 percent Government owned.          The measures being discussed focus on how the operations of DDL, DNL and SILA may be streamlined so that they include the stakes in S.A.S. No changes are planned in the Governments' stakes.   (Dow Jones)

headline: Kohlberg Kravis to Purchase Xerox Unit for $2.7 Billion
abstract: Culminating its exit from the financial services field, the Xerox Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell Talegen Holdings Inc., its property and casualty insurance subsidiary, to an investor group led by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company and Talegen management for $2.7 billion.         The deal had been rumored for some time and was greeted with thunderous applause on Wall Street, even though in announcing the sale Xerox said it would take a $1.5 billion after-tax charge in the fourth quarter of 1995 to cover a noncash loss and an increase in reserves against insurance claims.

headline: Silicon Graphics May Buy Cray Research
abstract: Silicon Graphics Inc. said late today that it planned to meet with analysts and hold a news conference Monday morning in New York to make a "major strategic announcement."         The company would not comment on the nature of the announcement, but people familiar with the Silicon Valley computer maker said it was planning to buy the  supercomputer maker Cray Research.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;PARKER & PARSLEY IS SELLING AUSTRALIAN ASSETS
abstract: The Parker & Parsley Petroleum Company said yesterday that it was selling its Australian oil and gas assets for about $240.3 million. Santos Ltd. said it had  already bought most of the company's minority interests in various projects for  about $155 million. Parker & Parsley, based in Midland, Tex., said it had an agreement with an unidentified buyer to sell the remaining asset, its 22.5 percent stake in a gas discovery in the Timor Sea, northwest of Australia.

headline: Motorola Venture With Sun Microsystems
abstract: Motorola Inc. and Sun Microsystems Inc. said yesterday that they planned to collaborate to build high-speed Internet access systems for home use.         The alliance intends to match Motorola's expertise in transporting digital information with Sun's expertise in computer networking. The two plan to sell their product -- a package of digital modems, computer network servers and networking software, plus installation and servicing -- to cable television companies and to regional telephone companies.

headline: González Rival Vows Tougher Anti-Terror Moves
abstract: MADRID—  José María Aznar, the center-right challenger to become Spanish prime minister in elections Sunday, promises he will introduce tougher measures to deal with Basque terrorism.

headline: India and Pakistan Troops Clash in Kashmir
abstract: Indian and Pakistani troops clashed today across the dividing line of the disputed Himalayan region of Kashmir, the Pakistani Defense Ministry said.         A ministry spokesman, quoted by the official news agency, accused the Indian  troops of starting the clash with "unprovoked firing" on Pakistani posts and civilians living close to the control line in the Rawalakot sector.

headline: 2 Fund Groups Said to Be Seeking Buyers
abstract: Michael F. Price, the money manager, is seeking to sell his $13 billion Mutual Series family of mutual funds, an investment banker whose client may want to buy the fund group said yesterday.         Mr. Price hired Goldman, Sachs & Company to help find a buyer for his firm, the Heine Securities Corporation, said the banker who spoke on the condition of  anonymity. Heine, based in Short Hills, N.J., is the parent of the Mutual Series funds.

headline: At State Department, Empty Pockets
abstract: Secretary of State Warren Christopher spent much of today grappling with the  latest foreign policy nightmare: trying to conduct diplomacy on behalf of a Government that has run out of money.         The shutdown for want of a new budget -- which has left 280,000 Federal employees furloughed without pay -- preoccupied the weekly senior staff meeting  that Mr. Christopher held with his Under Secretaries and Assistant Secretaries of State. For an hour afterwards, Mr. Christopher visited employees in their offices and in the State Department cafeteria, asking how the shutdown has affected their work and their lives.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;CAREMARK SETTLES WITH INSURERS FOR $65.6 MILLION
abstract: Caremark International Inc. will spend $65.6 million to settle disputes with  insurers arising from a Government fraud investigation of kickbacks that the company, a health services concern, paid physicians for patient referrals. The settlement announced yesterday "resolves good-faith business disputes" stemming  from the investigation and is not an admission of wrongdoing, said C. A. Lance Piccolo, Caremark's chairman and chief executive. The money will be deducted from Caremark's 1996 first-quarter profits. It is more than three times the $21.4 million Caremark earned in the first quarter of last year. Caremark, based in Northbrook, Ill., pleaded guilty last year to Federal fraud charges and agreed to pay $161 million in civil and criminal fines.

headline: Tecoluca Journal;The Rebel Is Mayor Now and It's Tough Slogging
abstract: As a guerrilla who spent part of his country's 12-year civil war on the slopes of the towering Chinchontepec volcano just west of here, Nicolas Garcia often looked down on his hometown from his mountain redoubt and dreamed of the day when he and his comrades would seize power and impose their revolutionary program.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;LOEWEN SETTLES SUIT FOR $30 MILLION
abstract: The Loewen Group, operator of a chain of funeral homes, reached a $30 million out-of-court settlement on Monday with the Provident American Corporation, a Pennsylvania insurer. In the latest court case, Provident American said that in  1991 it entered a 10-year agreement with Loewen to be the preferred carrier for  insurance that fixes funeral costs. Provident officials charged that Loewen had  broken the agreement by awarding the business to the Forethought Companies, a unit of Hillenbrand Industries. Provident American had sought actual damages of  $58.8 million to $132 million in addition to unspecified punitive damages.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Cline, Davis & Mann Shifts Management
abstract: Cline, Davis & Mann in New York has realigned top management.         Morgan E. Cline, 62, chairman, president and chief executive, has relinquished his position as president to Clyde P. Davis, who was also named to  the new position of executive art director. Mr. Davis, 57, had been executive vice president, executive creative director and treasurer; those positions will not be filled.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;German Trade Surplus
abstract: Germany's merchandise trade surplus widened to 8.5 billion marks ($4.6 billion) in October, from a revised 8.1 billion marks in September, the Federal  Statistics Office said yesterday. In a provisional report, the office said exports rose to 65.6 billion marks in October, from a revised 62 billion in September. Exports were up 10.5 percent from a year earlier. Imports rose to 57.1 billion marks in October, from 53.9 billion in September.   (AP)

headline: Lotus-Borland Copyright Battle To Be Played Out at High Court
abstract: A long-running copyright infringement dispute between the Lotus Development Corporation and Borland International is to be argued today before the United States Supreme Court, the first case in which the court will rule on the applicability of copyright law to computer software..         The issue is not whether the content of software can be copyrighted -- it can -- but whether a system of menus and commands used to control a program constitutes content, or are simply controls, like the buttons on a videocassette recorder, which are not copyrightable.

headline: Jail Letters Of Dissident In China Are Defiant
abstract: When China's leaders ordered the police to seize the country's leading dissident, Wei Jingsheng, two years ago and confiscate his notes and computer files, they presumably figured that they had silenced him.         Mr. Wei was sentenced to 14 years in prison, and he has had no contact with the outside world since his arrest. Nor has he been able to work on the autobiography he was planning to write for an American publisher.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Pechiney Returned To Profitability in 1995
abstract: The French aluminum and packaging giant Pechiney CIP said yesterday that it swung back to profit in 1995 and forecast more improvement this year, provided sales volume picked up in the second half.  Pechiney reported a profit of 1.465  billion French francs, or $290 million, after a loss of 3.181 billion francs in  1994. The profit included 730 million francs from the sale of assets. The 1994 loss was after a one-time write-down of good will of 2.8 billion francs.   Reuters

headline: World News Briefs;Israelis to Compensate Family of Slain Waiter
abstract: Without admitting responsibility, Israel has agreed to pay $400,000 in restitution to the family of a Moroccan waiter allegedly killed by Israeli agents in 1973 in a case of mistaken identity.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Senior Newsweek Editor to Head Little, Brown Adult Trade Unit
abstract: After more than a month without a publisher for its adult trade division, Little, Brown & Company said yesterday that Sarah Crichton, an assistant managing editor at Newsweek magazine, would take over the post beginning next month.         In her new job, Ms. Crichton, 41, will oversee all aspects of the division, including the marketing, sales and editorial departments. She will report to Charles E. Hayward, president of Little, Brown, which is owned by Time Warner Inc.

headline: Key Semiconductor Index Falls for 2d Month
abstract: The semiconductor industry's leading indicator fell for a second month in February, a trade organization reported late today.         Although the decline was within industry analysts' expectations, the report showed that orders for chips continued to slow.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt Alltel Corp., Little Rock, Ark., is selling $300 million of debentures due in 2016 through Stephens Inc. The debentures are rated A2 by Moody's Investors Service and A+ by Standard & Poor's.

headline: Pharmacia & Upjohn to Close 40% of Drug-Making Plants
abstract: Pharmacia & Upjohn Inc. said today that it would close 40 percent of its worldwide drug manufacturing plants, saving $300 million a year by 2000.         Pharmacia & Upjohn did not say how many jobs would be lost or which of its 56 plants would close. The cuts come on top of an expected $500 million in yearly cost savings announced last year, when the merger of Pharmacia A.B. of Sweden and the Upjohn Company of Kalamazoo, Mich., was planned. At that time, the company said it would cut 4,100 jobs from a combined work force of about 35,000.

headline: SPENDING IT;Picking a Health Plan: A Shot in the Dark
abstract: FOR Judy Wagner, the anxiety-ridden process of choosing a new health plan began five months ago.         For 30 years she had received her insurance through the Unisys Corporation, where her husband worked until his death five years ago. Now, she said, with her eligibility in the company-sponsored program about to lapse, she faced the daunting process of finding new doctors she liked in a health plan that she, as  a part-time Wal-Mart cashier, could afford.

headline: Beirut Radio-TV Plan Protested
abstract: A battle of words has broken out in Lebanon over the Government's plans to tighten control of radio and television stations, most of which first went on the air during the country's 15-year civil war.         Broadcast media owners and operators, supported by the powerful Confederation of Trade Unions, professors and journalism students, have scheduled a nationwide strike on Feb. 29. Many fear the protest could turn violent because of a Government ban on demonstrations.

headline: Officers at Nabisco Ordered to Testify in Suit
abstract: A Federal Judge in North Carolina yesterday compelled the top two executives  of the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation to testify this week in a lawsuit involving Bennett S. LeBow and Carl C. Icahn, the investors who are seeking a rapid spinoff of RJR Nabisco's food business from the company's tobacco operations.         Steven F. Goldstone, the company's chief executive, will be deposed today at  the offices of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy, the lawyers for Brooke Group Ltd., Mr. LeBow's holding company.

headline: New-Home Sales Drop 1.3% As Midwest Cold Hurts Buying
abstract: New-home sales slid nationally in February for the first time in four months, as unusually cold weather in the Midwest disrupted buying.         Sales improved in the Northeast, South and West, but a 24 percent plunge in the Midwest pulled down overall sales of single-family homes by 1.3 percent, to an annual rate of 700,000, seasonally adjusted, the Commerce Department said  today.

headline: Serbian Chief Moves to Suppress Opposition at Home
abstract: In the three months since signing the Dayton peace accords, President Slobodan Milosevic has been promoting himself internationally as a guarantor of  peace in the Balkans. But inside Serbia, he has been working to suppress political opposition and reassert state control of the economy, diplomats and economists here say.         Expectations that Mr. Milosevic, who has kept the red star on the spire of his palace, might encourage market reforms and democratization as have former Communists elsewhere in Central Europe have not materialized, they say.

headline: Pratt & Lambert Job Loss
abstract: About 200 employees of Pratt & Lambert United Inc. in Buffalo will lose their jobs by the end of May, a spokesman for the Sherwin-Williams Company said on Monday. Sherwin-Williams, which acquired Pratt & Lambert in January for $400 million, said it would close the company's headquarters and a paint plant. Sherwin-Williams, based in Cleveland, makes paints under the Sherwin-Williams and Dutch Boy brand names. The company sells its paints mainly through its paint stores and provides the Sears, Roebuck & Company with private-label paint brands.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;MINORCO TO SELL ITS STAKE IN SANTA FE ENERGY
abstract: Minorco, faced with an estimated $2 billion in mining expenditures in the coming years, plans to sell its 9.6 percent stake in Santa Fe Energy Resources Inc. Santa Fe, an oil and gas exploration and production company based in Houston, filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to register 8.71 million shares held by a Minorco subsidiary called Minorco (USA) Inc. Minorco, which is based in Luxembourg, described the stock sale as another step in its effort to concentrate on core metals, paper and agribusiness operations. Santa Fe shares fell 37.5 cents to close at $9.125.

headline: A.D.P. Makes Acquistion
abstract: Automatic Data Processing Inc.'s Dealer Services Group said today that it had acquired Performance Inc. of Chantilly, Va., for an undisclosed amount. Performance, a provider of consulting and professional service programs to the automotive industry, said that it would retain its president, Clay McCuistion. Automatic Data Processing, which is based in Roseland, N.J., provides data processing and other services to automotive dealers and other businesses.

headline: Biotechnology Companies End Joint Project
abstract: Sugen Inc. and Amgen Inc. said today that they had agreed to end their collaboration research one year sooner than planned.         The joint research between the two biotechnology companies on neurobiology and hematopoiesis, or the production of blood cells, was initiated in 1992 and intended to last four years. The companies said they had agreed to terminate the pact amicably one year early because their research priorities have changed.

headline: Civilian Effort for Peace In Bosnia Seen Lagging
abstract: While troops and equipment from NATO armies have been rolling into place under tough conditions in Bosnia, the civilians in charge of making peace meaningful through the rebuilding of daily life and political institutions have  been conspicuously absent.         Carl Bildt, the former Swedish Prime Minister who was appointed in early December to be the top diplomat in Bosnia and coordinator of all nonmilitary efforts there, will not arrive until this week, to the annoyance of American officials.

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

headline: Plans for Market Near Auschwitz Dropped
abstract: A Polish trading company said today that it was abandoning plans for a supermarket near the former Nazi death camp at Auschwitz because of controversy  surrounding the venture.         Earlier this month the Polish Government opened an inquiry into plans to build the supermarket and ordered work on the site suspended until a report was  issued.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;ROCKWELL PLANS SEMICONDUCTOR WAFER PLANT EXPANSION
abstract: The Rockwell International Corporation announced yesterday that it planned a  $1.2 billion expansion of its Colorado semiconductor wafer fabrication plant. Phase I of the new plant is expected to create 600 jobs by December 1997. Rockwell's Phase I investment is about $675 million; the Phase II investment is  expected to be greater than $500 million. Rockwell is the world's No. 1 supplier of facsimile modems, with about 80 percent of the global market, and personal computer data modems, with a market share of about 65 percent.

headline: Matamoros Journal;Canaries Sing in Mexico, but Uncle Juan Will Not
abstract: The sun is blazing on the street outside, but it is dark inside the Piedras Negras Restaurant, and it takes visitors a moment before they can clearly see the two bodyguards, wearing cowboy boots and beepers, slouched in chairs facing  the entrance.         These men work for the owner, a frail man, 80 years old, seated at the rear,  under a cage of chirping canaries: Juan N. Guerra, the patriarch of a criminal dynasty along the Texas-Mexico border.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Auto Sales in Japan Rose 4.8% in 1995
abstract: Auto sales in Japan exceeded five million vehicles last year for the first time in three years, the Japan Automobile Dealers Association reported yesterday. Domestic vehicle sales climbed 4.8 percent, to 5.15 million last year, the second successive gain. The Japanese market share of the Toyota Motor  Corporation stood at 39.4 percent in 1995, the first time in 13 years that it was below 40 percent.          Analysts said a slow economic recovery in Japan and the growing popularity of mini-vans and station wagons would provide a further push to the industry this year. "We estimate Japan's domestic vehicle demand at 5.463 million in 1996," said Noriyuki Matsushima, a senior analyst at the Nikko Research Center.   (Reuters)

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;South Africa Ex-Minister Gets Murder Trial Delay
abstract: The trial of South Africa's former Defense Minister, Magnus Malan, and 19 other defendants accused of plotting political killings in the 1980's was delayed today when a judge gave Mr. Malan's lawyers more time to study his case.         Defense lawyers said they lacked sufficient time to study an additional charge of conspiracy that prosecutors filed last week, alleging unspecified persecution of anti-apartheid figures.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;SHARES OF ATLAS AIR RISE AFTER IT AGREES TO LEASE PLANES
abstract: The stock of Atlas Air rose nearly 16 percent yesterday, a day after the company announced a deal to lease five Boeing 747-200 freighter aircraft from the Federal Express Corporation. Atlas will lease the bulk-cargo planes, which Federal Express acquired in its purchase of the Flying Tigers cargo carrier, until 1998. The agreement will give Atlas more than 10 percent of the world's large air-freighter capacity by year-end, the company said. Atlas, of Golden, Colo., provides airlines with Boeing 747 freighters, plus crews, maintenance and insurance, usually under three-year contracts. Its shares rose $4.875, to $35.625, in Nasdaq trading.

headline: 2 Unions to Seek Board Representation at Kmart
abstract: The International Brotherhood of Teamsters and another union said yesterday that they would ask shareholders of the Kmart Corporation to elect a new director as part of an effort to press the company to study a possible sale or merger.         A Kmart spokeswoman said the move, in a preliminary proxy filing by the unions, was part of a "cookie cutter" campaign waged by the unions against several other companies. And some analysts said the effort was hasty because Kmart's new managers were making progress with their plan to turn around the beleaguered retailer.

headline: America Online Expands Service
abstract: America Online Inc., the leading United States on-line service, has started AOL Canada, extending its international reach.         The new service from America Online, which is based in Vienna, Va., plans to  feature Canadian content and also provide E-mail and access to the Internet, the company said.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;BOMBARDIER DECIDES NOT TO BID FOR FOKKER
abstract: Bombardier Inc., the Montreal-based aircraft maker, said yesterday that it had decided against making an offer for Fokker N.V., leaving the Dutch commuter  aircraft maker with only a few days to find an alternate plan to avert bankruptcy. "The risks involved were too high," a Bombardier spokesman said. Bombardier, a company with a record of turning around troubled plane builders, had been seen as Fokker's best hope for survival. A unit of Bombardier, Short Brothers of Northern Ireland, makes wings for Fokker, and a spokesman said the unit was still in talks with Fokker. Meanwhile, Hans Wijers, the Dutch Economics Minister, said he expected Samsung of South Korea to make its intentions on Fokker clear in the next few days. Fokker's majority shareholder, Daimler-Benz A.G., halted its support for the company last month.

headline: Serbs in Bosnia See No Peace for Their Dead . . .
abstract: This morning Nikola Ljesic went to the Vlakovo cemetery for the last time. He carried with him several yellow candles, a small parcel of food and a piece of brown wrapping paper filled with nails.         He walked past the dun-colored mounds of earth beside several empty graves toward the wooden cross marked with the name of his son, Dragoslav. He said that the 18-year-old was shot dead by a Muslim sniper in June 1992.

headline: Nonviolence of Castro's Foes Still Wears a Very Tough Face
abstract: Jose Basulto, the leader of Brothers to the Rescue and the pilot of the plane that returned safely to Florida on Saturday after two companion aircraft were shot down, used to fight Fidel Castro the old-fashioned way.         In 1961, he took part in the ill-fated Bay of Pigs invasion. He returned to Cuba the next year to fire a cannon at a Havana hotel from a boat.

headline: Patents;The distilled essence of tobacco can coat more than your lungs. It also coats metal, and prevents rust.
abstract: RUST, it is estimated, costs Americans billions of dollars a year. It has to  be scraped off machinery and prevented from clogging car engines. The Golden Gate Bridge must be continually repainted in a bright orange laced with anti-rust compounds.         There is an environmental cost to fighting rust, as well. The chemicals commonly used in industrial paint and in cooling systems to retard rust are toxic pollutants. So, some that have been used for decades have recently been outlawed, leaving industrial manufacturers looking for alternatives.

headline: Drive-By Shooting Near Hebron Kills Israel Army Doctor and Driver
abstract: Palestinian gunmen ambushed and killed two Israeli soldiers tonight north of  Hebron, apparently in revenge for the assassination of Israel's most wanted terrorist 11 days ago.         The shooting, the first fatal attack on Israelis in the West Bank since much  of area was handed over to Palestinian control last month, came just four days before planned Palestinian elections. But there were no indications that the voting would be delayed by the shooting, which occurred on a section of the Jerusalem-Hebron highway controlled by Israel.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Stocks Post Recovery As Rate-Cut Hopes Revive Alan Greenspan's words were familiar, but the markets heard them with new ears.  Stocks surged, recovering in large part from a selloff on Tuesday that came after the Federal Reserve chairman appeared to knock down one of the pillars of  this year's rally: an expectation of a cut soon in interest rates. Mr. Greenspan offered many of the same opinions in Congressional testimony yesterday as he did Tuesday, but traders now saw in them suggestions that rate cuts were still possible.

headline: Response by G.I.'s Mixed As Hillary Clinton Visits
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton charmed American troops at a U.S.O. show here, but it  didn't hurt that the singer Sheryl Crow and the comedian Sinbad were also on the stage.         In her appearance at Tuzla Air Base, the First Lady told a couple of thousand of the 19,300 Americans serving in Bosnia that they were using military power to advance United States interests and values. She said they were part of "the kind of peacekeeping mission every American should be proud of and support."

headline: VOICES: VIEWPOINT;Look, Uncle Sam, No Form 1040's
abstract: THE worst part about the American income tax system is filling out long and complex tax forms -- the sort millions of Americans began receiving from the Internal Revenue Service last week. The I.R.S. already has most of the information we have to enter on numerous forms and schedules. If the United States followed the lead of Britain and many other European countries, most of us could avoid this annual burden. At the same time, the Government would pick up more revenue at less expense.        How? Through a return-free tax system based on withholding at the source with lower rates. With a few systemic adjustments, the United States could have a less burdensome income tax system that would be simpler and fairer to most taxpayers.

headline: Dr. Usim Odim, 72; Physician Tended To Biafrans in War
abstract: Dr. Usim Odim, a Nigeria-born psychiatrist who worked as a physician on the Biafran side to save civilian victims of the Nigerian civil war in the late 1960's, died on Dec. 25 at his home in Pittsburgh. He was 72.         The cause was prostate cancer, his family said.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS;U.S. Bonds Gain on Hope Of Rate Cut
abstract: Treasury prices ended moderately higher yesterday, buoyed by a resilient optimism that the Federal Reserve would soon cut interest rates again.         The market's optimism was fed by a sharper-than-expected rise in weekly unemployment claims. The data pointed to mounting weakness in the economy, which market participants expect will compel the Fed to cut short-term rates.

headline: Ilie Nastase, Bad Boy of Tennis, Runs Hard to Take Over Bucharest CityHall
abstract: Who would want to run a city where more than 100 homeless people froze to death on the streets this winter and there was no money to pay for the burials?  Where rubbish piles tower over parked cars, and potholes have cratered into mini-canyons?         Ilie Nastase, once the bad boy of tennis who enjoys the good life in Paris and New York, is running for Mayor of Bucharest. At 50, with a few extra pounds  on his frame and rimless glasses for watching television, he says he is coming home to help.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS;Long Bond Down Ahead Of Refunding
abstract: The prices of Treasury securities were mixed yesterday after the modest rises of Wednesday, when the Federal Reserve cut short-term interest rates.         Longer-term maturities slumped; the 30-year bond was down 23/32 , to 111, and the yield rose to 6.07 percent, from 6.02 percent on Wednesday.

headline: Louis Ward, 76, Manufacturer Built Fortune in Candy Business
abstract: Louis L. Ward, a businessman who built Russell Stover Candies Inc. into the nation's largest manufacturer and distributor of gift-packaged candy, died on Saturday at his home in Kansas City, Mo. He was 76.         Mr. Ward retired as president and chairman of Russell Stover Candies after a  stroke three years ago. He died of complications from that illness, said his son Thomas S. Ward.

headline: In a Rebuff To Kerkorian, Chrysler Picks Fund Manager
abstract: In a rebuff to Kirk Kerkorian, one of its largest shareholders, the Chrysler  Corporation announced tonight that it had chosen a prominent mutual fund manager to fill an open seat on its board.

headline: After Enduring Sharp Skid, The Dow Ends Slightly Up
abstract: Blue-chip stocks ended slightly higher yesterday after recovering from a sharp selloff earlier in the session.         After falling as much as 95.74 points at midday, the Dow Jones industrial average closed with a gain of 2.89 points at 5,583.89. Yesterday's swing followed two tumultuous sessions, in which the Dow plunged 171.24 points on Friday only to rebound 110.55 points on Monday.

headline: When Pointing and Clicking Fails to Click;More and More Questions, and Employees, at Computer Help Services
abstract: Their pay is modest, their labors are unheralded, and even their bosses admit that the job is grueling. Each second of their work is electronically monitored; the corporate Big Brother is always watching. So are these people seething with working-class resentment? Hardly. "This is the entry-level job of  the 90's," explained Colleen Dolan, a 43-year-old former kindergarten teacher, who joined Broderbund Software Inc. last year. "This is where the jobs are."         Unlikely as it seems, the computer help-desk job is one of the fastest-growing occupations in America's high-technology economy. These workers  are voices at the end of phone lines at hardware and software companies and at specialist technical-support firms. They try to walk frazzled users of personal  computers through the confusing labyrinth of "drivers," "extensions" and "win.ini" and "config.sys" commands often required to stir a frozen children's game or a desktop publishing program back to life.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;AST'S EARNINGS TO BE LOWER THAN EXPECTED
abstract: AST Research Inc., the maker of personal computers, said yesterday that its results would be lower than expected in the first quarter. AST said it had encountered less demand for its PC's as inventories have increased. The weak results for the first quarter are expected to follow a loss of $128.6 million and a drop in sales -- which is unusual in the PC industry -- in the fourth quarter of 1995. AST did not provide a specific estimate of its results for the first quarter.

headline: Market Place;The market predicts the Super Bowl and vice versa, so they say.
abstract: THE bull market is good for another year, no matter which team wins this year's Super Bowl. And that is just as well, because the stock market right now  sees the game as very close, although last week's sharp fall in share prices has given the Dallas Cowboys a small edge.         Those are the results of two theories relating the stock market to the Super  Bowl. It is, of course, absurd to think there is any relation between the two, but that doesn't stop Wall Street from paying attention.

headline: In Reversal, Brazil's President Backs Voluntary Sterilization
abstract: Two days after President Fernando Henrique Cardoso vetoed legislation that would have legalized sterilization, the second most common form of birth control in Brazil, he has pledged to seek a congressional reversal of his veto.         The President's veto on Monday surprised his Health Minister and congressional leaders and was criticized by family planning and women's groups.  They had expected approval of the bill to authorize voluntary sterilization in public hospitals of men or women over 25 who already have two children.

headline: World's Leaders Bid Farewell to Mitterrand
abstract: In flowing African robes, Arab headdresses and sober mourning clothes, the high and mighty of France and the world bade farewell today to former President  Francois Mitterrand at a Requiem Mass in Notre Dame Cathedral while his family quietly laid him to rest in the town where he was born.         The small family funeral in Jarnac, 250 miles from Paris in the Cognac country of southwestern France, and the public ceremony in Notre Dame were both  exactly as Mr. Mitterrand wanted them -- no political speeches or eulogies, just the usual homily by the celebrant.

headline: S.E.C. Proposal Would Revamp Mutual Funds' Sales Policies
abstract: In a potentially sweeping overhaul of mutual fund regulation, the Securities  and Exchange Commission later this year will propose major changes in the way mutual funds sell shares to investors and how they disclose the potential risks  of the funds they are offering, a top S.E.C. official said today.         Speaking at a mutual fund trade conference here, Barry P. Barbash, director of the S.E.C.'s division of investment management, said he believed that funds would be allowed to sell shares based on a two-page document known as a profile  prospectus without first delivering a more detailed fund description to investors, as is currently required.

headline: Too High for Buffett, Berkshire Stock Falls
abstract: The shares of Berkshire Hathaway Inc. tumbled $2,150 each, or 5.9 percent, yesterday as investors took to heart remarks by the company's billionaire chairman, Warren E. Buffett, that he would not buy the stock at current prices.          In his annual letter to shareholders, which was mailed this weekend, Mr. Buffett said he and Berkshire's vice chairman, Charles T. Munger, no longer believed that the shares in their company were undervalued.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;McDONALD'S DISCONTINUES ITS REDUCED-FAT BURGER
abstract: The McDonald's Corporation will discontinue its reduced-fat hamburger, McLean Deluxe, after it did little to improve the company's bottom line. The company will also discontinue its chef's salad and side salads, said Malesia Webb-Dunn,  a McDonald's spokeswoman. McDonald's introduced McLean Deluxe about five years ago. It has 10 grams of fat compared with 21 grams of fat in a Quarter Pounder.  Sales of the reduced-fat hamburger did not justify keeping it on the menu, said Mark Miller, an analyst at CS First Boston, especially as McDonald's opened smaller restaurants and satellite sites with limited menus.

headline: Milwaukee Daily's Parent Rebuffs Bid Inquiry
abstract: A New York investment group has approached Journal Communications Inc., which owns the Milwaukee Journal Sentinel and other media and printing interests, to discuss a possible purchase at a price of about $1 billion, but it has been rebuffed, Journal Communications said last night.         Robert A. Kahlor, the chairman and chief executive of Journal Communications, which is employee-owned, said he told the investment group, Sextant Partners, that Journal Communications was not for sale.

headline: Taybeh Journal;A Niche Beer, Made, You Might Say, to Toast Peace
abstract: As niche beers go, Taybeh Beer faces hurdles unknown to other brewers.         It is a beer whose main market is a Muslim society where the faith forbids alcohol. It is a Palestinian beer trying to gain a following among Israelis. It is beer made at a small, family-owned brewery whose fortunes rise and fall in tandem with a troubled Middle East peace.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Alitalia President Quits In Dispute on Costs
abstract: The president of the Italian state airline Alitalia angrily resigned yesterday, saying the carrier's owners were shying away from making heavy job cuts. The president, Renato Riverso, who was brought in two years ago to rescue  the money-losing airline, said in a letter to the Milan financial daily Il Sole  24 Ore that he was stepping down after his relations with Alitalia's owner, the  state holding company IRI, had broken down.          Mr. Riverso's is the second high-ranking departure at the airline in recent  months. The managing director, Roberto Schisano, was dismissed last year. Mr. Riverso's departure followed the appointment of a new managing director, Domenico Cempella, who said he wanted to avoid "traumatic" cuts.   Reuters

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Daiwa Bank Shares Rise
abstract: The shares of Daiwa Bank Ltd. rose yesterday after the bank agreed to pay $340 million in fines to settle fraud charges in the United States, bringing the bank's New York bond-trading scandal to a close. Traders called the fine a bargain since the bank had faced a maximum penalty of $1.3 billion. Daiwa shares rose as high as 734 yen before closing at 710 yen, up 18 yen, on the Tokyo Stock Exchange.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: Israeli Blockade Takes Toll In West Bank and Gaza
abstract: By about 5 this afternoon, after weeks of waiting, it looked as if Fatima Abu Jarad, a 4-year-old girl with leukemia, might finally get out of the Gaza Strip  to an Israeli hospital for treatment.         But as she sat sobbing and then dozing on her mother's lap on the steps of the outpatient clinic at Shifa Hospital here, nothing seemed certain. With an Israeli blockade of the Gaza Strip entering its fourth week, the 20-minute ride  to the Erez border crossing still seemed like a distant voyage.

headline: U.S. Memo On Israel Cited Its Spy Aims
abstract: A Defense Department employee sent a confidential memorandum to American military contractors last month warning that Israel would try to spy on them and to use the religious affinities of their Jewish employees to obtain secret information.         The letter, which described Israel as a "nontraditional adversary" in terms of espionage, was withdrawn by the Pentagon later in the month. Tonight, a Pentagon spokesman, Ken Bacon, said the letter was "unfortunate, unofficial and  unauthorized."

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Germans Reject Demand To Alter Nuclear Plant
abstract: At a little-publicized meeting in Bavaria this week, German scientists and officials flatly rejected American demands that a controversial nuclear research reactor designed to use weapons-grade fuel be remodeled to use low-enriched uranium, German officials said today.         The meeting was the latest twist in a United States effort, begun in 1978, to curb the potential spread of nuclear weapons by limiting civilian use of the high-enriched uranium needed to build bombs.

headline: World News Briefs;3 Are Killed in Gunfight At Mosque in Kashmir
abstract: A furious gun battle between troops and separatist guerrillas in Kashmir's holiest shrine today killed at least three people and raised fears of a widespread public uprising.         Guerrillas have occupied the white marble, onion-domed mosque in Srinagar, the state's summer capital, for more than a year. But until now, security forces had avoided fighting in the ancient Hazratbal mosque, which holds a sacred relic that Muslims believe is a hair of the Prophet Mohammed.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
abstract: * Steven T. Florio, president of Conde Nast Publications, New York, a unit of Advance Publications, was named to the added new post of chief executive. * Dick Salyer, senior vice president and national account director at Wells Rich Greene BDDP Advertising, Chicago, a unit of BDDP Worldwide, was promoted to president. He succeeds Larry Singer, who resigned last month.

headline: Denver Airport Completes Bond Auction
abstract: While it did not go exactly as planned, the Denver International Airport yesterday completed its Dutch auction -- a financing technique unusual in the municipal market that lowers the airport's borrowing costs.         The recent rise in municipal bond interest rates that began last week forced  Denver officials to scale back the size of the auction, along with another bond  refinancing that went to market yesterday. Together, the two deals issued about  $243 million in refunded debt at rates ranging from 4 percent to 6.05 percent. These borrowings replace existing debt with higher interest rates.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS;Treasuries' Prices Rise a Bit; Long-Bond Yield at 6.70%
abstract: Prices of Treasury securities moved moderately higher yesterday.
