The small rise followed a week of declines that were prompted by a March 8 employment report showing that a surprisingly strong number of jobs were created in February. But yesterday's gain was seen as mostly technical in nature.

headline: U.S. TO SHEPHERD PROTEST OFF CUBA BY AN EXILE GROUP
abstract: In a move aimed at heading off another confrontation between Cuba and anti-Castro activists, President Clinton today ordered the Coast Guard to escort Cuban-American protesters who plan to send boats and small airplanes into the Caribbean on Saturday.         A White House spokesman said the escort was intended to make sure the protest, commemorating the shooting down last week of two American aircraft by the Cuban Air Force, would be confined to international waters and airspace.

headline: Europe Clears Lufthansa-S.A.S. Link
abstract: The European Commission cleared a cooperation pact today between Lufthansa of Germany and Scandinavian Airlines System on the condition that the airlines take steps to insure the link does not turn into a monopoly.         It made the carriers promise to give up certain slots, flights and agreements with other airlines.

headline: Italy Begins Trial of Ex-Premier on Mafia Ties
abstract: As Giulio Andreotti, seven times a Prime Minister of Italy, sat hunched between his defense lawyers scribbling notes, the Mafia turncoat whose testimony led to his indictment asked confidently that a screen set up to shield him from  photographers and television cameras be removed.         Thus, in a high-security courtroom in Padua today, began the first face-to-face confrontation between Tommaso Buscetta, the Italian Government's key informer on the mob, and Mr. Andreotti, whom he accused of acting as the Mafia's protector during decades in public office.

headline: Then the Hard Part: Settling With Iacocca
abstract: The tense negotiations between Kirk Kerkorian and the Chrysler Corporation dragged on for nearly two months with some progress. Then came the tough one: What to do about Lee A. Iacocca.         Chrysler considered its former chairman a traitor because he had signed up with Mr. Kerkorian's campaign to take over the company last April. When Mr. Iacocca later tried to cash in his stock options, Chrysler blocked him and denied its former chairman a payoff of $42 million based on the price of Chrysler shares last summer.

headline: Judge Allows Gay Bias Suit Vs. Big Board
abstract: A former employee of the New York Stock Exchange has been allowed to push ahead with a lawsuit accusing the exchange of dismissing him because he is a homosexual.         The former employee's victory came three weeks ago, when Justice Stuart C. Cohen of State Supreme Court in Manhattan denied the exchange's request that the complaint be dismissed on summary judgment -- that is, without a trial. The judge's refusal to do so permits the ex-employee, Peter Degan, to proceed with his discrimination case.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Ferrero Consolidates Work at McCann
abstract: Ferrero International B. V. in Amsterdam, the marketer of products like Tic Tac mints, Rocher chocolates and Nutella spread, has consolidated its accounts in the United States, Puerto Rico, Latin America and the Asia/Pacific market at  the McCann-Erickson Worldwide unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies in New  York. The billings were estimated at $60 million.          McCann, which has worked for Ferrero in countries like Mexico and Japan, will gain accounts from agencies including Altschiller & Company in New York, a  unit of the Omnicom Group that is being sold to Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos in Boston. Altschiller had handled the Tic Tac account in the United  States, with billings estimated at $15 million, since 1981. The consolidation, which had been expected, brings the billings awarded to McCann so far this month to an estimated $450 million.

headline: In Auctions Of Airwaves, The Sky Seems To Be the Limit
abstract: As Assistant Secretary of Commerce under President George Bush, Janice Obuchowski was a passionate evangelist for what was then a radical idea: selling licenses to the nation's airwaves through auctions, rather than giving them away free.         Today, such auctions are real, and Ms. Obuchowski is still a true believer. Only now, she is backing her convictions with nearly $2 billion.

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: JAMES RIVER CORP., Richmond, the maker of paper products including Brawny paper  towels and Dixie paper cups, named Miles L. Marsh, its president and chief executive, to the additional position of chairman. He succeeds Robert C. Williams, co-founder, who retired on Dec. 31 and will continue on the board until April, when his term expires.

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization                                                Jan. 19   Jan. 12   Jan. 20                                              1996      1996      1995 Gasoline production, daily                    7.2       7.3       7.2 Distillate production, daily                  3.2       3.1       3.0 Gasoline stocks                             208.8     205.8     212.7 Distillate stocks                           122.8     125.8     139.6 Crude imports, daily                          7.7       7.4       6.5 Product imports, daily                        1.9       1.7       1.5 Crude stocks                                310.0     303.5     321.7 Crude production, daily                       6.5       6.5       6.4 Refinery utilization (%)                     90.7      89.8      90.7

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;ITT May Acquire Control of Sportschannel
abstract: As a result of negotiations with the Cablevision Systems Corporation about the repayment of a loan, the ITT Corporation may gain control of Sportschannel New York, which televises the games of the Mets, Islanders, Devils and Nets.         The negotiations stem from the partnership the two companies struck to buy Madison Square Garden in 1994 from Viacom Inc. for $1 billion. The Garden already has the MSG Network, which telecasts Yankees, Rangers and Knicks games.  Pairing it with Sportschannel would create a potent programming combination.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Reuters Says Profit Rose 17% in 1995
abstract: Reuters Holdings P.L.C., the world's largest distributor of financial information, said yesterday that its pretax profit rose 17 percent in 1995 as use of its market trading and information management systems increased. Pretax profit was $928 million last year, compared with $790 million in 1994.         Peter Job, chief executive of Reuters, said slower growth in revenue from existing customers because of mergers and job cuts in the securities industry was "substantially offset by the record volumes traded on our equities and foreign exchange transaction systems."

headline: Management Fees Aren't Everything
abstract: To the Editor:         As a mutual fund investor, I appreciate your efforts to disclose pricing practices that could be deemed harmful to investors ("The Rise in Fees: How a Little Can Mean a Lot," Mutual Funds, Jan. 28). There are, of course, numerous mutual funds that charge unsuspecting individuals unnecessarily high fees. Third Avenue Value Fund is not one of those funds. Moreover, the management fee highlighted in the article is just one component of what an investor is charged. The overall expense ratio -- the true cost to the investor -- is the relevant issue.

headline: 14 Arrested in Nicaragua Church Bombings
abstract: The Nicaraguan police said today that they had arrested 14 suspects in connection with a string of church bombings that have unsettled authorities as the nation prepares for a visit by Pope John Paul II on Feb. 7.         National Police Chief Fernando Caldera said at a news conference today that the arrests, including five that were reported last week, are the strongest blows yet delivered against the bombers, who have targeted 18 Catholic churches  since May. The bombings have caused only minor damage and no injuries.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;DOW CHEMICAL CO. (DOW,N)
abstract: The Dow Chemical Company's earnings rose in the fourth quarter, benefiting from higher prices for several basic chemicals and lower manufacturing costs.         Net income rose to $415 million, or $1.63 a share, in the fourth quarter, from $222 million, or 80 cents a share, last year, after various charges and special gains.

headline: YOUR TAXES;Late-Model Tax Software Can Accelerate Filing
abstract: FEW consumer goods have run so counter to inflation in recent years as computer software, and nowhere is that truer than for tax-preparation programs,  which have gotten much easier to use and more comprehensive, even as their prices have tumbled.         In the early 1980's, when PC's with dual floppy disk drives emerged as status symbols for executives and as the prize possessions of nerds, software publishers began offering tax-preparation programs, typically for $200 to $300,  that were little more than specialized spreadsheets for the most frequently used forms and schedules.

headline: Market Place;As America Online's share price has soared, so has the growing number of short-sellers.
abstract: LAST Thursday, Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation cut back its on-line service sharply, conceding that the future of electronic publishing is on the Internet.  And the News Corporation is just the latest of several big companies to have reached that conclusion -- the most notable being Microsoft, which scrapped its  plans for an on-line service and put Microsoft Network mainly on the Internet's World Wide Web.         Yet there was another development in the business of cyberspace last Thursday. The share price of the king of conventional on-line services, America  Online, quietly rose to another record, at $51 a share, up from less than $16 a  share a year ago.

headline: Treasury's Sales This Week Will Include Notes
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week consists of bills and notes,  beginning with today's auction of new three- and six-month bills. The Treasury will auction a two-year note tomorrow and a five-year note on Wednesday.         By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.96 percent and on a six-month bill 4.85 percent. In when-issued trading, a two-year note was being offered at a rate to  yield 5.02 percent and a five-year note at a rate to yield 5.26 percent.

headline: FUNDS WATCH;Think Small To Win Big
abstract: Many mutual fund investors and advisers have been beating the index fund drum lately. The argument goes that because more than 80 percent of diversified equity funds trailed the Standard & Poor's 500 last year, why not simply buy the index?         Depending on how you invest, that may not be a bad idea. A study by Morningstar Inc., the fund researchers in Chicago, shows that funds that invest  in large-capitalization stocks have generally not outperformed the overall market over the last 10 years. But many mid-cap and small-cap funds fared much better than their market indexes.

headline: Grace Spurns Baxter's $3.8 Billion Dialysis-Chain Bid
abstract: Hinting that it was considering more lucrative offers, W. R. Grace & Company  yesterday brushed aside a $3.8 billion bid by Baxter International for National  Medical Care, Grace's big chain of kidney dialysis centers. Albert J. Costello,  chief executive of Grace, said he would disclose "our plans" on Monday."         Baxter, a health care products manufacturer, made public its offer of cash, stock and assumed debt yesterday and said it "would be willing to negotiate all aspects of its proposal" with Grace, which is based in Boca Raton, Fla.

headline: For Copper Plaintiffs, the Venue Is Peru
abstract: The Southern Peru Copper Company won dismissal today of a lawsuit filed in United States District Court here by hundreds of Peruvians who accused the company of pollution. Judge Janis Graham Jack ruled that Federal and international law required that the case be tried in Peru.          Also named in the suit, filed in August, were Asarco Inc. of New York, which owns 51 percent of Southern Peru Copper, and the Phelps Dodge Corporation of Phoenix and the Newmont Mining Corporation of Denver, minority shareholders in Southern Peru Copper.

headline: MARKET TIMING
abstract: MONDAY      Banks, exchanges and government offices are closed to observe Presidents' Day.

headline: FUTURES MARKETS;Wheat Surges as China Buys 77.2 Million Bushels in 3 Days
abstract: Wheat prices surged on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday after China finished a three-day buying spree of 77.2 million bushels, equal to one-fourth of the wheat produced last year in Kansas.         On other markets, gold prices retreated, while coffee prices rose. The Commodity Research Bureau index of 17 commodities rose 0.51 point, to 242.21.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;FIRSTAR TO ACQUIRE AMERICAN BANCORPORATION
abstract: The Firstar Corporation of Milwaukee said that it had reached a definitive agreement yesterday to acquire the privately held American Bancorporation of St. Paul and its parent, the Jacob Schmidt Company, for $220 million in stock and cash. Of the total price of $220 million, Firstar agreed to pay 80 percent in stock and 20 percent in cash -- if the stock is trading between $36 and $44 at the time of closing. If Firstar is trading higher than $44 a share, the stock portion will gradually increase to 100 percent, and the transaction value will gradually increase to a maximum of $225 million. If Firstar is trading lower than $36, the transaction value will gradually decrease to a minimum of $215 million. Firstar was unchanged yesterday at $37.50.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;ADVO TO DROP 500 WORKERS IN COST-CUTTING MOVE
abstract: Advo Inc. said yesterday that it would dismiss 500 white-collar workers and eliminate a layer of management in an effort to cut costs amid declining profits. The company has 4,600 employees. Advo, the nation's largest direct-mail company, is also close to the sale of its Marketing Force unit. Advo's general counsel, David Stigler, declined to provide a price range or identify the buyer. Advo shares tumbled $3.375 yesterday, or 14 percent, to $20.625, in New York stock Exchange trading of 1.1 million shares. Advo also posted lower-than-expected first-quarter earnings and said it would take a second-quarter charge to pay a special $10-a-share dividend.

headline: L.I. Broker Sued Over Teachers' Loss
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission sued a Long Island broker yesterday, contending that he had stolen retirement money from at least five teachers. The  S.E.C. charged that the broker, Wayne T. Drinkwine, had told the teachers that their money would be invested in trusts that did not exist.         Five current and retired teachers lost a total of $450,000 in retirement savings while doing business with Mr. Drinkwine at Mutual Financial Services Inc. according to the S.E.C. complaint. The agency said it was seeking a permanent injunction against future violations of securities laws by Mr. Drinkwine, and has demanded that he return his "ill-gotten gains."

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Unitech's Shares Soar to All-Time High
abstract: Shares of Unitech P.L.C., a British electronics manufacturer, soared 34 percent yesterday to an all-time high after its larger rival, Siebe P.L.C., said it was in talks to buy the company. The purchase, estimated to be worth as much  as L500 million ($760 million), would catapult Siebe, a manufacturer of industrial controls and other electrical equipment, into the No. 1 position in the fast-growing market for power supply converters.          Siebe paid Elektrowatt A.G. L103 million in cash, or 590 pence ($9.03) a share, on Friday for a 24.9 percent stake in Unitech. Unitech's shares closed at 688 each, up 173 pence. The shares were at 515 pence before the announcement on  Friday.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: Market Place;G.M. has begun telling analysts it can't offset lost production.
abstract: AS the General Motors Corporation struggles to reopen its assembly plants after a 17-day brake-factory strike, the bad news for the company, for its shareholders and for the American economy is that much of the lost weeks of production may never be made up. And that disrupts G.M.'s planning for the third quarter, when it will shut many plants as it prepares to introduce many new models, its most ambitious retooling in years.         G.M. had built up unusually large inventories over the winter, anticipating limited production in the third quarter. But now a large chunk of that inventory is being sold and could be hard to replace.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;AMERICAN GREETINGS AGAIN BIDS FOR GIBSON
abstract: The American Greetings Corporation said today that it had made another offer  to buy Gibson Greetings Inc., this time for $18 a share, or a total of $292.9 million. American Greetings, the nation's No. 2 maker of greeting cards, said Gibson, the No. 3 card maker, had declined to meet with it to discuss the offer. Hallmark Cards Inc. is No. 1. Gibson spurned an earlier offer last July, citing  antitrust complications. The two companies together would have more than 50 percent of the United States market. In July, Gibson, which is based in Cincinnati, had said that it might put itself up for sale after it lost market share to American Greetings and Hallmark, posted its first annual loss since going public in 1982 and lost several key executives. The shares of Gibson closed yesterday at $14.50, down 12.5 cents. American Greetings stock rose 37.5  cents, to $28.25.

headline: SPENDING IT;Finding Your Glitch in Banking on Your PC
abstract: IT is a modern corollary to Murphy's Law that any time you find a way to do something more efficiently with a computer, enough bugs crop up so you wind up with no more free time than before.         That is the exasperating experience of many of the initial users of the home  banking features introduced last October in Quicken, the most popular software program for tracking personal finances.

headline: In Israel, Fertile Ground For Foreign Investment
abstract: To the Editor:         I do not believe that investors will stand on the sidelines or get cold feet  to the point that they will bypass Israel after the tragic death of Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin ("After Assassination, Israel Is a Fragile Market," Investing It, Nov. 12).

headline: Treasury Schedules Week's Auctions
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week consists of tomorrow's auction of three- and six-month bills and Thursday's auction of a one-year bill.         By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.93 percent and on the six-month bill, 4.94 percent. The rate on the outstanding one-year bill was 4.87 percent.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Marriott Rejects Proposal
abstract: Marriott International, the United States-based hotel chain, said yesterday that it had rejected an assets- swap offer from the British television and leisure company Granada Group P.L.C. under which Marriott would have acquired the Meridien chain and some trophy hotels. Granada succeeded last week in a bid  of L3.9 billion ($5.9 billion) to acquire Forte, the owner of Meridien. It plans to sell the Meridien and Exclusive chains, including such trophy properties as Grosvenor House in London. "Granada approached Marriott with that deal, but Marriott rejected it," a Marriott spokeswoman said.   (Reuters)

headline: COMPANY NEWS;DETAILS OF CAMPBELL TAGGART SPINOFF ARE RELEASED
abstract: The Anheuser-Busch Companies announced the terms yesterday of the planned spinoff of its baking business. The company expects to distribute to stockholders one share in the business, Campbell Taggart Inc., for every 25 Anheuser-Busch shares held, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The new concern, to be renamed the Earthgrains Company, will distribute a total of 10.2 million common shares, based on the 254 million  Anheuser-Busch shares outstanding as of Jan. 31. Based on the closing price Tuesday on the New York Stock Exchange, the spinoff is valued at $684.7 million. Anheuser-Busch also agreed to sell its Cape Cod Potato Chips business,  as well as the plant in Hyannis, Mass., where the chips are made, back to the founder, Steve Bernard. Terms were not disclosed. (Dow Jones)

headline: Colombia Closes In On President
abstract: Since virtually the day that President Ernesto Samper Pizano was elected two  years ago, allegations that his campaign accepted millions of dollars in contributions from drug smugglers have gnawed like a political tapeworm at the Colombian President and his administration.         But the rash of denunciations that has pushed his presidency to the brink of  collapse in recent days was set off largely by the decision of a panel of Colombian judges last month to extend by two years the office of a seemingly incorruptible and indefatigable prosecutor, Alfonso Valdivieso Sarmiento.

headline: Stock Prices Finish Mixed In a Day of Listless Trading
abstract: Stocks were mixed yesterday in slow trading, with little in the way of economic news or internal dynamics to propel the market.         "The stock market didn't have much of a direction all day long," said Rao Chalasani, chief investment strategist for Everen Securities in Chicago. "This is nothing new and always happens right before the end of a quarter."

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Countrywide Unit Picks Kovel Kresser
abstract: The Countrywide Home Loans unit of the Countrywide Corporation in Pasadena, Calif., has named Kovel Kresser & Partners in Santa Monica, Calif., to handle the direct-marketing portion of its account, which for the last eight months had been at the Wunderman Cato Johnson/Los Angeles unit of Young & Rubicam Inc. The  billings were estimated at $10 million. Kovel Kresser was awarded the account without a review. Lord, Dentsu & Partners in Los Angeles, a joint venture of Dentsu Inc. and Y.& R., continues to handle the advertising portion of the account.

headline: Chirac Reaps Glory, and Grumbling, on French Military Cutbacks
abstract: President Jacques Chirac, denounced around the world only a month ago for conducting underground nuclear weapons tests in the Pacific, reaped praise today for his decision to phase out the land-based third of the French nuclear deterrent and to stop all further production of weapons-grade fissionable material.         But his plan to abolish conscription and to shrink the uniformed military from 500,000 to 350,000 in an all-volunteer force six years from now met with mixed reactions, inside and outside the ranks.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;VW Says '95 Profits More Than Doubled
abstract: Volkswagen A.G., Europe's largest car maker, said yesterday that its profits  more than doubled in 1995 to 336 million marks ($228 million). But the results were weaker than industry analysts had forecast. Revenues climbed to 88.12 billion marks ($59.94 billion), from 80.04 billion marks a year earlier. Operating profit soared to 1.11 billion marks ($755 million), from 461 million marks the year before.          Although the profits were lower than expected, there is a growing view that  VW is back on the road to sustained profits after suffering a loss of nearly 2 billion marks in 1993.   Reuters

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Hewlett-Packard Account Review
abstract: The Hewlett-Packard Company in Palo Alto, Calif., said yesterday that it would begin a review on the account of its peripherals products in the United States, which include printers and scanners. The billings on the account, which  has been handled by Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide in San Francisco, were estimated at $40 million.         "Being with Saatchi for eight years, we felt it was time to take a fresh look," said Jeremy James, a spokesman for Hewlett-Packard. He said the company was seeking an agency that was "excellent in both consumer and business-to-business advertising." Other accounts handled by Saatchi & Saatchi,  such as computers in the United States and various products in Europe, are not involved in the review, he added.

headline: Cuba's Nuclear Plant Project Worries Washington
abstract: From the day the Cuban Government began building an atomic reactor here in the early 1980's, American officials were alarmed at the prospect that a nuclear power plant of Soviet design and questionable safety would be going into operation less than 200 miles from American shores, but powerless to do anything about it.         So when President Fidel Castro came to this beachfront site on Cuba's southern coast three and a half years ago to tell thousands of workers that construction of "the undertaking of the century" was being suspended, the United States, along with Cuba's Caribbean neighbors, breathed a sigh of relief, certain that Cuba's nuclear adventure was finally at an end.

headline: Prosperity In New Chile Nourishes Drug Trade
abstract: For the last decade, Chile has served as the model for economic growth and stability in Latin America, after opening its doors to foreign investment and shifting from military dictatorship to democracy.         But like a rising star with a dirty little secret, this enterprising country  of 13 million people, nestled on a narrow strip of land between the Andean Mountains and the Pacific Ocean, has also become a major center for drug trafficking and money laundering.

headline: In Uneasy Time, Saudi Prince Provides a Hope of Stability
abstract: Every Tuesday they come, petitioners by the hundreds -- bearded sheiks, tribal elders, impoverished Saudis and some of the country's elite -- to seek out the man who is poised to become the next king.         With burning incense, vast carpets and crystal chandeliers, the nighttime gathering is unquestionably a royal affair. But as even the humblest visitors step forward, each is allowed a moment to make his case face to face.

headline: Housing Gains as Economic Data Rebound
abstract: The first in an avalanche of statistics on the economy showed today that home building was buoyant in November throughout much of the country. But in the Northeast, building slumped to its lowest pace in nearly two years.         Builders broke ground on new homes at a 1.42 million annual clip in the month, 5.7 percent higher than in October, according to the Commerce Department  report, which had been scheduled for Dec. 19. The gain was entirely in multifamily dwellings, and compares with starts in October that were revised downward.

headline: Seoul and Tokyo Dispute Offshore Islands
abstract: Japan and South Korea staked competing claims to waters around their shores today, in a dispute over islets that fall within those waters.         Acting hours apart, the two Governments declared exclusive rights to the natural resources in the sea that lies between them, without mentioning the practically uninhabited islets, called Tok-do by the Koreans and Takeshima by the Japanese.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Cowboy in the Black Forest;Daimler Chief's Tough Style Isn't Business as Usual for Europe
abstract: On a warm evening last July, the chairman of Daimler-Benz A.G. and two of his subordinates were stopped by the Italian police near Rome's Spanish Steps, "in an exuberant mood" and carrying a bottle of red wine.         What ensued is not totally clear. But the Roman police said that a young woman in the group used "unfortunate language" with Italian officers, and that another group member grabbed an officer's wrist, causing a minor injury. The three were taken to the local precinct, where they presented their passports and were eventually let go.

headline: Fourth-Quarter Results Cap Off the Best Year Ever for the Nation's BigBanks
abstract: The nation's biggest banks capped off their best year ever -- reporting sharply higher operating profits yesterday for the fourth quarter -- as nearly everything went right. Revenue from loans and fees rose faster than costs, while the levels of bad loans continued to be relatively low.         This year, the banks' fortunes may be weakened somewhat, analysts said, by falling interest rates, which will depress profit margins on loans, and by increased losses on loans to consumers.

headline: Holding Compuserve Responsible
abstract: Germans often describe Munich as the country's largest village -- the picturesque Baroque capital of Bavaria with a million residents, home to BMW and the electronic giant Siemens A.G., but with no real pretensions to being an international metropolis.         But this region of castles and forests was catapulted to international attention last month when Compuserve, the world's second-largest on-line service, blocked access to more than 200 discussion groups on the Internet, many of which deal with sexually explicit material, after the state prosecutor's office said they violated the country's pornography laws.

headline: Texas Instruments Cites Surplus of Computer Memory Chips
abstract: Texas Instruments Inc. said today that an oversupply of memory chips was hurting prices as demand for personal computers slowed.         As a result, growth in the worldwide semiconductor industry this year is likely to be less than expected, the company said at its annual meeting here with analysts.

headline: Auto Club Purchases
abstract: The Automobile Club of Southern California is acquiring sister not-for-profit clubs in Texas, New Mexico and Hawaii. A spokeswoman, Layna Browdy, said the deal had been approved by the club's board and by the board of the national American Automobile Association, which has run the Texas, New Mexico and Hawaii  groups recently. Ms. Browdy would not disclose takeover details.  The deal would give the Southern California club, the largest A.A.A. affiliate, with 4.2  million current members, potential to expand its insurance, travel and auto finance businesses in markets where its penetration is far lower than in California.

headline: A Surge in Second Second-Chance Finance
abstract: THE neon signs promising "fast cash" flicker from dusty brick storefronts as  they have for 50 years on this narrow stretch of Church Street known as Loan Alley.         It's lunch hour on a brisk but sunny winter day as a handful of people line up at World Finance to borrow a few hundred dollars or to drop off a few $20 bills as payment on their old loans.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;TRIARC FINDS NEW BUYER FOR TEXTILE BUSINESS
abstract: The Triarc Companies said yesterday that it would sell its Graniteville textile business and that it planned an initial public offering for its National Propane unit. The company said it would sell Graniteville to Avondale Inc., of Monroe, Ga., for $255 million in cash. Triarc previously agreed to sell Graniteville to Galey & Lord Inc., but said yesterday that both companies had agreed to end the deal. Triarc will also seek Securities and Exchange Commission permission to market limited partnership units in National Propane, in which Triarc plans to keep a stake. Triarc, a New York company that is the parent of Arby's Inc. and the Royal Crown Cola Company, plans to take one-time charges in  the fourth quarter to account for the moves.   (Dow Jones)

headline: Russia Is Distrusted on Uranium Deal
abstract: The Clinton Administration is scrambling to fend off accusations that it cannot verify whether Moscow is cheating on a deal that was central to ending the cold war -- the purchase by the United States of enriched uranium from thousands of Russian nuclear warheads.         The doubts center on whether the Russians are indeed dismantling weapons, as  agreed, or are supplying the uranium from other sources, like stockpiles or continued production.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
abstract: * West Hollywood Convention and Visitors Bureau to Lois, Colby/Los Angeles, a unit of Lois/USA, to handle its advertising, which had been inactive. The billings were not disclosed. * Harrah's Entertainment, Memphis, to Targetbase Marketing, Irving, Tex., a unit of the M/A/R/C Group, as the first agency to handle direct marketing for the casino gambling company. The billings were not disclosed. * IVF America, White Plains, to Christopher Thomas Associates, Garden City, L.I., to handle its direct consumer advertising account, previously handled in-house. The billings were not disclosed.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                                               Previous      Year                               Yesterday       Day       Ago

headline: EARNING IT;The Virtual Office Bumps Into Some Very Real Limits
abstract: FOR seven years, Judith S. Lederman worked out of her home and employed six other consultants who worked from their homes, too. But whatever its benefits, this virtual office frequently left her frustrated. "I was getting a level of work that was unprofessional, and I was unable to monitor it," she said. "The projects were floundering."        It was the cheesecake, though, that really got Ms. Lederman's goat. One of the consultants she had retained failed to meet a deadline, and when Ms. Lederman asked her about it, the woman said that a friend had come over and brought a cheesecake. Apparently, the work had been put on hold while the two enjoyed some dessert.

headline: Taking In the Sites;A Ticket Backstage On the Web
abstract: Their daddies are rich and their mamas good lookin'. Orphans, cats and impossible dreams -- these are a few of their favorite things. What do these simple folk, these lovers of musical theater, do on the Internet?         If they are sincere, they may head for the rapidly evolving World Wide Web domain of Michael Butler, best known as the producer of "Hair!" There, they can find a wealth of details about the creation and staging of Mr. Butler's latest show, "Pope Joan," a tale of a ninth-century woman who rises through the  Roman Catholic hierarchy to become Pope while disguised as a man. The show opens at the Mercury Theater in Chicago on Feb. 18.

headline: Another Media Concern Dashes Into Professional Sports
abstract: In another case illustrating the growing attraction sports properties hold for large media corporations, the Comcast Corporation yesterday announced its purchase of two-thirds of a new venture to own the Philadelphia Flyers, the Philadelphia 76ers, the Corestates Spectrum, where both teams now play, and the  new Corestates Center, into which they will move in August.         Precise details were unavailable. But Brian L. Roberts, president of Comcast, said at a news conference yesterday in Philadelphia that he was paying $250 million for the cable company's 66 percent stake. Christopher Dixon, an analyst  for Paine Webber, estimated that Comcast was paying $125 million in cash, $100 million in stock and the rest in assumed liabilities.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;CASINO DATA SHARES PLUMMET AFTER 6 EXECUTIVES LEAVE
abstract: The shares of Casino Data Systems plunged 24.4 percent yesterday after six executives who joined the company in December returned to their previous employer, International Game Technology. Casino Data, a casino technology company based in Las Vegas, Nev., that is trying to enter the gambling-machine business, hired away four International Game vice presidents and two division directors in December. Casino Data did not return a telephone call seeking comment. International Game, which is based in Reno, Nev., said the executives would seek a release of their employment agreements with Casino Data or a determination that those obligations could not be enforced. Casino Data shares dropped $3.75, to $11.625, in Nasdaq trading. Shares of International Game, which makes video games, slot machines and gaming monitoring systems, climbed 75 cents, to $14.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: U.N., World Bank and I.M.F. Join $25 Billion Drive for Africa
abstract: With Africa falling deeper into debt and poverty, the United Nations has announced a joint program involving the World Bank, International Monetary Fund  and its own agencies aimed at raising $25 billion over the next decade to spur development on the continent.         Twenty-two of the 25 countries with the lowest levels of economic and social  development, as measured by the United Nations, are in Africa. Fifty-four percent of Africans live below the United Nations level for absolute poverty, and Africa is the only region in the world where poverty is expected to increase over the next 10 years.

headline: Russian Church Breaks Off From Orthodoxy's Historic Center
abstract: The Russian Orthodox Church has severed ties with the historic center of Eastern Orthodoxy, the Patriarchate of Constantinople, in a dispute over the independence of the church in Estonia.         The action sets the largest Orthodox church, with more than 100 million members, against the traditional and symbolic center of Eastern Orthodox leadership.

headline: I.B.M. Set to Release Cheaper Software
abstract: In a bid to blunt the growing momentum of the Microsoft Corporation and improve its weak software business, the International Business Machines Corporation plans to introduce a series of aggressively priced new software packages today that run on corporate networks.         The new software combines more than 50 products, which were previously sold separately, into seven integrated bundles centered around specific applications  such as those for data bases, communications and systems management. And in a break with tradition, the applications will run on Microsoft's Windows NT operating system as well as OS/2 and AIX, two of I.B.M.'s operating systems.

headline: Taking In the Sites;It's Never Off-Season For Bicyclists on Line
abstract: Bicyclists are notorious gearheads, craving the latest titanium doodad and convinced that life will be pure bliss once they own a set of Zipp 3000 three-spoke composite wheels.        So it should be no surprise that electronic gear appeals to them, too, and that many people jump right from bicycles to their keyboards. Bicycling sites are everywhere on the Web; in fact, there are so many out there that it is hard  to separate the useful from the fluff.

headline: Press Faces Repression In Africa
abstract: When this country opened the way for an independent press at the turn of the  decade, the blossoming of newspapers of nearly every political persuasion was widely hailed as a critical stepping stone toward true multiparty democracy.         But here, as elsewhere in Africa, rather than marking a clean break with an authoritarian past, the era of multiparty politics has been a time of increased  hardship and repression for journalists who dare criticize powerful incumbents.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS;Expectations Of a Rate Cut Raise Bonds
abstract: Expectations of an imminent rate cut by the Federal Reserve brought a steady  stream of buyers to the bond market yesterday, causing prices to climb.         As the Fed's Open Market Committee began a two-day meeting that will determine monetary policy for months ahead, investor beliefs were reinforced by  morning reports on January consumer confidence and a retail sales report for December.

headline: A New Compuserve Service Plans to Appeal to Families
abstract: Compuserve Inc. disclosed plans yesterday for a proprietary service aimed at  families and novice computer users.         In offering such a service, Compuserve is going against the tide of the consumer on-line industry, which has moved toward an open approach within the Internet.

headline: Stocks Revive After Move In House to End Shutdown
abstract: Stock prices were whipsawed yesterday, with stocks recovering in the afternoon after the House moved to end the partial Government shutdown.         "It was a stock picker's market, one that was completely hostage to the budget negotiations," said Richard C. Pell, chief investment officer of Bank Julius Baer. "There was a huge amount of rotation from group to group on surging volume."

headline: COMPANY NEWS;MARVEL NAMES EXECUTIVE FOR NEW SOFTWARE DIVISION
abstract: The Marvel Entertainment Group has chosen Scott Marden to be chief executive  of a new division, Marvel Software. Mr. Marden, 41, had been the president and chief executive of Philips Media, a unit of Philips Electronics. Mr. Marden said he hoped to propel Marvel into electronic publishing by developing on-line services and Web sites. Marvel, which owns comic-book titles like Spider-Man and the X-Men, has been somewhat haphazard in licensing those characters to multimedia outlets, he said. "It has become increasingly clear that the future of the company was going to be tied to electronic delivery," Mr. Marden said. At Philips, Mr. Marden established a multimedia publishing division and oversaw  the company's cable TV holdings.

headline: World News Briefs;Tribunal Asks Belgium To Give Up 3 Rwandans
abstract: A United Nations tribunal investigating the slaying of a half-million Rwandans in 1994 asked Belgium today to extradite three suspects, the first to be publicly named by the court.         In Brussels, a Belgian Foreign Ministry spokesman said the Belgian Government "supports the principle of the International Tribunal." He added: "We are cooperating."

headline: A New Element Is Found: Zinc's Heavy Kin
abstract: Scientists at a German research institute have added a new element to the periodic table: element 112, a heavier, still unnamed relative of zinc, cadmium  and mercury.         A team of German, Russian, Slovak and Finnish physicists detected a single atom of the new metal on Feb. 9, the Society for Heavy Ion Research in Darmstadt announced today.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;SHARES OF DEPARTMENT 56 FALL AFTER EARNINGS REPORT
abstract: Shares of Department 56 Inc. plunged 41 percent yesterday after the company,  a distributor of collectibles, reported lower than expected earnings and said that orders would fall. In New York Stock Exchange trading yesterday, shares of  the company fell $15.625, to $22.375. It was the most active issue with trading  volume of almost 5.7 million shares. The company, which also distributes specialty giftware, said orders in the current quarter would slip 10 percent after it terminated about 50 customers for violating its merchandise guidelines. Department 56 said net income in the three months ended Dec. 31 increased to $5.5 million, or 25 cents a share. But analysts had expected earnings of 27 cents a share, according to the First Call Corporation.

headline: 2 Companies Make Cable Modem Plan
abstract: The 3Com Corporation said that it had purchased an equity stake in closely held Com21 Inc. and that it would work with the company to develop cable modems.         Terms of the investment were not disclosed.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;IP TIMBERLANDS TO SELL MOST OF A UNIT FOR $550 MILLION
abstract: IP Timberlands Ltd. said yesterday that it plans to sell more than 80 percent of its IP Pacific Forests L.P. unit in an initial public offering for about $550 million, as part of an $800 million capital-raising effort. IP Pacific Forests plans to sell limited partnership units in the public offering and $350 million  in senior debt securities to repay existing debt. IP Timberlands, based in Purchase, N.Y., also said it would make an extraordinary distribution of approximately $5 to $7 per class A unit. But the company said it might have to reduce the regular quarterly distribution of 72 cents. The International Paper Company owns 84 percent of the class A units, and all of class B. IP Timberland  class A units fell $1.875 to close at $22.75. The company owns about 300,000 acres of forest in Oregon and Washington.

headline: Prudential in Talks on Accusations Some Customers Were Misled
abstract: The Prudential Insurance Company of America said yesterday that it was in talks with a task force of state regulators to settle accusations that its agents misled customers in at least 28 states.         "Prudential has discussed with the task force its desire, subject to the results of the task force investigation, to develop a process to provide remedies to customers who may be entitled to relief," said Robert DeFillippo, a spokesman for the nation's largest life insurer.

headline: Berlusconi Looks Like the Loser in Dini's Jump Into Politics
abstract: PARIS—  The transformation of Prime Minister Lamberto Dini from caretaker technocrat to leader of a new centrist political party has triggered a scramble in Italian politics that could spell more trouble for Silvio Berlusconi, the beleaguered media tycoon-turned-politician.

type: I've never heard anyone voice the same outrage over, say, a
headline: Sunday March 3, 1996: NO-FAULT PHOTOS;Picture Perfect Divorce
abstract: The divorce is long final, but the marriage's early promise is still enshrined in the wedding album. Now, thanks to an enterprising businessman in Vancouver, British Columbia, current marital reality and past photo op can be reconciled. Keith Guelpa's computer-aided photographic service, Divorce X, allows embittered customers to preserve the precious memories (usually pictures  of themselves) and edit out the bitter ones (their used-to-be's).          "Our initial idea was to take your ex out of the picture and give you back the original," Guelpa says. But manipulating memories has proved so successful that he now also offers Wedding Retakes, in which he fixes up unruly hair, trims love handles or exorcises entire wedding parties (see above), and Digital Reunion, in which he inserts relatives who just happened to miss that not-to-be-missed gathering.

headline: Real Estate;A securities firm finds some ready-made trading space available for lease in midtown.
abstract: BREAN MURRAY FOSTER SECURITIES INC. has leased 35,000 square feet at 570 Lexington Avenue, the landmarked Art Deco building that was for many years the headquarters of the General Electric Company.         The 15-year lease, for space on the 11th and 12th floors of the 50-floor building, was valued at more than $14 million. Brean Murray will be moving to the building, between 50th and 51st Streets, from 26,000 square feet at 633 Third Avenue, between 40th and 41st Streets. It has been subleasing that space from the Mobil Oil Corporation.

headline: CHECHEN RAIDERS GIVE UP HOSPITAL AND ARE FIRED ON
abstract: For a while it appeared that the crisis was easing: the Chechen rebels who had seizednearly 2,000 hostages on Tuesday at a small hospital in southern Russia were permitted to flee Wednesday morning -- still with 130 of their hostages -- and head toward their homeland.         But then the rebel escape was halted here, on the border between the Russian  republics of Chechnya and Dagestan, when a Russian helicopter fired on the caravan of 11 elderly buses and 2 trucks and Russian troops blew up the only bridge in this region that crosses the Terik River into Chechnya.

headline: OUTLOOK '96: MARKETS AND INVESTING;With U.S. Flat, Where Will the Money Go?
abstract: AMERICAN investors, pack your moneybags.         After a year in which United States stock and bond markets outperformed nearly every market around the globe, many market strategists and investment managers are predicting that 1996 will bring better opportunities abroad.

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Ready for Kashmir Talks With India, Bhutto Says
abstract: Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto said today that Pakistan was ready for talks with India to settle their longstanding dispute over Kashmir, but declared that  her country could match India "in every field" if need be.         In a televised speech on the eve of a national labor strike called to support the separatist revolt in the Indian-ruled part of Kashmir, she accused India of  provocations in the region and promised to support the Kashmiris "till our last  breath."

headline: COMPANY NEWS;PENTAGON CANCELS HUNTER AIRCRAFT PRODUCED BY TRW
abstract: The Hunter unmanned surveillance aircraft, produced by TRW Inc. and Israel Aircraft Industries , has been canceled, the Pentagon said today. The entire Hunter program, including development and production, was expected to cost $4 billion. The Pentagon will end up spending about $667 million. TRW's Avionics and Surveillance unit in San Diego makes the Hunter. A spokesman, Bob Such, said the decision will have no effect on the unit's work force.

headline: Seattle Boy, 4, Enthroned as a Lama in Nepal
abstract: He may be only 4, but his devout followers, who believe him to be the reincaration of a Buddhist monk, have waited nine years for his return.         The boy, an American, was circled by a cluster of monks when he arrived today at the Katmandu airport. They hoisted him onto their shoulders and presented him with a beige silk scarf, in keeping with an ancient Tibetan custom.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;McDONALD'S BOUGHT BACK 8 MILLION SHARES IN 1995
abstract: The McDonald's Corporation said yesterday that it bought back about eight million shares for about $300 million last year. The company bought the shares under a three-year, $1 billion repurchase plan that was announced in January 1994. McDonald's said last month that it expected the buyback to be completed early this year, and that it planned to buy back another $2 billion of common stock in the next three years. As of Dec. 31, there were 699.8 million common shares outstanding. Its shares fell 50 cents yesterday, to $49.75, on the New York Stock Exchange. The shares traded at about $28 when the buyback began.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;TAX RULING LIFTS PHILLIPS PETROLEUM EARNINGS
abstract: The Phillips Petroleum Company said yesterday that its first-quarter net income would be increased by about $565 million because of a favorable tax ruling related to a natural gas operation in Alaska. The company will receive about $375 million in pretax refunds from the Internal Revenue Service in the next few years, with the first $200 million expected in the next 60 days. The refunds will amount to about $275 million after taxes. The company said the remaining $290 million of the after-tax gain was money Phillips had accrued for  taxes and interest but had not yet paid. Phillips reported net income of about $111 million, or 43 cents a share, in the first quarter last year. Its shares rose 37.5 cents yesterday, to $35.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Bouygues of France Posts First Annual Loss
abstract: Bouygues S.A., France's largest construction company, sustained its first full-year loss ever in 1995, after setting aside provisions to cover lower values of property assets and start-up costs for a new mobile telephone network. The company said yesterday that preliminary estimates for 1995 showed it had lost about 4 billion francs ($800 million) last year after setting aside 4.4 billion francs in one-time charges. In 1994 it earned 573 million francs.          The charges were unexpectedly large. Analysts said they expect the Bouygues  shares to fall when trading in the stock resumes today. Stock trading was suspended yesterday at the Paris bourse at the company's request.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Fokker Says Asian Bids Are Not Forthcoming
abstract: The struggling Dutch plane maker Fokker N.V. said yesterday that no suitor had come forth to rescue it despite the passing of a deadline for bids by two Asian aerospace rivals: Samsung Aerospace of South Korea or China's Aviation Industries. If both Asian companies fail to make bids, Fokker's aircraft manufacturing business, with up to 5,500 jobs, would almost certainly close, causing the biggest layoffs in Dutch corporate history.          Fokker said it would make a statement today about its future. The company has hung on with the help of Dutch Government credits while searching for a buyer since its German parent, Daimler-Benz, decided in January not to put any more money into the enterprise.   (Reuters)

headline: Economic Scene;The rich are getting richer, etc., and it's likely to remain that way.
abstract: THE rich are getting richer, the poor, poorer and the middle class is barely  hanging on. But not to worry: it's not nearly as bad as the numbers look.         That has long been the word from Republican conservatives, who view the current handwringing over inequality of income as a distraction from the issue of getting the economy into higher gear. That view is likely to be embraced in the Presidential campaign by Bob Dole, if only because he cannot afford to alienate the "growth is everything" wing of his party. But new research is making the rationale for neglecting inequality harder to sustain.

headline: AMERICAN TOPICS : Short Takes
abstract: The sentinels in full dress uniforms at the Tomb of the Unknowns in Arlington National Cemetery in Virginia now have their first woman, Sergeant Heather Lynn Johnsen, 23, of Roseville, California. The sentinels are drawn from the Army's oldest active unit, the Third Infantry Regiment, which dates to 1784 and is better known as the Old Guard. Although women were admitted to the Old Guard's Fife and Drum Corps in 1982, Sergeant Johnsen is the first woman to take part in the Old Guard's ceremonial duties.

headline: From Book Editor to Publisher, Pretty Darn Quick
abstract: Jerry Seinfeld, Paul Reiser and Ellen DeGeneres have at least three things in common: hit television comedies, best-selling books published by Bantam and a young editor there, Rob Weisbach.         In late December, in a move that surprised many in the publishing world, Mr.  Weisbach jumped ship to join William Morrow, which lured him away, at age 30, with an accolade usually reserved for much more senior editors: his own imprint.

headline: BOMBING IN ISRAEL;ISRAELI RAGE RISES AS BOMB KILLS 19, IMPERILING PEACE
abstract: The dull thud of another exploding bus echoed through Jerusalem early today,  taking 19 lives and deepening the shadow over the future of the Israeli-Palestinian peace.         The suicide bombing came on the same No. 18 bus line as the attack exactly a  week earlier in which 26 lives were lost, although at a different place. This time the explosion occurred at 6:25 A.M. on a narrow stretch of Jaffa Road in the commercial and administrative heart of western Jerusalem, leaving little of  the bus, scattering flesh and debris, and shattering shops and office windows for 100 yards.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS;Treasury Securities Fall Again
abstract: Prices of Treasury securities fell yesterday for the second straight day, as  investor hopes of another rate cut by the Federal Reserve continued to fade on fears of more strong economic data that could lead to inflationary pressures.         Despite the widespread sentiment, there was little economic news on the calendar. The only official report yesterday was revised fourth-quarter productivity from the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Market participants viewed the modest upward drift in wage pressures in the report as inflationary.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS;Little Change For Treasuries As Gains Melt
abstract: Treasury prices ended little changed yesterday, paring early gains made on a  report showing a rise in weekly jobless claims.         Market participants limited their buying yesterday, preferring to await today's employment report for February.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising -- ADDENDA;Seagram Grows At FCB/Leber Katz
abstract: The Seagram Beverage Group said yesterday that it had expanded its relationship with FCB/Leber Katz Partners in New York by naming that agency to handle its North American Dole juices account, which had been at Lord, Dentsu &  Partners in Los Angeles, a joint venture of Dentsu Inc. and Young & Rubicam Inc., for the last five years. The billings were estimated at $5 million to $10  million.          Mark Gutsche, a spokesman for the Seagram Beverage Group, a unit of the Seagram Company in Bradenton, Fla., said the move consolidated Seagram's Tropicana Dole Beverages North America business at FCB/Leber Katz, a unit of True North Communications that was awarded the $25 million account for Tropicana juices in August. Seagram acquired the Dole global juice business from the Dole  Food Company in May. Mr. Gutsche added that FCB/Leber Katz had been awarded the  account without a review.

headline: Level Field or Uneven Results?;Tallying Up the What Ifs in the Flat-Tax Proposals
abstract: A year ago, it is safe to say, not one American in 100 knew much about the flat tax. But after Steve Forbes spent tens of millions of dollars from his fortune espousing it endlessly in the Republican Presidential campaign, the flat tax has become fodder for talk radio and stand-up comedy.         And while Mr. Forbes, who will be pushing the idea in debates leading up to the New Hampshire primary on Tuesday, is expected to fade from the picture, the  concept has generated enough attention to make it likely to be kicking around for some time to come.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;LOEWEN GROUP SAYS IT MIGHT SETTLE ANOTHER BIG SUIT
abstract: Loewen Group Inc., which settled a huge lawsuit this week, indicated it might settle a $60 million breach of contract suit with the Provident American Corporation, a Philadelphia insurance company. "I believe we will find a mutually satisfying settlement," said Raymond Loewen, chairman and chief executive of the company. The suit stems from a contract dispute in 1992. Loewen's comments came just days after the company settled a case in Mississippi that might have forced it into bankruptcy. Loewen, a Canadian funeral-home chain, agreed to pay Jerry O'Keefe, the owner of Gulf National Group in Mississippi, about $175 million in a breach of contract dispute.

headline: A New Chase Tries to Lead;Will the Merged Bank Be Greater Than Its Parts?
abstract: The last two decades make a humbling prelude to the rebirth of the Chase Manhattan Corporation.         On Monday, its merger will be complete with the Chemical Banking Corporation, which itself merged with the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation in 1992. And while Chase will become the largest banking company in the nation, its three predecessors have a record of muddled management, misplaced loans and mediocre performance.

headline: SFX in Deal For 16 Stations
abstract: SFX Broadcasting Inc. agreed yesterday to pay $105.3 million for the assets of the closely held Prism Radio Partners L.P., including 16 radio stations in five markets.         SFX, a New York-based radio station operator, said the deal involved four stations each in Jacksonville, Fla., and Tucson, Ariz; three stations each in Wichita, Kan., and Louisville, Ky., and two stations in Raleigh, N.C.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Amoco Unit Shifts To Leo Burnett
abstract: Amoco Petroleum Products Marketing, a division of the Amoco Corporation, has  abruptly left Campbell-Ewald in Warren, Mich., after almost a year and, without  a review, named as its primary agency the Leo Burnett Company in Chicago. The billings were estimated at $30 million.         "It was a mutual parting of the ways" primarily related to "creative differences," Arline Datu, a spokeswoman for Amoco in Chicago, said Friday. Mark O. Benner, senior vice president for marketing services at Campbell-Ewald, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, agreed, saying, "The fundamental issue was that we were not able to reach a common agreement on creative strategy."

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Carlson's New Hire For Lauren Account
abstract: Neil Kraft, a creative executive in fashion and retail advertising, has joined Carlson & Partners in New York in the new position of senior vice president and creative director, working on the Polo Ralph Lauren Corporation account.          Mr. Kraft, 38, is "an important addition to the management of the agency," said Sandy Carlson, the president of Carlson, adding that Mr. Kraft's experience would help with the introduction of a Lauren line of apparel under the Polo Jeans Company label. Mr. Kraft has worked for marketers like the Elizabeth Arden unit of Unilever N.V., Calvin Klein Inc., Barneys and Esprit de Corp.

headline: After the I.R.A. Bomb, Reviving the Peace Effort
abstract: In the three days since the Irish Republican Army resumed its campaign of violence by detonating a huge bomb in East London, political leaders in Britain  and Ireland have fallen all over themselves reiterating their continued dedication to achieving peace in Northern Ireland.         "We are not at the end of the road for peace," Prime Minister John Major of Britain said in a solemn speech to the House of Commons today. "If we are pushed back we will start again."

headline: World News Briefs;Papandreou to Meet Greek President
abstract: The ailing Prime Minister, Andreas Papandreou, broke his seven-week silence in a hospital today to say that he wants to see the President, raising speculation that he may be ready to resign or name an official deputy.

headline: Stocks Advance on Hopes For Rising Company Profits
abstract: The stock market rose modestly yesterday as traders bet that an expanding economy would push corporate profits upward.         Many traders sold some shares late in the day in anticipation of today's "triple witching," when futures and options on stocks and stock indexes expire simultaneously.

headline: BOMBING IN ISRAEL: THE MOOD;Day's Routine Now a Test of Courage
abstract: Reeling from four devastating suicide bombings in little more than a week that dimmed their hopes for peace, Israelis tried to pull themselves together today, going about daily routines that have become tests of courage.         Commuters and drivers sat in tense silence on city buses in Jerusalem, casting anxious glances at passengers getting on. In Tel Aviv, shoppers filled the sidewalks, burdened with heightened concern that disaster might confront them at the next street corner.

headline: Sarajevo Grenade Leaves One Dead And 19 Wounded
abstract: One man was killed and at least 19 other people were wounded today when a grenade slammed into a Sarajevo streetcar in the worst violence since NATO arrived to enforce the peace here.         The attack cast a shadow on modest celebrations marking the end of one of the few United Nations successes of the Bosnian war -- the longest aid airlift in history.

headline: Paine Webber Nears Deal With S.E.C. in Partnership Case
abstract: Paine Webber Group Inc. has reached an agreement in principle with the Securities and Exchange Commission in which it may pay $25 million to $50 million to settle charges that it misled investors in the sale of risky limited  partnerships during the 1980's, people with knowledge of the agreement said late yesterday.         The proposed settlement, which was still being completed yesterday, is expected to be announced in the next few days -- perhaps as early as today. It would be the second such settlement of a fraud allegation in the last few years  by a major Wall Street brokerage firm involving the sale of partnerships.

headline: C.I.A. WILL PRESS ARAFAT AND ISRAEL ON ANTI-TERRORISM
abstract: In advance of a summit meeting on terrorism, top Central Intelligence Agency  officials will meet this weekend with the chiefs of the Palestinian and Israeli  internal security forces to offer help and encourage the old enemies to cooperate against the suicide bombers of Hamas, American officials said today.         The Deputy Director of Central Intelligence, George J. Tenet, and ranking C.I.A. counterterrorism experts were in Israel tonight and are to meet on Saturday with their opposite numbers in Israel's Shin Bet and the secret police  of Yasir Arafat, leader of the Palestinian Authority.  Official meetings between an American intelligence official of Mr. Tenet's rank and his Palestinian counterpart may be unprecedented, they said.

headline: Business Travel;Executives on the go are the main buyers of portable computers.
abstract: IT may be post-Christmas bargain time for desktop computer buyers, but not for executives browsing the PC market for portable machines. Toshiba's Satellites, Apple's Powerbook 5300, the LTElite from Compaq and the I.B.M. Thinkpad 755 are just a handful of the hottest sellers, according to Kimball Brown, vice president of mobile computing at Dataquest Inc., a leading market-research firm that tracks information technology.         At the higher end of the notebook market, prices range from $3,500 to $7,500. Not cheap, but fine for a corporate traveler whose company is picking up the tab. Many self-employed business travelers settle for machines in the $2,500 to  $3,000 average range.

headline: Ex-Strongman At Seoul Trial Is Denying Taking Bribes
abstract: Pale and weak but defiant, former President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea today denied taking bribes at the start of his trial in Seoul on charges of amassing a huge political slush fund.         "I received money, but they were political donations," Mr. Chun told the court, adding that accepting contributions from industry was "the political custom of the time."

headline: A $40 Million Conceit
abstract: WHEN California's new money collides with old money, the results can be, well, unsettling.         Set in the hills west of Stanford University, Woodside has a population of 5,000 and a tradition of wealth. Members of the Bay Area's power elite have traditionally kept horses on sprawling estates here, and strict zoning ordinances maintain a woodsy, rural feel.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;PRESSTEK DISMISSES AUDITOR IN DISPUTE OVER REPORT
abstract: Presstek Inc. has dismissed its auditor after a dispute over how the company  disclosed an investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission. In a filing with the S.E.C., Presstek, a maker of printing equipment in Hudson, N.H., said its board voted to dismiss Deloitte & Touche, though it had no disagreements with the auditor over financial results. Presstek said in the filing that mentioning the investigation in a 1994 report was unnecessary because it was disclosed elsewhere in the report. Presstek later added the mention to the financial statement notes as well. In November 1994, the S.E.C. began an inquiry into possible manipulation of Presstek's shares. Officials for  Presstek and Deloitte could not be reached for comment. Shares of Presstek fell  $10.75 yesterday, to $83.5, before trading on the Nasdaq market was halted late  in the afternoon.

headline: WITH CHARLIE COMPANY;G.I.'s Meet Bosnia Serb Troops, but Gingerly
abstract: Today was the first day American soldiers drove through this hilly Serbian-controlled town, a dozen miles from the mountains that NATO bombed last  summer, and Capt. Hugo Jackson was looking for a place to hand out leaflets explaining the peacekeeping mission here.         He stopped his caravan near the center of town, but did not expect his receiving party: 15 or so Bosnian Serb soldiers, most carrying automatic weapons. On their second real patrol in Bosnia, the soldiers of Captain Jackson's Company C, 4th Battalion, 12th Infantry, had pulled up, by chance, in  front of the Drina Corps Command, the center of operations for 30,000 Serbian soldiers. The two armies, both professional and heavily armed, looked each other over.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                                               Previous      Year                               Yesterday       Day       Ago

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
abstract: Cray Research Inc., Eagan, Minn., to Marsteller Advertising, New York, a division of the Burson-Marsteller unit of Young & Rubicam Inc., to handle the computer company's advertising and public relations accounts, which were previously inactive. Billings were estimated at $5 million to $10 million. Mattel Inc., El Segundo, Calif., to Foote, Cone & Belding, Los Angeles, a unit of True North Communications, to introduce the Mighty Ducks action figures based on characters from the Walt Disney Co. Foote, Cone already handles several Mattel brands, including Hot Wheels. Billings were estimated at $3 million.

headline: Paying for a Mistake
abstract: To the Editor:         I read with interest how an employee of United Parcel Service who had taken a buyout offer was later informed by the company that the original offer was incorrectly computed and that his future pension would be reduced ("Retiring? Check Over the Boss's Arithmetic," Earning It, Feb. 18). The past overpayments to him would be taken out of future checks.

headline: Beuel Journal;It's a Woman's World (And Men Pay Lip Service)
abstract: This is the time of the year when a visitor here for the day from another planet might conclude that German women are ferocious and promiscuous, and about as benevolent toward men as black widow spiders; that German men wear polyester  ties and ride around in groups on ornate flatbed trucks, and that the children are all curbside beggars who subsist entirely on handout candy.         In other words, it's Carnival time in the Rhineland.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;Reebok's new campaign champions the athlete's will to win.
abstract: REEBOK INTERNATIONAL LTD., beset by competitors both larger and smaller, is hoping to reverse a serious slump in market share by substituting an exploration of inner space for a celebration of outer space.         "Planet Reebok," the nebulous subject of Reebok International's advertising for almost three years, is disappearing, perhaps to orbit Pluto. An ambitious campaign now being introduced worldwide replaces that amorphous concept with an  emotional and individualistic pitch, which underwent a two-year development and  testing process perhaps more arduous than any endured by a sneaker bearing the Reebok brand.

headline: Vietnam Air Leases Jets
abstract: The state-owned Vietnam Airlines said this week that it would lease 10 Airbus A320's and three Boeing 767's in the next year. Financial terms were not disclosed. The airline said it would lease the Airbuses from Aerostar Leasing, a subsidiary of Region Air Ltd., a Singapore aviation company. It will lease the Boeings through GE Capital Aviation Services, a subsidiary of the General Electric Company.

headline: Drug Chain to Offer New Class of Shares
abstract: Thrifty Payless Holdings Inc., the second-largest drugstore chain in the West, said today that it was planning a global initial stock offering of up to $374 million.         Thrifty said it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to issue class B common shares to raise funds to redeem about $175 million of outstanding senior notes. The proceeds will also be used to redeem $105 million  of senior subordinated notes of Thrifty Payless Inc., the unit that operates Thrifty Drug Stores and Payless Drug Stores.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Remy's Net Rises; Operating Profit Falls
abstract: Remy Cointreau S.A. said yesterday that its profit rose for the six months ended Sept. 30, but its operating profit dropped 45 percent after a price increase that hurt sales of Cognac. The company also expects operating profit to drop for its full year, which ends March 31. Remy Cointreau attributed the lower operating profit to price increases for Cognac of 3 to 15 percent.          Profit for the six months was 222.4 million francs, about $45 million, up from 135.4 million francs a year earlier. But the increase was attributed entirely to a one-time gain of 256.7 million francs from the sale of the commercial rights to Picon, an aperitif. Operating profit for the first half was 216 million francs, down from 394 million francs.   (AP)

headline: COMPANY NEWS;ST. JUDE MEDICAL TO ACQUIRE HEART-DEVICE MAKER
abstract: St. Jude Medical Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Daig Corporation, a maker of specialized cardiovascular devices, in a stock transaction valued at about $442.5 million. St. Jude, a maker of heart valves and other devices based in St. Paul, will exchange 10 million shares for all of  Daig's stock. Daig, based in Minnetonka, Minn., is a manufacturer of products to diagnose and treat cardiovascular illnesses, including coronary heart disease. Daig had sales of $38.3 million in the year that ended Sept. 30. In Nasdaq trading, shares of Daig gained $2.75, to $26.75, and shares of St. Jude fell $1.50, to $42.75.

headline: Bosnian Serbs Flee Homes In Sarajevo
abstract: Cars and trucks driven by Bosnian Serbs and loaded with baggage and bedding streamed out of Sarajevo today, part of an exodus that Bosnian Serb leaders said could turn violent.    NATO troops said Bosnian Serb families were taking their belongings out of the Bosnian capital for safekeeping in Serb-held territory.          As many as 70,000 Bosnian Serbs, who say they fear for their lives, are threatening to burn their homes and flee Sarajevo rather than live under a Muslim-led Government as called for under the Bosnian peace accords. Some families have exhumed their dead for reburial in Serbian soil.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;FUND AMERICAN TO BUY STAKE IN FOLKSAMERICA
abstract: Fund American Enterprises Holdings Inc. agreed yesterday to buy a 50 percent  stake in the Folksamerica Holding Company for $79.4 million. Fund American, an insurance holding company in Norwich, Vt., will receive preferred stock of Folksamerica Holding and rights to buy as much as 6.9 million Folksamerica common shares for $11.47 each. Folksamerica plans to use proceeds from the transaction to complete its $88 million acquisition of the Christiania General Insurance Corporation of Tarrytown, N.Y., which is owned by the Oslo Reinsurance Company, based in Oslo.

headline: Lotus Notes And I.B.M.: Still Happy Together?
abstract: Finally, I.B.M. can begin gauging whether it got its money's worth in paying  $3.5 billion for the Lotus Development Corporation last year.         The main goal of that acquisition was to get Lotus's Notes software, which enables groups of people to work collaboratively over computer networks. And last week I.B.M. began shipping out Version 4 of the program, the first new version of Notes in two and a half years.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Samsung and HyundaiTeam Up for License
abstract: Samsung and Hyundai, South Korea's two largest conglomerates, said yesterday  that they would jointly bid to win a Government license to enter the personal communications services business. The move is part of an alliance between the two in telecommunications before the opening of the Korean market to foreign companies in 1998.          For the personal communications services business, Hyundai and Samsung will  form a business group in which more than 100 small and medium companies will be invited to participate. Ownership of the new group is tentatively set at 20 percent each for Samsung and Hyundai, 30 percent for the medium companies and 30 percent for small companies.   Bloomberg Business News

headline: Tanker Runs Aground a 2d Time Near Welsh Port
abstract: Fearing an explosion, the police ordered residents to leave the area near this headland today after an oil tanker ran aground for the second time.         Salvage crews had been trying to reposition the tanker, the Sea Empress, to prepare for gale weather when 40 mile-an-hour winds snapped tugboat tow lines, and the tanker ran aground again today.

headline: Jericho Journal;Wake Up, Palestinians! Your Turn at the Airwaves
abstract: On a recent balmy morning in this sleepy oasis, Daniela Karim Khalaf slipped  behind a microphone to kick off her popular call-in show on the Voice of Palestine, the radio station of the Palestinian Authority.         "Good morning, Palestine," she cooed, her soothing voice going out to listeners throughout the West Bank, the Gaza Strip, Jordan and Israel. "To everybody, everywhere, a morning of love and well-being. Good morning to the folks inside and outside the homeland. Palestine, have a happy morning."

headline: World News Briefs;Agronomist Is Selected As Haiti's Prime Minister
abstract: President Rene Preval today appointed an agricultural economist, Rony Smarth, to be Prime Minister.         The choice is subject to confirmation by Parliament, where Mr. Preval's three-party Lavalas Platform holds 80 percent of the 110 seats. Under the Constitution, the Prime Minister is answerable only to Parliament, not the President.

headline: Gaming Joint Venture
abstract: Full House Resorts Inc. and the Gtech Holdings Corporation have agreed to form a venture to finance and develop Native American and casino gaming ventures, the companies said yesterday. Full House will identify and develop new gaming business opportunities, and Gtech will provide project management, technology and other expertise.

headline: Opposition Slows Move Of Capital To Berlin
abstract: The German Government's move from Bonn to Berlin is being slowed by quiet but fierce resistance from reluctant civil servants, who are unhappy despite being granted a series of benefits that will cost hundreds of millions of dollars.         After Parliament approved restoring Berlin as the capital of the reunited Germany in 1991, it was widely expected that the Government would begin functioning here within a few years. Now, it seems unlikely that the move will be completed before the turn of the century. Even then, a large part of the Government is to remain in Bonn, the capital of the former West Germany for four decades.

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Leader of Tajikistan Bows To Key Rebel Demands
abstract: Desperate to avoid another civil war, President Emomali Rakhmonov bowed to rebel demands today that he dismiss three top officials accused of corruption.         The President dismissed his First Deputy Prime Minister, his Chief of Staff and a southern governor today, with the approval of the Parliament, Itar-Tass news reports said. It said the rebels dropped their demand that the Defense Minister also be fired.

headline: McDonald's Looks Abroad
abstract: Facing stiff competition in the United States, the McDonald's Corporation is  looking overseas for growth.         The fast-food giant said today that it would speed up expansion, opening about eight restaurants a day, or 6,400, over the next two years.

headline: FUNDS WATCH;Buying at the Top? Don't Laugh. It Often Works.
abstract: Academics often scoff at people who buy the winning mutual funds of the previous year, but not Sheldon Jacobs, editor of The No-Load Fund Investor.         Mr. Jacobs, who edits his newsletter from Irvington, N.Y., set out to determine how you would do if you bought the top diversified no-load fund for the year just ended, held it one year and then replaced it with the top performer for that year. Quite well, he found.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Dockers Begins Khaki Campaign
abstract: The Dockers division of Levi Strauss & Company has introduced a campaign carrying the theme "The mission," which promotes the Dockers line of khaki pants by encouraging workers to dress less formally on so-called casual days.          The campaign includes staged events on city streets during which mock demonstrators chant "Change your pants!" and a humorous newspaper insert. The concept for the campaign was created by Garbergs Annonsbyra in Stockholm, which  works with the Dockers European marketing team.
