It was adapted for American consumers, using the Dockers theme "Nice pants," by the Dockers agency, the Foote, Cone & Belding unit of True North Communications in San Francisco.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Hard Pressed, Grundig Will Lay Off 3,000
abstract: German industry's pride and strength were dealt another blow today when the country's premier maker of consumer electronics, Grundig A.G., announced a severe retrenchment.         Grundig said it would lay off more than one-quarter of its work force, report a huge loss for 1995, and lose the financial backing of its parent company, Philips Electronics of the Netherlands, after 1996.

headline: Stockpiles Fell in December, Signaling Production Growth
abstract: Although storms and other special factors are making interpretation difficult, evidence mounted today that the economy could be perking up with the  approach of spring.         For the first time in nearly two years, inventories in the nation's stores, warehouses and factories fell in December, which many economists said sets the stage for revived production in coming months.

headline: Hamed Abulnasr, 82, the Leader Of Major Islamic Group in Egypt
abstract: Hamed Abulnasr, the leader of the Muslim Brotherhood, Egypt's largest and most powerful Islamic fundamentalist group, died in a Cairo hospital on Saturday, the group said. He was 82.         After Mr. Abulnasr assumed leadership of the Muslim Brotherhood in 1986, it became increasingly influential by financing social services, working through professional unions and taking part in elections in concert with the political opposition.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Two Banks Making Changes in Agencies
abstract: One financial institution is changing agencies and a second has placed its account in review.         The Fleet Financial Group in Boston named Clarion Direct in Greenwich, Conn., to handle the consolidated direct marketing account of its Fleet Bank division,  with billings estimated at $25 million. The account had previously been divided among more than 10 agencies; Clarion Direct was not among them. The decision came after a three-month review that began with 16 agencies and was narrowed to Clarion Direct, which is a division of the Clarion Marketing and Communications unit of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, and 2 other finalists: Barry Blau & Partners in Westport, Conn., and Epsilon in Boston. Pile & Company  in Boston managed the review.

headline: Rig Count Rises by 2
abstract: The number of oil and gas rigs operating in the United States jumped by 2 this week, to 707, Baker Hughes Inc. said today. There were 684 rigs operating nationwide during the comparable week a year earlier. Of the rigs running this week, 436 were exploring for natural gas and 265 for oil. Six rigs were listed as miscellaneous. The rig count represents the number of rigs actively exploring for oil and natural gas.

headline: Compromise Bills Due on Data Encryption
abstract: Legislation will be introduced in the House and the Senate tomorrow in an effort to break the deadlock between the computer industry and the Clinton Administration over the control and export of software and hardware used to scramble electronic data.         So far, though, the proposed measures have received only cautious endorsement from industry executives, while civil-liberties and privacy groups say they are worried that the bills would enable the Government to decode scrambled transmissions.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Trafalgar to Kvaerner In $1.4 Billion Deal
abstract: Kvaerner A.S. of Norway agreed yesterday to buy Trafalgar House P.L.C. for L904 million (about $1.4 billion). The merger will create one of the world's biggest construction companies involved in oil and gas projects. Kvaerner has long sought to expand internationally in oil and gas work. Its hostile bid last  year for another British engineering and construction company, Amec, failed.          The latest deal combines Kvaerner, which focuses on shipbuilding and offshore construction, with Trafalgar's construction and engineering operations. The takeover has the approval of Hongkong Land Holdings Ltd., which  has about 25.8 percent of Trafalgar's common stock and 25.1 percent of the convertible preferred shares.(AP)

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;Technology Stocks End Day Mixed
abstract: Semiconductor stocks were mixed yesterday as the sector seemed to search for  at least a temporary bottom after Tuesday's broad selloff.         Advanced Micro Devices Inc., whose stock has been battered recently after the company warned analysts that their earnings forecasts were too optimistic, reported results yesterday that were not as bad as had been feared.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;PERKIN-ELMER SHARES RISE FOLLOWING EARNINGS REPORT
abstract: Shares of the Perkin-Elmer Corporation rose 9 percent yesterday after it reported late on Thursday that it had had a strong rise in earnings and that it  planned to cut costs. In New York Stock Exchange trading yesterday, shares of the company, which makes analytical instruments, closed up $3.875, at $45. The company said earnings for its second quarter, which ended on Dec. 31, rose to $22.8 million, or 53 cents a share, from $17.1 million, or 40 cents per share, in the corresponding period in 1994. The company said it planned to take a third-quarter after-tax charge of $65 million to $75 million, or $1.30 to $1.50  a share, as part of a restructuring plan for its analytical instruments business.

headline: Vexed By Eurotunnel, They Slash Fares : Ferry Companies Get Cross
abstract: LONDON—  Spurred by increasingly stiff competition from Eurotunnel, the operator of the Dover-Calais undersea rail service, the ferry companies that ply the English Channel are slashing back.

headline: Insider-Trading Case Settled by Payment
abstract: A former Maryland Port Administration official has agreed to pay about $62,000 to settle insider-trading charges involving the takeover plans of a Baltimore bank, regulators said today.         Michael P. Angelos, 44, former deputy director of the port administration, agreed to settle Securities and Exchange Commission charges involving his 1994 trades of Baltimore Bancorp stock. He did not admit or deny wrongdoing.

headline: INVESTING IT;Bondholders Forgotten In the Fight Over RJR
abstract: BONDHOLDERS are used to being treated as second-class citizens. But they almost verge on the invisible in the battle by two corporate raiders for control of RJR Nabisco.         Ever since Bennett S. LeBow and Carl C. Icahn began clamoring to spin off the company's food business from its tobacco operations, the spotlight has been trained on the $9.3 billion in equity hanging in the balance.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Together Again, Separate Again
abstract: There was an agency "re-merger" last week as well as an agency "de-merger."         N. W. Ayer & Partners in New York, which merged its Los Angeles office with Gumpertz/Bentley/Fried in 1992 to form GBF/Ayer, has acquired full ownership of  GBF/Ayer and will rename it N. W. Ayer & Partners/Los Angeles. The terms were not disclosed.

headline: Patents;Scientists try to get a microbe that kills garden pests to turn against the common cockroach.
abstract: BACILLUS THURINGIENSIS is a naturally occurring microbe that gardeners have used to combat all manner of outdoor pests, from gypsy moths and bagworms to nematodes and beetles. So it seemed inevitable that entomologists would try to figure out a way to deploy it against that most persistent of indoor pests, the  cockroach.         In a joint endeavor, researchers at Johnson Wax, a unit of S. C. Johnson & Son, and the Mycogen Corporation have identified two types of Bt, as the microbe is known, that give cockroaches a deadly case of indigestion. This month they received a patent for the roach-killing Bt.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;THIOKOL PLANS TO BUY REMAINING STAKE IN HOWMET
abstract: The Thiokol Corporation said yesterday that it expected to buy the remaining  51 percent of the Howmet Corporation that it does not already own. The purchase  price was not disclosed. Thiokol, a rocket and ammunition maker based in Ogden,  Utah, and the Carlyle Group, an investment firm in Washington, D.C., bought Howmet in 1995 for $750 million, with Carlyle holding a 51 percent stake. Howmet makes precision castings for jet engines and industrial turbines. James R. Wilson, the chairman and chief executive of Thiokol, said at an aerospace conference in Arlington, Va., that after the company completed the acquisition,  by 1999, its annual sales would rise to about $2.2 billion from an expected $900 million in the fiscal year ending in June.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;INTERCEL TO BUY WIRELESS LICENSE FOR ATLANTA AREA
abstract: Intercel Inc., based in West Point, Ga., agreed yesterday to buy a personal communications services license for the Atlanta area from GTE Mobilnet Inc. for  $195 million. The Atlanta license area covers about seven million potential subscribers in most of Georgia and parts of Alabama, South Carolina and Tennessee. Intercel already owns licenses for three adjacent P.C.S. markets. GTE acquired the license in a Federal Communications Commission auction last year. Separately, the Scana Corporation, an energy holding company in Columbia, S.C.,  said it would invest another $75 million in Intercel. Scana currently holds about a 17 percent stake. Intercel shares rose $2.25 yesterday, to $18.50, in Nasdaq trading.

headline: Apple Raises Loss Estimate, In a Surprise To Wall Street
abstract: Apple Computer Inc., which warned last month that it might report a loss for  the quarter, put a number next to that prognosis today, and it was twice as bad  as most analysts had expected.         The company said it now expected to report next week a loss of about $68 million for its fiscal first quarter, which ended Dec. 29. The news came after the stock market closed, but in after-hours trading shares of Apple -- which had ended regular Nasdaq trading up $1.50 at $34.25 -- plunged to the $31 range.

headline: Nigeria, Critized Over Executions, Releases 6 Political Prisoners
abstract: Nigeria's military authorities freed six political detainees on New Year's Day, local newspapers and the News Agency of Nigeria said today.         The papers said that among those freed Monday was the former leader of the oil union, Nupeng, Wariebe Agamene. He led a long and crippling strike in the summer of 1994 to press for the release and installation of Moshood K. O. Abiola, who was widely believed to have won a presidential election in 1993.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;MEXICO TO REPAY PART OF U.S. LOAN
abstract: Responding to signs of its economic recuperation and impatience in the Clinton Administration for repayment, Mexico plans to return on Monday the $1.3  billion it borrowed from the United States last year.         While Mexico will still owe the United States $10.5 billion, as well as more  than $11 billion to the International Monetary Fund, the planned installment on  Monday underscores the Government's ability to bounce back after a disastrous economic crisis that brought Mexico to the brink of national insolvency and threatened the stability of other markets around the world.

headline: MUTUAL FUNDS QUARTERLY REPORT;What a Year It Was For Domestic Funds
abstract: ARE any mutual fund investors unhappy?         Maybe a few who made big bets last year on foreign markets or gold. But 1995  was one of the best years of the last decade for United States stock and bond funds, leaving most everyone to count their profits. And those who invested aggressively were swimming in them.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;TV Airwaves Becoming Issue In Budget Battle
abstract: The television airwaves are becoming part of the budget wars in Congress, with Senate Republicans taking a hard look at proposals to raise billions of dollars by auctioning off a part of the radio spectrum earmarked for advanced TV services.         The newest effort comes from the Senate Budget Committee, where lawmakers are looking harder for money to cut the deficit and have cast an eye on television licenses that are estimated to be worth tens of billions of dollars on the open  market.

headline: World News Briefs;Swiss Vote to Shore Up Minority Language Use
abstract: Swiss voters approved an amendment today to keep the Romansch language from dying out as the country's fourth national language.         The amendment was backed by the governing seven-member Federal Council as the latest in the longstanding attempt to balance support for languages in a country where German and French dominate.

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: CHATCOM INC., Chatsworth, Calif., named James B. Mariner president and chief executive, succeeding Gerald R. Sayer, who will continue to serve on Chatcom's board and executive committee. Mr. Mariner was most recently president of Turnaround Management Corp., Los Angeles, a consulting group specializing in turnarounds for technology companies.

headline: Ankara Journal;Islamic Victor Has Faith, Too, in Peaceful Politics
abstract: When the leader of Turkey's surging Islamic party, Necmettin Erbakan, stepped onto an Ankara street this week after a meeting with business leaders, a cheering crowd quickly engulfed him. From windows high above, people began waving and chanting his name.         "What will you do if you are excluded from the new government?" a reporter asked him.

headline: Major Visits Site of Killing Of Children In Scotland
abstract: As families of the 16 children slain here on Wednesday made funeral preparations, Prime Minister John Major and his chief political opponent, Tony Blair, arrived today to talk to parents, children, teachers and doctors, and to  visit the school gymnasium where the killings took place.         "I don't think it is possible to put into words what they have had to deal with," a grim-faced Mr. Major told reporters outside the Dunblane Primary School, standing against a backdrop of bouquets, sad messages and stuffed animals left at the end of the driveway. The school has been closed since Wednesday, when Thomas Hamilton, 43, burst into a class of 5- and 6-year-olds and sprayed the children with bullets from four handguns.

headline: Lufthansa in Accord With Air Canada
abstract: Lufthansa A.G. said today that it had an agreement with Air Canada to cooperate on international flights beginning June 15.         The two airlines will offer code-sharing on flights between Germany and Canada and share airport lounges and frequent-flier programs. They are also considering cooperating in freight transport and purchasing.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Inquiry on Renault Chief
abstract: The French auto maker Renault S.A. said yesterday that its chairman, Louis Schweitzer, had been placed under formal investigation in connection with a political wiretapping scandal that dates to the mid-1980's. According to a company spokesman, Mr. Schweitzer was placed under investigation by a judge in early November. Mr. Schweitzer is expected to be questioned on the matter at the end of January. Mr. Schweitzer was chief aide to Prime Minister Laurent Fabius in the 1980's.   Dow Jones

headline: A Forum on the Tax Deductions for Corporations
abstract: Tax Reformers, Take Your Mark" (Feb. 11), Reed Abelson's article on the tax  deductions available to corporations that have made expensive mistakes, drew many responses from readers. In general, the letters defended these deductions,  and for a variety of reasons. Some said the breaks were justified because a business cannot be expected to succeed in every project it undertakes. Others said no business would deliberately lose a huge amount of money just to save part of it in taxes. And others contended that the corporate deductions were not different from those available to individual taxpayers.      To the Editor:

headline: Germany Frees 4 Questioned in Fatal Fire
abstract: One day after a fire tore though a hostel for immigrants in northern Germany, killing at least 10 people, the police today released four men detained on suspicion of burning down the building but came up with no explanation of why the blaze started.         "Right now we are not talking about arson," said Winfried Tabarelli, the police chief in Lubeck, the northern port that was the site of the fire. But investigations into the blaze, thought to have started on the first floor of the four-story building, would continue for several days, he said.

headline: Large Stockholder Quits Board at Micron
abstract: In the latest chapter in the Micron Technology drama, Allen T. Noble, one of  the earliest investors in the memory chip maker, resigned yesterday from its board.         Mr. Noble was said to have played a key role in forcing Steve Appleton to resign last month as Micron's chairman and chief executive. Mr. Appleton was rehired after eight days in a reversal that the company has declined to explain.

headline: Winners and Losers in the Rohatyn Sweepstakes;Future of Lazard Freres If Fed Comes Calling
abstract: To many New Yorkers and even some in the financial community, Felix G. Rohatyn, Wall Street's premier adviser on takeovers, is Lazard Freres & Company, the international investment bank.         His work in helping to rescue New York City from bankruptcy in 1975, and on a range of other social and political issues, has secured him an important place in the public mind. And in New York he sometimes seems to have superimposed his  name on that of the firm.

headline: Russia Reform To Continue, Clinton Says After Meeting
abstract: President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore, after meetings today with Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin of Russia, expressed their confidence in Russia's continuing commitment to market reform despite Moscow's dismissal of well-known reformers and new plans for large social expenditures.         Since the Russian Communist Party did so well in December elections for the lower house of Parliament, President Boris N. Yeltsin, expected to seek re-election in June, has been moving to co-opt the Communist policy agenda and ridding his Government of ministers associated with Western-style reform.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Inco Bid Tops Falconbridge For Big Mine
abstract: Mining industry analysts said today that Inco Ltd.'s bid for the Voisey's Bay mine in Labrador might be just the beginning rather than the end of a battle with Falconbridge Ltd. over one of the richest mining discoveries in Canada in decades.         Inco's bid of $4.56 billion (Canadian), or $3.35 billion (United States), which was announced late Tuesday, topped the $4 billion (Canadian), or $2.9 billion (United States) offer of its rival, Falconbridge, for Diamond Fields Resources Inc. Diamond Fields, a former penny stock promotion based in Vancouver, British Columbia, was catapulted into the ranks of the world's major  mining companies by the find of a vast cache of nickel on the Labrador coast in  September 1993.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;New Editor in Chief At Reader's Digest
abstract: Reader's Digest promoted its executive editor, Christopher P. Willcox, yesterday to editor in chief. He succeeds Kenneth Y. Tomlinson, who announced his resignation last month.         Mr. Willcox, 49, will have editorial responsibility for the 48 foreign editions of the magazine published in 19 languages by The Reader's Digest Association. He will also oversee the company's special-interest magazines and the editorial content for multimedia and on-line services.

headline: Bristol-Myers Forms a New Generic-Drugs Unit
abstract: The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company's generic-drug business, Apothecon, has formed a division to focus on development as part of an effort to become the world's largest producer of generic drugs.         Apothecon is currently the third-largest American maker of generic drugs, with yearly sales of $350 million. Before yesterday's move, the business concentrated on developing and selling generic versions of Bristol-Myers drugs, once those drugs lost patent protection.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Germany Reports a Decline In Output for Recent Quarter
abstract: The German Economics Ministry said today that the nation's seasonally adjusted gross domestic product fell slightly in the fourth quarter of 1995 from the previous quarter, and was only slightly higher than for the comparable period in 1994.         It essentially attributed the slowdown to a "noticeable weakening" in manufacturing in the quarter. New orders, it said, were down throughout Germany.

headline: U.S. Plays Down Possibility of Attack On Taiwan by China
abstract: WASHINGTON—  President Bill Clinton said Wednesday that he was confident there would be no Chinese military actionagainst Taiwan, and he urged both sides to resolvetheir recent tensions peacefully.

headline: 2 at Vulkan Charged With Paying Bribes
abstract: Two managers of the troubled German shipbuilder Bremer Vulkan Verbund A.G. have been charged with influence peddling, prosecutors said today.         The director of Bremer Vulkan's military division, Werner Schwarz, and an unidentified director of a subsidiary were accused of paying a bribe of 40,000 marks, or $27,500, to win favor in the awarding of government contracts.

headline: Coleman Discusses a Deal
abstract: The Coleman Company, the maker of camping and outdoor recreational products,  said today that it was negotiating to add Camping Gaz's popular blue portable stove to its product line. Coleman said it was close to concluding talks on an acquisition of Application des Gaz S.A., the French camping equipment maker that is 70 percent controlled by Butagaz. Coleman's shares rose $1 today, to $40.25, on the New York Stock Exchange. Coleman is 80 percent owned by the financier Ronald O. Perelman's MacAndrews & Forbes Holding Inc.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
abstract: Argosy Gaming Corp., St. Louis, to Bates U.S.A./Midwest, Indianapolis, a unit of Cordiant P.L.C., as the first agency to handle advertising for a casino in Lawrenceburg, Ind. The billings were estimated at $2 million to $3 million. Twin Laboratories Inc., Ronkonkoma, L.I., to Slater Hanft Martin, New York, to handle advertising and sales promotion for its Nature's Herbs and Alvita Teas brands, previously handled by Greenstone Roberts Advertising, Melville, L.I. The billings were estimated at $2 million.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;MUTUAL OF OMAHA PLANS TO CUT MORE THAN 1,000 JOBS
abstract: The Mutual of Omaha Companies said yesterday that it would cut more than 1,000 jobs, or 12 percent of its work force, by the end of the year. The company said the job cuts were part of the shift from traditional health insurance to products that offer better opportunities for growth, such as life insurance, annuities and managed health care. About 800 jobs in Omaha and 250 outside Omaha are to be eliminated. The company cited an 8.5 percent decline in health-insurance revenue last year, saying that it had abandoned sales of major-medical and small-group insurance in eight states whose laws the company considered onerous. The states were California, Florida, Kentucky, Maine, New Jersey, New York, Vermont and Washington.

headline: MARKET WATCH;In '90s, As in '60s, Money Pours In
abstract: Did you buy your $447 worth?         That is what the average person in the United States -- man, woman and baby,  rich and poor -- invested last year in mutual funds that buy American stocks. At the end of the year, that average person owned such funds with a value of $4,074.

headline: A Texas Paper In a Dispute Over Gay Editor
abstract: After one reader complained, The Fort Worth Star-Telegram transferred an openly gay editor of a weekly children's section and apologized for failing to oversee his contributions to a weekly gay newspaper.         The complaint, from a woman who identified herself only as a parent, was sent to the newspaper's publisher, Richard L. Connor, along with copies of some cartoons that the section editor, Todd Camp, had created for The Texas Triangle, the gay newspaper.

headline: The Dutch Have Repaid More Fokker Debt
abstract: The Dutch Government acknowledged today that it had been required to pay more money to banks demanding repayment of state-backed loans to Fokker, the beleaguered commuter-aircraft manufacturer.         The Government paid $236 million to banks that granted Fokker credits in recent years, Economic Affairs Minister Hans Wijers said in a letter to Parliament.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;MCI COMMUNICATIONS CORP. (MCIC,NNM)
abstract: The MCI Communications Corporation reported fourth-quarter net income yesterday of $284 million, or 41 cents a share. In comparison with the corresponding quarter in 1994, when large pretax charges held down reported profits, net income was up 88.1 percent; excluding the charges, the gain was 17  percent.         Revenue for the quarter, which ended on Dec. 31, was $4.1 billion, up 21 percent from $3.4 billion in the 1994 period.     MCI shares closed unchanged yesterday, at $29.25, on Nasdaq.

headline: Wall Street Wary of Silicon Graphics Deal
abstract: Edward R. McCracken, the chairman of Silicon Graphics Inc., said yesterday that his company's planned acquisition of Cray Research, the supercomputer maker, would create "the No. 1 high-performance computer company in the world and a real national asset for America."         But investors registered their concerns about the financial value of that asset, as the shares of Silicon Graphics slid $2.125, or about 7.7 percent, to close at $25.375 on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;SEARS APPROVES BUYBACK OF UP TO 10 MILLION SHARES
abstract: Sears, Roebuck & Company said yesterday that its board had approved the repurchase of up to 10 million shares over the next two years. The shares are to be used for the company's stock-based incentive plans for employees, Sears said. As of yesterday, Sears, the retailer based in Hoffman Estates, Ill., had 392 million common shares outstanding.

headline: FUTURES MARKETS;Gold Is Lower Again on Signs High Price Is Curbing Demand
abstract: Gold prices fell yesterday for a second consecutive session on the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange on signs that six-year-high prices  had begun to curb demand from retail buyers and jewelers.         "With gold inching toward $420 an ounce, we see people hesitating," said Murray Kirsch, a vice president of Ross Refiner Inc. in New York, which sells gold to jewelers and other retailers. "Consumers are comfortable with gold in the $390-to-$410-an-ounce range."

headline: 5th Avenue Still Has Highest Retail Rents
abstract: Fifth Avenue in Manhattan from 49th to 57th Streets still represents Tiffany-like tastes in the retail real estate market, according to the Hirschfeld Group, a New York consulting firm. In the group's seventh annual survey of how much retailers pay for the privilege of a prestigious address, Fifth Avenue remained the world's most expensive street.         While Fifth Avenue has gone from jewels to jeans, it continues to be the place retailers want to be. In addition to such glamorous stores as Tiffany's, Bergdorf Goodman, Cartier and Saks Fifth Avenue, marketers with mass appeal, like Warner Brothers, Levi Strauss and Nike, now crowd the sidewalks. The avenue's average rent has climbed by one-third from last year's average, to $500 a square foot.

headline: Long Bond Ends Lower in Day of Mixed Prices
abstract: Prices of Treasury securities were mixed yesterday, with the longer maturities moving lower.         Market participants remained edgy with more reported delays of Government statistics because of the partial Government shutdown -- now in its third week -- and, with headlines about Washington's stalled budget negotiations moving on  the business news wires, few were in a buying mood.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;COMERICA TO SELL ILLINOIS BANKING UNIT TO ABN AMRO
abstract: Comerica Inc. agreed yesterday to sell its Illinois subsidiary, Comerica Bank-Illinois, to ABN Amro North America Inc. for about $190 million. Comerica Bank-Illinois has 25 branches and $1.4 billion in assets. ABN, a unit of ABN Amro Holding of the Netherlands, is the parent of the LaSalle National Corporation, a $16 billion holding company that operates LaSalle National Bank in Chicago. Comerica, a bank holding company in Detroit, also said it planned to buy back up to 15 million shares, or nearly 13 percent of its stock outstanding. Its shares rose $1 yesterday, to $39.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Managua Journal;Born Out of War, Nicaragua's Police Keep the Peace
abstract: The latest winner of the Police Friendship Medal, for civilians who give exemplary support to Nicaragua's crime fighters, was Pablo Antonio Vega, the Roman Catholic Bishop of a province that saw some of the meanest battles of the  civil war of the 1980's.         The head of the National Police, Fernando Caldera Azmitia, bestowed the medal in a ceremony last September, lauding discussion groups Bishop Vega had started  that brought together former contra rebels and their onetime enemies from the Sandinista National Liberation Front.

headline: It May Be Time to Give Bonds a Look
abstract: WHEN Mark Stumpp turned on his radio recently, he heard the tale of a person  who was holding down two jobs, and using the proceeds from one to invest in risky stocks.         To Mr. Stumpp, the chief investment officer at PDI Strategies in Short Hills, N.J., the story confirmed his suspicions that enthusiasm for equities had gone "a little overboard." As investors review their portfolios in this new year, he and others say, they should pay attention to something relatively ignored recently as stocks soared: bonds.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Clinton Renames Greenspan And Fills 2 Fed Vacancies President Clinton renominated Alan Greenspan to a third term as chairman of the  Federal Reserve Board and filled two other vacancies with appointees considered  unlikely to strongly dispute the chairman's strategy of slow growth to control inflation. One is the budget director, Alice M. Rivlin, nominated to be Fed vice chairman, and the other is Laurence H. Meyer, an economic forecaster.

headline: On Eve of Spanish Vote, Premier Seems to Fade
abstract: Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez loves bonsai trees and has spent long hours tending his collection, alone in the recesses of the official residence.         But just as the campaign for Sunday's general elections got under way, Mr. Gonzalez startled his supporters with the announcement that he was donating his beloved bonsai to the Botanical Garden of Madrid. The gesture seemed to indicate that Mr. Gonzalez was cleaning house, apparently recognizing that a new tenant will occupy the Prime Minister's residence after the vote.

headline: VOICES: FROM THE DESK OF;Adrift In Aisle 23
abstract: A GIANT supermarket opened recently in my neighborhood east of Syracuse. I had no plans to check it out. But then a store executive appeared on television  saying that not every community could appreciate such fine things, and that a store of this quality required a certain kind of customer: elite.         I knew then that he meant me, so I rushed to my car.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Acer's U.S. Unit Reassigns Account
abstract: The Acer America Corporation in San Jose, Calif., a unit of the Taiwan company Acer Inc. that markets personal computers, has named Hal Riney & Partners in San Francisco to handle its account, which had been at Lai, Venuti & Lai in Santa Clara, Calif., for four years. Billings were estimated at $20 million to $25 million. Riney was awarded the account after a review that had been narrowed to that agency and two other finalists, also in San Francisco: Anderson & Lembke, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, and Citron Haligman Bedecarre.

headline: U S West's Continental Ambitions;Thanks to Communications Law, A Baby Bell Presses to Be a Cable Power
abstract: If you listened hard enough yesterday, you could almost hear the crack of a starting gun.         Four weeks after Congress passed a bill intended to unleash a free-for-all among communications companies, U S West said yesterday that it would acquire the Continental Cablevision Corporation for $5.3 billion in cash and stock, and the assumption of $5.6 billion in debt. The deal would be the first big transaction of the deregulated era, and the choice of partners underscores -- figuratively and literally -- U S West's ambition to grow from a regional Bell telephone company into a continental company with a powerful presence in both phone service and cable television.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Isetan Sues Barney's,Calls Attitude Deplorable

headline: MEDIA;On their way to being digital, broadcasters feel they are still entitled to cost-free airwaves.
abstract: GET ready to hear a lot about the wonders of television in the next few months, along with a frightening warning that Congress is in danger of destroying "free" -- that is, advertiser-supported -- television as we know it.         The broadcasting industry, under attack by Senator Bob Dole and other critics for seeking a multibillion-dollar "giveaway" from Congress, is about to begin an advertising and promotional blitz to turn political opinion in its favor. The industry will spend "whatever it takes," said Edward O. Fritts, president of the National Association of Broadcasters, at an industry conference last week.

headline: Pratt & Whitney Buyout
abstract: About 160 Pratt & Whitney workers have accepted an early-retirement package,  leaving the company short of its buyout goal. Pratt, which makes jet engines, is a subsidiary of the United Technologies Corporation. It had expected 200 workers to take the offer, which was included in the new labor contract with the International Association of Machinists. The union estimated that 900 workers were eligible. Pratt, which has already eliminated thousands of jobs, has endured a five-year slump in production. The company has said it expects business to improve late next year.

headline: Americans Are Warned in Saudi Arabia
abstract: Americans in Saudi Arabia have been warned of the threat of terrorist attacks aimed at them, State Department officials said today.         The warning originated with flashes of Islamic fundamentalist anger detected  in recent days by United States intelligence agencies. Their sources included promises of retribution for the recent terrorism conviction of an Egyptian sheik in a New York courtroom; the reaction by Iran's leaders to reports of a covert plan aimed at them by the United States, and tensions between the Saudi Arabian  Government and its internal enemies.

headline: Cellmark DNA Lab Sold
abstract: The Zeneca Group P.L.C. has sold its United States unit, Cellmark Diagnostics, to the closely held Lifecodes Corporation of Stamford, Conn., for an undisclosed sum. Cellmark Diagnostics, based in Germantown, Md., the largest  private forensic DNA testing laboratory in the United States, analyzed DNA in the O.J. Simpson murder case.

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;7 French Trappist Monks Kidnapped in Algeria
abstract: Seven French Trappist monks were seized before dawn today from their monastery in northern Algeria by an armed group believed to be part of a Muslim  insurgency, French officials said.         A group of armed men came to the Notre Dame de l'Atlas monastery seeking a doctor, presumably for a wounded comrade, said Bishop Pierre Claverie of Oran. "They took seven monks who were sleeping in the main building," including the 82-year-old medic who is "very sick," Bishop Claverie.

headline: Faraya Journal;In Snow Country, the Lebanese Rise Above It All
abstract: From here the Mediterranean glistens nearly 8,000 feet below, and Lebanon's mountains stand a world apart from the rest of the Middle East.         In a region known for heat and dust, the treeless crests gleam white with snow for four months a year. While others elsewhere swelter, this village tends  to its well-groomed slopes.

headline: Orange County Threatens Suits
abstract: Orange County today put many of Wall Street's largest brokerages and law firms on notice that they could be its next legal targets.          In court papers filed in Santa Ana, the county seat, the county said it may  soon sue bond counsel LeBoeuf, Lamb, Greene & MacRae and its partners for breach of contract, professional negligence and breach of fiduciary duty.

headline: Son of Last Kaiser Meets Vienna Press : A Habsburg Defies Exile From Austria
abstract: In what might be described as an act of lèse-république, a Brussels businessman who was born an Austrian archduke challenged legal banishment from his native land by appearing at a press conference Monday in Vienna.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Ex-Daimler-Benz Chief Resigns From Board Post
abstract: Edzard Reuter, who retired last year as head of Daimler-Benz A.G., said yesterday that he was also giving up his post on the supervisory board of the financially troubled company. Mr. Reuter gave no reason for his decision, which  he disclosed during a news conference called with Chancellor Helmut Kohl on another topic. Mr. Reuter stepped down as chairman of the Daimler-Benz board last May and took a seat on the supervisory board.          Daimler-Benz recently announced losses of $4 billion in 1995, and some analysts said Mr. Reuter, who led the company on an aggressive expansion course  during his seven years as chairman, was partly responsible.   (AP)

headline: MUTUAL FUNDS;Biggest Gainers So Far in 1996 Are Not the Most Aggressive
abstract: Many of the year's best performers on this list are funds in the growth-and-income category. These funds look not only for capital appreciation,  but also for high dividends -- a relatively conservative approach that usually leads to blue-chip stocks. The average gain for the category is 4.67 percent so  far this year and 30.27 percent for the one-year period. Among the big funds, Vanguard Windsor II leads the group for both periods.

headline: Jordan Condemns Killing of Iraqi Defectors
abstract: King Hussein of Jordan today condemned the killing of two Iraqi defectors he  had sheltered, and predicted that his former ally, Saddam Hussein, would not remain in power.         "I am disgusted by what has happened, and I am really unable to express myself towards this terrible time," he said.

headline: Bad Weather Is Blamed for Inventory Rise
abstract: Business inventories jumped in January, the Commerce Department said today, but analysts said the surge reflected special factors and not a weakening economy. They similarly dismissed an increase in jobless claims.         Inventories rose six-tenths of 1 percent, the largest increase since a seven-tenths of 1 percent surge last October. At the same time, the Labor Department said that jobless claims shot up by 32,000 last week to the highest level in two months.

headline: Mazda Stock Slips After Engine Report
abstract: Shares of the Mazda Motor Corporation fell as much as 4.5 percent today after a Japanese newspaper said the company would stop making rotary engines, one of its first successful products. Mazda later denied the report.         Mazda's stock fell as much as 20 yen, to 420 yen in morning trading.

headline: Charges Fly As the Greeks And Turks Avert a War
abstract: The political reverberations of a narrowly avoided confrontation between the  military forces of Greece and Turkey over a cluster or rocks in the Aegean Sea continued in the capitals of both countries today.         In Athens, Prime Minister Constantine Simitis drew attacks from his political opponents as he and the other ministers of his Socialist Government defended their decision to withdraw Greek forces from the uninhabited 10-acre rocky outcropping known to the Greeks as Imia and to the Turks as Kardak.

headline: U.S.-British Electronics Merger Is Planned
abstract: In a trans-Atlantic merger of equals, Farnell Electronics P.L.C. of Leeds, England, and the Premier Industrial Corporation, which is based in Cleveland, announced yesterday that they had agreed to merge in a cash and stock transaction valued at about $2.8 billion.         The merger, which is subject to shareholder approval and regulatory review, would create the world's third-largest electronics distributor, with combined sales of more than $1.6 billion. The companies said they expected the deal to close in the second quarter.

headline: U.S. Said to Withhold War-Crime Data
abstract: Bosnia's representative at the United Nations accused the United States today of failing to turn over information on a notorious Serbian paramilitary leader known as Arkan, who has been linked to killings of Bosnian Muslims as late as last autumn.         The representative, Muhamed Sacirbey, said at a news conference that Washington had "conclusive evidence" of ties between Arkan, whose real name is Zeljko Raznatovic, and the Government of President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;TENNECO PLANS TO SELL REMAINING STAKE IN CASE
abstract: Tenneco Inc. is planning to sell its remaining 21 percent stake in the Case Corporation to the public, according to regulatory documents. Case, a maker of agricultural and construction equipment based in Racine, Wis., said Tenneco would sell its remaining 15.2 million Case shares. Case plans to offer an additional 1.5 million shares, for a total offering of 16.7 million shares. Case currently has 71 million common shares outstanding. Tenneco, a Houston-based automotive, energy, packaging and shipbuilding company, has been steadily cutting its stake in Case over the last two years. Case's stock fell $1.375 yesterday, to $50.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;ROCKEFELLER CENTER POSTS BIG QUARTERLY LOSS
abstract: Rockefeller Center Properties Inc., which holds the $1.3 billion mortgage on  New York landmark Rockefeller Center, said yesterday that it recorded a fourth-quarter loss of $28.8 million, or 75 cents a share, while the complex operated under bankruptcy court protection. A year earlier, the company had a loss of $1.4 million, or 3 cents a share. Rockefeller Center Properties' results have suffered since the owners of the center, two partnerships controlled by the Mitsubishi Estate Company of Japan, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in May after years of losses. In September, the partnerships decided  to turn the property over to Rockefeller Center Properties. As a result of the bankruptcy filing, the owners stopped making mortgage payments and Rockefeller Center Properties' revenue fell to $128,000 in the fourth quarter from $27.3 million a year earlier. Last fall, Rockefeller Center Properties agreed to a buyout offer by a Goldman, Sachs/Rockefeller team valued about $1.2 billion.

headline: Germany and U.S. Are Closer To Easing Limits on Air Travel
abstract: The United States and Germany agreed yesterday to drop restrictions on air travel between the two countries, though at least one important hurdle remains before the agreement can go into effect.         The agreement with Germany is the latest so-called open-skies deal, part of a broader strategy by the United States Transportation Department to expand travel choices for consumers. The agreement would allow American and German airlines to fly to each other's countries without restrictions on frequency of flights, routings or fares. The Transportation Department signed open skies agreements with 10 other countries last year.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Viacom Chief Ousted; Paramount's Performance a Factor
abstract: Viacom Inc. ousted its president and chief executive, Frank J. Biondi Jr., yesterday, sundering a nine-year partnership between Mr. Biondi and the entertainment company's billionaire chairman, Sumner M. Redstone.         Mr. Redstone said that Viacom needed more aggressive leadership as it tried to build on its twin 1993 acquisitions of Paramount Communications and Blockbuster Entertainment.

headline: U.S. Treasury Offerings Planned This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week begins with today's auction of new three- and six-month bills. On Thursday, the Treasury will auction a one-year note.         By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.94 percent and on the six-month bill, 4.88 percent. The rate on the outstanding one-year note was 4.75 percent.

headline: Retailer Plans Sales Growth And Expansion
abstract: Sears, Roebuck & Company, the nation's third-largest retailer, said yesterday that it planned to open 285 to 350 stores this year and to remodel 90 to 100 others. The company also said it expected to show sales growth, and that it might pursue acquisitions.         Sears, which also said yesterday that it would sell its stake in the Prodigy  Services Company, said it would increase capital spending to $1.6 billion this year from $1.4 billion in 1995 to help pay for building and renovation plans.

headline: World News Briefs;Several Die in Riot In Port-au-Prince Slum
abstract: A shootout today between the police and a street gang in the Cite Soleil slum left several people dead, witnesses said. Among those wounded were two policemen, one hit by a bullet and another struck by a bottle, the independent Radio Metropole reported.         The gang, called the Red Army, was angered over the shooting of one of its members on Tuesday by a security guard at the port.

headline: Rabin Assassin's Testimony: My Goal Was to Paralyze Him
abstract: Answering murder charges at his trial today, Yigal Amir said he had intended  only to paralyze Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin and his policies when he fired three shots that killed Mr. Rabin on Nov. 4.         The assassin spoke on the first full day of his trial in Tel Aviv District Court, which was marked by discord between his two lawyers and confusion over which of them was representing him.

headline: That First Job
abstract: It's not a first romance, but a first job can live long in memory: That strange stint for a fruit-basket company in 1980. That summer selling shoes, when you picked up the secrets of the trade from gruff, lovable old Jack. The year after college, when you opened the mail for the Esperanto Society and worked on that (still undone) novel.         If you have a story about your first years in the wacky world of work, send it to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send it by by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your phone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;McDonnell Douglas Seen In Talks With Fokker
abstract: Representatives of Fokker N.V. and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation would not comment yesterday on a report in the Dutch newspaper Volkskrant that the two companies met last week. Fokker, the struggling Dutch aircraft maker, has been looking for a partner since its German parent, Daimler-Benz A.G., cut off a cash lifeline last month. Other potential investors that have been identified in news reports include the Samsung Group of South Korea, Bombardier Inc. of Canada, British Aerospace, Taiwan Aerospace and Aerospatiale S.A. of France.          Fokker said all the companies had indicated interest only in its subsidiaries and did not want to buy the whole company. Fokker said it would prefer a partnership that would preserve its aircraft assembly business.   (AP)

headline: In Okinawa, U.S. Bases Remain a Big Issue
abstract: Okinawans are somewhat uncomfortable with the idea that, as The Okinawa Times remarked in an editorial today, it took the "sacrifice of a schoolgirl" to make  progress in the movement to scale back the American military bases that occupy 20 percent of the land on this Japanese island.         But there is no denying that the abduction and rape of a 12-year-girl, for which three American servicemen were sentenced on Thursday, unleashed a public outcry against the bases, focused world attention on the issue and forced Washington and Tokyo to deal more urgently with a situation that they had tended to sweep under the rug.

headline: Shrugging Off Indictment, Bosnian Serb General Skis
abstract: The Bosnian Serb military commander, who is wanted on charges of committing war crimes, was seen skiing near Sarajevo this weekend.         Tanned and appearing relaxed, the commander, Gen. Ratko Mladic, joined Bosnian Serb national guard cadets training on Saturday on Mount Jahorina, a popular ski area before the war. It was the first time in months that General Mladic, who was indicted by an international war crimes tribunal, had been seen  in public.

headline: Fears in Dublin
abstract: In response to the bombings in London, Protestant paramilitary groups indicated that they might end their cease-fire. Page A8.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;A new survey seeks to gauge the research needs of American companies as they look abroad.
abstract: THE association representing companies that conduct marketing and opinion surveys for corporate America has conducted a survey of its own.         The Council of American Survey Research Organizations, known as Casro, is releasing the results of its initial survey, which canvassed 313 executives at large and midsized corporations. The study, conducted during the summer, focused primarily on issues related to the growing globalization of American businesses  and their intentions toward using research in markets overseas.

headline: Spain Talks Of a Crisis In Credibility : Giscard Joins Chorus Urging Currency Delay
abstract: BRUSSELS—  Pressures to amend Europe's plan for a single currency reached a crescendo Wednesday as former President Valéry Giscard d'Estaing of France, one of the Continent's most senior Europhiles, broke ranks and suggestedsoftening the conditions of monetary union.

headline: How Fed Made Decision To Cut Rates in December
abstract: Federal Reserve policy makers listed the possibility of an economic slowdown  and low inflation as reasons for their decision in December to reduce a key interest rate, minutes of their meeting showed today.         Members of the the Fed's policy-making group, the Federal Open Market Committee, agreed 11 to 0 to reduce the Federal funds rate on overnight loans among banks to a target of 5.5 percent from 5.75 percent at the Dec. 19 meeting.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Germany and France Move To Pep Up Their Economies
abstract: Rushing to stimulate growth and hoping that a joint effort will embolden worried consumers in Europe's two biggest economies, Germany and France announced measures today aimed at encouraging spending, increasing growth, cutting taxes on business and reducing unemployment.         France took the approach of trying to bolster short-term spending by giving tax breaks to consumers on interest payments and by lowering the interest rates  paid on savings accounts. Germany took a longer perspective, announcing cuts in  income taxes, providing tax breaks for small- to medium-sized business and announcing a series of privatizations.

headline: First Interstate Is in Talks With Wells Fargo on a Sale
abstract: Bowing to what appeared to be insurmountable financial pressure, First Interstate Bancorporation said yesterday that it was now negotiating to sell itself to Wells Fargo & Company for $11.2 billion, breaking off its engagement to First Bank System.         While Wells Fargo does not have a signed agreement, merger experts say it is  likely to be victorious in the four-month-long battle. First Interstate, in trying to avoid being taken over by its California rival, had turned to First Bank System, which is based in Minneapolis, in October after Wells Fargo made an unusual hostile bid. Either combination would be among the largest bank mergers  in history.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                                               Previous      Year                               Yesterday       Day       Ago

headline: U.S. Payrolls Expand but Jobless Rate Remains at 5.6%
abstract: Easing fears for the moment that the economy is on the verge of sliding into  a recession, the Labor Department reported today that employers added a moderate 151,000 jobs to payrolls in December. The unemployment rate remained steady at 5.6 percent.         The first major report on economic performance last month -- delayed two weeks because the Labor Department was closed first by budgetary stalemate and then by a paralyzing blizzard -- was hailed by the Clinton Administration as evidence that the economy continued to expand solidly.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Computer Maker Bull Returns to the Black
abstract: Compagnie des Machines Bull, France's biggest computer company, reported yesterday that it had its first profit in seven years in 1995, posting net income of 306 million French francs ($61 million). The company had piled up losses totaling more than 22 billion francs in the preceding six years, including 1.96 billion francs in 1994.          Bull, a full-line computer maker, competes with the likes of the International Business Machines Corporation and the Digital Equipment Corporation. It has slashed costs, focused on specific market segments and found partners in various ventures in its effort to become profitable. Its sales from  continuing operations fell 2.98 percent last year, to 26.66 billion francs ($5.32 billion), from a restated 27.48 billion in 1994.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: VOICES: FROM THE DESK OF;Mutual Funds: The Musical
abstract: ALONG the byways of cyberspace, watch out for the intersection of Wall Street with Hollywood Boulevard and Madison Avenue!        There, you will find mutual funds zipping into the 21st century, courtesy of  the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Federal agency that shapes the fund world.

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Toll Is 73 and Rising In Sri Lankan Bombing
abstract: Rescuers dug out 13 more bodies today from the charred wreckage of a suicide  bomb attack on Wednesday that turned Colombo's business center into a knot of towering fires. The death toll from the blast, linked to Tamil rebels, stood at  73 and was expected to rise.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;2 CALIFORNIA BANK COMPANIES AGREE TO A MERGER
abstract: CU Bancorp has agreed to merge with Home Interstate Bancorp, creating a bank  with more than $810 million in assets and 22 branches in Southern California. CU Bancorp, the holding company for California United Bank, will exchange 1.409 of  its shares for each share of Home Interstate, which is the parent of Home Bank.  Home Interstate shareholders are expected to hold about 52 percent of the combined company. The deal was disclosed after the close of stock trading on Wednesday. CU's stock rose 75 cents yesterday, to $10.375, and Home Interstate shares rose 62.5 cents, to $13.875. Both closing prices were 52-week highs. CU Bancorp is based in Encino, Calif. Home Interstate is based in Signal Hill, Calif.

headline: EARNING IT;Who's Really Essential? In a Blizzard, It's a Blur
abstract: CAROLYN BURGER, the chief executive of Bell Atlantic-Delaware, could have done her work at home during the blizzard on Monday. Instead, she drove to the company office in Wilmington and served as an operator, helping connect person-to-person calls. "I came in and did the job in our building, which was understaffed," she said.         Angela Ramirez, executive administrator at the Daxor Corporation offices in Manhattan, clambered over snowdrifts that towered above her head that day to be  the only worker in the 15-person operation. She was worried about an expected shipment of liquid nitrogen, necessary to keep her company's human semen samples frozen. The samples did not spoil, even though the shipment never arrived.

headline: Possible I.R.A. Front Claims Ulster Killing
abstract: A group suspected of being an I.R.A. front claimed responsibility today for the fatal shooting of a man as he sat in a car with his girlfriend southwest of  Belfast.         The group calls itself Direct Action Against Drugs, suggesting it is dedicated to fighting drugs. Many Protestants and drug dealers say it is a front for the Irish Republican Army. The group also claimed responsiblity for three killings in December.

headline: 'Keep Fokker Flying': A Cry That Transports a Dutchman's Soul
abstract: AMSTERDAM—  In the Netherlands, the financial crash of Fokker,the world's oldest aircraft maker and a company as Dutch as Hans Brinker, has struck the national soul.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Gentle humor and an office not in New York help agencies in magazine advertising awards.
abstract: THE notion that geography is destiny, at least on Madison Avenue, is getting  a boost from the selection of the finalists in the annual awards competition for creative excellence in magazine advertising.         The 25 finalists in the 15th annual competition, for campaigns that appeared  in magazines during 1995, were announced yesterday by the Magazine Publishers of America, the magazine trade association in New York. In what is known as the M.P.A. Kelly Awards competition, named after a former president of the association, there is one prize for general excellence and four more narrowly focused awards.

headline: Stocks Rise in Japan
abstract: Stocks traded higher here today. At the close of trading, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 90.30 points, or more than four-tenths of 1 percent, at 20,812.74. On Tuesday, the Nikkei rose 133.24 points, or seven-tenths of 1 percent.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Anglo American to Buy 5.9% Stake in Lonrho
abstract: The Anglo American Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy a 5.9 percent stake in Lonrho P.L.C. for L91 million ($138 million) from a company controlled by Lonrho's chief executive, Dieter Bock. Anglo American, a South African mining concern, also said it had acquired first rights of refusal to buy Mr. Bock's remaining 18.5 percent stake should he decide to sell. Mr. Bock said  he intended to hold his remaining stock for the time being.          Mr. Bock acquired the stake to be sold to Anglo when Lonrho's former chief executive and founder, Roland W. (Tiny) Rowland, exercised an option to sell the shares to Mr. Bock's Dutch holding company, Yeoman Investments Ltd.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: Coup in Africa Frightens Democratic Neighbors
abstract: In a fragrant courtyard in this desert's-edge capital, a spokesman at army headquarters busies himself explaining how the military will bring about a "march toward democracy."         But less than a week after a coup that overthrew the country's first democratically elected President, the expression of cocky relaxation worn by young soldiers sitting in the shade, idly fingering their automatic weapons, suggests that they are already relishing being in charge.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Interest in Fokker Unit
abstract: The Swedish aircraft maintenance supplier FFV Aerotech, which is part of the  Celsius Industries group, said yesterday that its Aviocomp subsidiary was prepared to bid for the maintenance division of the bankrupt Dutch aircraft maker Fokker N.V. Aviocomp's managing director, Jan-Ingvar Johansson, said it could be two months or so before a bid was made. Fokker's maintenance division has about 900 employees. Fokker, which shut most of its operations on March 15,  has been in a crisis since January when its majority owner, Daimler-Benz of Germany, cut off financial support for the company.   (Reuters)

headline: Beninese Throng Polls in 2d Free Election
abstract: Polling stations were thronged today as people turned out in huge numbers to  take part in this West African country's second free election since a transition to democracy in 1991.         The election pitted President Nicephore D. Soglo against six other candidates, including the longtime Marxist dictator, Mathieu Kerekou, whom Mr. Soglo defeated in the democratic election five years ago.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;FIRST BANK BID FOR FIRST INTERSTATE CLEARS A HURDLE
abstract: The Justice Department said yesterday that it would not challenge the proposed friendly takeover of First Interstate Bancorp by First Bank System, because the two banks had agreed to shed about $170 million in deposits by selling Wyoming and Montana branches. But Wells Fargo & Company has made a competing hostile offer for First Interstate, which is based in Los Angeles. First Bank's operations overlap First Interstate's in a few Western states. Wells Fargo conducts retail banking only in California and competes with First Interstate in many markets there.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Ire and Votes: U.S. Vents Its Rage at Cuba In Trade Law
abstract: The bill that President Clinton signed this week penalizing foreign companies doing business with Cuba illustrates two of the most controversial trends in American trade policy.         The measure, which set off howls of protest from American trading partners, represents the latest of many attempts to extend the reach of United States law beyond the country's borders.

headline: Bond Buyers Snatch Up Disney Notes
abstract: The Walt Disney Company sold $2.6 billion in debt yesterday, the largest bond offering ever by a top-grade company.         Demand for the Disney bonds was so strong that the size of the offering was sharply increased twice in the last two days. Disney had originally planned to sell $1.5 billion of bonds but increased the sale to $2 billion on Thursday and  to $2.6 billion yesterday. The sale drew buyers away from the Treasury market, where prices were lower in light trading.

headline: U.S. Visa to Taiwan Aide
abstract: The United States said today that it has issued a transit visa to Vice President Li Yuan-zu of Taiwan, a move expected to bring protests from China.          The visa will allow Mr. Li's plane to refuel in Los Angeles on Jan. 11 and 16 on his way to and from the presidential inauguration in Guatemala, said a State Department spokeswoman, Phyllis Young.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;NEWMONT RAISES $250 MILLION IN STOCK SALE
abstract: The Newmont Mining Corporation said yesterday that it had sold 4.65 million shares for $53.75 each to raise $250 million to develop its mining projects. Newmont Mining, which is based in Denver, will pass the proceeds on to its main  operating unit, the Newmont Gold Company, by purchasing 4.65 million of the unit's shares. Newmont Mining shares fell $2.50, to close at $51.25, with almost six million shares changing hands. Newmont Gold shares closed down $1.625 at $50.375. "That's to be expected when that much goes on the market at once," said Doug Hock, a Newmont spokesman. Newmont sold the shares to Salomon Brothers Inc. of New York, which in turn sold them to investors. Salomon's head of trading, Terry Fitzgerald, said the entire offer was sold in two hours.

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Socialist Wins Portugal's Presidency
abstract: The Socialist candidate, Jorge Sampaio, was elected today to succeed Mario Soares as President of Portugal.         Final results showed Mr. Sampaio winning 53.8 percent of the vote, compared with 46.2 percent for his conservative rival, former Prime Minister Anibal Cavaco Silva. The turnout was 66.4 percent of the nearly 9 million eligible voters.

headline: More Journalists Jailed, but Fewer Are Killed
abstract: Journalists were imprisoned in record numbers around the world last year, according to an annual survey released yesterday in Washington.         The report, by the Committee to Protect Journalists, a nonprofit organization based in New York City, counted 182 journalists in prison because of their work  at the end of 1995, compared to 173 the preceding year. The 1995 figure is the highest since the committee began its annual tally in 1986.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;NORANDA TO BID FOR REST OF KERR ADDISON STOCK
abstract: Noranda Inc. said yesterday that it planned to offer $230 million (Canadian), or $167.1 million (United States), to acquire the remaining shares of Kerr Addison Mines Ltd. Noranda, based in Toronto, now owns about 9.2 million shares, or 52.1 percent of Kerr Addison, also of Toronto. The two companies are mining concerns. Noranda said it expected that materials relating to the offer would be mailed to Kerr Addison shareholders within the next two weeks.

headline: Bosnian Serbs Trying to Revive Devastated Economy
abstract: The last time Suzana Stanivukovic assembled a hearing aid at her job at Medical Electronics was more than a month ago. Co-workers who make pacemakers have not produced any in four years.         Now Ms. Stanivukovic, whose salary has plummeted to $20 a month, from $400, usually spends her shift chatting around an electric heater with her colleagues.

headline: 2 G.I.'s Are Injured In Bosnian Accident
abstract: An American military fuel tanker overturned on a road in northern Bosnia today, injuring two American soldiers.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Advertising
abstract: EFFORTS to overhaul a corporate image typically face challenges ranging from  entrenched support for the status quo to the fear of selecting a symbol that might be lampooned as abstruse or derivative.         For instance, few in the corporate-identity field can forget how NBC once spent $750,000 on a makeover that included a stylized "N" nearly identical to the symbol created in-house -- for about $100 -- by an educational television network in Nebraska.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;JOHNSON & JOHNSON GETS NEW PRODUCT APPROVAL
abstract: Johnson & Johnson said yesterday that it had won approval from the Food and Drug Administration to sell Renova, a prescription skin cream to reduce wrinkles, pigmentation and dryness in skin overexposed to the sun. It was developed by the Ortho Pharmaceutical Corporation, a Johnson & Johnson unit. Johnson & Johnson, based in New Brunswick, N.J., has made a big push into dermatology products in recent years, including the $924 million acquisition of the Neutrogena Corporation in 1994.

headline: For Olympic Licensees, Race Is On
abstract: Even though the first Olympic medals won't be awarded until July, the race for gold is already under way among corporate licensees, and some winners and losers are quickly emerging.         Makers of officially licensed products -- ranging from the official Olympic timepiece (SMH Swiss's Swatch) to the official Olympic doll (Mattel's Barbie), and even the official Olympic water (Crystal Springs) -- are sprinting to cash in before the Olympic torch is extinguished on Aug. 4.

headline: Fixed-Rate Mortgage Dips
abstract: Thirty-year fixed-rate mortgages averaged 7.81 percent this week, down from 7.83 percent last week, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 5.6 percent, up from 5.55 percent last week. Fifteen-year mortgages averaged 7.32 percent this week, unchanged from a week earlier.

headline: Edward Adamson, 84, Therapist Who Used Art to Aid Mentally Ill
abstract: Edward Adamson, a pioneer in using art to treat mental illness, died last Saturday at his London studio. He was 84.         Mr. Adamson believed that "one of the best ways to help people who are mentally or emotionally disturbed is to get them being creative," said Dr. Anthony Stevens, a Jungian analyst and psychiatrist who often referred patients  to him.

headline: THE NEW YORK TIMES BUSINESS BEST SELLERS
abstract: HARD COVER

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Nuclear Agency Threatens To Close Connecticut Plants The Nuclear Regulatory Commission gave New England's largest utility 30 days to  show that two reactors it operates in Connecticut are properly equipped for emergencies. If the company fails to prove their safety, the commission threatened to close them. The company, Northeast Utilities, is already under fire for safety problems at another reactor.

headline: In the Grisly Shadow of Rwanda, Ethnic Violence Stalks Burundi
abstract: The soldiers arrived in the village of Sororezo at 2 P.M. one bright day in early December, just as Herve Ntirabagire was finishing lunch with his family and getting ready to go back to his job in the Bujumbura market a few miles away.         He heard the rumble of a jeep, then a machine gun's hideous cackle and the giant hammer of a mortar blast. Bullets raked through the tiny house. When the firing stopped, the soldiers ran in and started hacking away with knives and hammers, killing Mr. Ntirabagire's parents, three sisters and one brother before he escaped into the hills.

headline: INSIDE
abstract: INVESTING IT /Page 4/ In 1993, he was bankrupt. Today, David Walsh is worth $250 million. By Clyde H.  Farnsworth.

headline: Stocks Rise in Japan
abstract: Stocks rose slightly here today. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 3.19 points, or two one-hundredths of 1 percent, at 20,570.26. On Tuesday, the Nikkei gained 279.65 points, or 1.38 percent.

headline: FUNDS WATCH
abstract: Growth Levels Off In Level-Load Funds

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;U.N. Chief Urges Reducing U.S. Dues
abstract: Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali said today that he favored reducing the United States contributions to the United Nations budget from 25 percent to  15 or 20 percent.         He said a reduction would lessen the dependence of the United Nations on Washington and "better reflect the fact that this organization is indeed the instrument of all nations."

headline: Britain Grants Hong Kong Visa Concessions
abstract: Prime Minister John Major of Britain announced today a visa-free entry to Britain for Hong Kong passport holders after June 30, 1997.         In what was billed as one of the most important political speeches on Hong Kong in years by a British politician, Mr. Major also announced that the handful of surviving widows of Hong Kong servicemen who fought for Britain in World War II would get full British citizenship.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Listed below are the tentative release dates for major economic indicators this week.      Monday

headline: President Of Retailing Chains Quits
abstract: In what many analysts say might signal a larger, imminent change in the Dayton Hudson Corporation's department-store unit, the company announced yesterday that the president of the unit had resigned.         Stephen E. Watson, 51, will be replaced by Linda L. Ahlers, 45, who has spent most of her career at the company.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;German Economy Shrank in 4th Quarter
abstract: Germany's economy shrank in the fourth quarter of last year, the Government said yesterday. The economy shrank five-tenths of 1 percent from a quarter earlier, when growth was flat. Growth for all of 1995 was 1.9 percent, the Federal Statistics Office in Wiesbaden said.          The lackluster final two quarters could increase fears that Germany is entering a recession, although the Government insists that is not the case. "There can be no talk of a slide into a recession, nor of zero growth for 1996," the Economics Minister, Gunter Rexrodt, said in a statement. A day earlier, the Government said that joblessness last month hit a new postwar high  of 4.27 million people, or 11.1 percent of the labor force.   (AP)

headline: Pope John Paul @ Vatican: How Many Angels Can Dance. . . ?
abstract: On Christmas Day, somewhere in the United States, a young girl named Sarah who was using a computer logged on to the Vatican's new World Wide Web site on the Internet and sent an on-line message to the Pope.         Like millions of others, she had just watched a visibly ill Pope John Paul II interrupt his televised Christmas message, and she wanted to pass on her father's remedy -- "lots of liquids, and chicken broth" -- for getting over the  flu.

headline: Host Marriott to Buy Interest in Hotels
abstract: The Host Marriott Corporation said today that it would acquire controlling interests in the San Diego Marriott Hotel and Marina, two hotels in Mexico City  and the Pittsburgh Hyatt.         The company, a lodging real estate concern that owns 90 properties operated primarily under Marriott brand names, also said it would buy the Delta Meadowvale Hotel and Conference Center in Toronto.

headline: For Rather, Technology Has Drawbacks, Too
abstract: On March 9, 1981, the night Dan Rather replaced Walter Cronkite as the anchor of "CBS Evening News," the camera showed Mr. Rather from the waist up, with nothing behind him but a blank dove-gray backdrop.         On his 15th anniversary broadcast Friday night, Mr. Rather sat enthroned at a semicircular mahogany desk the size of a small yacht, bedecked with a blue-suede top; behind him CBS producers busily worked the phones, with a solid wall of flashing television monitors as their backdrop.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;GPA Says Creditor May Cause Bankruptcy
abstract: The GPA Group, the Irish aircraft leasing company, said yesterday that it might be forced to seek bankruptcy court protection from creditors if a key debt holder did not approve its plan to refinance $2.7 billion worth of debt. The Public School Employees Retirement System of Pennsylvania has still not approved the company's plans to reorganize its debt. GPA said in December that it would sell two-thirds of its aircraft lease portfolio to pare debt.          The fund, which owns 30 percent of GPA's secured notes, wants the plan to cover some of the $100 million of preferred stock it holds. "If GPA is not able  to reach a satisfactory agreement with Psers within several days, it will likely be forced to withdraw the refinancing proposal," GPA said in a statement.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
abstract: * Insignia Solutions, Mountain View, Calif., to Goldberg Moser O'Neill, San Francisco, to handle advertising for the computer company, previously handled by Elliott/Dickens, San Jose, Calif. The billings were estimated at more than $5 million. * Carvel Corp., Farmington, Conn., to DeVito/Verdi, New York, to handle its account, previously at TBWA/ Chiat Day, New York, a unit of the Omnicom Group. The billings were estimated at $5 million. * Block Drug Co., Jersey City, to Publicis/Bloom, Dallas, a unit of Publicis S.A., to handle advertising for its newly acquired Nature's Remedy laxative. The account, with billings estimated at $3 million, had been inactive under the brand's previous owner, SmithKline Beecham.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;RAYCHEM SHARES JUMP 18 PERCENT ON IMPROVED EARNINGS
abstract: The shares of the Raychem Corporation rose 18 percent yesterday after the company reported late on Wednesday that it had a 21 percent increase in second-quarter earnings and said it had reached an agreement that would eliminate future losses from its venture with L. M. Ericsson Telefonaktiebolaget of Sweden. Raychem, a Menlo Park, Calif., electronics and telecommunications company, said the Ericsson agreement would eliminate its exposure to the venture, the Ericsson Raynet Corporation. Raychem also raised its dividend 25 percent, and Merrill Lynch & Company raised its investment rating on the company yesterday. Raychem's stock was up $9.50, at $62.75 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;LEVERAGED BUYOUT FIRM TO BUY ANDROS FOR $87.5 MILLION
abstract: Genstar Capital Partners II L.P. said yesterday that it would acquire Andros  Inc., a maker of equipment used in environmental and medical monitoring devices, for $18 a share, or about $87.5 million. Genstar, a leveraged buyout firm based  in Foster City, Calif., plans to begin a tender offer within the next week to buy shares directly from Andros stockholders. The board of Andros, which is based in Berkeley, Calif., has approved the merger agreement. The shares of Andros rose $2.75, to $18.25, in Nasdaq trading yesterday.

headline: RUSSIA AND I.M.F. AGREE ON A LOAN FOR $10.2 BILLION
abstract: In a major election-year boost for President Boris N. Yeltsin, the International Monetary Fund and Russia agreed today on a $10.2 billion loan to carry forward the country's free-market reforms.         The loan, second only to the the bailout package for Mexico last year, is linked to a sweeping plan to proceed with privatization, trade liberalization and other critical steps to move Russia toward a capitalist economy.

headline: NATO Presses Serbs To Release Civilians
abstract: A day after denying that NATO had a responsibility to address the issue, NATO officers visited Ilidza, a Serbian-held suburb of Sarajevo, to press officials to release up to 18 Bosnian citizens who have been detained by the Bosnian Serbs.         After the meeting, the commander of NATO land forces in Bosnia, Lieut. Gen. Sir Michael Walker, said he had not received promises that the civilians would be freed. In Washington, the State Department called for their immediate release.

headline: NATO Troops Arrest Some Foreigners Among Muslim Troops
abstract: French NATO troops raided a house near Sarajevo today, arresting 11 Muslim soldiers, including some foreigners, and confiscating "a large number of weapons, ammunition and explosives," a NATO statement said.    NATO officials called the presence of foreign troops and the arms cache "a serious violation" of the Bosnia peace agreement. The 11 soldiers are being held by NATO forces pending further investigation.          In Washington tonight, American officials said that five of the 11 men arrested were Iranian citizens with plans to attack NATO military buildings in different areas. The officials said they could provide no more detail about specific locations.

headline: G.I.'s on Alert After Report Of Threat by Bosnia Serb Chief
abstract: United States troops in Bosnia have been placed on alert after reliable reports that Gen. Ratko Mladic, the Bosnian Serb leader, had ordered his forces  to kidnap American soldiers and other NATO troops, Defense Department officials  said today.         The officials said General Mladic had apparently issued the order last week in retaliation for the capture of two deputies by Bosnian Government forces on Jan. 30. The two men were later placed in a NATO plane and extradited to the Netherlands to face trial on charges of war crimes.

headline: Dialing the Rabbi
abstract: To the Editor:         As a Christian, a Quaker and a spiritual counselor who was born into a Jewish family and received a Jewish education, I find the article about Rabbi Evan C. Radler humiliating ("Spirituality as a Business: Rabbis Are Standing By," Earning It, Dec. 31).

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                                               Previous      Year                               Yesterday       Day       Ago

headline: Raja N. Khuri, 61, Educator in Beirut
abstract: Dr. Raja N. Khuri, a former acting president and dean of medicine at the American University in Beirut, died on Wednesday at his home in Greenville, N.C. He was 61.         The cause was Parkinson's disease, his family said.

headline: Blow for Blow: Israelis Demolish Bomb-Maker's Family Home
