abstract: The house of the man held responsible for seven terrorist attacks in Israel was blasted to rubble today, the latest measure in Israel's attempt to deter Palestinian militants from carrying out suicide bombings.         The Government also announced that it planned to deport anyone linked to such bombings, that it had arrested 24 more suspects in raids on the West Bank and that the blockade on all 8 major Palestinian towns and 465 villages, which has largely brought life to a standstill, would remain for a long time.

headline: Ex-Aide Accuses Colombia Leader in Scandal
abstract: A former Defense Minister and campaign manager for President Ernesto Samper said in a televised interview tonight that Mr. Samper knew that Colombian drug traffickers were contributing money to his 1994 presidential campaign.         The former official, Fernando Botero, disputed the contention by Mr. Samper that if money had been taken from the Cali drug cartel it had been done behind his back.

headline: Europe Will Contest U.S.-German Air Pact
abstract: In a move that could undermine a fledgling alliance between Lufthansa A.G. and United Airlines, the European Commission said last week that it would take legal action against Germany for signing an open skies agreement with the United States.

headline: Equity Issues Set For This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:          America West Airlines, Phoenix, 6.1 million class B shares. Merrill Lynch.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;SUN COMMUNITIES TO BUY MANUFACTURED HOUSING GROUPS
abstract: Sun Communities Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire 25 manufactured housing communities, mostly in Michigan and Florida, from Aspen Enterprises Ltd. for $226 million. Sun Communities, a real estate investment trust based in Farmington Hills, Mich., plans to raise funds for the transaction by issuing common stock, debt and partnership stakes. The funds will also be used to retire $64 million of debt and to convert the company's secured line of credit to an unsecured facility. Sun Communities stock was unchanged yesterday at $26.625, but the deal was announced after the close of trading.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Liggett Breaks Ranks, Settling Tobacco Suit The Liggett Group, the smallest of the nation's five major cigarette companies,  broke industry ranks, agreeing to settle a huge class-action lawsuit. Lawyers representing millions of smokers agreed to drop the company from the suit in return for payments to a national quit-smoking campaign and Liggett's promise to withdraw from the fight against new tobacco regulations from the F.D.A.

headline: Belgrade Journal;Scathing 'Conscience' of Balkans Spares No One
abstract: During the Balkan war, most artists and writers in what was once Yugoslavia used their talents to glorify the ideologies that fuel violence or have found themselves silenced.         But amid the cacophony there has been one artist with enough stature in all six republics of the former Yugoslavia to continue to ridicule the nationalism and triumphalism that comes out of Belgrade, Zagreb and Sarajevo.

headline: Burmese Harbor Drug Lord
abstract: The leader of a Burmese drug operation who is wanted in the United States on  heroin trafficking charges is living in a lakeside villa in the most exclusive neighborhood of Yangon, Myanmar's capital, a diplomat said today.         The diplomat said that the drug operation leader, Khun Sa, had been living in Yangon for several weeks after his surrender to Government forces in January.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Senators Resist Both Plans For TV Airwaves Auction
abstract: Distancing themselves from both the White House and Bob Dole, the Senate majority leader, members of the Senate Budget Committee expressed deep reservations today about proposals to raise billions of dollars by auctioning off radio frequencies earmarked for digital television.         At a hearing today, neither Republicans nor Democrats on the panel had anything nice to say about the two rival proposals aimed at making television broadcasters pay for licenses estimated to be worth $10 billion to $70 billion.

headline: Report on Massacre Provokes A Political Storm in Mexico
abstract: Mexico's shaky political balance was weakened today as opposition leaders threatened to storm out of crucial talks on election reforms to protest what they claimed was an attempt to whitewash the massacre of 17 peasants by police in the state of Guerrero last June.         In his final report to the state congress yesterday, a special state prosecutor, Oscar Alejandro Varela Vidales, concluded that the mass killing was  an unfortunate accident caused by poorly trained police officers and not an ambush organized by Government officials, despite considerable evidence to suggest otherwise.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;HARTE-HANKS AND DIMARK IN DEAL WORTH $155 MILLION
abstract: Harte-Hanks Communications Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire Dimark Inc., a provider of marketing and data base services, for about $155 million in stock. Harte-Hanks, a direct marketing and media company in San Antonio, will exchange  0.656 share for each share of Dimark, which would value Dimark shares about $15  each. Shares of Dimark, which is based in Langhorne, Pa., fell 62.5 cents yesterday, to $14.125, on the American Stock Exchange; shares of Harte-Hanks fell 37.5 cents, to $22.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS;Weak Reports Bolster Prices Of Treasuries
abstract: Prices of Treasury securities returned close to their two-week highs yesterday. For the third consecutive day, market participants bought on weak economic data that pointed to continued low inflation.         The market began the day with overseas buying as the French and British cut interest rates, making dollar-denominated investments like Treasury securities more attractive to foreign investors. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bonds fell to 5.98 percent, from 6.01 percent on Wednesday, as the price, which moves  in the opposite direction, rose by 13/32 of a point, to 112 11/32.

headline: Market Place;Help Arrives For Pickens, But the Cost Is Very High
abstract: Even among the titans of the 1980's takeover era, T. Boone Pickens stood out  for having the vision, the money and the gall to make derelict corporate chiefs  with sagging stock prices quake.         But today, with his own Mesa Inc. besieged by hostile shareholders, inundated with nearly $1.1 billion in debt and beaten down on the stock market, Mr. Pickens announced an arresting epilogue to that era by granting a friendly investor preferential terms to save his company and his job.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;ATARI AGREES TO MERGE WITH DISK-DRIVE MAKER
abstract: The Atari Corporation and the closely held JTS Corporation agreed yesterday to merge in a stock swap worth about $75 million. Atari, a pioneer in the home video game industry, plans to issue 40 million shares to JTS, in a bid to expand into disk-drive manufacturing. Based on Atari's closing stock price of $1.875 on Monday, the transaction would be worth about $75 million. The merged company, to be called the JTS Corporation, would continue to develop the Atari video game console and software and sell specialty disk drives. Shareholders of Atari would own 60 percent of the new company, but it would be led by JTS executives. Shares of Atari rose 18.75 cents, to $2.06, on the American Stock Exchange.

headline: In Greece, Battle to Lead Goes Public
abstract: The battle to succeed Andreas Papandreou as Prime Minister formally opened today as several top members of his Socialist party declared candidacies in a race that until Monday had been kept under wraps.         Mr. Papandreou's resignation, announced on Monday night after a two-month illness that had left the country rudderless, was marked here today as an end of an era by commentators and politicians, who both praised the 76-year-old leader's long career and welcomed his decision to end it.

headline: 1995 Was Good for Companies, And Great for a Lot of C.E.O.'s
abstract: A preliminary survey of the compensation of chief executives at a number of America's largest corporations indicates that executive pay may have risen last  year at the fastest rate since the mid-1980's, when pay for performance became the guiding principle for rewarding corporate chiefs.         The median salary and cash bonus rose nearly 15 percent in 1995, to more than $2 million, for chief executives at 76 of the largest 150 companies in a survey conducted by an expert on executive pay. That compares with median pay increases for chief executives at large corporations of 11 percent or less since 1988.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;J. Walter Thompson Quits Boston Market
abstract: Just days after the Boston Market restaurant chain acknowledged discussions with several agencies for additional creative resources, its agency of record, J. Walter Thompson New York, said on Friday that it had resigned the estimated $30 million account, after only 10 months.         Boston Chicken Inc., which owns Boston Market, said that it informed Thompson New York of plans to unbundle the account among several agencies and media companies, and that Thompson New York then declined to take part in the changes.

headline: Sit-In at Japan's Legislature Ends
abstract: A day after losing an important by-election, Japanese opposition parties today ended a three-week sit-in that had blocked parliamentary debate on an unpopular bailout plan for bankrupt housing lenders.         Negotiations led by Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto and Ichiro Ozawa, the leader of the opposition New Frontier Party, resulted in an agreement that will  enable Parliament to continue to work on the fiscal 1996 budget.

headline: Toys 'R' Us Plans Charge For Global Reorganization
abstract: In a move intended to shore up sagging profitability, Toys "R" Us Inc. announced yesterday that it was reorganizing its worldwide operations, a plan that included closing 25 stores and paring the array of merchandise it offers to consumers.         To cover the reorganization costs, the company said it would take a one-time  after-tax charge of $270 million in the fiscal fourth quarter of 1996.

headline: World News Briefs;20,000 Attend a Protest Against Serbian Leader
abstract: Some 20,000 people demonstrated in Belgrade against the Government of President Slobodan Milosevic today, the anniversary of opposition protests crushed by troops in 1991.         Calling Mr. Milosevic and the ruling Socialists "red bandits," speakers blamed him for starting wars in Bosnia and Croatia and for wrecking Serbia's economy, which has been devastated by United Nations sanctions and by hyperinflation in the last five years.

headline: Chicago Pneumatic Move
abstract: The Chicago Pneumatic Tool Company said this week that it would close its Utica plant, which has 430 workers, within the next year. The company said on Tuesday that it would move its headquarters and manufacturing operations to a site in the Charlotte, N.C., area to be closer to its shifting customer base.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;South Korea Growth 9%
abstract: South Korea's gross domestic product grew 9 percent in 1995, helped by brisk  exports and capital investments, the central bank said yesterday. The performance was the strongest since an increase of 9.1 percent in 1991, the Bank of Korea said. Exports of goods and services increased 24.1 percent. Exports of  merchandise alone grew 25.3 percent with increased shipments of autos, semiconductors and machinery. Capital investment increased 15.9 percent.   (AP)

headline: World News Briefs;Taiwanese Urges Peace As China Moves Troops
abstract: President Lee Teng-hui of Taiwan, in a speech that he said was his definitive word on relations with China, emphasized the need for peace today, one day after China began moving troops toward its coast for what defense officials here described as military exercises.         "The one thing that all people on both sides of the straits passionately wish for is a stoppage to the hostile confrontation," Mr. Lee said at a campaign rally for Taiwan's presidential election, which takes place on March 23.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Clorox Parting Ways With Foote, Cone
abstract: The Clorox Company said yesterday that it would end its 71-year relationship  with the San Francisco office of Foote, Cone & Belding by moving its bleach and  home-cleaning business to DDB Needham Worldwide, effective April 15. Trade publications have estimated billings at $70 million to $100 million.

headline: A Puzzling Path: From P.S. 40 to a Cell in Peru
abstract: Before he goes to bed each night, Mark Berenson listens to a tape of his daughter Lori singing. He allows himself only one song a night from the tapes, which she used to send home from Peru, the country that has now convicted her of treason and sentenced her, at 26, to life in prison.         "It's all I may have for the rest of my life," Mr. Berenson said, sinking into a chair in the apartment near Gramercy Park where he and his wife, Rhoda, raised Lori.

headline: Unexpected Strength in Jobs Unsettles Stocks and Bonds;The Experts Stress A Wild Day Doesn't Always Set a Trend
abstract: As much tossing and turning as investors have done in recent weeks, the steady upward march by the markets has lulled most people to sleep.         But yesterday's sharp plunge in stocks and bonds, set off by the Government's release of surprisingly strong employment figures, has jolted wide awake nearly  every investor. The bond market experienced its worst day since 1987, while the Dow Jones industrial average dropped by more than 170 points, the largest point drop since 1991.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;J.& J.'s Profit Was Up 23% In 4th Quarter
abstract: Johnson & Johnson said today that earnings rose 23 percent in the fourth quarter -- more than expected -- lifted by strong sales of new drugs and medical devices.         The company, which makes Band-Aids and other health care products, said net income rose to $465 million, or 72 cents a share, from $378 million, or 59 cents a share, in the corresponding period of 1994. Analysts surveyed by Zacks Investment Research had expected a per-share figure of 68 cents.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Jacor to Buy Citicasters in $770 Million Radio Station Deal
abstract: Seizing on the recent deregulation of the radio industry, Jacor Communications Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire another large radio station owner, Citicasters Inc., in a deal worth $770 million.         By adding the 19 Citicasters stations to its lineup, Jacor will own 54 stations in 13 cities -- making it the largest collection of radio stations in the United States. Jacor will also pick up two network-affiliated television stations from Citicasters.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings this week:

headline: Colombia Chief Questioned on Drug Money
abstract: President Ernesto Samper of Colombia was questioned today before a Congressional committee that is investigating him on several charges related to  illegal donations made to his 1994 presidential campaign.         The campaign's former manager, Fernando Botero, as well as the treasurer, Santiago Medina, have accused Mr. Samper of having orchestrated donations worth  millions of dollars by the Cali drug trafficking organization to his presidential bid. Mr. Samper has denied any wrongdoing.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;BORDEN TO SELL WORLDWIDE PLASTIC PACKAGING UNIT
abstract: Borden Inc. said yesterday that it would sell its worldwide plastic packaging unit to focus on its main businesses. Borden, based in Columbus, Ohio, makes dairy items, pasta, snacks and other food products. It said the packaging unit had annual sales of $625 million. The unit has 27 plants in 12 countries with 3,500 employees. Borden, which is owned by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, has hired Morgan Stanley to help with the sale. Borden will use proceeds from the sale primarily for investment in other business areas, C. Robert Kidder, the company's chief executive, said. Borden employs about 30,000 people at nearly 200 plants.

headline: 1.5 Million Trader Theft Is Charged
abstract: In an unusually swift cooperative action, Federal prosecutors and securities  and commodity market regulators charged a New Jersey man yesterday with misappropriating at least $1.5 million from commodity pool accounts he managed for more than 100 investors.         Civil and criminal charges were filed in Federal District Court in Camden, N.J., against Michael Tropiano of Haddonfield, who has conducted business as Ardmore Financial Services since 1990. The filing by Federal prosecutors, the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission  came just three weeks after problems with the accounts first came to light. The  teamwork was remarkable because the public relationship among the prosecutors and regulators has often been marked by squabbling and turf battles.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;COLUMBIA/HCA INTENSIFIES ITS ACQUISITION PLANS
abstract: The Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation plans to step up its acquisition strategy this year and is "working on 150 individual transactions," a company official said yesterday. Victor Campbell, senior vice president at the Nashville-based company, said at a Hambrecht & Quist health care conference in San Francisco that the company was in discussions with individual hospitals and  groups of hospitals. Todd Richter, an analyst at Dean Witter Reynolds, said a third of the talks could result in acquisitions. Columbia/HCA, the largest for-profit hospital company in the nation, bought 41 hospitals in 1995. It owns  339 hospitals and 118 clinics.

headline: Pope Urges Reforms in Labor and Welfare
abstract: Pope John Paul II, resuming his travels outside the Vatican today after an illness, strongly defended workers' rights and warned of the dangers of "easy welfare."         The time has come "for a new policy of social solidarity, which has nothing to do with easy welfare, which in the long-run is harmful to the needy themselves," the Pope told a crowd of 5,000 during a visit to a crystal factory  in Tuscany. Such a policy, he said, should be based on "cooperation, a sense of  responsibility and industriousness."

headline: OUTLOOK '96: THE ECONOMY;1995 HIGHLIGHTS
abstract: Where Does Bill Gates Want to Go Tomorrow?

headline: Business Travel;Hilton is expanding its program that allows guests to swap hotel points and airline miles.
abstract: THE Hilton Hotels frequent-guest program -- the only loyalty plan that allows travelers to exchange hotel points for airline miles and miles for points, and to transfer mileage from one airline program to another -- has become even more  flexible, adding Trans World Airlines and Midwest Express to its roster of airline exchange partners.         Hilton, which also works with America West, Continental Airlines, Delta Air Lines, Mexicana and UAL's United Airlines in the exchange initiative, gives travelers a variety of ways to get the bonus they want. Members who do not have  a sufficient number of points for a specific hotel reward and who belong to a participating airline's frequent-flier program can exchange airline miles for hotel points to accrue enough points for the reward; the opposite exchange, hotel points for airline miles, is also allowed. In addition, participants in Hilton's program who also participate in American Express and Citicorp's Diners  Club loyalty plans can transfer points from these plans into the Hilton program.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Clinton to Seek Tax Cuts, But Not on Capital Gains President Clinton, presenting his 1997 budget to Congress today, will call for $100 billion in tax cuts during the next five years -- notably a tax credit of as much as $500 for families with at least one young child, and a deduction of up to $10,000 for college tuition and other degree programs -- while making business bear the brunt of the cost of those breaks. [Page A1.]

headline: MUTUAL FUNDS;When Your Fund Keeps Running Behind the Pack
abstract: IT'S that time when people pore over year-end mutual fund rankings -- some trying to hitch their investment wagons to rising stars, others fretting over whether they own any of the dogs.         Buying and selling off such lists is perilous. Morningstar Inc., the fund-tracking firm in Chicago, recently completed research indicating that one year's leaders tend to lag in the next year and that the wallflowers tend to blossom.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;DEAL TO ACQUIRE CORTIZONE AND HEMORID BRANDS
abstract: Pfizer Inc. said yesterday that its consumer health care group had agreed to  acquire the Cortizone and Hemorid brands from the Thompson Medical Company. Terms were not disclosed. Cortizone is an over-the-counter hydrocortisone product used to relieve itching related to skin irritations, rashes and insect bites. Hemorid is a hemorrhoid treatment for women. Thompson Medical, a privately held concern in West Palm Beach, Fla., is a pharmaceutical products company. Pfizer is a diversified health care company based in New York.

headline: With Land Sale Edict, Yeltsin Opens Way to Longed-For Era
abstract: The wheels of democracy were moving about as fast as molasses at the monthly  session of the Tula Land Reform Committee. There was a lot of talk about tractor repair and tax laws. There were farmers wondering about when to plant the spring grain, and whether the Government was going to give them any money to do it.         Then they got to the item that Russia has been waiting for -- in vain -- for  centuries.

headline: Afghan Capital Grim as War Follows War
abstract: Before the pink light of dawn could touch the snowy peaks of the Hindu Kush mountains around this ruined capital, five young Afghans met on a bitterly cold  morning last week for the gamble of a lifetime.         On borrowed bicycles, they planned to cross siege lines to the south of the city, load up with sacks of flour, cans of gasoline and bundles of firewood, and be back home by noon.

headline: Real Estate;A couple with a binder on a house who lost their bid collect in a Connecticut small claims court.
abstract: SOME real estate agencies in Connecticut are re-examining their practices governing the period from the acceptance of a bid on a house to the signing of a formal purchase contract after a couple took a home seller and agency to small claims court and won a judgment for $495.         The sum is small, seemingly out of proportion to the time spent by participants in this dispute. But in pursuing their claim, the couple, Peter and Christine Silkowitz, 28-year-old apartment dwellers in Rye, N.Y., have put a spotlight on a murky area in which laws and practices differ from state to state.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;U.S. BANCORP TO BUY CALIFORNIA BANCSHARES
abstract: U.S. Bancorp has signed an agreement to acquire a California Bancshares Inc.  of San Ramon, Calif., for $327 million, the companies announced yesterday. Under the acquisition agreement, each share of California Bancshares common stock will be converted into 0.95 share of U.S. Bancorp common stock. U.S. Bancorp, which is based in Portland, Ore., will add the 36 California Bancshares branches to its U.S. Bank of California operations. U.S. Bancorp is one of the 30 largest bank holding companies in the nation, with assets of about $32 billion. In Nasdaq trading yesterday, shares of U.S. Bancorp fell $1.313, to $32.938, while  California Bancshares jumped $2.563, to $30.313.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;Retailers' Sales Rise, but Shares Take a Beating
abstract: A quirk in the calendar, some good weather and a nation of shoppers who decided they could not live another day without a new shirt or scarf combined to lift retail sales in February. But the rebound, after months of low numbers, does not necessarily indicate that the retail industry is back with a vengeance.         The Goldman, Sachs same-store sales index, which compares stores open at least a year, rose 4.9 percent in February, compared with a 3.5 percent rise a year ago. It was the strongest gain since January 1995.

headline: Bahrain Rulers Say They're Determined to End Village Unrest
abstract: After a resurgence of civil unrest in the Shiite Muslim villages that surround this capital, a leading member of the Sunni Muslim ruling family said today that the Government was determined to put an end to the violence "once and for all."         "It cannot continue," the Prime Minister, Sheik Khalifa bin Salman al-Khalifa, said of the riots, arson and explosions that broke out last weekend  in a renewal of a 13-month-long confrontation between the Government and the Shiite-led opposition.

headline: Investment by Vitro
abstract: The glass maker Vitro S.A. of Mexico will invest $126 million in the next two years in its United States unit, the Anchor Glass Container Corporation, to upgrade machinery and improve profit margins, according to Anchor's new chief executive, Alfonso Gomez Palacio. Anchor's antiquated machinery has concerned analysts and investors who have wondered how well the company can fare in a weak bottle-making market.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;PANENERGY TO ACQUIRE NATURAL GAS ASSETS FROM MOBIL
abstract: The Panenergy Corporation said yesterday that it would purchase the Mobil Corporation's interest in some natural gas gathering, processing and pipeline assets in Texas, Oklahoma, Louisiana and Utah. The transaction, valued at about  $300 million, involves the sale of about 2,600 miles of pipeline and Mobil's interest in 24 natural gas plants. Mobil, based in Fairfax, Va., and Panenergy also said they intended to combine their natural gas marketing operations in a new joint venture. Panenergy, based in Houston, will own 60 percent of the new entity, while Mobil will own 40 percent. The Mobil assets to be acquired by Panenergy will not be included in the joint venture.

headline: Market Place;There is no clear victor in the Chrysler-Kerkorian battle, which was an odd affair from the start.
abstract: KIRK KERKORIAN is going to take in a lot of money as a result of his battle with Chrysler management, which ended in a settlement yesterday. But Chrysler has prevailed on the issue it painted as the most important: keeping adequate cash on hand in case a recession arrives.         There is no clear victor, and it is not clear if the stock will rise today. But that should not be surprising. This battle was always something of a sideshow.

headline: Shareholders Sue Hasbro Over Mattel Bid
abstract: Four stockholders of Hasbro Inc., the nation's No. 2 toy maker, filed suit against the company for rejecting Mattel Inc.'s merger offer, saying that Hasbro denied them increased profits.         The suits, filed in Rhode Island Superior Court, said that Hasbro violated its legal obligation to maximize shareholder value. The suits also asked the court to order Hasbro to sell itself and pay them damages.

headline: Short of Money, the French Face Cuts in Their Cherished Military
abstract: For decades, this town of tank-makers and army bases has thrived on France's  determination to be a military giant.         While similar cities in America -- Long Beach, Calif., home of Lockheed, and  Groton, Conn., headquarters of General Dynamics -- have suffered from sharp cuts in defense spending, Bourges and its 75,000 people have been cushioned so far by France's strong Gaullist tradition of maintaining an independent national defense, whatever the cost.

headline: Peace Plea Traps Yeltsin in Political Maze
abstract: Russia's war for Chechnya reached a dangerous new impasse today, after more than a thousand peaceful protesters in Grozny, the secessionist republic's capital, were surrounded by special forces army troops.         The protesters at the presidential palace -- not guerrillas but ordinary and  often elderly Russian and Chechen civilians sick to death of more than a year of war -- began on Sunday, after local officials decided to permit a peace demonstration.

headline: Day After It Refused Mattel, Hasbro Sees Its Stock Vault
abstract: Investors loaded up on Hasbro Inc. stock yesterday, even as representatives of the toy manufacturer mustered an aggressive defense in explaining why a $5.2  billion merger offer from Mattel had been rejected.         Hasbro stock, which has been a laggard in recent years, shot up by $9.875 yesterday, to $40.50, on the American Stock Exchange.

headline: Hamas Blames Killings by Israel for New Bombings
abstract: A top leader of the Islamic group Hamas said today that the resumption of suicide attacks in Israel after a six-month lull had been prompted by Israeli assassinations of Muslim militants that climaxed with the killing of the fugitive bomb-maker Yahya Ayyash in Gaza last month.         Sayid Abu Musamih, a deputy of the imprisoned leader of Hamas, Sheik Ahmed Yassin, said in an interview that the killing of Mr. Ayyash on Jan. 5 had jolted Hamas's military wing back into action after months in which attacks had been suspended.

headline: Jobless Claims Fall and Blizzard Is Cited
abstract: New claims for jobless benefits plunged by 67,000 last week, when the blizzard kept many government offices closed. The drop was the largest in more than two years.         The Labor Department said today that new applications for unemployment insurance totaled a seasonally adjusted 327,000 in the week that ended last Saturday, down from 394,000 a week earlier.

headline: Business Travel;Disruptions stemming from the big Northeast blizzard could extend into next week.
abstract: THIS week's great Northeast blizzard landed an equal opportunity migraine on  millions of Americans, disrupting lives, jobs and vacations. What is notable about the storm's impact on business travel is that its fury landed just as such travel was returning to normal after its usual holiday hiatus.         Washington suffered a double dose of misfortune: the storm arrived the day before furloughed Federal workers were expected back after 21 days. With the city's major attractions closed during those three weeks, the hotel industry lost 10 percent of its business and restaurants lost an estimated $1.5 million a day.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;British Petroleum To Drop 3 Refineries
abstract: British Petroleum P.L.C. said yesterday that it would close or sell three refineries, resulting in a $1.1 billion charge in a move that highlights the three-year overcapacity crisis in the oil-refining industry. The company plans to sell refineries at Lima, Ohio, and at Lavera, France, and to close the Pernis section of the Nerefco refinery near Rotterdam in the Netherlands. The measures  will trim capacity by about a third and follow earlier worldwide industry restructurings to raise prices for refined products.          The $1.1 billion after-tax charge, which will hit fourth-quarter results, includes losses on the refinery sales and closing of $610 million and provisions for environmental measures and other costs of $465 million.   (Reuters)

headline: Slow Pace Is Expected For Israel And Syria
abstract: Senior American officials say they are gloomy about the prospect of rapid progress in the Syrian-Israeli peace talks, which are to resume in Maryland for  a third round on Feb. 26.         The problem is not simply that Israeli officials are now saying that elections are set for May 28 instead of October. But it is also that President Hafez al-Assad of Syria simply refuses to be hurried, the American officials say, although they add that they believe Mr. Assad is indeed committed to a comprehensive peace treaty with Israel. And they reject the idea that he is merely stringing both the Americans and the Israelis along.

headline: U.S. SAYS CUBANS KNEW THEY FIRED ON CIVILIAN PLANES
abstract: The Clinton Administration made public today a transcript of aerial radio conversations that American diplomats say proves Cuban military pilots knew they had targeted a small civilian plane and screamed with glee when they made a direct hit.         "The target is in sight, the target is in sight," the pilot of one MIG-29 told a nearby MIG-23, as the fighters closed in on the aircraft piloted by a members of an anti-Castro Cuban-American group, Brothers to the Rescue. "It's a  small aircraft."

headline: Holiday Closings
abstract: All financial and commodity markets and banks in the United States will be closed on Monday in observance of Washington's Birthday. Most overseas markets will be open.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Investcorp Planning to Sell Its Remaining Stake in Gucci
abstract: Investcorp S.A. said today that it would sell its remaining 51 percent stake  in Gucci Group to the public.         The sale, which would be worth $1.14 billion at current stock prices, would complete the Italian luxury-goods company's move from a troubled money-losing company to one of Wall Street's hot stocks.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;FIDELITY NATIONAL BIDDING TO ACQUIRE GIANT GROUP
abstract: Fidelity National Financial Inc. began a bid yesterday to acquire Giant Group Ltd. for $12 a share, or about $57.3 million. Fidelity National, an insurance holding company that already owns 14.6 percent of Giant, said the offer was contingent upon Giant's abandoning its recent proposal to exchange Giant preferred stock for common stock of Rally's Hamburgers Inc. That plan by Giant,  which is based in Beverly Hills, Calif., would raise its stake in Rally's, a fast-food chain, to as much as 84.9 percent from about 47.5 percent. In addition to its interest in Rally's, Giant also makes cement. Fidelity National said it might appeal directly to Giant's shareholders in a hostile bid if talks with Giant's board were not successful.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Sharp and Alcatel Join on Phone Product
abstract: The Sharp Corporation of Japan and Alcatel Alsthom S.A. of France announced an alliance yesterday to develop new wireless equipment that combine cellular telephones with electronic organizers. Sharp will also distribute Alcatel equipment for digital cellular telephones.          The agreement calls for Alcatel and Sharp to develop "personal mobile communicators." The new product is expected to be on the market sometime during  the first half of 1997, Alcatel said. Ericsson of Sweden and Nokia of Finland have already announced plans to develop similar products.   (AP)

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Libya Congress Demands Answers on Oil Revenues
abstract: Libyan legislators have harshly criticized their Government during stormy debates in the Congress, demanding to know what happened to billions of dollars  in oil earnings.         The seven-day annual session of the Congress, formally Libya's highest decision-making body, closed today with an order for inquiries into all accusations of mismanagement made to the Congress.

headline: Surfing the Internet Sets the Agenda for Software
abstract: ONE of the more popular prognostications for the Internet and the World Wide  Web is that they will usher in a new breed of software: tiny "applets" that will replace bloated applications and continual upgrades.         But these applets and the $500 Netsurfer computer they will supposedly run on remain concepts today.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;PHONE CENTERS TO CLOSE, COSTING ABOUT 2,500 JOBS
abstract: The AT&T Corporation said yesterday that it planned to close its 338 Phone Center retail stores next month, cutting about 2,500 jobs, as part of its preparation for splitting into three companies. The company said it would rely on other retailers to sell its telephones, answering machines and related products. AT&T said it would continue to honor warranties and service claims from customers of the Phone Centers. People who lease phones from AT&T will be able to work with independent service agents. The job cuts at the Phone Centers  are part of the company's overall reduction of about 40,000 of its 300,000 jobs.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;TRACOR TO ACQUIRE WESTMARK'S ASSETS IN STOCK DEAL
abstract: Tracor Inc., a maker of military electronic systems in Austin, Tex., agreed yesterday to acquire all of Westmark Systems Inc.'s assets for about 7.95 million Tracor shares. Assets of Westmark, a closely held company in Dallas, consist primarily of Tracor stock and warrants and some real estate. James B. Skaggs, Tracor's president, said the agreement allowed the company to simplify its capital structure and broaden ownership of its shares. The transaction value of about $126 million is based on a valuation of Tracor's stock at $15.80  a share, the company said. Tracor's shares rose 50 cents yesterday, to $15, in Nasdaq trading. Upon closing of the deal, Westmark will liquidate by distributing the Tracor shares to its 29 shareholders.

headline: Indian Opposition Leader Faces Arrest
abstract: A judge today ordered the arrest of 10 politicians charged in an $18-million  bribery scandal, including four former Cabinet ministers and the leader of India's largest opposition party.         The warrants were the latest indication of the unusually hard-hitting approach the courts are taking in the scandal, the first to embroil the top rungs of all three main political parties, and the pall it has cast over general elections expected in April.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;MOBIL PLANS TO LAY OFF 500 WORKERS AT U.S. UNIT
abstract: The Mobil Corporation said yesterday that its Mobil Exploration and Producing United States unit would lay off about 500 workers by March 31 as part of a larger reorganization. The layoffs represented 15 percent of Mobil Exploration and Producing's work force of about 3,300 employees in 10 states and offshore in the Gulf of Mexico. The reorganization is expected to reduce fourth-quarter earnings by $21 million, Mobil said. In the 1994 fourth quarter, Mobil reported net income of $523 million. Mobil Exploration and Producing currently operates about 260 oilfields and gas fields in the United States and in the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: An Old Stab At Soldiers Opens Battle In Germany
abstract: In an article published 65 years ago, the German satirist Kurt Tucholsky wrote, "Soldiers are murderers." A court absolved him of charges that he had slandered the military, but his famous phrase is once again the subject of bitter debate among German lawyers, judges and politicians over the limits of free speech.         Last year the police here arrested a man for pasting a bumper sticker on his  car that said, "Soldiers are murderers." His case went all the way to Germany's  highest court, the Constitutional Court, which ruled that he had committed no crime.

headline: Burmese Heroin Trafficker Surrenders but Is Negotiating With Junta
abstract: The generals who govern Myanmar, formerly Burma, have claimed victory over one of the world's most notorious opium traffickers, but they are remaining silent about what will happen to a vast drug empire that supplies much of the heroin found on the streets of American cities.         In statements released through official newspapers here, the governing junta  has reported the surrender of Khun Sa, the opium warlord, and his private army.

headline: Real Estate;Brokers are reporting a surge in demand for midpriced apartments in Manhattan.
abstract: WHILE the biggest, most desirable prewar apartments on Fifth and Park Avenues have been rising in price for more than a year, real estate brokers in Manhattan are now reporting a surge in sales of midpriced apartments elsewhere.         Bidding wars, multiple offers to buy at the full price and sealed bids have not been seen in this market since the late 1980's. While such interest is not the norm, agents say it is definitely on the upswing.

headline: News Analysis;For the Tories, a Prime Disaster
abstract: The crisis over British beef is turning out to be more than a body blow to an industry worth $6.5 billion. And it's more than a humiliating comedown for Britain's staple foodstuff, celebrated in the novels of Henry Fielding, that symbolized the country's power and supremacy beginning in the 18th century.         On a more mundane level, it is turning into a full-fledged political debacle  for the Conservative Government of Prime Minister John Major. The Government's handling of the crisis that erupted with the disclosure that there may be a link between mad-cow disease and a fatal human brain disorder has enraged and confused everyone from farmers to consumers and from businessmen to parents, not to mention other governments in the European Union.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;Walt Disney Says Earnings Rose 2.9% in First Quarter
abstract: The Walt Disney Company reported yesterday that its earnings rose 2.9 percent in its fiscal first quarter, as the company's performance was restrained by marginal gains from its film division.         Disney's theme-park and consumer products divisions posted stronger increases.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;India Airlines Meet
abstract: India's international airline, Air India, said yesterday that it was working  toward closer cooperation with the country's domestic airline, Indian Airlines,  in the face of growing competition from international carriers and new private-sector domestic airlines. At a special board meeting of Air India and Indian Airlines, the two companies identified areas of cooperation, Air India officials said.   (Dow Jones)

headline: CREDIT MARKETS;Budget Block Knocks Down Bond Prices
abstract: Bond prices fell sharply yesterday, hurt by the gloomier outlook for budget talks in Washington. The drop sent yields on long-term Treasury issues back up to the levels of three weeks ago, before the Federal Reserve cut interest rates.         On shorter maturities, however, prices were shored up by the plunge in the stock market yesterday that sent investors in a flight to quality.

headline: Port of Spain Journal;Star Batsman Lashes Out, Sending Cricket Reeling
abstract: Imagine that after breaking the season record for home runs, baseball's top power hitter suddenly quits his team on the eve of the World Series, complaining of his manager's inability to maintain discipline. In retribution, the commissioner's office fines him 10 percent of his salary, and fans erupt in anger against management.         That is roughly the situation the world of cricket has been living through since Brian Lara, 26, of Trinidad, the sport's leading batsman, withdrew from the team that represents the West Indies in international tournaments.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Takeover Offer for BET
abstract: BET P.L.C., a British cleaning, security and catering concern, said yesterday that Rentokil Group P.L.C. had approached it with a takeover offer. Details of the offer were not disclosed, but analysts estimated that Rentokil's bid could be around L1.9 billion, or $2.9 billion. BET said its directors would meet to discuss the offer today. BET's American depository receipts gained $2.125 yesterday, to $11.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.   (Dow Jones)

headline: France Says It Is Willing to Discuss Its Nuclear Role in NATO
abstract: France, spelling out details of its plan to return to closer military cooperation with NATO after 30 years at arm's length, said today that it was willing to discuss the role its independent nuclear deterrent could play as part of a strengthened European pillar within the alliance.         "France is willing to participate in a certain number of debates on the nuclear question with its allies, including within NATO, provided there is a change of attitude about strengthening an independent European defense," Defense Minister Charles Millon told reporters here.

headline: U.S. to Call Balkan Leaders to Parley on Violations of Accord
abstract: American officials, believing that the Bosnian peace accords are beginning to unravel, decided on Monday to call an international conference in Rome this weekend "to read the riot act" to the Presidents of Bosnia, Croatia and Serbia and to get them "to recommit" to the accords, a senior American official said today.         All three Balkan Presidents are flouting the agreement on fundamental issues  ranging from prisoner and refugee exchanges to the expulsion of foreign volunteers and commitments to apprehend alleged war criminals, the officials say.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;Digital Reports Large Increase In Net Income
abstract: The Digital Equipment Corporation reported a more than sevenfold increase in  its fiscal second-quarter earnings today on growth in the company's core large-computer and personal-computer businesses and strong demand for its Alpha  chips.         Net income for the quarter that ended Dec. 30 increased to $148.8 million, or 91 cents a share, from $18.9 million, or 7 cents a share, in the comparable period a year earlier. Wall Street had expected earnings of 85 cents a share, according to a survey of 16 analysts by Zacks Investment Research.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Hongkong Bank Reports a Fraud
abstract: Hongkong Bank, a unit of HSBC Holdings P.L.C., a British-based banking and finance company, said yesterday that it was trying to locate $34.2 million it lost in a fraud in Indonesia. On Jan. 3, the bank, which is Hong Kong's largest, detected corporate fraud involving a fake transfer of funds at its branch in Jakarta, the company said. Of the 97 billion rupiahs, or $42 million, it lost, 18 billion have been traced, it said.          The Indonesian police are working with Interpol to solve the fraud. Local news reports have quoted police officials as saying the prime suspect is a Filipino who has fled the country.   Bloomberg Business News

headline: I.R.A. Says Bomb Victim Was a Guerrilla
abstract: The Irish Republican Army announced today that a 21-year-old Irishman who was killed by a bomb on a London bus last Sunday was one of its guerrillas.         It identified him as Edward O'Brien of Gorey in County Wexford in the Irish Republic and said that he had been "on active service," a statement that added to British investigators' suspicions that he had been transporting a device when it exploded prematurely.

headline: Schäuble Sees Split On Monetary Union Lasting Year or More: EU Heading For Political Crisis, Kohl Aide Says
abstract: DAVOS, Switzerland—  The European Union is headed for a "political crisis" that will be touched off by growing divisions over monetary union and the EU's future size and shape,a top adviser to Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany says.

headline: OUTLOOK '96: THE ECONOMY: Middle Age Catches Up With the MeGeneration; Changing the Shape Of the Housing Market
abstract: After having "paired and nested," many members of the baby boom generation are now in the process of trading up to single-family homes, public policy analysts say.         "They are trading up to bigger homes and to communities where they will want  to stay for quite a while," said James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Public Policy at Rutgers University.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: AMERICAN FINANCIAL GROUP INC., Cincinnati, a property and casualty insurer, said the $63 million sale of its Buckeye Management Co. subsidiary would result in a  pretax gain of about $35 million in the first quarter.

headline: Milnerton Journal;This $40 Crank-Up Radio Lets Rural Africa Tune In
abstract: Even in relatively rich South Africa, half the homes have no electricity. Go  far enough off the beaten track and there are villages with no place to buy even a little AAA battery. So in much of Africa, the portable radio is of little use.         Maybe not for long. For about six weeks now, a small factory in this town just north of Cape Town has been cranking out radios with cranks. Give the handle a few aerobic turns and the Freeplay radio holds forth for half an hour.

headline: Group Concerned About Family Members on Boards
abstract: Investors, citing the need for management accountability, usually frown on companies whose directors are beholden to the chief executive. Now the Council of Institutional Investors has come across an even bigger red flag: boards studded with members of one family, often but not always the chief executive's.          The practice, well known at companies with a family name on the door, like the Ford Motor Company, is hardly limited to those cases.

headline: Chemical Bank to Arrange $3.7 Billion Kmart Credit
abstract: The Kmart Corporation said today that Chemical Bank had agreed to provide $3.7 billion in credit, enabling the struggling retailer to clear its largest financial hurdle.         Kmart plans to use much of the $3.7 billion in credit to replace about $3 billion in debt due next year.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Four Executives Open New Shop
abstract: Four executives who have worked at agencies in San Francisco are opening their own shop there named Black Rocket.          The four, all partners in the new agency, are: Mark Barden, 33, who had been a senior vice president and planning director at Hal Riney & Partners; Bob Kerstetter, 35, formerly an associate creative director at Goodby, Silverstein & Partners, a unit of the Omnicom Group; Steve Stone, 34, formerly a senior vice president and creative director at Riney, and John Yost, 46, who had been an executive vice president at Riney before leaving late last year. The partners said the Black Rocket name was derived from a 19th-century British train.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;TRW IN TALKS TO SELL CREDIT INFORMATION UNIT
abstract: TRW Inc. is in talks to sell its credit information business for as much as $1 billion to an investment group that includes Bain Capital Inc. and the Thomas H. Lee Company, according to a person involved in the discussions.  TRW's Information Systems and Services unit is one of the nation's leading providers of credit reports on consumers and businesses. It had sales of $604.2 million and an operating profit of $86.8 million last year.  TRW, Lee and Bain Capital all declined to comment about the possible deal, which was reported yesterday in The Wall Street Journal. TRW's stock closed unchanged at $86.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.  Bain Capital and Thomas H. Lee Company are closely held buyout firms in Boston.

headline: Arrest Puts Israel Arabs Under Cloud
abstract: The disclosure today that an Israeli Arab has been arrested on suspicion of driving a Palestinian suicide bomber to Tel Aviv on Monday put Israel's Arabs on the defensive and highlighted the delicate problems they face as a minority in a Jewish state.         Although it was not yet clear whether the suspect had known he was ferrying a suicide bomber, allegations that he was involved raised questions of dual loyalty that hover constantly over Israel's Arab citizens.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;COLEMAN TO BUY STAKE IN MAKER OF CAMPING EQUIPMENT
abstract: The Coleman Company said yesterday that it had agreed to buy 60 percent of Application des Gaz S.A., a French maker of camping equipment, from Butagaz, a subsidiary of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group, for about $58 million. Coleman, a maker of camping equipment based in Golden, Colo., said Application des Gaz had  about $200 million in revenue in 1995. Coleman said it planned to try to buy the 30 percent of Application des Gaz that is publicly held. It also holds an option to buy Butagaz's remaining 10 percent stake. Coleman is 80 percent owned by the  financier Ronald O. Perelman's MacAndrews & Forbes.(Dow Jones)

headline: Kmart to Shut 15 Stores, Cutting 1,300 Jobs
abstract: The Kmart Corporation said yesterday that it would shut 15 stores by the end  of May and dismiss 1,300 workers, the opening move in its program to close 60 stores this year.         The company also announced further executive changes in its merchandising division.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;C-TEC TO SELL SOME TELECOMMUNICATIONS ASSETS
abstract: The C-Tec Corporation, a telecommunications concern, agreed yesterday to sell some assets to a major shareholder, the RCN Corporation, for about $123 million. The assets to be sold include C-Tec International, which holds a 40 percent interest in Megacable, a cable television system operator in Mexico; Commonwealth Long Distance, a long-distance reseller, and the Residential Communications Network, a start-up that plans to provide telecommunications services. RCN owns 48.5 percent of C-Tec, which is based in Princeton, N.J. RCN  is a unit of Peter Kiewit Sons' Inc. C-Tec is also planning to spin off its local telephone operations.

headline: Microsoft and MCI Agree On an Internet Alliance
abstract: In the promiscuous world of digital technology, where most companies prefer playing the field to going steady, MCI Communications said yesterday that it had signed an Internet alliance with the Microsoft Corporation. This, even though it already has an on-line partnership with the News Corporation.         Under the terms of the deal, MCI and Microsoft will jointly develop and market an array of on-line and Internet services. Microsoft said it had chosen MCI as the primary distributor of its commercial on-line service, the Microsoft  Network. And MCI said it would promote Microsoft's Internet software and browser throughout its network.

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: AMERICAN COMMUNICATIONS SERVICES INC., Annapolis Junction, Md., appointed Harry D'Andrea chief financial officer, succeeding Ronald Kaiser, who resigned.

headline: U.S. Details Plutonium Shipments Abroad
abstract: The United States during the last 50 years shipped nearly a ton of plutonium  to 39 countries, including Argentina, India, Iran, Iraq, Israel, Japan, New Zealand, Pakistan, South Africa, Sweden, Turkey, Uruguay and Venezuela. And it acquired nearly six tons of plutonium from such nations as Canada, Taiwan and Britain.         Although these transfers were all legal, they have never before been detailed publicly. Figures showing the volume of trade in the deadly radioactive substance, a fuel of reactors and nuclear weapons, is one of dozens of disclosures to be made today as the Federal Department of Energy unveils the first public accounting of all the plutonium that ever passed through Federal hands.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;GANNETT CO. (GCI,N)
abstract: The Gannett Company said yesterday that earnings rose 4 percent in the fourth quarter, exceeding expectations, because of strong results from its television and radio business.         Gannett earned $155.5 million, or $1.11 a share, up from $149.4 million, or $1.07, in the comparable period a year earlier. Results for the quarter included an extra week and the operations of Multimedia Inc., which Gannett acquired for  $1.7 billion on Dec. 4. However, Gannett said Multimedia did not affect 1995 earnings.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;COMPUTER ASSOCIATES INTERNATIONAL (CA,N)
abstract: Computer Associates International Inc. reported yesterday an unexpectedly strong 30 percent profit rise for its fiscal third quarter on continued strong sales of its corporate software.         The company, the second-largest independent software maker after Microsoft, earned $227.2 million, or 90 cents a share, in the three months ended Dec. 31, compared with analysts' estimates of 84 cents a share. Earnings for the comparable period a year earlier were $174.2 million, or 69 cents.

headline: Italy Cannot Form Cabinet And Plans Elections in April
abstract: Confronted by the failure of Italy's leading parties to agree on constitutional reforms, President Oscar Luigi Scalfaro signed a decree tonight dissolving both houses of Parliament, thus setting the stage for general elections on April 21.         The decree brings to an end a monthlong crisis that began with the resignation of interim Prime Minister Lamberto Dini and ended with the collapse  this week of a broad-based attempt to change Italy's flawed political system.

headline: Japan Stocks Rise
abstract: Stocks rose here on hopes that exporters' earnings would improve after the dollar gained against the yen. At midday, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up  148.20 points, or seven-tenths of 1 percent, at 20,339.05. On Friday, the Nikkei surged 267.19 points, or nearly 1.37 percent, to close at 20,190.85.

headline: Chechen Town's Fugitives Say Russians Shell Civilians
abstract: Chechen civilians said today that they had come under fire from Russian forces as they fled the battered town of Novogroznensky and that others had been trapped there, contradicting Russian statements that the assault had been delayed until all civilians had left.         The fortified town had served as the headquarters of Aslan Maskhadov, the Chechen military commander, and was a main stronghold of secessionist resistance. The Russian military announced today that it seized the town last night after attacking it with airplanes, helicopters, artillery and mortars.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Six Get Awards For Aiding Diversity
abstract: Six Diversity Achievement Awards, honoring executives in advertising, marketing and the media for their work in fostering diversity, were presented Monday night by District 2 of the American Advertising Federation in New York.          The honorees are: Jay Chiat, former chairman and chief executive of Chiat/Day, Venice, Calif., now the TBWA Chiat/Day unit of Omnicom Group; Ann Fudge, president of the Maxwell House Coffee Company unit of Kraft Foods, White  Plains, which is owned by the Philip Morris Companies; O. Milton Gossett, former chairman and chief executive at Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide in New York, a unit of Cordiant P.L.C.; Harold Levine, former chairman and chief executive of Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver in New York; Mark Rodriguez, president and chief executive of Great Brands of Europe in Greenwich, Conn., which is owned by Danone Group, and Brandon Tartikoff, chairman of New World Entertainment in Los Angeles.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;National Semiconductor Earnings Slide 59.6%
abstract: The National Semiconductor Corporation said yesterday that earnings tumbled 59.6 percent in its fiscal third quarter, hurt by lower-than-expected sales and  higher costs.         The maker of memory chips earned $23 million, or 17 cents a share, in the quarter ended Feb. 25, down from $57 million, or 43 cents, a year earlier. Earnings in the recent quarter were after a charge of $11.4 million for the purchase of Sitel Sierra B.V. of the Netherlands.

headline: Turkish Kurd Rebel Threatens Suicide Bombings in Germany
abstract: The leader of Kurdish insurgents in southeastern Turkey threatened today to send suicide bombers to Germany in retaliation for its crackdown on Kurdish dissidents here.         The threat was made in an interview by Abdullah Ocalan, head of the Kurdish Workers' Party, Marxist dissidents who seek a separate Kurdish state in Turkey.  It raised the likelihood of harsher German measures against Kurdish militants living in Germany.

headline: Peres Praises Arafat; Giuliani Not So Sure
abstract: The Palestinian Authority announced yesterday it had arrested three senior members of the military wing of Hamas, the Islamic movement linked to recent suicide bombings in Israel, and Yasir Arafat drew guarded praise from Shimon Peres, Israel's Prime Minister.          But Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York, visiting Jerusalem, injected himself into the maelstrom of Middle East affairs, cautioning Israel about dealing with Mr. Arafat, who was under mounting pressure from Mr. Peres to crush Hamas.

headline: 20 Trapped in Japan Tunnel After Avalanche
abstract: With the temperature sinking dangerously low, rescue teams in northern Japan  searched frantically early today for a way to free about 20 people trapped in a  crushed mountain tunnel without triggering a second rock slide.         The authorities were not sure how many people were trapped or if any were killed when the Toyohama tunnel gave way under an avalanche of mud and rocks Saturday morning. A passenger bus and at least one car were buried.

headline: U.S. Officials Confident That Mad Cow Disease of Britain Has NotOccurred Here
abstract: Federal officials are confident that the mad cow disease found in Britain has not occurred in the United States and that existing policies are adequate to protect the beef supply. A meeting of 70 animal and public health experts convened by the United States Department of Agriculture reviewed current policies last week and concluded without recommending any further safeguards.         Nonetheless, the department said it would increase the number of cattle brains routinely tested for mad cow disease.

headline: Patents;Where less can be much more: invention and technology's race to devise lower-fat junk food.
abstract: THE McDonald's Corporation announced last week that it was scrapping its low-fat hamburger, the McLean Deluxe, which just wasn't popular enough with burger buyers. But it is unlikely that this turn of events will stop food producers from pursuing the perfect method of removing fat from meat.         As sales of low-fat and fat-free food have skyrocketed, patents for engineered foods have become increasingly common. Manufacturers and researchers  are vying to create fat substitutes -- lower-fat cheeses and meats, reduced-calorie chocolate and other sweets. They are all trying to produce healthier food without sacrificing flavor, texture or appearance, and without driving costs way up.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Executive Joins Publicis/Bloom
abstract: Tony DeGregorio, who has long been a leading creative director at New York agencies, said yesterday that he would join the New York office of Publicis/Bloom in the new position of president and chief creative executive.         Mr. DeGregorio, 48, will report to Robert Kantor, who is being promoted from  president to chairman and chief executive; those are new positions at the New York office of Publicis/Bloom, which is a unit of Publicis S.A. Three creative directors who had reported to Mr. Kantor, 38, will now report to Mr. DeGregorio: Penny Hawkey, 53, vice chairwoman, and Nick LaMicela, 58, and Vince Nigro, 43, who are executive vice presidents.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Fokker Is Facing Cutoff Of Government Aid
abstract: Fokker N.V., the Dutch jet maker now under court protection from creditors, came under more pressure to find a corporate partner when the Dutch Government said yesterday that it would not make another emergency loan to the company. The current emergency credit expires the end of this month.          Fokker has narrowed its list of potential partners, with the most serious candidates considered to be Bombardier Inc. of Canada and the Samsung Corporation of South Korea. Last month, the large German industrial concern Daimler-Benz A.G., in the face of big losses, abandoned its three-year effort to rescue Fokker.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: Partial McDonald's Victory in South Africa
abstract: The McDonald's Corporation has won part of its battle in South Africa to defend its name and trademarks from a local competitor, the company and lawyers  said today.         A temporary court ruling granted last November was made final, preventing the local company "from using the name and other world famous trademarks of McDonald's," the company said.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;The small American agency for Intel is now inside a huge worldwide parent company, Euro RSCG.
abstract: THE high-tech marketer that urges computer users to insist on "Intel inside"  has unexpectedly consolidated its advertising at a global giant, but in a twist  will not leave its small American agency on the outside.         The Intel Corporation, which dominates the microprocessor market with its powerful Pentium chip, named Euro RSCG in Paris to handle its worldwide account, with billings estimated at more than $100 million. Intel, which is based in Santa Clara, Calif., selected Euro RSCG -- the world's seventh-largest agency company -- to handle the creative and media portions of the account in all countries except Japan, where Dentsu Inc. in Toyko will remain on the Intel roster.

headline: PRESIDENT AGREES TO TOUGH NEW SET OF CURBS ON CUBA
abstract: Driven largely by the downing of two civilian American planes by the Cuban military, Congressional negotiators and the White House agreed today on a package of sanctions intended to punish Fidel Castro by curbing foreign investment in Cuba.         The measure, which President Clinton had opposed until this week, would give  the weight of law to the nearly 40-year-old embargo against Cuba that has been the policy of every American President since Mr. Castro came to power. That would prevent any President from acting on his own, as Mr. Clinton and others have in the past, to loosen or tighten sanctions as relations with Cuba change.

headline: FUTURES MARKETS;Heating Oil Hits 4-Year High Because of Drop in Inventories
abstract: Heating oil prices jumped to their highest levels in more than four years as  refinery inventories fell following wintry weather that has lingered into spring.         Higher prices for corn pushed the Commodity Research Bureau index up 0.29 point, to 252.95, its highest since July 1988. The energy-weighted Goldman Sachs Commodity index gained 0.17 point, to 208.24.

headline: VOICES: VIEWPOINT;No Accounting for This Plan
abstract: IF a group of powerful corporate executives has its way, the current independent rule maker for accounting in this country will soon cease to exist.         The Financial Accounting Standards Board as we know it -- an independent and, despite its imperfections, a respected and quite effective private-sector body charged with establishing financial reporting standards for the benefit of the public -- would be replaced by a new F.A.S.B. in an effort to make it less "anti-business."

headline: Business Travel;USAir's terminal at La Guardia comes in second in a poll ranking airport concession programs.
abstract: WITH short runways, inadequate parking space and its location in the heart of a busy city, New York's La Guardia Airport wins few accolades from passengers or pilots. But the USAir terminal at La Guardia tied for second place with Portland, Ore., International Airport in a recent poll ranking airport concession programs. USAir's operation at Pittsburgh International finished first.         In the poll, airport executives, concessionaires and consultants were asked to rank the top three airports in the country with the best retail services, including concept mix, physical layout, design and theme. All three winning airports are among the growing number that charge "street prices" in their retail stores.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;OVERNITE TRANSPORTATION TO CUT UP TO 1,000 WORKERS
abstract: The Overnite Transportation Company, a trucking concern owned by the Union Pacific Corporation, plans to lay off up to 1,000 workers nationwide, beginning  on Monday, because of declining traffic and depressed freight rates. The cuts are to occur at all levels of the company. Overnite, which is based in Richmond, employs 14,000 workers at more than 170 terminals nationwide. It is one of the largest haulers that consolidate loads from several customers aboard one truck. Such companies, known as less-than-truckload carriers, have been squeezed financially in the last year as some operators have driven down rates.

headline: Vulcan Deal in Chemicals
abstract: The Vulcan Materials Company said today that it had agreed to buy the Mayo Chemical Company, a maker of specialty chemicals, for an undisclosed price. Vulcan, which makes construction materials and chemical products, is based here. It said the acquisition would complement its specialty-chemicals division and increase its production of products used in the water-purification, paper and textile industries.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Bayer Fined in Europe
abstract: The European Union fined the German drug maker Bayer A.G. $3.9 million yesterday for violating European antitrust law. The union's year-round executive arm, the European Commission, ruled that Bayer had held back supplies of Adalat, a drug used in cardiovascular treatments, to Spanish and French wholesalers to prevent them from exporting the drug to Britain, where it commands higher prices.   (AP)

headline: An Acquisition for Avon
abstract: Avon Products Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Justine Ltd., marking the beauty-care company's entrance into South Africa. Terms were not disclosed. Justine, of South Africa, is a privately held direct seller of skin care, color cosmetics, fragrances and other beauty products there.

headline: Company Sees Stock Fall 46%
abstract: The shares of Health Management Inc. plunged 46 percent today after it said it would restate some fiscal 1995 financial results and take a $15 million to $20 million pretax charge in its third quarter because of accounting irregularities. Its top officer took a lesser post and a second officer resigned.         The charges are expected to result in a loss for the third quarter, although  the company's results from operations in the period have not yet been determined, a company spokeswoman said. Health Management also said it expected  to be in default under its loan agreements.

headline: Kodak Names President of Imaging Unit
abstract: The Eastman Kodak Company named a former exectuive at the International Business Machines Corporation, Robert M. Unterberger, to the post of president of its Digital and Applied Imaging unit.         Mr. Unterberger, 55, an electrical engineer by training, succeeds Carl Gustin, who became Kodak's chief marketing officer last July. The post had been  vacant since than.

headline: I.R.S. Offers Companies a Deal in Contract-Worker Disputes
abstract: The Internal Revenue Service said yesterday that it would offer discounts of  up to 87.5 percent on the payroll taxes owed by employers who were found to have improperly paid employees as independent contractors.         But a leading lawyer in the contentious field of worker classification said the I.R.S. deal was no bargain.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;ADFLEX BUYS A DIVISION OF XYRATEX FOR $56 MILLION
abstract: Adflex Solutions Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired a division of Xyratex Ltd. which supplies interconnect products for computers. Adflex paid $56 million in cash, debt and stock. Adflex Solutions, of Chandler, Ariz., said the  division of Xyratex, a British company, had revenues of about $72 million in 1995. Adflex supplies flexible circuit-based interconnect products to the computer, communication and consumer electronics product industries. As part of the agreement, Xyratex, a maker of computer disk drives, communications systems and test systems, will acquire a 15 percent stake in Adflex. Adflex's stock slipped 75 cents, to $24.50, in Nasdaq trading.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Chastened by High Jobless Data, Paris and Bonn Seek a Solution
abstract: With both France and Germany staggering under the burden of chronically high  unemployment, President Jacques Chirac said today that he and Chancellor Helmut  Kohl had discussed the idea of coordinating measures to stimulate flagging economic growth throughout Europe.         The French head of state gave no details, but he said he had asked Prime Minister Alain Juppe to develop new measures to stimulate consumer spending in France; a wave of public strikes last month knocked the wind out of the economy  at the height of the Christmas shopping season.

headline: Enron Agrees to Resume Work at Project in India
abstract: Answering the objections of Indian nationalists, the Enron Corporation said today that it had agreed to cut sharply the cost of the electricity that a huge  project in India will provide.         As a result, Enron said, it had formally agreed with the government of Maharashtra state in west India to resume work on the plant and hoped to do so within 90 days.

headline: NATO Chiefs Press Serbs To Release 18 Bosnians
abstract: Only a day after denying that NATO had a responsibility to address the issue, NATO officers visited the Serb-held suburb of Ilidza today to press officials to release up to 18 Bosnians who have been detained.         The detentions appear to be a violation of the Dayton, Ohio, peace accords, which call for freedom of movement throughout Bosnia. They have also been portrayed by the Bosnian Government as a direct challenge to NATO's mission.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Burnett Takes Stake In Media Company
abstract: The Leo Burnett Company in Chicago said yesterday that it had acquired an equity stake in Giant Step Productions, a company in Chicago that specializes in developing marketing programs for the Internet, CD-ROM's and other interactive media. The terms were not disclosed.         Giant Step, which has 13 employees, will continue producing interactive marketing programs for Burnett clients like the Maytag Corporation, the McDonald's Corporation and the United Airlines unit of the UAL Corporation; Burnett has had an alliance with Giant Step since June 1994. Adam Heneghan, 25,  and his brother, Eric, 27, the multimedia directors who formed Giant Step in 1990, will report to Rashad Tobaccowala, 36, vice president and interactive marketing director at Burnett.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;STORAGE TRUST REALTY IS ACQUIRING 25 FACILITIES
abstract: Storage Trust Realty said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire 25 self-storage facilities from Balcor/Colonial Storage Income Fund-86 for $67.1 million. Storage Trust, a real estate investment trust based in Columbia, Mo., said the agreement was subject to certain conditions, including approval by the  limited partners of Balcor/Colonial. Storage Trust operates 138 facilities in 16 states.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Honors
abstract: The Association of Independent Commercial Producers, New York, elected Frank Stiefel, president of Stiefel & Co., Hollywood and New York, as 1996 chairman. Frank Scherma, partner and head of the Hollywood office of @radical.media, becomes vice chairman.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Publishers and Netscape Plan News Network
abstract: The Netscape Communications Corporation and a group of news organizations, including Reuters, ESPN and The Los Angeles Times, plan to announce Tuesday an Internet news network that can be displayed automatically in the screen-saver software of a personal computer.         The system, which runs on software created by Pointcast Inc., will permit a personal computer user connected to the Internet to receive a personalized newspaper that would be updated at regular intervals. The system takes the idea  of an on-line newspaper a step beyond news sites found on the World Wide Web. Such sites require an Internet user to connect manually to a particular Web page to view news articles.

headline: Market Place;The Wells Fargo wagon may be the merger vehicle of the future.
abstract: IS Wells Fargo's $11.6 billion takeover of First Interstate the beginning of  a decade of hostile bank takeovers?         The last big deal by Wells Fargo, its 1985 acquisition of its San Francisco neighbor, Crocker National, was a model for a generation of friendly mergers between banks that served the same markets. By closing more Crocker branches and dismissing more Crocker employees than had been thought possible, Wells Fargo showed the banking industry how profitable such deals could be.

headline: INVESTING IT;The Talk of Cyberspace: Is Iomega Losing Its Zip?
abstract: EVERY investor dreams of getting in on the meteoric rise of a hot stock like  that of the Iomega Corporation, a maker of high-capacity disk drives for computers. The stock could be picked up for about $1 a share early last year, and last week, it traded as high as $20.         Recently, though, Iomega has wound up with more detractors than perhaps any other company listed on the Nasdaq stock market. Last week, Nasdaq reported that as of mid-February more than 18.1 million shares of Iomega stock had been sold short, a bet that a stock will decline. The huge short position is equivalent to 30 percent of the company's shares.

headline: World News Briefs;Chechens Seize Hostages And Insist Russians Leave
abstract: Chechen rebels who seized a maternity home and hospital overnight have threatened to start shooting hostages unless Russia withdraws its troops from the separatist region, the ITAR-Tass news agency said today.         Tass said up to 50 rebels had seized the two buildings in the town of Kizlyar in the autonomous republic of Dagestan to the east of Chechnya. The rebels had forced civilians into the buildings, it added.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: SPYGLASS INC., Naperville, Ill., has agreed to buy Stonehand Inc., Cambridge, Mass., a privately held provider of Internet software, for $9.5 million.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;COORS ANTICIPATES STEEP QUARTERLY LOSS
abstract: The Adolph Coors Company said yesterday that it expected to report a steeper  first-quarter loss because of unspecified problems. A year ago, Coors reported a loss of 2 cents a share for the first quarter, which it restated after shifting  its fiscal year to conform to the calendar year. The company, in Golden, Colo.,  is expected to report first-quarter earnings about mid-April. Coors and other big American brewers have been struggling as specialty beers and imports gain market share in the sluggish industry. Shares of Coors fell 37.5 cents yesterday, to $18.75, before the earnings forecast was made.

headline: 240 Million Is Offered for Leslie Fay Unit
abstract: A new suitor has surfaced for Sassco, the most profitable division of the Leslie Fay Companies, the women's apparel manufacturer that has languished in bankruptcy protection for almost three years.         On Jan. 22, an investor group headed by Three Cities Research Inc., a fund that makes investments on behalf of wealthy families and other private investors, sent a letter to members of Leslie Fay's creditors committee, outlining a proposal to buy Sassco for roughly $240 million in cash and stock.

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: BEHRMAN CAPITAL, New York, said that William Merrill Matthes had joined the firm as a partner.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Honors
abstract: Dennis Holt, chairman and chief executive of Western International Media, Los Angeles, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos., was named leader of the year by the Western States Advertising Agencies Association. He will be honored at a  dinner on Feb. 13 in Los Angeles.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;BOARD BACKS REPURCHASE OF UP TO 10 MILLION SHARES
abstract: The Sprint Corporation said yesterday that its board had authorized the repurchase of up to 10 million common shares. Sprint has more than 400 million shares outstanding, including those held by France Telecom and Deutsche Telekom. Repurchased shares will be held as treasury stock and used primarily for employee benefit programs and other general corporate purposes, the company said. Sprint, based in Westwood, Kan., is the No. 3 United States long-distance company behind AT&T and MCI. Sprint and the French and German telecommunications companies earlier this year formed a joint venture called Global One.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;J. Walter Thompson Gets Zantac Account
abstract: The Warner-Lambert Company said yesterday that it had named J.
