Walter Thompson New York to handle advertising for an over-the-counter version of Warner-Lambert's Zantac prescription antacid.         Robert Casale, vice president for gastrointestinal marketing at Warner-Lambert in Morris Plains, N.J., confirmed a report of the assignment this week in Adweek. He declined to discuss billings, but Adweek estimated that the introductory advertising and promotional spending could reach $100 million. Thompson New York, which is a unit of the WPP Group, was awarded the assignment  without a review, Mr. Casale said; the agency already handles Warner-Lambert brands like Listerine mouthwash, e.p.t. pregnancy tests and Lubriderm lotions.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;BRODERBUND STOCK DOWN AFTER EARNINGS REPORT
abstract: The shares of Broderbund Software Inc., which makes educational software, slumped yesterday, one day after the company warned that second-quarter results  would be less than forecasts because of slower product sales. The negative report and a late conference call prompted several analysts to cut their ratings and earnings estimates, and the company's stock plummeted $7.125, to $46, in Nasdaq trading after falling as low as $43 during the day.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;DIGITAL AND CIRRUS LOGIC END PLAN FOR JOINT OPERATION
abstract: The Digital Equipment Corporation and Cirrus Logic, a computer chip maker, yesterday ended plans to operate a joint semiconductor manufacturing venture after Cirrus said it was cutting its capital spending. The companies announced an agreement in December that would have enabled Cirrus to produce semiconductor chips at Digital's plant in Hudson, Mass. Digital had been seeking a partner to  defray the cost of the plant. But earlier this week, Cirrus, based in Fremont, Calif., warned of a fourth-quarter loss because of lower-than-expected orders. Digital, based in Maynard, Mass., said negotiations this week failed to persuade Cirrus to continue with the plan.

headline: Investor Group Is Seeking Koger
abstract: An investor group said this week that it might increase its 13.8 percent stake in Koger Equity Inc. to as much as 25 percent, if the company lifted its takeover defenses.         The group, which includes RGI N.V. and Resource Group International Inc., also said it wanted to choose two members for the company's board.

headline: TECHNOLOGY: CONNECTIONS;Can Twinkies think, and other ruminations on the Web as a garbage depository.
abstract: HELLO, I am Stuart Roberts," reads a Web page I recently tripped over. "I have big feet."         This proclamation raised some expectations that somewhere under the photo of  Mr. Roberts would be an explanation of this fact, some elucidation of its importance or implications. But that was all: a Web page devoted to podiatric disclosure.

headline: An Antibacterial Accord
abstract: Cubist Pharmaceuticals Inc. said last week that it had reached an agreement with Pfizer Inc. to develop and sell antibacterial drugs. The terms were not disclosed. Cubist, a closely held biotechnology company based in Cambridge, Mass., said it would work with the New York-based drug maker to develop drugs to treat bacterial infections that are resistant to existing medicines. As part of the agreement, Pfizer will finance research at Cubist to develop the compounds and will have the option to make an equity investment in the company.  In return, Pfizer will get the worldwide right to sell any products developed by the collaboration.

headline: The Theft of Identities: A Long and Winding Road
abstract: To the Editor:

headline: In Taiwan, Few Admit To Worries About China
abstract: With less than 48 hours remaining before China was set to begin a new round of live-fire war games barely a dozen miles from Taiwan-controlled islets, Ho Chi-hung bent over his slender single-stringed erhu to find a first, single note.         Then, eerily, whispers of a classical melody, "Spirit of the Sword," floated  from the delicate instrument, spilling into an atrium where it jostled with strains from violins, a flute and a brass sextet struggling with Gustav Holst's  "Second Suite in F."

headline: Squeezing the Textile Workers;Trade and Technology Force a New Wave of Job Cuts
abstract: Martha Smith cried as she left the Dover Mills plant of Andover Togs Inc. on  a Wednesday afternoon late in January. Along with approximately 100 other people, she had lost her job sewing children's clothing.         Now she is enrolled in a state-sponsored program to learn clerical skills. "There's no more textile jobs around here," she said. "They are all going to Mexico and overseas."

headline: Tokyo Journal;The Land of Laureates: Japan's Passion Is Poetry
abstract: She is young and famous, with her own weekly television show, a radio program and fans who fawn over her on the street, but Madoka Mayuzumi is neither a movie actress nor a rock star.         She is a poet.

headline: Near Sarajevo, a Quest To Heal War's Hatred
abstract: Every evening, after walking his beat in this suburb newly transferred from rebel Serbian control, Radovan Zidovic, a police officer for the Bosnian-Croat Federation, drives to a hospital in Sarajevo. He weeps at the bedsides of his daughter and father, who were gravely injured by a Bosnian Serb grenade, and wonders why he spends his days cheerfully greeting his former enemies, offering them his hand and the reassurance that they should stay in their homes.         "That is what I do, but sometimes I think that I really want them to leave because of what they have done to my family, what they have done to my country," said Mr. Zidovic, scratching at his mustache and pointing to some of the few apartments still occupied by Serbian residents.

headline: VIEWPOINT;Standoff in Cyberspace Gulch
abstract: IN the new frontier that is cyberspace, a showdown is shaping up as the law moves into town. On one side is a band of cybercitizens bent on protecting their privacy as they explore this unmapped territory. On the other are the lawmakers  charged with safeguarding all cybercitizens from crime, even if it means forcing them to give up some of their privacy by, say, signing in as they enter town.        This is how the public debate over cyberspace security has been framed. And on-line users are, indeed, worried about security. Yankelovich Partners surveyed 400 randomly selected on-line users, aged 16 and older, by telephone in mid-October and found that 90 percent agree that better Internet security is needed to insure that personal and financial information is not accessible to unauthorized people. Nearly 80 percent believe it is too easy for one's credit card number to be stolen if used on the Internet. And almost 70 percent agree that pornography on the Internet has gone far beyond reasonable bounds.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
abstract: TMP Interactive, Framingham, Mass., to Harpell/Martins & Co., Concord, Mass., as the first agency to handle advertising for the developer of the Monster Board, which provides career information on the World Wide Web. The billings were estimated at $3 million. ERO Industries, a division of ERO Inc., Mount Prospect, Ill., to Anda & Scotti Advertising, New York, as the first agency to handle a national consumer campaign for the Slumber Shoppe line of products like sleeping bags and play tents. The billings were estimated at more than $1 million.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;EXIDE SAYS RUMORS OF F.B.I. INVESTIGATION ARE FALSE
abstract: The Exide Corporation said yesterday that rumors the Federal Bureau of Investigation was investigating the company were "totally false and without foundation." A spokesman for the company, a battery maker in Bloomfield Hills, Mich., said the rumor apparently started when the company's chief financial officer told several analysts yesterday about an F.B.I. investigation into an inventory loss at its plant in Greer, S.C. Exide's stock dropped $4.25, or 14 percent, to $26.25 a share on the New York Stock Exchange. When its stock started falling, the company learned that some on Wall Street misunderstood the  situation and incorrectly thought Exide itself was being investigated, the spokesman said. In fact, he said, the company is the victim.

headline: America Online Gives Microsoft Favored Status On Internet
abstract: What a difference a day makes in cyberspace.         A day after it announced a licensing agreement to adopt Netscape Communications' popular Navigator software for browsing the Internet's World Wide Web, America Online said yesterday that it would make Microsoft's rival program, Internet Explorer, its primary software for browsing the Web.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;ELECTRIC BOAT TO LAY OFF 1,500 EMPLOYEES THIS YEAR
abstract: Electric Boat, which has been steadily reducing its work force because of a decline in submarine orders, said yesterday that it will lay off 1,500 employees this year, most of them by the end of September. Electric Boat, a unit of General Dynamics, employs about 14,000 at its shipyard in Groton, Conn., and its plant in North Kingstown, R.I. The submarine builder currently has a backlog of  only five craft, with two scheduled to be delivered to the Navy this year. Electric Boat has said it plans to reduce its work force to 7,000 by the end of  1998. Jobs are also being eliminated through attrition, including retirements, the company said.

headline: AT&T Chief, Who Cut Jobs, Defends Pay
abstract: Robert E. Allen, AT&T's chairman and chief executive and the man who ordered  40,000 people cut from the company's payroll, received stock options last year that increased his total pay package to $16 million from $6.7 million.         Executives of the AT&T Corporation say Mr. Allen's actual pay is much less, because he and other top executives cannot cash in their options for at least four years. Mr. Allen, in a long and testy message to all company employees on Monday, said he had actually taken a 20 percent cut in cash compensation and was "in line with C.E.O.'s of comparable companies."

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Swiss Bank Registers 30% Profit Increase
abstract: The Swiss Bank Corporation announced yesterday that it registered a 30 percent rise in net profit for 1995, helped by greater-than-expected cost savings from its acquisition of the British merchant bank S. G. Warburg. Swiss Bank said it had earned 1.053 billion Swiss francs ($875 million), up from 811 million Swiss francs a year earlier. The increase was in line with forecasts. It represented a reversal from 1994, when profit slid 41 percent.          The bank -- Switzerland's third biggest after Union Bank of Switzerland and  Credit Suisse -- left the dividend unchanged. The company acquire Warburg last year for $1.3 billion.   (AP)

headline: COMPANY NEWS;B.P. SEEN IN EUROPEAN DEAL WITH MOBIL
abstract: The British Petroleum Company and the Mobil Corporation plan to combine their European refining, gasoline-station and lubricants operations in a $5 billion deal, according to articles today in The Financial Times and The Wall Street Journal. Under an agreement expected to be announced today, B.P. would control the refining and marketing businesses, while Mobil would handle the lubricants operation, the newspapers said. B.P. would have a 70 percent interest in the venture, which would have combined annual sales of $20 billion. The companies are expected to take charges totaling $400 million to start the venture. Company officials declined to comment last night. Separately, Mobil agreed yesterday to sell its Tucker Housewares subsidiary, which makes plastic containers and other products, to the Zeta Consumer Products Corporation for an  undisclosed price. (Reuters)

headline: U.S. Pushes Civilian Aspects of Bosnia Pact
abstract: With the military aspects of the Bosnian accords going reasonably well, with  the shelling stopped and opposing forces separated, American efforts are turning sharply toward the more complicated effort to build a shared peace among recent  enemies who have little trust for one another.         Warren Christopher, who has met the leaders of Croatia, Bosnia and Serbia in  the last two days, was the first American Secretary of State to visit ravaged Sarajevo and the first to come to Belgrade since 1991, before Yugoslavia shattered. But this trip will not be his last.

headline: Limited Partnerships Come Up From the Canvas
abstract: IF you're still fuming over the money you socked into limited partnerships during the 1980's, take heart. Getting rid of the hapless investments isn't as much of a losing proposition as it used to be.         Of course, many limited partnerships are still worth much less than what investors paid for them in the days before scandal put them in the headlines and the Tax Reform Act of 1986 shrank their tax advantages. But recently, the booming stock market has driven up the value of these partnerships. Add in the rebounding real-estate sector -- more than half of these partnerships are in real estate -- and resale values are better than anything seen in the last few years.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Samsung Tells Of Auto Plans
abstract: Samsung Group announced a $13 billion plan today to turn its fledgling automobile subsidiary into one of the world's top 10 car makers by 2010.         Samsung Motors Inc. said it planned to introduce its first model in Korea and other markets by 1998. Each subsequent year will see another introduction.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;FMC GOLD WEIGHS SALE OF ONLY PART OF THE COMPANY
abstract: The FMC Gold Company said yesterday that it was considering selling part of the company, rather than the whole thing, because there was greater interest in  its individual assets. The mining company, which is 80 percent owned by the FMC  Corporation in Chicago, hired Wood Gundy Inc. of Toronto in September to sell the entire company. FMC Gold said the recent upturn in gold prices had allowed FMC Gold to evaluate other options. FMC Gold has hired J. P. Morgan & Company to assist Wood Gundy in soliciting proposals. FMC Gold's shares were up 12.5 cents yesterday at $5.875.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;New York Planning Tourism Campaign
abstract: The New York City Economic Development Corporation has begun a search for agencies to handle advertising and public relations for its initial national and international campaign to promote tourism as well as recruit businesses to the city. Billings were estimated at $10 million.          Agencies that specialize in advertising or public relations (or both) will be asked to complete questionnaires, Charles Millard, president of the development unit, said Friday, adding that a maximum of 10 agencies would then be asked to make capability presentations based on responses to the questionnaires. A decision is expected by the middle of spring, he said, and the campaign is scheduled to begin in the fall.

headline: Donnelley Unit Offering
abstract: The R. R. Donnelley & Sons Company said last week that it planned to sell a majority stake in its Metromail Corporation direct-marketing information unit in a public offering, to focus more on its commercial printing business. Donnelley, the world's largest commercial printer, said it would retain a significant minority stake in Metromail. Metromail, based in Lombard, Ill., offers consumer information and reference services to companies involved in direct mail and telephone marketing.

headline: Market Place;As the market rebounds, utilities just aren't bouncing.
abstract: NEVER mind.         That was the message most of the stock market gave yesterday regarding Friday's huge selloff. Particularly for stocks that march in tune with economic  activity, the gains were extremely strong.

headline: Pronet Buys 3 Concerns
abstract: Pronet Inc. said today that it had completed its acquisitions of three paging companies for a total of $30.7 million. Pronet, a paging concern, said it bought Page One of Georgia for about $19.7 million, which will add more than 30,000 subscribers. It bought Sun Paging of Florida Inc. for about $2.3 million in cash. That purchase will add more than 12,000 subscribers. And it also bought Signet Paging of Raleigh Inc. for about $8.7 million. The purchase of the North  Carolina-based company adds more than 13,000 subscribers.

headline: Even in Peace, a Family Is Balkanized
abstract: As children, Irena Tomic and her cousin Tanya Madjarevic played with Barbie dolls together. They were best friends by the time they were adolescents, enjoying summer weekends around the swimming pool at Miss Tomic's house in the wooded hills outside Tuzla.         But the two have been unable to see each other since the war divided them nearly four years ago.

headline: Li Sung Li, North Korean Nuclear Scientist, 91
abstract: Li Sung Li, a scientist known as the father of North Korea's nuclear energy program, died on Thursday after a long illness, the North's official radio reported. He was 91.         A 30-member state committee, led by two Vice Presidents, was formed for Mr. Li's funeral.

headline: Fight Over Picking Up Tab For S.&L. Bailout Renewed
abstract: The savings-and-loan crisis may have passed, but the fight over who picks up  the bill rages on.         Six and a half years after Congress passed sweeping legislation to clean up $150 billion in losses from a decade of mismanagement and fraud at the nation's savings and loans, savings institutions and their commercial bank competitors are arguing anew over how much responsibility each industry has to make up a share of the losses.

headline: U.N.-Led Team Uncovers Grave in Bosnia
abstract: In a muck-filled ditch by a hillside road here, a team of coroners, soldiers  and workmen have been digging up skulls, bones and rotting clothing in what are  believed to be mass graves where Bosnian Serbs buried Muslims or Croats.         The team uncovered five sets of remains in this town in northwestern Bosnian  on Friday, but officials said up to nine people could be buried here.

headline: Market Place;The two big 'ifs' holding down Turner Broadcasting shares.
abstract: LAST week, boasting strong earnings, Time Warner Inc. not only painted a rosy picture of its fiscal health, but also indicated that the two thorniest problems facing its planned purchase of Turner Broadcasting System -- Government clearance, and a lawsuit by its erstwhile partner, U S West -- were moving toward resolution.         But Wall Street arbitragers, whose business is to make big bets on takeovers, don't quite believe that things are going that smoothly.

headline: NEC Plans to Increase Production of Chips
abstract: The NEC Corporation said today that it planned to double its output of 16-megabit dynamic random-access memories, or D-RAM, chips -- a key component in personal computers -- to 18 million units a month.         A spokesman, Makoto Miyakawa, said that NEC expected to further raise production to 20 million units by the close of the fiscal year that ends on March 31, 1997.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;ROADMASTER TO CLOSE PLANT AND CUT 600 JOBS
abstract: Roadmaster Industries, which makes bicycles, wagons, scooters and fitness equipment, said yesterday that it would cut about 600 jobs and close one plant as it warned of losses for the fourth quarter of 1995 and the full year. The Atlanta-based company also agreed to sell its Nelson/Weather-Rite camping division to the Brunswick Corporation for $120 million in cash. The company said it planned to close its fitness manufacturing operation in Tyler, Tex., and consolidate its fitness production at the Opelika, Ala., plant. The company also said it would reduce its lamp, distribution and other operations. The restructuring will result in a one-time charge to 1995 net income, it said.

headline: China Arrests Brother of Doctor Who Told of Orphanage Abuses
abstract: Zhang Shuyun, the doctor who accused an orphanage here of deliberately starving children in its care, said today that her brother had been arrested and charged with subversion, apparently in retaliation for her decision to publicize her allegations of abuse.         In an interview from New York, Dr. Zhang said her brother, Zhang Jian, was taken from his home in Shanghai on Jan. 9, one day after the Shanghai authorities arranged a tour of the orphanage for foreign journalists to deny that organized neglect ever occurred there.

headline: Serbs Appear To Ease Stand On NATO
abstract: The Bosnian Serbs appeared today to back away from the hard-line position that they might sever ties with the NATO-led forces deployed to oversee the Bosnian peace agreement.    NATO officials said that despite an order from the Bosnian Serb military commander, Gen. Ratko Mladic, to cut all contact with peacekeeping troops, there was continued cooperation at the military unit level in several areas.          The Bosnian Serbs announced earlier this week that they would not cooperate  after the arrest of some of their military officials by Bosnian Government forces on possible war crimes charges.

headline: Netscape Tie To Compuserve
abstract: The Netscape Communications Corporation broadened the reach of its popular Navigator World Wide Web browser program today by entering into a distribution agreement with Compuserve Inc., the world's second-largest on-line computer service.         Users of Macintosh and Windows-based computers who subscribe to Compuserve or its separate Internet access provider, Sprynet, will be able to download Navigator at no charge beginning this spring.

headline: Business Travel;Uruguay is becoming a hot spot -- at least hot enough to support daily flights from New York.
abstract: AS the air wars over South America continue to escalate, business travelers are being rewarded with a wide selection of flights. Beginning Feb. 5, for example, United Airlines will add Thursday and Saturday flights from Kennedy International Airport in New York to Montevideo, Uruguay, giving the carrier one flight every day.         The flights go through Buenos Aires, because there is no nonstop service between the United States and Uruguay, a country the size of Washington State with slightly more than three million people. But airline officials think service may pick up rapidly as tourists increasingly discover the country. Several American budget hotel chains plan expansions into Uruguay, while Hilton  is scheduled to open a 327-room hotel and casino next January in Punta del Este, a popular seashore resort.

headline: Brazil to Auction Rail Concession
abstract: Brazil will auction a concession to run a stretch of its federal rail system  on June 14 for a minimum price of 316.9 million reais ($323.4 million), officials said today.         The center-east stretch of the rail system is the second of six lines the Government plans to auction as part of an improvement program. The line traverses the states of Bahia, Minas Gerais and Espirito Santo.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                                               Previous      Year                               Yesterday       Day       Ago

headline: COMPANY NEWS;SOFTWARE SPECTRUM PLANS TO BUY EGGHEAD DIVISION
abstract: Software Spectrum Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the corporate, government  and education division of Egghead Inc. for $45 million. Software Spectrum said the purchase would increase its presence as a reseller of computer software to businesses and organizations. The acquisition would also roughly double the company's annual revenue to $767 million. The sale would allow Egghead, which operates 164 software stores, to focus on its core software retailing business. Egghead said it would retain the division's inventory and receivables, which it said it planned to liquidate.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Editor of New York Objects to Coverage
abstract: Kurt Andersen, the editor in chief of New York magazine, objected yesterday to elements of an article in The New York Times yesterday concerning an article  the magazine published contending that it had "unmasked" the anonymous author of "Primary Colors."         The Times described the article, entitled "Who is Anonymous?" and naming Joe  Klein, the political columnist for Newsweek magazine, as the book's author, as "a cover story" for the latest issue of New York. Mr. Andersen said that the magazine's cover contained only a promotional headline for the article. The headline was in the upper-left corner of the cover, in red and white and said: "Who Wrote Primary Colors? 'Anonymous' Unmasked." The article was also the lead  item in the magazine's table of contents.

headline: Eligio Panti, 103, Maya Healer With Modern Ties
abstract: Eligio Panti, a traditional healer whose ancient herbal remedies attracted the attention of modern medical scientists and drew thousands of patients to the door of his humble hut in Belize, died on Sunday in his home in the village of San Antonio. He was 103 and widely regarded as the last Mayan master healer in Belize.         A native of Guatemala who was taken to what was then British Honduras when he was a year old, Don Eligio never learned to read and write, but while working in a chicle camp, extracting sap to be used in chewing gum, he began to acquire the lore of the rain forest that would make him famous far beyond his country's borders.

headline: Dole Steps Up Criticism Of Telecommunications Bill
abstract: Denouncing what he called "corporate welfare," Senator Bob Dole, Republican of Kansas, said today that a House-Senate conference committee should not approve the big telecommunications bill until the committee changes a provision  that would give television broadcasters a chunk of the nation's airwaves worth tens of billions of dollars.         In a detailed speech from the Senate floor, Mr. Dole sent the clearest sign yet that he might block the telecommunications bill, which would overhaul laws for almost every segment of the industry. Mr. Dole has indicated that he is prepared to stand his ground against the politically powerful broadcasters.

headline: Tih-Wu Wang, 84, Taiwan Publisher Of Periodicals
abstract: Tih-Wu Wang, a Taiwan-based publisher of economic and other periodicals, died on March 11 at Veterans General Hospital in Taipei. A Taipei resident, he was 84.         The cause was a liver ailment, according to The World Journal, a Chinese-language newspaper he began publishing in 1976 for Chinese-American communities in the United States and Canada. The daily is published in New York, San Francisco, Los Angeles, Vancouver and Toronto and sells some 300,000 copies  at newsstands in both countries.

headline: World News Briefs;Security Council Urges Diplomacy in Burundi
abstract: With the call for a standby military force for Burundi muted by compromise, the Security Council unanimously passed a resolution today stressing diplomatic  solutions to the violence between rival Tutsi and Hutu factions.         Americans and other diplomats sought a more direct reference to a proposal for an international military response if conditions in Burundi worsened. But European nations were reluctant to appear to be authorizing a foreign invasion and accepted arguments by Burundi's leaders that such a prospect would provoke,  not deter, more violence.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Philips Acquisition
abstract: Philips Electronics said yesterday that it had acquired a majority stake in Holland Advertising Nieuwe Media B.V., a Dutch electronic media company. Philips said its media division had bought the 51 percent stake in Holland Advertising as part of its plan to expand in new electronic media and cable networks. The company gave no financial details of the transaction. Holland Advertising is one of the country's largest providers of cable news text and electronic information services, according to Philips.   (AP)

headline: YOUR TAXES;Some New Tricks To Help Filers Avoid An Old Audit Trap
abstract: SHOW Amir Aczel your tax return and not only will he tell you if it was audited, but nine times out of 10, he says, he can tell you why.         More important to taxpayers, Professor Aczel, who teaches statistics at Bentley College, a business school in Waltham, Mass., says he has figured out most of the reasons that Internal Revenue Service computers kick out returns for review by an audit clerk -- and how to draft a 1040 that should glide past the computers.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Procter & Gamble Reassigns Clearasil
abstract: The Procter & Gamble Company said yesterday that it had shifted responsibilities for its Clearasil brand of acne medication and skincare products in North America and Europe to Tatham Euro RSCG in Chicago from D'Arcy  Masius Benton & Bowles in New York. Billings were estimated at $20 million to $30 million.         The change, which came without a review, was "part of a realignment of our teen skin-care business," said L. Ross Love, vice president for advertising at P.& G. in Cincinnati. Tatham, which is owned by Havas Advertising, handles Biactol, a skin-care brand for teen-agers, in Europe; its other P.& G. assignments include Mr. Clean and Old Spice.

headline: World News Briefs;Populist Takes Lead In Guatemala Election
abstract: A populist candidate, Alfonso Portillo, snatched a narrow early lead in Guatemala's presidential elections today, radio and television stations said.         Radio Sonora quoted early results from the main electoral authority's computer showing that Mr. Portillo was winning around 54 percent of the early urban returns against his rival, Alvaro Arzu, with just over 5 percent of the vote counted.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;DU PONT (E.I.) DE NEMOURS & CO. (DD,N)
abstract: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company said yesterday that its fourth-quarter net income slipped almost 3 percent, though its operating profits rose 10 percent, led by gains in its white pigments, agricultural products and pharmaceuticals businesses.         The nation's largest chemical company said profits from operations rose to $710 million, or $1.28 a share. Net income was $627 million, or $1.13 a share, compared with $646 million, or 95 cents, in the year-ago period. A charge of $83 million, or 15 cents a share, to settle plumbing litigation and for write-downs of certain petroleum assets, reduced the recent quarter's net. Per-share results reflected 18 percent fewer shares outstanding in the recent quarter after the company bought back a stake from the Seagram Company. Revenue  rose 2.7 percent, to $10.68 billion.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;GERMAN BANK BUYS FIRM IN LONDON
abstract: West Merchant Bank, the investment banking arm of the German giant Westdeutsche Landesbank, said yesterday that it had bought Panmure Gordon from the Nationsbank Corporation, but would not confirm speculation that it had paid  at least $45 million. Nationsbank's chief executive, J. G. Richards Roddey, said that the American bank, based in Charlotte, N.C., remained committed to international capital markets and would continue to build on its existing operations in London. West Merchant had already been expanding and was expected  to double its staff of 300 in London in the next few months. Nationsbank took control of Panmure, which has 260 employees, in 1987.

headline: Talks Said to Break Off on Link Between McDonnell and Boeing
abstract: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation and the Boeing Company have broken off discussions, at least for now, about a possible merger or a combination of some  of their businesses, people with knowledge of the talks said today. But Wall Street still expressed hope that a deal could be put together.         Reports had emerged in November that Boeing and McDonnell Douglas, the two giant aerospace companies, were conducting secret discussions about a combination. The companies had refused to comment then, and they again refused to do so today.

headline: Digital Equipment Introduces Fast Chip
abstract: The Digital Equipment Corporation introduced a chip today that it said runs on AA batteries and is the first microprocessor as fast as a supercomputer -- paving the way for a new wave of mobile consumer products.         The low-cost SA-110 Strongarm computer chip could be used in personal digital assistants, electronic organizers, set-top boxes and video games, Digital said.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;BTR Says Profit Rises, And Plans Consolidation
abstract: BTR P.L.C. said yesterday that its pretax profit rose a higher-than-expected  6 percent in 1995 and announced details of a long-awaited strategy to refocus the business in fewer units with global reach. BTR, the diversified industrial company with Britain's biggest market capitalization, said profit rose in 1995 to a record L1.50 billion, or about $2.3 billion, from L1.41 billion in 1994.          Ian Strachan, BTR's chief executive, said that the company would not split itself into separate companies, as its rival, Hanson P.L.C., plans to do. Instead, BTR will bolster key operations and conduct a program of asset sales and acquisitions to focus on emerging markets.    (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: COMPANY NEWS;DIME BANCORP PLANS TO END FEDERAL SUPERVISION
abstract: Dime Bancorp Inc. plans to sell $93 million in stock to buy from Federal regulators a block of securities tied to the bailout of Anchor Bancorp Inc. Dime, the nation's fourth-largest savings institution, plans to sell 8.4 million shares of stock underlying warrants Anchor issued to the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation in 1993 to raise capital. Dime assumed responsibility for  the warrants when it merged with Anchor in late 1994. With the stock sale, Dime will eliminate the last vestige of years of Government supervision of both  Dime and Anchor. Dime shares were unchanged at $11.375.

headline: Africa Ills: Insight on Cure But Avoiding the Medicine
abstract: When a handful of heads of state and finance ministers from all over Africa gathered in this dusty capital this week, the ostensible purpose was to trade ideas on how to launch an economic takeoff for the world's poorest continent.         Throughout the discussions, which were organized by the United Nations Development Program, two themes, better governance and stability, were repeated  by nearly all as critical elements missing from whatever formula will eventually move this continent forward.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;Marketers see gold in the photogenic cast of a huge NBC hit.
abstract: THE devotion of Damon and Pythias has nothing on the ardor along Madison Avenue to pal around with "Friends."         The success of "Friends," the NBC sitcom about six 20-something New Yorkers,  has set off a stampede among marketers to capitalize on the appeal of the series' stars. The photogenic young cast members of "Friends," which is in its second season, are being wooed to pitch products separately and together.

headline: FUTURES MARKETS;Drought Sends Wheat Prices Up; April Gold Climbs to $400.50
abstract: Wheat futures soared yesterday amid concern that a five-month drought affecting winter wheat fields was unlikely to ease soon.         Gold prices also gained. April gold rose $1.50, to $400.50 an ounce on the New York Mercantile Exchange's Comex division -- its highest price since March 1 -- amid signs that the economy may be strong enough to generate stronger inflation.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;Two Big Investment Banks Report Increased Earnings
abstract: Morgan Stanley Group Inc. and Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. each reported strong quarterly earnings yesterday, benefiting particularly from their healthy  investment banking businesses.         "Both numbers were a bit better than expected," Alison A. Deans, a brokerage  analyst at Smith Barney, said. She added that "investment banking was incredibly strong, particularly at Morgan Stanley," while trading income was a bit weaker than expected.

headline: Corrections
abstract: An article on Dec. 24 about financial advice for a risk-taking investor misidentified the company headed by Jerry Barbalatt, a financial planner in Manhattan. It is Parker Allen & Company, not Allen Parker & Company.

headline: Stocks Off Third Day in Row as Blue Chips Retreat 48.05
abstract: Pulling back from their record highs for the third straight day, stock prices fell yesterday on investor concern about declines in bond prices and fears that  this year's rally had pushed values too high.         In heavy trading, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 48.05 points, or nearly nine-tenths of a percent, to close at 5,503.32. Since the declines began  on Wednesday, the Dow has lost 97.91 points, though for the week the total decline is only 38.30 points.

headline: EU Police 'Held Hostage' in Battle on Court's Reach
abstract: THE HAGUE—  Alerted to a suspected drug shipment coming from Morocco last year, British Customs officials decided to turn to Europe's fledgling police agency, Europol, to get a jump on the traffickers.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;ACCUSTAFF AGREES TO BUY ADDITIONAL TECHNICAL SUPPORT
abstract: Accustaff Inc. agreed yesterday to buy Additional Technical Support Inc., another provider of temporary employees. Terms of the deal, which is expected to be completed on March 1, were not disclosed. Additional Technical, which is based in Waltham, Mass., had revenue of $106 million for the year that ended on  July 31. Accustaff, based in Jacksonville, Fla., had 1994 revenue of $137.1 million. Its shares were up $2 yesterday, to $43.50, in Nasdaq trading. Additional Technical provides employees in information technology, software engineering and other areas.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;Compaq's Share Price Falls Despite Operating Earnings
abstract: The Compaq Computer Corporation reported strong operating profits for the fourth quarter today, but a hefty charge against earnings brought the company's  net down 66 percent from a year earlier.         The latest results included a one-time charge of $241 million related to acquisitions completed in the fourth quarter, Compaq said. Without the charge, the Houston-based computer maker earned $323 million, or $1.17 a share. But that was 1 cent below the consensus of analysts' estimates compiled by First Call, and Compaq's stock fell $1.875, to $47.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Exchange Re-elects Chief
abstract: The board of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange re-elected John F. Sandner as exchange chairman at an organizational meeting held late on Tuesday. The Merc, a marketplace for the trading of futures contracts in various agricultural commodities and financial instruments, said Mr. Sandner had served a total of 12 years as exchange chairman, though not consecutively. Mr. Sandner is chairman, president and chief executive of RB&H Financial Services.

headline: Ben Franklin Cutbacks
abstract: Ben Franklin Retail Stores Inc., the chain of crafts stores, said today that  it would close its distribution center in New Hope, Minn., resulting in the loss of 105 jobs. The company said the closing is expected to be completed by June 1. Ben Franklin owns 41 Ben Franklin Crafts Superstores and is a franchisor to more than 300 craft stores, as well as 540 variety stores.

headline: Micron Delays Chip Factory
abstract: Micron Technology Inc. said late today that it would delay completion of a $2.5 billion computer chip factory in Lehi, Utah, until market conditions improve.         The company said it would finish exterior work on the plant but delay equipping it for production. Most of the value in a new computer chip factory is related to production equipment and the special air systems needed to keep the production facility ultra-clean. It envisions a three to five-year completion, depending on market conditions.

headline: Claudia Inc.;A Model Seeking a Life After 30 Keeps an Eye on the Balance Sheet
abstract: Claudia Schiffer could be the real-life Barbie. Tall, long-legged, curvaceous, with flowing blond hair, a wholesome face -- and a wholesome life to match -- she doesn't drink, smoke or pose nude.         But appearances tell just part of the story. More and more, Ms. Schiffer seems to be trying to imitate the people who made Barbie -- the executives at Mattel Inc. who have taken the doll's enduring image and built a hugely profitable business around it.

headline: U.S. Delays New Financing of Companies' Trade With China
abstract: The Export-Import Bank has agreed to defer any new financing for American companies doing business in China for at least a month at the request of the Clinton Administration, which is weighing how to respond to evidence that China  has shipped nuclear weapons-related technology to Pakistan.         Harry Phillips, a spokesman for the agency, said today that it had received the request from Secretary of State Warren Christopher on Tuesday and would honor it.

headline: SPENDING IT;Should You Invest? Kick the Tires First
abstract: EVEN before they open for business, some chains of used-car stores are dreaming of going public.         Whether the chains' concept -- shopping on a vast lot and not haggling over the price -- appeals to the car buyer in you, the investor in you should know that some similar efforts have been a losing proposition in the past.

headline: Portrait of a Suicide Bomber: Devout, Apolitical and Angry
abstract: Just two days before he boarded a Jerusalem bus and ignited a satchel packed  with TNT, blowing himself up and killing 25 passengers, Majdi Abu Warda spent an hour quietly arguing with his mother about going on a family picnic.         His mother, Intisar, loved those short excursions to a nearby scrub-covered hillock, away from the cloistered concrete warrens of the refugee camp where they lived. She prepared little triangles of pastry filled with meat, cucumbers  in yogurt, rice -- an extended feast to fill the gaggle of 20 children, cousins, aunts, uncles and grandparents coming along.

headline: U.P.S. to Raise Its Prices And Revamp Rate Structure
abstract: United Parcel Service of America Inc. said today that it was raising prices for ground shipping of packages and changing the rate structure for domestic air delivery.         U.P.S. said that it was switching to basing its pricing for domestic air shipping in part on the distance that packages are sent, rather than relying solely on a package's weight. As a result, charges for long-distance deliveries  will rise as much as 28 percent, while shorter air deliveries will cost as much  as 40 percent less. Over all, prices for domestic air delivery will rise about 5 percent, U.P.S. said.

headline: Cable Chief Has a Full Agenda, and $1.2 Billion
abstract: If U S West completes its planned purchase of Continental Cablevision, Amos B. Hostetter Jr. stands to make about $1.2 billion from the sale of his 40 percent stake in the cable company. But Mr. Hostetter, the chairman of Continental, is not slowing down at age 59.         Indeed, he might have to speed up. With the sale to U S West, Continental would have the capital to improve its cable networks for phone service.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;100 Texaco Stations Planned for Poland
abstract: Texaco Inc., the second-largest service station operator in the United States, said yesterday that it would expand its European network by investing $150 million to build 100 filling stations in Poland within six years. Texaco, based in White Plains, joins a rush by oil companies into Poland, where the economy is growing faster than anywhere else in Eastern Europe.          Texaco already owns three Star Market convenience stores in Poland that were built in the last year. Texaco has about 13,750 service stations in the United States, second only to Citgo, and another 8,688 in other countries.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: Viacom Golden Parachute Has A Short Ripcord
abstract: Few things make Sumner M. Redstone's pulse quicken more than a hard-fought business deal. Recalling how he sold Madison Square Garden last year for $1.075  billion, Mr. Redstone, the chairman of Viacom Inc., said, "My heart was in my mouth for the last $50 million."

headline: World News Briefs;U.S. Sends Jets to Jordan For Patrol Duty
abstract: The Pentagon is sending 34 Air Force jet fighters and tanker aircraft to Jordan, a move that officials said was unrelated to the recent terror campaign against Israel.          The planes are part of what the Pentagon called an "air power expeditionary  force," and are expected to spend about two months in Jordan to cover a period when the United States will be without a carrier in the area, a defense official said.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;RETAILER TO CLOSE 17 STORES AND CUT 71 JOBS
abstract: Ames Department Stores Inc. reported sharply lower December profits yesterday and said it would close 17 underperforming stores by early March and eliminate 71 jobs at its headquarters in Rocky Hill, Conn. The discount retailer, which operates 307 stores in 14 Northeastern states, said it would take a $20 million  charge in the fourth quarter to pay for the cost-cutting measures. Ames said its profits fell to $30.4 million for the five weeks ended Dec. 30 from $34.6 million in the corresponding period in 1994. But the company said this was better than the $28.6 million that it had expected.

headline: Some Japanese Remain Abroad to Gain 'Returnee' Status
abstract: A Japanese mother, preoccupied with preparing her young son to take entrance exams for private elementary schools, is talking with her friend who plans to marry soon.

headline: MORE IRISH TROUBLES: THE OUTLOOK;In the Unraveling of a 17-Month Peace Effort, Disappointment, but Not Surprise
abstract: Five days ago, while the seekers of an Irish peace still seemed to be inching fitfully toward compromise, George J. Mitchell warned British television viewers that the quest for peace was in danger of unraveling.         Mr. Mitchell, a former United States Senator who is chairman of a commission  charged with breaking the Irish deadlock, sensed that the more militant Irish nationalists were losing patience with what they perceived as the intransigence  of Prime Minister John Major of Britain.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;3 KLM EXECUTIVES RESIGNING FROM NORTHWEST AIR BOARD
abstract: Three executives of KLM Royal Dutch Airlines are resigning from the board of  the Northwest Airlines Corporation and will be replaced by three independent directors, Northwest said yesterday. Northwest said KLM would designate three people not affiliated with KLM or any other current Northwest stockholder. Northwest said KLM was making this change primarily as a step in "enhancing the  independence of Northwest's board." The departing directors are KLM's president, Pieter Bouw; the managing director, Leo van Wijk, and the chief financial officer, Rob Abrahamsen. The two airlines are partners in a marketing  alliance and KLM owns 18.8 percent of Northwest.

headline: Supporters Of the U.N. Find It Hard To Be Heard
abstract: The United Nations Association of the United States, a citizens' foreign affairs forum and support group as old as the world organization itself, is in trouble.         The association, led over the years by a host of prominent public figures beginning with Eleanor Roosevelt, is to some degree a victim of American indifference and antipathy to the United Nations and the group's inability to turn that opinion around.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Ruder Finn Acquires Harrison
abstract: Ruder Finn Inc., a public relations agency in New York, said yesterday that it had acquired the E. Bruce Harrison Company in Washington in an effort to strengthen its services in public affairs and environmental public relations. The terms were not disclosed.          The acquisition, which Ruder Finn said was its largest ever, will increase its annual billings in Washington to nearly $5 million from $1 million and increase its employees there to 40 from 4. E. Bruce Harrison, 61, chairman and chief executive at Harrison, will continue in those positions at Harrison, which will become a division of the Ruder Finn Washington operations. He will also become chief executive at Ruder Finn Washington, which is a new position. Myra Peabody Gossens, 48, president at Ruder Finn Washington, and Jim Harff, 55, president at Ruder Finn Global Public Affairs, will continue in those positions.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
abstract: Robin Raj was named executive vice president and executive creative director at  Ikonic Interactive Inc., San Francisco, succeeding Jim Granger, who left to open Eye TV, Larkspur, Calif., a design and production agency for television and interactive media. Mr. Raj had been senior vice president and group creative director at TN Technologies, San Francisco, a unit of True North Communications.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;TYCO UNIT BUYS PROFESSIONAL MEDICAL PRODUCTS
abstract: Tyco International Ltd. said yesterday that its Kendall Health Care Products  unit had acquired Professional Medical Products Inc. of Greenwood, S.C. The terms were not disclosed. Professional Medical, which has annual sales of $150 million, makes adult-incontinence products and other disposable medical products. The company has manufacturing plants in Greenwood; Ocala, Fla., and Juarez, Mexico. Tyco makes disposable medical products, packaging materials, flow control products and electrical components. The company has annual revenue  of more than $4.5 billion.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;SHARES OF HCC INSURANCE UP 14% AFTER ACQUISITION DEAL
abstract: The shares of HCC Insurance Holdings Inc. rose nearly 14 percent yesterday after the company agreed late on Monday to buy LDG Management, an insurance underwriting management company, in a stock transaction worth $92.2 million. HCC's shares were up $5.125, to $42, on the New York Stock Exchange. LDG, based  in Wakefield, Mass., had 1995 revenue of about $27 million, mainly from management fees. LDG's operations in London will help HCC's overseas expansion, the company said. HCC, a Houston-based property and casualty insurer, had revenue of $59.9 million in 1994. HCC is to pay 2.5 million common shares of its common stock for LDG.

headline: MINDING YOUR BUSINESS;The Jackie Onassis Trust, and a Variation on It
abstract: Q. If Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis was able to leave money to her children tax free, why can't I do the same?    Margaret Trumbell    Columbus, Ohio

headline: Retailers Push Own Labels
abstract: MILAN—  After two decades on the defensive, as prisoners of big-name designers and their trademarks, clothing retailers are now attempting to recapture the high ground of consumer confidence. As usual, Italy's fashion industry has found a way to make money out of the change.

headline: The Specter In Guatemala
abstract: The closest election in Guatemalan history has given this Central American country a new President but left a familiar and disconcerting presence looming larger than ever in the background: Gen. Efrain Rios Montt, the country's mercurial former military dictator.         Disqualified as a candidate himself because of his participation in a coup and forced to turn to a little-known and unproven proxy, General Rios Montt and  his right-wing Guatemalan Republican Front nonetheless captured nearly half the  vote. They did so with pledges to institute the same "iron fist" that marked his bloody and repressive 18-month tenure as Guatemala's strongman in 1982 and 1983.

headline: Newsweek in Russian Magazine Venture
abstract: Under a licensing agreement with a Russian publisher, Newsweek will provide material from current issues of the magazine for a new Russian language newsweekly that will start up in May. Newsweek, which is owned by the Washington Post Company, will also provide commercial and editorial advice to the publication, which will carry Newsweek's logo on its cover. The agreement is to  be announced formally in Moscow today.         The new magazine, Itogi -- which means "summing up" in Russian -- will be published by the Most Group and its subsidiary, Seven Days Publishing House. Most Group also produces Itogi TV, an overview of the week's political events.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Matsushita Buys American Screen Maker
abstract: In a setback to efforts to develop an American flat panel display industry, one of the pioneering American companies in the business agreed today to be acquired by the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, Japan's largest maker of consumer electronics.         Cash appeared to the driving force behind the sale of Plasmaco Inc. to Matsushita. Plasmaco needed more money to continue its work on computer screens  and wall-hanging televisions.

headline: Advertising;True North Announces Acquisition As Agencies Reveal Vast Accounts
abstract: A wild week along Madison Avenue came to a frenzied end as three advertising  giants each made a month's worth of news on one frantic Friday.         "It's amazing," said Richard McGowan, a senior vice president at Young & Rubicam Inc. in New York, which along with True North Communications in Chicago  and McCann-Erickson Worldwide in New York flooded facsimile machines with multiple announcements of acquisitions, account consolidations and agency assignments.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;QUANTUM TO STOP MAKING DISK DRIVES AND LAY OFF 2,250
abstract: The Quantum Corporation will stop making its own high-end disk drives, a decision that will result in layoffs for 2,250 workers and the closing of a plant in Milpitas, Calif., and another in Malaysia. The company said late on Tuesday that work on high-end disk drives, which are used in large computer systems, will be contracted to Japan's Matsushita Kotobuki Electronics Industries. When the plant closings are completed, possibly by this fall, Quantum will have no manufacturing operations in the San Francisco Bay area for  the first time since the company was founded in 1980. A Quantum spokeswoman said 1,800 permanent and 450 temporary workers will lose their jobs.

headline: French Agency Accuses Rwanda of Theft
abstract: A French aid agency expelled from Rwanda last week accused Rwanda's army today of stealing the agency's vehicles, equipment and medicine.         The group, Doctors Without Borders, said its compound in Kigali, the Rwandan  capital, had been occupied by soldiers since Dec. 24, when the army confiscated 16 vehicles, medicine and other equipment worth more than $500,000.  The group said it was making a formal protest to the Rwandan Government.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;ITT to Buy London Hotel
abstract: The ITT Corporation said this week that its ITT Sheraton unit had offered to  buy the Park Lane Hotel in London for about $68 million. Boston-based ITT Sheraton, which owns and franchises more than 400 hotels, expects to buy the 308-room hotel in April.

headline: Up at Last, Bridge to Bosnia Is Swaying Gateway for G.I.'s
abstract: The first American tanks rolled into Bosnia early this afternoon on a floating ribbon of a bridge across the swift-moving Sava River, marking the end  of a problem-plagued engineering project and the real start to the American role in the mission here.         The pontoon bridge, stretching more than 650 yards from Croatia to this small town in northeastern Bosnia, is the narrow, swaying passageway that will carry most of the 20,000 troops in the American contingent into the country. That parade began today in a display of military might as about 150 tanks, artillery  pieces, Humvees and trucks carrying boxes of food and latrines rumbled south across melting snow into the American sector.

headline: Lehman Division Is Fined in Maxwell Case
abstract: Lehman Brothers International said today that it had been fined L80,000, or $121,600, by the Securities and Futures Authority for keeping inadequate records and for maintaining lax procedures in dealings with the late Robert Maxwell.         Lehman is the sixth securities firm to be fined by the British regulators in  connection with the pension fund scandal that erupted after Maxwell drowned in November 1991. Lehman Brothers International is the international arm of Lehman  Brothers Inc., the New York securities firm.

headline: Manila Journal;Queen of the Quirky, Imelda Marcos Holds Court
abstract: A pale blue bird began to chirp loudly high above the table where Imelda Marcos was eating breakfast.         "Oh, Ma'am," cried her companions, breaking into applause, "Ma'am, it's a sign, it's a love bird, oh, he's cheering for you! Ma'am, congratulations!"

headline: COMPANY NEWS;$1 BILLION LAS VEGAS CASINO COMPLEX SET
abstract: International Thoroughbred Breeders Inc. is planning to develop a $1 billion  casino, hotel, retail and entertainment complex in Las Vegas, Nev., where seven  gaming companies are expected to operate under the same roof. Each will have its own theme and management. The 5.4-million-square-foot Starship Orion project will be on the Las Vegas Strip, opposite Circus Circus. The project will also contain 300,000 square feet of retail space, 2,400 hotel rooms, theaters and other entertainment sites. Separately, International Thoroughbred said its former chairman, Robert E. Brennan, had said he would sell his 2.9 million shares to Cambridge Partners, a privately held investment partnership that already holds more than 5 percent of the company.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Pillsbury Pasta Purchase
abstract: The Pillsbury Company, a unit of Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., agreed yesterday  to acquire the Pasta House business of the Australian conglomerate Pacific Dunlop Ltd. for about $75 million. Pasta House makes pasta and sauces under the  brand names Latina and Leggos' Dorato. Pillsbury, based in Minneapolis, will make an additional payment to Pacific Dunlop depending on earnings of the Pasta  House business in the next three years.    (Dow Jones)

headline: COMPANY NEWS;QUORUM HEALTH SHARES RISE ON MERGER TALKS
abstract: The shares of Quorum Health Group Inc. rose yesterday after the company said  that it was in merger talks and that it expected to report second-quarter earnings that exceed Wall Street estimates. Quorum, a hospital operator, said the merger discussions were with an undis closed health care company. At yesterday's closing Nasdaq price of $27, up $1.125, Quorum has a market value of $1.29 billion. The company said it expected to post net income of $16.9 million, or 34 cents a share, for the quarter ended Dec. 31. That would be a 23  percent gain over the year-ago $13.8 million, or 28 cents a share.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;HANDY ANDY HOME CENTERS TO CLOSE REMAINING STORES
abstract: Handy Andy Home Improvement Centers Inc., which was forced by creditors into  bankruptcy last fall, said yesterday that it would close its remaining 54 stores, eliminating about 2,500 jobs. The company, based in Schaumburg, Ill., was already closing about 20 of its home-improvement stores. In filing for Chapter 11 protection on Oct. 17, Handy Andy listed debts of $123 million and said it planned to reorganize into hardware supermarkets. But several banks that it had owed money preferred that Handy Andy liquidate all operations to help repay its debts, the company's president, Richard George, said. The stores in Illinois, Michigan, Missouri, Ohio, Tennessee and Wisconsin are to close by June.   (AP)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: BAY NETWORKS Inc., Santa Clara, Calif., a maker of computer networking equipment, agreed to acquire Performance Technology Inc. of San Antonio, a closely held maker of a hardware and software package that provides Internet access, for about $13 million in cash.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Pearson's Pretax Profit Increases by 23%
abstract: The British media company Pearson P.L.C. reported yesterday that its pretax profit rose 23 percent in 1995, helped by a gain from the sale of its stake in the satellite television broadcaster British Sky Broadcasting Group P.L.C. Pearson, the publisher of The Financial Times, said its pretax profit was L365 million ($562 million), up from L298 million in 1994.

headline: G.E. and Rolls Alliance Is Seen
abstract: Rolls-Royce P.L.C. and the General Electric Company are expected to announce  on Monday the formation of an alliance seeking to supply the United States military with jet engines for a new generation of strike aircraft.         The aircraft, which are to have vertical take-off capabilities, are designed  to perform like Britain's Hawker-Siddeley Harrier "jump jets," which are powered by the Rolls-Royce Pegasus engine.

headline: That First Job
abstract: Making deviled egges at the local deli. Getting file-card finger as a summer  researcher for your history professor. Unpacking box after box of boots at the local Florsheim's. First jobs may offer little prestige, but they hold vivid memories -- like that first paycheck. If your have a story about your debut in the world of work, sent it to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 227 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your phone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

headline: OUTLOOK '96: THE ECONOMY;Recovery in California Wears a New Costume
abstract: CALL it the tinsel recovery.

headline: DIARY
abstract: AGRICULTURE

headline: Real Estate;A California city is attracting short-term leases to a naval shipyard while it works on a long-term plan.
abstract: IN what its backers view as a test of a new approach to the conversion of a military base to civilian uses, a real estate firm has begun a plan for short-term subleases by industrial and office users at the Mare Island Naval Shipyard.         The Navy is pulling out of the shipyard, which occupies 5,000 acres in this blue-collar town of 115,000 people 30 miles north of San Francisco. With about 7,000 civilian employees, the base has been central to the city's economy. The pullout is to be completed in April.

headline: Clinton Visits Bosnia to Thank the G.I.'s
abstract: With Apache attack helicopters patrolling the slate-gray skies overhead, President Clinton stood today before rows of the American soldiers he had sent to Bosnia and thanked them for being "warriors for peace."         On a chill airfield, the nearby roads mired in thick mud, President Clinton gazed at 500 soldiers in camouflage gear and told them they represented the American ideal.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;British Aerospace Profit Almost Doubled in 1995
abstract: British Aerospace P.L.C. said yesterday that its profit nearly doubled in 1995 as it started to see results of a three-year-old reorganization plan and widening margins in its military business. The company, which makes Tornado fighters, Seawolf missiles and Avro jets, said its pretax profit before the one-time cost of streamlining its business rose 95 percent, to L330 million, or  $505 million, from L169 million in 1994.          Excluding the one-time charges for its reorganization, the company's military profit rose 18 percent, to L487 million. Sales fell 20 percent, to L5.74 billion, reflecting the sale of the Rover car-making unit to BMW of Germany in March 1994.    (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: What Is a Book Publisher to Do When a Parody Hits Home?
abstract: Martha Stewart -- doyenne of gracious living and good crystal -- has little in common with Karen Finley, a performance artist whose fabled use for chocolate is not the stuff of old family recipes.         But they did share the same taste for Crown Publishers, where for a brief burst of creativity the two advice authors labored on their visions of living well. While Ms. Stewart dispensed tips about forcing gooseberry blooms and frosting pansy cakes, Ms. Finley offered hints on building coffins and blenderizing 20-pound tom turkeys.

headline: Guardian Company Stake
abstract: The Guardian Industries Corporation said today that it had acquired 70 percent of the Automotive Moulding Company of Warren, Mich., The value of the transaction was not disclosed. Automotive Moulding makes both plastic and metal  exterior body components for the automotive industry at four plants in Michigan  and Georgia.

headline: Threat to Press Freedom Seen in Kenya
abstract: The Government is moving to enact two laws that journalists here say would muzzle independent newspapers during the year preceding the next election, early next year.         The proposals have stirred a minor political storm in this East African country, where journalists have had increasing freedom since the Government first held multiparty elections in 1991.

headline: U.N. and Iraq Report Progress in Talks to Allow Limited Oil Sales
abstract: Talks between Iraq and the United Nations that could lead to limited Iraqi oil sales for the first time since the Persian Gulf war neared the end of an initial round today, with diplomats saying that the two sides are as close as they have ever been to an agreement.         United States officials said they thought the talks would recess late today,  but the United Nations spokeswoman, Sylvana Foa, said the two sides planned another meeting on details for Wednesday.

headline: Sprint Parcels Out Wireless Business
abstract: The Sprint Corporation said today that its wireless telecommunications venture had awarded contracts to an AT&T unit and BCE's Northern Telecom Ltd. to supply Code Division Multiple Access, known as C.D.M.A., personal communications equipment for its wireless network.         Under the contract, total expenditures can exceed $3 billion initially.

headline: Indian Parties Make Hay of a Scandal
abstract: Indian opposition parties forced the adjournment of both houses of Parliament today, serving notice they intend to use the last session before general elections to focus on a political corruption scandal.         Opposition lawmakers disrupted proceeedings in both houses, demanding the resignation of Prime Minister P. V. Narasimha Rao. They forced adjournment before business was completed on the opening day of the session.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings this week:      MONDAY

headline: COMPANY NEWS;GENERAL RE PLANS ITS EIGHTH BUYBACK OF SHARES
abstract: The General Re Corporation said yesterday that its board had authorized the repurchase of up to $300 million of the company's common stock, the eighth such  move under a longstanding plan. Since 1987, General Re has repurchased about 22.7 million shares, leaving 81.7 million shares outstanding at the end of 1995. The company's shares fell 87.5 cents yesterday, to $148.625, on the New York Stock Exchange. Based on that price, the authorization will cover the repurchase of about two million common shares. The reinsurer, based in Stamford, Conn., also raised its quarterly dividend by 4 percent, to 51 cents a share, from 49 cents. General Re will pay the new dividend on March 29 to stock of record on March 21.

headline: For New Trinidad Chief, Race Question Looms Big
abstract: Politics in this small but remarkably diverse Caribbean nation has always been based on race, with blacks the dominant bloc. But an election here last month brought a Prime Minister of Indian descent to power for the first time, and both ethnic groups are now struggling to come to grips with their unfamiliar new roles.

headline: Executives From Taiwan Worry, but Stay in China
abstract: Like many Taiwan businessmen who live and work in this city, Chiang Yu-min likes to relax by leaving his steel factory at the outskirts of town to meet friends for a meal at Taipei City or one of the other hip, upscale restaurants that cater to "tai shang," as Taiwan businessmen are known in mainland China.         But it is hard for Mr. Chiang to relax when all his friends are talking about what they see as the possibility of war.

headline: Peres Under Pressure to Call an Early Election in Israel
abstract: Pressure is increasing on the Israeli Prime Minister, Shimon Peres, to call an early election that could significantly slow American-mediated negotiations with Syria for a comprehensive peace.         Mr. Peres says he would prefer that the Government fill out its term, which expires at the end of October, and American officials are urging him to wait.

headline: Chevron Unit In Canada Deal
abstract: The Chevron Corporation's Chevron Canada Resources unit said today that it had agreed to buy Norcen Energy Resources Ltd.'s interests in a number of Canadian east coast offshore properties. Terms were not disclosed.         Chevron Canada said the properties included Hebron, Ben Nevis and West Ben Nevis, as well as other minor properties.

headline: The Siskel and Ebert of Telecom Investing
abstract: JACK GRUBMAN and Dan Reingold say they like each other. You'd never know it from the hand grenades they toss back and forth.         In a new report, Mr. Grubman, a prominent telecommunications analyst at Salomon Brothers, said any analyst who would recommend the stocks of regional Bell telephone companies was "starry eyed," "bull headed" and "nuts." Mr. Grubman acknowledged that this was a reference to Mr. Reingold, his equally prominent counterpart at Merrill Lynch & Company.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;NYNEX CORP. (NYN,N)
abstract: The Nynex Corporation reported yesterday that its profit jumped 19 percent in the fourth quarter because of an increased number of customers and more telephone calls.         The regional Bell company, based in New York, made $235.6 million, or 55 cents a share. In the fourth quarter of 1994, Nynex had a profit of $198.3 million, or 47 cents a share.

headline: News Corp. And MCI Win Satellite Slot
abstract: After a brief but spirited bidding war, MCI Communications and Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation agreed today to pay the Federal Government $682 million for the last unclaimed orbital slot for a satellite that can beam television straight to individual homes across the United States.         The two companies, which have formed a joint venture to build and operate the system, said they planned to invest another $1 billion and hoped to begin offering both television and a broad range of business communication services within two years.

headline: Liberia Faction Seeks to End New Fighting
abstract: Rebels waving white flags declared today that they were ready for talks in Liberia's civil war, after a weekend of infighting that terrorized the western countryside.         Seven members of a West African peacekeeping force were killed as they tried  to evacuate civilians caught in the rebel battles near Tubmanburg, about 40 miles north of Monrovia, the capital.

headline: Libyan Troops Clash With Foes After Jailbreak
abstract: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi has sent troops to northeastern Libya, apparently to  stamp out unrest, diplomats and opposition groups said today.         The clashes began last week after a prison break near the port of Benghazi. As many as 400 prisoners, many of them Government opponents and Islamic militants, escaped into nearby mountains and valleys, opposition groups said.
